column9: Is this a disease of aging?
column10: Speaking as a quasi-old person, I can truly say the only things I regret are the things I didn't do when I was young:  explore more, live more adventurously, be open to a wider range of activities.  For example, I didn't start whitewater rafting until I was 50.  Now at 62, it is a passion and something I look forward to two or three times a year.  And just for record, older people have plenty to look forward unless they are diagnosed with some terminal, gonna-die-tomorrow disease.  We do tend to revisit the past more often than you younger guys, but hey! we have more past to reflect upon.  If you are lucky, you too will be reflective of your past some day and find great pleasure in it.  Embed Quote

column9: Is this a disease of aging?
column10: People tend to remember what went wrong more than what went right. Also, when your past is all you have and no future to look forward to, you tend to revisit to see how things could have been better and not worse.  Embed Quote

column9: Or is it always relevant?
column10: 10-14 is an adolescent.  14-19 is a teenager.  19 to 25 is university aged.  25-30 is early career or grad school.  I think you become an adult at 30.  40-50 is middle aged.  Above 50 is boomer aged.  65-75 is a senior.  75+ is old.  Over 85 is geriatric.  That's how I think of it anyway.  Embed Quote

column9: Or is it always relevant?
column10: When your doctor is younger than you.  Embed Quote

column9: Or is it always relevant?
column10: I'm 43, and was recently shocked to find that people no longer consider me to be young.  Embed Quote

column9: Or is it always relevant?
column10: When they act and can not get a result for the things that they used to do lately.  Embed Quote

column9: This is a follow-up question to Anti-Aging: What can be done to delay the effects of aging?.
column10: There are no low dose intervention studies.  Epidemiological studies indicate reduced suicide rates in cities with higher levels of lithium in tap water.  Deficiency studies show behavioral problems in humans.  The only direct aging results were on nematodes, which are obviously not applicable to humans.http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/...  Embed Quote

column9: This is a follow-up question to Anti-Aging: What can be done to delay the effects of aging?.
column10: Lithium is a heavy metal.  Its bad for you. Period.Having said that, it is also one of the only known effective treatments for bi-polar affective disorder, also known as manic/depression.  While there are safer alternatives for the depression side, there aren't many for someone who suffers from true mania.So Id say its foolhardy to take if not needed, but in real clinical use it may be necessary.  Embed Quote

column9: Was everything really better in the past or is this just a flaw of the human brain when it gets older and reflects back?
column10: From their point of view, life was much better in the past.Generally speaking, their health would be better - the ageing population are more likely to suffer from arthritis and other joint problems, high blood pressure, heart and breathing problems, diabetes etc.They would be more likely to have been financially secure as they were in employment. The old-age pension provides for a standard of living which is basic, at best. Without an additional cushion of a private income source, many older people struggle.Socially, they may well have had more contacts. An inevitable reality about getting older is that one starts to both lose the ability to maintain a social life (perhaps being unable to drive) but also the social group becomes diminished because of ill health or death of the other group members.Additionally, older people are often seen as 'invisible' members of society. There have been studies which have shown that older people are often 'overlooked' in shops, restaurants etc. That is not a particularly good thing to become aware of, many individuals feel that it shows that they are not valued.Sadly, it remains a fact that older people are discriminated against in the health service (in the UK) this may take the form of not receiving the same treatment or enduring longer waiting lists.The summary then is that life often was better than it is now.  Embed QuoteVia  Adira Rotstein.

column9: Was everything really better in the past or is this just a flaw of the human brain when it gets older and reflects back?
column10: A friend once described life in regards to family and workplace as a treadmill. You're forced, to some degree, to keep up with technology because life requirements demand it.Then one day, you get off that treadmill - your children leave to start their own families and run on their own treadmills, and you retire from working. Once you are off the treadmill, technology changes move too quickly to keep up with. And since you are no longer required to - and an employer is no longer handing you new technology to deal with, you slow down. You're not sending yourself to classes to learn how to do social media, or neural networking or whatever the newest thing will be. And, for most people, income drops, so new technology purchases do, too.One day, you just think, my old my cellphone is fine, my iPod is fine. I don't really need to learn the new brainwave-controlled technology and anyway, it's expensive. The folks on the treadmill zip by and you are your grandparent, with one old cabinet TV, no cable, an old dial-up phone and a brand new stereo system that your kids gave you...and that you have no idea how to use.As the lack of constant new data that has to be assimilated catches up with you, you start reminiscing about how simpler it was when you were younger. People had three channels on TV, they went outside to talk to neighbors, the weather wasn't so strange. Food was tastier (because of course you were younger and could eat anything and now you're diabetic and have a heart condition and have to watch everything you eat.) Travel wasn't as scary, because you watch the news which uses the word "terrorist" every third sentence and there was no TSA.People were nicer then, of course, because everything "back then" was better. The fact that the sky over London is clearer now than in the 1870s when the coal smoke made it unbreathable notwithstanding, the air was cleaner in your youth, when cold and hot and exhaust didn't bother you half as much.Your memories of things start to focus on the good, and lose the bad. Your life gets smaller. You sell your house and move into a room in a senior community. Of course it was better when you were young and your family was starting out. Now TV talks about Twitter and Facebook and you don't really understand or like computers....everyone online is stealing your identity, the news says. Spam email terrifies you. (How do they know my name?!? Or that I went to school in Townville?!?) You knew what people were talking about back then. Music sounds weird, and people don't talk sense any more.The news terrifies you. War and danger on all fronts - ALL THE TIME. There is no respite. Children killed by drunk drivers, people dying of cancer, there's never any good news that doesn't have to do with pets being rescued. The world is bigger and has more countries than it did when the USSR was our only real enemy. How can a person really know if the girl who cleans their room is trustworthy? She wears a headscarf and the news tells you all the time that that means she can't really be trusted.My grandmother passed away this last winter at 95. We talked about things like this. In her final years, her only media was TV and because the news made her so upset, she mostly only watched TV Judge shows. She traveled a lot in her life, so she knew that the world was not terrifying. She stopped learning new things when it just became too much for her.But I see other older folks, being terrified every day by the news, sure that the world is waiting to get them, steal their money, torch their churches, etc. I've had personal direct experience with the narrowing of an already pretty narrow and grudging worldview and it's not hard to see how older folks can't see the positive in the changes around them. Change is hard and it's scary. The world right now is not predictable and most importantly...it's not the same as something they already know.  Embed Quote

column9: Was everything really better in the past or is this just a flaw of the human brain when it gets older and reflects back?
column10: A lot of "me" is my memories.  Most of the rest is my skills.  As I get older, an increasing proportion of my memories are of people who are dead, places that have are gone, and activities that fewer and fewer people pursue.  An increasing proportion of my skills are no longer helpful.  If I was successful and happy in the past, then it feels wrong to turn my focus away from those memories and those skills.  I think I can avoid increasing crankiness by focusing on my ability to learn instead of focusing on what I've already learned.  My plan is to look hard for new skills and experiences that will extend who I already am.  E.g., I like the idea of social media, but find Facebook & twitter to shallow. But I heard about Quora, investigated, and found that it provides a more interesting connection to a worldwide community.  I'll update this in about 10 years & let you know if the plan's working for me.  :)  Embed Quote

column9: Was everything really better in the past or is this just a flaw of the human brain when it gets older and reflects back?
column10: The comfortable feelings of nostalgia: life for everyone was not perfect at every moment, but wishful-thinking people would rather remember the good memories than reflect on the bad ones.   Embed Quote

column9: Was everything really better in the past or is this just a flaw of the human brain when it gets older and reflects back?
column10: A lot of this comes down to who's at the center of the narrative. When older people remember the past glowingly, most fundamentally, they are remembering a time that was **their** time; they were in their prime and in the driver seat of life. When one gets older, they are less in control of the world around them, less of a shaping influence, and as a result, typically feel a bit alienated by the present. It is foreign to them.I hearken back to a great quote by legendary San Francisco Chronicle writer Herb Caen talking about how San Francisco had lost its charms, how Market Street was always under construction, and how things had gotten so expensive that the locals were getting squeezed out.Nodding as I read this, it was all a set up by Caen, who quipped, "Would it surprise you to know that I wrote this in 1956."More of the story: everything old is new again, and the past is always better than the present, even when the present is just like the past.  Embed Quote

column9: Was everything really better in the past or is this just a flaw of the human brain when it gets older and reflects back?
column10: The human brain is complex and flexible. In most cases it prefers to remember the good and discard the bad. The other way around would be counter-productive to say the least. Basically, we're wired this way. We have to be to have made it this far.  Embed Quote

column9: Was everything really better in the past or is this just a flaw of the human brain when it gets older and reflects back?
column10: It can be argued that in many ways, things were better in the past. For one thing, real estate speculation hadn't raised the price of home ownership, and most middle class people, or even lower middle class people, could buy a house. Housing cost about a quarter of people's incomes. Now, thanks to the real estate market, aging parents are seeing it's impossible for their children to live as comfortably.But perhaps the most tragic development in modern times is the disintegration of the family. As people became more mobile, families no longer lived together, or even close. The extended family disappeared as a cultural norm and was replaced by the nuclear family, which in turn has become outflanked by the single-parent family. Older people once aged surrounded by their  younger family members, and were part of the social fabric, serving a purpose as mentors to their grandchildren, baby-sitters, and respected voices of experience. All too often now, they're shunted off to senior housing, where they are surrounded only by peers, and have no purpose.Society was once made  up of an amalgamation of age groups, but it is now far more segregated. If you go to almost any American venue, there is a general age breakdown-- places where elderly people go, places where 20-somethings go. There are senior hours at pools, kid hours at pools. Very few things are age-indiscriminate, like sporting events (and curiously, Burning Man).Experience used to matter in the workplace, but now if you're over 50 and unemployed, good luck getting a job. The value of hindsight has been overpowered by the bottom-line value of paying entry-level salaries. Psychologically, there's a clear indication that people are more troubled. A fifth of all children in this country now take meds for psychiatric difficulties, and we have become the Prozac Nation. Surely, people are more alienated, as real community involvement diminishes. We don't know our neighbors, and most of our interactions with others are mediated by one form of plastic box or another. (I write this of course as a devotee of community through the plastic box).Our food has become poisonous. Agribusiness coats growing things with chemicals to make harvests bigger and prettier. Companies like Monsanto genetically alter food so that we rely on them for crops, instead of nature, which figured it out perfectly well. Livestock is full of hormones, and we ingest these things. In order to produce food cheaply, fast food mega-industries feed cattle with ingredients that are raising  the methane production alarmingly, and producing products that are awful for us, if eaten often. Most processed food is full of stuff that's just bad for us, but people eat a lot of it, so they don't have to take time away from their plastic boxes to actually cook.Wars were once fought for better reasons, like getting rid of Nazis. Now they're fought for oil. The devastation of huge swaths of the population could be wiped out by some maniac pushing a button or a nuclear power plant going haywire. People used to matter more; but now, the entire world could be brought to a standstill if our plastic boxes stopped working. We're killing the environment, overpopulating, running out of of drinking water, and people are protecting their business interests by paying researchers to prove it isn't true. Our education system has become less effective, and plenty of college students don't know an adjective from an adverb, or even what an adverb is-- or care. The written language is getting increasingly reduced to to things like "R U OK?"Every generation has had its problems, and the escalation of difficulty has only increased over time. Very few things have actually improved. Things are faster, we live longer (potentially), and we have a black president. But we have lost patience in the process (pissed off when it takes 30 seconds to download information we used to go to library to get), we live longer but less healthfully, and there's still plenty of racism in our culture. Each older generation has regarded "improvements" sceptically, and for good reason.  Embed Quote

column9: Was everything really better in the past or is this just a flaw of the human brain when it gets older and reflects back?
column10: It just was! I was young once and my life was fun. I am like a prune on the outside but inside I am still a plum. Yes really!  You will find out one day.  Embed Quote

column9: This is a follow-up question to What are all the known biological effects that cause aging?.
column10: Natural selection perpetuates alleles that cause a lot of copies of  themselves to be manufactured. Individual organisms don't contain very  many allele copies, no matter how long they live.So, what have you done lately for your allele frequencies?Are you developing to sexual maturity?Are you fertilizing eggs / getting your eggs fertilized?Are you manufacturing embryos?Are you helping your offspring do the above?If you are doing these things, then your life is keeping your alleles competitive in the gene pool, and natural selection is obviously going to favor genes that let you keep doing those things for as long as possible.But a lot of external factors make you less effective at copying your genes, like aging, disease, and predators. Some alleles make organisms resistant to these factors. But other alleles contribute more to fitness by optimizing the organism's phenotype in the life stage when it really counts.Here are some examples of when lifespan gets traded for other fitness-increasing traits:Some organisms are weak and vulnerable to predators, so they die often.  If the most efficient way for an allele to increase its frequency is to  make the organism reproduce earlier and faster, then the short lifespan  phenotype is a local optimum in the fitness landscape. For organisms  that have good defenses against predators, the  expected payoff is higher for anti-aging genes.Instead of pacing yourself to get through a long life, sometimes  it's better to go all in and just fertilize as many eggs as you can in  one mating season. Think exploding testicles or getting devoured after  sex.Organisms are programmed to give up their life for the kinds of  things that increase the expected reproductive success of a large colony  of their close relatives, like kamikaze attacks on invaders.  Embed Quote

The book, "Healthy Aging" by Andrew Weil focuses on preventing chronic illness. Also, "The Longevity Projects" by Howard S. Friedman and Leslie R Martin; an eight-decade study into aging and longevity.  Embed Quote
You might want to check out 'A Means to an End: The Biological Basis of Aging and Death by William Clark'.  Embed Quote

column9: The question is more about the current state, not about what science could do around.Is it because God made us so?- could be very good reasons to die for not consuming the whole Universe. An intelligent design may end up with this dilemma/solution(/temporary solution?)- but why getting old?Is it because Evolution made us so?- evolution is driven by better children. Once the children have been produced and guided in their world, there is no much need for adults; at least not in the evolutionary process.- is this the meaning of life?
column10: Humans are long-lived enough that we generally live past our reproductive span.  That especially refers to women who go through menopause, since very old men do still have the ability to father children, even though sperm motility (and opportunity) are usually reduced.  It's purely an accident that when humans grow old, we suffer from an ever-increasing number of health ailments until we die.  There is simply no selective pressure for old humans to be as healthy as the young - for the most part, they've already dropped out of the gene pool.  Therefore, at that stage in life, the accumulation of negative mutations is unchecked by evolutionary selection.  Embed Quote

column10: Your cells die and are replaced all the time through cell division. However cells can only divide a limited number of times. There is evolutionary pressure to limit cell division as it helps protect against cancers (under normal circumstances an abnormal cell line will only continue so far before dying out).See: http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/H...This is one evolutionary drive toward ageing, there may be others.  Embed Quote

column10: There is no "need" for a moral or theological explanation. It is also even more fundamental than evolution, it is the physics evolution relies on. Every process produces waste. There is no way to make an action with perfect efficiency. The wasted produced is spatially linked to the process that produced it. Without a process to maintain itself a process will be subject to fluctuation to its environment. Homeostatis, that we find in living organisms is precisely such a process that makes an organism able to continue in a fluctuation environment. The accumulation of waste is not necessarily an issue but over time its consequences might be threatening for the process that created it.See also Second Law of Thermodynamics  Embed Quote

column10: Your premise is open to question.   Again your question has underlying premises that there is a reason for that which is--maybe it just is.  Embed Quote

It is general knowledge that you reach a point of maximum acuteness/wisdom in middle age then your faculties weaken as you move into old age. Not for everyone, a few people stay sharp until the end of their life, but for most: to age is to diminish. The difference between preserved faculty and diminished faculty was generally thought of as a product of the genetic lottery.Biologically speaking ageing is associated with progressive losses in function across multiple systems including sensation, cognition, memory, motor control, and affect. We weaken physically as bones calcify and muscles atrophy, and our senses become less acute with wear and tear. It has also been assumed that neurological decline in ageing was unavoidable because it was a direct consequence of brain machinery wearing out. This view has changed in the light of recent research in neuroscience, experimental psychology, and other related fields. There are four factors that affect this "wearing out" process and they are able to be manipulated. They are: reduced schedules of brain activity; noisy processing; weakened neuromodulatory control; and negative learning. These factors interact to create a self-reinforcing downward spiral of degraded brain function. Brain plasticity processes with negative consequences begin to dominate brain functioning, and this causes a loss of faculty. In other words, your ability to learn and think novel thoughts is greatly reduced by thinking in circles—by thinking the same thoughts every day: by habit and by not challenging yourself. If you consider your brain to be like other muscles, then like other muscles when you don't exercise, you lose mass and power. The solution for staying sharp into your dotage is exercise. Give your brain regular workouts.Experiments with this concept have shown that substantial improvement is possible even after brain function has started to degrade. Driving brain plasticity toward recovery and sustained power requires engaging in demanding sensory, cognitive, and motor activities on an intensive basis. This form of mental exercise measurably increases the fidelity, reliability, and power of cortical representations. You can actually choose not to lose your wits as you age. It just requires some thought.  Embed QuoteVia  Shubham Rander.

Not sure it should be deemed 'known', but the free-radical theory postulates that atoms or molecules with an unpaired electron in the outer shell are associated with oxidative damage that contributes to the aging process. Diets rich in anti-oxidants may help counteract these reactions.http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fre...  Embed QuoteVia  Anonymous.

One view is that aging is not 'caused' by biological changes, but it is the result of them. Something else causes us to age, and this is reflected on the different biological changes we see during aging, such as short telomeres etc. In other words, short telomeres etc are the result and not the cause of aging.  What causes us to age is, in fact, more related to physics rather then to biology and it is, of course, entropy. Our biological complexity declines with time, and this allows damage to accumulate and affect our tissues and organs.  Embed Quote

One important factor is that, due to repeated cell divisions, the copy/safety check code (telomeres) at the end of your chromosomes get shortened repeatedly during copying and at some point might be gone altogether. So any further cell division/copying might result in faulty shortened chromosomes, leading to unpredictable/reduced activity (tumors, cancerous cells etc). I'm sure there are many more other reasons. Hope this helps shed some light into the process.http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tel...http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tel...  Embed Quote

There is a good summary in Aubrey De Gray's book: http://www.amazon.com/Ending-Agi...
 
 He is currently work at http://sens.org/ on approaches to address many of the issues.  Embed Quote

Another factor- throughout life, stem cells help maintain tissue homeostasis, but as we get older, availability of these may decrease. For example, grey hair is caused by a lack of melanocyte stem cells.  Embed Quote
Embed Quote

Macaws (Parrots) can live 50-100+ years in captivity.  Several other types of parrot live in excess of 50 years.Several species of tortoise have lived beyond 200 years, but are not commonly kept as pets.  Turtles kept as pets can live 100-150 years.The longest lived primate is the human (122 years, documented).  Other primates live up to 50 years in captivity.  Embed QuoteAnswered in eight minutes.

column9: Examples I can think of are certain species of turtles and other reptiles who have developed immunity to cancer and such.There is a species of frog that has the ability to freeze completely and thaw out without any tissue damage.
column10: We know quite a lot about such animals, but very little of what we know seems to be useful. Either the animal has no long-lived non-dividing cells (such as clams), or it is cold-blooded and typically grows throughout life (such as various fish, amphibians and reptiles), or it lives in a very warm constant-temperature environment (such as naked mole rats), or it's reeeeally big so its specific metabolic rate is lower (such as whales), or it doesn't actually live longer than us, only longer for its size (such as various birds). All these differences result in either the "aging problem" being not so severe for those species as for humans, such that the animal can live longer than us without having more sophisticated anti-aging tricks, or else the problem being ostensibly more severe but not in ways that necessarily matter for longevity. On top of that, a modestly more sophisticated anti-aging setup would almost certainly not point the way to a human therapy, because the benefits conferred by copying some genetic difference or other would be outweighed by the problems caused by trying to dovetail it with the highly optimised network of everything else that humans have.The most promising exception to the above is the uncanny rarity of cancer in a variety of long-lived lower vertebrates, and also in naked mole rats. The incidence of cancer in such species appears to be so dramatically lower than in mammals (even humans) that there does seem to be a real chance of finding a trick that could be applied to humans without being outweighed by the dovetailing problem. Some of the best work on this is being done by the Gorbunova lab in Rochester.Don't get too excited about the frozen frogs - they only go a little below 0oC. They do it by replacing a lot of their water with sugar. Certain lower species can do this better and go down to as low as -30 as I recall, but for useful cryopreservation in anticipation of revival when better medicine exists we need much lower temperatures than that: plenty of chemistry, in particular decay of tissue, still happens at -30.  Embed Quote

At the infant stage, the membranous length of vocal folds is around 2mm. When we're children, the larynx grows rapidly, along with vocal folds and other support structures. Below is an illustration of the approximate difference between membranous length (Lm), cartilagenous length (Lc), and total vocal fold length (Lm + Lc):The first twenty or so years after birth typically show a growth rate of around 0.7mm/year for males and 0.4mm/year for females. Growth of vocal folds causes the Fundamental frequency (Fo) to drop off as demonstrated by the equation:Though children have smaller total vocal fold lengths, their greater Fo ability can cause a much more intense sound (example: a screaming baby). During adolescence, male Testosterone (steroid hormone) actually increases the rate of growth for the larynx (more quickly than in females) which in turn increases the overall thickness and size of vocal folds. The longer folds result in a lower Fo in males and increases in thickness cause a voice tone change. Physiologically, things like facial development, lowering of the larynx, and increases in chest wall/lung circumference all play factors in voice change. The voice is matured approximately at age twenty. The graph below illustrates Fo as a function of age:In the middle aged, potential ossification/hardening of cartilage in the larynx can have an effect on the voice. In some cases, this more rigid support can improve potential singing quality (supports tension in vocal cords). Undesired changes can also occur: edema, atrophy, dystrophy. Source: The National Center for Voice and Speech  Embed Quote

When we age, our vocal folds become less pliable , so when they are vibrating you often hear a tremulous quality, or inconsistent pitch and control.In addition, the lungs usually have reduced elasticity and capacity, which often puts more strain on the voice.  Embed Quote

column9: It seems harsh to send your parents to a nursing home or to orphanages , when you think about all the time, love, and sacrifice they went through to take care of you.I assume that most elderly would rather be taken care of by their children than at a nursing home [huge assumption I suppose, since the elderly could also feel like they are a burden at home], so how can the adult child not feel guilty about sending their parents to a nursing home?Update: This question pertains to the population of elderly that do not require advanced care from nursing homes.
column10: There are three segments to this question, I will attempt to address them in turn. Please bear with me.Why do so many people think it's acceptable to send their parents to nursing homes?Simply, because it is acceptable, why shouldn't it be?I don't know whether you have any awareness of the health care needs of some older people? I do. Both personally and professionally.When I was 5, my grandfather had a stroke. He was unable to stand or walk or speak or feed himself for the remaining 9 years until he died. He wasn't in a Nursing Home - I wish he had have been. My dad used to go 3 or 4 times a week to put my grandfather to bed. My dad was a military man, he was disciplined, I didn't see him for half of my childhood. My dad had a heart attack when he was 39, that may have been because he was in a very high pressured job, it may have been because he was never able to rest.Is that 'acceptable' I wonder, I'm not sure. My childhood, my brother's childhood was affected firstly by my grandfather's illness, then by my dad's absence, and then by the illness he suffered.I think it would have been far more 'acceptable' if my grandfather had been looked after in a Nursing Home, instead of the sheer bloody grind that we endured- we could have had quality time with my grandfather, sharing memories and laughing instead of worrying.Now the professional opinion. Again, I'm not sure that the questioner actually knows how 'needy' some elderly people are? Let me tell you about 'Joe' (obviously not his real name)Joe was a 82 year old male. He was an ex-sailor. He had served in WWII, he was decorated for bravery, he worked hard all of his life, he was a good man. When he was in his 60's he suffered a double amputation (years of smoking) he had high blood pressure, he had emphysema, he had diabetes. He was incontinent of urine (he had a stroke) His physical needs were huge, it required a team of carers to look after him. He deserved the best care, he received the best care. The best care was not that provided by his family, despite the fact that they loved him dearly - his needs were too great. The BEST care was that provided by the beautiful Nursing Home where he lived. The staff loved him, they cared for him, they fed him, they made sure that he was clean and shaved, they told him jokes. They sometimes 'sneaked' beer to him ( he liked a beer!) when he died, they wept tears of sorrow in my department, they stood with his family and cried.Is that unacceptable?The second question - 'It seems cruel to send your parents to a nursing home'I would ask why? Why is it cruel? Some people need 24 hour care. They are demanding, their physical needs are massive (think about Joe), I wonder what is more cruel, a family functioning on no sleep, with no training, who are unable to devote any time to caring because they need to earn a living. I don't think so.'I assume that most elderly would rather be taken care of by their children?'I'm on the fence about this one, (that is an English term for undecided), some of them would, some of them wouldn't. Most of them are pragmatic enough to realise that it isn't an option that is feasible.  And finally, I would say that there is no reason to feel guilty, being a child of a parent in need means that you want the best for them. The likelihood is that the best is the care that a Nursing Home can provide - with love and support and visits from children who are not bent double with exhaustion.  Embed Quote

column9: It seems harsh to send your parents to a nursing home or to orphanages , when you think about all the time, love, and sacrifice they went through to take care of you.I assume that most elderly would rather be taken care of by their children than at a nursing home [huge assumption I suppose, since the elderly could also feel like they are a burden at home], so how can the adult child not feel guilty about sending their parents to a nursing home?Update: This question pertains to the population of elderly that do not require advanced care from nursing homes.
column10: Whoever said the children of Nursing Home Patients and Residents do not feel guilty?Some feel so guilty they insist Mom or Dad be discharged to their care, they get in home health, they rent the hospital bed and put it in the dining room, they construct a ramp up to the front door, they buy another TV, there's even a riser on the main bath's toilet (which is a bit of a shock the first time you see/try to use it) and away they go-  home-  chattering and laughing about all the fun they'll have and who will do what little chore or task that Mom or Dad needs done.   And, just like having a new puppy, the family discovers some members are shirking their new duties (and they each feels it isn't *themselves* but others who I'm not going to name....) and so starts the friction, and then Mom or Dad doesn't feel good one morning, or has refused to get up and shower for two weeks now  (it's soo hard Mija, I'm too tired right now, we'll do it tomorrow....) or does get up, as usual, by her/him self, and falls (no, no, my hip doesn't hurt-  no- no-  don't call the ambulance!  I'll get up-  ow!  ow!  I can't move....) and they do what we in the nursing home business call FAIL.  They FAIL to thrive in a non-skilled environment.Some make it-  I've been surprised we've not yet gotten back a guy who right-side stroked last August, came to us for therapies because he had no left-side, aphasia and concomitant left-side neglect, and swallowing issues, but his extended family must be doing well.  He's been home a couple weeks now.  Of course, he is very impetuous (another side-effect of a right-side CVA) and so I know there'll be a few trips to the ER, at least;  let's hope these brushes with treatment remain minor.  Many do not make it, and come back to us in far worse shape than when they left.  Homer kept trying to make it on his own;  he'd come to us after the crisis stage of a bout of pneumonia for therapies (generalized weakness) and we'd get him going again- he'd be walking up and down the halls to the main dining room, proud as a peach, nodding and talking to everyone- and we'd grant his wish and send him home, with home health daily, and out-patient PT 3x a week.  Still he'd be back to us every 6 to 9 weeks for another 60 or so days;  been that way for over a year now.  This last time though,  Homer didn't bounce back as well.  In fact, Homer didn't bounce back at all-  Homer lay in bed, gray and squashed-looking, and finally his Doc gave us an order to ship him, so we did.  Homer went into ICU, and he never came out.  The funeral was last Monday.As the Questioner notes, some people must have a skilled-care environment.But here's the part the Questioner seems to be missing:  Skilled care (which is a nursing home) is not cheap.  My current facility runs around $6K/mo private pay, which just happens to be close to what Medicaid pays and the very few long-term care insurance policies out there;  $6K is a pretty average cost.  That's NOT cheap.  Even using Medicare, there's usually a $200/day cost-share which adds up right-smartly when you're in for 75 days of therapy.Insurance companies aren't going to pay that without good reason, they don't want to pay any claim, at all, ever; which is why we staff have to hold a weekly meeting called "Utilization Review" wherein we make sure we have all the documentation necessary to force an insurance company to pay for the stay. **  And Medicaid, (Federal/State insurance for the poor and elderly usually administrated by a third party such as, in our case, "Bridgeway")  usually doesn't quite cover costs, but is our bed-and-butter.  In our Facility, we figure every 8 Bridgeway patients and we break even;  see, Bridgeway doesn't pay by the cost, but by the month.  One patient may be fairly independent, care-wise, and another a two-person full-assist, but the money's the same.  So, putting Mom or Dad into a nursing home is rarely about getting rid of them so we can have a normal life, not unless you've got far more disposable income than you know what to do with-  skilled nursing is too expensive.  It might be about selfish comfort, but, at the same time, there's also a healthy dose of, deserved,  fear:  Do YOU know what to do when Mom chokes a bit on her coffee every single day?  When Dad's butt starts breaking down because he won't get out of that damned recliner?  When they can't get up by themselves without falling but they don't sleep well at night?  When you still can't use the dining room after 3 months because it looks like, well, a room in a nursing home?Here's another little statistic which might help put things in perspective:  Research shows that after 3 years of being a hands-on caregiver in the home, the caregiver is no longer able to ask for assistance- his or her self-image is so intertwined with the guilt of being the caregiver they are unable to admit they can't do it anymore.  This is when people die-  and it's usually the caregiver.________________________________________________________________**We are currently in our twice yearly fight with Bridgeway over our dementia care Residents.  See, folks who have dementia and meet a specific care need- in our case, "wandering"- are eligible for $20/mo extra to pay for the special care unit's special staffing and routines.  If someone wanders all over the facility looking for their room or their mother or their car or a way out, they get placed on the special care unit.  It's quiet, with special staffing who have special training.  Very, very soon, Residents calm down, feel safer (it isn't medication-  the SCU policy is to d/c meds as soon as possible) and so quit wandering.  And, twice yearly, Bridegway does an audit and discovers all these people they're paying extra for aren't wandering so they aren't going to pay for them to stay in the SCU anymore.  So we either have to come up with a way to creatively document that people are wandering when they're not, or we have to keep moving people back into the main units and stress the hell out of them, wait for them to have a crisis and try to elope, in order to get them back on the SCU where they belong.  That's just stupid.  Embed Quote

column9: It seems harsh to send your parents to a nursing home or to orphanages , when you think about all the time, love, and sacrifice they went through to take care of you.I assume that most elderly would rather be taken care of by their children than at a nursing home [huge assumption I suppose, since the elderly could also feel like they are a burden at home], so how can the adult child not feel guilty about sending their parents to a nursing home?Update: This question pertains to the population of elderly that do not require advanced care from nursing homes.
column10: Many people think it is acceptable, because in many situations it is the best option for children who seek to take care of their parents.  And that said, many people who do put their parents in nursing homes -- whether this be their best choice or not -- usually feel guilt over this choice anyway.Elderly parents moving in with an adult child caretaker is wonderful.  Their children might develop a great rapport with their grandparents.  And there is no better way to teach your children how to honor and respect elders than to show them how you honor your parents.  If you can manage this as your plan of action, great.  I know many who strongly suggest this is the best option for your elderly parents. And yet, people have such a wide range of needs and capabilities that having a categorical bias against nursing homes is simply narrow minded.  For many people, it is the best way to take care of their parents. And that is certainly acceptable, and actually preferable.  I recall not too long ago "putting my foot in my mouth" when I mentioned to someone how sad it was to see elders inventoried in these places, only to find out that he just put his mother in such a facility after being unable to take care of her as she advanced into very complicated medical issues.  Oops.  I made a judgmental assumption.  I was wrong.  Situations are more complex for some people.That said -- once in the nursing home, you do not have to treat them like inventory.  You can make it your business to visit them often.  You can even visit other people too.  In fact, I used to sing in a choir and we'd rehearse at a nursing home (someone had a connection with the management). Some of the residents really enjoyed the weekly activity (and we got to use the space!).  Better to be creative than judgmental.  Embed Quote

column9: It seems harsh to send your parents to a nursing home or to orphanages , when you think about all the time, love, and sacrifice they went through to take care of you.I assume that most elderly would rather be taken care of by their children than at a nursing home [huge assumption I suppose, since the elderly could also feel like they are a burden at home], so how can the adult child not feel guilty about sending their parents to a nursing home?Update: This question pertains to the population of elderly that do not require advanced care from nursing homes.
column10: Harshness, but nature is sharp and uncaring.  In music it is a sound of discord, in parenting it can be yelling or spanking.  Harshness in care would be ignoring the problem or providing unfit accomidations. When I was 28, my mother, an only child, lived 2500 miles from her mother when she needed care.  We had been trying for years to help my grandmother but she refused.  It was only after years of tribulation and heartache and police action (not by us-by them), that she was removed from her home and not allowed to go back.   My mother had two small children, 8 & 10 and a full time career.  My grandmother had spent all of her saving trying to win 'Sweepstakes'.  She had become a hoarder and had tens of thousands in credit card debt.  Her house had no upkeep and she had untreated mental illness. Once out of her home and on medication, she lived successfully for 3 years in a senior independant living facility.  We spent all of our free time and thousands of dollars traveling to visit her and cleaning out her house.   When my grandmother could no longer live indepedantly, we moved her to Oregon (with me)  where she received nursing care then lived in assisted living.  I visited her 2-3 times a day, ensured she had the best care and that all of her needs were being met.  I myself was a busy professional and when she broke her hip, I left a client meeting and spent two weeks working from the hospital. Our care choices were not harsh, they were based on our capibilities.  I did not have the expertise nor the finacial ability to provide her with round the clock care.  She had caring and loving care givers who brushed her hair and made sure she had proper nutrition.  It would have been harsh to leave her 9 hours a day in isolation or only with a care provider instead of going to the dining room every day, making friends and having activities. There are so many levels of care and we did what we thought was best.  I feel no guilt because the last few years of her life she was clean, safe, medicated and happy.  We got to enjoy the last few years with her that we would never have had.  My mom probably always wished she could do more, but there is what you wish for and there is reality. Making decisions about care is deeply personal based on your background and I suppose some people dump their parents in nursing care and never look back.  And that is  harsh and I suspect they feel no guilt. But independant living, senior living, assisted living and nursing care in and of itself is not harsh and can allow you to ensure your loved one receives the best care, without guilt.  Embed Quote

column9: It seems harsh to send your parents to a nursing home or to orphanages , when you think about all the time, love, and sacrifice they went through to take care of you.I assume that most elderly would rather be taken care of by their children than at a nursing home [huge assumption I suppose, since the elderly could also feel like they are a burden at home], so how can the adult child not feel guilty about sending their parents to a nursing home?Update: This question pertains to the population of elderly that do not require advanced care from nursing homes.
column10: Gil Yehuda, Gary Miller and Anonymous 's answers are quite thorough, but I'll add a few thoughts.I have actually been through this very case. When my wife and I had our son we asked my mother and father to move in with us. The thinking at the time was to combine households. The grandparents would help raise my son and they could retire (they are in the early 60s,so retirement was looming) and enjoy their later years. We'd be there to take care of them as they got older.They already have a number of health issues, but are not in need of any sort of daily care per say. Unfortunately, a fair amount of conflict arose. I would liken the issues to the problems parents face when college or adult age children move back in with them. Everyone's intentions were good, however we now had a household divided with two kings and two queens. This is harder to handle than it might sound. It wasn't constant fighting, and there were good parts to it, but it wasn't the storybook ending we'd hoped for. In the end my parents moved back into their home and it is still up in the air how things will proceed when they reach more advanced ages.That being said here are some other jumbled up thoughts.In the US, many elderly people do not want to give up living in their own homes. They are reluctant to lose the Independence of their retirement years whether it is by moving into a retirement home or by moving in with their children. The result is that many stay in their homes until very late into their lives. Often in the case of couples it is up until one of them passes away. At this point the remaining partner may be quite elderly and the care required may be overwhelming for a working family. If the elderly had been willing to move in when they were "younger" the transition may have been easier and more feasible.Related cultural observations. in the US, people are taught to be independent. Kids generally move out at 18 and if all goes according to plan, they don't move back in. This has the positive effect of teaching the children to be self reliant but it may also reduce their sense of obligation to their family. Multiple generation child rearing in the US is mostly a thing of the past. Historically families may have insisted the elderly stay with them, but up until it became unreasonable, the elderly contributed to the family.  Embed Quote

column9: It seems harsh to send your parents to a nursing home or to orphanages , when you think about all the time, love, and sacrifice they went through to take care of you.I assume that most elderly would rather be taken care of by their children than at a nursing home [huge assumption I suppose, since the elderly could also feel like they are a burden at home], so how can the adult child not feel guilty about sending their parents to a nursing home?Update: This question pertains to the population of elderly that do not require advanced care from nursing homes.
column10: Sometimes, it's difficult for children to manage the needs of the elderly person. If they have conditions, medication requirements or other medical care that is not provided outside of a medical facility then it is difficult, if not impossible, for the children to provide adequate care.Your tone assumes that children are simply pushing their parents into a facility to avoid inconvenience rather than placing them in a facility because it is in the elderly persons best interest.    Embed Quote

column9: It seems harsh to send your parents to a nursing home or to orphanages , when you think about all the time, love, and sacrifice they went through to take care of you.I assume that most elderly would rather be taken care of by their children than at a nursing home [huge assumption I suppose, since the elderly could also feel like they are a burden at home], so how can the adult child not feel guilty about sending their parents to a nursing home?Update: This question pertains to the population of elderly that do not require advanced care from nursing homes.
column10: The simple answer is - many simply don't have the resources to take care of their parents; which is why nursing homes were built in the first place. Because not everyone has the time, attention, and care to devote to their parents. Although, there are some alternatives to consider before choosing a nursing home. Mobility aids can make it easier to move around, protect us from falling, and help us live more independently. But if your parents need more support - a nursing home may be necessary.So instead of questioning the motive of the situation (thinking it's ""OK"" to send parents to a nursing home), it's important to also question the context of the situation (whether they have the resources and attention to care for the parents). Because in many cases, the option of sending parents to the nursing home come out of necessity.  Embed Quote

column9: It seems harsh to send your parents to a nursing home or to orphanages , when you think about all the time, love, and sacrifice they went through to take care of you.I assume that most elderly would rather be taken care of by their children than at a nursing home [huge assumption I suppose, since the elderly could also feel like they are a burden at home], so how can the adult child not feel guilty about sending their parents to a nursing home?Update: This question pertains to the population of elderly that do not require advanced care from nursing homes.
column10: Because sadly many of their children have not even been taught properly to care for themselves.  And if they have often both the husband and wife work and are not trained to provide the proper medical care and supervision necessary to deal with an elderly parent who may be suffering from dementia. I visit my father on a weekly basis and he is clean, well fed and gets his numerous medicines on a daily basis.  They have staff with emergency medical training should he suffer another stroke or heart attack.  He has daily visitors who come and engage him even though he seldom can remember our names.  I realize a lot of the people there have little or no visitors.  This is sad but if they have their mental facilities they talk together and enjoy music, television, and weekly activities.  There are many who are still very lonely because they have lost a wife or a husband or because their children don't visit them as often as they should.  So don't just assume that your children will be there for you.  Plan for the future and the ending of your life story in a way that will be dignified and comforting to you.  Embed Quote

column9: It seems harsh to send your parents to a nursing home or to orphanages , when you think about all the time, love, and sacrifice they went through to take care of you.I assume that most elderly would rather be taken care of by their children than at a nursing home [huge assumption I suppose, since the elderly could also feel like they are a burden at home], so how can the adult child not feel guilty about sending their parents to a nursing home?Update: This question pertains to the population of elderly that do not require advanced care from nursing homes.
column10: Firstly I believe the questioner should make a distinction between a high care nursing home, a hostel which is low care but has nursing staff on site (such as grandpa Simpson's home but usually much nicer) and places like retirement villages where people live independently but amongst a community and with lots of support.It's not just about the stress and anxiety and pain of the family members. Often a very physically or mentally debilitated old person has worse health and even mental health when looked after family members who are unable to cope.People develop pressure sores, infections, are sometimes neglected or have inadequate personal hygiene because the poor family members cannot physically look after the old person. Often they keep having to come to hospital because of these reasons and the hospital is certainly not a great way to spend the rest of your years.My extended family is from Sri Lanka and they have done a remarkable job of looking after the old people in our family, something they had no choice about. Fortunately none of them suffered from these complications. They however have much more support from the extended family because society is not structured in strict nuclear family units. I still wish though that there were many more options and social services and help for them.It's very romantic thinking from a privileged western perspective that taking care of an ill, disabled or demented old person is noble and should be compulsory. It's not romantic and it's often impossible. It involves faeces and urine and sputum and bedsores and pus and infections and pneumonia and spending hours and days and weeks in the hospital. And not getting enough help and feeling horribly guilty that you could not do more.Additionally, let's not forget the dark side of non-Western cultures and being forced to take care of elderly family members. There are people whose spouses desert them because they don't want to have to look after their in-laws, leaving them destitute. There are people who have to quit work to look after their family members full time and cannot feed their families. There are large families you fight and argue about the care of the old person and criticise the person who is actually looking after the old person without contributing anything.  Embed Quote

column9: It seems harsh to send your parents to a nursing home or to orphanages , when you think about all the time, love, and sacrifice they went through to take care of you.I assume that most elderly would rather be taken care of by their children than at a nursing home [huge assumption I suppose, since the elderly could also feel like they are a burden at home], so how can the adult child not feel guilty about sending their parents to a nursing home?Update: This question pertains to the population of elderly that do not require advanced care from nursing homes.
column10: Of course its acceptable to arrange nursing/residential care for your parents. At some point, a threshold is crossed where its simply not safe or dignified for someone to be living at home, even with a robust care package in place. I can only speak from the UK experience and having been a dementia physician and now as an entrepreneur trying to prolong independence at home.(HomeTouch: Home)A more elegant question might have been - what can be done to prolong the time before someone needs institutional care (bearing in mind that 95% + of older people want to remain in their own homes when asked before they become too frail) Imagine if you are cognitively and visually impaired, at risk of falls, and doubly incontinent. It would be practically impossible for someone that frail to remain at home for long. Some live-in care providers do this at home, but the costs of 24 hr 1:1 care are more than a home.Having said all this, one of the revealing (and unsettling) pieces of information I learnt was  the way the largest care home chains think of the "marketing funnel" for new care home residents. There is, apparently, the "crisis" route and the "considered" route. The crisis route is when Mum ends up in the ER after a fall; everything has broken down, its Christmas Eve and she can't go home. She needs to be placed immediately. Its a fait accompli.  The "considered" route is where the care homes knowingly play on families emotions to convert a sale. Nice surroundings, ensuite bathroom, gentle counselling, accessible visiting etc. Typically the sales cycle can last months as the family deliberate and agonise over the decision; there's sibling conflict, visits to other homes. Whatever you think of this, it is how some care homes chains think. Where I don't agree with the other posters is that this outcome is at least partially driven by family guilt, whatever the medical/care needs of the parent.  Embed Quote

column9: It seems harsh to send your parents to a nursing home or to orphanages , when you think about all the time, love, and sacrifice they went through to take care of you.I assume that most elderly would rather be taken care of by their children than at a nursing home [huge assumption I suppose, since the elderly could also feel like they are a burden at home], so how can the adult child not feel guilty about sending their parents to a nursing home?Update: This question pertains to the population of elderly that do not require advanced care from nursing homes.
column10: The underlying problem is that the word "nursing home" became a swear word in the United States. Lack of care, and in some cases even abuse inside nursing homes has seniors upset at the very mention of the word. However, from my experience, most nursing home and assisted living facilities passionately treat their residents with dignity and respect. Hopefully, as more families leave reviews of their senior care experiences, the good providers will stand out above the rest.  Embed Quote

column9: It seems harsh to send your parents to a nursing home or to orphanages , when you think about all the time, love, and sacrifice they went through to take care of you.I assume that most elderly would rather be taken care of by their children than at a nursing home [huge assumption I suppose, since the elderly could also feel like they are a burden at home], so how can the adult child not feel guilty about sending their parents to a nursing home?Update: This question pertains to the population of elderly that do not require advanced care from nursing homes.
column10: The most common reason for people choosing homecare over entering a facility is that they want to spend what remains of their life on earth with family and close friends rather than doctors, nurses, and other elderly patients. Additionally, being cared for at home is also generally less expensive than staying in nursing homes or assisted-living facilities. Your loved ones would also appreciate the fact that a homecare setup allows them to closely monitor your health and well-being as you grow older, which they probably won’t be able to do if you were in a nursing home and daily visits are too much of a hassle. Another good reason to go for elderly homecare as opposed to entering a nursing home is that it’s a more flexible solution. You can tailor-fit the kind of services you get to your specific needs and requirements. For example, if you can still pretty much do things on your own as long as they’re done while you’re seated, your caregiver could simply assist you with such tasks as getting in and out of bed or taking items from cupboards and shelves. In a nursing home setup, patients are generally cared for in the same way and differ only when there are special medications or treatments needed, thus taking away much of the flexibility of being cared for at home.  Embed Quote

column9: It seems harsh to send your parents to a nursing home or to orphanages , when you think about all the time, love, and sacrifice they went through to take care of you.I assume that most elderly would rather be taken care of by their children than at a nursing home [huge assumption I suppose, since the elderly could also feel like they are a burden at home], so how can the adult child not feel guilty about sending their parents to a nursing home?Update: This question pertains to the population of elderly that do not require advanced care from nursing homes.
column10: I see a lot of good answers here, so I'll keep my response short. An important quality for adult children in caregiving is to admit when they can't do it alone. It is one thing to appreciate their own responsibility towards their parents, and it is a good thing. But they also need to appreciate that it is the senior's livelihood and happiness which matters more than meeting the responsibility themselves.Caregiving, without a doubt, has more to it than what we see. It has complicated challenges. That said, sending the seniors to care homes should not be an easy way out, but a sensible decision in the best interest of the seniors in concern.  Embed Quote

column9: More people who live forever means a skyrocketing population.
column10: One way or another, we'd have to stop growing our population.  If we grow at the rate we were growing back in, say, the 60s, space exploration only buys us a few thousand years before the biomass of humanity becomes a sphere expanding at the speed of light.So the darwinistic struggle will continue.  We'll just be fighting each other, not old age.I know that sounds bad, but it still feels like progress to me.  Embed Quote

column9: More people who live forever means a skyrocketing population.
column10: There would be no increased strain.  When you look at the US and compare its population density to Japan, you find that most of the land in the US is completely underutilized.Third generation biofuels will be cost competitive with gasoline within a few years with existing technology.  Aside from oil, few natural resources are not already easily substituted.Eliminating human aging in the US is likely to have less an impact on natural resources usage than the industrialization of China and India.  Its not really a problem.Its also not clear that immortality would lead to increased population growth.  Population growth is highest in the poorest countries and is inversely proportional to GDP.  It is likely that population growth rates would first decline if immortality became technologically feasible.  Embed Quote

column9: More people who live forever means a skyrocketing population.
column10: Space exploration and colonization. It sounds far fetched, but so was landing on the moon.No matter how efficient we used our resources, the limit on Earth is finite. Going out to space is the ultimate route.  Embed Quote

column9: More people who live forever means a skyrocketing population.
column10: Well it won't be organic farming, I'll tell you that :)As someone with deep roots in California agriculture, I find the obsession with organic farming among progressives a bit inconsistent. Using natural resources as efficiently as possible requires the use of (well-tested and generally-recognized as safe) chemicals. Production and quality can increase by factors. To me, organic farming is a bit of a ruse - but the popularity of organic foods should definitely send a signal to the conventional farming and chemicals industry that they need to make a concerted effort at ensuring their products are 100% safe, well-tested scientifically, and positioned to consumers the right way.  Embed Quote

column9: More people who live forever means a skyrocketing population.
column10: Assuming we have the technology to reverse aging, we should just shrink people to 1/20 the size.  A brain with legs would be a huge improvement to our environmental load.    Embed Quote

column9: More people who live forever means a skyrocketing population.
column10: Assuming singularity. No problems at all. Just holo-love and shooting endorphins into our spinal cords all day long. This is the singularity section, right?Assuming no singularity, war, famine, disease and then we will all die. Literally. We will all die of old age and everyone will say that it's "natural" despite the fact that it's  a horrific tragedy each and every time.  Embed Quote

column9: Vitamin supplements, dietary modifications, exercises, etc ... ?
column10: Some things to likely avoid/minimize if you wish to delay the onset of the effects of aging:Tobacco/drugs/etc. Should be obvious right?Alcohol. Lots of controversy on this one. Anywhere from 0-2 drinks/day could be neutral or anti-aging depending on who you talk to. 3+ drinks/day and/or binge drink sessions are almost certainly pro-aging.Sugar/fructose. Tough to make any health claims for benefits of sugar or fructose consumption with the exception being whole fruits in moderation.Possibly casein and gluten. Jury does seem out here on whether everyone should avoid casein and gluten. The book The China Study makes a good case for avoid casein but has also drawn its share of criticism. Gluten is obviously a no-no for anyone with Celiac's disease but it's quite possibly that gluten causes low-level inflammation in many people that could be pro-aging.Stress. Another obvious one right?Trans fats/fried foods. Also hopefully quite obvious.So much more to say here but I think this is a good list to start with of things to avoid or minimize.  Embed Quote

column9: Vitamin supplements, dietary modifications, exercises, etc ... ?
column10: Free radicals are the main cause behind aging process. The same radicals cause cancer. Consuming the food that is high in antioxidants can assist in fighting against the aging process. Spinach, Berries, Dark chocolate, whole grains, and herbal teas are some of the foods that can make you look and feel healthy throughout the life. source: Anti-Aging Foods  Embed Quote

column9: Vitamin supplements, dietary modifications, exercises, etc ... ?
column10:
Staying healthy and avoiding aging has many strategies and nuances that depend on your age and current condtion.  I attended the recent http://lifeextensionconference.com and learned of at least 20 possible things you can do. 
  
 Here are few:  exercise daily; manage your stress; minimize sugar;  don't drink any kind of soda; take good care of your teeth and gums;  intermittent fasting (easier to do than calorie restriction);  take a good multivitamin with minerals; eat lots of veggies;  get a anti-aging doctor and use testing to determine your body's needs.
  
 The supplements listed above are all useful.   I found the products from http://juvenon.com to be excellent way to get many of them.   Use the guides at http://lef.org to understand various conditions and what  supplements might be useful.  Embed Quote

column9: Vitamin supplements, dietary modifications, exercises, etc ... ?
column10: Resveratrol - antioxidantN-acetyl-cysteine - glutathione precursorLow dose deprenyl - various anti-oxidant and neurotrophic effectsCurcumin - antioxidant, lightweight MAO inhibitor, may guard against Alzheiemer'sOmega-3 - mmmmmmm...makes cell membranes nice and supple and sexyB-complex vitamins - to support metabolic processesVery-low-dose lithium - neuroprotectiveGreen Tea - polyphenols, tea catechins, l-theanineBasically, Jack LaLane style fruits and veggies (the more colorful the better) smoothies/juices harness the ton of different polyphenols / flavanoids in plants. Most of which are dramatically under-studied. With the arrogance that is inherent in the young, I used to assume that the most intellectual were those, like myself, who had been to University and had letters after their name, (preferably more than one set of letters because that was even more 'intellectual')Then, days after the start of the first Gulf War, after the Iraqi army had invaded Kuwait, I was talking to an old chap in the Emergency Department. He would have been somewhere between 70-80.And he was telling me how conflict in the Desert was different and had different challenges to other conflict. And then he was telling me about air conflict. He seemed to know what he was talking about, so I pondered, out loud, how a retired baker from Nottingham would know this stuff. He wasn't offended that I'd asked.He had been, he told me proudly, one of the desert rats (a name apparently given to a unit of the British Army fighting in North Africa during WWII) and his older brother had been a pilot in the RAF.It was a salutary lesson to me. Previously, I had viewed all 'old people' as just that, old. It hadn't really occurred to me that they had 'history' and intelligence and experience.I've since had the enormous privilege of talking to a huge number of older people. All of them with stories to tell, some of them more mundane, all of them interesting experiences.I've met one of the men who developed ibuprofen, the man credited with developing the MRI scanner for use on patients, one of the only men who managed to escape from the Japanese on more than one occasion during the second world war.What every single one of these people, all of them amazing, had in common, was experience and time.So, in my opinion, one of the greatest intellectual advantages of aging is experience.And I am very lucky to have shared it.  Embed QuoteVia  Sheri Fresonke Harper.

Ah - what a question indeed! One must clarify though what intellect means and what it means to possess it, in order to determine whether aging confers an advantage. If by intellect one means, the ability to obtain better outcomes in a given context, then the only thing aging gives you, is the benefit of having had more opportunities and encounters. The increased numbers, improves the probability that some of those encounters were rich and that one correspondingly had the opportunity to observe patterns, and thereby gain knowledge and wisdom. Whether that indeed happens in all cases is not guaranteed.I do not think there are inherent intellectual advantages to aging otherwise. Physiologically there is deterioration beyond a certain point. Whether or not one obtains intellectual benefits depends on the individual.  Embed QuoteVia  Sheri Fresonke Harper.

For me, the intellectual benefits of aging fall into a number of categories from birth onward:1) you learn to make use of and rely on your senses2) you learn how to count and speak3) you learn how to coordinate your body movements and judge distance and time4) you learn other ways to communicate5) you learn how objects fit together spatially and to use tools6) you learn how to make music7) you learn how to judge peoples emotional states8) you learn society's expectations9) you learn to store your knowledge relationally10) by the time you've learned to live independently, you are judged and adult11) you learn how to learnbasically, all that's left from that time on is caring enough to stay alive.  Embed QuoteVia  Ankit Goyal.

As you grow older more myelin is deposited on your nerves (white matter). Myelin is an insulator and prevents the electrical currents of neuronal synapse from leaking out in transit.  As more and more myelin is deposited over the years (this can go on well into your 40's and beyond)  your "neural networks" become capable of generating currents that travel farther.  Hence you become capable of "lighting up" many more neurons in a possibly much larger network than when you have less myelin and leaky circuits where the electrical current dissipates much sooner and propagates much less.As you can light up much bigger sets of neurons you can hol din your thoughts much more complex and potentially contradictory and/or nuanced conceptual patterns which require more "parallel processing" power.Hence the more complex leadership tasks that require balancing hard power, soft power and integrating historical depth and social breadth are often only possible to the older members of society not just because of experience. One might also consider as social corroboration the fact that mathematicians are said to reach their peak powers in their 40's and also why traditional societies value their older members.Note: I am not a doctor or medical professional just an avid reader of brain research.  Embed Quote

There are endless stories about the search for a cure for aging and a way to extend life. Gilgamesh, the earliest known written myth, is specifically about that quest. In later tales there's always a price. Faust, per Goethe, sold his soul to the devil for just 24 more years. In Huxley's wonderful _After Many a Summer Dies the Swan_ the price is backward evolution. In Dr. Heidegger's Experiment (Hawthorne) the regenerated youth are found to be as stupid as they ever were.There are also tales of immortal humans wondering the Earth and paying the price of wandering through history without companionship. One of the earliest is Simon De Bouvier's.  All Men Are Mortal . There is also a list of such literature at the end of the wikipedia article on The Man From Earth:The Man from Earth  Embed Quote

Well, "gerontology and literature" would be the topic. What you're looking for is a thesis. But, as theses are fairly personal things (and coming up with one is likely part of your assignment), I'll recommend a few books that might be useful to you. Hemingway, The Old Man and the Sea. There are a lot of themes in Hemingway's novel that would be relevant. The main character, Santiago, seeks to live a simple, dignified life. He struggles with the village's perception of him as a washed up old man--since he has gone 84 days without a catch. There's some contrast between him and his young apprentice, Manolin. I can't guarantee that this novel will work for your paper, but it's short enough that you can read it, decide for yourself, and choose something different if you can't make it fit. In either case, it's a great read. Another book you might find useful, depending, to some extent, on your teacher's tastes, is Jimmy Carter's The Virtues of Aging, which gives a really nice portrait of living the late part of one's life in a meaningful, useful way.  Embed QuoteVia  Shoks Topsy.

Older people sometimes have difficulty hearing so their voice loudness can vary. The loss of teeth can affect their voice as can the use of dentures. Many people move to the warmer parts of the country where they are more affected by allergies which can alter the voice. The elderly voice can become weaker and more tremulous, shaky or thin with loss of muscle tone. Dementia affects other body parts in addition to the brain--my father-in-law's death was caused by his inability to close his windpipe when he swallowed so food ended up in his lungs. More specifics about the health issues related are at:http://www.entnet.org/HealthInfo...  Embed Quote

My personal opinion is the answer is no:There are currently few viable therapeutics with proven efficacy that use adult stem cells. While I am optimistic that stem cell technology will change medicine in the future, it is unclear what kinds of stem cells will be used and how they will be used. There are many different stem cell types and lineages - adult stem cells are already partially differentiated and lack the potential to generate many different mature cell types that embryonic stem cells can. If you are posting this question, I'm going to assume its too late to extract your embryonic stem cells. ;)The techniques to maintain and propagate a cell line are imperfect and imprecise. Even if there a beneficial stem cell based therapeutic is developed in ten years, there is limited infrastructure or understanding on how to "keep" stem cells. While it might be pleasant to think that one can just freeze cells and use them many years in the future, in reality many commonly used research stem cell lines are continuously maintained in cell culture and cells frozen for a long time can be considered suspect. From personal experience, it seems like freshly thawed cells grow slower and are more difficult to work with. One the hottest areas of investigation in regenerative medicine is the study of iPSC, induced pluripotent stem cells. Using a series of steps involving reprogramming by Yamanaka factors, mature and fully differentiated cells have been turned into cells that are similar to embryonic stem cells. These cells have been shown to exhibit the ability to differentiate into cardiomyocytes, neurons, and a variety of other cell types. These cells, which can be derived in a patient specific manner, can be generated at will, and probably will limit the value of collecting and banking stem cells.Aside: Different adult stem cell populations reside in different areas of the body - I would imagine any way to harvest them would be invasive. I wouldn't want to be stuck everywhere by tens of needles on the off chance it might be useful in the distant future.  Embed Quote

column9: E.g. they were very healthy up to their dying day (when they then die of a heart attack or die in their sleep).By "very old" I mean over 90.
column10: I cannot tell you the percentage-  I don't even know if such meta-research has been done.  But, using my experience in nursing homes...  not many.  No one dies in perfect health.That's not how it works.However, using that same experience, I can tell you that most people go "in their sleep", more or less.  Whatever disease process is getting the better of life starts weakening various systems- especially kidneys and liver- and gradually toxins build up in your blood stream, and, just as when you're ill with anything, your body gets tired, and you sleep more.  Only this time, well, the toxins continue to build, and you continue to sleep.  And the toxins build, and you sleep.  And the toxins weaken all organs, all functions, your digestion slows, your kidneys fail, your brain starts to lack oxygen, your heart starts fluttering, and--  away you go, like a balloon that's been let loose.  There are painful, stressful deaths;  I've seen a few.  But even my Dad, who died of asbestos poisoning and spent his last few weeks gasping for air, every single breath, gasp and cough and gasp some more,  when he went into active death, those last few hours, he was just...  asleep.  And then he was gone. But no one dies in perfect health.  Embed Quote
