column9: My grandmother, mother, and mother-in-law have all needed hip replacements or hip surgery after falling down. Anecdotally it seems like broken hips are extremely common among the elderly, especially women. What can my wife and I do while we're still middle-aged, e.g., specific types of exercise or nutrition, to minimize our risk of hip brittleness in our old age?
column10: Keeping up adequate levels of Vitamin D is critical to bone health. It is fairly safe to operate under the assumption that you are deficient, though getting a simple blood test is an easy way to know exactly how concerned you need to be. In addition to regular weight bearing exercise - spend a few minutes each day in a deep squat, with feet and knees apart and tailbone towards the floor (search "garland" pose for a visual of this position). This will build strength and flexibility into the hip girdle. You are wise to be thinking ahead!  Embed Quote

column10: Eating healthily and taking regular exercise (particularly weight bearing exercises) can help to strengthen the bones. Try to get plenty of calcium through your diet. Vitamin D (produced through sun exposure) is also a vital nutrient for bone health.If you dont get enough of these, you could try food supplements that boost levels.Here's an infographic we produced that offers some advice and risks associated with bone health at different ages, hope it helps in some way! :).  Embed Quote

""Neurogenesis (nerve-cell production) goes down with age … it's known that with old age there's a decrease in short- term memory," says Ronald Evans, a genetics professor at the Salk Institute for Biological Studies in La Jolla, Calif. "We know that if we can increase the process, we know what the consequence could be in the brain, which would be to increase short-term learning and memory." http://www.scientificamerican.co...  Embed Quote

column9: "Retirement communities", assisted living facilities, and so forth are extremely expensive and exist as businesses to extract the wealth from the aging.  On the other hand, retirees and the aging get more and more vuneralble and there's a point where the standard practice of living in and maintaining one's own dwelling becomes difficult or impossible.  What are some alternatives?  For example, see the topic definition for Aging in Place.The problems (and solutions) are, of course, pretty culture-specific.Also:Retirement: What are some of the best essays that examine Age-Restricted Communities?
column10: In the days of my grandparents a family simply 'absorbed' their elderly loved ones into their household.Never mind the inconvenience, added expense, or personality conflicts.Space was made for the elderly and their needs were met to the best ability of the younger ones of the household until the end of their (the elder ones) life.In the days of my parents it was considered appropriate for elder members of the family to be looked after in their own home as long as they could be safe there and the younger family members could check on them and aid them as needed.  Nursing homes were for the last and most extreme of illnesses where family could no longer provide sufficient care to sustain life for the elder one.Several years ago I found myself solely responsible for the well-being of both my aging parents.  For 14 years I cared for both of them (until my mother passed away and then only my father).  My mother was at home until she fell and broke her hip and could no longer be physically cared for.  She spent 4 months in a nursing home/hospital before passing away.Three years ago I had to put my father in a nursing home because his physical and mental condition had deteriorated to the point I could no longer care for his needs at home and his safety and health were compromised.  He is now 93 and in good care.When both my parents were still able to make rational decisions they made a 'living will' stating their preferences for their final care.One thing they were very clear about was that they did not want me or my brother to have to take any extreme measures that disrupted our lives to care for them.  They expected to be in a nursing home eventually unless they should die suddenly.  But when it came time to admit them to a nursing home neither wanted to go.  I had to make the decision against their wishes.  It was the fact of the living will which made the decision possible for me on an emotional level.  I knew that when they were cognitively capable they had made the decision and I had the right to abide by it.  In my opinion, the kindest thing a person approaching his/her elder years can do for their loved ones is to give them 'permission', in black and white, to do what is reasonable and sensible for all concerned when the time comes for steps to be taken to protect those who can no longer protect themselves.  Embed Quote

column9: That is, what would I get a PhD in if I want to do something related to the biomedical field/industry and am concerned about my future income? (I don't want an MD.)I was thinking about gerontology/genetics (due to the aging population and burgeoning research in this field) but I'm not entirely sure about that. I know pharmacology should remain pretty high-paying...
column10: I want to take a step back and explain why we may guess and estimate and predict but we can't know the answer to your question.If it's research, then you can't know its result in advance.By definition, research is a set of actions that attempt to discover something we don't already know.  If we're trying to find a better test for prostate cancer, it's because we don't know what the right test is.  Until we find the better test, we won't know if it's a blood test, a breath analysis, a new kind of imaging, ...  Also, we can't know in advance whether we'll find any acceptable answer by the end of this year or the end of this decade.  And we won't know in advance the person who will find the answer, or the company, or even the continent.This is important to your career in research because unpredictable results by people you don't know may create new tools and increase the range of questions you can answer.  That will make your field richer, broader, more interesting, and more profitable.  Or, an unpredictable lack of results by everyone in the field may make the field dull and uninteresting over the 20 years you are thinking about.If you can live with this level of uncertainty, here are three things to think about that will improve your odds.Pick a field that's important.  There are lots of measures of importance.  Gerontology will have an increasing number of customers over the next 20 years.  But people in mid-career may pay better for solutions to their problems.  Saving a child may add 80 productive, happy years of life.  Even solving problems for lab rats may enable new solutions for people.  Developing new tools may have the widest impact.  So look at a field you're interested in and ask who benefits from your work and how much is the benefit.Pick a field with a lot of good workers.  Avoid a field (and later a group within a company) that's below critical mass.  There are no guarantees, but the more people working in the field, the better the chance that someone will have a breakthrough.  And working with good people is one of the rewards of a life in research.Keep yourself able to move.  This involves finding a field that's related to other fields that you find interesting.  You'll probably have to specialize to develop employable skills, but always look for ways to apply what you know to other problems.Good luck!  Embed Quote

column10: My vote would be brain/machine interface.  For example, there are about 300M people who are seriously visually impaired.  This particular problem might be addressed by a camera plus a brain/machine interface, or stem cells to grow new eyes.  Either way the market is huge.  If  blind person would be willing to spend $10K to regain their sight (and I would if I was blind) then this alone is a 3 trillion dollar market.  But the brain/machine interface has a lot more potential than stem cells, in my opinion.   Want to see in the infrared?  Have a built in, diffraction limited zoom lens?  See overlays without google glasses?  Once this gets to the point of enhancement, not just replacement, the market is even bigger.  Embed Quote

It is not a criticism, there is nothing wrong on aiming to earn an outrageous amount of money. But, do not think on research then, because there is no assurance that the outcome will be rewarding. You may enter a dead end, and after years of work, find out that your investigation leads to nowhere, or that another, more powerful technology or product has made yours obsolete before hitting the market. Investigation is rewarding by itself, but it far away of being a safe bet to make money.  Embed Quote

For activating ltc, the most important piece is to demonstrate that the person needs help with the activities of daily living.  (ADL). So, it depends on what is causing the change in ADLS. If it is physical, then I would use a physician. If It is relaten to dementia or other cognitive functioning, then I would use a geriatric psychologist.  But, check with the plan as some require the assessment be completed by a medical doctor.   If you are having problems getting the doctor. to explain the changes in the way the insurance company needs, the services of a geriatric care manager or social worker can be very helpful.  Once the initial assessment is done, the ltc company will probably require periodic re-evaluations. It's important to stay on top of their documentation requirements and be proactive in securing your coverage.  Embed Quote

column9: Not every cell in the human body has the same lifespan. Some die and are replaced faster than others. Certain cells, like neurons, live much longer than the average epithelial cell?Which type lives the longest? What is that average age? Why do they live the longest, and how? What if they didn't?
column10: True, neurons have a long life period. It's commonly assumed that every two years our body replaces all it's cells (exept neurons and maybe others). Another exception are the egg cells on the female ovary, that ara created before the birth and last til they get out of the ovary.  Embed Quote

column9: I've heard that the faster an organism's metabolism, the shorter life span they'll have. Furthermore, smaller organisms like mice tend to have high metabolic rates, and don't live long (two years on average), whereas larger organisms like the blue whale have much slower metabolisms and live for a very long time. What's the relationship here?
column10: First, a terminological point: "metabolism" refers to all the molecular and cellular processes that go on in the body, not only breathing. It's only the term "metabolic rate" that specifically refers to oxygen consumption.So: Yes, there is a correlation between what's called "specific metabolic rate", SMR (which means rate of oxygen consumption per unit body mass) and rate of aging, i.e. an inverse relationship between SMR and maximum potential lifespan. This is no surprise, because breathing is undoubtedly bad for you: it creates free radicals, which damage DNA and other macromolecules, and the rate of accumulation of that damage is a major determinant of the rate of aging. But it's only a modestly tight correlation, because the evolutionary pressure to avoid aging varies from one species to another, and that variation is dependent on many factors. So birds tend to live far longer than rodents of the same size (and thus of similar SMR), because evolution has worked harder on them to bear down on the rate of free radical production per unit oxygen consumption, the resistance of their macromolecules to being damaged by free radicals, etc.  Embed QuoteVia  Michael Sinanian.

column9: I've heard that the faster an organism's metabolism, the shorter life span they'll have. Furthermore, smaller organisms like mice tend to have high metabolic rates, and don't live long (two years on average), whereas larger organisms like the blue whale have much slower metabolisms and live for a very long time. column10: That is the contrast I was thinking about.  Isn't it possible that the longer lifespans of larger animals are due to a longer growth/reproductive cycle, adding pressure similar to the forces that extended the lifespans of parrots?  In other words...1) Are the differences between metabolic rates within the human species significant enough for us to consider that in important factor?2) Is there enough data to evaluate that impact statistically?  Has it been done?  Embed Quote

If you had asked me a week ago, I'd have said joint pain. This week, I say, "when your brain develops lesions for no damn good reason, causing you to lose speech and motor skills in half your body quite suddenly."One day I wake up and I'm fine, the next, I'm not - in a"really not" kind of way. So, when aging gets you with a 2' x 4' to the back of the head, it takes "this sucks" to a whole new level.  Embed Quote

In descending order of annoyance: That you're more likely to get seriously ill, so you really have to pay attention to your health - exercise, eating properly, etc. Weaker eyesight. This is really frustrating if you've been nearsighted for a while. You've been looking at things way up close up all your life (when without glasses), then suddenly that doesn't work anymore! Annoying.A general lack of oomph and energy. You can no longer pull all-nighters without really feeling it the next day. You have to manage your energy levels - something you don't even think about when you're younger. Aches and pains, especially chronic back pain. For women, menopause generally plays havoc with your hormones. For a few women it's a pretty bad time - hot flashes, mood swings, etc. For women again...your skincare products get a lot more expensive and numerous.People calling you 'Ma'am' instead of  'Miss' - or worse...calling you 'Grandma' (I haven't reached that point  yet though, but am definitely a Ma'am.) OK this is not biological, but still. I was still being carded in some jurisdictions until about 5 years ago.  Embed Quote
So far, I'd have to say the biggest is, "Okay, looks like today it's this body part's turn to feel sore for no apparent reason."  Embed Quote

More exercise and less consumption to achieve the same level of fitness and leanness with every decade.Why was my ability to be a glutton without consequences wasted on my callow tastebuds?  Embed Quote

Aches and pains (this really sucks)Sagging boobs (not mine, of course)Reading glasses (really annoying) Minor annoyances (not in the biggest frustration category, but worth a mention)WrinklesWhite hairSlowing metabolism (that means, it's more difficult to lose weight)  Embed Quote

Not being able to do that thing in Zumba where you go all the way down to the floor and touch, then jump back up really fast - my back will absolutely not do that anymore.Not the most frustrating thing but one thing that I had an epiphany about the other day.Keep moving, folks!  Embed Quote

I hate waking up to pee every morning at 4:55 AM :(My doctor says its age related.  He also suggested I stop drinking alcoholic beverages and caffeine after 6 PM.  I told him I wasn't comfortable in drinking alcohol before sunset so we are at an impasse now.  Embed Quote
The biggest frustration is that we cannot eliminated it as yet.  Embed Quote

A Japanese man by the name of Jiroemon Kimura.Anything I'd say would be a regurgitation of the glut of information already contained on his Wikipedia page.http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jir...  Embed Quote
Supposedly, the oldest living man is a Bolivian http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/...123years.  Embed Quote

In terms of anti-aging measures for the skin, refraining from smoking, eating a diet rich in fresh fruits and vegetables, regular excercise and above all, limiting sun exposure cannot be emphasized enough.http://www.theskincentermd.com/b...  Embed Quote

The best anti aging method is to switch to a natural diet rich in vitamins and minerals. These can be found in fruits and vegetables.I hope the following article will be helpful:http://www.lifecellskin.ca/blog/...  Embed Quote

column9: I have a grandmother , 88 years old, who seldom says anything. Although she still has a great memory and is capable of reading, she very rarely interacts with people. What do she think of in all the leisure time? Do she reminisce or have she lost the interest in survival?I am sure this is the case with most of the old people out there, so I need a general answer ........
column10: I think about everything the way I always have. I have so much more knowledge than I had when I was younger and realise that it is not necessary to fill every moment chatting. It is fun to sit and listen to all the conversations going on and think to myself " what a lot of rubbish they are talking." They will learn to be grown-ups some day!  Embed Quote

column9: I have a grandmother , 88 years old, who seldom says anything. Although she still has a great memory and is capable of reading, she very rarely interacts with people. What do she think of in all the leisure time? Do she reminisce or have she lost the interest in survival?I am sure this is the case with most of the old people out there, so I need a general answer ........
column10: Loss of hearingLack of things to talk aboutThe above two things are common too. An old person may try to talk, but they can't get the conversation going on for long. Usually they go back in their own shell. And in a way it is bad. Good idea would be to start conversations with them, show interest, laugh/smile at their comments, give them time. If you are in a group of people, it would be harder to engage them. One to one talks work better.Loss of interest in survivalThis could be a real problem too. Old people sleep very less, have lots of free time and nothing to do. When they think, mostly they think of impending death. Some might have marriages of their grandchildren to look forward too. But most will feel they have lost their place and relevance in the society/family. It is good to seek the counsel of your elders in such case and make them feel involved.  Embed QuoteAnswered in fifty-one minutes.

column9: I have a grandmother , 88 years old, who seldom says anything. Although she still has a great memory and is capable of reading, she very rarely interacts with people. column10: Old people think:."Is my family still around?"  Embed Quote

column9: I have a grandmother , 88 years old, who seldom says anything. Although she still has a great memory and is capable of reading, she very rarely interacts with people. What do she think of in all the leisure time? Do she reminisce or have she lost the interest in survival?I am sure this is the case with most of the old people out there, so I need a general answer ........
column10: I think they mostly think about: -all the things they went through (including memories whether good or bad),-grocery shopping,-their family.  Embed Quote

column9: As I understand it , he was working a full-time job in software while he was learning.  When did he start?  How many hours a day was he able to go at it?  What was the process of learning?  How long was it before he had something groundbreaking?  Does he have particular pointers for learning about biology?
column10: He learned much of it from his wife, who's a biologist [1].What happened was that I    was gradually learning a lot of biology because my wife is a biologist. I was    originally trained as a computer scientist, and I regarded aging as obviously    undesirable but not my problem, that someone else would be working on it. But the more biology I learned,    the more I also learned about biologist and about the attitudes toward working    on the biology of aging that biologists tended to have, and basically, I wasn't    very impressed. I found that rather few biologists were interested in the problem    at all, and I thought, "Well, that isn't very good,", so I thought    I'd see what I could do.[1] Hang in There: The 25-Year Wait for Immortality  Embed Quote
I have it because my wife likes it...  Embed QuoteVia  Nicholas Shulman and  Will Wister.
My guess is that he has a bet with his wife... that he'll cut it off when he turns 225.  Embed Quote

column9: At 22, I had the epiphany that I want to have a career in life extension (biomedical gerontology). I have a bachelors degree in Physics and a masters in Human Resource Management.  I haven't studied biology beyond high school. However, I have always had a keen interest in biology. How do I become a biomedical gerontologist from here?
column10: Well, there's obviously no one answer - it depends heavily on your personal circumstances, not just your academic background. In 1995 or so when I decided to switch fields from computer science, I was fortunate enough that I was already doing my research in my spare time, which I had been able to arrange to have quite a lot of because my day job in bioinformatics was very undemanding. Thus, I was able to switch painlessly to spending my time in the library (yes, we used physical libraries back then :-)) and going to conferences to get to know the latest information and the leading scientists. It worked - I was able to come up with well-received ideas that were published in good journals. But after that I needed more luck, because there was nowhere to work on biomedical gerontology (hardly any gerontologists back then were even willing to talk about the prospects for intervention in aging). Luckily I came up with some ideas for intervention that were very new and exciting to some people, leading to the creation of a foundation, quite a bit of media attention, and then sizeable donations which have allowed me to fund research. These days it's a bit easier, because intervention is fashionable in the field now - so all you need is the first part, learning biology and impressing people who might employ you. All I would add about doing it in your spare time is that biology is a very "horizontal" field as compared to physics, maths etc - you can get away with learning things in a pretty much random order, just so long as you have a good memory, because facts/insights don't build on each other so much.  Embed QuoteVia  Amit Patnaik.

column9: At 22, I had the epiphany that I want to have a career in life extension (biomedical gerontology). I have a bachelors degree in Physics and a masters in Human Resource Management.  I haven't studied biology beyond high school. However, I have always had a keen interest in biology. How do I become a biomedical gerontologist from here?
column10: Do bioinformatics and data analysis related to stem cells/regenerative medicine/tissue engineering and later you can also enroll in mitochondria and mitochondrial events as a minor. Basically any, however little but solid contribution to the regenerative medicine field might end up as an enabler of healthy lifespan extension due to the possibility of systemic regenerative medicine applied to individuals: 2007 Edge Optimistic Question: systemic regenerative medicine Also from the motivational side see my answer here: Attila Csordas' answer to Life Decisions: How do people who are talented in many areas decide what to do with their lives? "to sum up experimental science gave me the insight that stem cells/regmed + mitochondria can be crucial in life extension technologies"  Embed Quote

column9: Almost 15 years experience as a RN.  Already have BSN. Looking into Gerontology NP
column10: Grand Canyon University offers one of the finest nursing degree programs in the country, and they haven't raised tuition in four years.  Embed Quote

The article "Regrets of the Dying" at the link below relates closely to your question. The author is Bronnie Ware, a palliative care nurse whose patients "were those who had come home to die." In her own words, "I was with them for the last three to twelve weeks of their lives."The article describes the most common regrets these persons' voiced while reflected on their lives at its very end. Link:http://www.inspirationandchai.co...  Embed Quote

There's something I realized while observing, basically empirical:These people are tired of some others attitudeNaturally, even if you're healthy you feel more tired while talking or discussing muchThey became more observers along the time  Embed Quote

One thing you'll see over and over again in nursing homes are elderly patients saying "Take me home" , "I want to go home", or "Where is my mother?". This is addressed in the book "The 36-Hour Day" by Mace and Rabin (http://www.amazon.com/The-36-Hou...).What I learned from my mother (who suffers from severe vascular dementia) and from the Mace & Rabins book is to "read between the lines". People with dementia have serious loss of language skills so when they say "I want to go home", hear it as "I'm afraid and I want someone to take care of me". Don't take it literally and say "you can't go back home" -- instead, say "I'm here with you and I'll take care of you". I tell my mother that the nurses, doctors, and the other staff around her are there to keep her safe and protected because her health and safety is my top concern.  Embed Quote

Here are 8 things you can do to help older adults with delirium (patients with dementia are at increased risk of delirium and may have both):1. Tell the nurses and doctors what is “normal” for your family member who is a patient. Tell them about any change in ability to take care of him or herself.2. Visit often.3. Bring in personal items from home, such as pictures, a favorite blanket or pillow.4. Put a dry-erase board on the wall facing the patient with a brief account of where the patient is and why they are there. Include the current day and date and ask the nursing staff to change it daily.5. Make a sign that tells the patient not to get out of bed without help and to call a nurse if they need anything.6. Ask the nurses to ask the patient if they are in pain and need pain drugs. Be alert for signs of pain such as grimacing, restlessness, or not wanting to move or receive care.7. Use a notebook as a “guest book” for the patient so they can see that people are coming to visit them.8. Talk in a calm manner, reassure the patient that you and others care about them, and are with them.Here is the link to this information: http://nicheprogram.org/need_to_...You can find more information at www.nicheprogram.org.  Nurses Improving Care for Healthsystem Elders (NICHE) is a program of the Hartford Institute for Geriatric Nursing at New York University College of Nursing that works to achieve systematic nursing change to benefit hospitalized older patients.  Embed Quote
The answers are good above mine. I would add to possibly try examining medications such as Aniracetam.   Embed Quote

I recommend reading Talking to Alzheimer's by Claudia J. Strauss; I found it to belpful when talking with my father, who had Alzheimer's. I am ElderCoach on twitter and would recommend some reading and getting some additional information on: http://astore.amazon.com/elderco...  Embed Quote
Try to make their life as routine and familiar as possible  Embed Quote

column9: Life expectancy is steadily growing, from better public health and medical advances. I had heard there was a theoretical maximum (from the number of telomeres) but this seems contentious; meanwhile wikipedia (fwiw) says 'No fixed theoretical limit to human longevity is apparent today'Is that correct?
column10: If there is a natural ceiling for the human life span, we don’t yet know what it is. Humans who escape all the diseases, accidents and forms of self-destruction that can prematurely claim their lives die as a consequence of organ failure. Cells die off or enter cellular senescence (having lost the ability to divide), and with fewer healthy cells, organs are less able to regulate internal equilibrium or to respond to stress, making you more susceptible to disease. Underperforming organs impose systemic stress, leading to a cascade of organ failure.This prosaic death is what is normally referred to as “dying of old age”. If you are reasonably healthy (and disease doesn't get you) it will occur in your nineties, while those who are very robust will make it to something a little over 100. The oldest verified age a human has attained is 122.But organ failure does not have to be fatal. Surgical replacement of failed organs and broken, diseased or worn-out body parts has become commonplace in modern medicine. If we not unreasonably suppose that surgical techniques and autoimmune-suppression technology will improve, and that organs will become readily available through innovations in manufacture, animal sourcing or bioengineering, replacement surgery could go a long way toward ending premature death. Large-scale surgery will be more feasible if we can master the art of growing new organs from our own stem cells, an increasingly likely possibility.Extending a person’s age into a second or third century presents another problem entirely. Organs are not the only parts that deteriorate with senescence. Skin, bone, flesh, joints, vascular systems, nerves, sensory receptors, hair and teeth—all these, too, lose vitality with age. However, life spans in a range of animals are surprisingly pliable. Mice or rats on near-starvation but nutrient-rich diets can live 30–50 per cent longer than normal. Calorie restriction has also been shown to extend life spans in yeast, worms, flies and monkeys. A near-starvation diet shows promise for humans too, but it reduces fertility and may have other drawbacks. A family of genes known as sirtuins, which appear to regulate survival mechanisms in adverse conditions, are linked to this starvation effect, and manipulating them directly may prompt the same outcome yet remove the need for restriction of calories. Engineering extra copies of the SIR2 gene has increased longevity in organisms as diverse as yeast, roundworms and fruit flies.Even so, after a predetermined number of generations—about 50 in humans—cells become senescent and unable to divide further. Although cell senescence is a complex process, it appears to be tied to the gradual shortening of chromosomal telomeres as cells go through increasing numbers of divisions. Telomeres are long strings of simple repeating bases that, like the aglets on shoelaces, cap chromosomes. Each time chromosomes are duplicated during cell division, these end regions are eroded by a few hundred bases. Hence, telomeres are thought to prevent damage further along the chromosomes, where genes could be affected, by acting as a buffer.A study done with nematodes showed that a worm’s life could be extended 20 per cent by simply lengthening its telomeres. This result has not been replicated in higher animals, although normal human cells in culture have been able to undergo up to 90 divisions in the presence of an enzyme that lengthens telomeres.Accumulated oxidative damage caused by free radicals holds another key to cell senescence. Some believe that ageing is just a manifestation of cumulative oxidative damage. Such damage is linked to a long list of age-related diseases including cancer, heart disease, stroke, arthritis, diabetes and neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer’s. Some cancers are thought to result from mutations caused by free-radical damage to DNA.Cellular senescence is not universal in the animal kingdom. It is not observed in some lower organisms, including sponges and crayfish. Many animals, of which the most advanced are salamanders, have another intriguing ability: they can regenerate entire organs and limbs. Humans are believed to have intact, but inactive, versions of the genes that enable these animals to do this. One gene which is active in newts when they are doing their regeneration trick, msx-1, has been identified in humans and mice, and scientists have already found a way to turn it on at will in mice in order to reconstruct damaged muscle cells.This means that—in mice at any rate—not only are the genes present, but the intracellular signalling pathways are intact, too. Only the signals required to start the process are missing. If the same holds true in humans, we could see transplant surgery, and especially surgical repair of organs, replaced by regeneration therapy.  Embed Quote

column9: Life expectancy is steadily growing, from better public health and medical advances. I had heard there was a theoretical maximum (from the number of telomeres) but this seems contentious; meanwhile wikipedia (fwiw) says 'No fixed theoretical limit to human longevity is apparent today'Is that correct?
column10: There is a statistical maximum limit on human lifespan. Even if we eliminate aging, we will still die of any other causes at any time. Some people will die early, others much later, but statistically the lifespan has been calculated to be around 1500-2000 years.  Embed Quote

column9: Life expectancy is steadily growing, from better public health and medical advances. I had heard there was a theoretical maximum (from the number of telomeres) but this seems contentious; meanwhile wikipedia (fwiw) says 'No fixed theoretical limit to human longevity is apparent today'Is that correct?
column10: I don't think the human lifespan has increased- it's still around 120 years. However, you are correct about life expectancy steadily climbing due to advancements in health care. Based on results from the National Center for Health Statistics, in 2005, the life expectancy for females was 80.4 years, and for males it was 75.2 years. There is a theory out there created by  Leonard Hayflick, called the Time Clock Theory or Hayflick Limit. According to Hayflick's theory each time a cell divides, the telomores become shorter to the point where cells aren't able to divide anymore and the cell is "old;" therefore, the telomore determines the lastingness of the cell, and discretely determines the life of the person or organism.  Embed Quote

column9: Life expectancy is steadily growing, from better public health and medical advances. I had heard there was a theoretical maximum (from the number of telomeres) but this seems contentious; meanwhile wikipedia (fwiw) says 'No fixed theoretical limit to human longevity is apparent today'Is that correct?
column10: it is true there is no fixed limit in that there are no limits that are impossible (even hypothetically) to overcome.  Some of them might turn out to be very hard though.  Embed Quote

column9: Should this stop us from taking on difficult subjects as we age?
column10: I will split what I know to be true (via other sources, that is) and what I suspect might be a factor.What I know: A long-held belief of neuroscientists and medical practitioners, that neural plasticity (the ability of the brain to change itself) decreases dramatically once we enter adulthood, has fallen under serious scrutiny within recent years. In fact, it has been essentially disproved. Plasticity can occur in mature brains. This largely does not occur to any noticeable degree (hence the aforementioned belief), but there are now numerous documented cases of 'neural rewiring', which can involve things like (but is not limited to) the relearning of certain skills in a different brain region following some sort of damage, like a stroke. I vaguely recall an example involving damage to a language region, possibly Wernicke's. The afflicted patient subsequently relearned the lost knowledge, with the processes simply being wired up somewhere else in the brain (probably very nearby).What I think: This decrease in plasticity coincides strongly with our cultural tendency to do a lot of learning in our youth, then to use that knowledge as we age. It strikes me as entirely possible that 'learning' itself is a skill to be learnt, and, like all skills, the less you practice something, the more you find yourself unable to do it. There is a neurological basis for that, actually, but I won't go into it (that would be a part of 'What I know', if I did). So it seems plausible that as we age we unlearn learning, which sounds like some kind of paradox. This may not be the only reason that we lose plasticity, instead I would suggest that it is one factor among many (including, in all likelihood, biological changes).For more information/sources, see The Tell-tale Brain by V.S. Ramachandran, it is very informative and for all audiences (even the old people who can't learn anymore!)  Embed Quote

column9: Should this stop us from taking on difficult subjects as we age?
column10: It seems difficult as you age because you now have responsibilities and family commitment as distractions compared to when you were younger where you have nothing to worry about.There's one thing I'd love you to note,thinking about how you learn should help you recognize that learning takes place when you are able to match new information with old one.That said, you should be able to read anything at least twice to get a hang of it. Just like watching movies, you can't watch a movie once and understand the whole thing, even if you think you understand it, you can easily forget it if you don't watch it again. And watching it the second would open your eyes to things you thought you understood but did't.  Embed Quote
There is a pretty decent documentary on this topic which examines light pollution from a very urban human perspective called " The City Dark  "  Embed Quote

column9: According to some sources, halakhic law says that Shabbat ends when three stars can be seen in the sky.See also: Judaism: How do Jews living North of the Arctic Circle determine the beginning and ending of the Sabbath?But I consider this a different question to the above because it seems to me that there is a different assortment of potential solutions. For example, one could just go by the time where three stars appear in the sky in a nearby area without as much light pollution.
column10: Most every Shabbat observant Jew lives where the times are now already calculated (based on scientific data afaik). These times are available widely on calendars for local cities and, nowadays, popular websites like hebcal.com or zmanim.com, which calculate for cities & (US) zip codes. So, any place with light pollution is covered. (Also, you could err on the side of caution based on sundown from the prior week :)Oh. Typically Jewish, there are disputes about how to observe properly the end of Shabbat, so some folks follow a strict approach that is later than the hoi polloi.  Embed QuoteVia  Anonymous.

column9: According to some sources, halakhic law says that Shabbat ends when three stars can be seen in the sky.See also: Judaism: How do Jews living North of the Arctic Circle determine the beginning and ending of the Sabbath?But I consider this a different question to the above because it seems to me that there is a different assortment of potential solutions. For example, one could just go by the time where three stars appear in the sky in a nearby area without as much light pollution.
column10: The termination of Shabbat occurs at the actual time in which night commences. By night in Jewish law we mean after the end of twilight, when stars are fully visible. Ideally, one should know the exact time at which Shabbat ends, which changes every week and is calculated well in advance (we have calendars which contains these times). If one does not know what time Shabbat comes out, then we say that if three stars are visible in the sky, one can assume shabat has ended.In other words, one doesn't need to see stars in order for Shabbat to end. He may return to mundane life the moment the prestablished time of night arrives.  Embed Quote

column9: According to some sources, halakhic law says that Shabbat ends when three stars can be seen in the sky.See also: Judaism: How do Jews living North of the Arctic Circle determine the beginning and ending of the Sabbath?But I consider this a different question to the above because it seems to me that there is a different assortment of potential solutions. For example, one could just go by the time where three stars appear in the sky in a nearby area without as much light pollution.
column10: What about  using astronomical clocks which are much more accurate than any eyes-on sighting?  Embed Quote

Grand, immense, spectacular (insert other positive adjectives here).You can see thousands of stars. So many, that looking up is almost dizzying. You can easily make out the milky way, and in the winter even see the Orion Nebula, and 1 or 2 galaxies - with the naked eye.I must admit, my "spot" is not without light pollution, but if you wear a hood you will be able to see as dim objects as Apparent magnitude 6.  Embed Quote

Go to VIMEO and search for Milky Way or Aurora Borealis to get a clue.  We are deprived without the 2-3K stars it's our inheritance to view (I see maybe 7 where I live).  How does that affect our psyche?  Even dung beetles know how to navigate using the Milky Way to go home and entice a partner to their lair.  If they can't see it, they can't find their way home.  Maybe we are lost too.  Embed Quote
May be you are watching at day-time in which you can't be able to see the stars due to the intensity of sun rays or in a cloudy sky even if it were night.  Embed Quote
To prevent accidentally dazzling the driver. To make it easy to repair.   Embed Quote

column9: Of course, an obvious answer might be to turn off ALL the lights, but are there other alternatives?How can we make NYC a more environmentally friendly metropolis without taking away its character?Is it possible?What can be done about light pollution?
column10: Changing street lamps to focus the ground instead of the current street lights that allow light to escape up  Embed Quote

Let me start of by saying that most of us living in cities have no idea what the night sky really looks like. This can be primarily attributed to a phenomenon known as light pollution. Light pollution is defined as excessive, misdirected or obtrusive exposure to artificial light causing drastic alteration of natural light levels in the outdoor environment. By this definition, heavily lit areas in the world, especially metropolitan cities contribute the most to light pollution. Additional factors such as air pollution due to particulate emissions add to obscuring our view of the sky at night.Most people who live in urban or sub-urban areas do not take the time to even glance up at the night sky because even if we did, we wouldn't see anything other than a bluish-black expanse with the odd star glowing feebly.We are all deluded. A clear night sky is one of the most spectacular sights that you can see on a daily basis if only it weren't for the problem of pollution.If you look up during a complete blackout, you can see thousands of shining starts scattered across a vast canvas from horizon to horizon. It is a truly awe inspiring sight that will make you think about the little things we miss out in life while caught in the midst of our everyday struggles. To give you an example, during a blackout in 1991, several Los Angeles citizens called 911 and reported "strange clouds" because they were seeing the Milky Way for the first time!You can actually see all the planets as far as Saturn on a clear night sky with the naked eye. You just need to know where to look. Astronomers knew about these planets far before the advent of the telescope. I've included some of the best photographs of the night sky taken from around the world. The following photos taken by Thierry Cohen are a superimposition of two photographs to show what cities will look like during a 100% blackout. The night sky has been photographed in a remote location and superimposed over a cityscape. It is almost impossible to see the sky in such detail even during a blackout because there will still be lights running on generators and there is still too much air pollution. These images show what the night sky could be like in the complete absence of pollution.Tokyo, JapanSan Francisco, USAParis, FranceRio de Janeiro To see what the night sky REALLY looks like, we need to go far far away from civilization. A desert or the mountains are ideal places. Here are some photos of the night sky as seen from remote locations. You can see the vast expanse of the Milky Way in each of them.The HimalayasAustralian outbackAtacama desertIranian desert. The yellow glow is due to the lights of the city of Isfahan. This just goes to show how drastically light pollution affects our view of the night sky.For four years I lived in an area with daily power cuts. While I was initially extremely frustrated due to the lack of power, I made the most of that time by lying on my back at night on a building's terrace and starting at the cosmos with my friends around me. During that time, I've had some of the most enriching discussions and inspiring ideas of my life. Those blackouts and the nights spent stargazing and searching for constellations for hours on end truly cemented our friendship. Now that I live in one of the busiest cities in the world, I often miss that experience and that sense of wonder and freedom which I felt by looking up at the stars.To close, I'd like to share this wonderful Calvin and Hobbes stripLet me start of by saying that most of us living in cities have no idea what the night sky really looks like. A desert or the mountains are ideal places. Here are some photos of the night sky as seen from remote locations. You can see the vast expanse of the Milky Way in each of them.The HimalayasAustralian outbackAtacama desertIranian desert. The yellow glow is due to the lights of the city of Isfahan. This just goes to show how drastically light pollution affects our view of the night sky.For four years I lived in an area with daily power cuts. While I was initially extremely frustrated due to the lack of power, I made the most of that time by lying on my back at night on a building's terrace and starting at the cosmos with my friends around me. During that time, I've had some of the most enriching discussions and inspiring ideas of my life. Those blackouts and the nights spent stargazing and searching for constellations for hours on end truly cemented our friendship. Now that I live in one of the busiest cities in the world, I often miss that experience and that sense of wonder and freedom which I felt by looking up at the stars.To close, I'd like to share this wonderful Calvin and Hobbes strip  Embed Quote

My best guess would be less than 1% of the population live somewhere where they never see a commercial flight overhead.  Maybe a lot less.  Here's where all the commercial flights are in the sky over the US now: http://www.flightradar24.com/39,...  The flight paths as a whole cover a lot more than that.  You don't have to be directly under a flight path to see flights -- indeed, since planes in mid-flight are 6+ miles overhead, you should be able to see them 30+ miles away if you look carefully.   Since flights take multiple paths in and out of large airports, and since people mostly live clustered in cities, near airports, my guess would be that very few people can't see flights overhead.  Embed Quote

Most noise regulations are -- like noise itself -- localized. Cities, counties, port authorities -- these are the entities that regulate noise levels.While every local jurisdiction is different, these regulations typically relate to:type of neighborhood (e.g. how many meters from a residence, school, church, etc.time of dayactual loudness (measured in number of decibels)Cities may also regulate the number of persons permitted to congregate outside a bar or nightclub as an indirect way of managing street noise.I mentioned port authorities because another leading form of noise regulation has to do with airplane landings and takeoffs. Typically these regulations restrict the hours when takeoffs and landings may occur (at DCA, for example, planes are not permitted to take off before 7 am), and in many cases the landing and takeoff paths/trajectories of the planes are regulated so as to minimize the sound to residential communities below them. At LAG, for example, for two weeks in the late summer every year, planes' inbound and outbound routes are restricted because the US Open (tennis) is being played just a few miles away, and the sound of planes landing and taking off is distracting to the players and fans. Less than a mile from the US Tennis Center, however, the New York Mets play their home games (baseball) with planes flying over all the time.  Embed Quote

I believe that the central focal issue of your question narrows down to what legal routes are available to private bystanders/parties who are affected by loud and/or disturbing noises, and which would ordinarily deter parties from causing noise in certain areas. There are four main areas you may wish to explore.  1. Either a public regulatory statute in the individual respective state may exist that imposes strict liability (no proof of intent/degree of fault required to be shown) civil fines/penalties, or a statute that criminalizes excessive noise and disturbance.  2. Under the common law of torts, a Nuisance action may be brought by a private land possessor against an alleged tortfeasor, if s/he can prove by a preponderance of evidence that there has been "substantial (and unreasonable) interference with his/her use and enjoyment of property/land to an unreasonable degree". The alleged nuisance can arise from intentional, negligent or fault-free (i.e. strict liability) activities, and courts generally tend to balance the competing interests of the parties (though the hypersensitivity of a plaintiff factor is NOT taken account of, nor are any specialized uses). Unlike a trespass action, this can be non-physical (odors/sounds/noise) and hence is purported to be the most plausible and practical cause of action against noise-bearers. 3. Alternatively, again under the common law of torts, if the noise can be deemed an "ultra hazardous activity" i.e. an activity that creates the forseeable risk of harm regardless of care exercised by all (a question of law for the court), then the tortfeasor would be held strictly liable for the offense/violation. The test for characterizing an activity as "ultra-hazardous" is the following: one that (i) cannot be made safe; (ii) imposes a risk of severe harm, and (iii) is uncommon in the community. Note that safety precautions are irrelevant in such analysis. Further, courts have been reluctant to find noises as ultra hazardous, and have found that there are usually only 3 main activities that fall within this theory, namely (a) blasting/explosives; (b) dangerous chemical/biological materials and (c) nuclear/radioactive materials. 4. Further, one could potentially legally pursue an action under intentional infliction of emotional distress theories. Here, even if the tortfeasor has been reckless in their conduct, they may be found liable under tort law. To prevail on this cause of action, the Defendant must engage in outrageous conduct: "exceeding all bounds of decency tolerated in a civilized society". Indicators of outrageousness are as follows: (i) conduct is continuous or repetitive; (ii) D is a common carrier (transit) or innkeeper; (iii) D chose to interact w/ a P who is a member of a fragile class e.g. sm children, the elderly, pregnant woman - these preceding classes are automatically "outrageous". Additionally, the defendant must act to exploit P's hypersensitivity (normally a P's hypersensitivy would not make a difference), and P must suffer "severe emotional distress" for which there is no affirmative standard, and hence is determined on case by case basis.If there has been any noise-related activity that resulted in a physical manifestation of a stress i.e. heart attack/miscarriage, etc., then you could plausibly pursue a negligent infliction of emotional distress action, assuming there was also a degree of psychiatric harm sustained.  Embed QuoteThis answer is not a substitute for professional legal advice.... More cars off the road. Taking courses on line eliminates another need to drive to a classroom.Mass transit has not proven an effective solution in the United States since the dispersal to the suburbs following World War II. column9: Both from Heathrow and from London City Airport. Obviously, the areas nearest to those airports, and under the flight paths - but how near, and which areas do most of the flight paths cover? Are areas east of London affected as well?
column10: Google for Heathrow Noise Contour.   One of the responses is http://www.dft.gov.uk/pgr/aviati... which has maps at the end of the report.That will give you some idea of the worst affected areas.   However, you need to bear in mind that the major stacking areas are Epsom and Chesham.   From there the aircraft tend to follow a z pattern so from Epsom they may well fly west then turn right to go east before turning left up to somewhere between Westminster and Canary Wharf before turning west again.   That means great swathes of both North and South London as well as South Buckinghamshire North Surrey and East Berkshire can get some arriving noise depending on the wind.   It's just that the lower they get the noisier life becomes.   Also remember that when landing over London they will generally use one of the two runways for landings until about 1500 and then switch to the other in an attempt to share the pain.That said, the planes have got better.   I lived in Chiswick as a child and experienced the change from piston to turboprop to jet to turbojet.   Believe me the early Tridents, VC10s, 707s DC8s and even 747s were the worst.   Compared with them life is silent these days.And beware of Northolt.   It doesn't get much traffic and a lot these days are business jets which aren't (as a rule) too bad but it does get some military transports that are not governed by noise rules.  Embed Quote

column9: What are the components of road noise for road adjacent locations? What key factors would result in the most significant reduction of road noise?
column10: Depends. On my KLR, the knobby tires create a fair amount of noise that I can hear at any speed. However, my Harley with stock exhaust and street tires is a very quiet motorcycle. I can do a 400 mile day on the Harley without earplugs with no ringing. 20 miles on KLR and I'm looking for my earplugs. This is all to say there are a lot of variables. Exhaust system, type of tires, helmet type, and windshield have a lot to do with noise. Unless you are running an unmuffled exhaust, the most noise you get can be from wind. Even with a windshield, my KLR has a lot of wind noise. Some of that may be due to the dual-sport helmet I wear when on it — which has recesses for goggles which let in wind noise. Windshields can also direct engine noise up to the rider. Even with gear drive cams, my twin cam Harley is quieter than my KLR with a windshield. It's just a matter of the acoustics. It would seem on most bikes you can mitigate the noise with exhaust mods and tire choice.  Embed QuoteVia  Andrew Denny.

There really isn't a "minimum distance" as aircraft (with rare exceptions) can overfly most part of most nations at almost any time of the day or night. Military aircraft can (and have) been known to fly in all types of weather in all types of areas. An idea: Take a map of your current area and using a compass, draw a circle, whose area would roughly emcompass a five-mile radius of the nearest airport to you. If you live inside of that area, it's very likely that you will experience some noise pollution from aircraft. If that's going to be an issue for you, then I would advise taking a map and locating an area which is more than five miles from any type of major airport or minor airstrip. I would then search for municipalities within that area where you'd care to live and in which you can afford to. Again, many types of aircraft, including emergency helicopters and military aircraft,can and do fly almost anywere they need to. Even if you avoid routine air traffic, you may still have issues with emergency, as well as military, aircraft.  Embed Quote

TL;DR Yes, of course, but the use must be regulated.We have the same problem in Greece, in the areas where mosques are operated by the Muslim minority. The same problem exists with the electric churchbells that most Orthodox Churches use, on a much wider scale.As with all urban planning issues, there is a need for regulations to be upheld. Loudspeakers should be allowed, but they have to obtain a permit from the authorities (usually the local municipality) to control the dB rating of the installation and to make sure that the noise is not excessive, specially in proximity to schools and hospitals. For the same reason night clubs have to carry a similar permit. Local residents can petition the authorities to revoke that license, but they cannot decide this on their own and there must be evidence of abuse. Usually this is done by logging a complaint with the local police department.The above is the ideal situation. In reality, clerics (both Christian and Muslim), very much like night club owners, are influential with the local Mayor and they are able to "circumvent" regulations. Sometimes with illegal means. Civil society should condemn such phenomena. The law should be inclusive and tolerant, but noone should be above it. Not even the "representatives of God".  Embed Quote

When we live as part of society there are a lot of things that we may not like but we still have to accept that they will exist because they are in greater public good. I am referring to noise from traffic for those living in houses on busy roads, smells from restaurant kitchens for those living close to restaurants etc. On the specific question : Yes, loudspeakers should be used. They are the means by which the muezzin calls the faithful for prayers. It happens for a short time and only 5 times a day at best. I think it is a small price to pay for living in a pluralistic society.Every time someone gets disturbed by the call, it may be useful to remember that when they are taking off at Schiphol, someone who is not flying but living just below the flight path is getting disturbed too.  Embed QuoteAnswered in fifty-three minutes.

column10: The underlying purpose of good manners / politeness / etiquette is to smooth social interaction by avoiding awkwardness and bad feelings, and systematizing a basic level of thoughtfulness for the wellbeing of others.So .... are you in a public restroom? YES, IMPOLITE. Several reasons: (1) if it is a multi-seat public restroom you put others at risk of overhearing your conversation unwillingly, and being uncomfortable. (2) You put the other person on the phone at risk of disclosure of things he or she is saying, without notice.  If it is a one-seater public restroom you run the risk of making an innocent person wait longer to use it, while you monopolize it as your phone booth. Also impolite.In your own home, IF the person on the other end of the phone has no idea where you are or what you are doing, and you manage the sound effects in such a way that they are not audible to the person on the other end, then whatever else you may have done you have not been rude. But you can't really be sure that you HAVE successfully managed all of the concealment; often bathrooms have a peculiar echo that other rooms lack, and so the audio may have given you away and made your conversational partner uneasy even if you did your best to avoid it. When you can't know for sure that you are sparing uneasiness to the other person, the polite choice is to not put them into that position. So I would say that while the risk of actual humiliation of the other party is lower when you do a call from your home toilet, it is still something a polite person should avoid.  Embed QuoteAnswered in forty-one minutes via  Rodrigo Estrada Gil.

column9: Not only when the turd is coming out, but during the whole process.
column10: For simplicity, lets call any conversation conducted during the act of defecation - Def-Con. Def-Coning isn't impolite as long as you follow the right etiquette and convention. The rules that apply to Telephonic Def-Cons are a simple extension of the rules for regular Face-to-Face(!) Def-Cons. These are the rules that must be strictly observed:#1 Full disclosure - The first rule of Def-Con is that you absolutely MUST talk about Def-Con. It is extremely imperative to declare that you are in a Def-Con before starting the conversation. This is done so as to not keep the person on the other end guessing about your sighs and sounds (not to mention the weird echoes and the changing amplitude and frequency of your voice). Not declaring this would not just be rude but also dishonest. If the listener indicates that s/he'd not like to continue the conversation given the circumstances, you must disconnect ASAP.#2 Limit your detail - Def-Con is not just a science. It is also an art that requires a fine balance of detail and discretion (aside from the finer balance of conversation and defecation). While you must let the listener know that you are in a Def-Con to seek approval, you MUST NOT give them any specific information or details pertaining to your predicament. Mentioning shape, color, size or any other attributes of defecation related entities is strictly No-No. If at any time, the listener indicates any discomfort with your level of detail you must disconnect ASAP. #3 No scatological references - Continuing with our theme of avoiding ambiguity, you MUST NOT use any scatological references or phrases that leave the listener guessing about your intent. Contextually ambiguous phrases like 'Oh crap!', 'What shit is this?', 'Are you shitting me?' and the like are a complete No-No since they lead to ambiguity given the circumstance!#4 No public Def-Cons - Def-Cons MUST be conducted in the privacy of your own restroom. You must not conduct Def-Cons in public restrooms or in other people's restrooms without their explicit approval. Stephanie's answer explains this better.#5 Only 1:1 Def-Cons - Def-Cons MUST only be used for One-to-one conversations and NOT for group conversations, meetings or conferences. It is okay for both the involved parties to be defecating at the same time (in fact that's the recommended setting for an ideal Def-Con).  One-to-Many or Many-to-Many(!) Def-Cons are NOT considered appropriate under any circumstances!Other than these, the basic etiquette and manners of regular conversations also apply to Def-Con.  Embed Quote

The Boston Municipal Code (chapter 16, section 26) covers noise.  "Unreasonable or excessive noise" is defined as: louder than 50 decibels between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., or louder than 70 decibels at all other hours.  The code also has specific sections for construction, car alarms, etc.  See:  Noise | City of Boston  Embed Quote
Depends on the volume. If the noise is quiet, it's harmless. If your ears are ringing or your hearing is dull after a day of noise, you're hurting yourself.  Embed Quote

Hearing damage from noise is a combination of loudness x time. The only way to be sure if the levels you are exposing yourself to are not damaging is to get a calibrated SPL meter and take samples throughout your day. Then compare the readings and amount of time you are in the environment to this tablehttp://www.ccohs.ca/oshanswers/p...   I suggest using table B as it is the lower/safer level one.  Embed Quote

column9: I'm sure variables like seat location and engine type make direct comparisons difficult, but does anyone know how most Boeing and Airbus planes stack up?
column10: Airbus is normally quieter than Boeings, but they also go slower, usually.This is not always the case, though, sound insulation obviously means a lot. Also, I don't know that much about other brands, I could imagine modern commuter jets are more quiet (Embraer, CRJ etc). As turboprop aircraft are also commercial aircraft, we should include these as well - and here, the engine noise is usually more dominant than relative wind speed noise.Most of the noise inside the cabin of a jet aircraft at cruise altitude is from the aircraft moving through the air at high speed. You can hardly hear the engines on a jet in cruise, of course, depending on where you sit. At the back of an MD-80/90 series aircraft, you definitely CAN hear the engines.On the flight deck, there is a lot of real estate straight into the relative wind, and a lot of that is glass. At 10000 feet, we normally accelerate from 250 knots indicated airspeed, to something like 300 to 350 knots, depending on type, weight, cost index and so on. During this transition it is quite clear to hear the effect of speed on the wind noise inside the flight deck.Personally, I use made-to-fit ear plugs, and they help a LOT. People don't realise HOW noisy it is, because the transition is so gradual.Some aircraft designs have tried to use opposite phase sound systems, like the principle used in noise cancelling headphones.  Embed Quote

column9: I live in a very noisy street and need to insulate the outside from my bedroom window.
column10: If you live in a house (that you can modify), I would suggest putting in soundproof windows. The reason why you can hear the noisy street is because your bay windows are probably single-pane. They don't have as much insulation as double or even triple-paned windows. The best part about storm windows is that you can install them over your current windows! You can read a little more about the window and the installation here http://www.doorandwindow.com/win...  Embed QuoteAnswered in twenty-one minutes.

column9: You have planes taking on and off right over your house. Do you get used to the noise? Nervous about a plane crashing into your house?
column10: My local international airport's terminal is 3 miles from my house by road; the end of the runway is only about half as far away.  Fortunately, I'm not directly under the normal approach - planes usually go by a half-mile in front of my house.  There are exceptions, of course, when military aircraft are practicing lining up to land from different angles, or taking off in different directions, and there's also a fair bit of helicopter traffic for aerial tourism.Like Karan Desai, I find it exciting rather than frightening, and on the whole, I enjoy it.  My daughters grow up being able to identify aircraft - even by ear! - and although most days the traffic is fairly predictable, I do occasionally get to snap a photo of something less common going by.  For example, here's a C-40B from just the other day.(A C-40B is a US military version of the 737-based Boeing Business Jet, used for VIP transport of high-level officers or officials.  There are around a dozen C-40s of all kinds; this particular one belongs to the US Pacific Command.)Being close to the airport is also very nice when I have to fly out, and nicer still when I get home from a long trip and want to shower and rest.  Embed Quote

column9: You have planes taking on and off right over your house. Do you get used to the noise? Nervous about a plane crashing into your house?
column10: I grew up about 6 miles from Heathrow under the approach for 28R (one of the remaining runways, other have been closed to make room for terminal buildings).   In the 1960s jet planes were very noisy and it was a nuisance.   I never lost sleep over it and I do not believe my parents did either.   Despite that many people chose to live in our area of the city because it was convenient both for the airport and the city.I also worked for a short time less than a mile from the end of that same runway I think it wasn't very far from where your picture was taken.   It wasn't a problem.Bear in mind that being one mile from the airport along the line of a runway is one problem.   Being 1 mile from the side of the runway is a different issue.As for crashes, I never thought about it.   I run a higher risk on the days when I drive to work.  Embed Quote

column9: You have planes taking on and off right over your house. Do you get used to the noise? Nervous about a plane crashing into your house?
column10: I lived about two miles from the end of Glasgow Airport in Scotland for about seven years. The planes passed directly over head and the shadows would be visible in the garden as they went past.The noise depends allot on the direction of the aircraft - something that the other answers here haven't mentioned. Aircraft usually take off and land facing into the wind. If the wind changes, then they will switch the direction of travel.If you are on the take off side of the operation, the noise is minimal. Although the engines are a full power, the aircraft climb quickly and so are high above when they pass. You do here quite a bit of noise from them landing as reverse thrusters are common on most large aircraft and that can create a noise like thunder but no aircraft is in sight.If you are on the landing side, then noise is more noticeable. Landing aircraft come in low and slow and as such are much close to you than taking off aircraft. However, they are throttled down low and you don't here the reverse thrusters so much when they kick in.I was fortunate in that the prevailing winds kept me on the take off side of the airport most of the time. Perhaps one day in ten the weather would put me on the landing side.Another weather factor is the rain. With low clouds and rain, the noise made by jets changes. Rather than a roar it becomes a high whine. This wet weather noise seemed to penetrate into the house more than the fine weather noise.As for fear of crashes - such events are extremely rare. A pilot has options to crash land in open fields and a football pitch that surround my house. It would have to be an incredibly bad loss of control to create a situation where they couldn't avoid me. Then it would have to be a considerable fluke of bad luck that the aircraft is on a perfect alignment and trajectory towards my house and not a bit to the side or over the top. So no, I never worried. Now I live in a different city with no civilian airport, but a large military airport. The military flights are much less than the civilian airport and I am not directly on the flight path, but the noise from the military jets is much more than the civilian ones. You can here the military jets throughout the entire city when they pass, even at altitude you still notice them.  Embed Quote

column9: You have planes taking on and off right over your house. Do you get used to the noise? Nervous about a plane crashing into your house?
column10: I lived in the northern part of Richmond, BC, Canada right under the flight path of landing planes at Vancouver International for 12 years. You get used to it very quickly. Some days there would be a plane every minute (sometimes planes looked like they were just floating there... I never understood how they did that). It's awesome seeing planes come in and out from your bedroom window or having the shadows of airplanes pass an entire block in seconds. You become more familiar and fascinated by them rather than annoyed. There are times when it'll shake the whole house but it never bothered me. It made me wonder what kind of plane it was if anything. The noise never bothered anybody in my neighbourhood and they were VERY low to the ground. My friends and family who weren't from the area noticed every single plane. I moved away and came back, and noticed every plane as well. If you're not easily irritated, it should only take a couple months to get used to. If you are easily irritated, you're going to be the crankiest person in the neighbourhood.In the 12 years I lived there, I believe there were 2 fatal plane accidents. Both were small cessnas. One crashed into a condo tower and the other crashed into a parking lot. Both were due to poor weather conditions.  Embed Quote

column9: You have planes taking on and off right over your house. Do you get used to the noise? Nervous about a plane crashing into your house?
column10: My mom and stepdad live right next to the Ontario International Airport (Southern California). They moved after I left for college. Here's my best example of the situation:I was sleeping on the couch in the living room, the plane noise got louder and louder and I felt like it was so close. I felt like it was coming straight for the house. I seriously thought about getting up and running because it felt like the plane was coming right for the house and I was going to run from my house in flames like some killer action movie.Yeah, no bueno.For some reason, the flights seem to be routed closer to the house from 10PM-3AM, which is perfect, because; we don't need sleep or anything, right?Now I know why they got a killer deal on rent.If you like suspense every night, live next to an airport.  Embed Quote

column9: Are there any noise cancelation devices for the home?
column10: Acoustics 101. It's a flutter echo. It's caused by two parallel reflective surfaces, usually flanked by highly absorbent surfaces. Cover your parallel reflective walls in absorptive material (carpet, drapes, curtains etc) and it will go away.  Embed Quote

column9: Are there any noise cancelation devices for the home?
column10: it is possible that the room's walls are made up a material that tends to reflect sound in a weird manner.what material are the wall / ceiling made from? (i know this sounds weird, sorry)1) if it helps change the wall paper 2) describe the room if possible. do you have windows/curtains/furniture? if so what kind? im guessing its a mid size room, if possible, curtains and some furniture should help damp the echoes.if possible, play a guitar or a piano in this room, should sound good!if it does'nt, well, that would be additional information..  Embed Quote

column9: Are there any noise cancelation devices for the home?
column10: Can you give more information?When does the sound occur, seasonally, times of day?Here is something that can occur and it might be one of these two things.  Some cans and jars can make a sound when heated or cooled.  The term "Tin Canning" is what it is called.  If the can does not have enough vacuum in it the top will pop back and forth.  If you have central air and or heat you can have the same effect in your duct work.  Not likely in an apt.  There is also the possibility that it is water hammer in the pipes, or water in the steam lines if you have steam heat.  These are a bunch of guesses.  If you give more information, I might be able to pinpoint for you.  Embed Quote

Noise levels are measured using Sound Level Meters (SLMs) that average dB levels over time. Measurements of 24-hours or longer are made along most (if not all) major roadways to sample traffic noise levels, which is usually the most dominant source. Airplane noise is also evaluated along with any other particular noise sources, e.g., railroad, industrial facilities. Often, a City's Noise Contour Map is modeled using software programs. The term "noise pollution" is not typically used in reports since regulations and noise ordinances vary from city to city. Search for the Noise sections of Environmental Impact Reports and the Noise sections of cities' General Plans.   Embed Quote

The noise was always there, but you couldn't hear it: Since  most recording instruments use various sort of amplification and often signal compression, the otherwise inaudible noise (let's  say -80dB or so), is amplified to audible levels.I assume it's because of a weak leaking electrical field nearby. If in close proximity, the field will couple. If not, it's more likely to simply radiate.Capacitances are never perfect. A poor analogy could be made with friction: If there was none, you would be unable to propel forward by walking. Likewise, a capacitor would simply be unable to release its stored charge (let's leave the solid state physics out of it)Electrons in a radiated field travel in a direct path towards your signal path. Good shielding practice prevents most of it, but even i don't know what's good shielding practice.A better solution is to use balanced signal cables that deliver the hot and antiphase on two wires. in the input end, a differential amplifier combines those and subtracts the pure noise out of the signal. This only works if both cables are of the same type and length, so use a decent XLR cables. Contemporary studio electronics should deliver this, but many conventional instrument chains don't (ex: guitar stompbox-type effects)Removing absolutely all noise is a difficult process, and will not necessarily guarantee better results. You could record in a full annechoic chamber, but depending on where and how your cables and setup is, you may not get a better signal to noise ratio. by definition, whenever you use compression your SNR is worsened.on a funnier note, recording in a chamber where you can hear your heartbeat is unbearable, as the musician needs to play much softer than they are used to.  Embed Quote

column9: Roosters aren't allowed in the suburbs but I would consider having one if it were able to be painlessly modified.Would it likely cause the bird psychological issues?People are welcome to comment on the ethics of this concept, but as always, be nice and helpful.
column10: If you don't already have the animal, I would suggest the following from an ethical point of view:An animal is made a certain way, and has an interest in its own welfare, and likely would not choose to be made mute, given the option.While Kantian ethics has plenty of positive aspects, I think it falls flat when it equates animals to things.  I do not like pets, but it is clear that they have personalities, feelings, and seek to avoid pain.  I choose to respect those desires by not harming them.A thought experiment for most situations would be:  Would I be willing to engage in this process with my own hands?  If the answer is no, don't do it, because some part of you identifies that action as wrong, and by accepting the result of a given activity, one also promotes and perpetuates the activity.I understand that everyone doesn't share my view, and I don't impose it on anybody.  Embed Quote
