Yes, it does. Noises that are "too loud, too close and for too long" destroy "auditory hair cells" in the inner ear and this is what causes noise induced hearing loss in both children and adults.Children are born with a fully formed cochlea at birth itself and each of them have a limited number of "auditory hair cells" in the inner ear. These, once destroyed (such as by loud noise) cannot be regrown or regenerated (yet, by any therapy).So listening to loud noises causes as much damage in childhood as in middle age.  Embed Quote

column9: I know that newer smart phones generate more radiation, but do older cellphones, that have received repeated falls and hits, become more dangerous over time because of possible damage to their antennas?
column10: There's no study which proves that cellphones generate more radiation as they grow older. Infact, there's no strong study that proves cell phone radiation is harmful at all. Cell phones and cell towers, both work on Radio Frequency which is a type of radiation having minimal heat like the electromagnetic fields. We experience the same amount of electromagnetic fields even from television sets and computers everyday. These signals are so weak that they don't cause any chemical reaction in our body or DNA. It hasn't been proved that old cell phones generate more radiation.  Embed Quote

No. All claimed instances of "WiFi illness" that have been rigorously tested have been shown to be not caused by WiFi at all. This is not surprising, because WiFi is little different from other sources of radiation we encounter in daily life in the West, so it is implausible that WiFi would cause different reactions.  Embed Quote

See also Cancer: Does cellphone usage (wireless) create a risk of brain cancer? andIs there any evidence that prolonged exposure to wireless Internet signals (cellphone, WiFi) causes health risks?Both have a host of references showing no credible health worries.As Robin Green says, WiFi is just wireless, and we have had wireless (often at MUCH higher power than WiFi) for a hundred years: if there were significant effects we would have noticed by now.  Embed Quote

Am also interested into the effects of radio frequency waves on people. I respect the comments so far that technologies such as wifi pose little threat to human health. On the flip side there are many documented stories and explanations from qualified physicists and health professionals that raise doubt on the use of Wifi. As I have read Wifi works on the same principles as microwaves in a microwave oven. Whilst the waves are negligibly lower to that of a microwave oven it is the fact that the waves produce a thermal warming effect which no doubt exposes us in the process. According to organisations such as the WHO these waves would have to produce serious effects such as burning before considered to be dangerous to humans. Long term wise is this such a good thing?  Embed Quote

Entamoeba Histolytica is a protozoan parasite.  It is transmitted in cyst form in contaminated water mostly.  Their are plenty of medications that have been shown to be effective against it.  To avoid it I reccomend drinking only from clean water sources and cleaning food carefully if you're in an at risk area.   http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ent...  Embed Quote

No, it is a sign of increased travel between NYC and countries that have bedbugs, and a product of the ban on DDT which had been previously used against them (Edit: Most bedbugs are DDT resistant today anyway). Because NYC is so populous and such a popular tourist destination, one should not be surprised to hear that bedbugs are making a resurgence in hotels there. From a theological standpoint, a very easily explained outbreak of a minor pest in a single major city does not come anywhere near the level of devastation that should precede an apocalypse. column9: This includes not only Harvard students, but also students from other local schools like MIT and BU.  Motivations may differ.
column10: Here is one explanation from the Harvard Crimson (http://www.thecrimson.com/articl... ):Nobody really forgets about the tourists. Rather, John Harvard’s adoring visitors endow the ritual with meaning. Harvard students do not pee on the statue in spite of its significance. They pee on the statue because of its significance. Urinating on the monument to higher education in America is a bizarre attempt at self-affirmation. It says: "Not only do I go to Harvard, but I spit, nay, pee, on it as well."I imagine that students from other schools pee on the statue as a manifestation of their insecurity towards Harvard as an institution and towards its students.I think AT Harvard it's sometimes seen as a "good luck" move also; perhaps getting away with it emboldens the soul.Or maybe everyone who does it is just really drunk.  Embed QuoteAnswered in two minutes.

column9: Would you get shocked?
column10: It appears that even Quora has that "weird part" that YouTube seems to be famous for.I've never done this, and I never plan on it. But as one of my favorite shows, MythBusters, proved, the electric charge has to have a way to reach from the fence to your, um, genitals. They tested it with an electrified third rail, but it is roughly the same thing as far as the concept is concerned. Urine streams usually are not a steady stream, and instead it is often separated by blank space. This is clearly seen in high-speed footage on the show. But if the charge is high enough, it is possible that the electricity could bridge the gaps in the urine stream and travel all the way up to the source. If that happens, the result would be "rather shocking".My personal recommendation: Don't pee on electric fences, or anything electric for that matter.  Embed Quote

column9: Does it has something with evolution or maybe it's more of a cultural thing?
column10: Anxiety is the reason.  And this anxiety might be rooted in evolution.  Urinating among strangers with your back turned, pants at half-mast, and one hand occupied would certainly leave you more vulnerable to attack so it might have been advantageous to evolve a predisposition against it.  The same aversion would also apply to social defecation although I'm not aware that that such anxiety can result in failure to perform.  And from a health standpoint too, communal urination and defecation would probably have spread disease and impaired fitness among hunters and gathers lacking basic sanitational infrastructure.Personally, I think if there's one human activity in civilized society that screams out for privacy, it's going to the bathroom.  Embed Quote

column9: I've heard answers ranging from "the DPW digs up every pee cake spot before the end of the event" to "the lake bed fills up every year and totally eliminates any trace of urine w/o any negative consequence".
column10: From an extremely strict LNT standpoint, no. The chemicals in your urine count as traces, and the acidity of urine reacts with the alkalai playa.From a more realistic LNT standpoint, it's not that big a deal. There are much worse things to worry about in terms of preserving the playa and not leaving a trace. Micro-moop is the worst, small particles that won't break down but are extremely hard to remove, like carpet fibers, astroturf shedding, sequins. From the standpoint of being a courteous participant, it's pretty undesirable and we would all prefer that you try to hold it and get to a potty. And if you aren't able to hold it, try to spread it around as much as possible so that it dries up quickly rather than making a nasty puddle.  Embed Quote

column9: I've heard answers ranging from "the DPW digs up every pee cake spot before the end of the event" to "the lake bed fills up every year and totally eliminates any trace of urine w/o any negative consequence".
column10: DPW does not dig up pee cake spots. Generally the urine from a single person does not make any sort of cake spot.DPW does dig up some cake spots from leaking evap ponds, which is a lot more water than the urine coming from the same camp members. People use about 1-2L of water washing dishes and stuff per day. People pee about the same amount normally (probably the lower end of this on the playa, of course). But the showers people take use 2-6 more liters per person, which is why evap-ponds get overloaded.The total output of urine and other waste has already been asked about: Burning Man: What is the total amount of urine produced at Burning Man each year?It's not nearly enough to fill the lake.  Embed Quote

I guess in my country we have the european system. But I can't say that for sure since I've never bought any drugs in the US nor Europe. A good thing about this system, as it was mentioned before, is the reduced chances of error. You can avoid the pharmacist's confussion on the amount or kind of drugs. The other good thing is the information leaflet (called prospecto here) wich can be consulted by the patient at any time. Very usefull when the patient has doubts about side effects and other things when they can't go to the pharmacy or the doctor's office to ask (for example if it's late at night). The bad part of this system is when you need to take 14 pills and the boxes have 10 pills for example. You have to buy 2 boxes, wasting money and medication. We don't have the refill option either. So you need to get a lot of prescriptions in advance or go to the doctor every time you need a new one. I don't know how it works in other countries.  I still think that avoiding human mistakes that can lead to serious problems and even death makes the european system the best choice.Not for Reproduction

I can't say which is better but it may help to explain that under European Union legislation, the original producer of any manufactured consumer product is legally liable without fault for any damage caused by a defect in the product. Use of original packaging, with patient information on the box (and usually in a leaflet inside as well) helps pharmaceutical companies minimise the risk of being held liable for adverse effects arising from someone else's fault in mis-prescribing the product or not telling the patient how to use it correctly.http://europa.eu/legislation_sum...  Embed QuoteVia  Fred Landis.

I do not believe one system is "better" or safer than the other.  I agree that the European system may be more expensive, although it is hard to say without looking in detail at the costs of the supply chain.  The US pharmacies are very heavily regulated and there are safeguard along the dispensing chain that minimize the errors in dispensing the medicine.  Embed QuoteVia  Fred Landis.

I agree with Greg Hard in that there would likely be a reduced risk of miscalculation with regard to the actual counting and distribution of pills. However, I would hesitate to say that this reduced risk would make the European system better. Mathematically more sound, perhaps, and less of a liability, perhaps, but better?As far as I can tell: by having the pill distributor package the pills themselves, we could assume an increase in labor and cost. However, thanks to the socialized medical communities in some of those countries, that doesn't mean that purchasing the pills would necessarily cost more (at the pharmacy, that is). As far as the United States is concerned, the pharmaceutical companies are pretty much able to charge whatever they want, so prices are going to be higher. The real issue, though, is whether either method improves and/or ensure proper use of the medicine. Once the package, whether it's individually packaged, or put into a pill bottle and given away like that, leaves the building, it's equally liable to be misused in any manner. In the end, to me, neither system seems better than the other. Honestly, as it stands, I would stick with the United States system on the basis that while there may be a slightly greater margin for error, there is also more opportunity to actually speak with pharmacists and their assistants, as opposed to just having a box handed to you.  Embed QuoteVia  Fred Landis.

When I was on a course of medicine I first received my medication in blister-packs. On repeat, the medication was loose. (One month's supply instead of the earlier three.)I certainly found, as a consumer, that I preferred the blister pack: It was far easier to know a) where I was in the programme (ie: did I need a repeat soon?) and b) whether I'd taken today's pill(s).The blister blister pack was arranged in rows of seven. No matter how many per day I should take, I could consistently be sure that I'd taken them (or not).As for cost? Well, I guess my self-employed shop-owning pharmacist is a specialised skill, at about half the rate of a lawyer; at least same as a plumber or mechanic. (In a land of socialised healthcare I've already paid for that, and the drugs...)Anyway, at that rate, surely blister-packing at the point of production would be more economical, even if shipping increase a bit. Custom, manual, counting and packing must be less efficient and expensive, no?I found that neither form restricted nor encouraged communication with the pharmacist. Both were handed to me by an assistant; the pharmacist was only a metre further away and available.  Embed Quote

Based solely upon the information in the question, I would say that the European system has a reduced chance of error. Theoretically, there's a slightly higher chance of sorting errors when US pharmacists dispense drugs, than when a sealed box is provided. Granted, errors such as this are likely extremely low, but in sealed boxes they're far closer to zero. On the flip side, you might have higher costs in Europe for packaging needs and, thus, a greater overhead on shipping as a result of increased weight of bulk packaging.However, I'd say that none of those differences make either system better than the other, and that they're comparable.  Embed QuoteVia  Fred Landis.

My Mom's in a nursing home setting, and I feel much better knowing that the meds come in the blister packs to minimize dosing errors which are very common in hospitals and/or nursing homes.  Embed Quote

It depends what you mean by better.  In the US, bulk dispensing is used for high volume oral solid drugs by pharmacies and mail order dispensers.  The acquisition cost per pill is typically the same, but this automation can reduce dispensing costs.  There is very little chance of the wrong product or quantity being dispensed.  Otherwise, most other oral solids are dispensed in 30 or 90 day supply packages from the original manufacturer.  Embed Quote

column10: Make sure that your brain temperature isn't too high (neurotoxicity is worse when the temperature is high), and try to take it in conjunction with a brain anti-oxidant to reduce neurotoxicity. In particular, melatonin is quite effective in reducing the neurotoxicity of amphetamine-like substances, although it has a sedating effect that may screw up MDMA (and it may also screw up one's sleep-wake cycle). Still, there are others.  Embed Quote

column9: From method of intake to necessary precautions to supplementary drugs (e.g. 5htp or something similar).
column10: MDMA is conclusively neurotoxic. Many, many studies have demonstrated lasting changes to the serotonergenic systems in both animals and humans, leading to impaired memory, cognition, and emotions.As a counterpoint, neither LSD or psilocybin has been show to be neurotoxic in any studies. This is not a biased, but an objective opinion based on review of a large number of recent studies.A number of studies have shown that injecting rats with large doses of anti-oxidants prevents neurotoxicity, indicating a few things:The neurotoxicity is almost certainly real, since it can be reduced in a predictable manner with anti-oxidants, without diminishing the acute effects of the drug.Neurotoxicity is likely caused by the presence of oxidative chemicals following MDMA use, likely MDMA, a metabolite, or dopamine.Neurotoxicity can possibly be prevented with antioxidants, though this has not been proven in humans, and in rats only with extremely high intravenous (not oral) doses.In short, there is no safe way to take MDMA.  MDMA is neurotoxic. There are theoretical ways to reduce neurotoxicity in humans, but they have not been proven in either human studies, nor in animals with normal doses taken orally.You may read that one major study on MDMA was retracted because of terribly flawed methodology, namely that the study was mistakenly done with methamphetamine. That is true. However there are scores of other credible studies indicating physiological damage to brains, neurotoxicity, and serious cognitive damage in animals and humans. You may also hear that damage is caused by tainted pills - this is categorically false, as numerous analyses of seized MDMA pills have found little or no evidence of other harmful chemicals in street bought MDMA.Search for "MDMA brain damage" and you will not only find these studies, but hundreds of anecdotal reports of disastrous effects from relatively minor usage. Do the same search for "LSD brain damage" and you will find little if any scientific or anecdotal evidence of lasting damage.Personal OpinionI am not an opponent of drug use in general. Smoke pot in moderation. Take LSD or mushrooms on occasion if you want a spiritual experience, though those drugs are not without risk of long term behavioral effects. Coke out in vegas, just don't get hooked. But don't risk your life and mind on MDMA. If you do, research "pre" and "post" rolling as that may help protect you, don't do it more than once every few months, and don't take it multiple times in a short period as that greatly increases the risk.  Embed Quote

column10: There are a few places that you can look online such as webMD or walgreens.com.  Generally, the best place to get information on your prescription is your pharmacist.  They are experts on medications and how they work in your body.  They rely on continuing education, peer review journals, clinical experience, and professional references.  As a pharmacist, my favorite professional references are Micromedix, Lexi, and Facts & Comparisons.  These are all subscription based references, but you have access to the information through your pharmacist.  I suggest anyone starting a new prescription get a consulation on what to expect from your pharmacist.  If you have futher questions, give your pharmacist a call to clarify any information you have missed.  Embed Quote

In some guy's basement. Or maybe his shop out in the backyard. If this was known information the DEA would have already shut it down.I would guess it would be produced in an area where methylamine has legitimate uses. Its been a long time since I studied the MDMA synthesis, but if I remember correctly, the common way its made is through the luekart-wallach reaction of methylenedioxyphenylacetone with methylamine.So it would likely be made where those might be easier to get. But MDPAc really isn't available anywhere, so it needs to be synthesized before the main reaction. This needs to be made using a few difficult to aquire chemicals like sassafras oil, piperonal and benzaldehyde if I remember right, but I am afraid that my knowledge of the procedure to make MDPAc ends here. In fact I am probably mistaken about everything I've said about MDPAc production.If I really cared I could probably figure out an easier way to make it by starting with methylenedioxyephedrine which would be reduced to MDMA using the birch reduction or reducing with hydriodic acid and phosphorus. Methylenedioxyephedrine shouldn't be too difficult to make, and some clever underground chemist may have figured this out somewhere. I am just guessing here, I don't know if anyone does this, but its possible.My guess is that it is made in a rural area, since the production of MDMA produces fumes that are very noticable. The chemicals needed to make it are likely more available in rural areas. I would assume that a secluded home with a barn or large garage that isn't easily seen from any main roads and is at least half a mile away from any neighbors would be the most likely place that the MDMA comes from.  Embed Quote

Essentially impossible.  Day to day usage is a death wish for depressives.  Scienctists have acknowledged that the effect of MDMA has great power to combat symptoms of depression in the short term, which seems quite obvious if you know the action of or have felt the effects of the drug.  But they are frustrated by the nature of depression allowing no reliable and safe circumstance for any kind of MDMA administration (except, technically, for one-off ideal situations which combine strict supervision and mind reading therapy - but this is beyond hypothetical)   Neurochemically, It is crucial to realise that MDMA causes not only an SSRI-like effect but also a release of what precious serotonin is stored in the brain and cells around the body!  So for a depressive who is almost certainly, to some degree, having trouble regulating the serotonergenic functions of the brain already, the withdrawal (or comedown) is far far worse than for the average person any way you look at it.  (And no, tapering from the drug doesn't work either, you feel less exaggerated withdrawal over time, but this only turns a suicidal situation into a problematic situation in which the illness is chemically exacerbated...    Consider, a depressive can't afford to deal with anything but the reality of their situation which is complicated enough as it is).While SSRI's have a bad reputation for withdrawal syndrome at the end of treatment, they only address a reuptake function of serotonin across synapses, whereas MDMA withdrawal will deliver not only the bad symptomology of SSRI withdrawal but its very OWN form of forced chemical depression, courtesy of having acted (aggressively) upon the site of serotonin management AND the finite stores in the brain and around the body.The potential for MDMA use in depression treatment is only theoretically viable in combination with a level of psychotherapy + CBT which simply doesn't exist (and that is the accepted view of researchers on the topic).  A shame really, everyone agrees.so...Problem in a nutshell - The idea relies on the depressive having control over their own treatment - which is a paradox...   Consider how much control a depressive has over even the simple aspects of their own life!Summary and opinion - Too hard if not impossible.  A wonderful idea in an ideal world, which is not the world anyone lives in, let alone a depressive.NB - please rely on the fact that I have experienced every side of this idea, from all the withdrawals (MDMA, SSRI, SNRI, MAOI etc) to all the symptoms of severe long term major depressive disorder and have attempted a variety of 'self-treatments'.I wish the answer wasn't so brutally against MDMA, but it has to be.Also, I speak of the 'opinion of science' but have not referenced any scientific sources.  This would be poor practise in a lot of explanations, but this answer speaks from personal experience (in the spirit of the question itself) and the science as it has been journaled is irrelevant to the value of the conclusion, and hence only of small interest in that it agrees on its own level.  Peace  Embed Quote

column9: From Wikipedia's Form 483 page: Form FDA 483, “Inspectional Observations,” is a form used by the FDA to document and communicate concerns discovered during these inspections. Also referred to as "Form 483" or merely "483", it states thereon that it “...lists observations made by the FDA representative(s) during the inspection of your facility. They are inspectional observations, and do not represent a final Agency determination regarding your compliance”"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/For...
column10: The biggest causes are likely: 1) The FDA's mandate expanded to include tobacco manufacturers and de facto expanded to include compounding pharmacies as cGMP facilities, neither of which had anything close to FDA level scrutiny heretofore. In essence, they are performing a bunch of "first-inspection-ever" for these outfits and the chance of a non-compliance is therefore much higher.2) The FDA adopted a risk-based approach to compliance in general, and as such has altered their inspection practices to be more attentive to high-risk data and less slavishly devoted to letter-and-law of particular predicate rules. There are plenty of statements in the regs that are high-level enough to cover almost any conceivable deficit in your product or systems, and the Agency is much more comfortable using these to note a deficiency than they were historically.  Embed Quote

column9: Assume that a person uses MDMA X times a year.How much will his serotonine levels probably go down if X is 3, 6, 12? And how big is the impact of this on everyday live and feelings? Will this certainly lead to a depression?Plot twist: Assume that the person is 16-18 years old.
column10: A lot comes down to individual body chemistry.  I know people who did X 20 times and lost all ability to enjoy it again.  And I know people who do it every week for years and everything's fine.I would recommend taking an antioxidant (like alpha lipoic acid) with the drug, and then 5-HTP the morning after to replenish your serotonin reserves.  Embed Quote

Indoors:Get an air purifier in your bedroom. If you're very concerned, put one in every room. If you live near a major highway, don't leave your windows open at night as that's when all the heavy duty, black smoke belching trucks come by.If you haven't already, consider using face wash and lotion daily. Beijing is very dry compared to most temperate US cities, this compounds with the pollution to irritate the skin. Outdoors:Check the pollution index every day (http://aqicn.org/city/beijing/). The pollution is especially bad after sunset, but is lowest in the morning. If you want to go running outside, do it in the morning, and not at night. There are many masks to choose from, but you'll want one with a rating of N90 and above. That means it filters out 90% of airborn particles. Here's what a simple one looks like. You can find these in 7-11, and they are inconspicuous Beijing pollution levels average around an index of 100, which is "unhealthy". Even if the pollution is below 100 in the daytime, it almost always jumps up at night. If you ride a bicycle you're going to be smack dab in the middle of the main cause of pollution, cars. You'll want a heavier mask like one of these:Live the cyberpunk dystopian future, today!Be sure to check your filters and replace them! (picture is from a cyclist who reported this was from just one day of biking!)Rain and effects on pollution levelsIn Beijing, pollution levels drop drastically the day after it rains, approaching the tolerable levels of an American city such as New York. These are the most pleasant days and are sunny too. But the heavy cloudy days building up to rain can be quite high in pollution levels. But remember, when that rain is falling, it's carrying everything in the Beijing air with it. Wash your clothes as soon as you can, I've had a rain soaked white shirt left unwashed overnight and now it's been permanently stained with blacksih spots. Wash it off your skin as soon as you can.Enjoy Beijing, and cherish the days where the sun shines brightly on a blue sky  Embed Quote
Make yourself strong enough that you can live without breathing. LOL  Embed Quote

Air pollution in China can be awful and is nothing to trifle with (see, for example, China breaks saddest record ever: 8-year-old is youngest lung-cancer patient). When Beijing has good air quality days it's lovely, but on bad air quality days (which are the majority)…well, here are some photos I took:And here's a collage from Weibo of 365 consecutive days of sky photos.The point being, Beijing's air pollution should be taken seriously. Download an air quality index (AQI) app, keep track of the air where you are, and react appropriately when pollution is bad. When the pollution is bad, this means avoiding physical exercise, not burning candles indoors (even though the air is stinky), keeping the windows shut, and having your air filters on.My wife and I did the following:Bought air purifiers for the home.You don't need to spend a fortune on an air filter. You can even build your own: How to Make a DIY Air Purifier.We started out with a generic HEPA filter from Midea. We changed the filters every three months instead of every six; we could tell when it was time to change because the air flow from the front vents would be noticably lower. Gross.The morning after we bought the filter was the first time since moving to Beijing that I didn't wake up with a sore throat from having a runny nose all night. I was sold.This filter did fine, but we eventually upgraded to a BlueAir. I didn't notice any difference between it and the Midea; I just kept not having a cough or a sore throat from the pollution. The BlueAir was nice, though, because it was quieter than the Midea, and we got it at a great price.Now, expats in Beijing love to talk air purifiers and show off their latest, expensive, buy, but I think that you're fine buying any HEPA purifier that can change the air in the room 3+ times/hour. I know others have argued that BlueAir &c are better because of the pre-filtering that takes out chemical fumes from construction and renovation, but if your apartment is full of formaldehyde fumes, maybe you should move.Bought those air-cleaning plants everyone talks about.Do they work? There's quite a bit of research to indicate they do, but I thought the effect (if any) from the plants we bought was much less noticeable than that of our HEPA filter. According to one source (which has a great list of NASA-approved plants for purifying the air), NASA research indicated you should have one plant per 10m^2 of floorspace, so be prepared to buy quite a few. The plants that we had be best luck with was mother-in-law's tongue. They are still going strong after three years.Luckily, most of these air cleaning plants are ubiquitous and cheap, so go to the flower market next to the US Embassy and have fun shopping and haggling over plants. If you want to buy large plants, try to get them from the same seller, as delivery will be included in the price.Bought a totobobo mask.This was sort of a low point of living in Beijing, acceding to the idea that to go outside I really should wear a mask to breathe. However, life was better with the mask than without it, so I wore the damn thing.When you are looking at pollution masks, there are two things to keep in mind: filtering ability and fit. If the mask isn't able to filter fine particles (the lingo most often heard about this is "N95"), it's worthless. The cloth masks you see people wearing don't do anything for pollution. Similarly, if the mask doesn't have a tight, consistent seal to your face, dirty air leaks in and the mask isn't as effective.We bought totobobo masks, which are great because (a) you can cut them to fit your face, ensuring proper fit, and (b) they have replaceable filters. On bad air quality days, our air filters would go grey after an hour of outdoor wear. (Think about that for a little bit…) This is a photo of my mask with new filters after an hour of wear on an AQI 300+ day.  The main downside to the totobobo is that moisture accumulates inside it. After about an hour of wear I'd need to take it off and swab out the inside.We have left Beijing, mostly because of the air pollution. The government says that it should have the problem fixed in "five to ten years". I'm skeptical of that, but hope it's true.  Embed Quote

Actually, it's not been that terrible in recent years. Anway I shall give you some tips nevertheless: Indoor: you may buy a air purifier and have some evergreen plants;Outdoor: a mask is necessary on windy and sandy days, and try to avoid rush hour;Other: if you are used to running outside, there are some gardens like Olympic Green which is good, especially if you are living nearby. And do not run along the ring roads, where there is heavy traffic. If you want to do some excercise, find a gym or club nearby.I have posted some pictures to show you the best time of the year in Beijing. I took these photos on my way to school yesterday.Around the library Kun Yu river,  I live nearbythe sunset glowSo do you feel better now? Come on, there are 20 million people here. Have fun in Beijing.  Embed Quote

For Indoors:1. Install Compact Fluorescent Lightbulbs (CFL) coated with TiO2 (Titanium Dioxide). Available here --> Medilite Air purifying lamp. TiO2 (Disclaimer: I didn't work with the company). Illustration on how  TiO2 (Titanium Dioxide) work:Figure above shows the TiO2 Photocatalyst [2]Fig 1: The photosynthetic reaction in plant is basically similar to the photocatalytic reaction in titanium oxide. [2]Fig 2: Self-cleaning effect based on the two key characteristics of titanium oxide photocatalyst. [2]Demo (video) on how CFL coated with TiO2 (Titanium Dioxide) work (indoor):2.Use natural way (biological): [3] Except from On Ted Kamal Meattle on, \'how to grow your own fresh air\': [8]Research – IIT, TERI, NASA The Discovery With only three varieties of plants, we can “grow our own fresh air” indoors, to keep us healthy This also allows us to have reduced fresh air supplied to buildings and yet meet Industry standards for healthy indoor air.Which are these plants?1. Areca Palm (Chrysalidocarpus lutescens)Works well in the day timeGreat for living areasOne needs about 4 shoulder high plants/personNeeds to be put outdoors once every 3-4 monthsThe leaves of the plant need to be wiped everyday in Delhi and perhaps once a month in a cleaner cityThe soil used should be of vermi manure or use hydroponics2. Mother-in-law’s Tongue (Sansevieria trifasciata)Converts CO2 into O2 at nightOne requires about 6-8 such waist high plants per person in the bedroomLeaves need to be wiped in the same way as the Areca PalmThe soil used should be of vermi manure or use hydroponics3. Money Plant (Epipremnum aureum)Excellent for removing Formaldehyde and other VOC’sBest grown using hydroponics The Results Tried and tested these plants for 15 years at: Paharpur Business Centre and Software Technology Incubator Park, New Delhi, India It is a 20 year old, 50,000 ft2 building Over 1,200 plants for 300 building occupantsThe Results – Health & Productivity Study (*Study published on September 8, 2008 by The Govt. of India, Central Pollution Control Board and Chittaranjan National Cancer Institute, Kolkata, India) found that there is a;... (more)Loading...
1. Sometimes it's not so bad, sometimes it's very bad. Check the U.S. Embassy Air Quality Monitoring Website before going out.2. When the AQI is bad, wear one of these:  Embed Quote

Hi Luke, thanks for the recommendation! I'm the nerd that did all the home air experiments and started Particle Counting. I started to get really concerned about air pollution during the "airpocalypse," but I was shocked at having to spend $1,000 on a single air purifier (let alone the replacement filters). So I researched how filters work and made my own. I posted all of my data and tests online, for example: 1. Live test of the filter2. Tests showing the DIY filter gets an average of 84% of particles larger than .5 microns and 92% of particles larger than 2.5 microns3. Tests of a newer, stronger model that gets 96% of both!Instructions on how to make one are on the Tumblr. However, several people told me they were having trouble finding the parts, so I've started ordering in bulk and shipping from Smart Air. My hope is that my nerd-ery can help people stay healthy without giving a wheelbarrow full of cash to filter companies.And Luke, you're right--particles aren't everything. If people are concerned about fumes from construction, you can add an activated carbon filter to the DIY pretty easily.  Embed Quote

Take cabs, not the subway, not a moped, and not a bicycle when the weather is particularly bad. Being in a car with no windows open makes a HUGE difference on your air quality. I learned that from a UN researcher in an Environment of China class. When pollution measures are off the charts (which happens a couple times a month), avoid going outside altogether. This might sound extreme, but if you plan on living in Beijing for years plural, its important. Lung related illnesses are the number one cause of death in Beijing. To know when the weather is bad, get a VPN and follow @beijingair on Twitter. It's a device that measures pollution by parts per million and I believe its on top of the US embassy in Beijing. It's also worthwhile to understand what the measures mean. The smaller the particles, the worse for your lungs. Everyone was freaking out with all the construction dust before the Olympics, but that just makes your boogers blacks, not a big deal.  Embed Quote
Inhale as infrequently as possible.  Embed Quote
Dont go there if you are worried about that in the first place  Embed Quote

column9: I'm trying to see if there's a chemical reaction in which PM10 particles or other pollutants in the air can form another (larger) substance that can be used in a beneficial manner.Is there a sustainable model for air purification of public spaces?
column10: This perhaps not the best way, but to eliminate air pollution sustainably require elimination/ minimize air pollution at source(s) - One way is plant a trees (a butt load of it) - grow an urban forest.Credit: [6]Trees and other plants make their own food from carbon dioxide (CO2) in the atmosphere, water, sunlight and a small amount of soil elements. In the process, they release oxygen (O2) for us to breathe.Trees:Help to settle out, trap and hold particle pollutants (dust, ash, pollen and smoke) that can damage human lungs.Absorb CO2 and other dangerous gasses and, in turn, replenish the atmosphere with oxygen.Produce enough oxygen on each acre for 18 people every day.Absorb enough CO2 on each acre, over a year's time, to equal the amount you produce when you drive your car 26,000 miles. Trees remove gaseous pollutants by absorbing them through the pores in the leaf surface. Particulates are trapped and filtered by leaves, stems and twigs, and washed to the ground by rainfall.Air pollutants injure trees by damaging their foliage and impairing the process of photosynthesis (food making). They also weaken trees making them more susceptible to other health problems such as insects and diseases.The loss of trees in our urban areas not only intensifies the urban "heat-island" effect from loss of shade and evaporation, but we lose a principal absorber of carbon dioxide and trapper of other air pollutants as well.Some of the major air pollutants and their primary sources are:Carbon dioxide: Burning oil, coal, natural gas for energy. Decay and burning of tropical forests.Sulfur dioxide: Burning coal to generate electricity.Hydrogen floride and silicon tetrafloride: Aluminum and phospate fertilizer production, oil refineries, and steel manufacturing.Ozone: Chemical reactions of sunlight on automobile exhaust gases. Ozone is a major pollutant in smog.Methane: Burning fossil fuels, livestock waste, landfills and rice production.Nitros oxides: Burning fossil fuels and automobile exhausts.Chloroflorocarbons: Air conditioners, refrigerators, industrial foam.The burning of fossil fuels for energy and large scale forest fires such as in the tropics are major contributors to the buildup of CO2 in the atmosphere.Managing and protecting forests and planting new trees reduces CO2 levels by storing carbon in their roots and trunk and releasing oxygen into the atmosphere.[3]Reference:Forest Service Study Finds Urban Trees Removing Fine Particulate Air Pollution, Saving Lives.Trees Reduce Air PollutionTrees Capture Particulate Matter From Road ExhaustModeled PM2.5 removal by trees in ten U.S. ci... [Environ Pollut. 2013]http://www.nrpa.org/uploadedFile...Beirut's Roofs and Walls Ripe for a Green Takeover  Embed Quote

As touched upon already, air pollution is a consequence of massive resource consumption, and there are different sources of air pollution, not just cars. However, I'm going to speak from a North American perspective (Hong Kong, as Anonymous points out, has different sources of air pollution, given 90% of people take transit there already). I argue that land use, not public transit, plays a bigger factor in reducing greenhouse gas emissions. Without proper land use, you can have lots of buses go any where, but they wouldn't be able to meet the right ridership since everything is far apart. As Seth Andrzejewski points out, land use is very critical. Your goal: you want to be able to reduce the travel time from your origin to your place of destination, so you choose the mode of transportation that is the least costly, from a time and monetary perspective. You want to reduce the time it takes to take to get to work or buy groceries. For example, if you can make the places between where you live and the places you want to go (grocery store, work, park, etc.) closer to each other, you make it a lot easier to depend on the car, since things are not spread out. If things are too spread out, the Golden Triangle of Transit here fails:From Jarrett Walker, international transit consultant: (Human Transit: basics: conceptual triangles).In short, without the right density and walk-ability, transit services can't justify frequent services (buses coming every five minutes!) or have the right ridership to meet the service. This is why in a lot of suburbs, you have buses coming every 30 minutes or hour: it is much more cheaper for them to take that route because not many people take transit.Without proper land use planning (which is a whole other subject on its own, as the comments on Seth's post point out), like in the US, you have a lot of suburbs, which makes it more convenient to drive than to take transit.  Jarrett Walker, from his book, Human Transit: How clearer thinking about public transit can enrich our communities and our lives (see here: human transit (the book): introduction ) notes that if land use ("development") is spread out, transit would not be very efficient:The red line is the transit line, the dark purples are the first and last stops, and the light purple are the intermediate stops. If we pretended, this was a suburb, having cul-de sacs (in light purple) would not be very efficient for transit vehicles because  the bus/rail would have to go through every destination. It would take a really long time for that red line to go to every place. This is a different transit line, but much more straight forward. Now, with the proper land use that is very dense in one line, this can be a very efficient transit line. This is key: proper land use. You can still have a straight line but it can be located in the suburbs, and it would be an inefficient transit line because there is not enough ridershipHere's an example of density, visualized, from the architecture firm, Perkins & Will, of a urban design plan for Vancouver, Canada, I believe. Here's another similar image of Vancouver, probably at a different location:Watch that transit line pass through that dense neighborhood! With the amount of development, it will have a justifiable amount of ridership to justify frequent service along the line to take transit!-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------So, in short, land use, not public transit, in North America, has a greater factor in influencing greenhouse gas emissions.Note: you might have noticed that I was sort of repetitive in different ways. It is really important to be clear when discussing or talking about transportation and the language of transportation because people interpret things different ways. That's why I provided lots of different visuals from different sources to help put everything in context.  The concept of density, for example, is a very broad concept. Does it mean 5 story, 10 story, 80 story (Manhattan), etc. There are different ways of measuring high density. Similarly, the concept of mixed land use or closer land uses is also very hard to visualize and thus has to be explained in depth to the reader.This is the role of urban planners, transportation engineers, and also to a growing extent, the smart cities / big data movement, which I talk more about in this article: http://www.quora.com/Smart-Citie...  Embed Quote

Yes, public transport could theoretically be a major solution to air pollution but keep two things in mind:1. There are many other sources of air pollution, not just from autos. I couldn't immediately find a % breakdown of where air pollution comes from, mainly because it's an apples to oranges comparison. Factories or refineries emit different pollutants than autos.2. The "public transport" solution shouldn't necessarily be viewed as a public transport problem. The real problem is how many American cities are organized - where people live, work, and shop. Take "auto-centric" Los Angeles for example. It does have a metro, metrorapid bus, and light rail system, mostly serving downtown. For commuting patterns between these points (i.e. from Hollywood to Downtown along the Red Line), there may be a significant transit mode share (say >20%). However, public transport would have to bridge a huge number of possible origin-destination combinations to make a serious dent in auto generated air pollution. People live in Torrence and work to Pasadena, live in Long Beach and work in Santa Monica. It would be much less expensive if we could convince people to live nearer to where they worked.  Embed Quote

It's not a slam dunk, as I write this answer from Hong Kong where something like 90% of the people use public transit daily and the air pollution ranks amongst some of the worst in the world.Pollution isn't just cars.  Here for example we have coal fired power plants and the downwind effects of being located near "China, Inc" and the factories on the mainland.  And on top of that, we also have problems with--get this--public transit.  The buses they use for public transportation here are very dated and pump considerable amounts of pollution into the air.  Efforts to upgrade to the new Euro IV standards have been stalled by concerns about the cost of new buses, etc.So while it might help in some places, the problem with air pollution is that there is no one source causing the pollution and thus, there is no one answer or cure.  You need to look at air pollution in a more "whole" sense--examining all the potential impacts and then act in a coordinated manner to reduce the pollution.  Embed Quote

We all agree that an efficient public transportation system will help to reduce the pollution, but, the 75% of the people who buy a car never go back to use the public transportation. This number it’s the reality in USA and Canada. The attributes to use a car or the public transportation it’s the real challenge. If the public transportation can’t offer attributes like security (door to door), a “nice” ride, whatever you call “nice” (music, space, etc), be at any time and all of that with a less cost to use a car, the cars will still be the first choice of those who already have one, and those who are going to buy one. There is the real challenge  Embed Quote

Of course! It is a no brainer. But..... Getting decent public transport infrastructure in place - with all the massive public investment that is entailed - is a huge stumbling block. Cost of usage is another barrier. If users are to pay for it, they will be kept away by high fares (that pay for it).  To get people out of cars it has to be a comprehensive, integrated, reliable, affordable and reasonably comfortable alternative to cars. Public taxation is key to providing decent public transport that ticks all the boxes. And that is a message many do not wish to hear.....  Embed Quote

column9: I'm thinking about the kind of dust that might be produced by sawing, grinding, sanding, and welding metals in a machine shop setting. If so, what can I do to protect myself? For example, irrigate my nose daily, wear a mask, or get the air more ventilated.
column10: Steel and aluminum dust will not cause horrible diseases like silica or asbestos dust do. The lungs can handle a certain amount of normal dust without any lasting harm, although all metal dusts are irritants. Large amounts of airborne metal dust are a sign the machine shop was improperly set up, and should be overhauled. A dust mask will not protect you against very small particles, so it's always best to just keep the dust out of the air in the first place. There are government standards in every developed country for maximum allowable airborne metal dust in the workplace, and dust controls such as wet machining equipment or negative pressure areas must be in place to get levels low enough for safe long-term exposure. There is also some evidence linking aluminum exposure to Alzheimer's, but it's far from proven.  Embed QuoteVia  Ben Mordecai.

column9: I'm thinking about the kind of dust that might be produced by sawing, grinding, sanding, and welding metals in a machine shop setting. If so, what can I do to protect myself? For example, irrigate my nose daily, wear a mask, or get the air more ventilated.
column10: The type of dust you speak of is generally much too heavy to become airborne in the sense that you could 'breathe' it.  Having run a machine shop for many years, I've never had to do any machining process on stainless or aluminum that produced an airborne powder.  Generally, outside of sanding, the chips are much larger than beach sand.  If you were sanding it, you'd have to actually put your mouth in the outgoing side of the process to get some in there before it fell to the ground.There may be some very fine grinding process that could produce breathable aluminum or stainless dust, but odds are that would be a process done with coolant which would remove the possibility.  Stainless and aluminum are gummy metals and don't tend to turn to powder easily like, for example, brass or iron.What you should be much more worried about in a machine or welding shop is breathing in welding fumes, especially from fluxes, and aerosolized coolants.  Wood dust, on the other hand, is light and quite prone to end up airborne and I have known many woodworkers who have had health issues as a result of exposure.  Even being somewhat careful, I'd say my experiences with wood dust in a production shop were 'unpleasant' to 'dangerous'.  Embed Quote

column9: I'm thinking about the kind of dust that might be produced by sawing, grinding, sanding, and welding metals in a machine shop setting. If so, what can I do to protect myself? For example, irrigate my nose daily, wear a mask, or get the air more ventilated.
column10: Yes, continuing exposure to fine airborne dust of every kind is best avoided. There are two approaches to this, eliminating dust at the source, and eliminating it at the intake. I'd start with stopping it at the source. Cutting and machining metals with a lubricating coolant will improve the quality of the work, make your tools last longer, and eliminate airborne dust. Do this first. For operations which must be done dry, arrange for dust collection. Be careful of fine aluminum powder. It can be hazardous! Finally, protect yourself with a dust mask. Your nose and lungs will thank you for it in the long run, no matter how sweaty you feel underneath it.  Embed QuoteVia  Ben Mordecai.

column9: I'm thinking about the kind of dust that might be produced by sawing, grinding, sanding, and welding metals in a machine shop setting. If so, what can I do to protect myself? For example, irrigate my nose daily, wear a mask, or get the air more ventilated.
column10: For complete information on questions of this type, one should always refer to the Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) Database.Now, you are talking about stray particles created in your work environment, not piles of the stuff being flung about with shovels.  So the following does not strictly apply to your situation.  However, for aluminum metallic powder, the MSDS has this to say:Appearance: silver-gray powder. Danger! Dust may form flammable or explosive mixture with air, especially when damp. Reacts violently and/or explosively with water, steam or moisture. May ignite or explode on contact with moist air. May cause eye and skin irritation. May cause respiratory tract irritation. Air sensitive.Target Organs: Lungs, eyes, skin.Potential Health Effects     Eye:          May cause eye irritation.      Skin:          May cause skin irritation. Low hazard for usual industrial handling.           No sensitizing effects known.      Ingestion:          May cause gastrointestinal irritation with nausea, vomiting and           diarrhea.      Inhalation:          May cause respiratory tract irritation. May cause respiratory           difficulty and coughing.      Chronic:          Aluminum may be implicated in Alzheimer's disease. Inhalation of           aluminum containing dusts may cause pulmonary disease.So basically, it would seem to be a Bad Idea to expose yourself to aluminum dust on a regular basis.  A dust mask would be a wise choice.  Get one that will filter the correct size of particles.MSDS Aluminum Metallic Powder: Page on Iastate.edu  Embed QuoteVia  Ben Mordecai.

column9: I'm thinking about the kind of dust that might be produced by sawing, grinding, sanding, and welding metals in a machine shop setting. If so, what can I do to protect myself? For example, irrigate my nose daily, wear a mask, or get the air more ventilated.
column10: I work for a company that manufactures industrial air pollution control equipment, and I have received many inquiries concerning aluminium and other airborne dust. Although breathing aluminium dust is not advisable for health reasons, there are much greater dangers associated with sanding, cutting, grinding, deburring and finishing of aluminium parts. The most serious risk arises when aluminium and steel (or stainless steel parts) are worked on in the same area. Mixing aluminium and steel dust creates a potential for combustion (an explosion or a fire) when an ignition source (a spark) ignites the airborne or settled dust particles. To mitigate this risk, ferrous and non-ferrous metals should not be operated on in the same area and the different dusts should be collected using separate dust collectors or downdraft tables. An alternative way to capture combustible dusts such as Aluminium, Titanium, Magnesium etc. is to use a wet dust collector which safely captures combustible dust and complies with all NFPA and OSHA standards. To specifically answer your question, above all else, make sure that you are not breathing in any fumes from stainless steel welding. Although all welding fumes are toxic and cause health problems, fumes from welding on stainless steel produce Hexavalent Chromium, a known carcinogen which can cause lung cancer, immunity disorders, neurodegenerative disorders... Hexavalent chromium. Welders working on stainless steel must use a fume extractor with a HEPA filter to comply with OSHA standards.My suggestions relating to your question:Capture dust and smoke at source with the correct air filtration equipment If not feasible, ventilate the shop with ambient air cleaners/ exhaust systems Workers exposed to the aluminium dust should wear masks/ respirators  I have linked to some videos below on the hazards of combustible dust:Shameless plug :D  Embed Quote

column9: I'm thinking about the kind of dust that might be produced by sawing, grinding, sanding, and welding metals in a machine shop setting. If so, what can I do to protect myself? For example, irrigate my nose daily, wear a mask, or get the air more ventilated.
column10: It can be harmful for you if you are welder and breathe in the gases produced by it on regular basis. You should try to wear a mask that saves you from it.  Embed Quote

column9: What's the actual evidence, and which work best?
column10: Yes, I do think they work, and I do recommend them to my patients here in Beijing -- and anywhere in the world. I've highlighted the actual data multiple times on my blog, including this post here: How Good are N95 Masks For Pollution?.  The key is "N95" or better -- this literally is a US-government certification that tested the mask and demonstrated 95% decrease (or better) in blocking particulate matter (PM) smaller than 2.5 -- or even smaller, at 0.3 microns. Europe has a different rating system. These systems started for work safety mostly in construction sites (dust, paint fumes etc) and the 3M company is the most reputable US company making these masks. This is why all the good research studies use a 3M mask as a "gold standard" masks. This is also why I recommend them over any other mask. By the way, we focus on PM2.5 and not gases or other toxins because it's felt that PM2.5 causes the most health problems compared to the other pollutants. A particle smaller than 2.5 microns is easily breathed in and directly absorbed into your bloodstream, starting the pro-inflammatory cascade which leads to all the bad health effects. So do N95 masks work? There are a couple studies recently which demonstrate effectiveness in wearing a mask and improving heart rate, blood pressure and also blood markers of inflammation (CRP and others). The test subjects were here in Beijing, literally walking around Second Ring Road and other areas (must have been an interesting site!). The most recent and most convincing study is here: Reducing personal exposure to partic... [Environ Health Perspect. 2012] The first study is here: Beneficial cardiovascular effects of reducing exposure to particulate air pollution with a simple facemask  This is the best evidence so far that a good mask can help decrease exposure and actually help protect your health. Hopefully, better long term studies will be more convincing. But I certainly think the evidence is sound, and it's more than logical to use a proper N95 mask anytime the air is bad. I personally recommend using a mask anytime the AQI is over 200 -- which happens all the time here. As for brands -- a great issue. On my blog I compared the two more popular brands Respro and the newer Totobobo: Respro Vs. Totobobo: Which Mask Works Better For Air Pollution? I actually prefer Totoboto because they are the only consumer version that I am aware of which has published actual real world fit-test results, showing more than 99% effectiveness against PM0.3: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubm... Respro claims 88% effectiveness but didn't provide me with the actual independent test. This is why I recommend Totobobo over Respro. As for other brands, many other new companies are claiming their material is 95-99% effective, which is great -- but what about the real world, with the mask on a face? Because air leakage and a proper fit is crucial. What good is 99% if tons of air leaks around it? This again is why I always prefer the tried and true 3M brand as the "gold standard", and then the Totobobo and Respro types. Don't even bother with a cotton mask or even those blue/green surgical masks, they are 30-70% effective at best.  Embed QuoteAnswered in thirty-one minutes.

column9: I think one of the most polluting religion is Hinduism. I curse myself daily for being born in a hindu family.
column10: Chill, dude.Pollution is not anywhere in the top 10 list of horrible things about Hinduism in particular, or religions (all of them) in general. There are people out there killing other people in the name of religion (and this is true of most major religions of the world). Do you really want to get worked up over pollution?As to why this is a part of Hinduism, the simple answer is that this made much more sense 2500 years ago when these rituals were probably first practiced. In those days, with much lower populations, and societies living close to nature, pollution was not a problem. Fire was what separated humans from the animals, and was great for purification, cooking and other "good" things. There was no electricity, or natural gas, so all heating required coal or wood.Some of these rituals don't make sense now - but the nature of religions (as most people follow them) makes it difficult to adapt to modern conditions.  All religions suffer from this problem of having to follow rituals and rules that made sense thousands of years ago, but don't any longer.And finally, do you really think that pollution due to havans is really a pressing problem? Have you tried to estimate how much of the pollution in India is caused by havans, and how much is caused by your motorcycle, and how much was caused by the factories that built the laptop and mobile phone you're using?  Embed Quote

column9: I think one of the most polluting religion is Hinduism. I curse myself daily for being born in a hindu family.
column10: As Navin Kabra rightly highlighted in his answer, the rituals were designed to serve a purpose but are not adapted to current living standards and environment.As far as havans/yagnas are concerned, it was/is considered a good thing to offer specific materials to the fire as the heating of them in certain proportion would cleanse the environment and have positive impact on the body and soul. The Rishis of those times were also experts in Ayurveda and other medicines. So they mostly came up with such rituals where positive effects of such havans can be reached to a good number of people. One such example is the bonfire at the night of Holi (Holika Dahan). Originated from a religious believes, this fire does cleanse the air from the insects that specifically originates in fields after winter harvest.So in some cases, the rituals were originally started to have a positive impact but probably over the time they might have become a reason for pollution. But again, how much is their contribution to over all rise of pollution in recent times?  Embed Quote

column9: I think one of the most polluting religion is Hinduism. I curse myself daily for being born in a hindu family.
column10: All religions worship the higher source/energy in the form of fire, seen as lighting candles or lamps during prayers. It’s an ancient method of submitting the pleas and prayers to the higher source beseeching their Divine blessings.Only difference is lighting candles and lamps have invisible toxic gases (CO2 and CO mainly) while Havan has visible fumes due to solid substances being burnt. and believe me these gases produced by lamps/candles are as toxic as burning any form of gasoline which is far worse than outcomes of Havan.Few images to prove what other religion followers are doing:Christians (candles/lamps):Shingon Buddism (fire):Islam (another form of pollution):So as every other religion has some ceremony you can call pollution until you do some research and get to real meaning of those acts.Coming back to Havan again:In fact Havan is performed as a personal ritual performed for the benefit of the society or the whole living beings.Havan(Homam) is not just burning some woods and eatables for sake of performing a typical ritual with no reasons. Though I am sure lot of people does not know the real benefits behind the act. Here are few facts about ingredients used in Havan and their benefits: 1. Havan Samagri(a mixture of various dried herbal medicines, roots and leaves) is offered in the blazed fire which disseminates in micro form, in the air, to purify the environment besides activating the air as disinfectant germicidal agent.2. Pure Ghee (Butter made from cow milk) is burned in fire which gets converted into micro form to purify damp air.3. Camphor (Kapoor):Camphor is used in almost all Havan ceremonies. Camphor is a cough suppressant which helps avoid cough to the people performing Havan as they have to sit next to fire during ceremony. Camphor will deter snakes and other reptiles due to its strong odor. Similarly, camphor is believed to be toxic to insects and is thus sometimes used as a repellent.There are many different thing which seem illogical at first but they make lot of sense when you go behind the real reasons.I am sure you will start feeling very blessed one day when you understand real essence behind Sanatana Dharma (Hinduism). Hinduism is not just a religion but it's a way of life!  Embed Quote
