column9: Plastic bags are harming our environment; isn't it a no brainer they should not be made anymore?
column10: Because science. That's why. At least, that's why I oppose the bans. More specifically, I oppose the bans because:Plastic is not necessarily worse for the environment than paper bags. It's complicated and depends what tradeoffs and assumptions you make [1]. Yes, paper degrades, but it's also a lot bulkier. Guess what? All that bulk has to be transported... using lots and lots of gas. Paper also requires cutting down forests which kill trees and require more gas. Paper production is, generally speaking, a heavily polluting industry. You can certainly argue that paper is worse than plastic too. It's not clear cut. It's sort of like asking if it's better to eat fast food everyday or to smoke. Both are bad, but in very different ways so it depends on how you compare risk of cancer / lung problems to obesity. This is much like the paper vs. plastic debate, except there's even more factors to consider. Ultimately, you can argue equally well that either one is better or worse.Plastic is not necessarily worse for the environment than reusable cloth / canvas bags [2]. How could this be? Because plastic bags have less environmental impact per bag than reusable bags. This should be expected - reusable bags are way more durable, and thus take a lot more energy to produce. It's only through reuse that reusable bags compensate for their far, far greater environmental impact. The thing is though that reusable bags are reused an average of 50 times and it's looking like it takes 130+ or more reuses to compensate for the additional environmental impact of reusable bags. D'oh!Plastic bags are a lot more convenient. With a large load of groceries, the paper bags get very bulky. They fill up an entire [plastic!] trash bag by themselves. The handles are flimsy and tear. You can't carry as much in one, or carry as many bags at once. Plastic bags can be reused for lunch bags, dog poop, bathroom / small trash can liners, and other things. In many cases, not getting plastic bags "for free" at the grocery stores means going out and purchasing them instead.So, given equal (or equally unclear) harm or to the environment, I'll go with the more convenient option.The bans in particular frustrate me because they're a knee-jerk reaction based on false science that greatly inconvenience people. If you're going to ban plastic bags, then it needs to be very clear that they're substantially worse. That's just not the case. I'm all for getting serious about the environment and legislating some changes, but it needs to be actually better. It can't just be an assumption that takes into account only one factor (trash production).And, to make matters worse, people aren't focusing on where they could make a difference: educate people on recycling and make it more convenient. For example, why not require apartment buildings to have a recycling bin next to the mailboxes? Why not spend more effort educating people on what can be recycled? There is so much more work to be done here. I think these bans are focusing on the wrong areas.Some studies to get you started on paper vs. plastic vs. reusable bags:[1] Paper vs. Plastic: (a) Myth: Paper is Better Than Plastic (b) A New Look at the Bag Scourge[2] Disposable Bags vs. Reusable Bags:(a) A Survey on the Economic Effects of Los Angeles County’s Plastic Bag Ban, (b) Paper or Plastic? The Answer Might Surprise You (c) Political  Calculations - Paper, Plastic or Cloth: Which Bag is Best for the Environment? (d) Study: Plastic grocery bags better than canvas?  Embed Quote

column9: Plastic bags are harming our environment; isn't it a no brainer they should not be made anymore?
column10: I have reluctantly supported various efforts at bans.  Not many people do, apparently.That said, we like the bags and use them for lots of things before dropping them into the recycle bin.IMHO, the core problem is the sheer utility of the bags.  One can carry an insane amount of grocery in ONE HAND, leaving the other free to navigate the various things between the stash of newly acquired groceries and their home at home.  For some reason, I've always hated lugging them into the house.  Fewer trips make that task better.The bags work with the carts very well too.  Using paper sucks, there are tears and such.  Plastic tears too, but I've just not noticed the apocalyptic disasters with plastic that I've experienced with paper, especially paper containing glass. Around the house, they can be used to contain lots of basic things, and are great poop insulators.  When we did not have unified "one stop" recycling, the bags didn't always get recycled, and we tried to reuse, but it wasn't very good.  Adding that service everywhere possible would do a lot of damage on the problem.  "just put it in there, no worries" type recycling is awesome!  If it's got the symbol, do it!  A fantastic number of things can be recycled now.  We've done the work, now we need to improve collections.Frankly, this is a great opportunity for somebody.  Make plastic bags, or something like plastic bags that reduce into something else, good for a coupla days, or weeks, and people would adopt them rapidly, assuming material properties that keep the benefits of the bags intact.And that's why!  The utility of the bags exceeds the pain perception of the problem.  Embed Quote

column9: Plastic bags are harming our environment; isn't it a no brainer they should not be made anymore?
column10: I oppose the bans. Banning plastic bags sends a message: if people think that something is bad for the environment, then ban it, and ban it in isolation. Like it or not, plastic bags are just minutia. I mean, look at the contents of your shopping cart. The plastic bag is probably the least amount of packaging out of everything you're buying. Plastic bags aren't a one-dimensional environmental decision. Does it cost more to transport other bags besides plastic ones? How many saved plastic bags equal the amount of material required to produce a reusable bag or a paper bag? Even bundling everything together as an "environmental decision" is problematic. How much landfill space is equal to one gallon of diesel emissions? Do alternatives spend more fuel in the process than plastic bags? What percentage of plastic bags are recycled? Does recycling itself pose environmental hazards?The same thing happens frequently with bottled water. People are outraged over the extra packaging that is produced and thrown away and that we're shipping water across the country, but ultimately... no one is upset about doing the same thing with Coke or Pepsi. So shipping and packaging water is terrible because of its environmental effects, but if you carbonate it and add corn syrup and flavoring then it's forgivable?Disclosure: I work in the packaging industry, but my company has no stake in the choice of paper vs. plastic vs. reusable packaging.  Embed Quote

column9: Plastic bags are harming our environment; isn't it a no brainer they should not be made anymore?
column10: There are (much) better ways to drastically reduce use of plastic bags with advantageous second order effects than banning plastic bags outright.There are few times when Welsh policy influences the rest of the UK and Europe but they did something very smart to reduce plastic bag consumption by up to 90%[1]. They introduced a mandatory charge of 5 pence (10 cents) per bag.Some consumers saw this as an extra tax or way to make money but the majority supported the idea. Clerks have to ask customers how many bags they want and remind them there is a charge.82% of Welsh shoppers bring their own multi-use bags to do their groceries [2]. This is a major behavioural change. Those that used the single use bags used less, opting to pack the bags more efficiently.It turns out that associating a cash value to plastic bags led to a major shift in the way people thought about them. They were no longer free and worthless, but an expense that can be avoided.I noticed when I moved to San Francisco that there were no plastic bags and instead they used these huge thick brown paper (actually more like card) bags. I was not impressed. This is like replacing one vice with another. Better to incentivise bringing your own bag.[1] Carrier bag reduction up to 90%[2] Bag charge 'can help all of UK'  Embed Quote

column9: Plastic bags are harming our environment; isn't it a no brainer they should not be made anymore?
column10: This a very interesting question, actually.The answer in my mind is a mixture of things, most of which has been beautifully described here already. I just want to present 1 observation from my life to point out a positive externality of plastic bags.I remember when I was a kid and I lived with my grandparents for a while the situation with the garbage was the following:My grandma had a plastic bucket and all garbage went there. Roughly once a day (or once in 2 days) we took that bucket out and in big metal containers that were serviced by garbage trucks. And 90% of the people did that.TODAYEveryone is packaging their garbage into the bags, To the end point this doesn't matter (the garbage either gets dumped on special sites, or burnt or recycled) BUT to the city that makes a massive difference. Most of the garbage is "prepacked" therefore there is much less of it lying around.We buy food from the store, we put that food in the plastic bags, we then use those bags for garbage packaging - its a very efficient system!Thus no one wants to abandon it.  Embed Quote

column9: Plastic bags are harming our environment; isn't it a no brainer they should not be made anymore?
column10: Quite the contrary, in my opinion it's a no-brainer that plastic bags are awesome. This article puts it well: In Defense of Plastic BagsWhat stood out the most to me was the wasted time. I saw checkout people asking everyone ahead of me in line how many bags they wanted. They were slowing down the whole line.At Trader Joe’s, the checkout person actually had to cancel my checkout, after my credit card was already processed, to add a bag fee. She tried to guess how many bags I needed, without asking, in order to save time. But she got it wrong. Everyone behind me had to wait.…Why would anyone want to ban plastic bags? They are light, clean, strong, cheap and useful. Grocery stores chose them for a reason: because plastic bags work great.…Another issue with the plastic bag ban is health:I want to stress the importance of buying WASHABLE bags and recommend that you wash them in hot water very frequently. … I won’t be specific, but I had a family member that worked In grocery and shared horror stories of the filth and unsanitary reusable bags handed to them by customers. One word: maggots.Unsanitary and disgusting! Note that we’re not just talking about convenience or aesthetics. This has deadly consequences: banning plastic bags in the entire U.S. would kill 1,380 people per year.  Embed Quote

column9: Plastic bags are harming our environment; isn't it a no brainer they should not be made anymore?
column10: Grocery shopping on foot provides a purpose and objective for daily walks in the city and by the beach. The major complaint about paper bags with handles like Whole Foods is that the handle cuts into your fingers as you walk (assumes no winter gloves). Especially on multi-mile walks where the slight swing of one's arms turns the handles into dull saws by the time you reach your destination.Please no hectoring about bringing my own bags and strangling baby seals - we know about that. I am speaking about the freedom to shop spontaneously while enjoying a healthful walk.  Embed Quote

column9: Plastic bags are harming our environment; isn't it a no brainer they should not be made anymore?
column10: As you can see, there are lots of reasons people object. My concern is that this is just another knee-jerk environmentally motivated response that seems like the right thing intuitively but may not be better at all. Like hybrid cars or corn ethanol. The two problems we're trying to solve, as I understand them, are pollution and energy consumption. Carbon is on everyone's list of pollution issues (those who think there is a problem, anyway) but the chances that the energy to make anything comes from carbon based sources are so overwhelming I'm just assuming carbon footprint is a wash. Does a plastic bag ban solve the pollution problem? Not really. Yes, you'll see fewer paper or cloth bags on the side of the road. But most of our garbage winds up as pollution anyway - just because we localize the pollution in huge landfills or dump it where no one can see it doesn't mean it actually goes away. It just goes away from you. And those tissue paper thin plastic bags degrade faster than paper.Take a good look at that fabric bag your grocer just sold you for a dollar. Cheaply made of non-renewable materials. Might last you a year of regular use, if you're lucky. And what happens to it then? It ends up in the landfill right next to most of the plastic bags, which will be gone long before it is. Yes, the $10 bags they sell at Whole Foods last a lot longer, and are made of natural fibers. But that isn't what most people are using for "reusable grocery bags". No one has ever cut down a hardwood forest so they could plant trees for pulp. They plant trees for pulp after the hardwood has been cleared and sold. Paper doesn't cause old growth deforestation. As for energy, do we know how much energy it takes to make a plastic bag? A paper bag? A fabric bag? Someone does, but the people passing these laws don't.If we're really trying to save the planet, lets take a minute and see what the consequences of our decisions are going to be before we jump in to these things.  Embed Quote

column9: Plastic bags are harming our environment; isn't it a no brainer they should not be made anymore?
column10: Because of a combination of laziness, habit, and rationalization. Plastic bags are convenient and ubiquitous. Even those who pay attention and recognize the environmental impact still don't think about it before they walk into a store. Someone who remembers with a cart half full of groceries isn't likely to walk back out to get a bag from the car.I doubt that most stores have any interest in curtailing plastic bag use. We live in a society where purchasing habits have been carefully studied and scrutinized (see Paco Underhill's books on the subject) to optimize store layouts and attend to any little detail of shopping that might potentially interfere with our buying everything in sight impulsively, without a second thought to whether or not we actually need it or can afford it. It is in the stores' interest to make the shopping experience as frictionless as possible, which includes keeping lines short, as well as happily handing out advertising-laden bags to convey the new purchases home. They are not now free, but the charge is figured into the cost of our purchases at some point. Occasionally, it is refunded if we bring our own bags, but I wonder whether most stores really want customers wandering around with opaque canvas bags. (Aside: when I bring my bag, I sometimes use it in lieu of a cart or basket. I buy less that way, which is certainly not what the stores want. I am limited to what I can easily carry, which is important to me if I arrived on foot—not exactly a typical suburban behavior. If I were a store manager, though, I expect I would just see one more potential means of shoplifting each time a canvas bag walked in.)For those shoppers who bother to notice and think about it, there is another sort of justification. How bad, goes the reasoning, could my one or two bags be? We can recycle them, right? Of course, the problem isn't that there are one or two bags, but that there are one or two bags per person, per purchase, times billions of people times thousands of purchases.Yet the day-to-day consumer sees only a few bags at a time. S/he does not see the volume of bags generated by even a single store for a single day (much less a world's worth of stores over the course of decades), or the great garbage patches in the ocean. S/he does not see the fact that there is truly no "away" in "throw away," or the still relatively minuscule percentage of bags that actually do get recycled, or the energy and resources that went into manufacturing the bags in the first place.S/he sees, instead, that bags are there (as they always have been), they are free, they are pretty handy for carrying stuff and keeping wet and sticky stuff from messing up the car, that one or two aren't really so bad. Besides, they're handy for lining the trash can and picking up after the dog. If the public is so opposed to plastic bag bans (how presumptuous of our government to try to tell us what is good for us!), a good intermediate measure would be to charge a small but noticeable fee per bag, perhaps 25¢. They would be there for those who really do still need them, but it would be an incentive for people to bring back bags, and to think twice about double bagging and bagging fewer items in each bag. Here's how it works in Sweden. A store customer may buy a bag by picking it up in front of the check stand and adding it to his or her order. It is rung up like any other item. These bags are generally a little larger and sturdier than the bags here, so fewer are needed, they invite reuse, and they hold up to taking the train or bus home. The purchases, once scanned, are placed in a divided tray behind the checker. Someone (usually the customer, after paying) bags the groceries. The checker then slides the tray divider to the other side and checks the next person's purchases into that side. It's not so drastically different from how we do things here, but I believe they are much more aware of how many bags they use.  Embed Quote

column9: Plastic bags are harming our environment; isn't it a no brainer they should not be made anymore?
column10: I will get in trouble offering any rationalization for not banning the bags.  For many folks the plastic bag, when used judiciously, comes in handy for dog shit and lining a trash can.  Many towns do not offer a method for separately collecting wet garbage, so a plastic bag is necessary with wet trash.  If there is no trash, or the trash is dry, then there is no reason to have a plastic bag; however, we have not reached that end state - trash is still wet.  What I have discovered unfortunately in my household is that now that our town has the plastic bag ban (Palo Alto, CA), we have started buying rolls of plastic bags to be trash can liners etc. We even happily shop in other towns that still offer a few of those useful plastic bags.  I would have preferred a policy mode whereby we could inspire reusable bags for shopping, but not make the plastic bag illegal.  Perhaps the symbolism of the bag ban is good, but I am just not sure the science is behind it. Unknown is how many households now are buying plastic bags to replace the ones not used by the shopping stores.  Embed Quote

column9: Plastic bags are harming our environment; isn't it a no brainer they should not be made anymore?
column10: Lots of good reasons have already been given.  I agree with most.  I would add that here in Rochester, there was a big push about a year ago to get everyone to buy cloth bags.  I keep a bunch in my backseat.  But they always seem to hold less than plastic bags.  I know this sounds like it must violate a conservation law.  But the footprint of the bag is fixed, even when it's less than completely full. It's hard to know how many to take in.  Maybe a new design would solve these problems.  Bottom line:  Over the last six months I've seen fewer and fewer people in the checkout line with cloth bags.  Also, in Austin, TX, where my mother-in-law lives, the city council has outlawed the plastic bags.  So, people have to buy plastic garbage bags since the garbage pick up companies want everything packaged inside the garbage cans.Edit - One more re-use of the bags:  A friend has a mail order business. In these difficult economic times he is able to save money by using the bags as fill in boxes he ships, rather than spend money on Styrofoam "peanuts."  I haven't seen an analysis but I think Styrofoam might be worse for the environment.  Embed Quote

column9: Plastic bags are harming our environment; isn't it a no brainer they should not be made anymore?
column10: I walked into a deli in Byron Bay (kind of like Boulder, but by the ocean in Australia) about ten years ago.I bought a drink, and on the counter next to the cash register was a container full of straws with a yellow and black sign that read:PLEASE HELP YOURSELF TO ANOTHER USELESS PIECE OF PLASTIC AT THE EXPENSE OF THE ENVIRONMENTI asked the owner when the last time was that someone had taken a straw - he said not in the six years since he had put up the sign.Telling people that it's harmful to the environment and to future generations, as well as whales, dolphins, sea-otters and mermaids is one thing.Making people feel ashamed and embarrassed for doing something stupid, unnecessary and dangerous is another thing altogether.Nobody wants to look like an idiot.  Embed Quote

column9: Plastic bags are harming our environment; isn't it a no brainer they should not be made anymore?
column10: Lots of great answers here. From my perspective I see this debate from a longer view:1955-1980 Paper bags were fine.1980 We were told that paper bags were destroying our rain forests. "Save The Trees", was the hue and cry! Switch to plastic.1995 We were told "Plastic Is Killing Birds!"I obeyed and switched from paper to plastic. There used to be two phrases that are now totally passé:"Paper or Plastic?""Smoking or Non-Smoking?"Now what do we switch to? Cloth sacks. Great, they are re-usable and have a friggin' handle. Glad we solved that issue ...... Not so fast! Now we find these cute reusable, non-paper, non-plastic bags contain LEAD. Yes, the paint used to print ads and cute images on cloth bags contain lead in the ink!!!But, problem is finally solved at last.Groceries are so expensive you can't afford a whole bag of food. You can just carry your stuff in your hands. No paper, plastic or lead required....next environmental issue is expected any day now...That is the problem period  Embed Quote

column9: Plastic bags are harming our environment; isn't it a no brainer they should not be made anymore?
column10: Because it takes forever to grow a plastic tree. And because it's a gateway throw away, just like excessive packaging. The proper workaround is a reusable conveyance, but because that requires mental effort, we justify the plastic bag "just this once, because I forgot mine". It justifies the very notion of disposable. This is something that was made to be thrown away.  Embed Quote

column9: Plastic bags are harming our environment; isn't it a no brainer they should not be made anymore?
column10: People (especially us Americans) don't like being told by government that they can't do something. So why give them something to oppose? The grocery store I went to earlier tonight gave me a five cent discount for each reusable bag I brought with me. If they were to take that one step further and charge for plastic bags, as others have done, you could make a significant dent in plastic bag use without raising much opposition or inconveniencing anyone. With a significant drop in plastic bag use, people might be more willing to live with a ban.  Embed Quote

column9: Plastic bags are harming our environment; isn't it a no brainer they should not be made anymore?
column10: Myself being a social thinker and humble fan of nature's beauty, I feel plastic ban is not a bad idea, however I could think of some of the key reasons for the opposition. 1. People are Self centered People tend to be self centered and infact there is nothing wrong about it. Plastics are cheap, comfortable, durable and ubiquitous, making them best fit for everyday use. Plastic has become vital like electricity for majority. Ban to such a product obviously won't be favored by majority.  2. No proper substitutes There is no proper substitues for plastic bags that are equally good, cheap, comfortable and durable. Paper bags could be a substitute but it's niether environment friendly nor comfortable nor durable. Paper production requires hundreds of thousands of gallons of water as well as toxic chemicals like sulphurous acid, which can lead to acid rain and water pollution. Jute bags could be comfortable and durable but not cheap. Hence there is no effective substitute for plastic bags as of now. 3. Less awareness about impacts and environmental degradation plastic causesMost people are not aware about the impacts of plastic and the amount of environmental degradation that plastics have caused.Plastic causes serious damage to environment both during its production and disposal. It is a non-biodegradable material composed of toxic chemicals it pollutes not only ecosystems but human health. If plastic get into the environment it is a hazard to all life living in the water environment and land. Fish, birds, marine mammals, reptiles, and other animals can become entangled in discarded plastics and sustain injuries from ingesting plastics. Thus they don't find sufficient reasons to ban plastics from their perception.4. Lack of knowledge on the scales of consumption Most people are driven by thought that 'I use just 1 or 2 plastic bags per day, how can that be a threat to environment?' howerver the scale of consumption is beyond their perceptionPlastic bags in USA alone [1] Approx. 380 billion plastic bags are used in the United States every year. That’s more than 1,200 bags per US resident, per year.Approx. 100 billion of the 380 billion are plastic shopping bags.An estimated 12 million barrels of oil is required to make that many plastic bags.Only 1 to 2% of plastic bags in the USA end up getting recycled.Thousands of marine animals and more than 1 million birds die each year as a result of plastic pollution.The United Nations Environment Programme estimates that there are 46,000 pieces of plastic litter floating in every square mile of ocean.Plastic bags are often mistakenly ingested by animals, clogging their intestines which results in death by starvation. Other animals or birds become entangled in plastic bags and drown or can’t fly as a result.Even when they photo-degrade in landfill, the plastic from single-use bags never goes away, and toxic particles can enter the food chain when they are ingested by unsuspecting animals.Greenpeace says that at least 267 marine species are known to have suffered from getting entangled in or ingesting marine debris. Nearly 90% of that debris is plastic.Americans consume more than 10 billion paper bags per year. Approximately 14 million trees are cut down every year for paper bag production.Possible alternates to plastic banI suggest plastics can be dealt by government the way they deal with tobacco products like cigarette. Increased taxation Making it mandatory to include Warning message: 'Avoid plastics, it degrades our beautiful environment'  to each plastic bagFine civilians for improper disposal of plastics Banning plastic in reserved areas for tourism, wildlife and bird sanctuaries Support jute products, reduce taxes for jute companiesSource: [1] Dangers of plastic bags  Embed Quote

column9: Plastic bags are harming our environment; isn't it a no brainer they should not be made anymore?
column10: Because people hate being told what to do and when has banning something ever really worked that well?I think there are better alternatives to a ban.Plastic bags are bad because they are around for forever.1) Make bags that are not low density polyethylene (LDPE) that can degrade into something like a fertilizer maybe by enzymatic catalysis, UV-Light, or hydrolysis.2) Enact a plastic bag tax where each bag is five addition cents to whatever that person might buy. Washington DC and Montgomery County (Maryland) have both enacted these policies after SF did showed that it could work. I saw people buying 100 dollars worth of groceries refuse to pay 20 cents for bags to carry them to their car and just insisted on putting their food back into their cart and transporting it out loosely. People will go crazy to save just that little bit of money if they can.Plastic bags are also extremely cheap to make and since they are bad for the environment there should be a tax on their consumption (like taxing cigarettes) to counteract the strain they put on our environment so make them expensive enough to where the price outweighs the convenience and no more plastic bags.  Embed Quote

column9: Plastic bags are harming our environment; isn't it a no brainer they should not be made anymore?
column10: One of the reasons I believe there is so much opposition, in addition to what's already been posted,  is due to the fact that many people re-use the plastic bags they get from grocery shopping. Many folks re-use them to transport items at a later date and a large number of people use them as trash bags. I support banning of plastic bags though not much thought is paid to trash can liners which are made of much heavier material and are used in most households; each household with multiple trash cans. This adds up to a massive amount of these bags in landfills and this is one of the reasons I came up with a patent-pending easy clean bagless trash can. You can learn more about it at : .  Hopefully there will come a time when plastic bag bans are in full effect world wide!  Embed Quote

column9: Plastic bags are harming our environment; isn't it a no brainer they should not be made anymore?
column10: The main reason is that it's a ban.Just about anything in our modern built environment was made through a process that harmed the environment, so why single out plastic bags and incandescent bulbs?  We ban things when they are disproportionately dangerous to ourselves and our environment (DDT, Lead paint) but for everything else, it's a trade-off.The right policy response to these issues is a tax or fee to offset the external harm they do.  And since you don't want to be taxing harm in one form but not in another, you should be applying the tax at the root level.  In this case, petroleum.This is why a carbon tax on fossil fuels is a popular idea.  It avoids the minutae of banning this or that use, subsidizing this or that alternative energy source, and setting mandates for efficiency one industry at a time.  Price carbon correctly, and everything falls into place.  Wasteful products become prohibitively expensive.  Efficient alternatives become the most cost-effective option without the need for subsidies.  And individuals still get to choose what they spend their money on.  Embed Quote

column9: Plastic bags are harming our environment; isn't it a no brainer they should not be made anymore?
column10: Plastic bags are not as environmentally damaging as we are led to believe.  One important way to measure the ecological effect of a product is to calculate its "embodied energy" or the amount of energy it takes to mine the materials to produce the product, to manufacture the product, to transport the product, the use the product, and to dispose of the product.  And the plastic bag is EXTREMELY efficient.  For every paper bag, 100 plastic bags can be produced for the same amount of embodied energy.Now, there are other factors than embodied energy, like physical damage to the environment and how easily the product breaks down.  Plastic doesn't break down as easily as paper, but paper requires an enormous amount of water in its manufacture and it causes a great deal of pollution.  Furthermore, manufacturers are getting better and better at producing plastic bags that decompose faster.  And plastic bags can be reused more often than paper bags.Plastic bag bans are BAD for the environment.  Embed Quote

column9: Plastic bags are harming our environment; isn't it a no brainer they should not be made anymore?
column10: I am convinced the main, underlying reason why no ban of plastic shopping bags currently has a chance in the US is a combination of customer apathy and the enormous power of two different lobbies in the halls of both state capitols around the country and in Washington; namely the chemicals industry and the national retailers association, which represents mostly huge national retail chains (not small independent stores like mine). Plastic bags are an anachronistic symbol of old retail concepts suitable for a world where everything was meant to be disposable. We should know better by now.   Embed Quote

column9: Plastic bags are harming our environment; isn't it a no brainer they should not be made anymore?
column10: Have you ever considered what materials you would be using if all plastic bags were to disappear all of a sudden? Do you think the manufacture glass or paper is not an energy intensive process?  Embed Quote

column9: Plastic bags are harming our environment; isn't it a no brainer they should not be made anymore?
column10: There is opposition to ban plastic bags because nobody wants to move their butt and bring their own bags for shopping trips, especially since stores are all too happy to spend a little extra and provide bags to their customers. If 'bring your own bag' was enforced everywhere, we will automatically begin to manufacture, sell and buy non-disposable bags.It is a bit like wanting all kinds of produce at all times of the year. Once you know it can be done, counter-arguments, such as how your lettuce and beans are driven in (or even flown in some cases) don't work. Oranges in the New England winter? F' Yeah! I can walk into a store empty handed whenever I want and buy a week's worth of stuff? Of course.People want to care about the environment, but only after their own comforts are secured.  In this direction, sustainability initiatives are almost always PR stunts. What can be said in the case of Plastic vs. Paper can be said about Hybrids vs. regular cars too in terms of overall environmental impact. It is true, as many have mentioned here, that paper vs. plastic is a trade off. Any kind of disposable bags constitute a huge mass in the supply+disposal chain, which takes money and oil to run. Get your own bag(s). Bags that last. It is not that hard.  Embed Quote

column9: Plastic bags are harming our environment; isn't it a no brainer they should not be made anymore?
column10: I am very much in support for bans on plastic bags. Right now, there are no incentives for consumers to not use plastic bags and the indifference of most people causes bags to pile up in drawers, the ocean, etc. The way I see it, it's on the stores to do something about this issue. People who don't care aren't going to change, so we might as well not even give them the option to use plastic bags. You can see more at the petition I started: http://www.thepetitionsite.com/1...  Embed Quote

Plastic bottles and other forms of plastic have a higher recycle rate of 20-35%.[1]Plastic usually ends up on highways, waterways and litter dumps. column9: It had every opportunity to choose a different path and no one was agitating for the freedom of the open road. So why foul the nest?
column10: I find the rapid spread of auto ownership to be a lamentable trend (living as I do in an increasingly smoggy and gridlocked Beijing), but I think I understand the mentality behind it. For a while there was official resistance to it: licensing was prohibitively expensive, not to mention the exorbitant tariffs on imported automobiles (at a time with the domestic Chinese auto industry was negligible). Domestic consumer desire was, as far as I can tell, what drove the development of the industry--not. as with many other industries, the lure of export markets. So we need to look at why so many ordinary Chinese citizens found car culture so alluring.One simple reason is that American culture--America has never been shy about promoting its way of life--has for so long so venerated the automobile. So much of our pop culture, from rock and hip hop songs to Hollywood movies, pushes it out there. It's a symbol of individualism, an expression of the self, the ultimate consumer item and it's so celebrated in our culture. Why wouldn't Chinese aspire to it?Because it's environmentally irresponsible, of course. That sounds reasonable enough to recent American converts to environmentalism. Of course many of them have owned a car and been driving since their mid teens. Chinese tend to bristle at this and find it insufferably patronizing. You've had your turn at the trough now for a hundred years, guzzling down fossil fuels and putting more carbon in the air, cumulatively, than China has by many multiples. Now it's China's turn, the thinking goes. It's shortsighted and entirely regrettable, of course, but part of me can be empathetic. Chinese friends of mine have described the feeling like this: China arrives late, still hungry and still skinny as a rail, and takes its seat at a banquet already long in progress. Sitting around the table are corpulent and morbidly obese Western countries, who immediately browbeat the new arrival as he reaches for the prime rib, regaling him with woeful tales of their gout, their diabetes, their fatty livers, their clogged arteries--all the result of a lifetime of overindulgence. "Eat vegetables," they say to China. "Stay away from meat and dairy, or  you'll end up like us."  Embed QuoteAnswered in twenty-four minutes.

column9: It had every opportunity to choose a different path and no one was agitating for the freedom of the open road. So why foul the nest?
column10: For the government of China, automobiles are second only to electrification as a massive driver of industrial and economic development. The auto industry will also be largely a domestic industry, with a good size export factor.  What can substitute for a large auto industry? I can't think of anything, even massive military production. The rest of the world is already pushing back at exports from China - so a massive growth in exports is not an option,Are automobiles an appropriate technology for China ? China is still 57% rural.  http://www.landingchina.com/chin...If we look at this map, we will see there are some big high density areas (red and dark orange) - but there are also huge areas with population densities lower than most US suburbs - the light orange and the medium orange.There is also extensive rural poverty.  To end this poverty cars will be needed to so people in rural areas can get to rural cities to work, and buy and sell farm products - just like in the Midwestern US and the Great Plains states.  That is a model that has been shown to work.So the answer is yes, not only are cars (& trucks) appropriate, not only the best solution for rural areas, but in many cases the only solution.  Bullet trains aren't going to be built in the sticks (only California is stupid enough to do that)China is not just giant cities like Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Beijing.Environmental impacts  will be much less than expected. First, every car built today gets recycled, and has a high recycled metal content. So once the fleet is built, metal consumption drops.Electricity will provide most of the power, not gasoline.Natural gas from shale will supply much of the energy for transport.The cars will have pollution controls, and get high mileage.How many cars and trucks will be needed? Much less than we would think.  Look at the demographics of China in the age pyramid -http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dem...Notice how sharp narrowing of the number of young people, primarily due to the one child policy. Using the US numbers for 1960 of 180 million people and 75 million cars, I would take a SWAG and say that a fleet of ~ 300 million would work for 2025, for a rural population of about 600 million. That's around 15 million a year, current production is about 13 million per year, with 1 million exports.I think a Chinese car culture would be cool. The potential for incredible road trips - on new, smooth highways - would be great.  I think I would be great if Chinese young people could use a car to get out of their parents house's and drive somewhere to go makeout.If China, with 5000 years of civilization, chooses to copy what the US is doing, that is very flattering, and it is really bad form to discourage this.I like Kaiser's banquet analogy.As for the US lecturing China on economic development, that's about as stupid as Calpers requesting changes in the way Steve Jobs runs Apple. It is amazing to me that the PRC financial ministries have only told the US to STFU a few times.  Embed Quote

column9: It had every opportunity to choose a different path and no one was agitating for the freedom of the open road. So why foul the nest?
column10: One problem that China faces that factors into this new car culture is necessity. In many ways the dramatic turnaround in the US economy at the end of WWII and the increase of discharged GI's entering the civilian workforce drove a construction boom that centered around development of suburban areas. This was possible because of the wide availability of automobiles and their relative affordability. In China this development has occured backwards to that of the States. Local governments, in order to meet their budgetary requirements, rely on the sale of land use rights to fill their coffers.  This leads to massive urban sprawl and poor urban planning for many of the the newly minted 2nd and 3rd tier cities. This, in turn, spawns a demand for personal transportation that is not only serviced by the luxury segment but also affordable local automobiles, electric mopeds and three wheelers. This is perpetuated by cities mimicking urban design themes from Beijing that are intended to convey grandiosity and authority rather than practical urban planning for, what should be, a largely pedestrian population. If you head to many of these cities' new areas, they are often  vacant and soulless places intersected by four lane buleavards that lead to no where. So if you live in a mid-rise apartment far from the city center, some form of personal transportation is practically a necessity for your daily life.  Embed Quote

column9: It had every opportunity to choose a different path and no one was agitating for the freedom of the open road. So why foul the nest?
column10: It hasn't.China is spending a ton of money on Public Transport, and infrastructure. You can get by in most major cities without a car if you just have a motor scooter.The thing though is that China is big, so as China is doing everything it can to avoid the some sort of car culture in the United States, you end up with massive amounts of people on the road, simply because you have a billion people. The per capita car ownership rate in China is low, but anything times a billion means traffic jams.Also, there are some paradoxes and ironies. Chinese government policy in general tries to make it very difficult to own a car. There is a wait list for car registration and license plates, and there are taxes and large expenses associated with a car. The paradox is that because it is so difficult to own a car, it becomes a huge status symbol, because having a car means that you are either rich or politically connected, and so every upwardly mobile middle class family wants a car so that they can show it off to their neighbors.  Embed Quote

column9: It had every opportunity to choose a different path and no one was agitating for the freedom of the open road. So why foul the nest?
column10: "Speed provides the one genuinely modern pleasure" - Aldous Huxley.  Embed Quote

column9: It had every opportunity to choose a different path and no one was agitating for the freedom of the open road. So why foul the nest?
column10: A pretty broad question, and I'm not sure if "chosen" is appropriate to include in the question either (though I could make a case for it). I think cars have always appealed as status symbols and the Chinese, like everyone else, are creatures of vanity. That, for starters, is what I'd offer as an explanation for the demand side. For the supply side, I believe the automotive industry (manufacturing) is a good source of employment for China's population. I'm speaking broadly here, but I don't think it is difficult to understand China following both Japan and South Korea's footsteps in using auto manufacturing as a key step in their economic development. The pollution, congestion, and sprawl that results have therefore been decided to be acceptable costs and, in some cases, even desirable (it suggests things are a happenin'!)I'm going to cut it short here and 1) hope Kaiser Kuo provides a better answer since I see him currently answering as well, and 2) consider editing my answer for more later. Overall though, I'm worried that this question is too broad to adequately answer without the answer spanning several screens.  Embed QuoteAnswered in seventeen minutes.

column10: It's a wrong question. column10: China is a growing nation and has taken a proven, established route for success by copying existing models in other industrialized countries.The automotive industry in North America is one of the largest drivers of economy. China recognizes this and would like to drive it's economy also. The car is the icon of materialism. Many Chinese would like to have a piece of the same opulence that North Americans have enjoyed for decades. Unfortunately, the quick expansion of the automotive (and other) industries in China has also caused some environmental issues which have not been checked as in North America. Many of the issues China is seeing today are a mirror image of the same issues in North America many decades ago. Although China has it's own manufacturers, many of the North American Companies also have a large presence in China. A higher standard of living in North America has also brought about higher costs of manufacturing. In an attempt to lower costs, North American manufacturers now have very large facilities in China. This has been a huge economic benefit to the Chinese at the expense of the North Americans. Not to mention, China is benefiting from huge strides in emissions control, quality and safety that North American vehicle manufacturers have built into their cars over the decades. This type of technology can ultimately help China as they bring control to their industrialization.  Embed Quote

column9: I've read that coal-burning is a source of Hg in fish... and also that there is naturally-occurring Hg in the ocean... where is the Hg in fish today coming from?
column10: The mercury found in fish comes from both anthropogenic (human-made/induced) and "natural"sources. However, it should be noted that "natural" mercury emissions are accounted as including re-emission of both anthropogenic and "natural" deposits, and that re-emission of previously anthropogenically-attributable mercury has been estimated to account for 50% of all "natural" land and ocean emissions into the atmosphere (Lindberg et al. 2007, pg. 20). So, mercury vapor entering the atmosphere from an open field would be counted as a "natural" emission, even if that mercury had been deposited in that field as a result of a nearby coal-fired power plant.Mercury cycles through the environment, so the question of where the mercury found in fish comes from depends on how many steps back you go. The short version is that mercury in fish comes from what they eat, including plants, crustaceans, and other fish. Mercury bioaccumulates up the food chain, which is why top predatory fish have higher concentrations than those at the bottom of the food chain. The mercury bioaccumulating up the food chain (and the one of major concern to human health) is methylmercury (MeHg), which has been converted from inorganic mercury by bacteria living at the sedimentary level. This methylmercury is then taken up by the marine food web, and also explains why bottom-dwelling animals tend to have higher mercury concentrations than you would otherwise expect.The mercury in sediment has settled from the water. Mercury enters the water from atmospheric and terrestrial deposition. There is run-off from surface deposits, direct dumping, settling of mercury-laden atmospheric particulates, mercury-laden rain, etc. A 2002 paper by Mason and Shau (see bottom of comment reference) estimated that atmospheric deposition into the oceans accounted for around 15.4 times that of surface deposition.According to a 2010 estimate by Pirrone et al., annual "natural" emissions to the atmosphere (including re-emission of anthropogenic emissions) totalled 5207 megagrams (5,207,000 kilograms), while annual anthropogenic emissions totalled 2320 megagrams (2,320,000 kilograms). The study found that "fossil-fuel fired power plants, ferrous and non-ferrous metals manufacturing facilities, caustic soda production plants, ore processing facilities, incinerators for urban, medical and industrial wastes, cement plants and chemicals production facilities" released significant amounts of mercury into the atmosphere, and that "fossil fuel-fired power plants are the largest point sources of mercury released to the atmosphere" (Pirrone et al. 2010, pg. 4726). It's also important to note that mercury concentrations are higher near their source, so fish living in an area close to coal-fired power plants are likely to have higher concentrations than those that are not. Deposits in sediment and elsewhere may also endure for a long time, so closure of a plant or other point source may not reduce risk for years or decades. My doctoral thesis, Fish Consumption, Mercury Intake, and the Associated Risks to the Kuwaiti Population, considers the past presence of a nearby chlorine and bleach processing plant that had used mercury cathodes as a possible contributor to mercury concentrations in fish in the Arabian Gulf, though the plant closed in the 1970s.I'll have a look for historical databases on mercury concentrations in fish and let you know if something comes up. For which region were you looking for information?- Mey AkashahReferences:Akashah, M. (2010), Fish Consumption, Mercury Intake, and the Associated Risks to the Kuwaiti Population, Harvard School of Public Health.Lindberg, S., et al. (2007), “A Synthesis of Progress and Uncertainties in Attributing the Sources of Mercury in Deposition," Ambio, Vol. 36, No. 1, pp. 19-32.Mason, R.P. and Sheu, G.R. (2002), "Role of the ocean in the global mercury cycle," Glob. Biogeochem. Cycles, Vol. 16, pg. 093.Pirrone, N. et al. (2010), "Global mercury emissions to the atmosphere from anthropogenic and natural sources," Atmos. Chem. Phys. Discuss., Vol. 10, pp. 4719–4752.  Embed Quote

column9: Yesterday (12/6/2013) Shanghai AQI over 500, and most of city in China, AQI over 200-300.How do you think China's future, and will continue live or work in China?
column10: Respirator Masks are a cool fashion accessoryIt adds to the "Future dystopia" charm of Beijing. Now all I need is more sandstorms so I have an excuse to wear goggles too.  Embed Quote

column9: Yesterday (12/6/2013) Shanghai AQI over 500, and most of city in China, AQI over 200-300.How do you think China's future, and will continue live or work in China?
column10: I look on the bright side and think: "At least I'm in Beijing, a first-tier city where media scrutiny will hopefully shame authorities into taking some action, even if it's short term."Spare a thought for the poor saps living in second- and third-tier cities, where bad air doesn't rank on the news agenda and local officials pursue promotion by allowing factories and smelting plants to pump all sorts of pollutants into the air in the name of local economic growth.Hang in there, Hebei!  Embed Quote

column9: Yesterday (12/6/2013) Shanghai AQI over 500, and most of city in China, AQI over 200-300.How do you think China's future, and will continue live or work in China?
column10: Pollution is a fact of life, if not quite ever-present, in Shanghai. I'm pretty blase about it generally speaking. I know people who monitor the AQI with apps on their phones, but I don't pay it much attention. Whenever they comment on it I just shrug my shoulders and get on with things. However, Friday was something else. You know the pollution is bad when even I start talking about it and adapting my behaviour to avoid it. Usually I walk home from my nearest subway stop (about 20-25 minutes) but I took the bus this time; I didn't want to spend any meaningful time outside. I also picked up a mask on my way home (though one much less impressive than Andy Lee's) and when I got home I kept all my windows closed (I often have them open a little to air the apartment). The smog was overwhelming. Visibility was down to a hundred yards and you could taste the dust, not just in your mouth but all the way back in your throat, and it was still there the next morning. I've drunk a lot of water this weekend. It's not been pleasant.But, as I say, it's a fact of life. The cloud will move on and things will get back to normal quickly, which is to say, they will return to the normal levels of tolerable pollution. I'm also glad the Shanghai Marathon took place last weekend and not this week. They would surely have had to cancel it if it were otherwise.  Embed Quote

column9: Yesterday (12/6/2013) Shanghai AQI over 500, and most of city in China, AQI over 200-300.How do you think China's future, and will continue live or work in China?
column10: I had essentially the same reaction as Andy Warwick. I've been rather jaded about air pollution until it reached meteoric levels last week. I was waiting for the Blade Runne Blimp to silently swoop in through the haze advertising Pan Am and Koss headsets. Now I'm looking at dropping serious cash for a clean room strength air purifier for the home and the office while considering if an off-world colony is right for me. What concerns me is the short-term solution, at least in Shanghai, is to lower the benchmark for alerts during the WInter( Shanghai just lowered its air quality benchmark because that's how bad it is), which is a stark reminder that China still deploys such brazenly self-serving tactics. From what I have read, there is no long-term solution to the problem and it is likely to get worse before it gets any better.  Embed Quote

column9: Yesterday (12/6/2013) Shanghai AQI over 500, and most of city in China, AQI over 200-300.How do you think China's future, and will continue live or work in China?
column10: The pollution scare seems to have come and gone and people are back to their normal routines. Beijing's air quality is always in the news and it is probably a lot worse, but Shanghai's AQI has been consistently >100 since October. While 100 is not as bad as 500, I feel like this "it could be worse" mentality is quite unhealthy (literally). While I'm not getting on the next plane back home, it's definitely something I'm going to take into consideration when it comes to deciding whether I will stay in the longer term. People don't realize how serious the adverse health effects of air pollution are because it's not readily apparent. Beijing's lung cancer has gone up 60% in a decade despite the % of smokers remaining flat, and I wouldn't want to become part of that statistic for Shanghai in another 10 years. In the meantime, I'm stocking up on PM2.5 masks (they were completely sold out last week) and hoping I don't see another 500+ day anytime soon!  Embed Quote

column9: Yesterday (12/6/2013) Shanghai AQI over 500, and most of city in China, AQI over 200-300.How do you think China's future, and will continue live or work in China?
column10: As a foreigner in China, I am glad to not be living in one of this country's horribly polluted cities. I have contemplated relocating to one of the larger cities, but the air pollution is one of the main factors keeping me away (I also just don't enjoy the fast-paced lifestyle of the bigger cities like some people do). I have lived in Kunming, a city in Southwestern China famous for its "clean air". Indeed, Kunming regularly enjoys air significantly better than its big city eastern counterparts. However, even Kunming's air has been getting worse, due to increased automobile use and lots of construction. This is one reason why I am moving to Dali, a small town in western Yunnan Province where the air is several times better than that in Kunming, and several hundred times better than that in Beijing or Zhengzhou.  Embed Quote

No, global warming is not a "hoax".There are many more interesting questions, such as: is global warming real, what is the evidence that global warming is occurring, what is the rate at which it is occurring, is global warming primarily human-caused, and so on.  But a "hoax" is a deliberate attempt to fool people.  For global warming to be a "hoax", there would need to be a world-wide conspiracy of scientists and many other people, all trying to fool us.  This is extremely implausible, given how scientists love to advance their careers by gaining attention - and the best way to gain attention would be to reveal the existence of this world-wide conspiracy.If global warming were a hoax, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration would need to be part of this conspiracy:See: http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/oa/clim...The National Academy of Sciences, an organization whose members include2,200 top scientists from the US, would also need to be part of this conspiracy.  They write:Since the beginning of the industrial revolution, concentrations of  greenhouse gases from human activities have risen substantially.  Evidence now shows that the increases in these gases very likely (>90 percent chance) account for most of Earth’s warming over the past 50  years. This is one sentence from their free online book on global warming:http://books.nap.edu/openbook.ph...The Economist, a top-notch business magazine with a strong free-enterprise ideology, would also need to be part of the conspiracy.  They have a special issue on what should be done to stop human-caused global warming:http://www.economist.com/node/14...The Chinese government would also need to be part of the conspiracy.  As the Economist report points out:UNLIKE America’s  leaders, China’s bosses are not much troubled by recalcitrant legislatures.  The government  has therefore had no difficulty in executing a smart volte face [turnaround] on climate change.  Around three years ago its fierce resistance to  the notion of  any limit on its greenhouse gas emissions  started  to  soften.  It now seems to be making serious  efforts to control them.One reason for this change is  the country’s growing awareness of its vulnerability to a warming world.  The  monsoon seems to be weakening, travelling less far inland and dumping its rainfall on the coasts. As a result China is seeing floods in the southeast and droughts in the northwest.  At the same time the country’s leaders are deeply concerned about the melting of the glaciers on the Tibetan plateau, which feed not just the Ganges, the  Indus, the Brahmaputra and the Mekong but also the Yangzi and Yellow rivers (see map). And so on - I could go on for hours.  If global warming is a hoax, it's the world's biggest hoax.  Embed Quote

"Hey, I never said the global warming hoax wasn't elaborate..."One could add the thousands of scientists who are part of the conspiracy, all the faked temperature measurements, the insurance companies who are lieing to their investors about future costs, the fraudulent measurenents of sea levels....  Embed Quote

"Global warming" is a term that incites emotion, sparks debate, and now is a marketing tool.  There are some hoax or conspiracy elements tied up in global warming .However "climate change is 100% real, and worse yet the desertification of our farmable soils by poor farming practices and intensive industrial agriculture is also real.  Climate change may be occurring by natural causes. This can be debated, but humans are changing the planet and not for the better.Call it what you may.  I'm okay with "global warming" but humans need to change our ways if we want the earth to be a nice place to live.  Embed Quote
Refer to Joshua Engels answer to:Climate Change Skepticism: Is the climate change debate being effectively argued? Are we hearing equally from both sides?  Embed Quote

Although there are some misconceptions regarding climate change, I wouldn't describe them as a hoax. They're just common misconceptions and misreadings into the science. And seeing as Climate Science is quite complex, making a misconception is very easy.It is a misconception to think that the everywhere in the world is going to get hotter. It won't. Many places will get hotter, but many will also get colder. Global temperatures will rise as a result though, because there will be more places getting hotter than there will be places getting cooler. This is why 'climate change' is a better phrase to use than 'global warming'.It's also a bit of a misconception to think that all climate change is anthropogenic. We know at least a small portion is caused by humans, and it's highly likely that we cause the majority of it. However, we don't cause all of it. That's a misconception.Other than that, the climate is changing and it isn't a hoax.  Embed Quote

Global warming is not a hoax.Climate change is real.Human beings are detrimental to the long term health of the planet.A vast majority don't give a shit and won't enact change.Now what?Maybe the planet gets so hot it wipes our species out and starts anew.Maybe after that there are more cycles of ice and heat.  Embed Quote
No. Global warming is real. What I wonder is why everyone here simply writes it off as inevitable, as if we can't cool the earth. We can if we wanted to.  Embed Quote

This all started because back in the 90's, data retrieved by NASA didn't appear to support what scientists alarmed by climate change intuitively knew to be true. So they made some stuff up. It turns out that they were right, and additional data supported their assertions, but the damage was done. There is some debate over whether we are causing climate change, and if we can do anything to stop or reverse it. But the climate is changing. At this point, all you have to do is walk outside to understand that.  Embed Quote

A recent poll by Yale University showed that 97% of American scientists believe in climate change, compared to 13% of the American public... it seems like the only people who publicly argue that it's a hoax tend to be more politically motivated. Case 1: A recent story in Mother Jones about about Sarah Palin revealed that while she was governor of Alaska, she did in fact take climate change seriously. Once she got a lot more national attention, though... she started referring to it as "a bunch of snake oil science." Convenient for headlines, eh? OrCase 2: A recent story in the Guardian Environment section discussed how while the Daily Mail's editorial line is that climate change is suspect, their corporate owners have very quietly been reducing their emissions.As for whether or not climate change is a hoax, well... check out NASA's climate change website. Maybe that will convince you...  Embed Quote

There is a clear effort to shut down dissenting opinion and  information, Also refer to Joshua Engel answer to Climate Change Skepticism: Is the climate change debate being effectively argued? Are we hearing equally from both sides?The history of "end of the world " scenarios is not a good one. Everyone laughed at the cartoon of the bearded naked man carrying 2 sign boards in a major city pleading with citizens to repent before the end of the world.  But the climate is so complex that many distinguished scientist, engineers have come to the conclusion of the naked man , they just don't carry the sign boards.  This is alarming on several levelsLet me try and frame the argument slightly so we don't get too far off track Facts and bounding principlesThe laws of thermodynamics LAWS OF THERMODYNAMICSThe sun is our primary source of energy for everything on earthCO2 has various interesting properties but it is not a energy sourceThe world warmed .75 degrees in the last centuryThe GW data of the last 16 years does not indicate GW is continuing  Update and confirmation of ‘Global warming stopped 16 years ago’ aka ‘the pause’So what should we do with all this?The increase in temperature in the last century should be traced to the overpowering factor in the same time period.  Solar output increased in that time period.The obvious conclusion is that increased solar activity is responsible for any increased global temperature.  There is no need to consider complex theories of the role of CO2.  Solar activity has a direct influence on global temperature   CO2's role is indirect and somewhat controversial.Much of the GW hysteria has come from climate models that ignore some basic laws of thermodynamics.If we take the earth as a closed system and the energy input(solar) as fixed, then under the conservation of energy all energy must be accounted for.  This means that the models that show a split off of energy by CO2  then a recycling of that energy in some infinite cycle is bogus.  When the solar input is fixed you can distribute energy in different ways(CO2 can be part of that) but the total energy available does not change.To answer the question directly.  Decent people have always been the victims of hoaxes. History is full of them.  Lets just try and keep the debate civil and recognize some fundamental laws that can help us with a very complex problem.  Embed Quote

A hoax? I don't think it was ever intended to intentionally mislead anyone.However, here is a recent and objective article released from The Economists. The article is heavy on the current state of climate science and the article strongly suggests that perhaps claims of catastrophe caused by human emissions were overblown and projections need to be revised downward.So to label it a hoax would be a stretch. However this is most certainly a case where a few excited scientist jumped the gate and now reality does not match predictions. It was overblown and rushed to conclusions. It all a lie? No. However you should really consider how much,you should worry.http://www.economist.com/news/sc...  Embed Quote

column9: People have answered along the lines of- change to unhealthy diet, increase in smoking etc etc. These are clearly due to the rise of economies as suggested by this article- http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/....M What has caused this development in economies/ the drive for developing countries to be like western countries??
column10: I think your question refers to the causes and drivers of HD? If so, I've written several articles about this issue.  The SAD (Standard American Diet) is one of the worst in the world, and we are exporting it to other countries!  That diet is high in processed/junk/fast foods, high in refined carbs, salt, fats (especially veggie oils from frying), preservatives, and chemicals, now in the thousands. Many are not disclosed on food labeling.  This diet helps to spike blood glucose and inflammation, both are detrimental to health and arteries.  Plus, those foods lack quality nutrients or balance (vitamins, minerals, fiber and antioxidants). In fact, those processed carbs like wheat and sugar take vitamins and minerals from other areas to complete digestion, creating a deficit. It's been known for several years that the worst LDL particles (small, dense ones), are driven by wheat and sugar, not cholesterol or saturated fats!  In addition, refined veggie oils (high in omega-6) can quickly oxidize in the body, which also triggers arterial inflammation. The only oil I recommend is EVOO (Extra Virgin Olive Oil) because it has a set of unique antioxidants and anti-inflammatories. It's great for salads or dressing veggies but frying will destroy the delicate antioxidants.  Smoking, inactivity, stress and a lack of sleep also add to weight, inflammation and compromise immune function. Taken together, we have the perfect storm of a bad diet and other habits which contribute to weight gain, hypertension, diabetes, systemic inflammation and athero! It's so bad, they are finding early athero in young people in their teens and 20s!  Here's are some links for more info and source material: 3 Shocking Myths About Heart Disease http://www.sott.net/article/2425...  Embed Quote
