column9: Of course, anything is toxic to high enough amounts. But it seems that many of them still cause brain damage even at low exposures.The only one I can be sure of: Vitamin D is actually used as rat poison
column10: Neem oil comes to mind, although cases of need seed oil toxicity in infants have been reported. It is also listed in the EU as a potential endocrine disruptor.  Embed Quote

column9: How do you think the environmental legislations should be adapted ? Is eco-design a possible solution? http://sci-env.ch/l%E2%80%99effe...
column10: Yes it is!Every pesticide/or other substance before it's placed on the market is tested for the environmental impact. Basically we know toxicity of every pesticide placed on the market. But once used pesticide doesn't disappear from the environment. It stays in the soil, water, plants etc. in (I hope) small doses.What we don't know is toxicity of  mixture of pesticides/other pollutants present in the environment. The effect may be unpredictable.The effects of two chemicals, when given together are often additive, that is, the combined effect of two chemicals is predictable based on the known toxicity of both compounds.2+2=4The combined effect of the administration of two compounds may be greater than the sum of the two effects; this is called synergism. 2+2=10So how environmental legislations should be adapted?1. I think the organic farming should be promotes as much as possible. There are natural ways to deter pests. 2. Biotechnology- create new cultivars resistant to pests.3. Introduction of bioassay to standard studies of drinking water and treated waste water.  Embed Quote

In short, there is no real difference, except that different chemicals kill by different means of disrupting your body's important functions.Rat poison is wafarin (pretty much); you and the rat will both bleed to death intestinally.  The only reason humans don't bleed out is that they don't eat enough of it.  Dogs and cats who eat rats and mice killed with rat poison may well die, so the LD50 isn't all that narrow.Strychnine and cyanide kill by disrupting the nervous system, I think, immediately.  Arsenic, mercury and lead are heavy metal poisons that kill a bit more slowly, or drive you stupid (lead) or crazy (mercury) first.Carbon monoxide suffocates you.Bug sprays, AFAIK, are organo-phosphates that disrupt your nervous system.  They are very real poisons and can cause HORRIBLE birth defects in children born to mothers exposed to too many.  I believe they persist in fat cells, so they are hard to clear.The trouble with pesticides is that amateurs (you and I) don't read those tiny labels, don't follow mixing directions, and use household tools to mix and measure and apply.  We don't have dedicated clothing.  We wash our contaminated clothing in a regular load, with cold water.  We won't wear gloves and masks.  And then we play with the kids.Watching a professional apply pesticides is an entirely terrifying matter, when you realize how seriously they take the risks.In addition, it's remarkably easy to be stupid about home pesticides.  Friend told me about horrible nightmares she had one night.  Later, she told me about killing a roach in the bathroom, by spraying roach spray on him till he died.  She had inhaled the blow-back from the spray when it hit the wall and splashed back into her inhaled-air source.  Nasty.ADDED:  there are a VERY FEW insecticides that actually interfere with the reproduction of the insect, rather than killing the beasties outright.  In theory, these are safer for humans.  Frankly, I think it's simply easier to treat virtually every pesticide as "highly toxic" and take appropriate precautions.That said, there are a few--boric acid--that kill through mechanical means.  You don't want to inhale it, but it won't hurt you if you get it on your skin.  But that's not what you were talking about in the original question.  Embed Quote

Pesticides are designed to (in most cases) kill pests. Many pesticides can also pose risks to people. However, in many cases the amount of pesticide people are likely to be exposed to is too small to pose a risk. To determine risk, one must consider both the toxicity or hazard of the pesticide and the likelihood of exposure. A low level of exposure to a very toxic pesticide may be no more dangerous than a high level of exposure to a relatively low toxicity pesticide, for example.See more on:Human Health Issues  Embed Quote

It is certainly evolution. My lab has even published papers on it in fruit flies.http://www.sciencemag.org/conten...Evidence that Adaptation in Drosophila Is Not Limited by Mutation at Single SitesFrom a strict population genetic perspective of evolution as change in allele frequencies over time, the rapid rise of pesticide resistance mutations certainly qualify. Even better, we can precisely attribute this phenomena to selective pressures instead of neutral processes such as genetic drift. The selective pressure might not strictly be "natural", as humans introduced the pesticides, but this is considered to be natural selection as opposed to the artificial selection that occurs when breeding dogs for example (humans pick specifically choose individuals to mate, and then select which offspring are kept)Thanks for the A2A!  Embed QuoteAnswered in twenty-five minutes via  Satish Babu Bonu.

Humans are part of nature. The adaptive pressures exerted by our activities are every bit as real as any other. I get so frustrated with ignorance of and opposition to evolution in America, because it's taking place in real time all around us, in ways that directly affect us. Insect resistance to pesticides is a big one; antibiotic-resistant microbes are another.  Embed Quote

Yes, it is called as anthropogenic evolution. Insects and animals adapt  to anthropogenic stress factors like pesticides in this case. Here again natural selection and survival of the fittest decides what stays and what dies.  Embed Quote

column9: Brown Marmorated stink bugs were accidentally introduced to Pennsylvania in 1998 from China or Japan and have spread to other States over the years.  They arrived here in Southwest Virginia two years ago and I have yet to find any pesticide that will kill or repel them.
column10: Effective is arguable, but there are some pesticides that work for certain applications, including one for organic farmers. More are being made, but the process is slower than the spread of the insect.EPA Approves Two Insecticides for Control of Invasive Stink Bug  Embed Quote

column9: Brown Marmorated stink bugs were accidentally introduced to Pennsylvania in 1998 from China or Japan and have spread to other States over the years.  They arrived here in Southwest Virginia two years ago and I have yet to find any pesticide that will kill or repel them.
column10: Stink bugs are difficult to eliminate. The haven't found any natural predators in the United States that can eliminate them and there is only one type of parasitic wasp in Asia that is a natural predator. There really aren't alot of products that effectively eliminate stink bugs. Pyrethrin is a substance that does kill them. Since stink bugs are located in your house most of the time when you find them, using a product that is organic is probably the best solution. a really good organic product that eliminates stink bugs as well as a bunch of other insects is EndALL by Safer Brand. http://www.saferbrand.com/store/...  Embed Quote
Purchase some live ladybugs. I did this for some roses and the aphids were gone by the next morning.  Embed QuoteAnswered in seven minutes.

Soap and water. Dish soap works- Palmolive, Dawn- just use a good dish soap.  Put a good, soapy mixture into a spray bottle and spray the plant- over and under the leaves.  Embed QuoteAnswered in four minutes.

This isn't the direct answer, but it's pretty correct: control the ants that feed on the aphids. No ants, no aphids. In the meantime, soapy water applied every other day or so as a spray works fairly well for me.  Embed Quote

Live ladybugs are ideal if you are not using electric lighting. In a greenhouse or outside setup live ladybugs as Crystal White said are ideal however if you are growing with bulbs and ballasts the ladybugs will be more attracted to the warm sun then your plants, hence frying them in no time.I grow legal medical cannabis and have been doing so for years. The best product I used and highly recommend is SNS 209 Pesticide Concentrate. Its an all natural pesticide good for spider mites, aphids and many other garden insects. You can find this at innovativegreenthumb.comhttp://www.innovativegreenthumb.com/sns-209-pesticide-concentrate-1-gallon/  Embed Quote

It may be wise to do nothing. The aphids will be food for their predators and the system will balance. (maybe)I had a huge aphids problem the first year I grew tomatoes in the Bosque Village. I did nothing and the aphids ate the plants. But the next year there were no a´aphids.  Embed QuoteAnswered in thirty-nine minutes.

There is no hard and fast answer to this.  It depends on the methods, the animal, the feed and the handling of the animals.  For example, beef in the US are allowed to have hormones and antibiotics, and can eat genetically modified feed and there's no requirement to label any of this,  In China, it is required that GM products be labelled, not sure about their stance on antibiotics and hormones, but their safety record is not the best - you may recall the melamine incident in baby formula. Unfortunately answering this question is a little bit like comparing apples to oranges - and there's no simple answer  Embed Quote

column9: We have a flea problem with our small dog. The pest company uses dinotefuran. Is it safe for humans after 4 hours like they claim? We have small children? Any suggestions on safer products?
column10: Is dinotefuran safe for humans? Safety is a relative term and the answer depends on the extent and route of exposure. This is true for all chemicals - including table salt and water.  If a pesticide has been selected wisely and applied in accordance to the label directions, then it very likely will offer far more benefit than risk to people and pets. You should ask the pest control company for a copy of the specimen label (the label on the package). That specifies how the product can be used (and by whom), and where/when it cannot be applied. Then, ask for the MSDS (material safety data sheet). These tend to be overly technical reviews that are akin to some of the nearly unreadable package inserts in medicines. They basically tell you almost every kind of possible adverse reaction that might happen, even if the risk is tiny.  The pest control company should happily hand you readable copies. Ideally, they would offer them to every customer, whether or not they asked. You can also find them online if you know the formulated product's brand name. If you really want to become overwhelmed with information, read the EPA's registration packet Page on EPA for this active ingredient.Are there 'safer' products? Perhaps. There are diverse products registered for use against fleas. Actually, I'd advise you to have a conversation first with your veterinarian. There are products that can be applied directly to the dog (some topical and some oral) that can be quite effective. Those work by killing the fleas that feed on the dog, or they cause the next generation of fleas not to mature (and hence, those won't ever blood feed). If you have many fleas that are free in the home environment, then it may make sense to have a treatment to your home. Whereas you can purchase some anti-flea products yourself, it usually is wisest to hire a competent licensed pest management professional. They should have the proper training and equipment to do it right.  Embed Quote

Dicofol, ethion, quinalphos, hexaconazole, fenpropathrin, fenvalerate and propargite are used in India. Pesticides like methomyl and endosulfan have been found in samples fron China.China is the world's largest tea producer and purportedly the world's largest user of pesticides.  This does not automatically mean that a large amount of pesticides are used on tea but in April of 2011 the environmental organization, Greenpeace, released the results of tests for pesticides that they had done on a number of samples of tea.  You can read about the results here:http://www.greenpeace.org/eastas...Samples of tea from south India were tested and an abstract of the results can be found here:http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubm...  Embed QuoteVia  Anonymous.

In rural regions it is very common to drink water straight from the well with no purification or disinfection. Also, these wells can be surrounded by agricultural areas which have pesticides applied to them. Another reason can be that these wells are not as deep as a well used by a water purification plant. A deeper well can have less pesticides in its water because there is a greater chance of the pesticides getting trapped or breaking down as it soaks through the earth.  Embed Quote

column9: Looking for one of those solutions you can do out of everyday homeproducts, like mix detergent and viniger or something
column10: Put some diluted ethanol into a pan and add sugar water to it, and a drop of washing liquid. The sugar will attract, the ethanol will drug them, and the detergent will lower the surface tension of the water so they drown. It doesn't work universally, but should do a decent job.You can try grinding up some herbs, diluting with water, and applying to window sills. Several herbs have natural oils that are repellant to insects. Try them out.The best way of all is to just get some spiders and put them on your windows. No more insects inside.  Embed Quote

column9: Looking for one of those solutions you can do out of everyday homeproducts, like mix detergent and viniger or something
column10: This depends on the flying insects.For many flies, e.g. fruit flies, a small amount of sugary liquid (dregs of wine, beer) in a bottle or jar with a homemade paper funnel inserted and secured into the top will suffice.This probably won't work with mosquitos.  Embed Quote

While some of them most probably do, their cumulative negative health effects are most likely inconsequential when compared to what just a round or two of severe famine could wreak upon most people's well-being.Put another way, I doubt many Somalians or Ethiopians would raise much of a fuss over the excessive use of ammonium nitrate fertilizers.In fact, there are many solid arguments to be made that the banning of DDT—largely due because of poorly documented and alarmist ecology-oriented publications like Rachel Carson's "Silent Spring"—contributed, in some part, to a near-genocide of African people due to a resurgence of the Anopheles mosquito and its ability to vector malaria.  Embed Quote

Put some apple cider vinegar in a glass or jar, place a paper cone with a small opening pointing into the jar (but not touching the vinegar).  (I rolled a piece of paper and taped it). make sure there are no gaps between the top of the glass/jar and the paper cone. They'll be attracted to the apple cider vinegar but not be able to get out once they enter the small opening in the paper cone.  Also, remove any old fruit veggies that they're attracted to.  Embed Quote

Iodine is useful for xray contrast because it absorbs xrays at a similar energy to calcium, which is what xrays were originally used for. Importantly, it is also non-toxic at useful doses.  Embed Quote

column9: I heard someone say today that grapes, prunes and strawberries should be avoided because they are the most prone to soaking up the most chemical fertilizers/pesticides etc...Is this true? If so, how can I go deeper into this and research it? Thanks!
column10: A good starting point is the dirty dozen by EWG. They research the fruit and veggies every year to see which has the most pesticides. They have the dirty dozen and the clean 15 list. These are the dirty dozen and should be bought organic:1Apples2Celery3Sweet bell peppers4Peaches5Strawberries6Nectarines– imported7Grapes8Spinach9Lettuce10Cucumbers11Blueberries – domestic12PotatoesPlus+Green beans+Kale/Greens+ May contain pesticide residues of special concernThese are the clean 15:1Onions2Sweet Corn3Pineapples4Avocado5Cabbage6Sweet peas7Asparagus8Mangoes9Eggplant10Kiwi11Cantaloupe - domestic12Sweet potatoes13Grapefruit14Watermelon15MushroomsSource: Executive Summary: Eat your fruits and vegetables!  Embed Quote

column9: I heard someone say today that grapes, prunes and strawberries should be avoided because they are the most prone to soaking up the most chemical fertilizers/pesticides etc...Is this true? If so, how can I go deeper into this and research it? Thanks!
column10: Technically, any root crop would be the most likely to soak up any pesticides or toxins since that's what they're meant to do... Soak up, store and feed the above ground plant.  Carrots, potatoes, beets, onions, etc. always buy those as organic, above all others.  i've actually read about setback requirements for growing carrots next to roadways since they are thought to soak up and store the cadmium wash off from tires when it rains. The dirty dozen list is based on residue levels, meaning pesticides found on the outside of the fruit, and most can be washed off after buying.. thus I tend to take that lists recommendations lightly. What you want to avoid is systemic pesticides that move into and through the plant and into the flesh of the fruit - those cant be washed off or removed. And there's no way to know if a farmer used a systemic pesticide or not on any specific crop. Another reason to consider organic for all produce purchases.  Embed Quote

column9: I heard someone say today that grapes, prunes and strawberries should be avoided because they are the most prone to soaking up the most chemical fertilizers/pesticides etc...Is this true? If so, how can I go deeper into this and research it? Thanks!
column10: Here's a starting point link, but keep in mind that a pesticide resistant food may have other concerns; for example, soybeans - 90% of N. American soybeans are GMO - modified to be resistant to pesticides, and nicknamed "round-up ready" So while some vegetables and fruits may better to get in organic form, when possible, there are also organic GMO, and organic non-GMO for some food sources. link: 'Dirty dozen' produce carries more pesticide residue, group says  Embed Quote

column9: In every realm of technology I know, the materials and chemicals used in 2012 are different than the ones used in 1960.  But current insect repellants still rely on the same old chemical that's been around for decades: DEET.  What's up with that? It seems like screening new compounds for insect repellant properties should be easy--a lot easier than pharma development--and so how can the old molecule be the best anyone can find?  (And if it is the single best repellant in the universe, how on earth did anyone stumble on it in the first place?)  Just curious...
column10: You're behind on the times. There is a new, 21st century repellent as good or better than DEET, and it's called Picaridin. The data so far shows it provides all the benefits of DEET (works really well and is extremely safe, as long as you don't drink the stuff or swim in it) with the added bonus of not dissolving certain plastics like DEET does, which makes it safe for use on all clothes. As for why DEET is still relied on, that's because it works, is well understood (we don't yet know the safety limitations of high-dose Picaridin), and is still the longest lasting repellent available (Picaridin lasts 70% as long). Newer isn't always better.  Embed Quote

column9: In every realm of technology I know, the materials and chemicals used in 2012 are different than the ones used in 1960.  But current insect repellants still rely on the same old chemical that's been around for decades: DEET.  What's up with that? It seems like screening new compounds for insect repellant properties should be easy--a lot easier than pharma development--and so how can the old molecule be the best anyone can find?  (And if it is the single best repellant in the universe, how on earth did anyone stumble on it in the first place?)  Just curious...
column10: We don't really know how DEET works. We don't really know how insects find their targets. Finding DEET was kind of an accident. They we looking for an insecticide, playing around with organic chemicals of a type that might work. It didn't, but it did repel them, a bit. Nobody really knows why, though they have some guesses.It's hard to optimize when you have no idea what you're doing. Nobody even guarantees that there is a better insect repellent out there; it's not like mosquitos are built with special off switches. You basically just spray and pray, poking around until you find something that works, if you ever do. And then you have to hope that whatever it is isn't toxic to humans, doesn't stain your clothes, etc. It's a big space with few if any hits.  Embed QuoteVia  Hal Pashler.

column9: I would think the last thing either of them wants is a lawsuit on their hands.
column10: You should always wash your produce. Not for the pesticides -- those are perfectly safe in the quantities allowed on food -- but because of the disgusting, drippy-nosed, unhygienic pigs who have been rifling through that stack of apples all day, looking for the prettiest ones to take home and forget about in their crisper drawer. Modern farming is quite clean. People are disgusting.  Embed Quote

column9: I would think the last thing either of them wants is a lawsuit on their hands.
column10: If they were to be sued, they'd in turn sue the suppliers. Grocery stores depend on certifications that suppliers provide. The suppliers depend on the certifications the growers provide.In a litigious society, lawyers tend to sue everyone they can identify who can be linked to their cause even tangentially. Grocery stores have lawyers who deal with this all the time.The reason you don't read much about it is that the cases are usually losers... courts correctly identify the responsible party and dismiss against those not responsible. There has to be a spectacular case for it to be worth a major class action suit. If there is merit, the grocery chains usually settle out of court.  Embed Quote

column9: I would think the last thing either of them wants is a lawsuit on their hands.
column10: As John pointed out it is not likely that a supermarket would be held responsible for pesticide residue on the products they sell. There are however a lot of precautions in place to protect consumers from pesticide residue in place further up the supply chain.The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) regulates pesticides. They determine a pesticide tolerance for each pesticide they approve. The pesticide tolerance is the amount of pesticide that can legally be found in food products. Both the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) monitor and enforce the these pesticide tolerances. In 2012, the USDA tested 12,845 samples of fresh produce and other foods, and once again said that pesticide residues are not a safety issue. (Food Safety News, 2012).  Embed Quote

column9: 'Victory for bees' as European Union bans neonicotinoid pesticides blamed for destroying bee population
column10: I've been attending some talks recently on this topic, you can see my notes at BL Talk science 26th June 2013 - Pollinators and pesticides: is there a plan bee? and A Future Without Bees - a talk at the Southbank Centre. The general consensus amongst scientists seems to be that two years is not long enough to tell if the ban has had an effect, but it does at least give time to do further research. Clothianidin, a type of neonicotinoid, has a half-life of four years. So this stuff is still going to be around in the soil at the end of the two year ban.Also, in the case of many species we don't really have figures for how many bees there were 50 years ago or how many bees there are now, so how will we know if numbers have increased when the ban ends? There is currently no scheme in place to monitor how the ban is going.  Embed Quote

column9: 'Victory for bees' as European Union bans neonicotinoid pesticides blamed for destroying bee population
column10: What has been seriously lacking in the neonicotinoid debate is that what are farmers going to be using instead of neonicotinoids? The evidence that neonics are seriously damaging to honeybees is not particularly convincing when looking at the original scientific papers. It may very well be than new pesticides will be used that are more harmful to honey bees than neonics. It is also clear that there are many instances of CCD or extensive bee deaths that cannot be linked in any way to neonics. It is unlikely that an examination of the bee populations after the EU ban will help in determining the causes as there are too many factors that are influencing honey bee survival. What is really needed is very good field science not lab science which often doesn't translate well into the real world.One of the most comprehensive places on neonics science and analysis is the site of commercial beekeeper Randy Oliver. A good place to start is here Neonicotinoids: Trying To Make Sense of the Science and then move on to many of the other extensive articles that he has written as more information has come out.  Embed Quote

column9: Paul Stamets and others have had patents on various mycopesticides and related technologies for several years (Google Patent Search) and an Australian company was reported to be working on these in 2010 (Killer fungi taking fight to roaches). So, why aren't there any mycopesticide products on the market? I've read some pesticide companies are suing keep these off the market. If that's true, then on what grounds? Are there safety concerns? Are people just too creeped out by turning insects in to mushrooms?
column10: Besides the economic argument that Anonymous outlined, I would just add that Cordyceps and Ophiocordyceps are pretty slow in their action. If you have a real cockroach infestation, it would give a lot of time for females to lay eggs for next season. Plus, cockroaches are social animals. In ants, infected individuals are promptly kicked out of the colony to die alone, so the infection never spreads. I don't know cockroaches have a similar mechanism (it wouldn't surprise me either way). If they do, that effectively makes it useless.  Embed QuoteVia  Craig Talbert.

column9: Paul Stamets and others have had patents on various mycopesticides and related technologies for several years (Google Patent Search) and an Australian company was reported to be working on these in 2010 (Killer fungi taking fight to roaches). So, why aren't there any mycopesticide products on the market? I've read some pesticide companies are suing keep these off the market. If that's true, then on what grounds? Are there safety concerns? Are people just too creeped out by turning insects in to mushrooms?
column10: Cordyceps, which germinates in living larva, is one of the most expensive (botanical) medicinals in the world.  While it is now cultivated using a rice substrate, it is considered inferior on the open market.  Hand-picked cordyceps can go for up to $600 for one gram. Cordyceps crazy: Beijing highest per 600 grams of gold invesSo...I think if you are in the Cordyceps business, you can make a lot more money selling the fungi versus using it to kill cockroaches.  Because there is a portion of people who have cockroach allergies (which can be severe),  I don't think it is viable to collect the dead and infected cockroaches.  Additionally, since they are good at hiding, harvesting may prove too dificult. Currently, Cordyceps is harvested out doors.Traditional Use among Tibetan People, Harvesting Techniques, and Modern UsesStamets does have the patent: Patent WO2002028189A2 - Mycoattractants and mycopesticides but I am not sure how strong it is -- many herbal patents have  weak elements. I will update upon further investigation.  Embed Quote

There are certain methods to control thrips. The most common use is chemical control which depend on the grown crop. The used compounds to manage thrips are:1. untraditional compounds.abamectin, thiamethoxam, imidacloprid, thiacloprid, azadirachtin, pottasium soap (liquid ), Acetamiprid, Novaluron (IGR), Pymetrozine (anti feedent), Beauveria bassiana (fungi)2. traditional compounds.chloropyrifos, oxamyl (systemic nematicides), lambada cyhalothrin, deltamethrin, cypermethrin(http://www.guidechem.com/cas-523...), malathion (if register in your country) .3. reducing moisture as you can. 4. yellow sticky traps is the best trap kind, follow with blue one.  Embed Quote

The best answer to this can be found in the current issue of Annals of Internal Medicine.  Researchers from Stanford did a meta-analysis of 240 studies on organic v. conventional foods and their health outcomes.  The take-away related to your question is that conventional foods carry a higher risk of ingesting detectable levels pesticides but not in ingesting dangerous levels of any of these pesticides.  It's important to note that the organic foods were not actually free of pesticides, but they showed ~30% lower levels of them.  So in short, I think the answer to your question is that, no, you will not be in danger of ingesting clinically meaningful or "dangerous" levels of pesticides from consuming conventional fruits and vegetables.  You can read the study here:  http://annals.org/article.aspx?a...  Embed QuoteThis answer is not a substitute for professional medical advic... (more)Loading...

I'm going to guess that you are referring to White Fly. There is a really effective bio-control called Encarsia Formosa that does a great job controlling them in a greenhouse type setting. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enc...  Embed Quote

column9: Are the natural ones currently being used any safer than synthetic ones used?
column10: "Natural" or "organic" pesticides (organic growers all use pesticides, they just use organic ones) can be just as safe/harmless as synthetic ones. They can also just as dangerous, and they can sometimes be much, much worse! It depends on the pesticide. "Natural" does not mean "good" or "safe" and "synthetic" does not mean "bad." You must consider each alternative independently.Firstly, if the natural and synthetic compound are identical chemicals, then they have the same safety. The origin does not matter in the slightest: distilled rainwater and water made from hyrolysis in a lab are both distilled water, botch chemically identical. The same for "artificial" and  "natural" colors and flavors in food. Often they are identical compounds.Second, if a pesticide left residue on your food that could harm you, it wouldn't be sold, else the farmer applied it wrong. Whether the pesticide was organic or not would not matter. Third, if the organic chemical is weaker, it will be applied in a higher dose and more frequently. That increases the risk of you consuming it.Last, several cases exist where organic pesticides are worse than synthetics. Here is an herbicide example, but I'm sure a pesticide pair exists for this. The synthetic herbicide Roundup leaves no residues and is harmless when eaten, but can cause eye irritation. The organic equivalent, that also leaves no residues and is equally effective as an herbicide, is Pharm Solutions Weed Pharm, made of 20% acetic acid (concentrated vinegar). It is corrosive, can cause permanent eye damage, causes skin sensitization, and is FATAL if swallowed or absorbed through the skin. What does that mean? For the farmer, it means they must use goggles and protective clothing when using the organic herbicide, but can use roundup naked if they so choose. As long as they follow the directions, they won't be harmed. As for the consumer, as neither compound leaves a residual, crops treated with either will be equally safe.Evidence shows that people who eat organic food have no health benefits compared to conventional agriculture food, and tend to get food poisioning a bit more. That's it.  If you are a grower, look at the labels on the pesticide and decide for yourself if it is toxic or not, but pay no heed to buzzwords like "natural," "organic," or "synthetic" that have no bearing on safety of efficacy, period.  Embed Quote

column9: Are the natural ones currently being used any safer than synthetic ones used?
column10: There are many different ‘recipes’ for organic pesticidesand insect repellents. Many use ingredients that may be natural or organic but still aren’t goodto spray on your food e.g. rubbing alcohol and nicotine. The Country Farm Lifestyles website has a comprehensive list  http://www.countryfarm-lifestyle... however the following recipe seems the safest: 4 chillies, 4 large onions, 2 bulbs garlic, 2 L soapy water(you can use an organic castile soap e.g. http://www.ewg.org/skindeep/prod...)Chop and combine all the ingredients, including the seedsfrom the chillies. Cover with the soapy water and steep for 24 hours. Strain.Add water to dilute if required and spray. Can be stored in a sealed containerin a dark place for up to 2 weeks.  Embed Quote

column9: Are the natural ones currently being used any safer than synthetic ones used?
column10: Of course. The same goes for food as well.You wouldn't say that hemlock is good for your health simply because it's natural.  Embed QuoteAnswered in four minutes.

column9: I define "worse" as worse for consumer health to the extent that disease probabilities increase - even if marginally. I define healthier as healthier for consumers to the extent they may help avoid various health problems, even if the benefit is marginal.
column10: I don’t have any examples of specific foods but yes there are organic pesticides that are more dangerous than synthetic pesticides. I have a link to a great article on some myths about organic farming here. http://bites.ksu.edu/news/149506...Here is a little summary of that article. First let me say I support any form of agriculture that is sustainable, environmentally sound, and is safe. Organic food can, let me repeat that, can have many of the issues big ag does. There are "organic" pesticides that are more toxic than synthetic. Copper is used a lot, this has consequences for the environment. There have been recalls and food borne illness outbreaks associated with organic products. A lot of people make an automatic assumption that if they buy organic it is safer and better on all aspects. What needs to happen is for consumers to be more aware, question the seller. There is no reason to stop buying organic, we just can't buy it for the label. Buy because someone is proving to you they have a safer product, their livestock is kept/treated properly, they're willing to tell you what pesticides they use. Hell, they should be bragging about stuff like that and more they just need make it verifiable to the consumer.   Embed Quote

column9: I define "worse" as worse for consumer health to the extent that disease probabilities increase - even if marginally. I define healthier as healthier for consumers to the extent they may help avoid various health problems, even if the benefit is marginal.
column10: Rotenone. It used to be banned by the government as it causes Parkinson's-like symptoms and DNA damage in the brain. They re-approved it as a natural/organic pesticide. And its use is not regulated. Organic farmers use it ad libitum (up to their own discretion).All organic produce are nutritionally equal in terms of vitamin profiles. However synthetically treated varieties are actually more nutritious in that they have a more favorable chemical profile. As in, organic produce is at a higher baseline toxicity (seeds are bred that way). Not only that, but when they are in danger (pests, crop harvest, etc) toxicity levels go up as the plants' only means of protection. Yes, this is the same in the other plants, but organics start out at that higher level, skyrocketing final readings.SO much so that synthetic plant carcinogen levels are measured at parts per billion, whereas organic plants are taken at a parts per thousand, or a parts per million level. That means that organics are on the magnitude of 1,000 to 1,000,000 times more toxic. I'm not even sure if that's before or after countless rotenone applications.Lastly, synthetic treatment for plants give them adequate protection so that they may have the safety reassurance of spending their time manufacturing healthy/beneficial chemicals. EVen with natural pesticides, organics are not fully protected and spend a lot of their valuable time making more self-defense toxins.  Embed Quote

column9: When living in apartments or renting a room, how do you keep the bugs out of your house/room?
column10: I'm not trained in extermination in any way, so take my advice with a grain of salt.To keep out roaches, first keep out their food! Roaches are attracted to filth, so clean up any leftovers, sweep up the crumbs, and check behind the fridge or in high cabinets for forgotten foodstuffs. Anything they can eat, keep away from them in a closed cupboard or fridge. Don't do what Joe from "Joe's Apartment" does, essentially. If you have no food for them, they should not come. If you do see roaches, feel free to kill them (or pick them up and toss them outside like I do... because I'm badass like that). Plenty of traps and sprays exist in most general stores, pick the one that seems best to you. A bait station where they take poison food back to their hideout is good. Herbal types are garbage: Roaches can survive nukes, do you really think they can't handle whatever your local food CoOp can throw at them? Poison them.Just be warned, especially for apartment people: if your nextdoor/upstairs/downstairs neighbor is messy and has a cockroach infestation, then no amount of cleaning will spare you. The roaches will probably wander into your place by accident despite your best efforts. Likewise, depending on what part of the planet you live in and how tightly sealed your house is from the great outdoors, you simply might not be able to make it bug proof. The key is to make the insects not want to stay, and cleanliness should do that. If all else fails, call your landlord or an exterminator. But save that for really nasty infestations. The truth is cockroaches are harmless; they don't bite, sting, or transmit diseases and actually spend 50% of their day cleaning themselves. Some people develop roach allergies with prolonged exposure, but otherwise the odd insect scurrying across the hall is not something to worry about. If they start singing and dancing on your toilet or following you to work à la "Joe's Apartment," then you have a problem.  Embed QuoteVia  Eric Waters.

column9: When living in apartments or renting a room, how do you keep the bugs out of your house/room?
column10: As Matan Shelomi said, keeping your house clean and not leaving any food outside (including dirty dishes) are both necessary. Roaches can smell the food, even little crumbs you might not see on the floor from very far away. If they will smell anything, they will come. If your neighbor has a messy house, or if you have a pet and you have to leave food the pet, roaches will come. Especially if the building you live in is an old building.I myself live in a 20-year old building and every year, as the weather gets warmer, roaches start to visit. I learned all these from experience;1. If you're gonna live in an apartment building, avoid living on the first floor. Roaches and all kinds of non-flying bugs first prefer the apartment that is closest to earth.2. Again, do NOT leave food outside and keep every food well-covered. Make sure your garbage bin is a closed one, and not leave any dishes outside. Either wash them after you finish using, or put them in the dishwasher.3. Fill every crack on the house/apartment's walls and on the floor. Roaches and other insects usually come out of walls. When you're not showering or using the sink, also close the drains as they sometimes come out of drains as well. 4. Roaches can survive in the cold but not like it, they usually appear when the weather is warm. Since I know there are roaches in my neighborhood and I have the problem in my apartment every year, I call an exterminator the day I see a roach. When the weather gets warm, seeing one of them mean more of them will come very soon, sometimes even within hours.5. I'm afraid there's no good solution other than calling an exterminator if you see more than one roach within a week when the weather is warm. Spraying poison in the apartment just once sometimes doesn't work too well. (It doesn't in my apartment.) The best way is to call an exterminator, and then 7-15 days later once again. You will probably see couple dead ones but very soon they will all move away to a safe place.6. Make sure you keep a Raid in the house for emergencies.  Embed Quote

The problem with the honeybees started back in the 1950s when monocrop farming was made the priority of the country, and crops like almonds were planted in northern California in a former desert.  Almonds need to be pollinated in late February, and at this time of year, we just don't naturally have enough bees to do the job.  Neither bees nor almonds (nor most of the foods we rely on) are native to America.  So bees are fed High Fructose Corn Syrup, and are doused with antibiotics, fungicides, and other chemicals, and are lumped in with imported bees from Australia and other countries, and shipped cross country on huge trailers from Florida (where they are raised) to northern california for the february pollination season.This happens 1-2x a year.  This is very stressful on bees.  Since the 1970s, a mite calls Varroa Destructor has been very detrimental to our bees, in addition to the widespread bad breeding and poor diet.  The bees have just been stressed.To add to the problem, more farmers are using insecticides on their crops which are also causing problems for the bees.Most scientists at this point believe that the problem isn't just one or two things, but a larger systemic problem.  Right now, the thing we're calling "CCD" hasn't been identified, but we know it is detectable by other bees.  We know this because if a hive has been abandoned in a typical CCD way, this hive will not be "robbed" of its honey and wax by others bees in the usual fashion, but instead, it is avoided as a hot zone.  Embed Quote This answer may be out of date. (more)It appears the source has been identified -- see Ian Douglas's answer.

Update June 2012:http://io9.com/5916845/honey-bee...It turns out that the parasitic Varroa mite - long known to torment honey bee populations - may be the culprit behind CCD. Or more accurately, it's the Deformed Wing Virus (DWV) that's being transmitted by these mites that's causing all the trouble.  Embed Quote

Chemicals and fungicides make them more vulnerable to parasites and sickness. Industrial agriculture from the "green revolution" is killing the bees, and without them food production will be in danger. June 2013.Scientists discover what’s killing the bees and it’s worse than you thoughtBut in a first-of-its-kind study published today in the journal PLOS ONE, scientists at the University of Maryland and the US Department of Agriculture have identified a witch’s brew of pesticides and fungicides contaminating pollen that bees collect to feed their hives.  Embed Quote
There was an interesting New Yorker article back in 2007 on this topic that may contain some clues: http://www.newyorker.com/reporti....Not for Reproduction

Edit June 8, 2012: A new study places the cause of CCD to the combination of the Varroa mite and the Deformed Wing Virus, see Charlie Cheever's answer.Original answer:A couple of new studies on honey bees and bumblebees have found strong evidence that Colony Collapse Disorder can be caused by a family of pesticides called neonicotinoids. See this Wired article: http://www.wired.com/wiredscienc...Some experts however believe that this is probably due to a combination of reasons, besides the neonicotinoids.Citations:“Neonicotinoid Pesticide Reduces Bumble Bee Colony Growth and Queen Production.” By Penelope R. Whitehorn, Stephanie O’Connor, Felix L. Wackers, Dave Goulson. Science, Vol. 335 No. 6076, March 30, 2012.“A Common Pesticide Decreases Foraging Success and Survival in Honey Bees.” By Mickaël Henry, Maxime Beguin, Fabrice Requier, Orianne Rollin, Jean‐François Odoux, Pierrick Aupinel, Jean Aptel, Sylvie Tchamitchian, Axel Decourtye. Science, Vol. 335 No. 6076, March 30, 2012.....  Embed Quote

A study by a mixture of academic and military researchers last year found that a combination of a mite and a virus were present in all CCD cases, and that increasing their concentration increased the incidence of collapse.http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/...  Embed Quote

I can't think of any cases where aerosol sprays are used to kill mosquitoes indoors. Even in developed countries, nobody does this. Mosquitoes enter houses from the outside, so most mosquito abatement strategies deal with removing mosquito breeding sites outside (such as eliminating puddles or insecticide-treated pools or using oil or using mosquitofish) and preventing bites indoors. People in developing nations can't afford insect repellants or insecticide sprays, so they either use traps or, most commonly, insecticide-treated bed nets.What are the health impacts of insecticide-treated bed nets on children? Reduced child mortality by 20%. According to UNICEF, one in five childhood deaths in Africa is caused by malaria, and a child dies from malaria every 30 seconds. If that sounds ridiculous to you, I remind you that Earth's population is at 7billion and growing, and malaria was and probably still is the number once cause of death among humans, period. Bed nets last for about 5 years and practically prevent all mosquito bites on children who sleep on them: in the unlikely event that the bed nets pose a health risk, such risks would be nothing compared to the almost certain mortality and morbidity from not using them. Unfortunately, few children use these bed nets, as locals tend to give the nets to older (and less at risk) persons because in societies with high childhood mortality the life of an elder is worth more than that of a child. It's a pity, but bed nets are still increasing in usage and the fight against vector-borne diseases continues.  Embed Quote

column9: I work as a landscaper and find it very inconvenient when I spray round-up to kill weeds and redundantly have to spray the same patch of weeds over to "hit" the spots I missed.
column10: There are a number of dye products available for this purpose. Here's one that makes it in consumer and commercial package quantities. Turf Mark® Blue Spray Pattern Indicator for Turf | Becker Underwood. Turf Mark should be available at most agricultural supply places, even some of the chains.Hi-Yield also makes a dye that is sold at small/chain yard, garden, and home improvement stores if you want to try it out. column9: I recently purchased a foreclosure that had been abandoned for approximately two years. The roof was poorly done on the addition to the house and two of the gutters were backed up. While I have dealt with these two problems, water had gotten into the house and some of the wood has rotted away.I noticed a tree stump approximately 9 feet from this addition that had been cut down but not removed. When I pulled the stump up (it was rotten) I noticed a rather large number of orange-looking ants or termites. I have not yet pulled up the sub-floor in the addition to see if these ants/termites are in the house but I was hoping to make some sort of termite bait/killer and place it in the stump and a few other areas of the property before I decide to try store-bought termite bait or go with a professional. Today when I visit the property I will take another good look at the insects and take a picture or find one on Google that resembles them. Either way, they are wood-dwelling insects and should be dealt with.I did a search on Google and the only suggestion I found was a mixture of 1 part cornmeal, 2 parts confectioners sugar, and 2 parts borax. Does this sound effective or are there any better (homemade) solutions?
column10: Termites love to eat soft wood, so by providing them with another source yourself, you can try to get them out of their nest and onto your disposable source. A good trick is to bring out some loose cardboard boxes or pieces and place them in strategic areas such as near the tree stump you saw. They will surely be attracted to this "soft wood" type of material and come out to feast on it! Once they do, you can simply burn these items away, burning the termites at the same time. One you've done this a couple of times, you should start looking to renovate this  home and make sure to use materials that are not termite-friendly. Add plenty of gutters that move rainwater away from the foundation of the home so the infrastructure is not penetrated and does not get damp.  Embed Quote

column10: Most consumers don't like the thought of pesticides on food. However, even more intolerable is the thought of insects having partially eaten the food.  Modern pesticides are so potent that farmers are down to spraying teaspoons per acre. Also note, that there are naturally derived pesticides (like Spinosad) that are sprayed on many organic crops because the rules of organic say they can, and because pest pressure is so heavy on farmers. Put yourself in their shoes: pretend you have an apple farm and you've been farming it for a few years. Last year about 5% of your trees had insect damaged fruit, but this year it's 25%. What do you do? What is your first inclination? What do you think will happen next year if you continue to use no pesticides?  Embed Quote

column9: Is it better for the environment?
column10: This is a difficult question deserving of a complicated answer, which should start by disambiguating the term "organic".Organic farming can refer to a method intended to simulate biological systems in the natural world. In this sense, organic food is inherently grown without chemical pesticides, herbicides, fertilizers, etc. In addition, organic farmers promote complex interactions between plants, animals, and ecosystems that are not found on industrial farms, whether conventional or certified USDA organic. Such interactions may include utilizing rotational grazing instead of feeding grain to livestock, or using multiple crops in the same space instead of separating them. In short, this method of farming uses systemic, holistic approaches, rather than input substitution. Organic food in this sense is better for you and for the environment.Conversely, organic food may also refer to food labeled as such according to USDA standards, and whether this food is better is less obvious and can depend on the situation.For example, USDA organic certification mandates that cattle receive 30% of their diet from grazing. While their remaining diet may include certified organicgrain, cattle’s digestive systems evolved to process grass, and feeding themgrain causes health problems and results in beef that contains fewer nutrientsimportant to human health (such as vitamins and Omega 3 fatty acids). In thiscase, grass-fed beef may be better for you than organic beef.Another example involves non-certified organic polyculture as compared to certified organic monoculture. USDA organic standards allow monocultures, that is, large areas populated by a single crop type. Monoculture crops can produce a myriad of detrimental environmental effects, including stripping the soil of its nutrients (which can in turn result in less nutritious food), disrupting ecosystems, and jeopardizing biodiversity. Is organic monoculture better for the environment? Perhaps yes, if compared to conventional monoculture, and perhaps not, if compared to a non-certified polyculture that does not use chemical inputs.Farmers that practice organic agricultural methods in the first sense may choose to not certify their products as USDA organic for several reasons, including the cost of certification or disagreement over the value of USDA standards. I once met a dairy farmer who implemented many environmentally sustainable practices on his farm, but chose not to pursue certification because he thought it was cruel to not treat dairy cows with antibiotics when their udders were infected. USDA organic certification also does not address some important concepts in sustainable eating such as the nutritional and environmental costs of shipping food long distances, or the benefits of eating seasonally.While USDA organic certifications do not necessarily equate to healthier or moreenvironmentally friendly food, the standards are relatively new (the OrganicFoods Production Act passed in 1990) and are still being revised (amendments to the act including stricter standards on the treatment of livestock, among other things, will take effect this July). Several states and countries have organic certifications that differ from USDA standards, some of which attempt to more tightly embrace the emulation of natural plant and animal systems.Food may also be labeled according to other terms, such as “all natural”,“environmentally friendly”, or “Earth Friendly, Farm Friendly”. While theselabels may be accurate, they are not monitored or enforced by a governing body and there are no legally mandated national standards to which they must adhere. In fact, the “Earth Friendly, Farm Friendly” label is condoned by anorganization (the Center for Global Food Issues) partially funded by Monsanto that is anti-organic, and the Union of Concerned Scientists advises avoidingproducts with this label (according to their publication Earthwise).In sum, organic food is usually better for you and for the environment. However,in order to know for sure you must know the practices used when growing a particular food item, and because of ambiguous labeling this is often difficult.  Embed Quote

column9: Is it better for the environment?
column10: It depends on what food it is (see http://www.ewg.org/foodnews/summ... [1]) - but in general, fruits from the Rosaceae family (apples, peaches, nectarines, and strawberries), have the highest levels of neurotoxic pesticide contamination. However, most non-organic vegetables (except celery) do not contain such dangerous pesticides, so they probably aren't much more risky.The Rosaceae trees are also sprayed with neurotoxic herbicides that the USDA doesn't even measure - like paraquat and ziram - see What crops are most likely to be contaminated with ziram? Or paraquat?I haven't found any studies on the negative effects on people who consume the fruits yet (they also depend on the extent to which exposure to pesticides in food contributes to blood levels of pesticides in food), but there are studies that have found neurotoxic effects in people who simply live near fields that have been sprayed with pesticides (listed below). In that case, until we learn more, there is definitely good reason to advise caution with eating non-organic fruit from the Rosaceae trees if you naturally eat a lot of fruit.I don't think that you should worry about an increased risk of cancer (see Are we exposed to more carcinogens now than any other time in history?) or decreased lifespan at all. But there is a risk that all the pesticide residue could make you dumber if you eat a lot of fruit (this is more relevant for vegetarians/vegans than for most others). Most pesticides are quite selective by acting on the nervous systems on the pests, so they naturally have selective effects when consumed by people too.Here is a list of pesticides in the most contaminated fruitApples: http://www.whatsonmyfood.org/foo...Nectarines: http://www.whatsonmyfood.org/foo...Peaches: http://www.whatsonmyfood.org/foo...Pears: http://www.whatsonmyfood.org/foo...Strawberries: http://www.whatsonmyfood.org/foo...Celery: http://www.whatsonmyfood.org/foo...Almonds: http://www.whatsonmyfood.org/foo...[1] Note that the EWG site should only be seen as a rough source, and is somewhat misleading, as it counts the total number of pesticides inside. In reality, many of the "most contaminated" vegetables actually contain a lot of the more benign pesticides like the neonicotinoids. Also, note that the neurotoxic organophosphate Azinphos methyl will be banned by the EPA in mid-2012.=====So what's up with some of the pesticides I mentioned? Some of them have nasty neurological effects that have been demonstrated in people who simply live near areas where pesticides are sprayed (effects such as significant increases in one's risk of Parkinson's Disease, and yes - even decreases in intelligence). Many of these effects are not effects that you can capture through mortality data in animal (or human studies), and were only discovered in the last few years, so any conclusions (prior to 2010) about the safety of such pesticides are now moot.Now, do these effects transfer to consumers? We don't know yet. But we *do* know that they *do* apply for people who simply *live* near areas where pesticides are sprayed. Also - you can't get rid of pesticides by washing your produce: http://www.reddit.com/r/askscien... . And the major route of exposure to organophosphates (in children) is through food (see http://ehp03.niehs.nih.gov/artic... )Keep in mind that humans are especially vulnerable to neurological effects (there aren't really any animals that naturally develop Alzheimer's or Parkinson's - so any neurotoxicity will be underreported in most animal studies, and completely glossed over in lifespan studies. They often develop plaques but with no clear evidence of mental decline). See http://news.harvard.edu/gazette/... and Are there any animals that don't get Alzheimer's Disease?With that said - I'm not totally sure if pesticides do that much damage to the brains of most people, give... (more)Loading...

column9: Is it better for the environment?
column10: Frankly, I don't believe there's any convincing evidence thus far to support the claim that organic food is way better than "conventional" food.A review article analyzing a total of 240 studies was recently published in the Annals of Internal Medicine: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubm...For those interested in the short and sweet version, here are some links for you:http://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/0...http://www.usatoday.com/news/hea...http://www.latimes.com/health/bo...http://www.washingtonpost.com/bl...For those interested in the longer and nerdier version, I did a brief read of the paper, and apparently various analyses showed the following (my personal thoughts are in italics):No association between organic vs. conventional diet in the development of eczema, wheezing, serum IgE levels or other atopic conditions in children.Lower levels of pesticide metabolite levels in the urine of children on organic diets. Sounds scary. But realistically? What's the objective measurement here? You need a lot more data to prove this is clinically significant. If the level at which harm is seen is X and children on organic diets have 0.2X and children on conventional diets have 0.4X, does it really matter? Can you even prove it's due to diet, not other factors? Another study showed that household use of pesticides, NOT diet, predicted urinary insecticide levels.One study actually showed that consumption of organic meat in winter was a risk factor for infection with Campylobacter bacteria. So...this meat is more expensive, and it might cause greater rate of infection? Where exactly is the so-called benefit of being organic here?6 studies "found no consistent differences in plasma or urine carotenoids, polyphenols, vitamins E and C content, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, antioxidant activity, ability to protect against DNA damage, immune system markers, or semen quality between participants consuming organic and conventional diets" Again, not seeing any real benefits of spending lots of money for the organic label here...151 studies reported that harvesting or processing methods were the same for both organic and conventional foods; the rest didn't actually describe harvesting or processing methods. I find it rather difficult to believe that in the studies that did not report these methods, they were significantly different; if they were, any researcher worth their salt would've realized it would be an awesome conclusion to report."We did not find significant differences in the vitamin content of organic and conventional plant or animal products" So...maybe shopping for organic food only doesn't necessarily enhance vitamin intake...?A few studies found that organic milk and chicken had higher levels of omega-3 fatty acids. However, several studies showed that the season of sampling and brand affected these levels at LEAST as much as the farming method. Seriously, if you're that worried about omega-3 intake, you can get a year's supply for about $10 at Amazon or Costco. Much more cost-effective if you ask me.No difference in protein/fat between organic and conventional milk.Some studies showed higher levels of pesticide residues in conventional produce. Each study had a slightly different level of what was considered "positive", though. If you look at studies examining the prevalence of contamination exceeding maximum allowed limits, two studies showed no difference, and one actually showed 6% in organic vs. 2% in conventional...Prevalence of E. coli contamination in produce was 7% in organic vs. 6% in conventional. Of the 5 studies examining this, 4 showed higher risk for contamination among organic produce."differences in the prevalence of bacterial contamination between organic and conventional animal products were statistically insignificant" Interesting part: if you look at just pork, 65% of organic pork was contaminated with E. coli vs. 49% of conventional."No significant differences were found in the ascorbic acid content of cabbage (3 studies), carrots (3 studies), potatoes (3 studies), or tomatoes (8 studies); beta-carotene content of tomatoes (3 studies); or protein content of wheat (6 studies) when grown organically versus conventionally."I should note some of the problems with research in this field:Over half of studies don't actually list what on earth their standard for considering a product "organic" was. Why is this a problem? Well, European Union has one, many European countries have country-specific additional standards, the International Federation of Organic Agriculture Movements has another, and the U.S. Dept of Agriculture has yet another. They all have slightly different requirements.Some papers have really, really small sample sizes. Like...only 6 study subjects. It's kind of impossible to rely on such a study for a generalized view of humanity.Some papers have really, really short time periods. Like...only 2 days. It's kind of impossible to rely on such a study for a generalized view of longitudinal health outcomes 10, 20, 30 years down the line.Data analyzing produce can come from specialized experimental farms, which can control for factors such as weather, geography, etc; however, almost a third came from commercial farms that have no control over these factors, which may affect study results.There are no long-term studies of populations subsisting more on either organic or conventional foods, isolating this difference as the only variable. This is basically impossible at this time and for the near future for obvious logistical reasons.Hope this helps.  Embed QuoteThis answer is not a substitute for professional medical advic... (more)Loading... Via  Austin Conlon,  Mickael Bergeron Neron, and  Kovács András.

column9: Is it better for the environment?
column10: No, organic food is not nececssarily better for you.In my opinion, there is a lot of utter tosh talked about organic food by its producers, wholesalers, retailers, consumers and political promoters. And it shouldn't need to be said that most of these people have either commercial or ideological motives for extolling the virtues of organic produce. Because of this, their claims about its supposedly superior taste and nutritional value, its lower environmental impact, and so on, should be treated with no less circumspection and objective skepticism than they encourage us to apply to the counter-claims of their non-organic opponents. While some of the claims of the organic lobby may contain a grain of truth, they might still not be true in all circumstances, without exception. And it is relativiely easy to cherry-pick one's data, selecting that which supports one's viewpiont and ignoring that which does not. All successful marketing campaigns employ the dark art of 'creative  statistics'. Other claims for the benefits of organic food are flatly contradicted by the available evidence, and one suspects that those who repeat them and believe them are simply doing so because they have become dogmas and articles of faith within the 'wholefood movement', and to question them is regarded as dangerously heretical. But we must not let profits and politics obscure hard scientific data. Take just a few such claims about organic food, already repeated on here: Firstly, that organic food is more nutritious than conventionally produced food:[The] London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine examined 162 papersthat compared organic and conventionally produced food. They concluded that there was no evidence to back up claims that organic food is more nutritious. http://www.newscientist.com/arti... (subscription required for full article, but the research cited is below)'Our review indicates that there is currently no evidence to support the selection of organically over conventionally produced foods on the basis of nutritional superiority.' - Alan Dangour, London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine’s Nutrition and Public Health Intervention Research Unithttp://www.lshtm.ac.uk/news/2009...Secondly, that organic food carries less risk of bacterial or other contamination:Organic broiler chickens are three times as likely as conventionally-bred poultry to be contaminated with a bacterium that causes food-poisoning, say Danish vets. http://www.newscientist.com/arti...[By] shunning science, organic producers could be increasing consumers' risk of contracting Escherichia coli and other food-borne diseases....In theory, organic food could be more prone to microbial contamination due to the absence of preservatives and the use of manure as fertiliser....Studies carried out on organic and conventional produce by Minnesota farmers in 2004 found that E. coli contamination was 19 times greater on organic farms which used manure or compost less than 12 months old...Another extra risk factor in organic production is the avoidance of fungicides, which can lead to the growth of moulds and increased risk of mycotoxins such as aflatoxin and ergot in crops.http://www.newscientist.com/arti...Thirdly, that food irradiation is dangerous and degrades the nutritional value of foods: There is no evidence that food irradiation is harmful to consumers, and also no evidence that it affects the nutritional quality of food.See preceding link.Fourthly, that organic foods are inherently safer than conventionally produced foods because they are not treated with synthetic agrochemicals and additives:In contrast to the popular perception that chemical residues in food are the major source of food contamination, recent food-borne disease outbreaks have demonstrated that microbial hazards are much more significant for food safety (Cliver, 1999). The risks due to pesticide residues and food additives are relatively minor, compared with both acute and chronic effects caused by microbiological and other naturally occurring toxicants (Fig. 3) (Cliver, 1999). ... In the past decade, outbreaks of human diseases associated with the consumption of raw vegetables and fruits, or unpasteurised products originating from them, have significantly increased in number (Beuchat & Ryu, 1997; Keene, 1999)....consumers’ demand of minimally processed foods has had an apparent adverse influence on food safety (Zink, 1997)....Furthermore, there is no evidence that toxic hazards such as pesticides have had a major impact on total cancer mortality (Fisher & Worth, 1995); populations with diets rich in fruits and vegetables have a substantially lower risk of many types of cancer (Centers for Disease Control, 1999), despite the use of synthetic agrochemicals in conventional farming. Hence, the benefits may outweigh the risks....But neither is the organic label a seal of food safety. Organic refers only to a product that has been produced in accordance with certain standards throughout the production, handling, processing and marketing stages; it does not refer to the characteristics and properties of the finished product. The asserted health benefits are impossible to quantify and do not seem, as yet, to compensate for the increased price. ....Summing up, no hard evidence currently exists to support or refute claims that organic food is healthier and safer than conventional food, or vice versa, and assertions of such kind are inappropriate and not justified....The main health-promoting properties of food, however, lie in their ability to provide the human organism with carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins, minerals, fibre and protective factors needed for growth, repair, reproduction, energy and good health. Plants produce these complex nutrients from water, air, soil and sunlight. How well they do so is under the influence of many environmental and genetic factors, and the type of agriculture is only one variable.- Faidon Magkos, Fotini Arvaniti and Antonis Zampelas, Laboratory of Nutrition and Clinical Dietetics, Department of Nutrition and Dietetics, Harokopio Universityhttp://journals.cambridge.org/do...Regarding this last point, I recall reading about a scientist who was strongly pro-organic foods. [1][2]. He believed all the hype and propaganda put out by the wholefood industry, and set out to win the debate for organics by conducting research into the comparative toxicity of organic versus conventionally produced foods, with regard to the levels of carcinogens found in both, from either man-made or naturally occuring sources. The results he found shocked him, and completely reversed his previous beliefs: he discovered that organic foods contain many times (in some cases, thousands of times) more carcinogens than conventionally produced foods! He concluded that this was because the specific genetic varieties of crops chosen for organic agriculture are precisely those that produce the highest levels of natural fungicides, herbicides and pesticides, as these crops will be the most resistant to disease and infestation, and so produce the highest yields and least wastage from crop damage. The irony for organic farmers is that many of these naturally occurring substances are hugely more carcinogenic than the synthetic agrochemicals used in conventional agriculture!   Finally, this research article refutes many of the common claims made by proponents of organic food, particularly concerning claims that organic farming methods do not use any harmful chemicals (false) and are more 'sustainable' (false) and environmentally friendly (false). It makes interesting reading, and also contains an extensive list of references to related scientific ressearch:http://www.gene.ch/gentech/2001/...In summary, when you subtract all of the ideological rhetoric and commercial self-interest that currently distorts their arguments, the claims of organic proponents that 'organic is best' simply don't stand up to impartial scientific scrutiny. This doesn't mean that conventionally produced food is any safer or healthier (though some would argue that it is, at least in some cases). It simply means that organic food has yet to be proven superior in these respects. So continue to consume organic food if you want to, and if you can afford its typically higher prices (though many poorer people cannot, which is probably why organic food consumption has become something of a status symbol of the middle-classes in recent years). I'm willing to concede that some of it may even taste nicer than the conventional alternatives, though there is research that also refutes such claims.(Taste is subjective, of course, and I also wonder how much of this is psychological, with people convincing themselves that it tastes better simply because they have a pre-conceived belief that it should.) Just don't fool yourself into believing that it is any healthier or safer for you, because the jury is still out.[1] I have been wracking my brain to recall his name, so far to no avail, but his research is quite famous. Can anyone help?[2] I'm not sure if this is the same guy, but his research has uncovered more-or-less the same facts: http://texasbot.tripod.com/lovej...  Embed Quote

column9: Is it better for the environment?
column10: From what I understand, there isn't really any hard evidence to suggest that organic food is better for your body.  Organically grown food is without a doubt better for the environment and communities surrounding where the food is grown.  Embed Quote

column9: Is it better for the environment?
column10:
“Consumers may choose to buy organic fruit, vegetables and meat because they believe them to be more nutritious than other food. However, the balance of current scientific evidence does not support this view” – source: http://www.food.gov.uk/foodindus...    “There is little scientific evidence to prove that organic food is better in quality than conventional food”.  Source: http://www.organicfacts.net/orga...  
 There is probably (or will be soon) some scientist somewhere with data that will say it is better, but another that will contradict it.  Food purity, organics,local foods, pasture raised, etc.  -   are all ways to make extra money from the food consumers (us).  Books about “healthier” eating and speaking engagements by the authors are popular and will continue to be as long as they can keep us confused, concerned and insecure about our own choices... For some reason we always figure the more expensive item must be better for you.  Embed Quote

column9: Is it better for the environment?
column10:
Kali Albright's answer is very thorough and accurate. Outside of the the US and Canada, some organic certification processes may be dubious. 
  
 Katie is also correct that few long term studies show a nutritional benefit to organic products. But the studies showing the environmental benefits grows stronger each day. 
  
 My general rules of thumb are:
 Buy products grown in season, which tend to have the most time to have accumulated nutrients and is usually also grown closer to home. 
  
 If you can find local and certified organic, bonus! I love supporting my local farmer and his family's health. 
  
 From a nutrition point of view, cook vegetables as minimally as possible and save any cooking fluid for soup. 
  
 Try and have as many colours of the rainbow on your plate from veggies and fruit which will increase the likelihood of an array of vitamins, minerals and antioxidants. 
  
 Regardless of organic or not, use good food safe sanitation practices at all times.  Embed Quote

column9: Is it better for the environment?
column10: That organic is better for the environment is a no-brainer (assuming you didn't buy organic apples from New Zealand instead of non-organic ones from your native UK!) Better for human nutritional health? Intuitively, it feels like 'as nature intended' ought to be. I think the 'better' gap may be pretty small for some foods, but fairly significant for others. A very new UK study of cows' milk discovered the organic to be far healthier than non-organic, in terms of fat composition. There are other factors too. Can you get all the pesticide residues out of your non-organic carrot, even if studies claim the nutritional quality matches organic? And what of other factors like freshness? Non organic veg straight from the field of a neighbouring farm is likely to have a lot more vitamins in it than something organic that has been kicking around in the retail system for days on end. But like for like, organic is surely the best.  Embed Quote

Even though many would say that there are no 100% organic these days due to the polluted environment we have. Still, minimizing the risks of eating food filled with chemicals will be good for our body.Here is an article which can be helpful for you to decide whether organic is truly better for us: http://www.naturallygrassfed.com...  Embed Quote
