column9: Is it better for the environment?
column10: Organic food is decidedly better for your body, the body of old Ma Earth, and society (organic farmers make a better living). What follows comes from the Organic Consumers Association:Beyond Frankenfoods and Toxics: OCA’s Ten Reasons to Buy OrganicOrganic foods and products are the fastest growing items in America's grocery carts. Thirty million households, comprising 75 million people, are now buying organic foods, clothing, body care, supplements, pet food, and other products on a regular basis. Fifty-six percent of U.S. consumers say they prefer organic foods.Here are 10 reasons why you should buy organic foods and products:1. Organic foods are produced without the use of Genetically Modified Organisms (GMOs). Consumers worry about untested and unlabeled genetically modified food ingredients in common supermarket items. Genetically engineered ingredients are now found in 75% of all non-organic U.S. processed foods, even in many products labeled or advertised as “natural.” In addition the overwhelming majority of non-organic meat, dairy, and eggs are derived from animals reared on a steady diet of GM animal feed. Although polls indicate that 90% of Americans want labels on gene-altered foods, government and industry adamantly refuse to respect consumers’ right to know, understanding quite well that health and environmental-minded shoppers will avoid foods with a GMO label.2. Organic foods are safe and pure. Organic farming prohibits the use of toxic pesticides, antibiotics, growth hormones, nano-particles, and climate-destabilizing chemical fertilizers. Consumers worry about pesticide and drug residues routinely found in non-organic produce, processed foods, and animal products. Consumer Reports has found that 77% of non-organic produce items in the average supermarket contain pesticide residues. The beef industry has acknowledged that 94% of all U.S. beef cattle have hormone implants, which are banned in Europe as a cancer hazard. Approximately 10% of all U.S. dairy cows are injected with Monsanto and Elanco’s controversial genetically engineered Bovine Growth Hormone, banned in most industrialized nations. Recent studies indicate that an alarming percentage of non-organic U.S. meat contains dangerous antibiotic-resistant bacteria.3. Organic foods and farming are climate-friendly. Citizens are increasingly concerned about climate-destabilizing greenhouse gas pollution (CO2, methane, and nitrous oxide), 35-50% of which in North America comes from our energy-intensive, chemical-intensive food and farming system. Organic farms and ranches, on the other hand, use far less fossil fuel and can safely sequester large amounts of CO2 in the soil (up to 7,000 pounds of CO2 per acre per year, every year.) Twenty-four billion pounds of chemical fertilizers applied on non-organic farms in the U.S. every year not only pollute our drinking water and create enormous dead zones in the oceans; but also release enormous amounts of nitrous oxide, a super potent, climate-destabilizing greenhouse gas.4. Organic food certification prohibits nuclear irradiation. Consumers are justifiably alarmed about irradiating food with nuclear waste or electron beams, which destroy vitamins and nutrients and produce cancer-causing chemicals such as benzene and formaldehyde. The nuclear industry, large food processors, and slaughterhouses continue to lobby Congress to remove required labels from irradiated foods and replace these with misleading labels that use the term "cold pasteurization." The USDA and large meat companies have promoted the use of irradiated meat in school lunches and senior citizen facilities. Many non-organic spices contain irradiated ingredients.5. Consumers worry about rampant e-coli, salmonella, campylobacter, Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), and fecal contamination in animal products coming out of the nation’s inhumane and filthy slaughterhouses. The Centers for Disease Control have admitted that up to 76 million Americans suffer from food poisoning every year. Very few cases of food poisoning have ever been linked to organic farms or food processors.6. Consumers are concerned about billions of pounds of toxic municipal sewage sludge dumped as “fertilizer” on 140,000 of America’s chemical farms. Scientific evidence has confirmed that municipal sewage sludge contains hundreds of dangerous pathogens, toxic heavy metals, flame-retardants, endocrine disruptors, carcinogens, pharmaceutical drugs and other hazardous chemicals coming from residential drains, storm water runoff, hospitals, and industrial plants. Organic farming categorically prohibits the use of sewage sludge.7. Consumers worry about the routine practice of grinding up slaughterhouse waste and feeding this offal and blood back to other animals, a practice that has given rise to a form of human mad-cow disease called CJD, often misdiagnosed as Alzheimer’s disease. Animals on organic farms cannot be fed slaughterhouse waste, manure, or blood—daily rations on America’s factory farms.8. Consumers care about the humane treatment of animals. Organic farming prohibits intensive confinement and mutilation (debeaking, cutting off tails, etc.) of farm animals. In addition to the cruel and unhealthy confinement of animals on factory farms, scientists warn that these CAFOs (Confined Animal Feeding Operations) produce enormous volumes of manure and urine, which not only pollute surface and ground water, but also emit large quantities of methane, a powerful climate-destabilizing greenhouse gas.9. Consumers are concerned about purchasing foods with high nutritional value. Organic foods are nutritionally dense compared to foods produced with toxic chemicals, chemical fertilizers, and GMO seeds. Studies show that organic foods contain more vitamins, cancer-fighting anti-oxidants, and important trace minerals.10. Consumers care about preserving America’s family farms, world hunger, and the plight of the world’s two billion small farmers. Just about the only small farmers who stand a chance of making decent living these days are organic farmers, who get a better price for their products. In addition study after study has shown that small organic farms in the developing world produce twice as much food per acre as chemical and GMO farms, while using far less fossil fuel and sequestering large amounts of excess CO2 in the soil. Yields on organic farms in the industrialized world are comparable to the yields on chemical and GMO farms, with the important qualification that organic farms far out-produce chemical farms under extreme weather conditions of drought or torrential rains. Of course given accelerated climate change, extreme weather is fast becoming the norm.For all these reasons, millions of American consumers are turning to organic foods and other organic items, including clothing and body care products--part of an overall movement toward healthy living, preserving the environment, and reversing global warming.http://www.commondreams.org/view...  Embed Quote

column9: Is it better for the environment?
column10: If you are trying to eat healthy, you already know that you should be including plenty of fruits, vegetables and lean protein in your daily diet.  But what about eating organic foods?  Are they healthier?  What constitutes organic food?  And will there be a noticeable difference in your overall healthy if you eat organic foods?Proponents of organic foods say that it is healthier, safer, better tasting and better for the environment.  Most often, organic food is significantly more expensive than non-organic foods.  Although the demand for organic foods has dramatically risen in recent years, there is very little evidence that shows positive proof that eating organic foods has a material difference in your overall health.  There is very limited information on the actual health outcomes of consuming organic foods over regular food.What constitutes organic food?  In order to be considered organic, crops must be grown without the use of pesticides, synthetic fertilizers or bioengineering.  Organically raised animals used for meat must be given organic feed and be free of steroids, growth hormone and antibiotics.Because there is not enough evidence to show non-organic foods as being unhealthy and dangerous, the actual health benefits of eating organic foods are not conclusive.  And at this point, there is not enough evidence to show a significant health benefit of eating organic foods over conventionally produced foods.  So eating organic or non-organic foods comes down to personal preference. When eating organic fruits and vegetables, the amount of pesticide residue is dramatically reduced and when eating organic meat, you are not running the risk of ingesting growth hormone or antibiotics.                                                     For more Health and Fitness Tips Follow me on Twitter @JackKenefick or on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/OrangeC.... You can also check out my blog post on this at http://www.balanced-life-fitness... along with many other blog post on Fitness and Health!  Embed Quote

Indoors:Get an air purifier in your bedroom. If you're very concerned, put one in every room. If you live near a major highway, don't leave your windows open at night as that's when all the heavy duty, black smoke belching trucks come by.If you haven't already, consider using face wash and lotion daily. Beijing is very dry compared to most temperate US cities, this compounds with the pollution to irritate the skin. Outdoors:Check the pollution index every day (http://aqicn.org/city/beijing/). The pollution is especially bad after sunset, but is lowest in the morning. If you want to go running outside, do it in the morning, and not at night. There are many masks to choose from, but you'll want one with a rating of N90 and above. That means it filters out 90% of airborn particles. Here's what a simple one looks like. You can find these in 7-11, and they are inconspicuous Beijing pollution levels average around an index of 100, which is "unhealthy". Even if the pollution is below 100 in the daytime, it almost always jumps up at night. If you ride a bicycle you're going to be smack dab in the middle of the main cause of pollution, cars. You'll want a heavier mask like one of these:Live the cyberpunk dystopian future, today!Be sure to check your filters and replace them! (picture is from a cyclist who reported this was from just one day of biking!)Rain and effects on pollution levelsIn Beijing, pollution levels drop drastically the day after it rains, approaching the tolerable levels of an American city such as New York. These are the most pleasant days and are sunny too. But the heavy cloudy days building up to rain can be quite high in pollution levels. But remember, when that rain is falling, it's carrying everything in the Beijing air with it. Wash your clothes as soon as you can, I've had a rain soaked white shirt left unwashed overnight and now it's been permanently stained with blacksih spots. Wash it off your skin as soon as you can.Enjoy Beijing, and cherish the days where the sun shines brightly on a blue sky  Embed Quote
Make yourself strong enough that you can live without breathing. LOL  Embed Quote

Air pollution in China can be awful and is nothing to trifle with (see, for example, China breaks saddest record ever: 8-year-old is youngest lung-cancer patient). When Beijing has good air quality days it's lovely, but on bad air quality days (which are the majority)…well, here are some photos I took:And here's a collage from Weibo of 365 consecutive days of sky photos.The point being, Beijing's air pollution should be taken seriously. Download an air quality index (AQI) app, keep track of the air where you are, and react appropriately when pollution is bad. When the pollution is bad, this means avoiding physical exercise, not burning candles indoors (even though the air is stinky), keeping the windows shut, and having your air filters on.My wife and I did the following:Bought air purifiers for the home.You don't need to spend a fortune on an air filter. You can even build your own: How to Make a DIY Air Purifier.We started out with a generic HEPA filter from Midea. We changed the filters every three months instead of every six; we could tell when it was time to change because the air flow from the front vents would be noticably lower. Gross.The morning after we bought the filter was the first time since moving to Beijing that I didn't wake up with a sore throat from having a runny nose all night. I was sold.This filter did fine, but we eventually upgraded to a BlueAir. I didn't notice any difference between it and the Midea; I just kept not having a cough or a sore throat from the pollution. The BlueAir was nice, though, because it was quieter than the Midea, and we got it at a great price.Now, expats in Beijing love to talk air purifiers and show off their latest, expensive, buy, but I think that you're fine buying any HEPA purifier that can change the air in the room 3+ times/hour. I know others have argued that BlueAir &c are better because of the pre-filtering that takes out chemical fumes from construction and renovation, but if your apartment is full of formaldehyde fumes, maybe you should move.Bought those air-cleaning plants everyone talks about.Do they work? There's quite a bit of research to indicate they do, but I thought the effect (if any) from the plants we bought was much less noticeable than that of our HEPA filter. According to one source (which has a great list of NASA-approved plants for purifying the air), NASA research indicated you should have one plant per 10m^2 of floorspace, so be prepared to buy quite a few. The plants that we had be best luck with was mother-in-law's tongue. They are still going strong after three years.Luckily, most of these air cleaning plants are ubiquitous and cheap, so go to the flower market next to the US Embassy and have fun shopping and haggling over plants. If you want to buy large plants, try to get them from the same seller, as delivery will be included in the price.Bought a totobobo mask.This was sort of a low point of living in Beijing, acceding to the idea that to go outside I really should wear a mask to breathe. However, life was better with the mask than without it, so I wore the damn thing.When you are looking at pollution masks, there are two things to keep in mind: filtering ability and fit. If the mask isn't able to filter fine particles (the lingo most often heard about this is "N95"), it's worthless. The cloth masks you see people wearing don't do anything for pollution. Similarly, if the mask doesn't have a tight, consistent seal to your face, dirty air leaks in and the mask isn't as effective.We bought totobobo masks, which are great because (a) you can cut them to fit your face, ensuring proper fit, and (b) they have replaceable filters. On bad air quality days, our air filters would go grey after an hour of outdoor wear. (Think about that for a little bit…) This is a photo of my mask with new filters after an hour of wear on an AQI 300+ day.  The main downside to the totobobo is that moisture accumulates inside it. After about an hour of wear I'd need to take it off and swab out the inside.We have left Beijing, mostly because of the air pollution. The government says that it should have the problem fixed in "five to ten years". I'm skeptical of that, but hope it's true.  Embed Quote

Actually, it's not been that terrible in recent years. Anway I shall give you some tips nevertheless: Indoor: you may buy a air purifier and have some evergreen plants;Outdoor: a mask is necessary on windy and sandy days, and try to avoid rush hour;Other: if you are used to running outside, there are some gardens like Olympic Green which is good, especially if you are living nearby. And do not run along the ring roads, where there is heavy traffic. If you want to do some excercise, find a gym or club nearby.I have posted some pictures to show you the best time of the year in Beijing. I took these photos on my way to school yesterday.Around the library Kun Yu river,  I live nearbythe sunset glowSo do you feel better now? Come on, there are 20 million people here. Have fun in Beijing.  Embed Quote

Illustration on how  TiO2 (Titanium Dioxide) work:Figure above shows the TiO2 Photocatalyst [2]Fig 1: The photosynthetic reaction in plant is basically similar to the photocatalytic reaction in titanium oxide. 1. Sometimes it's not so bad, sometimes it's very bad. Check the U.S. Embassy Air Quality Monitoring Website before going out.2. When the AQI is bad, wear one of these:  Embed Quote

Hi Luke, thanks for the recommendation! I'm the nerd that did all the home air experiments and started Particle Counting. I started to get really concerned about air pollution during the "airpocalypse," but I was shocked at having to spend $1,000 on a single air purifier (let alone the replacement filters). So I researched how filters work and made my own. I posted all of my data and tests online, for example: 1. Live test of the filter2. Tests showing the DIY filter gets an average of 84% of particles larger than .5 microns and 92% of particles larger than 2.5 microns3. Tests of a newer, stronger model that gets 96% of both!Instructions on how to make one are on the Tumblr. However, several people told me they were having trouble finding the parts, so I've started ordering in bulk and shipping from Smart Air. My hope is that my nerd-ery can help people stay healthy without giving a wheelbarrow full of cash to filter companies.And Luke, you're right--particles aren't everything. If people are concerned about fumes from construction, you can add an activated carbon filter to the DIY pretty easily.  Embed Quote

Take cabs, not the subway, not a moped, and not a bicycle when the weather is particularly bad. Being in a car with no windows open makes a HUGE difference on your air quality. I learned that from a UN researcher in an Environment of China class. When pollution measures are off the charts (which happens a couple times a month), avoid going outside altogether. This might sound extreme, but if you plan on living in Beijing for years plural, its important. Lung related illnesses are the number one cause of death in Beijing. To know when the weather is bad, get a VPN and follow @beijingair on Twitter. It's a device that measures pollution by parts per million and I believe its on top of the US embassy in Beijing. It's also worthwhile to understand what the measures mean. The smaller the particles, the worse for your lungs. Everyone was freaking out with all the construction dust before the Olympics, but that just makes your boogers blacks, not a big deal.  Embed Quote
Inhale as infrequently as possible.  Embed Quote
Dont go there if you are worried about that in the first place  Embed Quote

I found this infographic that reveals that "Particulate matter in indoor pollution can inflame the airways and lungs -- which impairs immune response, reduces the blood's oxygen-carrying capacity, and increases allergic reactions."  The ability of bad air to reduce the blood-oxygen level can certainly have effects on mental productivity.  The two are very closely correlated.  Infographic is here: Plumbing Tips Heating Tips Air Conditioning Tips AC  Embed Quote

column9: I'm trying to see if there's a chemical reaction in which PM10 particles or other pollutants in the air can form another (larger) substance that can be used in a beneficial manner.Is there a sustainable model for air purification of public spaces?
column10: This perhaps not the best way, but to eliminate air pollution sustainably require elimination/ minimize air pollution at source(s) - One way is plant a trees (a butt load of it) - grow an urban forest.Credit: [6]Trees and other plants make their own food from carbon dioxide (CO2) in the atmosphere, water, sunlight and a small amount of soil elements. In the process, they release oxygen (O2) for us to breathe.Trees:Help to settle out, trap and hold particle pollutants (dust, ash, pollen and smoke) that can damage human lungs.Absorb CO2 and other dangerous gasses and, in turn, replenish the atmosphere with oxygen.Produce enough oxygen on each acre for 18 people every day.Absorb enough CO2 on each acre, over a year's time, to equal the amount you produce when you drive your car 26,000 miles. Trees remove gaseous pollutants by absorbing them through the pores in the leaf surface. Particulates are trapped and filtered by leaves, stems and twigs, and washed to the ground by rainfall.Air pollutants injure trees by damaging their foliage and impairing the process of photosynthesis (food making). They also weaken trees making them more susceptible to other health problems such as insects and diseases.The loss of trees in our urban areas not only intensifies the urban "heat-island" effect from loss of shade and evaporation, but we lose a principal absorber of carbon dioxide and trapper of other air pollutants as well.Some of the major air pollutants and their primary sources are:Carbon dioxide: Burning oil, coal, natural gas for energy. Decay and burning of tropical forests.Sulfur dioxide: Burning coal to generate electricity.Hydrogen floride and silicon tetrafloride: Aluminum and phospate fertilizer production, oil refineries, and steel manufacturing.Ozone: Chemical reactions of sunlight on automobile exhaust gases. Ozone is a major pollutant in smog.Methane: Burning fossil fuels, livestock waste, landfills and rice production.Nitros oxides: Burning fossil fuels and automobile exhausts.Chloroflorocarbons: Air conditioners, refrigerators, industrial foam.The burning of fossil fuels for energy and large scale forest fires such as in the tropics are major contributors to the buildup of CO2 in the atmosphere.Managing and protecting forests and planting new trees reduces CO2 levels by storing carbon in their roots and trunk and releasing oxygen into the atmosphere.[3]Reference:Forest Service Study Finds Urban Trees Removing Fine Particulate Air Pollution, Saving Lives.Trees Reduce Air PollutionTrees Capture Particulate Matter From Road ExhaustModeled PM2.5 removal by trees in ten U.S. ci... [Environ Pollut. 2013]http://www.nrpa.org/uploadedFile...Beirut's Roofs and Walls Ripe for a Green Takeover  Embed Quote

column9: This is a follow-up question to What is the difference between various gas station brands?.
column10: The difference you're seeing is actually due to different measurement methods used between the US/Canada and other countries.  US & Canada uses AKI ratings which is roughly 5 points lower than the equivalent RON rating used by other countries. 87/89/93 gasoline in the US are the same as 91/94/98 elsewhere.As a sidenote, only 98 RON is available in Hong Kong, when most cars on the road only require 95 RON or lower. As a result, groups like the Motor Industry Institute have called for lower octane gas made available there.References:- http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oct...- http://www.stretcher.com/stories...- http://www.hkimi.org.hk/technolo...  Embed Quote

column9: This is a follow-up question to What is the difference between various gas station brands?.
column10: 98 RON is also available in Europe when most cars require only 95 RON. Introduction of ethanol should increase Octane index (using same fuel base) allowing engine efficiency improvment (compression ratio).  Embed Quote

column9: I've been wearing one on my bicycle commutes in Beijing and it turns grey / brownish surprisingly fast.  How can I figure out when the best time to replace it is?  I am torn between wanting not to be spending a lot of money on these filters and not wanting to breathe this air. A sentiment I suspect shared by the asker of Are there any particulate filters for the consumer market ?At the moment, moving out of Beijing is not an option so let's just throw that out now.
column10: The longer a mask is worn the more particles will get trapped (or loaded) onto the filters in the mask.  Breathing resistance (airflow resistance) increases as a function of the loading.  At some point it will be very difficult for you to breath easily through the filter part of the mask and you will just be sucking air around the face seal.  You'll want to replace the filter before you reach that point.  Unfortunately, this is difficult to judge as changes in breathing resistance are a function of the size and concentration of particles in the air and the design of the pollution mask (i.e., it varies model to model).  If the mask is a NIOSH certified N95 respirator, NIOSH recommends that the device be changed out after 8 hours of continuous or intermittent use. http://www.cdc.gov/niosh/npptl/t... http://annhyg.oxfordjournals.org...  Embed QuoteVia  Russell Stadler.

That's a positive and a negative.Other than that, the constant greyness does make one feel gloomy when it hasn't let up for more than a week.My line is: "You know it's a good day in Beijing when things have shadows". column9: I think one of the most polluting religion is Hinduism. I curse myself daily for being born in a hindu family.
column10: Chill, dude.Pollution is not anywhere in the top 10 list of horrible things about Hinduism in particular, or religions (all of them) in general. There are people out there killing other people in the name of religion (and this is true of most major religions of the world). Do you really want to get worked up over pollution?As to why this is a part of Hinduism, the simple answer is that this made much more sense 2500 years ago when these rituals were probably first practiced. In those days, with much lower populations, and societies living close to nature, pollution was not a problem. Fire was what separated humans from the animals, and was great for purification, cooking and other "good" things. There was no electricity, or natural gas, so all heating required coal or wood.Some of these rituals don't make sense now - but the nature of religions (as most people follow them) makes it difficult to adapt to modern conditions.  All religions suffer from this problem of having to follow rituals and rules that made sense thousands of years ago, but don't any longer.And finally, do you really think that pollution due to havans is really a pressing problem? Have you tried to estimate how much of the pollution in India is caused by havans, and how much is caused by your motorcycle, and how much was caused by the factories that built the laptop and mobile phone you're using?  Embed Quote

column9: I think one of the most polluting religion is Hinduism. I curse myself daily for being born in a hindu family.
column10: As Navin Kabra rightly highlighted in his answer, the rituals were designed to serve a purpose but are not adapted to current living standards and environment.As far as havans/yagnas are concerned, it was/is considered a good thing to offer specific materials to the fire as the heating of them in certain proportion would cleanse the environment and have positive impact on the body and soul. The Rishis of those times were also experts in Ayurveda and other medicines. So they mostly came up with such rituals where positive effects of such havans can be reached to a good number of people. One such example is the bonfire at the night of Holi (Holika Dahan). Originated from a religious believes, this fire does cleanse the air from the insects that specifically originates in fields after winter harvest.So in some cases, the rituals were originally started to have a positive impact but probably over the time they might have become a reason for pollution. But again, how much is their contribution to over all rise of pollution in recent times?  Embed Quote

column9: I think one of the most polluting religion is Hinduism. I curse myself daily for being born in a hindu family.
column10: All religions worship the higher source/energy in the form of fire, seen as lighting candles or lamps during prayers. It’s an ancient method of submitting the pleas and prayers to the higher source beseeching their Divine blessings.Only difference is lighting candles and lamps have invisible toxic gases (CO2 and CO mainly) while Havan has visible fumes due to solid substances being burnt. and believe me these gases produced by lamps/candles are as toxic as burning any form of gasoline which is far worse than outcomes of Havan.Few images to prove what other religion followers are doing:Christians (candles/lamps):Shingon Buddism (fire):Islam (another form of pollution):So as every other religion has some ceremony you can call pollution until you do some research and get to real meaning of those acts.Coming back to Havan again:In fact Havan is performed as a personal ritual performed for the benefit of the society or the whole living beings.Havan(Homam) is not just burning some woods and eatables for sake of performing a typical ritual with no reasons. Though I am sure lot of people does not know the real benefits behind the act. Here are few facts about ingredients used in Havan and their benefits: 1. Havan Samagri(a mixture of various dried herbal medicines, roots and leaves) is offered in the blazed fire which disseminates in micro form, in the air, to purify the environment besides activating the air as disinfectant germicidal agent.2. Pure Ghee (Butter made from cow milk) is burned in fire which gets converted into micro form to purify damp air.3. Camphor (Kapoor):Camphor is used in almost all Havan ceremonies. Camphor is a cough suppressant which helps avoid cough to the people performing Havan as they have to sit next to fire during ceremony. Camphor will deter snakes and other reptiles due to its strong odor. Similarly, camphor is believed to be toxic to insects and is thus sometimes used as a repellent.There are many different thing which seem illogical at first but they make lot of sense when you go behind the real reasons.I am sure you will start feeling very blessed one day when you understand real essence behind Sanatana Dharma (Hinduism). Smog consists of a mixture of gases and particulate matter (PM), microscopic particles suspended in air, that are emitted from various sources as well as the products from these compounds when they are chemically reacted in the atmosphere. Currently the two compounds that we are most concerned about for health reasons are ozone and PM.Ozone is not directly released to the atmosphere but is formed from the reactions of nitrogen oxides and hydrocarbons in the presence of sunlight. Nitrogen oxides are emitted from cars, trucks and power plants. Hydrocarbons are also emitted from vehicles but have other man-made (industrial, household chemicals, paints, etc.) and natural (vegetation) sources as well.Particulate matter (PM) in smog has direct emission sources from cars and trucks, but these are overwhelmed by the PM that is chemically formed in the atmosphere. PM contains various chemical compounds: organics, sulfate, nitrate, ammonium and elemental carbon make up most of the mass. Organics have direct sources from cars and trucks, but are mostly formed in the atmosphere from hydrocarbons emitted from man-made and natural sources. Sulfate is formed from sulfur dioxide that has large sources from coal-fired power plants. Nitrate is formed from nitrogen oxides from vehicles and power plants. Ammonium is formed from ammonia from agriculture and vehicles. Nitrate is more abundant at cooler temperatures, as it forms a volatile salt with ammonium, ammonium nitrate, that is more stable at lower temperatures. Elemental carbon, also called black carbon, is directly emitted from predominantly Diesel vehicles.  Embed Quote

Industry in general is a major source of particulate matter. Industries such as cement, steel, and power generation create massive amounts of particulate matter (PM2.5) in the course of their normal operations. These emissions are controlled by the use of a dust collection system (known as a baghouse). These systems suck up the fugitive dust, or dust-laden air and send it through a fabric filter (baghouse filter), which traps the dust particles but allows the air to pass through. In areas where smog and PM pollution are notoriously high, such as in Southern California, the emissions limits for PM2.5 VOCs (Volatile Organic Chemicals) and mercury (now also nationwide) are much stricter than in other places due to their direct role in the formation of smog. In these places usually factories, and industrial sites in general will have to constantly monitor the amount of particulate that is being exhausted into the atmosphere. If they exceed their limit for any substantial period of time (sometimes only hours) they face massive fines and even being shut down by the regulatory bodies. Samuel DalSantoParticulate FilterBaghouse.comAir Pollution  Embed Quote

After you start blowing your nose, the mucous will be the color of the dust around you . column9: How much CO2 is being pumped into the atmosphere due to server farms? Water quality? What other global impact does the Internet have?
column10: While some may say that it has negative impacts on the environment, it also has numerous potentially positive effects on it.Largely thanks to the computer, people no longer need to buy so many separate appliances anymore. Lots of Gen Y'ers [1] no longer buy a TV, stereo, radio, or numerous other appliances - simply because they can get everything they need off the Internet. Similarly, with the spread of digital distribution, Gen Y'ers are now buying physical media less and less too. So it translates into far less energy used to make things (and reduced CO2 emissions).The Internet has also significantly decreased the amount of mail the post office has to process through (which has caused some funding crises in the post office) - and it also has spelled trouble for the newspaper industry. But do you know what this means? Fewer trees are killed [2]. With e-readers on the rise, this is also more likely to happen with books.As some people prefer Internet interaction to long-distance interaction (in many cases - sure it's more rewarding to interact in real-life with your close friends, but with those who you aren't so close to, is it really that much more rewarding?), they drive less and take the airplane less. This means reduced CO2 emissionsTelecommuting also has significant potential, and could easily reduce the amount people need to commute. This also means reduced CO2 emissionsNow, let's not deny that computers have to use electricity and pump CO2 into the atmosphere. But really - the fact is - people are going to need a computer no matter what these days (so there's just a fixed lump sum production cost that is going to be happen anyways), and computers are not particularly more energy intensive than a 100-Watt lightbulb. In fact, I can definitely say that thanks to the Internet, I won't need as big of a house as I thought I would need (in the future), since most of the things I need will be in digital form.There are other names used for this new era - the "digital transformation", and the "post-materialistic" ageNow, using Chris Riso's recent report, we can also expect a savings of...186 MtCO2e from e-commerce533 MtCO2e from telecommuting181 MtCO2e from teleconferencing61 MtCO2e from dematerializationAnd it all adds up to a savings of 961 MtCO2e. This is actually greater than the total footprint of the ICE sector in 2007 (830 MtCO2e) - although this sector will experience annual growth.[1] Generation Y - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gen... - the generation that is currently coming of age[2] Yes, I'm actually aware that raising trees and killing them could actually act as a form of carbon sequestration, but http://www.physicsforums.com/sho... convinced me otherwise  Embed Quote

column9: How much CO2 is being pumped into the atmosphere due to server farms? Water quality? What other global impact does the Internet have?
column10: The asker should definitely look into the Smart 2020 report, which was produced by The Climate Group in partnership with the Global e-Sustainability Initiative (GeSI):http://www.smart2020.org/_assets... Pg 17: "In 2007, the total footprint of the ICT [information and communications technology] sector – including personal computers (PCs) and peripherals, telecoms networks and devices and data centres – was 830 MtCO2e, about 2% of the estimated total emissions from human activity released that year."If you're interested specifically in data centers, on pg 21 it's estimated that in 2002 these accounted for 76 MtCO2e. The report forecasts 7% annual growth in emissions from this source, so you can do the math.Alex mentioned some of the ways that the use of the Internet can reduce emissions from other sources; the Smart 2020 report includes some in-depth exploration of this topic for some specific technologies. Additional case studies were included in a recent report by the Carbon Disclosure Project (my organization): https://www.cdproject.net/Docume...  Embed Quote

column9: Require all major factories (emitting pollutants above a certain threshold) to install filters. Major companies should be rich enough to not go bankrupt because of such regulation (give them a generous grace period to adjust if necessary). Would this not solve most of China's air pollution problem? What's preventing it from happening?
column10: Adding to Kirk's good answer, air pollution in China is not that simple, and there are several answers to your question.Of course, there are things that major factories could do. The central government is currently in a serious campaign to make factories upgrade their facilities, but this is harder than it sounds. The central government is authoritarian but not as powerful as many outside China imagine. Many large factories are protected by local governments through some combination of being important to local production numbers and employment, and outright corruption. There are lots of other factories that are small, gray-market affairs - literally, a dozen people in a corrugated steel shed with some equipment and a smokestack - and it's hard to find them all and even harder to make them clean. Even if you shut them down, they open again next week somewhere else.But lots of air pollution is not caused by factories (I don't have actual proportions, maybe someone can find some numbers.) Some is caused by mining, some is caused by farmers burning agricultural waste, some is caused by trucks, tractors, etc, burning dirty fuel, and an increasing amount of it is caused by middle class people driving cars. All of these require their own solutions.The central government actually has figured out over the past year or two (too late or not, we will find out) that air pollution is a problem that needs to be solved - not an unfortunate by-product of development, but an existential crisis that is killing growth and if not addressed has the potential to end Party rule in China. So now air pollution is being treated very, very seriously. Teams of environmental inspectors from Beijing are being sent down to the provinces to do tests. State-owned firms are getting the message that now is the time to make those changes they have been dragging their feet on. Lower grades of coal and diesel are being phased out. Restrictions on car ownership and use are spreading.The consensus I have heard from both Chinese and foreigners who follow China is that all this will have results. But it will take time, just as it did in the West. London and LA both had serious air pollution problems (the kind that killed a lot of people) and both solved them, but it took decades.  Embed Quote

column9: Require all major factories (emitting pollutants above a certain threshold) to install filters. Major companies should be rich enough to not go bankrupt because of such regulation (give them a generous grace period to adjust if necessary). Would this not solve most of China's air pollution problem? What's preventing it from happening?
column10: It's not that easy.  Public policy usually isn't.One major problem is that air pollution is regional.  For example, the thing about Beijing air pollution is that most of it comes from outside of Beijing.  If the coal factories that caused Beijing pollution were located in Beijing it would be easy to deal with, but since they come from other provinces, the companies there are in no mood to install any sort of equipment which costs them a lot but doesn't benefit them.At that point you have to deal with things at the national level.  First of all this involves balancing Beijing's interests with other interests, which means a lot of meetings which take a lot of time.  Second you have the problem that even if the national government issues an order, all of the implementation takes place locally which means that you have to find some mechanism to insure that local governments aren't just reporting that they are following instructions and then ignore them. None of this is unfixable, but it involves a lot of meetings and negotiations, and will take a few years.  It's been done before.  The United States ran into exactly the same problem, and one of the nice things about the Clean Air Act is the it gives a pretty good mechanism for how to deal with air pollution.  Essentially the Federal government issues standards, but state governments are required to come up with the way of actually meeting those standards and the EPA and state government agree as to what needs to be done and how.  Embed Quote

column9: Require all major factories (emitting pollutants above a certain threshold) to install filters. Major companies should be rich enough to not go bankrupt because of such regulation (give them a generous grace period to adjust if necessary). Would this not solve most of China's air pollution problem? What's preventing it from happening?
column10: I am sorry to tell you that there is no magic filters on this world that could one shot solve air pollution... The coal power stations and local heat stations are major sources of air pollution in China. To change their emission they need to completely upgrade their facilities (much more than just adding a filter), burn more efficient (and more expensive) coal, or of course, shut down (like many has already did). China is looking desperately for alternatives like wind and solar generations but those plants tend to have much smaller output and cannot satisfy the growing power demands from urban areas.  Embed QuoteAnswered in nine minutes.

As touched upon already, air pollution is a consequence of massive resource consumption, and there are different sources of air pollution, not just cars. However, I'm going to speak from a North American perspective (Hong Kong, as Anonymous points out, has different sources of air pollution, given 90% of people take transit there already). I argue that land use, not public transit, plays a bigger factor in reducing greenhouse gas emissions. Without proper land use, you can have lots of buses go any where, but they wouldn't be able to meet the right ridership since everything is far apart. As Seth Andrzejewski points out, land use is very critical. Your goal: you want to be able to reduce the travel time from your origin to your place of destination, so you choose the mode of transportation that is the least costly, from a time and monetary perspective. You want to reduce the time it takes to take to get to work or buy groceries. For example, if you can make the places between where you live and the places you want to go (grocery store, work, park, etc.) closer to each other, you make it a lot easier to depend on the car, since things are not spread out. If things are too spread out, the Golden Triangle of Transit here fails:From Jarrett Walker, international transit consultant: (Human Transit: basics: conceptual triangles).In short, without the right density and walk-ability, transit services can't justify frequent services (buses coming every five minutes!) or have the right ridership to meet the service. This is why in a lot of suburbs, you have buses coming every 30 minutes or hour: it is much more cheaper for them to take that route because not many people take transit.Without proper land use planning (which is a whole other subject on its own, as the comments on Seth's post point out), like in the US, you have a lot of suburbs, which makes it more convenient to drive than to take transit.  Jarrett Walker, from his book, Human Transit: How clearer thinking about public transit can enrich our communities and our lives (see here: human transit (the book): introduction ) notes that if land use ("development") is spread out, transit would not be very efficient:The red line is the transit line, the dark purples are the first and last stops, and the light purple are the intermediate stops. If we pretended, this was a suburb, having cul-de sacs (in light purple) would not be very efficient for transit vehicles because  the bus/rail would have to go through every destination. It would take a really long time for that red line to go to every place. This is a different transit line, but much more straight forward. Now, with the proper land use that is very dense in one line, this can be a very efficient transit line. This is key: proper land use. You can still have a straight line but it can be located in the suburbs, and it would be an inefficient transit line because there is not enough ridershipHere's an example of density, visualized, from the architecture firm, Perkins & Will, of a urban design plan for Vancouver, Canada, I believe. Here's another similar image of Vancouver, probably at a different location:Watch that transit line pass through that dense neighborhood! With the amount of development, it will have a justifiable amount of ridership to justify frequent service along the line to take transit!-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------So, in short, land use, not public transit, in North America, has a greater factor in influencing greenhouse gas emissions.Note: you might have noticed that I was sort of repetitive in different ways. It is really important to be clear when discussing or talking about transportation and the language of transportation because people interpret things different ways. That's why I provided lots of different visuals from different sources to help put everything in context.  The concept of density, for example, is a very broad concept. Does it mean 5 story, 10 story, 80 story (Manhattan), etc. There are different ways of measuring high density. Similarly, the concept of mixed land use or closer land uses is also very hard to visualize and thus has to be explained in depth to the reader.This is the role of urban planners, transportation engineers, and also to a growing extent, the smart cities / big data movement, which I talk more about in this article: http://www.quora.com/Smart-Citie...  Embed Quote

Yes, public transport could theoretically be a major solution to air pollution but keep two things in mind:1. There are many other sources of air pollution, not just from autos. I couldn't immediately find a % breakdown of where air pollution comes from, mainly because it's an apples to oranges comparison. Factories or refineries emit different pollutants than autos.2. The "public transport" solution shouldn't necessarily be viewed as a public transport problem. The real problem is how many American cities are organized - where people live, work, and shop. Take "auto-centric" Los Angeles for example. It does have a metro, metrorapid bus, and light rail system, mostly serving downtown. For commuting patterns between these points (i.e. from Hollywood to Downtown along the Red Line), there may be a significant transit mode share (say >20%). However, public transport would have to bridge a huge number of possible origin-destination combinations to make a serious dent in auto generated air pollution. People live in Torrence and work to Pasadena, live in Long Beach and work in Santa Monica. It would be much less expensive if we could convince people to live nearer to where they worked.  Embed Quote

It's not a slam dunk, as I write this answer from Hong Kong where something like 90% of the people use public transit daily and the air pollution ranks amongst some of the worst in the world.Pollution isn't just cars.  Here for example we have coal fired power plants and the downwind effects of being located near "China, Inc" and the factories on the mainland.  And on top of that, we also have problems with--get this--public transit.  The buses they use for public transportation here are very dated and pump considerable amounts of pollution into the air.  Efforts to upgrade to the new Euro IV standards have been stalled by concerns about the cost of new buses, etc.So while it might help in some places, the problem with air pollution is that there is no one source causing the pollution and thus, there is no one answer or cure.  You need to look at air pollution in a more "whole" sense--examining all the potential impacts and then act in a coordinated manner to reduce the pollution.  Embed Quote

We all agree that an efficient public transportation system will help to reduce the pollution, but, the 75% of the people who buy a car never go back to use the public transportation. This number it’s the reality in USA and Canada. The attributes to use a car or the public transportation it’s the real challenge. If the public transportation can’t offer attributes like security (door to door), a “nice” ride, whatever you call “nice” (music, space, etc), be at any time and all of that with a less cost to use a car, the cars will still be the first choice of those who already have one, and those who are going to buy one. There is the real challenge  Embed Quote

Of course! It is a no brainer. But..... Getting decent public transport infrastructure in place - with all the massive public investment that is entailed - is a huge stumbling block. Cost of usage is another barrier. If users are to pay for it, they will be kept away by high fares (that pay for it).  To get people out of cars it has to be a comprehensive, integrated, reliable, affordable and reasonably comfortable alternative to cars. Public taxation is key to providing decent public transport that ticks all the boxes. And that is a message many do not wish to hear.....  Embed Quote

Make your house a 'shoes off' home. Our shoes bring in dirt, feces, mold, and pollutants that then circulate inside.Use your exhaust fans everytime you cook and shower.Keep humidity below 40% -- reduces dust mites and moldFollow Selwa's recommendations on filters -- changing quarterly is a good baseline.Have your ductwork cleaned on an older home.Use low/no VOC paints and adhesives for projects around home.Remove furniture with high levels of formaldehyde and don't buy items made with particleboard, unless it is certified voc compliant.Use non toxic cleaning products.Flush your home throughout the year by opening windows and turning on your exhaust fans for the afternoon.  Even in the winter pick a warmer sunny day, turn off the heat and open up the house for a half hour to get a big dose of fresh air. (If you have allergies, you may want to be aware of which plants are blooming  when you do this)Consider an Energy Recovery Ventilator. Can be added to your existing furnace to force ventilation -- all new homes should be required to have one.  Embed Quote

You can improve indoor air quality by cleaning, and changing your home's air filters regularly. I'd recommend purchasing filters with a high MERV rating - this ranges from 1-16 and I wouldn't go lower than a MERV 8 filter. The higher the rating, the more effective it will be at capturing smaller particles. You can also improve air quality naturally with indoor plants. Or by using cleaning products that don't contain harsh chemicals. You may want to consider an air purifier and/or humidifier for the various rooms in your home. Maintaining an optimal humidity level (not too high) is key to preventing mold growth. Filters Fast (www.filtersfast.com) carries a variety of air filters, purifiers and humidifiers online. Perhaps you can start there?  Embed Quote

Source: Tips to Improve Indoor Air Quality in summerClean it up – Allergens and chemicals can linger in  the air for years, thereby increasing the amount of dust and lead  content indoors. You can use a vacuum cleaner with strong suction power,  rotating brushes and quality filter to ensure that the dirt and dust  does not get blown back out in the exhaust. You need to vacuum high  traffic areas like carpets, walls and upholstered furniture where dust  can easily accumulate. It’s important to wash the air filter also  regularly.Keep dust outside – Shoes can bring in all the  dirt, dust and pollutants from outside into your home. Place mats at the  entrance to your home so that some amount of the pollutants get trapped  on the mat and not on the floors of your home.Mop it up – Mopping the floors of your home cleans  up the leftover dust that vacuuming leaves behind. New micro fiber mops  with plain, clean water can effectively clean the surface area without  the use of harsh cleaners and detergents.Avoid the use of harsh chemicals and cleaners –  Household items like lemon juice, baking soda and vinegar can clean and  disinfect as effectively as conventional cleaners. These items will not  put harsh chemicals in the air. Change AC filters regularly – Proper maintenance of  your AC systems can help with improving indoor air quality. It’s very  important to clean air filters regularly and replace them with new ones  every two or three months. Avoid the use of synthetic fragrances and air fresheners – A combination of various chemicals are used for air fresheners and  fragrances which can irritate people’s nasal passage and lungs. You can  use natural sources like fresh flowers, essential oils to add a pleasant  fragrance indoors. Install plants – A natural way to filter toxins and  purify the air is by keeping plants around the house.  To get the best  results, try incorporating at least fifteen to eighteen plants into a  standard home of 1800 square footage. Test for radon – You could have a radon problem if  you have a new or old home. This odorless, colorless gas raises the  potential for developing lung cancer. If someone in your home smokes,  then your indoors has high radon levels.  Second hand cigarette smoke or  passive smoking is worse as it induces health problems like heart  attacks, lung cancer, breathing problems, etc. Cigarette smoke contains  over 4000 chemicals so whoever smokes indoors in doing harm to  themselves and to others around them. Either it’s best to kick the habit  or smoke outside.  Embed Quote

In homes, indoor air quality is most improved by replacing inadequately vented and unvented sources of combustion that produce CO, NOx, particulates, and other pollutants with electric or sealed combustion appliances, or at least by adding adequate ventilation. Since these sources can not just make you sick but kill you, I strongly encourage people to start with the completely unvented sources that pose the greatest risk.  1. Vehicles stored in attached garages:  either store them outside or, as section 403.3 of the Intl Mechanical Code requires, install 100 cfm of continuous [24/7] exhaust per vehicle. This will prevent CO and other pollutants  from entering the rest of the house whenever you start the car.  [this is more likely in winter when it is colder outside garage than inside].   Without such a fan, starting a car in an attached garage is like starting it in your living room.  You can buy whisper quiet fans for under $200 and they cost less than $30 per year in electricity to run. 2. Unvented gas space heaters and gas  log fireplace sets that are wall mounted with fake mantels and no flues: get rid of them!3. Gas ovens and ranges: replace with electric.   Even if you have a vented range hood instead of the kind that just blow air back in your face, the hood is too far above the range top to work effectively, and the typical fan is not powerful enough to keep some CO from accumulating in the room whenever you cook .   If you want to keep using a gas oven or range, make sure the range hood actually vents outdoors and turn it on before you light any burners, as CO production peaks in the first 5 minutes.  And whether gas or electric, always open kitchen windows wide when using that self clean cycle that turns the oven on HI for hours. . 4.Gas water heaters with open flue collars:  these allow combustion gases to spill into the room and can't stop backdrafting.  replace with electric or sealed combustion water heaters. 5. Wood fireplaces:  these also backdraft whenever you decide to let the fire burn out--like when you go to bed on a cold winter night.  As the fire cools, the updraft weakens until it is reversed by cold outsider air falling down the chimney.  This blows across the embers and sends all the combustion gases into the room.   If you want to keep using it, install tight fitting glass doors with air vents in front of the fireplace, and close the air vents when you go to bed. 6. Candles and incense:  no  big problem in small doses, but don't light more than 1 or 2 at a time in any tightly closed room.  Embed Quote

Indoor air is two to five times more polluted than outdoor air. After renovations or new construction, it can be up to 1,000 times more polluted. One of the biggest sources of indoor air pollution, believe it or not, is the products and materials we use to construct, furnish, and maintain our buildings. This includes drywall, insulation, flooring, kitchen and bathroom cabinetry, mattresses, furniture, electronics, paints, sealants, adhesives, cleaning products, and more. These products can off-gas, or release chemicals, known as VOCs (volatile organic compounds) into the indoor air--compounds like formaldehyde and acetaldehyde. Exposure to VOCs can cause numerous health problems--from headaches and nausea to dizziness and asthma. In fact, research has shown that children who are exposed to airborne VOCs are four times more likely to develop asthma. The best way to ensure optimal indoor air quality is to practice source control. That means keeping the pollutants out in the first place so you don't ever have to worry about eliminating them. An easy way to do this is to look for GREENGUARD Certified products. They've been scientifically tested and screened for over 10,000 chemicals and proven to meet exceptionally tough chemical emissions criteria. The GREENGUARD Environmental Institute keeps a database of all products that have been certified at www.greenguard.org. There are also plenty of other free tips and interactive tools to check out on GREENGUARD's website to help you better understand indoor air quality.Other tips include ensuring adequate ventilation (including opening your windows to allow fresh outdoor air to come indoors), ensuring that your HVAC filters aren't clogged up, avoiding cleaners with fragrances and/or harsh solvents, and wiping your feet at the door.  Embed Quote This answer needs to disclose relevant affiliations. Richard Petit expressed perhaps the biggest reasons. Another contributing factor: there's a near permanent inversion layer that sits above LA. This is due to constant high pressure systems that gives the region its famously sunny weather but also prevents smog from rising out.  There's a daily onshore flow which comes in every afternoon.  This blows much of the smog inland until it pushes up near the foothills and mountain areas. So contrary to the belief that LA as a whole has poor air quality, the air near the westside and coastal areas are quite good. It's just inland where it tends to be awful.  Embed Quote

If you look at this image:you see that the Los Angeles Basin is bordered on the west and southwest by the ocean that provides an on-shore flow and the mountains on the east and north. Add in a few million gas powered vehicles, the smog is heavier than air so it does not rise out, and there you have it, L.A. air. "I don't trust air that I can't see" we used to say.I once heard that when the Spanish explorers first arrived in L.A. they saw a cloud of smoke hovering over the basin from the campfires of the indigenous people. I don't know if it's true but it stands to reason and means that smog of some kind has always been there.  Embed Quote

Well, the basic answer is because there are so many polluters in LA. Not going into any technical details, the amount of pollution is interconnected with the GDP. So if the pollution is high then you can be sure that recession is not there in the near future. But at the same time, when all the developing countries are observing an increase in pollution day by day due to inefficient energy usage, developed countries are reducing the pollution because of availability of latest technology and ample capital. So there may exist a possibility that LA still needs some development.  Embed Quote

The best source I've found is the meta-analysis of full lifecycle emissions based on ISO standard LCA methods:You can choose a reasonable number of options at the site, but this is the basics.Wind - 8 g CO2e / KWHNuclear - 11 g CO2e / KWHGas - 480 g CO2e / KWHCoal - 1010 g CO2e / KWHSolar wasn't represented in the mix last time I checked, likely due to low utility scale generation, and hydro isn't a manufactured object so is in different format.Source:  http://en.openei.org/apps/LCA/Note that some things will shift these numbers up and down a bit.  Wind will always be at the bottom, and nuclear isn't going anywhere.  Gas can easily go up if poorly capped wells or bad fracking techniques extend around the world instead of being localized problems. Coal might come down a bit if the worst coal plants are mothballed and might come down a bit more if carbon capture and sequestration is every applied in earnest (don't hold your breath).Did I mention coal sucks?Less than 1 percent of US power plants produce nearly a third of the energy industry's carbon emissions, according to a new report released Tuesday. "If the 50 most-polluting U.S. power plants were an independent nation," reads the report from Environment America Research & Policy Center, an independent nonprofit, "they would be the seventh-largest emitter of carbon dioxide in the world, behind Germany and ahead of South Korea." The vast majority of the top 100 offenders—98 of them in fact—are coal plants.Source: Stunning stat: The dirtiest 1% of America's power plants release 33% of America's power-plant carbon emissionsThe EPA tracks these things too, so looking at their answer to this question and sources of information is always worthwhile.Electricity generation is the dominant industrial source of air emissions in the United States today. Fossil fuel-fired power plants are responsible for 67 percent of the nation's sulfur dioxide emissions, 23 percent of nitrogen oxide emissions, and 40 percent of man-made carbon dioxide emissions. These emissions can lead to smog, acid rain, and haze. In addition, these power plant emissions increase the risk of climate change. Congress is currently considering proposals to require further reductions of emissions from power plants, including the President's Clear Skies Initiative. However, renewable energy is receiving increased attention by environmental policymakers because renewable energy technologies have significantly lower emissions than traditional power generation technologies. To find out more about the air emissions generated by U.S. power plants, you can use EPA's Emissions and Generated Resource Integrated Database, or eGRID. eGRID provides emissions data on virtually every power plant and company that generates electricity in the United States.Air Emissions | Clean Energy | US EPA  Embed Quote

Yes. Air pollution can contain irritants that cause chemical conjunctivitis, according to the American Optometric Association. (Source: Conjunctivitis). Additionally, pollution can cause other harmful effects like respiratory problems and increased risk of cancer (depending on the specific type of pollution), according to the Environmental Protection Agency. (Source: http://www.epa.gov/airquality/pe...)--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Disclaimer: Information presented is for educational purposes only and is not meant to substitute for the advice of a doctor or other medical professional.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  Embed Quote

column10: Acid Rain from auto emissions is a result of  Lean Burn Combustion.  Oxygen translates to Ozone O3 with the increase of temperature greater than 200 deg. C.  And, at peak pressure, N2 splits to singular N which reacts with O3.  Then, NO3, the Nitrate Ion with an energy charge of 226,000 of calories per mole. Water, H2O reacts with NO3 to form Nitric Acid,  HNO3.  Dilute Acid Rain.deposits in the Forests.  The Hydrogen splits off to form H2O, water.  The NO3 has a negative formal charge.  All Hydrocarbons have a positive formal charge.  NO3 imbeds in the tree, and stores the 226,000 of calories per mole.  With each rain,  NO3 is continually added.  In the event of a Forest Fire, the intensity of the fire is increased with the increased release of the NO3 energy.  Nitroglycerin contains three Nitrate Ions.  NO3 has 1/3 of the energy of the three Nitrate Ions in Nitroglycerin.  Nitric Acid from Auto Emissions must be controlled/  David Wofsey,   dwofsey@msn.com  Embed Quote

column9: Ironically, China is already trialling cap and trade schemes in certain provinces... for carbon emissions... which is much needed for the long-term.But it is not doing much about particulate air pollution, which creates real problems right this minute in terms of healthcare costs (which will stretch into the future), and therefore also lost worker productivity, which exacerbates worker shortages. Epidemiological studies from the US have shown that US SO2 abatement efforts, driven by a cap and trade scheme, have had enormous unexpected human health benefits, many times greater in financial terms than the cost of the scheme.To be clear, the US scheme was not a fiscal stimulus; that was actually the opposite of a fiscal stimulus, as costs were passed on to consumers in many cases. However, China could combine a cap and trade scheme with explicit subsidies (e.g. matching grants for emissions reductions improvements) and/or implicit subsidies (e.g. free allocations of emissions permits). The US scheme, despite its efficiency, was criticised for being theoretically vulnerable to pollution hotspots; however, this could be addressed with e.g. local pollution caps. Then the programme could:a) be on average cost-free to Chinese consumers and exportersb) cost-effectively reduce pollutionc) bring human health benefitsd) bring ecological benefitse) make Chinese citizens happier, and therefore happier with their governmentf) retain the fiscal stimulus effects of existing government spendingg) develop Chinese green industry and green engineering skills and innovationh) divert investment away from wasteful and pointless construction projects (which could still be funded in later years, if desired) - which would in itself reduce pollution, and thus reduce the costs of the schemeSo why isn't China doing it? It seems like a no-brainer to me.
column10: Just to follow on the excellent answer of Julian Zhu, this is not a science or policy issue. It's about who benefits.If local officials don't benefit, it won't get done. It's that simple.  Embed Quote

column10: The first thing came into my mind is who is responsible to make such kind of public policy in China. The central government probably has more incentives to protect the environment due to the fear of furious citizens going on the street to compromise the already slowly crumbling social stability.But any decision made by the central government has to be enforced by local administration such as province or city government. Officials at this level have a very subtle mentality concerning the politics and their own career goals. Most of them don't have too much political morality about making our society a better one in the future because their children are or will be studying in the western nations and foreseeably will get immigrant identities in the future or at least can travel around the world freely with affluent financial resources so if anything really goes wrong they can just leave. And their political ambition is limited to the scale of getting to a higher position for more political power in exchange for more bribery and a bigger chance to evade the judicial prosecution for their corrupted conduct.That has been said, let's take a closer look at the proposed advantages of your suggestion and what local officials would likely to think about them:a) be on average cost-free to Chinese consumers and exporters: What's the point to make consumers and exporters cost-free? Does that make me richer? Probably not, so why bother?b) cost-effectively reduce pollution: Pollution only matters when it is causing imminent troubles like the PM 2.5 problem haunting many cities recently. But we don't have to do anything other than telling people that it'll take about 50 years to solve the environmental problems. And if we are lucky,  one or two windy days will make the problem disappear and we're good again.c) bring human health benefits: What's the point to make people healthy? Don't tell me it will reduce the medical expenses of the society, it's not my money, and reduce it or not, tax payers will cover it anyway. And FYI I have deluxe medical care package only available for retired government officials and will not be impacted by the deficiency of the public health fund. Lucky me.d) bring ecological benefits: Believe it or not, we and our families work and live in air-conditioned and filtered environment. We eat organic food called special offer. And we barely do any domestic travel anymore.e) make Chinese citizens happier, and therefore happier with their government: What's the point to make your servants happy? They're not happy with the government? Come on, guns in hands we communists fear nothing. :Df) retain the fiscal stimulus effects of existing government spending: We already have good relations with infrastructure contractors who have bigger business and therefore can deliver bigger kickbacks.g) develop Chinese green industry and green engineering skills and innovation: Innovation? Why bring up the only thing we're not good at?h) divert investment away from wasteful and pointless construction projects (which could still be funded in later years, if desired) - which would in itself reduce pollution, and thus reduce the costs of the scheme: I'm tired and my mistresses are waiting. How about take question H as your home work?Sometimes, if you can't understand all the preposterous things in China in a social-economic analytical way, just try to understand it in my way. You'll be enlightened. Cheers!  Embed Quote

column10: Anti-pollution doesn't work well as a fiscal stimulus.  1) The thing about fiscal stimulus is that you want to be able to stop doing it once you reach full employment.  So you hire millions of people building railroads and buildings, and once the economy starts to get back on its feet, *you tell them to stop*.  Anti-pollution is something that China is going to have to spend large amounts of money on over the next several decades, and it not something that you can or should flip on and flip off.2) Most construction jobs don't require a lot of skill.  You take a farmer with a middle school education, give him some tools, and ask him to mix concrete.  For most environment jobs, you can't do this.  Even for a coal factory, you need construction workers that have more skill than you need than to build an apartment complex.3) Anti-corruption - OK, if I pay you $5 million RMB to build apartments, I can see whether or not you in fact actually built apartments.  You may have pocketed some fraction of the money, you may have entered into all sorts of weird deals with local officials, but in the end I can tell that you in fact built the apartments, and since I know what apartments cost to build, it's easy for me to keep you from pocketing all the money.With licenses and pollution caps its harder to tell.  If I pay you money to build apartments, I can tell that you actually built the apartments.  If my goal is to just get money into workers hands, I can just look to see if you have lots of workers, and if they aren't getting paid, they are likely to rat you out.If I pay you money to install anti-pollution devices, it's easier to fool me into thinking that you did so when you didn't.  In situations where there isn't an "obvious" thing to be built, it's even worse, cap and trade works rather badly in most developing countries because it requires a very well run and clean government which doesn't exist in China.  I "sell" you a license to pollute, and I do it anyway, and if I'm a Party boss, are you going to stop me?One other thing is that ghost cities is more complex than the government ordering someone to do something.  Part of the reasons ghost cities exist is that you cannot own empty land in China.  If you think that a piece of land is going to be valuable in 20 years, you have to build *something* on it, or else you lose it.  Embed Quote

column9: A single flight from the United States to Europe can easily generate 5 tons of carbon dioxide. Why do people who recycle, carpool, drive hybrids, and turn off their lights at home, not realize that a single vacation flight can cancel out many years of all of their other green efforts put together? In other words, these people are behaving extremely irrationally. It would be much greener if they made no effort to be green whatsoever, and simply did not go on international vacations.
column10: I'd say I fit this profile — I recycle, bicycle, don't own a car, compost, let it mellow if it's yellow, buy wind power, etc., but in 2009 I flew more than 70,000 air miles and barely fell short of 50,000 in 2010, which by your calculator gets me easily over 25 tons per year (equivalent to my driving 2.5 Hummers all year). I'm flying mostly for work, not pleasure, but if I were really determined I could have flown much, much less for work. I never in so many words "claim to support the environment" but I think I'm otherwise the person you're asking about.The implicit assertions behind your question include: these people are selfish, hypocritical, unaware or have their heads in the sand. I plead no contest on three of four counts: I cannot claim to be unaware of the carbon burden of my flying.There is, of course, no other practical way to go overseas with any kind of timeliness. This is the meta-reason: it's not like the choice is "fly to Botswana or take a high-speed train to Botswana"; the choice is more "fly to Botswana or drive to Appalachia". I think that globetrotting Americans certainly do miss out on the amazing and diverse kinds of beauty you can find in the US—but I'd say Americans who never leave the country are missing out on a basic understanding of their place in the world.A key thing is that not all of these behaviors are only about CO.• Several of the behaviors you list — carpooling, turning off lights — also save money. Saving money means I can buy more tiger bones and polar bear pelts on my decadent international vacations.• Recycling is also about doing less mining and therefore less of the other environmental damage that comes from mining — tailings, runoff, stripping mountaintops, hydrofracking, etc.• Recycling/composting: taking recyclables and compostables out of the waste stream should make for smaller landfills and encourage more responsible/sustainable waste management.• Carpooling/bicycling is also about the health of cities, more reducing traffic congestion, etc. Bicycling and using public transit are also about making better infrastructure.• Hybrids are sort of immaterial since they don't currently really spare any CO over their whole lifecycle anyway. But buying them does encourage the development of other alternatives: it is arguably better for people to be buying hybrids than Hummers just to make it clear that there's a market for greener cars.But I'd say in my case it ultimately comes down to moral-relativistic selfishness. I know it makes tons and tons of CO for me to fly. I know that the only way to reduce the amount of fuel used by the airline industry is for everyone to fly less — putting the lie to my "encouraging better practices" justifications for recycling, public transit, and not buying Hummers. But I pretty much willfully ignore the environmental burden of my actions in the case of flying. I love going to distant countries. I don't have time to go by container ship.I don't buy carbon offsets because they seem like a racket with dubious effectiveness. But putting that veneer afterthought of rationality on top of the generally irrational & irresponsible dumping of CO directly into the sky is pretty dumb/hypocritical: I like trees, so any gesture would probably be better than no gesture at all.  Embed Quote
