column10: I fit this category. You're absolutely correct about the emissions of flights. I take about 1-2 international flights a year which alone emits more carbon than the rest of my life. I'm more than aware of that. I also try not to fly more than that much. Here are some things to consider, though:Every little bit of savings counts. Compared to someone who flies 1-2 times a year and doesn't recycle, it's still better to recycle, no?Greenhouse gases are only one of many environmental problems. In fact, greenhouse gases and fuel consumption are probably the only environmental problems caused by aircraft. Recycling and reusing not only reduce carbon emissions but also cut down on waste and conserve natural resources and ecosystems, other very crucial environmental issues today.I'm extremely aggressive in cutting down emissions in the rest of my life. I do not own a car. I bicycle and use public transportation whenever possible, eat vegetarian, pay close attention to buying as much seasonal local produce as possible, don't use an electric dryer or air conditioner, use heating sparingly, and cut my electricity usage to a very bare minimum. My hope is to mindfully take a lot of relatively big measures in parallel all year to reduce my emissions to at least offset some decent fraction of the flight emissions when it all adds up.I feel like the airline industry to some degree reaches limits to how much it is used. Only a small fraction of the world flies frequently. Aircraft CO2 emissions account for about 3% of greenhouse gas emissions in the world -- which is a lot, but I don't believe the number of people who fly will blow up any time soon. However, city planning issues, expansion of suburbia, lack of public transportation options and other environmental issues plague entire populations, and when added up, accounts for a much more than aircraft in the world today. By being environmentally conscious in ones' daily life, one also promotes environmental friendliness in the community and helps encourage others to do so. I can safely say that through my recycling and reusing and energy-saving habits, I've managed to encourage dozens of others to change their habits every year. The power in numbers will hopefully reduce the emissions from the problematic, non-aircraft 97% due to the smaller emissions of everyone added up.There are many instances where flying is the only practical option to get from A to B, especially when there is an ocean in-between, and in some scenarios the only safe option to get from A to B. Many times, there is a goal in mind (for example, visiting relatives, visiting friends, engaging in cultural exchange, learning about aspects of a place that one could not from books and the internet, charity work, seeing and understanding nature that one does not have access to near home, academic work, etc.). At least there is a goal at the other end, and something is getting accomplished. I would never fly to a faraway resort to relax. Any plane travel I take must always be justified by a goal that I would not be able to accomplish by staying at home.You're absolutely right that aircraft CO2 emissions are huge -- I'm not claiming innocence -- I'm just saying that there are more than enough reasons to be environmentally friendly and (humbly) promote environmental awareness even and perhaps especially if you fly, if at least for the lots of other reasons besides CO2 emissions. Being environmental is more about working together, and less about preaching to a crowd. As far as CO2 emissions goes, yes, I emit a lot, and I admit that.  Embed Quote

column9: A single flight from the United States to Europe can easily generate 5 tons of carbon dioxide. column10: Because the vast majority of people need to live and work using currently available technology - this will always be a constant when dealing with behavior and the environment. Your question assumes that given a set of unfavorable alternatives, the only option is to not participate. Of course you will always have a small segment of a population who chooses not to participate in standard comforts of Western life (like a trip to Europe), but for most people, the world is not binary but rather consists of a continuum of tradeoffs. The difference among most of the population is simply where you sit on that continuum. An environmentally conscious consumer taking a flight is not irrational behavior. This consumer would likely be aware of the tradeoff they are making, but has decided for whatever reason that the benefits outweigh the risks. They are simply choosing the only mode of transport available, given the delta among the alternatives (plane vs boat vs swim). However they will likely continue their green behavior well beyond that trip and continue to take advantage of every green alternative (such as recycling) that is provided to them. If airlines offered cleaner alternatives (they do), then they would likely take that option.We all work within the constraints. The fact that many choose to operate within those constraints rather than to go without is not irrational. In fact, many successful people in the environmental movement have learned to change the system from within, with promising results. Most of us wouldn't recycle if we didn't have a recycling service dropping by our house each week. We wouldn't care about climate change if the world's scientists weren't exposing the risks to us. And we wouldn't care about fuel efficiency if reducing subsidies and declining oil production (among many other things) didn't push our gas prices through the roof. Changing behaviors on a global scale - or the technologies that drive those behaviors -  takes years, sometimes decades. Opting out of choice during these transitions simply isn't an option for most people.  Embed Quote

column10: It is possible to (relatively) save CO2 when flying, too. Someone who consolidates trips; aggressively seeks air bargains (thus filling seats which may otherwise have gone empty); reduces luggage weight; flies nonstop, even when that means a land trip after arrival; prefers high-altitude airports like Denver or Mexico City (which use much less fuel on take off and landing); and refuses to fly in smaller airplanes; is emitting a lot less marginal CO2 than someone flying first-class on packed, high-season flights. Since my air travel is my largest carbon emissions, I do all of these things; I will customarily accept an extra 12 hours travel time (sleeping on a bus) if it minimizes my air travel emissions. If I'm traveling with my (young) child, of course, the premium on convenience is higher, but I'm still willing to accept significant inconvenience to minimize emissions.(Another ,significant relative CO2 savings would come from sloped runways, to get a gravity assist for both take-off and landing/braking. But currently, no pilots have training for that, and no country's safety regulations would allow it. Oh well.)  Embed Quote

column9: A single flight from the United States to Europe can easily generate 5 tons of carbon dioxide. Why do people who recycle, carpool, drive hybrids, and turn off their lights at home, not realize that a single vacation flight can cancel out many years of all of their other green efforts put together? In other words, these people are behaving extremely irrationally. It would be much greener if they made no effort to be green whatsoever, and simply did not go on international vacations.
column10: Setting aside Maslow's hierarchy of needs, the calculator the question linked to shows that a roundtrip flight to London from New York is actually 60% of the carbon output of driving a Prius for a year, and a mere 10% of owning a small-ish (by American standards) home.  One would do far more good by downsizing one's house than giving up the annual trip abroad.  Also, the very availability of carbon offsets, like those provided by the Carbon Fund and Terrapas allow environmentally conscious travelers the option of offsetting their travel; not the same as not traveling, but a nice environmental hedge all the same.  Embed Quote

column10: Because I live in a more energy- and fuel-efficient fashion than (the generic) you, including using mass transit rather than an automobile, the other 360-something days of the year. And because the planes are going to fly with or without me, whereas a personal automobile will not drive itself (not yet at least).I take and agree with the point that if fewer people fly, so will fewer planes. But in fact, I don't fly much. I have flown to Europe only twice in my life, once as a child. Domestically, I am more likely these days to travel by bus or train than by air, regionally rather than cross-country if need be. And I hope others start joining me.  Embed Quote

column10: Because regardless of one's personal environmental beliefs, one must still live one's life.Unless you're living in a cave eating cold potatoes that you raised organically by hand, you're contributing to the problem.  But given that most of us aren't interested in living like that, the reality is that we all make compromises with our beliefs and principles every day just to live.The kind of "gotcha" moral questioning represented by this question is the kind of pseudo-intellectual drivel that makes people roll their eyes.  People, even those most devoted to environmental causes, are free to make whatever personal choices they want, and pretending to be holier-than-thou doesn't really advance the debate much.  Embed Quote

column10: It's the same reason why people can entrust their lives to science in pretty much every single life-and-death situation they find themselves in, but will turn towards you at the the same time espousing a belief network that is not scientific.You can't logically place your life in the hands science just when it really matters, like when you get treated in a hospital, travel by air, car or rail, or eat food produced using modern methods (it goes on and on), and then simultaneously state that you believe in something that directly contradicts science.That's logically inconsistent. Hence people practice cognitive dissonance to make this logical inconsistency vanish.Hence the reason people believe in one thing when it suits them, but in another when it doesn't, is just because it's convenient.  Embed Quote

column10: I'm an environmentalist, and I've stopped taking flights. I had a group of exchange students from Beijing this spring, and the one thing they most enjoyed about being in Cambridge was the air quality.  It was wonderful to them to be able to run outside in our clean air.  I think it's because there's almost always a lot of wind.Cambridge, MA Air Quality shows that Cambridge has been improving fairly rapidly in most aspects of air quality in the last decade, as it's switched over from being a city of light industry to businesses and high technology.  The water quality is also quite good, as 2012 Annual Drinking Water Quality Report indicates.  Embed Quote
Pretty much non-existent. Maybe when Mass Ave is jammed up you get more than a whiff of car exhaust, but otherwise I've never had a problem with air quality.  Embed Quote

Added to that, when I lived there, the city of Cambridge had this water quality report mailed to your home in which it extensively detailed the contents of its tap water and I can tell you from experience that it was reassuringly good and that the city of Boston, barely double the size in its official limits, should make a benchmark of it.I miss the cleanliness of Cambridge, though it can be a pretty dull place at times.  Embed Quote

column9: Air purifiers are expensive and loud. They cost a lot of money to buy and they also cost a lot of operate due to filter and power costs. Many purifiers also sound like a loud fan when operating which can be annoying. But people put up with all the negatives because of the promise of cleaner air, free from pollution and allergen. While there are many reviews online that report on air purifiers, how can a consumer measure how well their air purifier is working for them?
column10: Get a magnifying glass, some index cards, and some Vaseline.  Draw a circle on the card, fold it into an  upside-down V, and slather a thin layer of Vaseline on the card.  Leave it where you want to measure air quality for a week or so, then repeat for the exact same amount of time without the filter running.  Look at the two circles under a magnifier, and try to count the particles in each one to see if there is an improvement.  This isn't scientific, but it is a way to catch particles and count them.  You could use multiple cards in multiple places, or repeat the experiment a bunch of times, or use a microscope, in an effort to get a better average measurement and more precise results.  But this isn't a class 10 clean room, it is a house.  This little grade school technique should show you if an air purifier is doing any good at all.  Embed Quote

column9: Air purifiers are expensive and loud. They cost a lot of money to buy and they also cost a lot of operate due to filter and power costs. Many purifiers also sound like a loud fan when operating which can be annoying. But people put up with all the negatives because of the promise of cleaner air, free from pollution and allergen. While there are many reviews online that report on air purifiers, how can a consumer measure how well their air purifier is working for them?
column10: The 2 major independent testing entities are Consumer Reports and the Clean Air Delivery Rate program.  Both have pluses and minuses though.  CADR was started by a home appliance interest group so a bit of conflict of interest there.  But they did come up with an ANSI standard test methodology that did get approved so it is probably the best thing going.  Consumer Reports is Consumer Reports - you either love them or hate them.Pros and Cons of CR - http://www.airpurifierguide.org/...Pros and Cons of CADR - http://www.airpurifierguide.org/...Suggestions on improving CADR system - http://www.air-purifier-power.co...Best way to test is the number of particles in the air before and after adding an air purifier.  You would need to get a laser particle counter to do measure that.  Embed Quote

column9: Air purifiers are expensive and loud. They cost a lot of money to buy and they also cost a lot of operate due to filter and power costs. Many purifiers also sound like a loud fan when operating which can be annoying. But people put up with all the negatives because of the promise of cleaner air, free from pollution and allergen. While there are many reviews online that report on air purifiers, how can a consumer measure how well their air purifier is working for them?
column10: Unless the filters really suck, you don't have to. The matter isn't a complicated one. You have a unit which draws air into it, passes that air through a HEPA filter (usually) and then spits it back out into the room.The CFM (Cubic Feet per Minute) will clue you in to how much air it moves around. More is better. The filter efficiency is important, as the percentage is usually outlined somewhere on the package for the sake of clarity. A filter which is 95% effective lets approximately 1 in 20 particles past. A filter that is 99.97% effective will let approximately 1 in every 3,333 particles past. As the efficiency of the filter goes up, so to does cost and also difficulty in moving air through it.If you're absolutely determined to measure anyway, go find a company to do indoor air quality testing. Best way to test it would be to put a bunch of whatever you're trying to filter out (pollen?) in the air (while appropriately protected) and leave the room closed up with that air purifier on. Calculate how many air changes you'll need by dividing the cubic footage of the room by the CFM of the air purifier, and leave it alone. Let's just say a day to keep things simple. Have the air tested, if the air is fine, your purifier works.Full Disclosure: I am a mold remediation foreman.  Embed Quote

column9: I was thinking about planning a trip to Beijing in May. However, the recent reports seems quite scary. Should I still do the trip? One of the people in our travel party has asthma. Is it safe for him? Or are there any precautions we should take.
column10: The air pollution a few weeks ago indeed was dangerous for sick and vulnerable populations, such as anyone with serious lung disease such as asthma, emphysema (COPD), and cystic fibrosis. Also, anyone with serious heart disease has a greatly increased risk of heart attacks during serious air pollution. Those people certainly shouldn't have traveled here, or been outside here without proper N95 masks. Short term pollution spikes definitely can cause premature deaths -- just Google "Great London Smog of 1952" for the most classic example.  But having said that, there's no way to predict the May weather, which certainly could have bad days (any AQI over 200 would be reasonably bad, certainly over 300). As a family doctor in Beijing and blogger, my standard answer is that almost every traveler of reasonable health will have no problems here and should have a wonderful vacation. That includes people with well controlled asthma -- but they definitely need to be prepared, and bring their medicines.  Embed Quote

column9: I was thinking about planning a trip to Beijing in May. However, the recent reports seems quite scary. Should I still do the trip? One of the people in our travel party has asthma. Is it safe for him? Or are there any precautions we should take.
column10: Overall, the air in Beijing is pretty bad compared to any city in the United States.  But it varies widely from day to day and week to week, depending on weather patterns and the time of year.  This week was worse than it ever got while I was living there, with the air quality index hitting 800.  But its back down to the 300-500 range, which is just insanely bad, rather than being apocalyptically bad.  (I actually learned how to say "apocalypse" in Mandarin in a conversation about the air pollution. ).  For contrast, New York's current AQI is 14, with a high of 75 predicted for the day.  The pollution tends to be worse in winter, when more people are burning coal for heat.How should you take this into account for your trip?  Pollution is going to be an issue most places you might go in China.  Although, places on the ocean tend to be better on average, and less developed places tend to be better.  But, unless your friend's asthma is bad enough that it would trigger an attack, its not that big a deal for a week or so.  So have your friend talk to his doctor before booking his ticket.  Embed QuoteAnswered in fifty-three minutes.

column9: I was thinking about planning a trip to Beijing in May. However, the recent reports seems quite scary. Should I still do the trip? One of the people in our travel party has asthma. Is it safe for him? Or are there any precautions we should take.
column10: Yes, the air is a extremely bad right now, and if you are traveling with someone with respiratory problems you need to take extra precautions, or, quite frankly, consider not bringing them along.The World Health Organization sets a maximum limit on exposure to Particulate Matter 2.5 of 25ug/m3.  This is actually a compromise between health concerns and economic reality because, in the words of the W.H.O., there is basically no acceptable level of particulate pollution from a health standpoint.Beijing was over 700ug/m3 the other day.Now a good deal of this particular outbreak is due to weather concerns 'trapping' the air over the city.  It should clear in a few days when the weather moves a new front through the city blowing out some of the bad air.  But particulate pollution is a significant problem in Beijing such that on even an 'average' day you'll see levels 200-300% of the W.H.O. guidelines.You'll need to ask your friend how he deals with "Code Orange" and "Code Red" air days in the USA (note: by US standards nearly every day in Beijing is at least Code Orange and most are Code Red or beyond).  Does he cut back exercise, avoid going out, use an inhaler, etc? Beijing right now is beyond even this.  Beyond a "Code Purple" and beyond a "Code Maroon"--hazardous. It's off index, or "crazy bad" as they called it a few years ago (long and funny story). If he alters his daily activities in the USA on Orange and Red days, he would definitely need to alter his arrangements for a trip.  Embed Quote

column9: I was thinking about planning a trip to Beijing in May. However, the recent reports seems quite scary. Should I still do the trip? One of the people in our travel party has asthma. Is it safe for him? Or are there any precautions we should take.
column10: The air pollution is bad.  No worse than it was in Eastern Europe twenty years ago and no worse than Detroit and Los Angeles Forty years ago, or London farther ago than that.  It's unhealthy but always reported.  When the AQI is worst, over 250, normally healthy people shouldn't do anything aerobic outside. What this means to me is that at it's worst the air pollution is slightly depressing.  But unlike, for example, Los Angeles where I lived in the southern part of the county in 1971 and never new there were mountains right there beyond the smog until I'd been there for four months, I have a clear view of the Western Hills one or two days a week from my 19th floor apartment.  Though friends of mine claim to have, I never notice the smell or any health effect.My impressions is that the Western media accounts are more or less accurate but hysterical, and somewhat smug.  Embed Quote

column9: I was thinking about planning a trip to Beijing in May. However, the recent reports seems quite scary. Should I still do the trip? One of the people in our travel party has asthma. Is it safe for him? Or are there any precautions we should take.

column9: If Tesla Motors continues to do well, what impact will it have on the automobile industry, as well as other industries it touches (such as the oil industry) in the coming years and decades?
column10: I had an existential crisis resolved for me when watching Elon Musk have a conversation with Salman Khan.The specific line (I paraphrase, because I don't have the time to re-watch this right now) was- "Tesla exists to accelerate the development of electric cars and electric transportation."The keyword is accelerate. In the grand scheme of things, it seems inevitable that we will see electric vehicles- at least that's what Elon says, and he says it so persuasively that I'm willing to bet that he's right.Tesla exists to accelerate that process. If it works, it'll inspire copycats and competitors, which is a good thing. That means more electric cars. The oil industry should be around for quite some time more, but they'll surely be paying attention.In the ultimate grand scheme of things, if Tesla did not exist, something else would take its place. If we're talking about electric cars, though, it seems that Tesla is at the tip of the sword. We'll see an industry begin to form around electric cars, and we'll see more and more people choosing electric cars over gasoline. Existing automobile manufacturers will feel the heat, and will start accelerating development of their own electric vehicles. It's a net good for humanity as a species.Here's the full video:(About that existential crisis, if you're curious- the question is: What impact are you going to have in the world? What's so great about you? There are so many others who are more talented, more hardworking. What can you contribute that's new, different, innovative? The answer: Possibly nothing. But you can accelerate what you believe is right and good. And that makes all the difference.)  Embed Quote

column9: If Tesla Motors continues to do well, what impact will it have on the automobile industry, as well as other industries it touches (such as the oil industry) in the coming years and decades?
column10: There is every reason to believe that Tesla is going to massively disrupt the automobile industry:It badly needs disrupting, primarily for environmental reasons. A small-ish fraction of the world's population currently own cars, but hundreds of millions of people are rapidly rising out of poverty now in countries like India and China. The mobility and status afforded by car ownership are a primary focus for people with fresh disposable income. Most of them are going to buy cars, and if those are cars with internal combustion engines, pollution from automotive emissions, already killing millions in China and India, is going to hockey stick -- not just in urban areas and these individual countries, but in the atmosphere of the entire planet.  Electric cars pollute less overall today, and as more and more clean sources of power generation are brought online, that advantage will continue to increase considerably.Tesla has demonstrated its ability to design and build first-rate cars. The Roadster surprised automotive journalists by being an eminently capable sports car. The Model S, freshly designed from the ground up, has won 2013 Automobile of the Year Awards from virtually every source that matters, from serious car magazines like Automobile to Consumer Reports "Best Car Ever Tested" to the World Green Car award. It's a genuinely good-looking car, which is as critical as performance in this market segment.Tesla's financial model is working. It recently repaid its Department of Energy Loan from 2010 of nearly half a billion dollars -- nine years early. The company was technically profitable in Q1 of 2013. They've demonstrated mastery of design, supply chain, manufacturing, and marketing in a hurry.And they've done all this selling to the classes, but not yet the masses. The cars the Model S and Roadster compete against sell in the few thousands each year. Tesla's battery and drive train technology are ready to be applied to more mainstream cars that sell in the many hundreds of thousands each year. Elon Musk has demonstrated his ability to innovate and make a nickel at the same time across multiple industries. When it brings the $40,000 Model X to market in  in late 2014, Tesla's tiny current market penetration and stock price of around $100/share will both be faint memories.Innovation and disruption inspire innovation and disruption. We'll have to wait to see who the future entrepreneurs are who tell us, "I saw what Elon and Tesla did, and I swung for the fences just like them" -- but we know there will be a bunch of them. Tesla's impact has already been big, it's going to be huge, and it's got long legs, because human beings love, need, and use cars like few other products.  Embed Quote

column9: Looking at http://sparetheair.org/ - it is difficult to tell what one can and can't do on a Spare The Air Day. It is also difficult to distinguish between what one legally can and can't do versus what one should or shouldn't do if trying to be conscientious. I would have thought this would have been explicitly spelled out on the website, but it isn't, at least not that I can see.
column10: During the summer months when ground-level ozone, or "smog," becomes a pollution problem, the Air District issues Spare the Air Alerts for days on which air quality is forecast to be unhealthy.These advisories are posted on our website with our daily air quality forecasts, recorded on our 1 (800) HELP AIR forecast phone line, announced in local newspapers, and broadcast on local TV and radio stations.  The EnviroFlash AirAlert email system also notifies registered Bay Area subscribers.In the Bay Area, the summer Spare the Air season generally runs from May through mid-October when clear skies, hot temperatures, lighter than usual winds, and strong temperature inversions combine to create smoggy conditions.  Spare the Air Alerts are declared for days forecast to have ozone concentrations that exceed federal health-based standards.On these Spare the Air days, we urge residents to cut back on any activities that cause pollution - such as driving, using oil-based paints, gasoline-powered lawn mowers, or household aerosol products like hair sprays.  People who are sensitive to unhealthy air are advised to limit their time outdoors, particularly in the afternoon hours.Learn more about the health effects of ozone.View historical "box scores" listing the number of times ozone standards have been exceeded on an annual basis in the Bay Area.Watch Bay Area Ozone Animations showing smog activity on selected days.Read the Spare the Air FAQs.  Embed Quote

column9: Numerous studies have shown risks to young (or unborn) children, but should an otherwise healthy adult worry much?
column10: Well half a mile is not right next to the freeway. They have done studies on living right next to the freeway. That caused brain damage in mice.Here is the data:Scientists have for the first time directly linked freeway vehicle emissions with brain damage. Scientists used a new technique that involved trapping airborne toxins along Los Angeles’ 110 Freeway, freezing them in water, and exposing lab mice to the toxins.The researchers used a particle sampler to collect “fresh ambient particulate matter” along the CA-110 Freeway near Los Angeles City for 30 days. After gathering grime on filters, they then soaked the filters in water for 30 minutes before freezing the water-toxin cocktail.Frozen pollutants only remain chemically stable for around 3 months, so after collecting freeway toxins, the scientists brought the toxic ice cubed back to their lab soon after. They thawed the ice and released the toxins into the air breathed by their lab mice, exposing them to the fumes for a total of 150 hours over the course of 10 weeks.The scientists then harvested the brain tissue of the mice, discovering through various cultures and tests that the mice brains resembled the brains of those suffering from memory loss or Alzheimer’s disease. For example, among other changes, specific receptors in the  hippocampus had degenerated and parts of the cerebral cortex were inflamed.[1][2][1] http://blogs.discovermagazine.co...[2] http://ehp03.niehs.nih.gov/artic...  Embed Quote

column9: Numerous studies have shown risks to young (or unborn) children, but should an otherwise healthy adult worry much?
column10: There is much evidence that people living with 500 m of a road with heavy traffic poses a significant health risk as concluded recently by an international panel of experts which is reviewed here:Global Overview of Health Impacts from Particulate Matterhttp://pollutionfreecities.blogs...“Given the large number of people living within 300- 500meters of a major road, the Panel concluded that exposures to primary traffic generated pollutants are likely to be of public health concern and deserve attention”“Highest exposures 300-500 meters from major roads - Growing evidence of effects, especially asthma exacerbation in children”In Los Angeles, 44% of population live in the maximum     zone of impact of major roadsin Delhi: New HEI Analysis: 55% of the Population     within 500 meters of a highway; 50 meters of a major roadin Beijing: New HEI Analysis: 76% of the Population     within 500 meters of a highway; 50 meters of a major road”“the Panel found:Sufficient evidence that exposure to traffic can cause exacerbation of asthma, especially in children  Embed Quote

The answer hinges on what kind of pollution you have in that city. In most cases, for big cites, it's air pollution. To be specific, PM2.5 in modern cities.Wikipedia Reference: Particulates, Air quality indexMy ExperienceI live in Beijing, China. One of the most polluted big city in the world. Beijing suffers from pollution for a long time, especially since 2013. PM2.5 has become the main pollutant.According to the report published by Environment Protection Department of China, Beijing is the most polluted domestic city. What Is It Like To Be Here(My Experience)Before everything, you need to know sometimes you don't feel the pollution even if it's always bad. But the effect exist all the time. Like one out of five days you'll get a seriously polluted day.(PM2.5 over 150)Like one out of ten days you'll get a polluted day when you'd better go out with a mask.(PM2.5 over 200)Like one out of fifteen days you'll get a polluted day when your visibility is significantly affected.(PM2.5 way over 200) Like one out of ninety days (three months) you'll get a polluted day when you can hardly breath.（Here are two pictures capturing from my phone app which show two certain days' AQI (air quality index), numbers in the middle are the index.）What Is It Like To Be Here(Statistics)The U.S. Embassy in Beijing once described the air quality as "crazy bad", how bad can it be?The answer is no one really know. or at least we don't know.If you check the data announced by the Environment Protection Department of China, the air quality in Beijing is getting better, while every single citizen will tell you: even if it's not getting worse, it can't be "getting better".The U.S. Embassy in Beijing used to publish their own data, but not anymore. Maybe there is something between the embassy and Chinese government?(Here is the data from Statistic Yearbook of China)What's MorePollution is a problem threatening every burgeoning city, things will pick up in the future.Welcome to Beijing! I'm looking forward to you guys!  Embed Quote

I don't think it wise to state the corporations outright, but I will say that literally any oil, gas or energy co have been damaging this planet for far too long! Even with strict regulations, there's just no telling what might happen, especially when these corporations are dealing with something so unpredictable as nature.There was an event a few years ago you might still remember that is still having disastrous consequences on surrounding ecosystems.Oil spill offshore in the Gulf of Mexico.Unrecognizable bird covered in crude oil.Oil on the surface water.Pictures really do speak louder than words on this topic and any big business or corporation that willingly uses the following equation will definitely be harming the environment both directly and indirectly: Profit = Economy/Ecology  Embed Quote

Beijing is a fantastic place for a student, and I strongly recommend anyone come out here for a term or two. The air pollution is definitely a concern but for most healthy young students, it's a very manageable short-term problem. But anyone with serious heart or lung disease, especially bad asthma or cystic fibrosis, may need to think twice about staying here. Or at the very least, first discuss with your doctor and definitely be ready with medicines as well as awareness of where to go in an emergency. I take care of many traveling students in my medical practice here in Beijing, and the great majority have no major problems from air pollution.  Embed Quote

Beijing is a wonderful locale for any student interested in learning Mandarin (the local dialect is the national standard, can't beat that!). The pollution, however, does pose a problem, especially if you are planning on staying in China for 6+ months. It shouldn't deter you from pursuing a program there though, but it is advised to take some extra steps to ensure you are staying healthy. One simple solution is to frequently wear a face mask - you may feel silly, but your lungs will thank you in the long run (and just about everyone is doing it anyway!). Definitely worth chatting with your local physician about before you leave.You could also consider studying in Shanghai for a few months instead. This article may help you make a better decision: Where should I Study Chinese in China: Beijing or Shanghai?Cheers,Megan  Embed Quote

Possibly. If you are fit and healthy then you'll survive but if you suffer from a repiratory ailment like asthma, then you might be advised to avoid poluted cities.That is not to say that the whole country suffers from air pollution. There are vast areas of the country where you find blue skys and clean air. If you worry about the pollution then perhapse look to live in a smaller city. Also cities near the coast tend to have cleaner air. Though not perfect, Qingdao, Dalian and Xiamen are consistently voted as good cities for expats to live in China.  Embed Quote

At the end of the day whenever one leaves the comforts of the US there are going to be pluses and minuses to going anywhere.  If you are going to study abroad I think the experience in China will be very interesting.  Assuming the status quo doesn't change...China and the US will be the two super powers for the next few generations.  Being exposed to China will give you a leg up back in the US from a professional standpoint.  It will also help you personally to see how things are in China from a self development standpoint.Should the pollution stop you from going?  I don't think it should.  Embed Quote

First of all, you will be appreciated if you can figure out my English error.To study abroad is a choice for every student which is in Beijing and not in Beijing.But can we say that due to the air pollution you must study abroad?No, we should think twice about this.Studying abroad is a good opportunity to open your eyes. However, is it necessary ?If you have a good choice to study something you cant get out of here, why not stay?Let's show a example. You wanna buy a notebook, and now you have two choice: Iphone or Galaxy. They are both very nice, but you maybe still want a Iphone because your last one is a Iphone. Though Iphone have smaller screen.So have you understand my idea?Good day  and merry christmas  Embed Quote

column9: What's the actual evidence, and which work best?
column10: Yes, I do think they work, and I do recommend them to my patients here in Beijing -- and anywhere in the world. I've highlighted the actual data multiple times on my blog, including this post here: How Good are N95 Masks For Pollution?.  The key is "N95" or better -- this literally is a US-government certification that tested the mask and demonstrated 95% decrease (or better) in blocking particulate matter (PM) smaller than 2.5 -- or even smaller, at 0.3 microns. Europe has a different rating system. These systems started for work safety mostly in construction sites (dust, paint fumes etc) and the 3M company is the most reputable US company making these masks. This is why all the good research studies use a 3M mask as a "gold standard" masks. This is also why I recommend them over any other mask. By the way, we focus on PM2.5 and not gases or other toxins because it's felt that PM2.5 causes the most health problems compared to the other pollutants. A particle smaller than 2.5 microns is easily breathed in and directly absorbed into your bloodstream, starting the pro-inflammatory cascade which leads to all the bad health effects. So do N95 masks work? There are a couple studies recently which demonstrate effectiveness in wearing a mask and improving heart rate, blood pressure and also blood markers of inflammation (CRP and others). The test subjects were here in Beijing, literally walking around Second Ring Road and other areas (must have been an interesting site!). The most recent and most convincing study is here: Reducing personal exposure to partic... [Environ Health Perspect. 2012] The first study is here: Beneficial cardiovascular effects of reducing exposure to particulate air pollution with a simple facemask  This is the best evidence so far that a good mask can help decrease exposure and actually help protect your health. Hopefully, better long term studies will be more convincing. But I certainly think the evidence is sound, and it's more than logical to use a proper N95 mask anytime the air is bad. I personally recommend using a mask anytime the AQI is over 200 -- which happens all the time here. As for brands -- a great issue. On my blog I compared the two more popular brands Respro and the newer Totobobo: Respro Vs. Totobobo: Which Mask Works Better For Air Pollution? I actually prefer Totoboto because they are the only consumer version that I am aware of which has published actual real world fit-test results, showing more than 99% effectiveness against PM0.3: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubm... Respro claims 88% effectiveness but didn't provide me with the actual independent test. This is why I recommend Totobobo over Respro. As for other brands, many other new companies are claiming their material is 95-99% effective, which is great -- but what about the real world, with the mask on a face? Because air leakage and a proper fit is crucial. What good is 99% if tons of air leaks around it? This again is why I always prefer the tried and true 3M brand as the "gold standard", and then the Totobobo and Respro types. Don't even bother with a cotton mask or even those blue/green surgical masks, they are 30-70% effective at best.  Embed QuoteAnswered in thirty-one minutes.

column9: Over the last 10 years the pollution in Hong Kong has regularly increased. It is currently at levels which are not suitable for anyone living there.Is corruption a reason for a no action position ? Are lobbyists preventing any action ? Or is the Government just too incompetent to tackle this issue ?
column10: Because there is an easy scapegoat.  Every time someone mentions pollution, people point to factories in Guangdong even though they aren't the major source of pollution.The Causes Behind Hong Kong’s Air Pollution Problem  Embed Quote

column9: Over the last 10 years the pollution in Hong Kong has regularly increased. It is currently at levels which are not suitable for anyone living there.Is corruption a reason for a no action position ? Are lobbyists preventing any action ? Or is the Government just too incompetent to tackle this issue ?
column10: The HK government is aware of the problem, but air quality will not be a priority since there are more attractive diversions. It is rare to see a blue sky in HK. The HK government has not done enough to tackle the problem. Whilst a lot of taxis use LPG, there are simply too many cars on the roads. HK has an excellent public transport network, unless you live somewhere which is quite remote, then you don't need to drive. HK'ers need to get out of the status symbol mentality with cars. Whilst virtually all vehicles sold comply with the EURO standards, that doesn't help reduce pollution if your car is stuck in one of those frequent traffic jams. Some of the worst offenders are old dirty freight vehicles from mainland China. They come in their thousand every day. People often forget that some of the pollution drifts down to HK from mainland China. So no matter how much the HK government does, they can't control what big brother sends down. Then there is the lack of change in terms of how people live. Namely the reliance on air conditioning. Which uses a lot of power. I'm sure that there are innovations out there that can help, but apartment blocks seem to be built the same way for decades. However, nobody seemed to have gone the extra mile to change the thinking regarding energy saving designs. So whilst these apartment blocks look good, they are still very conservative and rather behind. More can be done here. A lot of these civil servants and government ministers don't seem to know what to do. Maybe they lack experience in handling environmental issues. However, they can always find more interesting projects to work on, such as selling land to build luxury apartment blocks to sell to wealthy mainlanders, who will spend very little time in HK. In the meantime, the native HK'er waits for an affordable apartment to become available. This is how the HK government treats the people they serve.   Embed Quote

column9: Over the last 10 years the pollution in Hong Kong has regularly increased. It is currently at levels which are not suitable for anyone living there.Is corruption a reason for a no action position ? Are lobbyists preventing any action ? Or is the Government just too incompetent to tackle this issue ?
column10: I personally do not think that it is corruption.  In HK there is an organization called ICAC, which is an independent organization that specialized in corruption case.In my opinion, the gov just move too slow, and work very ineffective.  It is because tackling pollution involves a lot of different parties.  It is not just: Do this, don't do that, or you will get fine or jail problem.  It is often time that when the gov comes up a policy to solve one problem, because it takes too long to do so the situation changed and the policy is less effective and later on, useless.Here is the prove: http://www.gov.hk/en/residents/e...This is the link from HK Gov which lists out what they have done, or plan to do in the future.  I am not saying that they are all highly effective and HK will be clean tomorrow morning.  But they indeed work on that.I understand that other governments are tackling this problem nicely and why can't HK.  I agree, and there are many things that HK gov can do.  But they just don't know how to do it, and how to do it well, while at the same time not sacrificing everyone's rights.　To conclude: HK Gov knows what is going on, but they just move too slow and very ineffective to solve every problem.Just my opinion, hope it helps.  Embed Quote

column9: Over the last 10 years the pollution in Hong Kong has regularly increased. It is currently at levels which are not suitable for anyone living there.Is corruption a reason for a no action position ? Are lobbyists preventing any action ? Or is the Government just too incompetent to tackle this issue ?
column10: Not an easy solution. Hong Kong thrives on attracting businesses and low tax rates. Both of which in some way conflict with the idea of environmental responsibility.As an example the HK government would need to enforce and impose strict fines and taxes (carbon offsets) for businesses whom are major polluters. This is not conductive to business as it is a regulatory hurdle and politically is tough to gather support for.This article on SCMP recently underscored that HK govt did reduce pollution on power plants in conjunction with Guongdong province but saw that vehicle and ship pollution increased since then [1]. So it isn't for lack of trying. Its just that an environmental strategy needs big thinking and a political driver both of which don't exist at the moment.You can tell that big thinking isn't there by the government strategy to turn down AC in malls this year. It's a nice gesture but falls short on so many fronts. For instance how small businesses are allowed to blast AC with their storefronts open. It'd be a risky political move to ban open storefronts that waste energy like that but clearly a wider brush would help reduce energy use and pollution.And as other commenters have said these goals would need China partnership to succeed.[1] http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-ko...  Embed Quote

column9: We live on a very busy street (lots of buses) and have noticed that we have more dirt that average on windowsills, etc. What's the best strategy for removing that dirt from the air so it doesn't damage our health?
column10: Air purifiers. But don't just buy any air purifier - and especially not the ionizing ones.In general, there is also a cost vs effectiveness tradeoff, so you'll have to determine how much you're willing to pay.There's some more discussion at http://www.longecity.org/forum/t... and at http://www.air-purifier-power.co...  Embed Quote

column9: We live on a very busy street (lots of buses) and have noticed that we have more dirt that average on windowsills, etc. What's the best strategy for removing that dirt from the air so it doesn't damage our health?
column10: For indoor, read Muhammad Syawalfiza's answer to Beijing: What are some tips for surviving the air pollution in Beijing?  Embed Quote

column9: We live on a very busy street (lots of buses) and have noticed that we have more dirt that average on windowsills, etc. What's the best strategy for removing that dirt from the air so it doesn't damage our health?
column10: I used to live in an apartment that was above a train stop (suburb train to and from city).  I noticed soot all over after the blinds and floor after people steam cleaned the carpet because they left the windows open.  It took so long to get rid of the soot, so I understand your problem.Number one is to not leave your windows open.  You will likely need air purifiers with hepa filters that actively clean the air.  I bought two of them (5 years ago they were $100 a piece for a decent one; maybe cheaper today), and I ran them while I wasn't at home.  Plants are also a big help in general because they create oxygen.  I write about this and include NASA's top 10 plant list on my blog: http://findingfoodorlove.blogspo...If you don't have central air, then maybe a box unit that has a major hepa filter on it?  Hepa filters will add up, just address that before purchasing.  And if you need air after you cook or whatever, open the window when the bus routes are quiet, like at midnight or on Sunday morning or something like that.  If that never happens, and the other options are not that helpful.  You might want to consider moving out...  Embed Quote
Many of us think that one of the proper roles of government is to protect the environment, particularly in cases like air pollution where a good free market solution has not been found.  Embed Quote

There is no reason property rights can't be used against air pollution. Every land-owner has property rights in the air immediately above their land.A tort-based solution to air pollution would require that individual property owners are able to efficiently aggregate their claims. Making tort claims transferable will be a big step forward.Consumer choice may well buttress tort-based solutions. While consumers are unlikely to be willing to pay an arm and a leg, experience with such consumer-driven drives as dolphin-safe tuna and free-range eggs (not to mention organic foods) show that they are willing to "pay up" to support issues they believe in.  Embed Quote

I think the Libertarian preference would be lawsuits against those who do damage on others. Since that's hard to do with pollution (who isn't an accomplice?) then the second answer is probably is it really a problem?Once a Libertarian can be convinced it's a real problem then obviously the costs need to be included in the price of all goods and services. The tricky question is how to 1) estimate the right cost to be added and 2) how to implement it worldwide. Regarding the cost: it's interesting to note estimates around what it takes to prevent a more than +2 degrees Celsius global warming (which all countries agreed upon in Copenhagen 2009)It's estimated that less than 600 Gigatons of CO2 emissions can be allowed (in the foreseeable future while earth regrow and create new carbon sinks)Interestingly there are estimates that approximately fossilfuels equivalent of 3000 Gigatons of CO2 emissions are discovered in the world (yet still untapped). Very roughly speaking this means current supply need to be capped at 600 Gigatons which in turn could be approximated with a 5 time increase in price on every ton of CO2 emissions required to produce goods and services. Regarding the implementation: political decisions has to be made to implement e.g. carbon emission trading. This is done in EU but currently the amount of allowed emissions is too high to limit emissions and therefore the price is lower than it ought to be. Ultimately a worldwide agreement needs to be in place otherwise all production will simply re-locate to whatever tiny place on earth where emissions aren't capped. The only forum for such agreements is the United Nations. I'm not sure all Libertarians have come to that conclusion yet but I personally don't see a better alternativ.  Embed Quote

Pretty simple, actually: as consumers, we financially support companies that cause less pollution (and so on). You don't buy your jeans from companies that get their prduct from sweatshops.You don't listen to radio stations that offend you.You use the alternative power company that doesn't dump toxic waste into the river.The market sorts it out.  Embed Quote

To measure indoor air pollution you need to test for every possible or likely pollutant. An exception to this is a Volatile Organic Compounds (VOC) sensor, which tests for multiple pollutants and gives you an aggregated value/level.There are devices that test for one or a few pollutants. Most air quality monitoring devices test temperature & humidity ( combined can lead to mold ), Carbon Dioxide, Carbon Monoxide. Usually for Carbon Monoxide there are standalone devices.However, this is just the tip of the iceberg, there are lots of possible and probable pollutants: Ozone, Nitrogen oxides, Sulfur Dioxide, Radon, Lead, etc. The list goes on and on and they are not as rare as one might think/hope.For example, Radon is a radioactive gas without color or smell. Radon comes from Uranium, which is present in the soil nearly everywhere in the US. It is said to be the second leading cause for lung cancer in the US.There is a lot of information and studies on the subject of indoor air quality, although much more is needed. I myself found only limited scientific studies exist for some specific pollutants.I am fascinated by this topic and I am actually currently involved in creating a monitoring device called AirPlusPlus for common indoor air pollutants. This is just the first step of a much larger vision. Hopefully one day anyone interested can monitor, track and improve the quality of the air in their homes.  Embed Quote

The federal government recommends that you measure the level of radon in your home. Without measurements there is no way to tell whether radon is present because it is a odorless, colorless, radioactive gas. There are Inexpensive devices available for measuring radon. There are also specific mitigation techniques that have proven effective in reducing levels of radon in the home.For pollutants other than radon, measurements are most appropriate when there are either health symptoms or signs of poor ventilation and specific sources or pollutants have been identified as possible causes of indoor air quality problems. Before monitoring your home for pollutants, consult your local health department or professionals who have experience in solving indoor air quality problems.  Embed Quote

Let's consider a greatly simplified model and pretend air pollution is caused by only three things: burning oil, burning coal, and burning tobacco products.Let's further pretend that timing and location is unimportant in the contribution of combustion products to air pollution. Let's pretend that all oil, coal, and tobacco produced is consumed by burning.Let's pretend that total air pollution is:   a_c*p_c + a_o*p_o + a_t*p_t(That each of these three pollutants has a "dirty-index" relating how polluting it is compared with the others. (a_c for coal, a_o for oil, a_t for tobacco.)A 2010 estimate put world oil consumption at 93,250,000 bbl/day(List of countries by oil consumption),an estimate of coal production was 7831 Mt in 2012 (Coal Facts | WCA | World Coal Association) , an estimate of tobacco production in 2000 is 4928 thousands of tons (Tobacco industry)This Page on Eia allows us to convert bbl to Metric tons. Let's pretend the conversion is 10.In common units, ignoring that our data spans over a decade, and curde conversions:     Coal  7831 Mt, Oil 3404 Mt, Tobacco 5 MtTo proceed much further we would need estimates of the relative values of a_c, a_o, and a_t. But unless tobacco is over a hundred times more polluting than coal, tobacco does not dominate global air pollution under the restrictive and unrealistic assumptions herein.  Embed Quote

There are many things that they have done and are doing but so far it is too little and too late. Some events that I found:One story I noticed was that Liaoning province aims to dismantle 3,805 small boilers by the end of this year (2013). A small boiler refers to the central heating system used here, similar to New York, where there are stream boilers in each district that supply heat to the local buildings. Most of these burn coal at a rate of 35 kilograms of coal, per square metre of property, during the five-month heating season. So a 100 square metre house will use 350kg of coal for heating. China burns almost as much coal each year as the rest of the world combined.I noticed the boiler behind my house here was upgraded this year. It is now noticeably quieter and seems to be eating the stock pile of coal more slowly.Another is that they are adopting the use of geothermal heat pumps to replace the heating system based on burning coal. Shenyang, capital of Liaoning province, applied the new heating method in an area of 15.28 million square meters last year. They reckon that saved them burning about 630,000 tons of coal, has reduced sulfur dioxide emissions by 8,060 tons and reduced soot discharges by 5,040 tons.[1]Another big pollution source is the ever increasing number of cars on the roads. More than 13 million cars were sold in China last year (2012).  Vehicles account for 22 percent of PM2.5 in the Beijing, followed by 17 percent from coal burning and 16 percent from construction site dust. In Beijing alone, the number of vehicles has increased to 5.18 million (2012) from 3.13 million (2008).[2]Beijing and Guangzhou have already put in place rules that limit the number and use of new cars. Beijing started capping new car ownership at 20,000 a month through a lottery system in January last year. But the number of applicants reached 1.07 million in August 2012. Guangzhou recently announced a similar policy, which allows only 10,000 new cars to be registered per month. [3]In Shanghai, the government uses an auction to control the plate supply and the price has kept going up. The plate, currently worth more than 60,000 yuan (US $9,464).Nanjing and Hangzhou in east-central China are moving to require cleaner gas and diesel. Xi’an and Urumqi in north western China are banning and scrapping cars built before 2005, when automotive emissions rules were less stringent.[4]Public transport is also being improved. Already 18 cities have built subways, light rail or or other mast transit systems. Another 17 cities are building such systems at the moment and existing systems are being expanded. Yet another 24 cities are in the planning stages.[5]Power supply is another area that needs work. Most of China's electricity comes form coal power stations. At the end of 2011, wind power in China accounted for 62 gigawatts (GW) of electricity generating capacity. The country aims to have 100 gigawatts (GW) of on-grid wind power generating capacity by the end of 2015 and to generate 190 billion kilowatt hours (kWh) of wind power annually. Hydropower capacity at the end of 2015 will increased to 260 GW. Also by 2015 they plan to have 10 GW of solar power capacity.[6] As part of the environmental goals included in China’s 12th Five Year Plan (2011–2015) targets have been set for non-fossil energy to account for 11.4% of the total energy consumption, and for CO2 discharge per unit of GDP to reduce by 17%.[7][1] China Daily: Liaoning to replace small heating boilers[2] National and Local Weather Forecast, Hurricane, Radar and Report: China's Love Affair with Cars Chokes City Air - weather.com[3] China Daily: China fears new car restrictions[4] NY Times: Guangzhou Moves to Limit New Cars[5] Wikipedia: Rapid transit in China[6] Reuters: China revises up 2015 renewable energy goals: report[7] Wikipedia: Wind power in the People's Republic of China  Embed Quote

Rumor has it that Zhongnanhai, the Chinese leadership compound in central Beijing, is outfitted with some of the best air filtration systems available.  So, you know, they're right on top of it.  Embed QuoteAnswered in two minutes.

Recently the Beijing municipal government changed its air quality reporting standards, which although not a solution to the problem, it was a major step. Previously, official reports only disclosed larger air particles of up to 10 microns diameter and neglected the smaller (and more hazardous) PM 2.5 particles. This resulted in the ludicrous situation of the government telling its coughing populace that the grey smog they were driving to work in was in fact an official "blue sky day".An impetus for the change was public outcry (mostly online) over the US embassy releasing its own hourly readings of PM 2.5 concentration through twitter (despite the censor's strong arm, netizens are still the most powerful lobby group in China). The government tried to discredit the readings by painting them as some US plot to contain China's rise. I remember one editorial in 2009 tried to suggest they were inaccurate because the embassy was too close to a major ring road. In the end, science and empirical evidence won out.  Embed Quote
They've employed a team of experts to help reduce smog – Photoshop experts.  Embed QuoteAnswered in seventeen minutes.
The government put up a billboard.http://blogs.ft.com/beyond-brics...  Embed Quote

They are still struggling to solve the water quality problem first. I had an Environmental Science degree in China 5 years ago. We had about 5~7 courses in water pollution control but only one elective in air pollution control. The research direction of the faculties were about 60 on water  problems and 5 on air quality problems. That should give you some perspective about where things are now.  Embed Quote

WIth the updated monitoring changes (switching from measuring particulate pollution from PM10 to PM2.5) they likely will soon begin changing the emissions standard/limits for factories. One way they could control emission is by requiring increased use/better operation of dust collection equipment (such as baghouses) in industrial settings. In the US industrial sites are required by law to meet strict emissions standards for PM2.5. The only way to meet these standards is by installing dust collection equipment throughout a facility. This technology sucks up fugitive dust emissions/dust-laden air and pushes it through a fabric filter to capture all of the dust particles before exhausting the air back into the atmosphere. This technology can take a extremely dusty operation such as cement production or steel manufacturing and reduce the dust generated  by upwards of 99%. If this type of equipment were required in China as it is in the US, (and elsewhere) they would see significant reductions in their air pollution levels. Samuel DalSanto Baghouse.comParticulate FilterAir Pollution  Embed Quote

The government has published information about weather quality already. This image is from 北京空气质量 (Chinese, Beijing Air Quality), a website built by the government.Also they moved high pollution workshop like Shougang out of major city. This will be helpful with improving air quality.So, just wait. Air quality will be better.  Embed Quote

Statistics suggest that China is increasing the level of funding used to counter pollution. The following chart shows the increase in expenditure between 2006 and 2010: http://www.statista.com/statisti...  Embed Quote
Internet GIS for Air Quality Information Service for Dalian which can be further used for management at local level.Citation:- http://www.collectionscanada.gc....  Embed Quote
I don't think Chinese Government is actually thinking that far ahead, let alone do anything about it.  Embed QuoteAnswered in two minutes.

column9: I'm looking for overall carbon footprint based on pollution at the power plant and pollution by the car.
column10: Well, it seems the best side-by-side analysis is from the DOE [1]. For the national averages, seen below, electric vehicles emit considerably less CO2 than conventional gas vehicles per year.   Using the same website you can determine what the emissions would be where you live. Of course, as with anything in the real world, there are complexities.  When discussing electric cars, their "fuel" source can vary from nearly all coal fired plants (still better than gas cars due to system efficiency but not extremely so) to solar, wind, and hydro (no question that there's no CO2 emitted here), to everything in between.  To the question asker: any assessment of electric car pollution will always without exception include the power plant. That's not quite so for petroleum burning cars because there are far more energy sinks (wastes) along the path (drilling, transport, refining, transport again, electricity to pump it...) before the fuel reaches the tank.[1] http://www.afdc.energy.gov/vehic...  Embed QuoteVia  Sumi Kim.

column9: I'm looking for overall carbon footprint based on pollution at the power plant and pollution by the car.
column10: The gasoline emissions from your tailpipe don't account for the emissions generated from flaring natural gas when the oil is taken from the ground. They don't account for the energy used by the tanker that ships your oil. They don't account for the energy used in refining that oil. They don't account for the energy used to truck that oil from a refinery to your gas station. (They also don't account for the second-order costs of producing oil like invading Iraq, but let's just leave those aside for now.)The net emissions from an electrically powered automobile in the U.S. are a fraction -- sometimes meaningful, often vanishingly small -- of the net emissions from a gasoline-powered car.  Embed Quote

column9: I'm looking for overall carbon footprint based on pollution at the power plant and pollution by the car.

column9: In other terms, why is there more nitrogen in diesel fuel than in other fuels ?
column10: Diesel Engines work on the Diesel cycle as against the petrol engine which works on the Otto cycle. This means that in the diesel engine the piston travels farther and compresses the inlet gas to a higher compression ratio(up to 22:1). Pressure at TDC can be found using the following formula (Picture courtesy Wikipedia):CR => Compression Ratio => Specific heat ratio of working fluid(air = 1.4)This would result in pressure at top dead center in excess of  75 bar for diesels and ~25 bar for Petrol Engines.The enthalpy of formation of NO2 gas is 33kJ/mol(which is pretty high). This means that NO2 requires high pressures at temperatures to form.Therefore even at comparable displacements more NO2 will be formed in a diesel engine as compared to a petrol.  Embed Quote

column9: In other terms, why is there more nitrogen in diesel fuel than in other fuels ?
column10: tl;dr They run hotter and at higher pressures.A petrol (gas) engine ignites the fuel-air mixture with a spark.  A Diesel engine ignites the fuel-air mixture by compressing it really hard, and making it hot. Diesel engines therefore run both hotter and at higher pressures.(For this reason, Diesel engines tend to be bigger and need to be stronger - you get a lot of Diesel powered trucks, you don't get Diesel powered motorbikes.)NOx is formed when nitrogen and oxygen from the air are combined - under heat and pressure. More heat and pressure gives you more NOx.  Embed Quote

column9: In other terms, why is there more nitrogen in diesel fuel than in other fuels ?
column10: NOx formation is a reversible reaction. The rate of any reversible reaction is the product of concentration of the products divided by the concentration of the reactants. This rate of reaction directly corresponds to the quantity of NOx in the exhaust. i.e. higher the rate of reaction, higher the quantity of pollutants. The rate of any reversible reaction is strongly influenced by the temperature at which the reaction takes place. This is also known as chemical kinetics. As we all know that in cylinder pressures in a Diesel engine is much higher when compared to a gasoline engine, the temperature is much higher too. And that's why there is much more NOx in diesel exhaust.  Embed Quote

column9: In other terms, why is there more nitrogen in diesel fuel than in other fuels ?
column10: The Nitrogen comes from the air not the diesel fuel.The combustion flame of a diesel engine is hot enough to cause oxygen and nitrogen to react slightly, thus giving a trace of nitric oxide in the exhaust fumes.  Embed Quote

column9: Anecdotally and in limited sources that I can find [Water and Air Pollution — History.com Articles, Video, Pictures and Facts], it seems that lots of countries had trouble with runaway ecological damage during their respective periods of industrialization.Is what China is experiencing today not as bad, as bad, or worse than their peers at similar points in their development?
column10: Although not entirely representative of China, a lot of comparisons are made between Beijing's air pollution levels today and the Great Smog of London in the 1950s, as well as London during the Industrial Revolution / Victorian era (18th/19th century). This was not uncommon:December 1952 in LondonIn the latter two cases, high density of pollution particulates (especially sulfur dioxide from burgeoning industrial zones in Greater London and neighboring industrial cities like Birmingham) caused significantly reduced visibility due to coal burning (driving was difficult), serious health hazards (4000 recorded deaths), and a cascade of other environmental repercussions (the peppered moth evolution comes to mind). Beijing's basin-like geography (similar to that of Los Angeles), however, is particular, and does intensify the effects of air pollution for which London has no comparison.Given this, it's still difficult to assess the levels of air pollution in China compared to other developed countries including the UK at the same point in economic development because it was nearly impossible to accurately measure air pollution such as sulfur dioxide until the 1950s, and thus we essentially have limited dependable recorded history of air pollution levels at the time when other currently developed countries were at comparable stages. In terms of runaway ecological damage, China may be in a league of its own due to a variety of factors (lack of legal transparency, complex bureaucratic barriers in implementing environmental laws, only recently growing strength of civic/grassroots movements in the Chinese Green Revolution). A really fascinating documentary I would recommend to understand the complex problems of environmental pollution in China is called the The Warriors of Qiugang (2010) by Chinese-American filmmaker Ruby Yang. It really puts things in perspective and gives you a very real picture of what sorts of environmental challenges China is facing today as a result of furious development and relentless industrialization, as well as what it means for the people living through it.  Embed Quote

I've spent about a month in Shenzhen spread over 2 years, so I'm not the best person to answer this question.  In general, the ari quality in Shenzhen is a LOT better than in Beijing.  This is in spite of the fact that its significantly more industrialized.  My sense is that being on the ocean, the pollution gets blown elsewhere.  Embed QuoteVia  Steven Kaplan.

I grew up in Shenzhen, and I am fully responsible to say that Shenzhen has the best air quality among all the big cities in China. We even get to see the blue sky for about 50% of the time, which is always nice.  Embed Quote

column9: I understand that a massive air conditioner wouldn't do the trick, since it produces a greater amount of heated air than cooled. However, with all of the incredible advancements of technology that have been created throughout the past century, I'm surprised that a device that cools the air without the opposite effect has yet to be created.Also, if that were even possible, would it actually offset the effects of global warming and maintain a certain temperature?
column10: Many different global cooling schemes have been proposed. The two major mechanisms are Greenhouse gas removal and Solar radiation management. The former directly reduces the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere to decrease the heat trapped before it radiates into space. The latter reduces the solar energy absorbed by the planet, such as by producing artificial clouds to reflect light back into space.Many studies suggest that SRM would be a credible and cost-effective measure to delay global warming. (Although you can't ever stop, which is a bit scary.) If you wanted to, it could cool the planet even further than is required to offset the recent warming trend.For example, dispersing an aerosol of sulfates in the upper atmosphere has a powerful reflective effect to reduce the amount of sunlight absorbed by the planet. The effect was proven effective by the sulfur-laden eruption of Mt Pinatubo, which noticably cooled the entire planet -- so the only significant unknown is how to engineer the deployment system. Various proposals have been raised, such as adding sulfur to jet fuels, launching artillery shells into the air, and even building an enormous miles-tall pipe.Stratospheric sulfate aerosols (geoengineering)The cost of the "sulfur" plan to completely offset anthropogenic global warming has been estimated at $25-50 billion per year, which is easily within the means of a single large nation. But there are large error bars on that number -- no one's tried it yet.  Embed QuoteAnswered in twenty-five minutes.

column9: I understand that a massive air conditioner wouldn't do the trick, since it produces a greater amount of heated air than cooled. However, with all of the incredible advancements of technology that have been created throughout the past century, I'm surprised that a device that cools the air without the opposite effect has yet to be created.Also, if that were even possible, would it actually offset the effects of global warming and maintain a certain temperature?
column10: Three things:1. No matter how advanced our technology gets, cooling something without heating something else up is a physical impossibility.  That heat has to go somewhere.  Yes, we could fire the heat off into space or something like that, but if that's the case, then it would be easier just to reduce the amount of heat arriving on earth in the first place (such as giant space mirror ideas)2. Affecting climate on a global scale is not only extremely difficult, and beyond what we are capable of doing today, it is also an extremely risky thing to do since we don't fully understand the consequences, we could equally end up screwing ourselves over even more.3. Nobody is willing to fund such a massive thing.  As a species, we don't have the kind of cohesion and forward-thinking to be able to come together and do something like this for the good of ourselves and the other species on the earth.  There are also many many arguments against doing such a thing and using that money for something else, such as solving humanity's other problems; or maybe acknowledging that sooner or later something's going to wipe out humans on Earth, whether it's man-made or natural, and we'd better be making plans to be able to get off the planet and establish colonies elsewhere to ensure the survival of the human race.  Stuff like that.In summary: we can't because what you're suggesting is impossible.  We can't because what you're suggesting is too risky.  We can't because humanity doesn't have the resources, unity, or will to see through what you're suggesting  Embed QuoteAnswered in twenty-three minutes.

column9: I understand that a massive air conditioner wouldn't do the trick, since it produces a greater amount of heated air than cooled. column9: I understand that a massive air conditioner wouldn't do the trick, since it produces a greater amount of heated air than cooled. However, with all of the incredible advancements of technology that have been created throughout the past century, I'm surprised that a device that cools the air without the opposite effect has yet to be created.Also, if that were even possible, would it actually offset the effects of global warming and maintain a certain temperature?
column10: No. Such a machine would violate the first law of thermodynamics, which is essentially a version of the law of conservation of energy. It's just how the universe works. Basically, what goes in must come out; energy can neither be created or destroyed.Now, something that could work in theory - albeit impractical - would be to "store" the heat in some object and cast off that object far away from the earth, though the energy required to cast off such an object may produce more heat energy than you're trying to get rid of.  Embed QuoteAnswered in eleven minutes.

column10: Thermodynamics demands that energy can be transferred from one form to another. The additional solar energy trapped by greenhouse gases has to be reflected out into space, or you need to get some sustainable irreversible endothermic reaction to do it. Probably we can talk about devices that use solar energy to fixate the carbondioxide back into hydrocarbons. But there are already a highly optimzed machines to do so, we only lack space to have them. They are called Trees.  Embed Quote
