column10: Unfortunately we have to breath. That means we need our atmosphere.  But that is what is preventing the trapped heat near the ground from getting to outer space which is cold.  If we could remove the atmosphere and  still live to tell about it the problem would solve itself.  And earth without an atmosphere would radiate as much heat as it received.  Embed QuoteAnswered in thirteen minutes via  Stephen Bardutz.

column9: I understand that a massive air conditioner wouldn't do the trick, since it produces a greater amount of heated air than cooled. However, with all of the incredible advancements of technology that have been created throughout the past century, I'm surprised that a device that cools the air without the opposite effect has yet to be created.Also, if that were even possible, would it actually offset the effects of global warming and maintain a certain temperature?
column10: A summary of below: Energy cannot be created or destroyed (well, energy and mass combined if you're traveling near the speed of light). This is why we can't cool the atmosphere. The process of cooling requires 3 things:1) A hot "reservoir" to be cooled2) A cold "reservoir" to receive #1's heat3) In the case of standard matter, a medium in which the transfer takes placeWhen something is cooled, it is transferring molecular kinetic energy to its surroundings. The reason it does this is because of equilibrium. Everything wants to be in equilibrium with everything. It's how the universe works. So a system of hot and cold reservoirs will transfer heat until each reservoir contains equal amount of heat (or temperature). In order to cool the atmosphere, we'd need a cold reservoir for the energy to transfer to. Energy can't be destroyed, so the heat HAS to go somewhere. Well why not into space, it's cold, right? Space is void of matter. Once you leave the atmosphere, there literally is nothing. No molecules anywhere (aside from drifting bits and pieces of this and that). The medium for heat transfer doesn't exist. Nor does the cold reservoir (no molecules). Therefore we cannot cool the atmosphere with any known devices invented so far in history. How does the atmosphere get hotter/why global warming? Radiation. The sun radiates heat our way and the earth's atmosphere absorbes it. We reflect quite a bit of it, so we don't get scorched; from the sun's perspective though, we are a cold reservoir. The radiation heat is able to travel through a medium of electromagnetic waves and events. However when this heat transfers into actual matter, it must have matter as its travel medium. Hope this helps!  Embed Quote

column9: What are their causes and how to solve them?
column10: One of the major problems for north China is the depletion of underground fresh water sources.This is a large issue which has gone largely undiscussed. The main reason for the rapid depletion over the past 30 years is because the government has encouraged China's manufacturing and industrialization, and in the process, priced water at very low rates for industry. In order to help resolve this problem, the government has proposed a major engineering project to move water from China's south, which has adequate water, to the north. In Chinese, this project is called the 南水北调工程计划. This would involve moving water through huge underground tunnels; the engineering challenges for this project are tremendous. For Beijing, the government is proposing building water desalination plants for Beijing's population. Another side effect of the industrialization policy has been topsoil erosion. With no significant plant life on the surface, and winds from Gobi desert blowing dust in every spring, desertification in north China is continuing to spread. The government has encouraged tree planting to slow the desertification, but without sufficient underground water to keep the trees alive, the problem continues.I believe the whole problem began with China's decision to turn Beijing into a mega-city. This was done for political reasons: China wanted a megacity to compete with Seoul and Tokyo. Over the past five years the Beijing city government has been rolling out new subway lines rapidly, but it is still insufficient to meet the demands of Beijing's residents.When more and more work is done by service jobs over the Internet, one needs to ask "Is there really a need for people to be concentrated in huge cities in order to work?"Now it is paying the price.  Embed Quote

column9: What are their causes and how to solve them?
column10: Two major themes underlie Beijing's contemporary issues: unsustainability and unpreparedness.The major issues are not the reversible environmental concerns, but the fact that their is no sign or direction for sustainable solutions to these problems.  Let's review these concerns.   Pollution, not just air:Health and wealth: Why China needs cleaner citiesAir pollution has been covered many times and their are many views on how to solve this problem even on Quora:Beijing: What is Beijing going to do about its horribly disturbing pollution problem as of recent?What is the Chinese government doing about pollution in major cities like Beijing, if anything?However, many people forget the rising water pollution and sewage issues in Beijing.  See Eutrophication for a unique aspect of this issue.  Most of the pollution seems to come from chemical and pharmaceutical enterprises.  Untreated, these wastes can lead to high levels of carcinogens in the drinking water, which is not always purified.  Corporate citizenship and stronger regulation and transparency would help curb this, but are unlikely in the near future.  Furthermore, many numbers are "fudged" by city leaders to make their city appear cleaner to get more incentives from the government.All Wet and Nasty: Beijing's Polluted WaterwaysAll Five of Beijing’s Major Water Systems Seriously Polluted - The Epoch Times.  We can hope that Beijing will be able to solve these problems soon like Mexico City in the 1990's, Tokyo in the 1980's, or even London's on-again, off-again air problems since the 1950's.Massive migration and overpopulation:Overpopulation vexes city plannersWhile Beijing can sustain its natural growth rate of 4%, its carrying capacity is currently higher than is sustainable.  As a metric, 500,000 people move into the Beijing area every year, with the population density having nearly doubled since 1999.  This creates issues in gender balance, food supply and consumption, sanitation and lack of landfills, water shortages, increased housing prices, lower birth rates, higher death rates, and even (eventually) sunlight availability.  As an example, Beijing boasts roughly only 10% of water availability per capita set by international standards [Source].  Fortunately, Beijing is very spread out and not confined geographically, but resources will be moved around less and less efficiently.  Beijing on the brink due to overpopulation - Beijing TodayBeijing's population tops 19.6 mln, migration key contributor to growthPromoting a green economy, moving migrating populations towards nearby cities, efficient city planning, and much much could alleviate the problem.  I've even heard the suggestion off moving China's capital to alleviate pressure on Beijing. Moving wholesale markets that attract millions of temporary vendors are also considered being moved to more remote areas of the city:Of course, the Hukou system (户口) was meant to address the issues of mass-migration from the rural areas, but a discussion regarding the effectiveness, fairness, and reform issues are for another time.Property, prices, and disappearing culture:China's Beijing tightens property controls to cool pricesJust search online "China property bubble" and choose a side to debate the economists on.  What is guaranteed are the increasing housing prices in large cities, Beijing included.  The skyline is rapidly growing, with parts of Beijing already looking like Panama City and Miami.  While China's number of millionaires is growing, many of units in these tall apartment buildings cost more than $100,000 to purchase, well out of reach for the average Chinese citizen.  Until middle class growth matures over the next decade, many of the apartments will likely sit empty.No Confidence in China Markets Inflates Housing BubbleMeet China's Housing Debt SlavesHutongs (胡同) ar... (more)Loading...

column9: What percentage can we attribute to cars, the economy, or just geography?  Looking at the online AQI website, China's index is off the charts compared to that of other developing/developed nations.  Other nations have cars and an economy too so why is China the only one that's suffering from this?  Nearby Korea and Japan seem to be fine which makes me wonder, what steps are neighboring nations taking to protect their own air from the pollutants over China?
column10: First of all, I am not an expert.  However, I lived in China for a year and I have read a lot about the country so I think I more or less understand it. Therefore,  I can suggest three factors that are contributing to the pollution problem that China is facing:-         Industry-         Coal-         TransportationIndustry: China has faced a rapid industrial expansion. It is now one of the main global manufacturing centers. Industry is good for the economy, but not so good for the environment. And China is one of the leading countries in some of the most polluting and energy-intensive industries, such as cement, iron and steel and mining.Coal: China burns coal to produce most of its electricity (more than 65% of its energy mix is coal-derived). Coal is relatively cheap and abundant in both China and Mongolia; however it’s one of the dirtiest ways of producing energy. And China burns a lot of it: it needs a lot of electricity for the industry and for more than 1.3 billion people. This makes the country the biggest consumer of coal in the world. Furthermore, China also uses coal to heat up water used for district-heating during winter (coincidentally winter is when most of the pollution-peaks occur) and many small houses that do not have access to district-heating systems (like those in Beijing’s Hutongs) also use coal. Just as an example, there are coal-powered thermic plants and coal-powered district-heating plants in the Beijing area.Transportation: China has had an amazing expansion of its total number of cars and flights, which undoubtedly contribute to the pollution problem, although I don’t believe they do as much as the first two factors.  Embed Quote

Unlike western countries, for earning the same one dollar, china has to produce more and pollute more. In past years, GDP is the unique goal of government and air quality...no body cared.Seconds, China has the largest population in world and thus such a huge food, housing, transportation and energy demand. Each of these demands aggravates air pollution. It is noteworthy that most of power station in China is by coal, which is one of the main causes of air pollution. Another reason I think is the urbanization in China and meantime, more people become one of the middle class. If you know how many vehicles are sold in China compared to 10 years ago, you'll understand it.  Embed QuoteAnswered in fifty-four minutes.

It's absolutely much more harmful to smoke even 1 cigarette a day compared to living in any city in the world. You can do the math yourself, read the studies yourself: a day in Beijing is equal only to 1/6 of one cigarette. That Atlantic Cities article below was discussing an interview with me and my blog article: A Day In Beijing Is Like Smoking Only One Sixth Of A Cigarette? It's Almost...Disappointing! Here's the basics: Step 1: Read The Research People should read the scholarly article from Dr Pope, who has authored or co-authored most of the most important research on air pollution over the last 20 years. In his latest spectacularly useful research from Environmental Health Perspectives, he analyzes death rates from heart disease and lung cancers caused by smoking and air pollution. The detail is stunningly useful, and it also provided us with the data needed to actually measure mortality risk of air pollution. Step 2: Do The Math First, just what is an average day in Beijing? We get rightfully scared about these occasional 500′s, but those are rare peaks. The official average PM10 level from 2010 is 121 µg/m³, which converts to an AQI of 84, which is “Moderate” on the US EPA’s guideline. From a Steven Andrews article, we get the US Embassy’s average daily PM2.5 over the last two years of 100 µg/m³ (which converts to an AQI of 171, “Unhealthy” for the US EPA). Now we know the daily data. So how much of these particles do we breathe in a day? First, we need to know how much air an average person breathes. This can vary in the research literature, but Dr Pope mentions that most studies use an average adult inhalation of 18m³/day of air. Now we can do our calculations. If we use:PM10 data: 121 µg/m³ x 18m³/day (÷1,000 to convert µg to mg) = 2.2mg/day of inhaled PM10 PM2.5 data:  100 µg/m³ x 18m³/day (÷1,000 to convert µg to mg) = 1.8mg/day of inhaled PM2.5 Since Pope’s studies mostly use PM2.5 data for comparisons, we will focus mostly on PM2.5 and not the “official” PM10. As you can see, it’s not a stretch to use the US Embassy’s “unofficial” data, as 2.2mg and 1.8mg are relatively close numbers, in my opinion. Also, since it’s estimated that Beijing’s PM2.5 concentration is roughly 85% of PM10, then the numbers mostly are equal. Step 3: Compare To A CigarettePope also uses the research standard that an average cigarette contains 12mg of inhaled PM2.5. Yes, there are differences in smoking habits (some of us even claim “I didn’t inhale”…) but this seems to be the standard in most research literature.So if we compare the above numbers:PM2.5 data: 1.8 mg/d air pollution ÷ 12 mg cigarette = 15% of one cigarette That means that a daily dose of Beijing’s average air pollution is equivalent to 1/6 of one cigarette.  What About The Really Bad Days?So what about the really bad days when the US Embassy’s 24-hour data hits “Very Unhealthy” 200; “Hazardous” 300 or “Crazy Bad/Beyond Index” 500? Let’s find out. First, you must convert the AQI to PM2.5 concentration, which is easy to do with the online calculator:AQI200 = 150µg/m³ x 18m³/day (÷1,000) = 2.7mg/d ÷12 = 23% of one cigarette a day AQI300 = 250µg/m³ x 18m³/day (÷1,000) = 4.5mg/d ÷12 = 38% of one cigarette a dayAQI500 = 500µg/m³ x 18m³/day (÷1,000) = 9.0mg/d ÷12 = 75% of one cigarette a day This means that even with an extremely rare average of 500, that’s still equivalent to smoking less than one cigarette a day! What About Your City?What about Shanghai, or Mexico City, or LA? Just find out the average daily PM2.5 concentration or AQI and plug in the numbers! For example:City X: PM2.5 concentration =  __ µg/m³ x 18m³/day (÷1,000) = 0.27mg/d ÷12 = __ % of one cigarette a day  Embed Quote

It's worth taking into account that living in a city like Beijing inevitably involves being exposed to second-hand cigarette smoke. On the street, in restaurants and even in elevators - it can be unavoidable. Unless you never leave your IQAir-equipped apartment, you're probably breathing in more than 1/6 of a cigarette.  Embed Quote

column9: Yesterday (12/6/2013) Shanghai AQI over 500, and most of city in China, AQI over 200-300.How do you think China's future, and will continue live or work in China?
column10: Pollution is a fact of life, if not quite ever-present, in Shanghai. I'm pretty blase about it generally speaking. I know people who monitor the AQI with apps on their phones, but I don't pay it much attention. Whenever they comment on it I just shrug my shoulders and get on with things. However, Friday was something else. You know the pollution is bad when even I start talking about it and adapting my behaviour to avoid it. Usually I walk home from my nearest subway stop (about 20-25 minutes) but I took the bus this time; I didn't want to spend any meaningful time outside. I also picked up a mask on my way home (though one much less impressive than Andy Lee's) and when I got home I kept all my windows closed (I often have them open a little to air the apartment). The smog was overwhelming. Visibility was down to a hundred yards and you could taste the dust, not just in your mouth but all the way back in your throat, and it was still there the next morning. I've drunk a lot of water this weekend. It's not been pleasant.But, as I say, it's a fact of life. The cloud will move on and things will get back to normal quickly, which is to say, they will return to the normal levels of tolerable pollution. I'm also glad the Shanghai Marathon took place last weekend and not this week. They would surely have had to cancel it if it were otherwise.  Embed Quote

column9: Yesterday (12/6/2013) Shanghai AQI over 500, and most of city in China, AQI over 200-300.How do you think China's future, and will continue live or work in China?
column10: I had essentially the same reaction as Andy Warwick. I've been rather jaded about air pollution until it reached meteoric levels last week. I was waiting for the Blade Runne Blimp to silently swoop in through the haze advertising Pan Am and Koss headsets. Now I'm looking at dropping serious cash for a clean room strength air purifier for the home and the office while considering if an off-world colony is right for me. What concerns me is the short-term solution, at least in Shanghai, is to lower the benchmark for alerts during the WInter( Shanghai just lowered its air quality benchmark because that's how bad it is), which is a stark reminder that China still deploys such brazenly self-serving tactics. From what I have read, there is no long-term solution to the problem and it is likely to get worse before it gets any better.  Embed Quote

column9: Yesterday (12/6/2013) Shanghai AQI over 500, and most of city in China, AQI over 200-300.How do you think China's future, and will continue live or work in China?
column10: The pollution scare seems to have come and gone and people are back to their normal routines. Beijing's air quality is always in the news and it is probably a lot worse, but Shanghai's AQI has been consistently >100 since October. While 100 is not as bad as 500, I feel like this "it could be worse" mentality is quite unhealthy (literally). While I'm not getting on the next plane back home, it's definitely something I'm going to take into consideration when it comes to deciding whether I will stay in the longer term. People don't realize how serious the adverse health effects of air pollution are because it's not readily apparent. Beijing's lung cancer has gone up 60% in a decade despite the % of smokers remaining flat, and I wouldn't want to become part of that statistic for Shanghai in another 10 years. In the meantime, I'm stocking up on PM2.5 masks (they were completely sold out last week) and hoping I don't see another 500+ day anytime soon!  Embed Quote

column10: As a foreigner in China, I am glad to not be living in one of this country's horribly polluted cities. I have lived in Kunming, a city in Southwestern China famous for its "clean air". Indeed, Kunming regularly enjoys air significantly better than its big city eastern counterparts. However, even Kunming's air has been getting worse, due to increased automobile use and lots of construction. This is one reason why I am moving to Dali, a small town in western Yunnan Province where the air is several times better than that in Kunming, and several hundred times better than that in Beijing or Zhengzhou.  Embed Quote

column10: There are many different opinions for this answer but the most common answer for cleanest country would be SWITZERLAND.See the EPI rankings by Yale : 2012 EPI :: RankingsAt a previous study, researchers at Yale and Columbia ranked countries’ environmental performance based on 25 metrics, including water and air quality, habitat protection and the impact of the environment on the health of the population. [The World's 10 Cleanest Countries]Iceland ranked first on their Environmental Performance Index (EPI). It scored 93.5 out of 100. Countries who ranked highest on the list were those who had diverse ecosystems, a rich supply of fresh water and little industrial contamination, and wealthy countries who had made the most improvement at environmental restoration.  Embed Quote

column9: Such as particulate matter and formaldehyde
column10: Indoor air pollution is certainly the cause of headaches.  Some people experience mild to severe headaches when exposed to mold.  According to Dr. Ritchie Shoemaker, some 25% of the population lack the gene to form antibodies when exposed to mold. The mold toxins are free to travel throughout the body and attack every system in the body.  They can even pass through the blood/brain barrier thus causing the headaches.  There is also no way to clear the toxins if not diagnosed and properly treated.  Another cause is multiple chemical sensitivity also an inherited genetic trait.  Also the amount of chemicals in your house leach out more during times of high humidity.  This is called chemical off-gassing. There are more chemicals in your house then you think.  Consider: paints, solvents, glues, hobby stuff, cleaning products, construction products, furniture, carpeting, cigarette smoke, even the basement can have mold and or radon.  There is much more to say; But I am not a doctor just one who suffered because of both conditions that made me research.  Embed Quote

Snopes says "no" and explains:So where does the idea that SLS is carcinogenic come from? Back in the 1970s some shampoos were found to be contaminated with small amounts of nitrosamines, which are carcinogenic. Ethanolamine lauryl sulfates used in these shampoos were determined to be the source of the nitrosamine contamination, and manufacturers took corrective action. Perhaps someone is now confusing ethanolamine lauryl sulfate with sodium lauryl sulfate. Or, since the "SLS is dangerous" message has been widely disseminated by sellers of "alternative" or "all natural" products who tout that their wares don't contain SLS, perhaps someone in the "natural products" business deliberately created the message as a way of drumming up sales.Sodium Lauryl Sulfate and ShampooAnd "How Stuff Works" HowStuffWorks "Sodium Lauryl Sulfate and Cancer "  Embed Quote

SLS is not dangerous; however, in toothpaste (this question has a dentistry tag) SLS can reduce the bioavailability of fluoride and has been associated in some studies with an increased incidence of aphthous ulcers.  Embed Quote

Sodium lauryl sulfate [SLS] and sodium laureth sulfate [SLES] are the lathering agents in soap and shampoo—they make the bubbles.  Every few years “natural” soap and shampoo marketers target SLS and SLES as caustic agents to convince potential buyers to switch brands.  Their efforts are working as I have recently witnessed my friends with no science background discussing the topic.  Because of this, I have watched the videos and read the propaganda written by unqualified authors using bits and pieces of outdated studies that have been taken out of context.  It makes me chuckle.I was first introduced to SLS and SLES bashing in the late 90s when I was taking chemistry courses at UT. One of my professors worked in the soap industry and we had lengthy conversations about chemicals found in soaps, shampoos, and detergents.  SLS and SLES are benign lathering agents with no documented general risks or adverse effects.  Both have been studied rigorously by independent agencies.  Because of the “electric” pull and the size of the molecule, it does not enter the skin and end up “in your system.”  This is true for most other ingredients in shampoo as well. SLS and SLES don’t grow on trees but they are derived from nature.  Because the process of doing so occurs in a lab, they are known as chemicals.  However, there is a difference between chemicals derived from nature and those constructed by man.  Any ingredient with a number in the name is synthetic (manmade) and in large quantities can become a health hazard.  1,4 Dioxane (synthetic chemical carcinogen) and quaternium-15 (a formaldehyde releasing preservative) are ones to watch for. In addition to synthetic chemicals (again, usually has a number in the name), watch out for “fragrance” on a product’s ingredient list.  Under FDA law, a manufacturer does not have to disclose ingredients labeled as “fragrance” to protect against knockoff perfume formulations.  Ingredients used to scent shampoos, soaps or detergents are not disclosed to any governing agency and that is where known cancer causing agents may be purposefully hidden. There are movements in the US to change the “fragrance” protection law but the US Cosmetics, Toiletry and Fragrance Association (CTFA) has strong lobbyists who are paid well by a 60 billion dollar industry.  The EU has banned over 1100 chemicals from personal care products because they may cause cancer, birth defects or reproductive problems.  The US has banned only 9. In the meantime, you can protect yourself by avoiding synthetic chemicals and products that contain “fragrance” on the ingredient list.  Switching brands frequently might also help to reduce continued exposure to the unlisted ingredients.  Alone, the "natural chemicals” in shampoo, such as SLS and SLES, are not going to harm you but the fragrance might. Check out my blog.  Nurse Gail - Gail Ingram is a NYC nurse sharing her perspective on health care and wellness.  Embed Quote

column9: The average pH of honey is around 3.5, according to Wikipedia and various Quora answers. While I understand that a markedly low or high pH is not essential to be corrosive, such as with HF (where the F- ions play a role), How is it that something with a pH close to gastric acid pH isn't? Where's my chemistry wrong? Or is it the biology?
column10: If the pH = 4, it will corrode things that are not stable to acid.  As Robert Gluck pointed out, the mouth is buffered, which means it resists pH changes.  If you were monitoring the pH of your mouth with honey in it, you would see an initial drop in pH and then it would adjust back to somewhere around 5 or 6 (the pH of your mouth).Some solutions at low pH are buffers themselves.  For example, pure acetic acid has a pH around 2.  If you add base, the acid will be consumed, but the acetic acid will dissociate and release more acid to maintain the pH around 2.  On the other hand lemon juice, which also has a pH = 2, is not going to be resistant to pH changes.  As you add base to lemon juice, the pH will quickly rise as the acid is consumed.  Because of this, pure acetic acid is much more corrosive than lemon juice.  Although I'm not familiar with the chemistry of the human stomach, I imagine it is buffered at a pH of 2, which is why it is so effective at dissolving the food you eat.  Also, recall that the pH scale is logarithmic.  The difference between a pH of 2 and 4 is two orders of magnitude.  Thus, stomach acid at pH = 2 is 100 times more acidic than honey at pH = 4.  Embed Quote

column9: The average pH of honey is around 3.5, according to Wikipedia and various Quora answers. While I understand that a markedly low or high pH is not essential to be corrosive, such as with HF (where the F- ions play a role), How is it that something with a pH close to gastric acid pH isn't? Where's my chemistry wrong? Or is it the biology?
column10: Disclaimer that I am not a biochemist or physiologist, but having been asked by Prarthana Bhat K will add what I can.[In a comment to Prarthana's fine answer, I focused on potential damage to skin. I won't duplicate that here.]Specifically as to the mouth, there are both chemical and mechanical protections. The mechanical protections, beyond tissue structure, relate to various proteins in saliva that begin the alteration and breakdown of ingested substances as well as lubricate and coat the various tissues in the mouth.Prominent in the list of proteins are mucins and amylases. As to chemical protection, one of the functions of saliva is to neutralize acids by way of three main buffering systems: carbonate, phosphate, and proteins.This buffering function is by way of protection of the downstream gastrointestinal tract, and specifically esophagus, as much as it is the mouth. While stratified squamous epithelial cells line both the mouth and the esophaugus, the mouth cells are coated with a protective protein called keratin, in addition to the protective mucous coat .By the way, What happens to stomach cells that are constantly bathed in stomach hydrochloric acid at a pH of 1-2?They are protected by mucous. Unlike the esophagus.Point of fact is that in abnormal situations where the valve function between the upper stomach and lower esophagus is not normal and "acid reflux' happens, the cells can get damaged and change. Scarring and even cancer can result. One other note: even when cells do get damaged the body can deal with it by replacing them. This turnover rate is protective, but in certain situations not sufficient and pathology results.  Embed QuoteVia  Prarthana Bhat K.

column9: The average pH of honey is around 3.5, according to Wikipedia and various Quora answers. While I understand that a markedly low or high pH is not essential to be corrosive, such as with HF (where the F- ions play a role), How is it that something with a pH close to gastric acid pH isn't? Where's my chemistry wrong? Or is it the biology?
column10: I am not a chemistry student.But think about it this way.If pH was the sole factor for deciding degree of corrosion, then lemon juice would burn your tongue because it has a pH as low as 2.2. But. That doesn't happen.So, I'm inferring that pH is not the sole criteria for corrosion.Gastric juice is corrosive because it contains hydrochloric acid, a strong ionic acid. Which dissociates RAPIDLY AND COMPLETELY in solution, producing H+ ions. Honey is made up of ORGANIC ACIDS. Chiefly gluconic acid and malic acid. Which  ionize only partially. This should also holds good for other naturally occurring food substances like tamarind ( PH can be as low as 1.8) ,yogurt ( pH is around 4) Even apples contain malic acid! But that doesn't make them corrosive.I am not a 100% confident about this answer.Let's ask Dr Gluck just to be sure :)  Embed Quote

column9: The average pH of honey is around 3.5, according to Wikipedia and various Quora answers. While I understand that a markedly low or high pH is not essential to be corrosive, such as with HF (where the F- ions play a role), How is it that something with a pH close to gastric acid pH isn't? column10: It all makes as much sense to me as this:Some foods such as lemons test as acidic while in their natural form, yet have an alkalizing effect during digestion. On the other hand, meats are alkaline before digestion, but leave acidic residues in the body.Honey and sugar yield as alkaline in their raw, unprocessed state, yet due to their high concentration of sugar, they can become form acid. column9: Found from this Facebook infographic:https://www.facebook.com/photo.p...
column10: Well yes, you do, but not in such a magnitude as suggested in the image there. There are 2 pieces of information about that image that should immediately suggest this is a less than reliable source. Firstly, it is from Facebook, town of scammers and fraudsters. Secondly, 'According to a research'.With any kind of claim like this, the best thing to do before reposting it is to quickly Google the argument outlined. I just searched for 'benzene poisoning air conditioning' and the first result was from Snopes. [1] This immediately suggests that the claim presented in the image is not entirely true, as Snopes is a site that examines commonly-held myths and urban legends.The article quotes almost exactly the text of the image included in the question context. It lists the date of this as May 2009. The article begins by listing actual research by the American Cancer Society about the dangers of Benzene and its links to cancer. The Snopes article then provides an extract from a scientific study carried out by a South Korean university [2] that seems to refute some of the claims made in the image.A short summary of the study's findings is that it is not the dashboard of the car that emits the highest level of Benzene, but actually the fuel. In addition to this, they found that Benzene levels were higher in older cars, refuting the claim that the 'new car smell' is partly to blame. Finally, they found Benzene levels to be higher during winter, casting doubt on the claim that air conditioning elevates the level. [2] [1] http://www.snopes.com/medical/to...[2] http://www.sciencedirect.com/sci...Edit: Just realised that this is my 200th answer here on Quora. Thought I'd point that out.  Embed Quote

column9: What in its chemical structure makes it so?
column10: Acrylamide is water soluble and accumulates everywhere rather quickly. I used to think that the toxicity was do to its extreme susceptibility to forming free radicals but there apparently aren't many acrylamide adducts.Instead, the proposed mechanism is that it is quickly metabolized into glycidamide which is a highly reactive epoxide that binds to DNA.AcrylamideGlycidamideAs you should recall from your organic chemistry (or see Biochemistry: What makes so many epoxides so carcinogenic?), the last thing you want is an epoxide accumulating in your brain or your liver.http://enhs.umn.edu/current/5103...  Embed Quote

column9: ethanol then doesn't get converted to acetaldehyde. in fact, could someone KO'ed for ADH be resistant to methanol poisoning?Turning off 'aging genes' is interesting too
column10: Not for methanol poisoning.Both methanol and ethanol are in part poisonous because they are amphiphilic and therefor they can enter every part of our body. They can activate some of on our receptors but mostly they enter the lipid membrane around all our cells and makes it less rigid than it should be. This will interfere with normal cell functions and can be poisonous.The Alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH) turns ethanol into acetaldehyde and acetaldehyde is very poisonous and and gives very unpleasant side effect. The faster your ADH works, the less alcohol you need to drink before feeling unpleasant and getting hangover like symptoms. A slower working ADH gives you time to consume more alcohol and also gives you livers acetaldehyde dehydrogenase more time to removed the acetaldehyde and therefore fewer hangover symptoms. (Antabus/Disulfram works by blocking the acetaldehyde dehydrogenase and so the acetaldehyde makes it uncomfortable to drink too much)If the ADH enzyme doesn't work at all, ADH won't be able to break down ethanol to acetaldehyde. Luckily we have another enzyme, CYP2E1 which can do the work, though at a slower rate.If CYP2E1 is also nonfunctional (and you're still alive somehow) the body won't be able to start metabolizing alcohol. Alcohol can be secreted through skin, lungs and be removed by intestinal bacteria, but it would most likely be too slow.Then the alcohol levels would rise so much that the mentioned cell functions would stop working and the body would go into a coma and die.  Embed Quote

column9: I am hoping someone can provide me some details about the differences between organic and inorganic arsenic:1. How is it possible that two obviously different molecular structures are called the same thing in the first place?2. What is the difference in terms of effects on the body?
column10: Inorganic arsenic refers to arsenic atoms that occur in their pure, metallic form, or in compounds where they are bonded to other non-carbon elements, such as in arsenic trichloride AsCl3.Organic arsenic refers to organic (i.e. carbon based) compounds that contain covalently bonded arsenic atoms. One example of this is 4-Hydroxy-3-nitrobenzenearsonic acid:Believe it or not, this compound was marketed by Pfizer under the brand name of Roxarsone for use as a chicken feed supplement in the US. That is, until the FDA cried foul and outlawed it. Now you may wonder, how was feeding this to chickens possible in the first place, if arsenic is such a vicious poison? Well, the toxicity of the arsenic atom stems from how it chemically disrupts the complex sequence of metabolic reactions in the body that ultimately provides energy in the form of ATP. However, when the arsenic atom is already bonded to other functional groups, as in this example compound, it cannot react in the same way. For that reason, most organoarsenic compounds are far from as acutely toxic as the pure metal.[1] Commonly, the toxicity of many organoarsenic compounds actually stems from how the body can detoxify it back to inorganic arsenic, which is what the FDA was worried about. Still, it is a good idea to steer clear of all arsenic compounds in general as they tend to be toxic in one form or another._____________[1] http://www.medterms.com/script/m...  Embed Quote

This would depend on the form in which the Aluminium is presented, as a sheet of metal there is no issue as many standard household items and everyday items which we touch and use are made of Aluminium. However if the Aluminium is in the form of a dust or powder which is of small enough particle size to become airborne it's not so great. In the UK the HSE (Health and Safety Executive) have a document called EH40, which was last updated in 2007 (and is due to be replaced when REACH kicks in), and Aluminium is given a WEL or Workplace Exposure Limit, of 10mg/m3 for inhalable dust and 4 mg/m3 for respirable dust. This means that the concentration of Aluminium dust in the air should never exceed 10mg of dust per m3 of air in the working environment. As such the danger is inhaling the metal dust in the air, and for info inhalable dust is dust with a particle size such that you can inhale it, but it is not small enough to get into your bloodstream. Respirable dust however is somewhat finer/smaller and once inhaled into your lungs can be absorbed into the bloodstream, and as such is far more dangerous.I'm not trying to worry you here, as in most conditions you don't need to worry about it, but if you are working in an environment which exposes you or your colleagues to Aluminium dust or Aluminium fumes (from melting Al or working with molten Al), then you need to look into this further. Normally some sort of extraction system would help, and as a last resort workers can wear face masks with P3 filters that will filter out fine particulates down to about 5microns - Hope that helps.  Embed Quote

It feels like you are “Mad as a Hatter”, perhaps…Johnny Depp's Mad Hatter.HistoryThis is a phrase from Lewis Carroll’s 1865 book, Alice's Adventures in Wonderland [1].  Carroll’s use of the phase very well cemented it in to the future.  This was a direct reference to what was commonly known as “Hatter’s Shakes” or “Hatter’s Twitch”.  Although Carroll likely molded this wildly fictional character on a local furniture dealer and not a Hatter but it served his creative purpose as the term “Mad Hatter” was widely understood in this epoch.  Milliners (Hatters) [2] of fine hats manufactured felt from fur using a process called Carroting [3].  It is this process that caused the “Hatter’s Shake”.   The Carroting process primarily used rabbit pelts soaked in Mercuric Nitrate [4].   As the pelts dried they turned orange, the color of ripened carrots, thus the name of the process.  This process allowed the fur to be separated from the skin and would then be formed into a basic hood and then heat pressed into a hat.   Rather large amounts of Mercuric Nitrate was needed in this process.   Milliners were exposed to the chemical mix performed with no gloves with hands that commonly had cuts and wounds.  They also were exposed to the fumes that were quite dense and tended to hover over the processing tubs.  The Unknown PoisonThe unfortunate bit is that most people, even the very well informed (Doctors and Scientists) did not know the impact of Mercury on the human body although some laws were in acted in the late 1800’s it had little impact on most workers.  Milliners only stopped the process on December 1, 1941 when the United States Public Health Service banned the use of Mercury in the Felt manufacturing industry.  It was too late for the Milliners in Danbury, Connecticut.   Known as “The Hat City”, It became the hat making capital of the world in the mid 1800’s.   Over 56 factories and five million hats a year were produced.  This also produced the term “Danbury Shakes” as a reflection of the same symptoms.  One interesting point, Alchemists very well knew the toxic side of Mercury spanning back to perhaps 3000 BCE and early Egyptian Alchemical knowledge and for the most part handled it in a manner of a potential poison. What Does It Feel Like?Mercury in all of its forms is a rather strong neurotoxin [5] although methylmercury and inorganic Mercury have a more powerful impact to animals. Neurotoxins inhibit neuron control over ion concentrations via the cell membrane or via communication between neurons across the nerve synapse. The impact it may have is based on the quantity, term and situation of the exposure.  Thus how this may feel will be directly translated by the exposure(s) and duration. If a threshold is reached on either level the symptoms may become irreversible. Early StagesIn the very early stages of Mercury poisoning there are usually no obvious symptoms.  Most simple aches, pains and itches would be discounted.  Most would also ignore the “mental fog” and temporary insomnia.  One may note a decline in the resistance to catching colds and flus but the impact to the immune system would not be quite pronounced.These early stages would give way to itching, burning and then perhaps pain in the extremities, known as peripheral neuropathy [6]. Mercury poisoning at this stage is often not easily diagnosed as it can mimic other diseases and temporary aliments.  The symptoms will move on to the more obvious where skin turns to a pronounced pink to red color along with perhaps some swelling and skin shedding called desquamation.  At this stage in our epoch one may think they need to visit a Demonologist. Medium StagesIn medium stages the victim of Mercury poisoning will began to have a shutter or swing to the movement of limbs that may give way to a more pronounced involuntary and continuous shake.  One would note an increase in salvation almost to the point of drooling and perfuse sweating.  The victims immune system would also be compromised and there would be nearly constant colds and flu-like symptoms.  At this point the impact to the brain will become very pronounced and would result in a number of notable markers:IrritabilityShyness or TimidityAnxiety and/or nervousness Exaggerated response to stimulationEmotional instability Loss of self confidenceIndecisionLoss of memoryInability to concentrateLethargyInsomniaDepressionDespondencyWithdrawalSuicidal tendenciesIn this stage one would very well become the very definition of what it feels like to go insane.  There would still be a great deal of normal memory and thought processes but mixed with profound withdrawal from just about all normal activities. This is the stage that many Mad Hatters were identified.  In Carroll’s Alice his Mad Hatter was more an extrovert and perhaps this was a useful literary tool or perhaps in some cases he observed there was more “madness” and less withdrawal.In most cases the withdrawal is so profound that the afflicted person would not seem to want or seek help and may have lost all ties to friends and family. In some cases misdiagnoses can happen and consequently Parkinson's, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS, Lou Gehrig's Disease), dementia, and multiple sclerosis may be attributed to the cause of the symptoms. End StagesIn the end stages of Mercury poisoning a complete breakdown of vital organ functions would begin.  The victim would have slowly lost most memory and the shakes would have become vigorous.  The heart, lungs and liver would begin to fail and death would result at this point.Living As A Mad HatterMedical treatment is indicated at any exposure to Mercury under any and all circumstances but most especially in children.  There are a number of tests and protocols that could impact the progression of the poisoning.  It would be of paramount importance that if it is known that there was exposure to Mercury that this should be shared with the Doctor.If the primary exposure to Mercury has stopped, the impact would remain unless otherwise treated and in some cases reversed. The transition through the early stages where the impact could be assumed to be anything to the early medium stages, one could live what appears to be a normal life if there is no more exposures to Mercury and no Chelation [7] therapy to reduce or eliminate the toxin. It is noted in the literature and newspaper accounts from the 1700s through the early 1920s that victims of what is now known as Mercury poisoning lived just perhaps less then a normal lifespan and in many cases continued on with personal and professional life.  But clearly with the notable side effects mentioned.If you survived a medium stage Mercury poisoning the world would have transitioned over time to a very lonely and dark place.  You will feel like a grade B horror movie where you are the central character and the world would seem to look on in horror.________[1] Alice's Adventures in Wonderland[2] Hatmaking[3] Felt[4] Mercury(II) nitrate[5] Neurotoxin[6] Peripheral neuropathy[7] Chelation  Embed Quote

column9: I recently found out about Dihydrogen Monoxide and I'm worried about my exposure to the chemical. What could overexposure to Dihydrogen Monoxide cause? What foods and substances is Dihydrogen Monoxide present in? Is there a way to measure how much Dihydrogen Monoxide is in my system?
column10: No, it's generally a good thing.It's in all foods and drink, with the possible exception of Eucharist bread and raw pot noodle.Consumption can lead to moisturization, respiration, and cellular replication. However it can also aid digestion leading to defacation.Consumption of up to 70% of your body weight of this chemical is perfectly tolerable. Babies can tolerate up to 90%!However, at such levels, you should avoid electrolysising yourself, as this can lead to explosive wind.You can get a broad measure of your current level by holding a mirror in front of your mouth. If it fogs up, you have between 45% and 70% of you body mass in the form of this chemical. Probably nearer the bottom of the range if you have been drinking alcohol, exercising, or are diabetic or obese.  Embed Quote

column9: 1,3-Butadiene - listed as a carcinogen
column10: As far as I can tell, it really isn't.  The oral LD50 for butadiene is over 5g/kg (rat), which is a hair over that of ethylene glycol (4.7g/kg) and about 40% lower than ethanol (7g/kg).  Compare this to something truly toxic like formaldehyde, which has an acute LD50 oral toxicity of about 0.1g/kg.  Butadiene's a really important molecule for the chemical industry (it's used to make synthetic rubber), but to my knowledge it has never posed any special safety hazards beyond those common to any molecule of its type - e.g., flammability, skin irritation, etc.  I was a little shocked when I read this question, and since the LD50 doesn't tell us everything (for example, the LD50 of methanol is about 5g/kg in rats, but the threshold value for causing blindness is well below that) I went and did some research.Turns out my initial skeptic reaction was correct: butadiene, and aliphatic hydrocarbons in general, aren't very toxic at all.  The primary hazard seems to be irritation and damage to the lungs from accidentally aspirating drops of the liquid and irritation of the digestive system, and unless there is a pre-existing injury to the digestive or respiratory system the hydrocarbon itself is blocked from entering the bloodstream.  For any liquid hydrocarbon, systemic toxicity is really only present for halogenated hydrocarbons and aromatics.  Butadiene's in the clear.Honestly, in retrospect it makes sense that even olefinic non-aromatic hydrocarbons should be nontoxic: medical mineral oil, composed of hydrocarbons often distilled directly from petroleum, is taken directly with no additives as a laxative. Source: Children's Hospital of Philadelphia: (Poison Control Center) Hydrocarbon Ingestion  Embed Quote
Are you planning a murder?  Embed QuoteAnswered in twenty-five minutes.

Ethanol.The LD50, or concentration that kills half the population, of your friendly inebriating drug is about 10.6 grams per kilogram of body weight (1). I weigh about 65 kilos, so to reach the amount of EtOH that would probably kill me, I'd need to consume a little less than 700 grams of alcohol to kill me. Given the density of ethanol at room temperature and sea level (0.786 g/ml), that's about 540 ml of ethanol. Drinking PBR at about 5% alcohol by volume (2), I would need to drink almost 3.5 gallons to kill myself. Not going to happen, which is why it's so much safer to shotgun beer than do shots. Stay safe, kids.But everything changes if instead of drinking PBR, I inhale alcohol. Such a mistake can be made by well-meaning people trying to, say, make jello shots. To make jello shots, one should mix alcohol and water and chill the mixture. When adding hot liquid to dissolve the jello mix, only boiling water should be used, and the alcohol added later (3).This seemingly convoluted way of producing jello shots, instead of mixing alcohol and water and heating the mixture, is done just so for the reason that the crazy party you wish to throw will be much less cool if you die before it starts. While we could do some decent estimation for a vapor-liquid equilibrium of an ethanol-water system while varying temperature and mole fractions using Raolt's Law or be more specific by examining the azeotrope of ethanol and water, I'm writing this on an iPad at the moment. An engineering student doing calculations without Excel is like writing with a broken pencil: it's pointless (heh, heh).Suffice it to say that, since ethanol is more volatile than water, if we have a closed system (like a pot on the stove with a lid on it) and heat it, the resulting vapor will have a lot more ethanol in it than water. If one inhales that vapor, as one might do when pulling the lid off the pot and breathing deeply, one breath of 70+% ethanol vapor is quite enough to exceed the CDC's IDLH limit (Immediately Dangerous to Life or Health), which is a measly 15,000 ppm, or the lethal inhaled dose, which is somewhere above 20,000 ppm for long exposures, or above 2% (4).However, while inhaling a very concentrated ethanol vapor could certainly kill someone, the total amount of ethanol required wouldn't be all that high, and certainly not much more than a determined soul at an end-of-the-semester party could consume. And since the liver could easily metabolize the relatively small amount of ethanol inhaled over a couple hours, vaporized ethanol could be your toxin of choice!But man, what an awful waste of a good vodka.(1) http://m.wolframalpha.com/input/...(2) PBR can being drunk by friend with whom I am facebook chatting(3) http://m.wikihow.com/Make-Jello-...(4) http://www.cdc.gov/niosh/idlh/64...  Embed Quote

I own an art school for kids:There are all sorts of inks available---but here's the general breakdown:Standard ballpoint ink is not toxic. Not if you drink it, not if you draw on your body...Inks sold in stores have to undergo testing and certification. If it's labeled non toxic, it's exactly that. (Parents often ask me this when their child has eaten a Crayola marker, etc.) All children's art supplies MUST undergo strict tests for lead, hazardous materials, etc. The US government is very rigid about children's products (regulated by the CPSIA) and will ask companies to provide samples frequently and at random to ensure manufacturing guidelines have been followed consistently. In addition, certain pigments are certified for food, others for cosmetics, etc---so these things are pretty well documented as far as toxicity. For example, inks and pigments for eye make up are not necessarily allowed to be used in lipstick or markers.  If it's a homemade ink (like from walnuts) you might have some problems if it isn't preserved well (bacteria and mold---or alcohol poisoning if there's an alcohol base) or there is a nut allergy in the house. Inks meant to be permanent usually have chemicals in them that are toxic (which is why they aren't for kids) and their labels will not have the non-toxic markings on them. The toxicity in these usually comes from the solvents or chemicals used to disperse the ink pigments and to retain an ink's fluidity. Inks for clothing are usually toxic until they are set--at which point (in particular in children's clothing) the dried inks are supposed to be tested for toxic content before the item is sold. So in their liquid form they might be toxic but once they are cured, their chemical composition changes and are no longer toxic. Either way, none of it is meant to be consumed in large amounts. Just like you really aren't encouraged to eat the logo off your t-shirt...One last thing--The pigments old artists used to use (like Van Gogh) often WERE toxic---as were the inks. These, of course, were proprietary blends with formulations known only to the artist and a few of his/her assistants. These types of inks and pigments were usually made even more toxic by the addition of solvents and chemicals. These are generally not the kinds of inks you will find at a store---at least, I have never encountered them. Although, I wouldn't recommend licking an old manuscript, etc. Often these inks contained salts and metals (like lead). Old children's books (leaded printing ink was banned in '78) also often contain this metal in debatable quantities.  Embed Quote

column9: And if so, how, by who, and with cooperation from whom?
column10: It's way too late to speculate about that and quite frankly I'm disappointed in Al Jazeera for even airing something that would cause such a stirrup.Digging up the poor man's remains will probably not be of any help.What doesn't historically fit about poisoning Arafat at the point:If the was poisoned by polonium, it would have decayed so much (half-life of Po-210 is around 180 days) that I find it very strange that any significant levels could have been detected postmortem in traces of his bodily fluids in his clothes 6 years later. Anonymous made me realize the Swiss could have really measured a significant abnormality, yet to repeat the words of Darcy Christen, spokesman for Lausanne’s Institute of Radiation Physics:Clinical symptoms described in Arafat's medical reports were not consistent with polonium-210 and that conclusions could not be drawn as to whether the Palestinian leader was poisoned or not.He was cooperative to the peace process at that point and was actually an asset to it, I believe this was seen as such by all sides: The father of the hope for a nation for the Palestinians, a way less radical and more open to debate politician on the US/Israeli side (cf. Camp David etc.), making the scenario less credible.He was already in the late stages of Parkinson's Disease and his days as an active politician were counted. The move would make no sense.My own medical take on the Polonium: it would have made Arafat die a slow, painful death, like Alexander Litvinenko. It would have not killed him invisibly, nor as quickly as whatever did in reality. Even at megadoses, radiation poisoning is something the expert doctors that treated him in Paris must have had recognized.In the end-stages of Polonium poisoning he would look like Litvinenko in his last days:I doubt that this would have go unnoticed and kept quiet for 8 years.  Embed Quote

column9: And if so, how, by who, and with cooperation from whom?
column10: We'll never know for sure because no autopsy was performed immediately after his death, and the chain of custody of the samples taken from his since decayed body is ambiguous. However, based on the multiple tests, the answer is: almost certainly not.Five reports are available: Arafat died in a French hospital, and at the time they concluded he died of natural causes. He was rather sick at the time, as to be expected given his advanced age. An autopsy was not performed at the request of his widow, Suha Arafat.Two weeks afterwards, his nephew and UN Observer Nasser al-Kidwa was unable to find cause of death based on a review of the medical records, but did state a tox screen performed had no traces of any known poison. The medical records are owned by the Palestinians, who have refused to publish them.Eight years after his death (way too long for a decent autopsy or radiation test), Arafat's widow ordered his body exhumed and samples sent to three independent labs around the world.  The results:The Swiss lab said they found traces of polonium, but did not go so far as to say he was poisoned, saying the study was "inconclusive." The Russian lab leaked that they found no traces of polonium at all and that he could not have been poisoned, though they quickly tried to cover up that leak.Most recently, the French lab declared they were unable to find any polonium and formally concluded the cause of death was natural causes.Let's convert those inconclusives to conclusives. We have 4/5 reports stating there was no evidence of poisoning and no traces of polonium on the body. Furthermore, the one study that did find polonium could not determine whether Arafat was poisoned or whether or not the samples were deliberately tainted. Add to that Suha Arafat's mysterious motives: why wait so long to run studies? Why did she prevent the autopsy in the first place? You won't see this in Western media, but among Palestinians Suha's actions are seen as unusual and she is a controversial figure. In other words though we will never know for sure, the evidence suggests he died of natural causes.To answer your subquestions, Arafat had a lot of enemies… mostly internal. The foreign tests were funded by al Jazeera, who were trying to prove  Israel poisoned Arafat. However, according to the more liberal al Arabiya, most Palestinians close to Arafat agree  that, if he was murdered, it was by political rivals. Suha herself suspects he was killed by other Palestinians: if not Hamas then by others in his own party trying to usurp his power (Hence why so many in the PLO leadership are wary of her). To date Suha has never mentioned Israel or cast any suspicion on them for the assassination; rather, she feels it was an inside job. Since the tests could never show who was responsible anyway, most actual Palestinians believe they are a waste of time at best and a desecration of his body at worst. Sources:Yasser Arafat's widow challenges French finding of 'natural cause' deathPage on Alarabiya: Arafat exhumation hopes quell poison quandaryPage on Alarabiya: Russia denies issuing conclusions over Yasser Arafat's Death  Embed Quote

column9: And if so, how, by who, and with cooperation from whom?
column10: What we know:Polonium 210 has a half life of 138 days.Scientists at the Institut de Radiophysique in Lausanne, Switzerland said:Even in case of a poisoning similar to the Litvinenko case, only traces of the order of a few [millibecquerels] were expected to be found in year 2012His toothbrushes registered 54mBq, and a urine stain on his underwear registered 180mBq, even in 2012. A control from another man's underwear registered 6.7mBq.Most of the Polonium, 60%-80% came from unnatural sources.The amount of Polonium is simply too high (it is very, VERY high) to conclude anything other than he was poisoned by Polonium 210. Simply by Occam's Razor, we would have to conclude it was the most likely cause of his death at this point. This may change as his body is tested.The main assumption that I'm making, of course, is that the materials tested had not been contaminated (deliberately or otherwise) after his death. This will be confirmed by testing his body.As for who, that is speculation. I would need to be convinced that Israel was behind it, but it's a pretty high-tech mode of assassination, so a suspicious glance must be thrown their way.With more time, and a review of the science, I've put some more coherent thoughts together:http://www.avrammeitner.com/2012...  Embed Quote

Lots of foods contain acrylamide. Here are a few especially common examples:Potatoes: chips, French fries and other roasted or fried potato foodsGrains: bread crust, toast, crisp bread, roasted breakfast cereals and various processed snacksCoffee; roasted coffee beans and ground coffee powder. Surprisingly, coffee substitutes based on chicory actually contains 2-3 times MORE acrylamide than real coffee [1]The amount of acrylamide in foods can vary[11]Here is some data on the amount of acrylamide contained:Acrylamide in Foods: Micrograms per ServingWater, 8 oz., EPA limit 0.12Boiled Potatoes, 4 oz.<3Old El Paso Taco Shells, 3, 1.1oz.1Ore Ida French Fries (uncooked), 3 oz.5Ore Ida French Fries (baked), 3 oz.28Honey Nut Cheerios, 1 oz.6Cheerios, 1 oz.7Tostitos Tortilla Chips, 1 oz.5Fritos Corn Chips, 1 oz.11Pringles Potato Crisps, 1 oz.25Wendy’s French Fries, Biggie, 5.6 oz.39KFC Potato Wedges, Jumbo, 6.2 oz.52Burger King French Fries, large, 5.7 oz.59McDonald’s French Fries, large, 6.2 oz.82[2]The amount of acrylamide in a large order of fast-food French fries is at least 300 times more than what the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency allows in a glass of water. Acrylamide is sometimes used in water-treatment facilities.[2]Grilling vegetables can produce acrylamide too:Food	 Acrylamide level in parts per billion (ppb)	Asparagine level in milligrams per gramAsparagus**	 ND* or <10 (frozen, canned, grilled)	41-820 (raw)Carrots	61 (grilled)	3.2 (raw and dehydrated)Onions	70 (grilled)	3-5 (raw)Potatoes	114 (roasted)	6.6-16.0 (raw)Broccoli	235 (canned)	179-393 (raw)Plums and Prunes	31-188	16-116 (raw)Coffee beans	179-351 (roasted)	0.33-0.97 (raw and dried)Cocoa beans/Chocolate	24-909	9-31 (both raw powder and roasted beans)Wheat/breads	27-364	20-215 (fresh wheat) 2-5 (fermented and non-fermed)[3]Monsanto uses it in pesticides under the brand name Krilium, so it could make its way into non-organic food that relied on those pesticides.[6]In terms of its prevalence, in the U.S.:The top 20 foods by average acrylamide intake by the U.S. population are as follows:French Fries (made in restaurants)French Fries (oven baked)Potato ChipsBreakfast CerealsCookiesBrewed Coffee...
