column9: Are dogs similarly influenced by the inhalation of nicotine as humans?
column10: Dogs are affected by the inhalation of nicotine (and other smoking related substances) MORE then humans. Tobacco smoke is a mixture of gases and particles. It contains more than 7,000 chemical compounds. More than 250 of these chemicals are known to be harmful, and at least 69 are known to cause cancer.In toxicology we have something called DOSE-EFFECT RELATIONSHIP. The effects of exposure to poisons vary with the amount of exposure, which is another way of saying "the dose." Usually when we think of dose, we think in terms of taking one vitamin capsule a day or two spoons of syrup every four hours, or something like that. If you take to your hand any medicine you will see there are different doses for kids and adults. Why? Because kids are lighter and the dose is related to the mass of organism. the bigger mass of organism the bigger dose it needs to get some therapeutic effect.In the case of inhalative exposure dose is the resultant of: -weight of organism-concentrations of substances in the air,-time of exposure,-and frequency of exposure.If we have dog (body mass 35kg) and man (body mass 70kg) locked in the room in the same time with the same frequency of exposure, where somebody is smoking or has been smoking recently, the dog will be more affected by the smoke then the man, becouse of smaller body weight. Lets say they both absorbe 70mg of toxins. The dog will absorb 2mg per kilo of his body mass (70mg/35kg) and the man 1mg per kilo.Secondhand smoke (SHS) is classified as a “known human carcinogen” (cancer-causing agent) by the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), the US National Toxicology Program, and the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC – a branch of the World Health Organization). So yes, the dogs with owners who smoke are more likely to suffer from cancer than other dogs, becouse they are exposed for cancerogenic secondhand smoke.In dogs, second-hand smoke has been found to be greatly associated with nasal sinus cancer and also linked with lung cancer. A study conducted at the State of Colorado reveals that there is a higher incidence of nasal cavity tumors in dogs that were exposed to ETS as compared to dogs that live in households with non-smoking members. This conclusion was particularly found amongst breeds with long noses such as Collies. There were no significant nasal tumors amongst dogs with short to medium noses exposed to second-hand smoke.Experts indicate that long-nosed breeds are more at risk because their nasal passages consist of greater surface area on which the carcinogens can be deposited before it reaches the lungs. Also, they pointed out that because their nasal passages have more cells, there is a greater chance that some of these cells get mutated by carcinogens into cancer cells.The same study mentioned that despite the fact that dogs with short to medium noses exposed to ETS do not have a great nasal tumor risk as compared to those unexposed, they, nonetheless, have a slightly greater incidence of lung cancer. This is likely because their shorter nasal passages tend to be less effective at filtering the said carcinogens out of breathed-in air before it enters the lungs. Unlike human beings who can develop bladder cancer as a result of second-hand smoke exposure, dogs generally do not run a higher risk of bladder cancer when exposed to these harmful elements.As a pet owners’ bond with their four-legged companions become stronger, they share more of their lives, their leisure time and their living space with their pets, thereby exposing them to the same environmental hazards that they do. Many human habits, including smoking, can affect animals just as they can affect the other members of the household. By designating a separate room in the house or smoking only outside, you can minimize exposure for your pooch as well as the other non-smoking members of the family.Literature:Page on dogingtonpost.comSmoking And Your DogSecondhand Smoke  Embed Quote

Short summary: Adderall/Dexedrine can be neurotoxic in the long run (by damaging dopamine neurons) while Ritalin has no neurotoxicity potential. Surprisingly, when Ritalin *and* Adderall are mixed together, Ritalin can actually help counteract Adderall's neurotoxicity potential. Tolerance can happen with either, but tolerance is not neurotoxicity as it can be reversed by taking breaks.Long answer:It depends on many factors(I will use the word dexedrine interchangeably with Adderall, since they're mostly similar - Adderall is 75% d-amphetamine and 25% l-amphetamine, and Dexedrine is 100% d-amphetamine)As someone with ADD who has been concerned about their long term effects, I have done a huge amount of research into this. I'll update this post with time.First of all, regarding the cardiovascular risks: http://www.sciencedaily.com/rele... shows that there is no increase in severe cardiovascular events for children with no pre-existing heart abnormalities. This could be different for older adults who may be more vulnerable to getting heart attacks, however. Most young people shouldn't worry about the cardiovascular effects.Taking either of them could result in tolerance (see http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S0006-... - discussed in [1]). This means that you may need to get higher doses over time in order to achieve the same effect. However, numerous people with ADD are able to achieve a stable dose of either drug over time. In any case, tolerance is reversible, and you can prevent it by taking breaks once in a while.[1] Link shows that both amphetamine and methylphenidate produce deficits in striatal dopamine markers after treatment, but that the markers recovered in methylphenidate-treated mice but not amphetamine-treated ones (indicating something reversible in methylphenidate but possibly not amphetamine). Although it didn't identify the mechanism and a 2-week waiting period may not be enough to extrapolate permanent effectshttp://neurosciencenews.com/adhd... is a possible mechanism of tolerance (apparently, the brain compensates by increasing the number of DAT transporters)Now to discuss the possible effects beyond toleranceThere is a real difference between the two, however. Adderall is a dopamine release agent, whereas Ritalin is a dopamine reuptake inhibitor. Both of them increase dopamine signalling by increasing the amount of dopamine in the synapse (so more dopamine ends up binding to the dopamine receptors in the postsynaptic neuron). The key difference is their action on the dopamine transporter, which generally moves a lot of the dopamine in the synapse back into the presynaptic neuron - which reduces the amount of dopamine in the synapse, and dopamine signalling. Ritalin increases dopamine signalling by effectively blocking the dopamine transporter. Meanwhile, Adderall does it by reversing the action of the dopamine transporter, which effectively forces even more dopamine into the synapse (where it can increase dopamine signalling even further). The mechanism of amphetamine (the chemical name for Adderall) is shown belowThere is another difference between the two: and that difference is related to the activity of the VMAT-2 transporter. This transporter effectively transports dopamine from the cellular cytosol into synaptic vesicles (pictured below), which effectively sequesters up the dopamine and prevents it from auto-oxidation.The difference is this:  Amphetamine effectively inhibits the activity of the VMAT-2 transporter, so it packages up less dopamine. Methylphenidate (the chemical name for Ritalin), on the other hand, enhances the activity of the transporter. And this difference is actually what makes amphetamine neurotoxic and methylphenidate comparatively benign. The thing is, dopamine is a very reactive molecule when it isn't packaged by VMAT-2, and when it autooxidizes in the presy... (more)Loading... Short summary: Adderall/Dexedrine can be neurotoxic in the long run (by damaging dopamine neurons) while Ritalin has no neurotoxicity potential. Surprisingly, when Ritalin *and* Adderall are mixed together, Ritalin can actually help counteract Adderall's neurotoxicity potential. Tolerance can happen with either, but tolerance is not neurotoxicity as it can be reversed by taking breaks.Long answer:It depends on many factors(I will use the word dexedrine interchangeably with Adderall, since they're mostly similar - Adderall is 75% d-amphetamine and 25% l-amphetamine, and Dexedrine is 100% d-amphetamine)As someone with ADD who has been concerned about their long term effects, I have done a huge amount of research into this. I'll update this post with time.First of all, regarding the cardiovascular risks: http://www.sciencedaily.com/rele... shows that there is no increase in severe cardiovascular events for children with no pre-existing heart abnormalities. This could be different for older adults who may be more vulnerable to getting heart attacks, however. Most young people shouldn't worry about the cardiovascular effects.Taking either of them could result in tolerance (see http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S0006-... - discussed in [1]). This means that you may need to get higher doses over time in order to achieve the same effect. However, numerous people with ADD are able to achieve a stable dose of either drug over time. In any case, tolerance is reversible, and you can prevent it by taking breaks once in a while.[1] Link shows that both amphetamine and methylphenidate produce deficits in striatal dopamine markers after treatment, but that the markers recovered in methylphenidate-treated mice but not amphetamine-treated ones (indicating something reversible in methylphenidate but possibly not amphetamine). Although it didn't identify the mechanism and a 2-week waiting period may not be enough to extrapolate permanent effectshttp://neurosciencenews.com/adhd... is a possible mechanism of tolerance (apparently, the brain compensates by increasing the number of DAT transporters)Now to discuss the possible effects beyond toleranceThere is a real difference between the two, however. Adderall is a dopamine release agent, whereas Ritalin is a dopamine reuptake inhibitor. Both of them increase dopamine signalling by increasing the amount of dopamine in the synapse (so more dopamine ends up binding to the dopamine receptors in the postsynaptic neuron). The key difference is their action on the dopamine transporter, which generally moves a lot of the dopamine in the synapse back into the presynaptic neuron - which reduces the amount of dopamine in the synapse, and dopamine signalling. Ritalin increases dopamine signalling by effectively blocking the dopamine transporter. Meanwhile, Adderall does it by reversing the action of the dopamine transporter, which effectively forces even more dopamine into the synapse (where it can increase dopamine signalling even further). The mechanism of amphetamine (the chemical name for Adderall) is shown belowThere is another difference between the two: and that difference is related to the activity of the VMAT-2 transporter. This transporter effectively transports dopamine from the cellular cytosol into synaptic vesicles (pictured below), which effectively sequesters up the dopamine and prevents it from auto-oxidation.The difference is this:  Amphetamine effectively inhibits the activity of the VMAT-2 transporter, so it packages up less dopamine. Methylphenidate (the chemical name for Ritalin), on the other hand, enhances the activity of the transporter. And this difference is actually what makes amphetamine neurotoxic and methylphenidate comparatively benign. The thing is, dopamine is a very reactive molecule when it isn't packaged by VMAT-2, and when it autooxidizes in the presynaptic cytosol, it can actually damage the presynaptic terminal. Amphetamine accelerates this, and causes presynaptic terminal damage. Meanwhile, methylphenidate prevents it from happening. Surprisingly enough, this produces interesting results, which led to this paper: http://jpet.aspetjournals.org/co.... Basically, that paper shows that methylphenidate actually attenuated the deficits associated with damage induced by methamphetamine (methamphetamine does all the damage of amphetamine , but adds A LOT to that damage). So surprisingly enough, methylphenidate actually can attenuate the neurotoxicity associated with amphetamine, if taken along with it. Keep in mind, though, that methylphenidate has a shorter half-life than amphetamine.Some of dopamine's neurotoxicity is actually caused by monoamine oxidase A (MAO) in the presynaptic terminal. When MAO catalyzes the degradation of dopamine, hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is produced as a result, and this H2O2 can go on to damage the presynaptic terminal. Methylphenidate effectively reduces the amount of MAO degradation of dopamine in the presynaptic terminal by blocking dopamine reuptake - this reduces the amount of H2O2 released. Has amphetamine's neurotoxicity (relative to methylphenidate) been experimentally demonstrated? Here's one of the papers (http://jpet.aspetjournals.org/co...As the use of amphetamine in the treatment of ADHD has increased, a large body of preclinical data has accrued indicating that amphetamine has the potential to damage brain dopamine-containing neurons in experimental animals. In particular, animals treated with amphetamine develop lasting reductions in striatal dopamine, its major metabolite dihydroxyphenylacetic acid (DOPAC), its rate-limiting enzyme tyrosine hydroxylase, its membrane transporter (DAT), and its vesicular transporter (VMAT2) (Gibb et al., 1994; McCann and Ricaurte, 2004). Anatomic studies indicate that lasting dopaminergic deficits after amphetamine are due to damage of dopaminergic nerve endings in the striatum, with sparing of dopaminergic nerve cell bodies in the substantia nigra.In particular, the results of the present study indicate that an oral regimen of amphetamine, modeled after dosing regimens used in patients with ADHD, engenders plasma amphetamine concentrations that result in toxicity to brain dopaminergic axon terminals in baboons and squirrel monkeys. These results may have implications for the pathophysiology and treatment of ADHD and raise the question of whether or not plasma monitoring might be indicated in ADHD patients receiving higher, chronic doses of amphetamine.Anyways, here's another very good thread discussing this theme:http://www.longecity.org/forum/t...And a very comprehensive lit review article (discusses what I said here + more): http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/...That all being said, amphetamine's effects are not universally bad. It can increase neurogenesis, perhaps because many individuals with ADD are so distracted that their distraction effectively inhibits neural pathways from forming. Amphetamine/methylphenidate can help promote the formation of these neural pathways by reducing this noise. See below:http://jad.sagepub.com/content/1...In early studies, high doses of amphetamine, comparable to amounts used by addicts, were shown to damage dopaminergic pathways. More recent studies, using therapeutic regimens, appear contradictory. One paradigm shows significant decreases in striatal dopamine and transporter density after oral administration of “therapeutic” doses in primates. Another shows morphological evidence of “trophic” dendritic growth in the brains of adult and juvenile rats given systemic injections mimicking “therapeutic” treatment. Imaging studies of ADHD-diagnosed individuals show an increase in striatal dopamine transporter availability that may be reduced by methylphenidate treatmentAnd from the mentioned lit review (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/...In contrast to concerns about potential adverse effects of amphetamine on the brain during aging, it is remarkable that the reduction of the heightened risk for substance abuse that is otherwise associated with ADHD by the initiation of stimulant treatment during childhood appears to be accompanied by a congruent reduction in structural brain pathology. Unmedicated children with ADHD had smaller brain white matter volume than medicated children with ADHD (−8.9%, P<.001) or children without ADHD (−10.7%, P<.001), suggesting that early stimulant treatment may normalize brain white matter volume in ADHD 182.The mentioned lit review also says that amphetamine appears to be less neurotoxic in younger primates, as compared to older primates. With that being said, there is one study that says that high doses of amphetamine in adolescence can impair adult working memory: http://www.sciencedaily.com/rele.... With that said, the study was done in rats that didn't even have ADD, so it may not be that applicable. But it is still something that may merit consideration.==Recent update (press release article after my original post): In fact, one end result of dopamine neurotoxicity is Parkinson's - the risk of which is increased among methamphetamine users - see http://www.sciencedaily.com/rele.... However, meth users destroy *far* more dopamine neurons than any person on Adderall could ever do (meth is far more neurotoxic than amphetamine, and the doses are usually far higher), so I don't think Adderall users need to fear a significantly higher risk of Parkinson's.One study suggests a possible effect at ADD-related doses too (not too rigorous of a study, but it is suggestive):http://www.sciencedaily.com/rele...The study involved 66,348 people in northern California who had participated in the Multiphasic Health Checkup Cohort Exam between 1964 and 1973 and were evaluated again in 1995. The average age of the participants at the start of the study was 36 years old. Of the participants, 1,154 people had been diagnosed with Parkinson's disease by the end of the study.Exposure to amphetamines was determined by two questions: one on the use of drugs for weight loss and a second question on whether people often used Benzedrine or Dexedrine. Amphetamines were among the drugs commonly used for weight loss when this information was collected.According to the study, those people who reported using Benzedrine or Dexedrine were nearly 60 percent more likely to develop Parkinson's than those people who didn't take the drugs. There was no increased risk found for those people who used drugs for weight loss.  Embed Quote

Completely anecdotal, but...The effects of amphetamine abuse are well known and quite harmful. However, despite being quite similar in function and structure, Adderall and Ritalin can indeed be taken without destroying your life. Some of the subjective effects that are possibly of concern are effects on your personality and sense of self. It is hard to explain, but you can end up with a feeling that you are sort of just "observing" yourself live your life, you are not actually experiencing it. You can find yourself being extremely productive and doing everything right, but somehow it feels like someone else did it, you were just along for the ride. It can be a good idea to take a break from the drugs from time to time to get your bearings and make sure you are in touch with yourself.   Embed Quote

I've been taking 30mg of adderall xr + 30mg of adderall ir (60mg total) daily for over 5 years now. I definitely notice feeling very tired when I don't take it, and my husband says that I'm irritable when I don't take it, too.I don't think that I'm dependent upon it physically, but I think mentally I am for sure! I didn't take it for a couple of weeks last year because I had moved and was switching doctors and insurance, and I was very unhappy to say the least. I slept for almost 2 whole days.  Embed Quote

Classified  as a Schedule II Narcotic by the federal Controlled Substances Act, Adderall is  actually minutely habit-forming; instead very likely to be abused. Prolonged high doses of amphetamines followed by an abrupt cessation can  result in extreme fatigue and mental depression. Chronic abuse of  amphetamines can result in the manifestation of amphetamine psychosis. Luckily, the amount of Adderall  prescribed for the treatment of ADHD is low enough to avoid severe  health risks. Taken under medical supervision, these effects can be  avoided completely.  Embed Quote

I have tried Ritalin and Concerta. After talking with other ADHD people, their effects and side effects are a bit of a crap shoot; roughly half of those I spoke with had minimal-to-no side effects. For me, they were only marginally effective and the Ritalin caused a long-term neural side effect that comes and goes despite ceasing the drug many months ago. Overall, if they help but have side effects, you have to carefully weigh the potential long-term negatives and closely monitor your symptoms. Most all are cataloged in the drug interaction and warning sheets given with the drugs; it is advisable to also research them on the web. There are two alternatives that I am aware of that are non-amphetamine medications; Intuniv and Strattera. Intuniv was marginally helpful to me and it was obvious that a dose capable of being sufficiently efficacious to help me was going to be more than I could handle due to side effects. Strattera was a wonder drug for me, but my prostate enlarged drastically, and I consider that a very cruel outcome.Any of the meds that can cause brain function changes significant enough to quell ADHD symptoms (depending on the severity of your symptoms) are indeed profound medications and need to be carefully monitored. The long-term use of any amphetamine-based product has shown to be somewhat-to-very deleterious over the life of the user. As someone once said, "You might see old junkies, but you never see an old speed freak." Beyond that, the psychoactve and behvioral changes these drugs bring on are more insidious than the physical ones and, in some cases, can become permanent — a small percentage, granted, but who knows who it will be? As with anything in life, those changes that you can effect without introducing foreign substances into your body have the best chance of making real changes vs. the temporary effects afforded by a drug. Learning to meditate (which is a huge accomplishment for most with ADD/ADHD) is major, as are learning organizational methods, dietary changes, exercise and other things. Yes, a pill is easier, but only in one sense in that the effects are temporary and the side effects can be permanent. ADHD is a bitch, pure and simple, otherwise it wouldn't be listed as a covered condition in the Americans with Disabilities Act. Still, as with any disability, there are myriad coping and conditioning methods that should be attempted in earnest, and pills should be the last resort.Thanks to Alex Chen for his thorough article. Excellent work.  Embed Quote

column9: This is a companion question to What common harmless foods are poisonous in large quantities? Answers to this question should not include foodstuffs that are lethal.
column10: The Cinnamon challenge is a challenge to eat a heaping tablespoon of cinnamon almost no one can do it. You will cough gag and burn your mouth and throat first. You could choke and inhale the cinnamon and asphyxiate yourself.Doing the same thing with Nutmeg will likely kill you due to natural toxins in Nutmeg in small quantities.  Eating just 0.2 ounces of it can leave you convulsing and eating 0.3 ounces will lead to hallucinations. Feeling brave? Or maybe you have a death wish? Eating a whole one will leave you in a state of “nutmeg psychosis” and with the sense of an impeding doom.Too much salt mixed in anything will cause instant vomiting.Each bitter (unheated) almond contains 4-9 mg of hydrogen cyanide. If not heated properly in cooking then the danger still looms. The severity of their risk is enough for the USA to limit the sale of their raw variety. Unroasted (bitter) almonds mixed in anything unheated can kill you.Tomatoes Despite the extreme popularity of tomatoes and many countries, it is true that they are poisonous. Though the fruit itself doesn’t contain poison, the stem as well as the leaves contain a chemical known as glycoalkaloid. Higher levels are said to be found in wild tomatoes, but those grown domestically still contain glycoalkaloid. This chemical is known to cause upset stomachs and nervousness. This chemical is so powerful that it is actually used as a way to control pests.Cherries are definitely one of the most versatile fruits. You can eat them raw, cook them, bake them, and get them tart or sweet. Cherries can even be used in certain types of liquor. Despite their overall red goodness, cherries are toxic. If you’ve ever eaten a cherry and without thought chewed on the pip or left it in your mouth, you more than likely introduced hydrogen cyanide into your body. If a cherry pip is chewed, crushed, or somehow damaged, it automatically produces hydrogen cyanide. Symptoms of mild poisoning include headache, dizziness, confusion, anxiety, and vomiting. Larger doses can lead to difficulty breathing, increased blood pressure and heart rate, and kidney failure. Reactions can include coma, convulsions, and death from respiratory arrest.Potatoes. Potatoes contain glycoalkaloids (solanine and chaconine), toxic compounds which are more prevalent in the wild potato varieties. Cooking at high temperatures mostly removes the toxin, although headaches, diarrhea, and cramps—and in severe cases, coma and death—can occur in rare cases. Ever wonder why we’re told to keep potatoes away from light? It’s to prevent higher concentrations of solanine. So don’t eat potatoes after they have turned green.Apricot Stones (Seeds). Actually, many fruits of the rose family contain cyanogenetic glycosides, which upon ingestion release hydrogen cyanide gas. These include seeds from cherries, apples, plums, almonds, and peaches. Although it would take a mega-dose to do you in, keep this in mind the next time you go on an apricot seed binge. There have been reported deaths in Turkey, a large apricot grower, for this very reason.Chocolate. Chocolate contains the alkaloid theobromine, which in unusually high doses can be toxic to humans. However, it would take an unholy amount of chocolate to achieve this. But other species react much worse: dogs, parrots, horses, and cats can be killed by ingesting chocolateTapioca. Tapioca, if not processed properly, can be toxic. It contains a natural source of cyanide, whose precursor, linamarin, is rendered harmless if properly dried, soaked, and baked.The Ackee is the national fruit of Jamaica and features in its cuisine. When picked before it is fully ripe, the fruit contains a chemical that limits the body’s ability to release the backup supply of glucose that is stored in the liver. That supply is essential because once the body uses up the sugar immediately available in the bloodstream, an event that usually occurs several hours after eating, it depends on this glucose to keep blood sugar levels normal until the next meal. Without it, blood sugar plunges dangerously. Enough people have died from eating unripened ackee to make it illegal to bring the raw fruit into the U.S although that restriction doesn’t apply to canned and properly processed ackee.Hot Dogs They're much more than a tailgating staple. In a new paper, the American Academy of Pediatrics says hot dogs are also a choking hazard to children and should come with a warning label. About 17% of food-related asphyxiations in those younger than 10 are caused by hot dogs, according to a 41-state study cited in the paper. The Academy even recommended that hot dogs be redesigned to make it less likely that they will get lodged in the throats of the young.Water! Water intoxication, also known as water poisoning, is a potentially fatal disturbance in brain functions that results when the normal balance of electrolytes in the body is pushed outside of safe limits (e.g., hyponatremia) by overhydration, i.e., over-consumption of water.  ^ At the onset of this condition, fluid outside the cells has an excessively low amount of solutes (such assodium (hyponatremia) and other electrolytes) in comparison to that inside the cells causing the fluid to shift through (via osmosis) into the cells to balance its concentration. This causes the cells to swell. In the brain, this swelling increases intracranial pressure (ICP). It is this increase in pressure which leads to the first observable symptoms of water intoxication: headache, personality changes, changes in behavior, confusion, irritability, and drowsiness. These are sometimes followed by difficulty breathing during exertion, muscle weakness, twitching, or cramping, nausea, vomiting, thirst, and a dulled ability to perceive and interpret sensory information. As the condition persists papillary and vital signs may result including bradycardia and widened pulse pressure. The cells in the brain may swell to the point where blood flow is interrupted resulting in cerebral edema. Swollen brain cells may also apply pressure to the brain stem causing central nervous system dysfunction. Both cerebral edema and interference with the central nervous system are dangerous and could result in seizures, brain damage, coma or death. On January 12, 2007, Jennifer Strange, a 28-year-old woman and a mother of 3, from Rancho Cordova, California, was found dead in her home by her mother, hours after trying to win one of Nintendo's Wiigame consoles. KDND 107.9 "The End" radio station's "Hold Your Wee for a Wii" contest, involved drinking large quantities of water without urinating. A nurse called the radio station to warn them about the danger in which they were putting people, but the disc jockeys were less than impressed. Lucy Davidson, the winner of the contest, was severely sickened while picking up her prize. Civil charges against the radio station were filed by Jennifer's family, and the family was eventually awarded $16.5 million in the ensuing wrongful death lawsuit.  Embed QuoteAnswered in twenty-three minutes via  Kat Tanaka Okopnik.

column9: in Africa.
column10: It depends on the type of maggot, of course. Most maggots probably would be killed by stomach acid. There are some, however, that can survive it and prove a danger to health.In fact, one of these maggots is intentionally introduced into food (it's not from Africa, but it's entirely possible that some African maggots could do it too)What the hell is it? This, dear reader, is a medium-sized lump of Sweet Fucking Christ. Casu Marzu is a sheep' milk cheese that has been deliberately infested by a Piophila casei, the "cheese fly." The result is a maggot-ridden, weeping stink bomb in an advanced state of decomposition.Its translucent larvae are able to jump about 6 inches into the air, making this the only cheese that requires eye protection while eating. The taste is strong enough to burn the tongue, and the larvae themselves pass through the stomach undigested, sometimes surviving long enough to breed in the intestine, where they attempt to bore through the walls, causing vomiting and bloody diarrhea.Read more: The 6 Most Terrifying Foods in the World | Cracked.com http://www.cracked.com/article_1...  Embed Quote

column9: in Africa.
column10: Human beings that consume food that contains maggots could potentially fall ill from a disease called Myiasis, also known as blowfly strike. While not fatal, this illness could cause further infections and serious health issues for some people.Also, any product that has maggots may have been poorly stored and may subject its consumer to one or more foodborne illnesses.When in doubt. don't eat it.reference:http://www.bioline.org.br/reques...  Embed QuoteAnswered in thirty-six minutes.

column9: When lazing acrylic glass the smell of the vaporized material does not really suggest that it's too healthy to be exposed to the fumes for a long time, though I couldn't find any warnings anywhere.
column10: The following is an extract from http://www.ajnr.org/cgi/content/... which tries to answer that specific question in a medical environment.  "MMA vapor levels to which medical personnel are exposed during percutaneous vertebroplasty are well below the level typically considered hazardous. However, it is important to note that some individuals may experience adverse effects, such as asthma, coughing, nausea, and decreased appetite, when exposed to levels typically considered to be within acceptable limits. At the levels of MMA vapor measured in our study, routine use of a fume hood is not necessary for MMA use in vertebroplasty, but a fume hood may be useful to reduce exposure of medical staff who are particularly sensitive to MMA vapor."My take is that it's not that bad but why take the risk, get rid of all gases coming out of your laser cutter.  Most of them stink anyways.  Embed Quote

column9: When lazing acrylic glass the smell of the vaporized material does not really suggest that it's too healthy to be exposed to the fumes for a long time, though I couldn't find any warnings anywhere.
column10: As a default, assume inhaling unnatural things isn't safe. The lack of a warning label just means that the product that it hasn't been fully evaluated. Often times esoteric things like this only get evaluated if a university decides to look into it, which can get the ball rolling to get federal regulators' attention (think Bisphenol A (BPA)).As a rule of thumb, if you aren't sure it's safe, assume it isn't.  Embed Quote

column10: the amount of lasing and pmma qty in the referenced medical application of bone repair is a tiny fraction of the amount lased in device fabrication using sheets of acrylic being cut, and needs to be noted. The fumes from lasing sheets ( me not being the primary machine operator, just in same poorly ventilated small lab ) hugely increased my blood pressure and likely has other systemic effects. PMMA/ MMA  is referenced to be toxic when used in plastic nails and as liquid monomer glue for cosmetic nails such that the FDA recommends using ethyl methacrylate ?nails & monomer glues for health reasons. Most of the published research does not examine exposures to MMA / PMMA ( acrylic and laser fracture byproducts ) from using a laser cutter with typically poor to negligible exhaust ( as by hobbiests ). The volumetric amounts of MMA released from cutting lots of acrylic sheets for prototype fabrication far exceeds the amounts in bone surgery / repair - hugely. To some many folks it will have inconsequential effects until some indeterminate cumulative exposure or complications with other health problems, after which who knows? What is different versus solvents, is how plastic monomer vapors will accumulate in the lungs and digestive tract, seemingly insolubilized  and how vapors formed by ablating cutting solids will be far larger in net dosing than vapors from exhausted solvents.  Embed Quote

column9: Is it dangerous?
column10: The airborne material released in the initial explosions was technically detectable for a very short period in 2011, but for any practical purpose it was indistinguishable from the natural background radiation. The radioactive seawater concentration from leaking/dumped coolant long ago dropped below the detectability threshold somewhere in the mid Pacific due to dilution and half-life decay. Note that our ability to detect radioisotopes in the environment is exceptionally sensitive due to decades of military funding of a global network of land- and satellite-based sensors, intended to identify nuclear weapon tests (for enforcing the Comprehensive Test Ban and Non-Proliferation Treaties). We can detect a faint whiff of xenon released by a sub-kiloton underground detonation halfway around the planet. It's crazy how little radiation it takes to set off the detectors. So when I say "barely detectable" or "below the threshold" you should take that as a truly minuscule amount of radiation. In comparison, the radioactive material in the atmosphere from the airburst nuclear weapons tests from 1945-1980 is still quite detectable, and every living creature on Earth is exposed to it. And there has been no statistically-measurable health impact to the public from that in the past 50 years. Any health impacts have been so minimal as to be indistinguishable from normal cancer rates. There's no reason for anyone in the US to worry about Fukushima, and there never was. The stress and fear (eg taking unnecessary iodine pills) definitely caused more harm than the meltdown did.For more information on the health impacts of radiation, I highly recommend spending some time reading this comprehensive article:http://world-nuclear.org/info/Sa...  Embed Quote

column9: Is it dangerous?
column10: The health effects of Fukushima radiation -- airborne, waterborne, bio-accumulated in fish -- are not yet known and not yet knowable. Fukushima is a long way from over, and the information we've gotten from TEPCO and the Japanese and American governments is both extremely patchy and thoroughly distorted. That's what governments and interested / liable parties do by default: withhold and bend information. TEPCO and the government of Japan have told an endless series of lies about how much radiation has been released, where it has gone, and what the acceptable limits of exposure are (the Japanese government simply revises acceptable limits of exposure upward every time they're caught in a fresh lie about what people have actually been exposed to, sometimes by as much as 20x). Stanford scientists have established that there isn't a tuna swimming in the Pacific today that isn't carrying radiation from Fukushima. Other scientists attempting to conduct intelligent risk assessment have frankly stated, There is a dearth of publicly available data, or at least little data known to us, regarding the levels of radioactive contamination in the sea and in seafood as a consequence of these chronic leaks of radioactivity into the sea from Fukushima. (Dr. Thomas Cochran)The health effects of Fukushima radiation -- airborne, waterborne, bio-accumulated in fish, are not yet known, and not yet knowable. As Ryan Carlyle himself writes in an answer dismissing the effects of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, "Radioactive fallout is mutagenic and sticks around for decades." The patient person can begin to learn more about the reality of long-term effects of radioactive fallout by watching something like "Medical and Ecological Consequences of the Fukushima Nuclear Accident":I'm a huge fan of Ryan Carlyle's learned and well-written answers here on oil exploration. The trouble I have with Ryan Carlyle's answer to this question is the same as my trouble with Ryan Carlyle's answer to Fukushima Prefecture: Is Fukushima radiactive leaking going to effect on the health of people living in Tokyo? and Ryan Carlyle's answer to Fukushima Dai-ichi Reactors: How many people have died or will die from radiation from the Fukushima accident? and Ryan Carlyle's answer to Travel: I am going to Japan in August 2013. Will it be safe from leaking radioactive material to swim in water in the Izu Penninsula region? and Ryan Carlyle's answer to Fukushima Dai-ichi Reactors: What is the global worst case scenario that can result from the recent increase in severity level for this incident?     And that is each answer, as of this writing, is wholly unsupported by anything other than "because Ryan Carlyle says so" -- but for the last, which is buttressed by stock market charts. (Forgive me for singling you out like this, RC, but you're going to great lengths to assert non-harm, and always on scant or completely absent foundations.)In that respect, they are all quite like this answer to What is the current (early 2012) condition of the Gulf of Mexico following the Deepwater Horizon oil spill?, which says, in essence, "No harm, no foul: -- again, without any documentation. That is quite a different story from the massive catch declines, tumors and other deformities in seafood, and decades of effects that have been reported and predicted by marine scientists studying the Gulf.These effects are being shown by a series of studies -- they're just not shown to you by the U.S. government much, and BP goes to great and largely effective lengths to tell a different story with its PR machine.Trusting governments, trusting power vendors who are on the hook for cleanup costs and liability for health consequences, or trusting undocumented assertions on Quora is foolish.  Embed Quote

I have no opinion on how dangerous or addictive it is, but about what it's like:Depending on how much you take and your tolerance also varies, of course. As a disassociative, it makes you a bit out of touch with your physical body, but it's rarely if ever the type of "out of body" experience that laypeople think that means. It simply is more like when you're sober, you know where your left foot is, even if you don't consciously direct your thoughts to it. On ketamine, that "where your left foot is" can be a little hazy. Obviously as an anesthetic you feel little to no pain, which can be anywhere from amusing to disastrous. It's something like tripping but without distinct visual hallucinations -- when on acid or shrooms one can typically can see lines and edges and pictures and visualizations, whereas ketamine was a bit more abstract: fuzzy edges of things, taking a few moments to register things in your vision field.Effects vary but sex is interesting, don't accidentally slam a cab door on your knee because you won't notice you've done it until people look at you funny as you walk down the street and you look down and realize you are bleeding profusely, and try to stay within safe areas because your sense of reality goes out the door. This information is all on the order of 2 years old so what I remember of it may be distorted.Not for Reproduction

Ketamine can also impair memory. It's an NMDA receptor antagonist, and NMDA receptor activity is generally necessary for memory formation (as NMDA receptor activity induces long-term potentiation - see The Synaptic Self for details).See http://www.telegraph.co.uk/scien..., http://www.ketamine.com/memory.html, and http://www.ketamine.com/episodic.... The latter two sources may look biased, but they're actually extra-credible when they discuss the risks of ketamine, as they come from a pro-ketamine site.As for how dangerous it is - it also depends on what you take it for, and how long you take it for. Many ketamine users aren't exactly responsible types of people, so they're more likely to forget about precautions when taking a dissociative anesthetic. It is possible to take precautions if you're careful, of course.  Embed Quote

Ketamine is actually relatively safe as a drug -- the "safety factor" between a minimum interesting dose and a lethal dose is quite high.  As an anaesthetic, it is incredibly safe -- safe enough to let veterinarians use it, or battlefield medics, wthout respiratory support.High-dose ketamine is possibly psychologically terrifying ("bad trip"), based on reports from the use of the drug in human patients (which is why it has largely been discontinued).  However, a lot of the trauma was most likely related to the context in which it was administered -- battlefield trauma, surgery, and waking up in a strange place PLUS being in a semi-dissociated state due to the drug.  Embed Quote

Compared to other recreational drugs, ketamine is quite dangerous. An evidence-based ranking of drugs by potential for harm done by UK scientists placed ketamine just one place behind alcohol, several places more dangerous than cannabis. (http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/64740...)As a central nervous system depressant, the main effects and risks of ketamine are not entirely unlike those of alcohol. Ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic. It impairs perception and physical coordination. It also separates the user's sense of mind and body. Consequently, ketamine users have a much higher than normal risk of accidental physical injury. The drug's anesthetic properties may prevent the user from even realizing they have injured themselves, and the dissociative properties may cause users to fail to appreciate the significance or severity of injury. It is very important to always have a sober person around who can evaluate and respond to the situation in case of emergency.Recreational use of ketamine presents dangers common to most illicit materials. It is very difficult to reliably know much about the purity of material. It is also somewhat difficult to control dose when insufflating an eyeballed amount of ketamine powder (the most typical method of recreational consumption). Because ketamine's effects onset relatively rapidly (typically in less than 10 minutes), some users try to diminish dosing risk by taking a series of small doses.When insufflated, the risk of overdose is very low. However, it is quite easy to inadvertently take an amount that leaves the user in an uncomfortably detached semi-conscious state, often referred to as the K-hole (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K-hole).There is increasing evidence for recreational ketamine use leading to bladder and kidney problems (http://www.bmj.com/cgi/content/e..., http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/r...).No physiological basis for ketamine addiction has been shown. However, the drug is prone to psychological dependence, which is often casually referred to as "addictiveness." Though stopping ketamine use would not result in physical withdrawals as with drugs like cocaine or heroin, many users do feel compelled to take the drug with both increasing frequency and dose.In terms of what it is like, ketamine is highly dose-variant, and is similar to other dissociatives. A light dose is similar to being drunk on alcohol, but more euphoric and with less nausea. It puts the user in a dreamy state, imaginative and comfortably detached from reality. Stronger doses can be much more intense and world-shifting. Perception of time, sound, light, and shapes may vary wildly, sometimes with auditory or visual hallucinations. Some users find this experience extremely enjoyable, others find it terrifying and may become convinced they are trapped forever. A wealth of subjective reports, varying from ecstatic to nightmarish, can be found on Erowid (http://www.erowid.org/experience...).  Embed Quote
It is hard to overdose on so it isn't very dangerous in that regard. I found it to be very addictive though. If you are prone to substance abuse stay away.  Embed Quote

column9: It seems like there are many chemicals that can poison someone, each with unique mechanisms of action. Cyanide is an inhibitor of the enzyme cytochrome c oxidase, sarin is a potent inhibitor of acetylcholinesterase, alcohol overdose shuts down respiration through excessive inhibition of subcortical neurological structures, etc etc. If a person is brought to the hospital but no one knows what they were exposed to, how does a doctor know which antagonists to try?
column10: From IMAI district clinician manual: Hospital care for adolescents and adults, page 163-165Try to determine what was taken (name of drug, product, plant), whether multiple substances were taken (ethanol is often a co-ingestant), how much (strength of tablets, volume, and concentration of liquids), when it was taken (time elapsed since exposure) and the duration of exposure, whether the patient has vomited, and whether any first aid has been given (obtain a description of the fi rstaid). It is also important to find out why the poisoning occurred: was it accidental or deliberate? If the latter (suicide or homicide attempt), then the overdose may be more severe. [...] The route of exposure is important since this may determine the speed of onset of toxic effects. Multiple routes of exposure are possible (e.g. inhalation and dermal).Ask for the container, bottle, or plant sample to be brought in with the patient (it may be found near the patient or in a rubbish bin).Check whether another person was involved.Check the medical and occupational history of the patient since these factors may infl uence the risk of toxicity, e.g. chronic illness such as diabetes, cardiovascular disease, drug dependency, occupational exposure to chemicals, or psychological and familial problems. Nutritional status is also important, e.g. malnourishment may increase the risk of toxicity in paracetamol overdose.Check what other medications the patient is taking, including traditional medicines, because these may interact with the substance that has been taken in overdose, resulting in faster onset of toxic effects, or more prolonged or severe toxic effects. The co-ingestion of two serotinergic drugs, for example, increases the risk of serotonin syndrome. An important group of medicines are antiretroviral protease inhibitors, which are metabolised by hepatic P450 enzymes. Ritonavir, for example, inhibits metabolism of dextropropoxyphene resulting in a greater risk of toxicity and a number of protease inhibitors inhibit metabolism of benzodiazepines such as diazepam.Diagnosis and treatment decisions should be based on a combination of the history (identity of the poison, quantity taken), physical examination (assessment of vital signs, presence of characteristic symptoms and signs, i.e. toxidromes), simple bedside laboratory tests (e.g. urine colour tests and SpO2) and general laboratory examinations (blood glucose, ECG, and arterial or venous blood gas). In the case of opioids, a challenge dose of naloxone is diagnostic, but should be given cautiously, especially in opioid-dependent patients.It is important to note that a number of factors affect the risk from poisoning, such as body weight, age, pre-existing health problems, chronic use of medications, and genetic factors. Therefore, the patient should be assessed as a whole, rather than relying on the history of the overdose alone. If a toxicology laboratory is available to measure serum levels, these provide helpful indicators of the need for treatment for certain drugs and toxic substances.If there is no clear history of the agent ingested, the diagnosis of the agent involved should be based on symptoms and signs and a limited number of investigations. If this is not possible, patients should be given supportive care and vital parameters should be stabilized, such as blood pressure and SpO2.Check for emergency signs and to provide emergency treatments as appropriate (e.g. airway management, oxygen, IV fluids, glucose, naloxone).Look in the patient’s mouth and smell the breath.Feel the pulse and do an ECG to check for arrhythmias.Examine the patient from head to toe: look for trauma, cyanosis, blisters, burns in or around the mouth, and check for stridor (laryngeal damage from corrosives).  Embed QuoteAnswered in forty-seven minutes.
Fat soluble vitamins exhibit toxicity, because unlike water soluble vitamins, they cannot be rapidly excreted in the urine.  Embed Quote

Cyanide is the anion NC- and as such it does not exist on its own, only in combination with cations. The conjugate acid, HCN, is volatile and smells like almonds. Potassium cyanide KCN is not volatile and therefore has no odour.  Embed Quote

column9: Which one is the best alternative to the other, and why?Petro-chemical polymer, or Stainless steel?
column10: I have different preferences for different situations. I use all three, but only non-BPA Nalgenes.  Here's the Wiki on BPAs:"BPA is controversial because it exerts weak, but detectable, hormone-like properties, raising concerns about its presence in consumer products and foods contained in such products. Starting in 2008, several governments questioned its safety, prompting some retailers to withdraw polycarbonate products. A 2010 report from the United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) raised further concerns regarding exposure to fetuses, infants, and young children.[2] In September 2010, Canada became the first country to declare BPA a toxic substance.[3][4] The European Union, Canada, and recently the United States have banned BPA use in baby bottles.[5][6]"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bis...  Let's look at 1) Camelback2) Non-BPA Nalgene3) Stainless steel or glass or ceramic1. Camelback has become my absolute favorite for hiking/backpacking/ any physical activity because it's really nice not to have to root around for your water source while you're moving.  It's light, it's safe (non-BPA) and it's easy to fit in a pack.  Downside: you have to clean it carefully, doing a final rinse with alcohol to sterilize and evaporate any leftover water drops that could mildew in the water line.2. Nalgene bottles (non-BPA) are nice because they are light and easy to clean.  We still use one 1-litre bottle for collection/sterilization with a Steri-Pen for cooking and filling the Camelbacks.  Downside:  water tastes funny after it has been in one, especially after a long time or if the bottle has heated from the sun, etc.This is of special concern to me as the parent of a child (see above).  The jury's still out, I may be wrong, but the early research is concerning enough for me to not take undue chances, especially during my son's main growing years.3. Stainless steel/glass/ceramic is my favorite for everyday desk and daypacks/lunchpacks.  It's heavy, but if you don't have to carry it far it's not an issue.  The water simply tastes the best from these non-leaching containers. Steel is the obvious choice for children's lunchboxes/packs because it's non-breakable and dishwasher-safe for sterilization.  Embed Quote

column9: Which one is the best alternative to the other, and why?Petro-chemical polymer, or Stainless steel?
column10: I don't have an opinion on BPA, but for convenience I like a combination of Platypus collapsible bladders (1 and/or 2 liter) which tuck away in the pack when I don't need to have water in them. (They are designed for hydration systems, but I use them just to hold water.) While hiking, I prefer to drink from a 500 cc Nalgene bottle rather than a hydration system because I want to know the amount I am drinking either to make sure I am fully hydrated or to ration water on a long dry stretch - hydration systems usually don't let you know easily how much you are drinking)   So I usually bring 2-3 Nalgene 500 cc wide-mouth bottles for collecting water, for drinking on trail and for convenience. The wide mouths (esp. on the square bottles) make it easy to pick up water from a lake or a shallow stream (small mouths are a pain unless you always use a filter that fits the small mouth).  In winter or over high passes, the wide mouths also allow you to put in some snow periodically to replenish water you are drinking.  I have one round 500cc Nalgene which has the ounce (and cc) measurements printed up the side, which is useful when doing trail cooking (e.g., measuring 8 oz for  my morning oatmeal and 12 oz for evening soups).  I also typically carry one or two square widemouth 500 cc Nalgenes which are wrapped in black 10-mil plumbers tape and are each fitted with a clip that attaches  easily to a PALS strap on my shoulder harness.   (Picture shows the bottle with clear duct tape securing the clip - I now prefer the black tape both for warming and because it is a bit stronger).  The black tape warms up the water, mostly good in winter to melt added snow but also slightly saving fuel if I use it for cooking (if I want water to stay cool, I can put it inside the pack). If you plan to use this in winter, fashion the clip so the bottle hangs with the threads faced downward (the threads will freeze tight if carried upright). If you can carry water forward of your center of gravity it slightly helps you hiking balance. You didn't ask about this, but I will gratuitously add: (1) a folding bucket is a great addition because you can draw plenty of water quickly and then get away from the water's edge (important in our Sierra Nevada mosquito season); and (2) a 17 ounce Platypus bottle is a great way to carry olive oil to add calories to most any dinner or for field-making hummus or tabbouleh (olive oil otherwise likes to leak). Though once used for olive oil, you won't be using it for water.  Grainger.com has a good selection of wide-mouth Nalgene bottles in a variety of sizes and shapes (and with ounce measurements). Platypus bladders are available at REI. PS: a one-ounce Nalgene gives you a way to measure out the olive oil without getting a measuring cup all oily and nasty. Sorry, way too much information is response to a shorter question.   Embed Quote

column9: despite all belonging to the same group
column10: Bismuth is actually quite toxic, but it is also poorly absorbed, which means that bismuth compounds are useful for things like gastrointestinal imaging and treating intestinal upset due to food poisoning. Haschek and Rousseaux's Handbook of Toxicologic PathologyIt should also be noted that "group" doesn't necessarily imply similar toxicity, it is intended to show the kinds of general physical properties of pure elements. Just because something is a pnictogen doesn't mean we can generalize all its properties as a component in molecules.People are rarely poisoned with "arsenic"- they are poisoned with arsenic-containing insecticides, which aid transport into the body. Compounds such as Lewisite, a volatile liquid, don't really have an equivalent in Bismuth, but do have equivalents in phosphorous and nitrogen.   Embed Quote

column9: Does it have any long-term effects? Especially on the brain?Does it have potential for proteotoxicity, lipotoxicity, or genotoxicity?
column10: IPA or 2-propanol is a volatile solvent, and if you look on the internet you should easily be able to find a Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS), sometimes also called an SDS. I have seen IPA on a safety data sheet which said 'May be harmful if inhaled and in contact with skin,' and 'may cause irritation to respiratory tract.' So the answer is yes, it is not the best idea to inhale this vapour, and there are limits to the concentrations in air that you should not exceed known in the UK as Workplace Exposure limits (WELs) for IPA the 8 hour WEL is 980mg/m3 and the short term (15 minute) concentration limit is 1225mg/m3. Thes are the current values and these do change occasionally as more data becomes available on the chemical's effects.If you have to work with this solvent, you should wear gloves, and ensure the area is well ventilated, ideally with a proper Local exhaust Ventilation (LEV) system, to remove fumes from your breathing area. Alternatively you can buy half mask respirators that filter out solvents, but PPE should be a last resort.  Embed Quote

Well, they're highly reactive. In biological systems, they often participate in reactions where nucleophiles are added to formyl carbons (oxidative deaminations, forming of imines, forming of hemiacetals) [1]. I'll use aldehydes in cigarette smoke as an example [2]. Over time, these end up accumulating in your lung tissue. One species is formaldehyde which, upon contact with your broncho-epithelial cells, can react with DNA.  Formaldehyde can also irreversibly cross-link with primary amino groups of your proteins or with nitrogen atoms in your DNA by way of a CH2 linkage. This ability to cross-link biological materials together is why it's great for embalming dead bodies.Acrolein is another example. The carboxylic group (C=O) can undergo nucleophilic substitution. The double C-C bond can undergo electrophilic additions, hydroxylations, etc. Now, the smoke contains approximately 33-228 micrograms of acrolein per cigarette [2]. Upon inhalation, it will end up in your respiratory system. In cells, there are many reactions in which it may take part. It might induce covalent modification in proteins. It can also act on certain so-called "stress genes" like c-fos (and potentially activate certain transcription factors). In summary, their carcinogencity is a consquence of their reactivity with biological molecules. Compounds with aldehydes tend to be able to participate in a host of reactions which disrupt the delicate and intricate biochemistry taking place in and around our cells. [1] Smith, Michael B.; http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jer... (2007), Advanced Organic Chemistry: Reactions, Mechanisms, and Structure (6th ed.), New York: Wiley-Interscience, ISBN 0-471-72091-7[2] Toxicity and Carcinogenicity of Aldehydes  Embed Quote

column9: (not inclusive of PM2.5 and brominated flame retardants here, which are also two big concerns)
column10: I mostly focus on chronic effects, since these are the effects that others almost always ignore. So I'm not concerned about CO, but I'm more concerned about neurotoxic non-lethal VOCs.Overall though, the possible neurotoxic effects are the most worrisome. The increased risks of cancer from any of these is very small (see Are we exposed to more carcinogens now than any other time in history? ). One chart here: Loads of EPA Factsheets over at https://www.google.com/search?su...CDC factsheets at http://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/substan... (CDC often has different MRLs than EPA)Concerning:benzeneformaldehydestyrene (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sty... ) [1]. Also, http://www.epa.gov/iris/subst/01.... http://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/mrls/pd... shows 0.02 ppm MRL (or 367 ug/m^3)acetaldehydes (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ace... ) - 7x common indoors than outdoorsxylenes (adds another CH3 group to toluene): http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xyl... - NFPA 2. EPA technical factsheet says that very little is known about chronic effects. 100 ppm produces long-term neurological effects in rats. An MRL of 0.05 ppm has been derived for chronic-duration inhalation exposure. Also see  http://www.epa.gov/iris/subst/02.... 100 ppm = 467 mg/m^3, 0.05 ppm = 234 ug/m^3toluene (anything above 34 ppm (or 138 mg/m^3) carries a risk of neurotoxicity - see  http://www.epa.gov/iris/subst/01... ). http://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/toxprof... shows that lvls in suburban outdoor air are 1.3-6.6 ppb, avg lvls in indoor air are 8 ppb. MRL is 80 ppb (or 325 ug/m^3). 8000 ppb is usually needed for odor detection of toluene. Non-carcinogen.n-hexane (http://www.epa.gov/iris/subst/04...  ). 30 ppm definitely has chronic effects ( see  http://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/toxprof... ), and effects probably exist for an undetermined concentration well below that. http://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/mrls/pd... establishes 0.06 ppm (or 228 ug/m^3) as MRL.See http://www.lenntech.com/calculat... to switch between ppm and ug/m^3Chronic Effects Debateable:ethylene glycol (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eth...). But low vapor pressure and tends to settle down within 10 days. See http://cfpub.epa.gov/ncea/iris/i... . Not a carcinogen, and low-level chronic neurological effects appear to be limited (http://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/toxprof... )butyl ether (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Met... )Chronic Effects Unknown:2-pentylfuran, decanol, propenoic acid (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acr... ), acrylonitrile (acute toxicity very high)Little evidence of chronic effects:Propylene glycol (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pro..., NFPA 0 )vinyl acetate - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vin... .  http://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/toxprof... shows limited toxic effects, non-carcinogenacetone adult body weight, 70 kg and assuming 100% absorption) to3obtain the dose in mg/kg (U.S. EPA 1988b).Increases in reaction times and decreases in memory/concentration correlated to both these data the U.S. EPA (1994) calculated a chronic RfC for styrene of 1 mg/m  (0.23 ppm).3Human volunteers exposed to 370-591 mg/m  (85.1-135.93 ppm) for 80 minutes had alterations3in visual suppression and saccade (rapid, intermittent eye movements) tests when compared tounexposed controls (U.S. EPA 1994).  The concentration of 370 mg/m  is roughly equivalent to38.88 mg/kg over the 80 minute period .2Boat builders occupationally exposed for an average of 10.8 years to 50-140 mg/m  styrene3showed alterations in the vestibuloocular reflex (U.S. EPA 1994).  Other occupational studieshave linked styrene exposure to hearing loss (138 mg/m  for 8.6 years) and decreased visuomotor3accuracy (25 ppm for 4.9 years) (U.S. EPA 1994).  Longer reaction times have been reported inseveral occupational studies with exposure concentrations ranging from 9 to >150 ppm anddurations of days to years (U.S. EPA 1984).====A chart that plots indoor vs. outdoor distributions (though column9: (not inclusive of PM2.5 and brominated flame retardants here, which are also two big concerns)
column10: VOCs are difficult to isolate in measurements, so usually a emission permit will simply specify a substitute such as PM2.5 and mercury rates as being indicative of VOC removal success. In most cases removal of VOCs is accomplished simultaneously with efforts to remove particulate matter and acidic gases such as SO2 and NOx. Common methods to remove these compounds (and thus VOCs) include combustion control (low NOx burners), wet scrubbers, and fabric filter dust collection systems (baghouses). At times dust collection equipment such as baghouses are supplemented with sorbent or activated carbon injection to control elements such as mercury (formerly treated as a VOC by the EPA). Samuel DalSantoBaghouse.comParticulate FilterAir PollutionVolatile Organic Compounds  Embed Quote

column9: I guess this can be measured in terms of toxicity of the venom and probably the actual number of human deaths they inflicted.
column10: [The original question asked what are the most poisonous snakes in the world]None! Technically snake venom is not a poison, it is a venom. Poisons can be absorbed through the skin or digestive tract whilst venoms have to be injected into the tissue or bloodstream. This is why snake venom can be drunk. This actually happens in parts Asia as it is believed to carry many health benefits.In terms of toxicity there is as yet no definitive answer as the testing systems vary so greatly. There have also been no tests done of all using at least one of these systems. Most importantly though the different venoms may have characteristics that may make them more deadly to the mice they are usually tested on than humans.That being said, it is pretty much accepted that the most toxic venom is that of the sea snakes. In studies done in Costa Rica the pelagic sea snake was found to be more than twice as venomous as any land snake. However, it is rare to receive a fatal bite because almost always only tiny amounts of venom are injected.In terms of percentage of bites resulting in fatalies, the bites of both the black mamba and coastal taipan are almost 100% fatal. Others probably are too. I knew a herpetologist who was at that time the only person who had survived a full black mamba bite. I did a course on snake bites with him many years ago in Zimbabwe. He explained that he had been working with a medical professional on a theory. Black Mambas are neurotoxic and kill by paralysing all the muscles in your body. Your first stop breathing and the last muscle to become paralysed is your heart. Their theory was that if you could keep the person's lungs and heart going artificially until antivenom could work then someone could survive. Amazingly he was bitten by a mamba, rushed to hospital by his wife and the very doctor he worked with met him there (within ten minutes of the bite) and they put him on a heart lung machine and pumped him full of anti-venom and antihystamine. He lived and had no lasting side-effects.Sadly he was bitten again by a black mamba a few years later and this time died before he could get help. Black MambaIn terms of fatalities India has the most fatalities reported of all countries and I believe Spectacled Cobra and Common krait  and [EDIT- Thanks Karandeep Singh] russell's viper are responsible. I have also read about the poor ladies in Sri Lanka who pick tea without protection to their legs and are frequently bitten and die. King CobraCommon KraitRussell's Viper  Embed QuoteVia  Karandeep Singh.
