column10: For Human Deaths, it's the Russel's Viper.  For venom toxicity, I believe it's the Beaked Sea Snake.  Now, if you mean snakes that are actually poisonous (as in, toxic when eaten), then some North American garter snake populations, and the Japanese grass snake, are both able to concentrate toad toxins on their bodies, thus making them poisonous to eat.  They are not the only animals in the world to render themselves poisonous by eating prey that contains toxins.  Embed QuoteVia  Shubhendu Aggarwal.

column9: I guess this can be measured in terms of toxicity of the venom and probably the actual number of human deaths they inflicted.
column10: From medical perspective its more difficult to manage a hemotoxic snake bite than neurotoxic venom in the ER .Neurotoxic snakebites (In India) are mostly from Cobras and Kraits , although the symptoms of neurotoxic venom develop quite early as compared to Hemotoxins but once patient arrives alive in the ER , He/she can then be very easily saved by simply providing mechanical ventilation alone , ASVs (anti snake venom) are administered to neutralize the venom although even if its unavailable in sufficient quantity as it happens quite frequently in India , Doctors may buy the necessary time on ventilators for the patient's body to neutralize the venom on its own . The foremost cause of death from cobra , krait or any other neurotoxic snake is respiratory muscle paralysis and since the venom do not effect pathologically to the lungs , O2 saturation of blood can be maintained with ventilators , proper antibiotic cover and acid base management .For Hemotoxins (all vipers) the situation is very different , this category of venom causes hemolysis of the RBCs and prevent the clotting of blood aka disseminated intravascular coagulopathy (DIC) . Death is generally due to Multiple organ failure caused by massive internal bleeding and sepsis . Hemotoxic symptoms develop late (upto several days) and if not neutralized by ASVs at appropriate time , the prognosis of the patient's condition is very poor .Even if the ASV is administered early and major amount of venom is successfully neutralized , The damage already done to the Kidneys , spleen and GIT is irreversible . I havent seen any Pit viper or saw scaled viper bitten patient to have survived even though the best possible medical care has been provided at optimum time .  Embed Quote

column9: I guess this can be measured in terms of toxicity of the venom and probably the actual number of human deaths they inflicted.
column10: Here are 11 of the world's most venomous snakes:#10 - Eastern Diamondback Rattlesnake:The only snake from the Americas on the list, the Rattlesnake is easily identifiable by the tell tale rattle on the end of its tail. They are actually a part of the Pit Viper family, and are capable of striking at up to 2/3rd their body length. The Eastern Diamondback in considered the most venomous species in North America. Surprisingly, juveniles are considered more dangerous than adults, due to their inability to control the amount of venom injected. Most species of rattlesnakes have hemotoxic venom, destroying tissue, degenerating organs and causing coagulopathy (disrupted blood clotting). Some degree of permanent scarring is very likely in the event of a venomous bite, even with prompt, effective treatment, and can lead to the loss of a limb or death. Difficulty breathing, paralysis, drooling and massive hemorrhaging are also common symptoms. Thus, a rattlesnake bite is always a potentially fatal injury. Untreated rattlesnake bites, especially from larger species, are very often fatal. However, antivenin, when applied in time, reduces the death rate to less than 4%#9 - Death Adder:The appropriately named Death Adder is found in Australia and New Guinea. They actually hunt and kill other snakes, including some on this list, usually via ambush. Death Adders look quite similar to vipers, in that they have triangular shaped heads and short, squat bodies. They typically inject around 40-100mg of venom with an LD of 0.4mg-0.5mg/kg. An untreated Death Adder bite is one of the most dangerous in the world. The venom is a neurotoxin. A bite causes paralysis and can cause death within 6 hours, due to respiratory failure. Symptoms generally peak within 24-48 hours. Antivenin is very successful in treating a bite from a Death Adder, particularly due to the relatively slow progression of symptoms, but before its development, a Death Adder bite had a fatality rate of 50%. With the quickest strike in the world, a Death Adder can go from strike position to striking and back again within 0.13 of a second.#8 - Vipers:Vipers are found throughout most of the world, but arguably the most venomous is the Saw Scaled Viper and the Chain Viper, found primarily in the Middle East and Central Asia, particularly India, China and South East Asia. Vipers are quick tempered and generally nocturnal, often active after rains. They are also very fast. Most of these species have venom that cause symptoms that begin with pain at the site of the bite, immediately followed by swelling of the affected extremity. Bleeding is a common symptom, especially from the gums. There is a drop in blood pressure and the heart rate falls. Blistering occurs at the site of the bite, developing along the affected limb in severe cases. Necrosis is usually superficial and limited to the muscles near the bite, but may be severe in extreme cases. Vomiting and facial swelling occurs in about one-third of all cases. Severe pain may last for 2-4 weeks. Often, local swelling peaks within 48-72 hours, involving the affected limb. Discoloration may occur throughout the swollen area as red blood cells and plasma leak into muscle tissue. Death from septicaemia, respiratory or cardiac failure may occur 1 to 14 days post-bite, or even later.#7 - Philippine Cobra:Most species of Cobra would not make this list; however the Philippine Cobra is the exception. Drop for drop, its venom is the most deadly of all the Cobra species, and they are capable of spitting it up to 3 metres. The venom is a neurotoxin which affects cardiac and respiratory function, and can cause neurotoxicity, respiratory paralysis and death in thirty minutes. The bite causes only minimal tissue damage. The neurotoxins interrupt the transmission of nerve signals by binding to the neuro-muscular junctions near the muscles. The symptoms might include headache, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, dizziness, collapse and convulsions.#6 - Tiger Snake:Found in Australia, the Tiger snake has a very potent neurotoxic venom. Death from a bite can occur within 30 minutes, but usually takes 6-24 hours. Prior to the development of antivenin, the fatality rate from Tiger snakes was 60-70%. Symptoms can include localized pain in the foot and neck region, tingling, numbness and sweating, followed by a fairly rapid onset of breathing difficulties and paralysis. The Tiger snake will generally flee if encountered, but can become aggressive when cornered. It strikes with unerring accuracy.#5 - Black Mamba:The feared Black Mamba is found throughout many parts of the African continent. They are known to be highly aggressive, and strike with deadly precision. They are also the fastest land snake in the world, capable of reaching speeds of up to 20km/h. These fearsome snakes can strike up to 12 times in a row. A single bite is capable of killing anywhere from 10-25 adults. The venom is a fast acting neurotoxin. Its bite delivers about 100–120 mg of venom, on average; however, it can deliver up to 400 mg. If the venom reaches a vein, 0.25 mg/kg is sufficient to kill a human in 50% of cases. The initial symptom of the bite is local pain in the bite area, although not as severe as snakes with hemotoxins. The victim then experiences a tingling sensation in the mouth and extremities, double vision, tunnel vision, severe confusion, fever, excessive salivation (including foaming of the mouth and nose) and pronounced ataxia (lack of muscle control). If the victim does not receive medical attention, symptoms rapidly progress to severe abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, pallor, shock, nephrotoxicity, cardio toxicity and paralysis. Eventually, the victim experiences convulsions, respiratory arrest, coma and then death. Without antivenin, the mortality rate is nearly 100%, among the highest of all venomous snakes. Depending on the nature of the bite, death can result at any time between 15 minutes and 3 hours.#4 - Taipan:Another entry from Australia, the venom in a Taipan is strong enough to kill up to 12,000 guinea pigs. The venom clots the victim’s blood, blocking arteries or veins. It is also highly neurotoxic. Before the advent of an antivenin, there are no known survivors of a Taipan bite, and death typically occurs within an hour. Even with successful administration of antivenin, most victims will have an extensive stay in intensive care. It has been likened to the African Black Mamba in morphology, ecology and behavior.#3 - Blue Krait:The Malayan or Blue Krait is, by far, the most deadly of this species. Found throughout South East Asia and Indonesia, 50% of bites from the deadly Blue Krait are fatal, even with the administration of antivenin. Kraits hunt and kill other snakes, even cannibalizing other Kraits. They are a nocturnal breed, and are more aggressive under the cover of darkness. However, overall they are quite timid and will often attempt to hide rather than fight. The venom is a neurotoxin, 16 times more potent than that of a Cobra. It quickly induces muscle paralysis by preventing the ability of nerve endings to properly release the chemical that sends the message to the next nerve. This is followed by a period of massive over excitation (cramps, tremors, spasms), which finally tails off to paralysis. Fortunately, bites from Kraits are rare due to their nocturnal nature. Before the development of antivenin, the fatality rate was a whopping 85%. Even if antivenin is administered in time, you are far from assured survival. Death usually occurs within 6-12 hours of a Krait bite. Even if patients make it to a hospital, permanent coma and even brain death from hypoxia may occur, given potentially long transport times to get medical care.#2 - Eastern Brown Snake:Don’t let the innocuous name of this snake fool you, 1/14,000 of an ounce of its venom is enough to kill an adult human. Coming in a variety of species, the Eastern Brown snake is the most venomous. Unfortunately, its preferred habitat is also along the major population centers of Australia. The Brown snake is fast moving, can be aggressive under certain circumstances and has been known to chase aggressors and repeatedly strike at them. Even juveniles can kill a human. The venom contains both neurotoxins and blood coagulants. Fortunately for humans, less than half of bites contain venom and they prefer not to bite if at all possible. They react only to movement, so stand very still if you ever encounter one in the wild.#1 - Fierce Snake or Inland Taipan:The incredible Inland Taipan has the most toxic venom of any land snake in the world. The maximum yield recorded for one bite is 110mg, enough to kill about 100 humans, or 250,000 mice! With an LD/50 of 0.03mg/kg, it is 10 times as venomous as the Mojave Rattlesnake, and 50 times more than the common Cobra. Fortunately, the Inland Taipan is not particularly aggressive and is rarely encountered by humans in the wild. No fatalities have ever been recorded, though it could potentially kill an adult human within 45 minutes.Other snakes worthy of being on the list:#1 - Belcher’s Sea Snake:The most venomous snake known in the world, a few milligrams is strong enough to kill 1000 people! Less than 1/4 of bites will contain venom, and they are relatively docile. Fisherman are usually the victims of these bites, as they encounter the species when they pull nets from the ocean. Found throughout waters off South East Asia and Northern Australia.D.  Embed Quote

column10: This question reminds me of my school days when I would watch animal planet for about 8 hours in a day. I remember watching a program which listed the deadliest snakes on the planet. So here’s applying that knowledge to answer your question. There are several parameters to measure how venomous a snake bite is, but for this question let’s consider the most simple and useful one – Potential Deaths per bite.1.  Inland Taipan-The most venomous snake in the world. This is baddest snake in all of the Australian outback. Sure there are other marine snakes whose poison is even stronger when compared drop by drop, however, their venom volume is far from enough to consider them life threatening.Avg. Venom per bite: 77mgNo of human deaths per bite- 44 .2. The Common Krait- We actually found one of these in our house 5 years ago in New Delhi. Found abundantly in the forests and farmlands of India. They prey on other snakes and can even turn cannibalistic. They are not aggressive toward humans even when provoked, they prefer to coil and hide their heads for protection. The bites are usually a result of close encounters in inhabited areas; sometimes these snakes chose to make human habitation their own.Avg. Venom per bite: 30mgNo of human deaths per bite-113. Tiger Snake- Again an inhabitant of Australia .These snake can differ broadly in their appearance but they usually have stripes resembling those of a Tiger (hence the name) and they can reach a length of up to 6 feet (2m). The Tiger Snake possesses a powerful cocktail of drugs. The venom is among the most powerful; it is simultaneously Hemotoxic, Neurotoxic and Myotoxic.Avg. Venom per bite: 112mgNo of human deaths per bite-8The next spot is a tie between the Black Mamba , The death adder and the Australian Brown Snake. They will all kill about 4 humans with a single bite.Though the black mamba features pretty late on this list compared to its reputation, it should be noted that it probably is the most dangerous snakeas it is super aggressive and can run like the wind with a top speed of 12 km per hour.Shows you death inside its mouth. The black mamba.Courtesy: http://thelistcafe.com/  Embed Quote

column9: Assuming they take them one after the other with about a minute between each shot, and they don't vomit.
column10: Let's run some numbers:A possibility of death occurs in the mid-0.30s as far as BAC goes [1]One shot of 80-proof vodka has roughly 0.6oz of alcohol in it. [1]Let's say the "average" person is a 180-lb male; every drink they have within an hour adds roughly .02 BAC; this means they would need to have more than 15 drinks in this hour to reach a BAC of .30 - still not quite enough to kill them.If we say the "average" person is a 140-lb female; every drink they have within an hour adds roughly .03 BAC; this means they would need to have around 10 drinks in this same hour to reach a BAC of .30 - again, not quite enough to kill them.BAC spikes, then diminishes over time, on a fairly predictable curve.  Which allows us to use some fun calculators.  According to this[2] one, a 180-lb man would have a BAC of .384 (definitely in the danger zone) after having 20 shots over 4 hours.  Our 140-lb woman hits .386 after 14 shots over the same 4 hours.Using that same BAC calculator, if you narrow the time limit to 30 minutes, then the man hits .353 at 16 shots and the woman hits .349 at only 11 shots.[1] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blo...[2] http://bloodalcoholcalculator.or...  Embed Quote

column9: No links to commercial sites or pseudo-scientific ads please. I can use an electronic grid to make water any pH I like but clear purified water as far as I know lacks the cations needed to produce a buffered alkaline solution that won't just dissipate when it meets stomach acid. Example of a cation is Na+ when NaOH is mixed with water. A liter of pure water of pH 10 from a popular processor can be made acidic with a single drop of hydrochloric acid. I did the experiment myself to the chagrin of a hapless marketeer. How does that survive the much more acidic stomach?
column10: The body strictly maintains blood pH between limits on its own through homeostatic buffering mechanisms. If blood pH ever crosses the range 7.35 - 7.45 you will suffer acidosis or alkalosis respectively, which are life-threatening medical conditions. This won't happen however, unless you have some underlying cause of disease.This is why all "pH health water" is pseudoscientific bunk.  Embed QuoteAnswered in twenty-two minutes.

column9: As in, levels below those needed to produce any physiological effects?Personally, I'm far more worried about particulate matter and other VOCs. Some of them accumulate and some of them do long-lasting damage to cell membranes and DNA. Meanwhile, CO is nontoxic to plants and doesn't do damage to cell membranes/DNA. It's acutely toxic (just because it takes up hemoglobin slots that oxygen would otherwise take up), but people have already adopted safety measures for the acutely toxic things. They just systematically underestimate the risk from the things that aren't acutely toxic, but that can do long-lasting damage.Yes, I know that sublethal doses of CO can be bad. But these are related to oxygen deprivation and not the effects of CO itself. To the extent that CO doesn't significantly depress the body's usage of oxygen, I don't worry about it as much as I worry about the VOCs and particulate matter.But, I'd really like to see anyone else who might say something else.
column10: In the UK, in Post-Mortems (autopsy) we do not routinely screen for Carbon Monoxide in the blood (COHb) , we do not know how big a problem it is. A good document is the Effects on health of prolonged exposure to low concentrations of carbon monoxide - to me it seems we are tolerant to low levels (concentrations)  of Carbon Monoxide over short periods, the real issue comes with low levels over a greater period. The drive for better insulation in the home, fuel efficiency and airtightness in building I personally believe means this issue will grow in importance. At he moment I campaign hard to just get Working Smoke Alarms and Working Carbon Monoxide Alarms into homes, but I think they will come a time, where we will have Wifi or Zigbee enabled Alarms and our iPad's (Tablets) will graph the CO in our homes over time.  Embed Quote

column9: For example, the convenience store was selling some plastic crocodiles. My 4 year-old has wanted one for days. It costs $1. It could be totally safe, or it could have lead paint on it. How do I know? There will not be a recall of this no-name product. I can't stop my kids from putting food in its mouth and then eating the food, etc. Is there any lead testing kit that anyone has used that is cheap / effective / easy?

You can hire someone to perform the testing, but even that isn't that cheap.Another option is to see if the item has already been tested - healthytoys.org provides its test results for toys it has tested using XRF testing on the web.  Embed Quote

column10: I would like to suggest that "proof of testing" is not in itself a guarantee that a product is safe. Factories in places like China, and/or their suppliers, might intentionally or accidentally make changes to a product after it has been tested. Common sense would seem to support the idea that a better known brand is probably less likely to be subject to such shortcutting or poor control than a generic (and especially, cheap) brand. But bad things have happened with bigger brand companies too. Personally I try to buy toys that are made in the US and Europe as much as possible and avoid ones with coatings such as paint.  Embed Quote

column9: For example, the convenience store was selling some plastic crocodiles. My 4 year-old has wanted one for days. It costs $1. It could be totally safe, or it could have lead paint on it. How do I know? There will not be a recall of this no-name product. I can't stop my kids from putting food in its mouth and then eating the food, etc. Is there any lead testing kit that anyone has used that is cheap / effective / easy?
column10: The lab that I used to work for tested primarily for lead in consumer products. It cost $40 for a wet chemistry (quantitative) result, and I think they charged $10-$15 for each XRF shot (rough qualifier). Honestly, if you are talking about a $1 toy, it just isn't worth it if you feel there is a risk. Walmart requires testing of all toys and various other products so that they meet CPSC guidelines.  Embed Quote

The spider venom probably doesn't last long outside the spider. Like most proteins, it degrades over time, and complex chemicals like venoms probably degrade fast. Plus, if the venom is mixing in with the enzymes in the rest of the squished spider, it will get digested. So don't worry about it.Let's say the venom does last, though. The amount of venom in a spider is tiny: they aren't made of poison, they just have a puny pair of glands in their small head. For most spiders, the venom has little to no effect on humans when injected into the skin, so it touching an open wound might not do much. Some spiders do have powerful venoms, and it's plausible that they could enter an open wound. The odds that you are encountering such a spider with a bad poison, however, and the odds that you squish it in such a way that the venom does not get digested by the squished stomach or denatured by whatever other compounds are in the spider goo, and the odds that it will enter an open wound on a foot, are all so tiny that you needn't be concerned about this.Or, you know, don't kill the spider. Be nice and shoo it outside!  Embed QuoteVia  Daniel McLaury.

It's quackery. Have a look at 'The Drugstore Detox Delusion' by the Science-Based Pharmacy blog http://sciencebasedpharmacy.word... or any of Ben Goldacre's Bad Science columns on the topic of detox http://www.badscience.net/index.... - I highly recommend his excellent book of the same name.The charity Sense About Science also produced a detox dossier highlighting the lack of evidence and also the fact that manufacturers don't appear to be able to agree what they mean when they use the word 'detox' ;) http://www.senseaboutscience.org...Save your money, tell your friends :)  Embed Quote

Detoxification in certain situations make complete sense. Drug detoxification, alcohol detoxification, even caloric restriction all have to do with getting the body back to a state where it can function in the absence of said substance. By that definition, antitoxins are also a form of detoxification. All in all, no one is going to argue that smoking less, eating healthy, drinking water, and exercise isn't going to keep you alive longer.As for dietary detoxification and methods that involve extracting "toxins" out of your body, that's more hogwash.  Embed QuoteAnswered in twenty-seven minutes.

If you use the 2 words: "alternative" and "medicine" in the same sentence, this would surely ascertain a quackery assumption.  Alternative treatments are what is used in replace of or in conjunction with conventional medicine or methodology.  There is lack of evidence in the results of body detoxes in the scientific realm.  Who wants to foot the bill of research for something that is not going to produce an increase in revenue?  In other words, if everyone's health issues were subsiding and disappearing, how can Big Pharma ever make money?  But, in the clinical and independent studies, the results are amazing.  Since there are various ways to detox, there are varying results.  I am a practicing detoxification specialist.  Every one of my clients are highly advised to consult and work with their health practitioner so that they may be monitored, especially if they are on meds or have any health issues.  My business is legit in that my protocol strictly consists of food/diet.  Remember Hippocrates?:  "Let food be thy medicine and medicine, thy food."  If helping people choose a healthy eating program to heal the body is quackery, then I guess I'm guilty!For all those out there pushing their detox products that are, in fact, unhealthy, then I can see where others regard the whole idea of detox to be just a glorified scam.  Embed Quote

Not sure of the legitimacy, but efficacy of detox is known from time immemorial. When properly performed, Ayurveda's  "Panchakarma" (five actions) is a highly effective way to detox your body. Having said this, Panchakarma is not for everyone - as Dr. Robert Svoboda says "Panchakarma is not heroics". You need to figure out whether you really need a detox, and what type of detox is required for you. You need to "study your body" under a trained Ayurvedic physician to be able to understand the effects of all the 3 ayurvedic "doshas" (forces) on your body.Just because some minds are not capable of comprehending Ayurveda & Panchakarma does not mean it is ineffective. And Ayurveda is a holistic science - there are "no size fits all" solutions to all problems. It treats everyone's body type to be unique, and every treatment or nutritional recommendation is customized according to one's body type.  Embed Quote

I interviewed Marianne Morrison of TMI Colonics for my blog a few weeks back and she has some really interesting stories of how so many people doubt colon hydroptherapy and can sometimes be downright rude about it. Echoing Anonymous' answer below, there's no doubt that detoxification is a long held practice although in varying forms. But, it's all the sh** we eat that gets stuck in our body and causes leading diseases. Our colon can be likened to our body's sewage system and a detox lessens the toxic load it has to carry. Having tried it, I can tell you that it makes me feel more energized.So what is legitimate and what is quackery? In my oversimplified opinion, something is legitimate in healthcare and medicine if it indeed makes you feel better or the side effects are less than the cost of what the medicine is preventing. This brings Adderall and the whole debate of the ADHD "epidemic" into question, but that's out of scope. Because I have tried it and because it did make me feel better after having it done, I'd call colon hydroptherapy legitimate. Whether all forms of detoxification are, I'm not sure. I'd be interested in knowing what makes a person's answer to this question "legitimate" if he/she has not had a colon cleanse or done a serious detox.If you want to read more of what Marianne has to say, here's a link to the post: TMI Colonics Keeps Your Digestion (& Humor) On Track  Embed Quote

Yes and No. There are some kinds of poison that you can become immune to with exposure (such as some snakes). Other types of poisons accumulate in the body and become more lethal as you're exposed to them more (heavy metals are an example) so you can't become immune to the latter.  Embed Quote

column9: Fruits, vegetables, meats etc.Which are toxic before cooked? Or even after cooking?What is the effect of eating too much? I know many foods have toxins from chemicals used in industrial agriculture, but I am curious about toxin which a food would have even if raised in a clean natural environment.
column10: Almonds — Well the non-domesticated variety, at least, are so unbelievably toxic that a few nibbles will land you six-feet under.  Cyanide tends to do that.    Embed Quote

column10: Raw potatoes are poisonous. Potato - Toxicity on Wikipedia. They have been breed to be less so, but a green potato is still pretty bad for you.The toxin does break down with cooking, but not entirely.Cassava/Yuca is even worse! It has to be specially prepared in order to be edible. Beyond those we have other known poisonous food items that humans still enjoy. Pufferfish, mushrooms, cashews, almonds, rhubarb.And then there are the seeds or pips in cherries, apples and peaches.  Embed Quote

column9: Fruits, vegetables, meats etc.Which are toxic before cooked? Or even after cooking?What is the effect of eating too much? I know many foods have toxins from chemicals used in industrial agriculture, but I am curious about toxin which a food would have even if raised in a clean natural environment.
column10: While not a food in and of itself, a natural contaminant that is fairly widespread is Aflatoxin. This is a known and well-characterized carcinogen (it causes liver cancer after chronic exposure and can be acutely toxic at high doses) that is  caused by fungal contamination in a wide variety of foods, like peanut butter. In fact, it is so ubiquitous in the US that many foods are monitored for aflatoxin levels to keep the contamination at safe concentrations. These compounds are fairly stable, and contamination occurs when Aspergillus infects the plant before or after harvest. Some more information on aflatoxin can be found here: Cornell University Department of Animal Science  Embed Quote

column9: Fruits, vegetables, meats etc.Which are toxic before cooked? Or even after cooking?What is the effect of eating too much? I know many foods have toxins from chemicals used in industrial agriculture, but I am curious about toxin which a food would have even if raised in a clean natural environment.
column10: Funny-looking guy, isn't he?Meet the puffer fish (Tetraodontidae). It is primarily consumed in Japan as puffer soup (fugu chiri) or raw puffer meat (sashimi fugu). If not prepared properly, it can kill you....sashimi fugu often causes intoxication, light-headedness, and numbness of the lips, and is often eaten for this reason.Pufferfish tetrodotoxin deadens the tongue and lips, and induces dizziness and vomiting, followed by numbness and prickling over the body, rapid heart rate, decreased blood pressure, and muscle paralysis. The toxin paralyzes diaphragm muscles and stops the person who has ingested it from breathing. People who live longer than 24 hours typically survive, although possibly after a coma lasting several days.From Wikipedia [1]I once saw in a documentary that people actually consider it a feat of courage to eat dishes containing puffer fish. The chefs who make it have to undergo rigorous training, and only 35% of those who apply to be professional fugu chefs pass. Trying to prepare a fugu dish at home most often leads to death.A plate of sashimi fugu. Photo from WikipediaIf you are accidentally poisoned by the puffer fish's tetrodotoxin, your stomach will be flushed and you will be fed activated charcoal to bind the toxin. You will be put on life support till the toxin wears off. [2]Sources[1] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tet...[2] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fug...  Embed Quote

BTW, foods with less toxicity seem to be consumed (in medicinal contexts) across cultures - so mildly toxic may actually be beneficial? (under some circumstances?)  Embed Quote

column9: Myth #1 Conventional medicine and the healthcare system helps                 sick people.                    Perhaps the                 biggest health myth  today is the public's misconception that mainstream                  medicine and the healthcare system helps sick people. Nothing could                  be further from the truth.                       The freedom of people to choose natural healing,  alternative medicine                 and methods of disease prevention  could soon be threatened by corporate                 lobbyists who will  do anything to protect their wealth at the expense                 of  your health.                    Promoters of                 conventional  medicine claim that all the drug studies, approvals,                  surgical procedures,  all other treatments are based                 on  scientific evidence.  But is it really science? What passes for  "science"                 today is a collection of health myths,  half-truths, intellectual                 dishonesty and  fraudulent  reporting to help serve higher interests. Science is not really science anymore.                    90 percent of                 all diseases  (cancer, diabetes, depression, heart disease, etc.)                 are  easily preventable through diet, nutrition, sunlight and exercise.                  None of these solutions are ever promoted by conventional  medicine                 because they make no money.                    No pharmaceuticals                 actually cure  or resolve the underlying causes of disease. Even                  "successful" drugs only manage symptoms, usually at the                  cost of interfering with other physiological functions that will                  cause side effects down the road. There is no such thing as a  drug                 without a side effect.                    There is no                 financial incentive  for anyone in today's system of medicine (drug                  companies, hospitals, doctors, etc.) to actually make patients well.                  Profits are found in continued sickness, not wellness or  prevention.                    Almost all                 the "prevention"  programs you see today (such as free                 mammograms or other  screening programs) are nothing more than  patient recruitment schemes  designed to increase revenue and sickness. They use free screenings                  to scare people into agreeing to unnecessary treatments that  only lead to further disease. Mammography is a very good example. Chemotherapy is another. Nobody has any                 interest in your health except you. No  corporation, no doctor, and                 no government has any desire  to actually make you well. This has                 served the  short-term financial interests of higher powers in the                  west very well. The only healthy, aware, critically thinking individuals                  are all 100% free of pharmaceuticals and processed  foods.YTH #2 Vaccines prevent diseases and increase immunity.                                                                  The term                     "immunization",  often substituted for vaccination,                     is false and  should be legally challenged. Medical research                     has  well established that the direct injection of foreign proteins                      and other toxic material (particularly known  immune-sensitising                     poisons such as mercury) makes  the recipient more, not less,                     easily affected by  what he/she encounters in the future. This                     means  they do the opposite of immunize, commonly even preventing                      immunity from developing after natural exposure.                         The actual                     frequency of  health problems has been estimated by authorities                     to  be possibly up to 100 times, or more, greater than that reported                      by government agencies. That difference is due to the lack  of                     enforcement or incentive for doctors to report  adverse effects.                     With the anti-vaccination movements  now exposing the truth on                     the internet, the medical  community is now on high alert, defending                     their  claims and being told by vaccine manufacturers that they                      must never let their patients (or parents) think that the risks                      could outweigh the benefits, when in reality, it is  precisely                     the opposite that is true.                          The benefit risk ratio is an important  decision in anyone deciding                   whether to vaccinate or  not. Contrary to popular belief and marketing,                    childhood diseases in a developed country are not as dangerous                    as we are led to believe. Catching a particular disease does  not                   mean you willdie from it. Vaccines were actually introduced at a time when                    diseases had already declined to a low risk level. This fact is                    proven, scientifically.                          The main advances in combating   disease over  the last 200 years have been better   food and clean drinking  water...not vaccines. Improved sanitation, less overcrowded   and better  living conditions also   contribute. This is also borne out   in  published peer reviewed research which prove that vaccine did not save us.All vaccines contain sterility agents, neurotoxins, immunotoxins, and carcinogenic compounds. Some examples include formaldehyde, a carcinogen found in almost every vaccine,  neurotoxins such as monosodium glutamate, potassium                 chloride, thimerosal, sterility agents such as Triton X-100, octoxynol-10, polysorbate 80, and immuntoxins such as neomycin, monobasic potassium phosphate, sodium deoxycholate to name a few of many. It is no coincidence that the more educated you are, the less chance you will vaccinate which contradicts the misconceptions of many health  professionals who      profess that parents don't vaccinate because they are  under-educated,     poor or misinformed. Those who become fully informed  of the dangers of   vaccines never see them in the same light again, as  their motives then   become clear.                           MYTH #3 We must all focus on lowering bad cholesterol.                          Perhaps one                 of the biggest  health myths propagated in western culture and certainly                  in the United States, is the misuse of an invented term "bad                 cholesterol"  by the media and medical community. Moreover,                 a  scientifically-naive public has been conned into a fraudulent                  correlation between elevated cholesterol and cardiovascular  disease                 (CVD). Cholesterol has not been shown to  actually cause CVD. To                 the contrary, cholesterol is  vital to our survival, and trying to                 artificially lower  it can have detrimental effects, particularly                 as we age.We have become a culture so obsessed with eating foods                        low in cholesterol and fat that many health experts are now    questioning the consequences. Could we really maintain a dietary     lifestyle that was so  foreign to many of our ancestral populations    without any ill effects on our health? Many researchers are now    concluding that the answer to that question is "NO." Current data is now    suggesting that lower cholesterol levels predate the development of    cancer.The 'noddy-science' offered by marketing men to a generally                        scientifically-naive public has led many people to    believe that                     we should replace certain food choices    with specially developed                     products that can help    'reduce cholesterol'. Naturally this                     comes at a    price and requires those who can afford it to pay                        maybe four or five times what a 'typical ordinary' product might                        cost. But is this apparent 'blanket need' to strive  towards                       lowering our cholesterol justified? And,  indeed, is   it healthy?The cholesterol itself, whether being transported                     by    LDL or HDL,                     is exactly the same. Cholesterol is    simply a necessary ingredient                     that is required to  be   regularly delivered around the body for                     the    efficient healthy development, maintenance and functioning                        of our cells. The difference is in the 'transporters' (the    lipoproteins                     HDL and LDL) and both types are    essential for the human body's                     delivery logistics to    work effectively. Problems can occur, however, when the LDL particles are both                        small and their carrying capacity outweighs the  transportation                       potential of available HDL. This  can lead to more   cholesterol                     being 'delivered'  around the body with   lower resources for returning                      excess capacity to the   liver. MYTH #4 Medical screening and treatments prevent death.                          Even though the medical community advocates  for regular screenings                     for those with illnesses,  they may bring little benefit and                     may actually pose  harm to your health. This applies to almost                     every  type of medical screening for cancer and several other                      diseases. Medical screening carries an immense risk in itself,                      not only due to the damage inflicted by screening  techniques                     on the human body, but by the very nature  of medical follow-up                     protocols. These protocols  usually encourage patients to enter                     deeper into more  invasive techniques, which further cripple                     health  and lead to a very high percentage of fatalities.                          In a Swedish study of 60,000   women, 70  percent of    the mammographically detected tumors weren't   tumors at  all. These "false    positives" aren't just financial and   emotional  strains, they may also    lead to many unnecessary and   invasive  biopsies. In fact, 70 to 80 percent    of all positive   mammograms do not, upon biopsy, show any presence of cancer.                          A prostate (PSA) blood test looks for  prostate-specific                    antigen, a protein produced by the  prostate gland. High levels                    are supposedly associated  with prostate cancer. The problem                    is that the  association isn't always correct, and when it is,                    the  prostate cancer isn't necessarily deadly. Only about 3 percent of all  men die from prostate cancer. The                    PSA test usually  leads to overdiagnosis -- biopsies and treatment                    in  which the side effects are impotence and incontinence. Repeated biopsies   may spread cancer cells                    into the track formed by  the needle, or by spilling cancerous                    cells directly  into the bloodstream or lympathic system.News coverage                     of many  diseases focus too much on treatments and not enough                      on prevention, a trend that could prove risky in the long run                      for most people who don't understand how to take care of  their                     health.                           The biggest single type of story we usually  hear about on the                     news involves treatment, and  narratives lend themselves much                     better to that kind  of story. Stories about prevention, about                     people  exercising and eating right, just don’t make great                     copy.                         If our current                     treatment  approach to health continues, hundreds of years from                      now, mankind may look back at today’s “modern medicine”                      and think: “How could they have been so primitive in ideology                      and so wrong? What lack of humanitarianism in government  allowed                     the medical industries to kill people with  economically driven                     false beliefs and ideas? Why  didn’t government stop them?                     Who were the people in  charge of protecting those citizens?                                                    Preventive                     education  demands increased funding for research into new dietary,                      physical activity, behavioural, socioeconomic, environmental                      and medical approaches for the prevention of chronic  disease.                     Children who grow into teenagers and then  adults require more                     accountability for their own  well-being through health conscious                     decisions which  are motivated by proper practical and theoretical                      applications. They need to know that treatment modalities and                      pharmaceutical applications may not save their health in the                      future. Substantial political and financial  contributions are                     also imperative to invest in  prevention more effectively to                     regulate revisions  and mandate policies which affect the governing                      bodies of health and education. Any procrastination or failure                      to resolve these matters in the next decade will only lead to                      the further deterioration of human health and  healthcare systems.                     Proper leadership and effective  communication regarding these                     preventive measures  may still reverse screening/treatment trends                     and  consequently reverse this thinking to ultimately promote                      a healthier aging population.MYTH #5 Fluoride prevents tooth decay.Water fluoridation is a hoax.  Drinking any                 amount of fluoride is dangerous to your  health and has NEVER been                 proven to prevent tooth decay.  It's actually the biggest scientific                 fraud ever to be  promoted by national and international Governments.                  Fluoride has been linked to osteoporosis, cancer, auto-immune diseases,                  and even very small concentrations can disrupt DNA  repair enzymes                 by 50%.  The fluoride added to our water is a waste product of   aluminum and    phosphate fertilizer processing. And it’s not even calcium   fluoride    that appears naturally in water, but sodium fluoride, which is a    whole   different thing--and loaded with bad news.  In fact, sodium fluoride has no good news. Except for a few suspect      reports by the people selling the stuff, study after research study      proves that sodium fluoride does not protect our teeth, and it does a      number on our bones. And on other body parts, too, including our  thyroid     gland.  - Fluoride was found to be an equivocal carcinogen by the                                                    National Cancer Institute  Toxicological Program.   - Drinking fluoridated water will double the number of hip                         fractures for both older men and women.     -  Infertility in women was found to increase with water                          fluoridation.                       Food and Drug  Administration (FDA) scientists reported                         a close  correlation between decreasing total fertility rates                          in women between ages of 10 and 49, and increasing fluoride                          levels.                           - Fluoride has never been found to   effectively reducing tooth decay by any notable margin.                         No causation or even correlation was found between the level of  fluoride                         in water and dental caries in any  study.  Fluoride also attacks the pineal  gland. The pineal controls our  inner     clock, provides good sleep, works with our adrenal glands to  handle     stress, keeps the thymus gland fed and cared for, and  communicates 24/7     with the rest of the endocrine system about how  things are going.     Fluoride calcifies our pineal gland into a  non-functioning rock.                          -                          The government classifies sodium fluoride as  environmentally     hazardous waste. Anybody handling it must wear  HazMat protective gear.     Dumping it into rivers is a crime.                          Much of                     the original  proof that fluoride is safe for   humans in low doses                      was generated by A-bomb program   scientists, who had been secretly                      ordered to   provide "evidence useful in litigation"                      against   defense contractors for fluoride injury to  citizens.                       The first lawsuits against the U.S.  A-bomb program were not                       over radiation, but over  fluoride damage, the documents show.                          It seems that the healthiest  people on the planet right now are those that have deviated from the  norms of conventional medical quackery, and have migrated towards  natural health. The proof is in the pudding. Find the healthiest 5  people you know and you'll find they typically don't subscribe to the  health myths promoted by mainstream medicine. Your longevity and aging  gracefully depends on it.                                          Marco Torres is a research specialist, writer and     consumer advocate                                  for healthy lifestyles. He holds     degrees in  Public         Health     and                     Environmental Science  and       is a         professional     speaker on topics                    such   as   disease           prevention,     environmental toxins  and health     policy.Okay I am skeptik about the first two, but the last one is really bothering me the most...The water full of carcinogen..? Could it be true?
column10: Virtually all information presented by these people is false or deliberately misleading. They are charlatans. They employ scare tactics to drive up their page views, then sell advertising space to the true snake oil salesmen. Sorry, but if it's from a site that posts these conspiracy theories it's wrong or it's information perverted to sound convincing. They are scum.1. This is where alarm bells ring. "Mainstream medicine" he says, like there are valid alternatives. Then of course he sets the scene, this one is not about being truthful, it's about setting up the pitch. He needs to convince you the legion of people who are going to school, working 18 hour days and breaking their backs to give care to the ill are EVIL, because if they weren't pure satan excrement how could you believe they are part of a vast conspiracy to make (and keep) people sick. He also attacks science, because when he makes later arguments, science will not help his cause. Like I said, this is just groundwork though and is meant to reach out to those who follow alternative medicine. You can tell from his mentioning of them as realistic option, and his mention of "the vast corporate hegemony" attacking it.He mentions how exercise, diet and sunlight are the three things you need to be healthy. But he implies that doctors don't tell people these things, like it's some kind of huge secret the way most of us live is unhealthy.Of course he finishes with "the only healthy people are the ones who don't take medicine" which makes me think he's not all that good at this. Or thinking in general.2. Vaccines! I just have no words for this one. Is taking yearly flu vaccinations over the top? Shit, probably, just get the flu and run the chance of death you pussy. Vaccines for kids? In my day kids dropped like flies and you know what? We liked it that way! Helped the cream rise to the top!Seriously though this is mostly propaganda. He makes an appeal to intelligence (smart people don't vaccinate). He fully embraces the science he rejected earlier because it proves his point and he uses the anti-vaccination network as proof there is something wrong with vaccinations. That's like saying since the KluKluxKlan exists, black people are subhuman.3. Fuck you Mr Writer AND fuck the doctors. I'll eat what I like and get a bypass. (At least I am honest.)4. Medical testing doesn't save lives???   Maybe he's right, I assume cancer just goes away if you don't check for it.Like pulses in babies. I did get a little hot under the collar when he talked about the results of prostate cancer and tried to say the "negative side effects" were worth leaving the cancer untreated. "Don't check for cancer, it might spread the cancer through your system" he said that. He fucking said it. Not me. Him.5. Helps teeth, only causes the symptoms he mentioned at ludicrously higher doses than we receive. Based off tests on children in India exposed to huge chemical contamination. Since he's using the suffering of children to sell bottled water, is he evil?Yes. Yes he is.  Embed Quote

column9: Can you detect a drugged drink?
column10: It depends.This may interest you:In various studies of women who have reported they thought they were given such substances, only a tiny minority have tested positive. In most cases it is assumed that the women mistook the effects of alcohol for date rape drugs.[3][4]*So yes, alcohol has a distinctive taste, and it is a drug, as Karen has written.Rohypnol has no taste or smell.Other drugs used in DFSA include hypnotics such as zopiclone or the widely available zolpidem (Ambien), sedatives such as neuroleptics (anti-psychotics) Quetiapine "Seroquel" or Ziprasidone "Geodon", chloral hydrate or some histamine H1 antagonists, recreational drugs such as ethanol, marijuana, ecstasy, cocaine and LSD, and anticholinergics,barbiturates, ketamine, cough suppressant ingredient dextromethorphan, opioids and nasal spray ingredient oxymetazoline.[6][11] Some may taste bitter, and of course, not all are orally administered. *Researchers note that the media scare in the 90's has left a permanent misconception about date rape drug usage: In a 2008 study by the University of Kent, researchers found that young female students often “mistakenly linked sickness, blackouts and dizziness to poisoning by a stranger — when it was likely to be caused by excessive alcohol consumption.”[44] Commenting on the research, Nick Ross, chair of the Jill Dando Institute of Crime Science, confirms that many women’s fear of being drugged — or belief that they have been — is unfounded. “There is no evidence of widespread use of hypnotics in sexual assault, let alone Rohypnol, despite many attempts to prove the contrary.” Though excessive fear and protective measures had significantly subsided by the late 2000s relative its peak in the late 1990s, a 2009 Australian study found that of 97 instances of patients admitted to the hospital believing their drinks might have been spiked, tests were able to detect drugs in none.[40]Some scholars claim that this extensive coverage has created or amplified a moral panic[45] rooted in societal anxieties about rape, hedonism and the increased freedoms of women in modern culture. Researchers say it has given a powerful added incentive for the suppression of party drugs,[42] has inappropriately undermined the long-established argument that recreational drug use is purely a consensual and victimless crime, has threatened to seriously curtail women's sexual and social freedoms, and by shining a spotlight on premeditated clearly predatory behaviour, has relieved the culture from having to explore and evaluate more nuanced forms of male sexual aggression towards women, such as those displayed in date rapes that were not facilitated by the surreptitious administration of drugs.[46]Source: Date rape drug  Embed QuoteVia  W. Anh.

column9: Can you detect a drugged drink?
column10: Depends on the sedative. In high-school we tried to prank a friend by putting a sedative one of us stole from his grandmother in his bottle of water. We saw the trick in movies and we were eager to see him falling asleep in class. Would have been a blast. It seems that the pill was horrible bitter. He almost puked from the first sip. It was childish, stupid, immature for us to try such a prank. If you are doing it, don't be surprised if it has serious consequences. You can harm someone. You become a criminal and you could go to jail for a long while.  Embed Quote

column9: Can you detect a drugged drink?
column10: Apparently not, if the drug is roofies.  Page on medicinenet.com I'm too old (at least in my mind) to be drinking alcohol in bars with people I don't know.  I can see how it would be easy to drug a drink in a lot of situations, though.Of course, alcohol in the greatest sedative that is delivered in drink form, and people taste it all the time, and don't acknowledge the sedative effect.  Embed QuoteVia  W. Anh.

column9: Specifically for chemotherapy and targeted cancer therepy
column10: Drugs are very varied things. Within subclasses of medicines, drugs may share the same toxicological profiles (i.e. Statins have the same bio-clearance, analgesics have similar half-life profiles). But the reasons why one group 'fails' in a clinical trial will be different to another. There are many different stages to a clinical trial. They are normally referred to as 'phases'. Clinical trials involving new drugs are commonly classified into fouror five phases. Each phase of the drug approval process is treated as aseparate clinical trial. The objectives of a phase 0 clinical trial are toestablish at the very earliest opportunity-before large numbers of patientshave been accrued and exposed to potential drug-associated toxicity-whetherfurther clinical development is warranted. Phase I trials are the first stage of testing in human subjects and these typically involve a small group (20-60) of healthy volunteers. The safety (pharmacovigilance), tolerability, pharmacodynamics and other attributes of a drug are determined before the number of volunteers and strength/dose of the drug is scaled up through the other phases. Phase II trials are performed on larger groups of people and even larger more varied groups (anywhere from 250-2,000) are used for phase III trials. Most drugs fail in phase II. Many drug failures are caused by unforeseen side effects. Introducing the drug to a more varied population also bring sup situations, circumstances and problems researchers may otherwise not have been able to test for. Much like with beta testing of software.A drug can also fail because the disease does not work the way the investigator thinks. Again, results from a narrow group of volunteers in the earlier trials will vary much more when the drug is exposed to other people (i.e. not mice or computer models).  Embed Quote

Around 7 p.m. on a cold Chicago evening (January 2004), I arrived home a bit surprised that dinner was not already underway. My wife was in the bedroom with our 2 year old toddler. She said he had gotten sleepy under the dining room table and now seemed pretty listless. She thinks maybe he has a cold. She also mentioned that our 8 year old had gone to lie down, complaining of a headache. But she herself didn't seem inclined to get up. So I went to check on him...Our older child was lying on his bed. He seemed a bit weird to me. Not quite sleeping, but I couldn't rouse him either. He'd open his eyes -- but not wake up, though he did moan or make sounds.The situation with our children struck me as odd. However, when I went back  to my wife, she seemed even less inclined to talk it through. She also felt headachy, nauseous, and just wanted to rest. (She tells me that she remembers thinking, oh, this is what a panic attack feels like. She never had one, but she figured she should lie down and be calm!! )Part of me wanted to eat dinner alone, but it just seemed so strange  for them to be so sleepy. It was like they were drugged and I didn't get it. Just thinking about it seemed to make me feel spacey myself. It felt difficult to think clearly; somehow the apartment seemed stuffy to me. It occurred to me that maybe I would catch the same bug and I felt  faint. Feeling spooked, I opened up the window, stuck my head out and gulped the freezing air. It occurred to me to call a friend for advice. I tried calling one friend. Then I called our downstairs neighbor. (We're on the top, 3rd floor of a 6 flat building.) She told me that her daughter had felt really faint, so they had opened their windows. She said the gas people came by earlier and found a problem...Suddenly, I kicked into high gear. It was like being pumped simultaneously with an anesthetic and adrenaline. First, I snatched the baby, ran downstairs to the foyer, left him on the cold floor, banged on the apartment doors and  screamed for help, and immediately ran back upstairs for the 8 year old. I managed to hoist him into a fireman's carry and brought him down. Started to run back upstairs. But I felt weak and realized that I might be unable to carry down my wife and would just pass out. So I ran barefoot out the building and into the snowy-slushy street. I stopped the one car. Felt focused and desperate. Fortunately, there was a big guy nearby who got the point. He went with me upstairs and carried my wife downstairs.My head cleared fairly quickly in the cold. My wife and older son were able to walk, assisted, by the time the ambulance arrived. They all did fine after some oxygen and rest.P.S. Unlike a gas leak, the CO emissions from the broken furnace exhaust had no smell. It can cause irreversible brain damage and death. We got a CO detector for our apartment the next day...Update. Since many folks are reading this post, it seems appropriate to add some basic info on prevention:Carbon Monoxide Information Center: CO Alarms (Consumer Protect Safety Commission, USA)Top CO & smoke alarm Reviews | Best CO & smoke alarm – Consumer ReportsNot for Reproduction

I recently came home to my flatmate having left the oven on for two days while we were both out of town. Of course, I didn't know that at the time. All I knew was that the apartment was kind of warm. I was pretty exhausted from a transcontinental flight, and had been planning on taking a nap after checking email, but didn't after it became apparent something was wrong. I felt extremely nauseous and dizzy and started getting a terrible "head going to explode" headache. Like I said, I was really tired, but when I started to realize that I felt like I was going to pass out, I called up a friend, told him that I was alone in my apartment and felt like I was going to pass out, and asked him to routinely check up on me to make sure I was conscious. He asked me what he should do if I don't pick up, and I told him to call 911. I think he was put off by how chill I was, but agreed. Since I couldn't concentrate on work and wanted to stay awake, I decided to stay on my feet and do housework. When I was cleaning my kitchen I figured out that the oven was on. I turned off the oven, opened all the windows, and turned on some fans. Then I called my friend, who told me to go to the hospital, so I called the hospital, who told me to call 911, so I called 911 and the firefighters and paramedics came to my apartment.Everything was fine in the end, but it really ruined my day.  Embed Quote

The Vermont winter was long and cold. I had cabin fever (too much time indoors) and just had to get out for awhile so I drove 45 minutes to the movie theater in town.The road salt had eaten away at the bottom of my vehicle and I could see the road through the holes.  I had the heat set on high and, of course, the windows were closed.  I think that the salt finally corroded enough of the exhaust system so that there were holes in the pipe and exhaust fumes got into the vehicle's cabin.As I was driving along, I started to become disoriented, nauseous, dizzy and developed a headache.  Because the symptoms were so gradual, I didn't make an immediate connection to the leaky exhaust.  Fortunately, the roads were fairly empty so I didn't have an accident.  When I finally arrived at the theater, I got out of the car and experienced one of the most piercing headaches of my life. I wobbled to the theater door.  My face was numb (but not from the cold) and I could barely talk.The fresh air did revive me somewhat then it dawned on me; I had CO poisoning.  I remembered from one of my chemistry courses that CO has an affinity for red blood cells that is several hundred times greater than oxygen.  I was breathing, but I wasn't absorbing enough oxygen.I sat through the movie and eventually recovered.  On the long way back, I opened all the windows and froze; this time I was numb with the cold.  The temperature was well below zero F.I had the vehicle repaired the next day.  I also installed a CO detector in my house which can emit an incredibly loud ear piercing noise.  Embed Quote

My father and I went to our lake house to do some repairs and prepare for the next tenants one winter night. When we got to the house we found it was warm and realized the heat had been left on from the previous tenants over a week ago. Even though we planned to work on the house that night, we decided instead to sit and watch a movie. About 30min into the movie, my father decided to go to bed. I fell asleep on the couch soon after, too tired to go to my bed. I woke up because my heart was racing and I had sweat through my clothes. I was convinced that I must have the flu. I called to my father and he called back that he was getting out of bed but he never came. I tried to get up but my body was too heavy. I went back to sleep, but woke up again in the same state, so again I called to my father, but this time he didn't answer. I forced myself up and went to his room to find him unconscious. I found his cell phone and called 911, telling them that both my father and I were very ill and I mentioned I also thought I was having a panic attack because my heart was beating extremely fast. The dispatcher told me to take deep breaths and I subsequently went unconscious, as well. I woke up to firemen in the room opening the windows and shouting about carbon monoxide. Waking up, I remember that I was soaking wet in sweat, my heart was beating rapidly, and I felt terrified, which I think is partially attributed to the confusion I was feeling. I also could not feel my body, and moving was very difficult. My father was still unconscious and on a stretcher, and I was picked up and carried out. In the ambulance my father woke up and was actually angry, insisting he was only asleep and he wanted to go back to bed. I remember that his face was unusually red, which I later found out was a symptom of carbon monoxide poisoning. The paramedics explained to him that he was poisoned and that if I didn't call 911 we would have been dead within 30min. They told us that the concentration of carbon monoxide in his bedroom was the highest they had ever seen, 1000ppm, measured after the windows were opened. In the hospital, our oxygen saturation was found to be very low, and we were treated in hyperbaric oxygen chambers. We were discharged after about one day.What I find unusual about carbon monoxide poisoning is that my father and I had very different reactions. He is elderly and fell asleep very calmly, and also woke up much more disoriented and confused than I did. I, 25 at the time, was showing severe flu-like symptoms, and was waking up from sleep due to those symptoms. My understanding of the event is clearer than my fathers, and my memory of the event is more accurate. The reason the house filled with carbon monoxide is because there was a leak to the basement that corroded a hole into the furnace, which had been left on for an extended period. The batteries from the carbon monoxide detector were removed by the last tenant, likely because it was going off.  Embed Quote

One winter when I was a kid my grandmother took me to a friend’s place somewhere in Russian countryside. The house had a really old furnace used for heating and if you left it on for too long, you got CO poisoning. One night I got vigorously shaken awake; I was sitting down and I wasn't where I fell asleep. Our family friend told me that I got poisoned by gas to which I only said “I did what?” As I sat there, head aching, ears ringing and all, it slowly started sinking in… but it didn't have any gravity. It’s the same kind of feeling you get when you’re very sleep-deprived. Everything is really slow, except you no longer feel like a participant, you feel like a spectator. It’s the same feeling you get when you faint – you kind of “let go” and whatever happens to you feels really far away and irrelevant. Apparently our family friend woke up in the middle of the night and realised that she’d left the furnace on. She slept in a different part of the house so the gas didn't affect her. I guess that if she didn't randomly wake up that night, I wouldn't be answering this question today.  Embed Quote

Hillel's description of acute high level CO poisoning is better than most textbooks.But much more common is chronic repeated low level CO poisoning that never produces acute symptoms and so never gets emergency treatment.Chronic CO poisoning is called The Great Imitator because it causes symptoms of so many other disorders by which it is commonly "missed"-diagnosed, including autism in children and CFS/FM/IBS/MCS in adults.So how to know if easily tested and treated CO poisoning is the cause in any particular case?Easy: if chronic symptoms include multi-sensory sensitivity to odors, lights, sounds, touch and tastes, (=MUSES syndrome), because CO is the only known cause.Bad news is that CO effects last as long as tissues retain more CO than normal. It is much easier to wash out a few hours of acute high level CO poisoning than weeks or months of repeated low level exposures.Good news is that MUSES and many other chronic symptoms of CO poisoning are easily tested, treated and reversed even years and decades after their initial poisoning.It might be difficult to find a doctor who already knows this, but hang in there and keep explaining.The appropriate test to confirm acute current or chronic past CO poisoning is not arterial OR venous carboxyhemoglobin (=COHb) but BOTH and from the same elbow or wrist.While acutely exposed to CO and for up to one hour thereafter:aCOHb>>vCOHbbecause more CO is going into your tissues than coming out.But after exposure ends, arterial COHb falls faster than venous and this gap flips. So in the "chronic" phase as more CO diffuses (very slowly) out of tissues:aCOHb < vCOHb.This abnormal unhealthy condition may last years or even decades unless and until properly treated.Arterial and venous CO levels and even the average level of CO in tissues can be measured non-invasively in exhaled breath using any (small and portable) professional CO detector that displays accurately from zero.You can do this at home--no doctor or lab is needed--but not with a home CO detector because they are both inaccurate and prohibited by UL and CSA stds from displaying below 30ppm (except in recall mode when they may show recorded peaks as low as 10ppm, which is still not low enough for breath analysis).So BEWARE if you have a home CO alarm --> when it displays "O" , the actual level may be anywhere from 0 to 29ppm. In contrast, the EPA avg. limit for outdoor exposure is only 9ppm.  Embed Quote

Every industrial activity has impacts on the environment, so in general it is not possible to make any product that "does not have any impact on the environment," even if that product is 100% recyclable AND is recycled. (note those are two different things).  Recycling itself has impacts as well.If you ever read a piece of marketing information that says a product has "zero impacts," know that the author is lying to you.  It is possible for management of a product at end of life to potentially avoid impacts equal to (or even greater than) the impacts caused by creating the product.  But that is emphatically not the same thing as not having had an impact in the first place.You can avoid the most egregious toxic impacts from waste electronics by ensuring that they are recycled responsibly- or even reused.  The biggest threat presented by waste electronics is in informal recycling, common in impoverished areas in Asia, where electronics are melted down to recover copper and trace quantities of gold and other metals.  The base metals, flame retardants, and other substances used in producing these products are often leached into the soil or groundwater in these areas, leading to contamination and public health concerns for decades.  On the other hand, the recovered resources may provide the only source of livelihood for a family or village, so removing access to the waste can be harmful.  The best outcome would be for people to understand how to extract valuable materials from waste electronics safely.  But that requires industrial technology that may be expensive, possibly putting it out of reach of the impoverished people presently doing the informal recycling.  The problem is pernicious.Informal electronic waste recycling: A sector review with special focus on ChinaThe challenge of electronic waste (e-waste) management in developing countriesUnfortunately, these articles are paywalled.. but interesting if you can get your hands on them.  Embed Quote

No. It is completely impossible to build a 100% recyclable computer/phone/tablet which does not have any impact on the environment given the existing technologies and those for the forseeable future.  Embed Quote

Ralph Eckstein's post right above me was the article I was going to link to. Most electronics will have an impact on the environment. You have to consider the energy it takes to make the product, use the product, and recycle the product. Let's say that we can find a way to use all recyclable materials in a computer. The one in the link above is a good start. Energy and resources are still necessary to manufacture the computer. Now when you use the computer, you are using electricity, which is a resource. Now let's say we find a way to use a "green" energy source like solar power or wind power. That would lesson the impact. However, using the internet also takes resources. Think of all of the internet servers that run 24/7. That consumes a lot of energy. All of those consume a lot of energy. Last but not least, the recycling of a products uses energy as well. Machines are required to take apart and sort the materials, after all, and that requires energy.For the time being, the best thing to do is to reduce the amount of electronics you buy, and when you no longer want/ need something, donate it or take it to a recycler who will try to refurbish it. The company I work for, All Green Electronics Recycling (If you're curious, check out http://allgreenrecycling.com), refurbishes electronics whenever possible. If that is not possible, we'll break down and refurbish/ reuse individual parts. If that's not possible, we sort and break down the materials and send them back to manufacturers to be reused. So any steel we recover would be sent back to a steel manufacturer and so on. It does use resources and impact the environment, I won't deny that, but with our current technology, it is impossible to avoid doing so. Consider this though: More energy is typically required to manufacture a computer than to use it. And it actually is quite cost- and energy-efficient to refurbish computers. Plus it can help out someone who can't afford a brand-new computer.  Embed Quote

Great question. Recyclability of a product is one  of many factors that have an impact on the environment. A product starts with mining of natural resources which has an impact on miners and the environment. Then it is manufactured which has an impact on factory workers and environment. Then it is distributed air, ship, and trucks that run on gasoline. Then it is sold and retail spaces have impact on environment. Then it is used and the energy it takes to run the device and servers has an impact on environment. And we still don't know if heavy use of these products have an impact on human health. Then all of this embodied energy is measured up against the durability of the product - how long it lasts. And finally we look at where the product goes when user throws it away. Often it goes to China were poor people disassemble it for precious metals and expose themselves to horrible toxins in the process. On the other hand, some are arguing that these devices enable wonderful social and educational benefits. And we don't know how to measure those against environmental impact. My hope is that an increase in the ubiquity of 3D printing will empower users to build and upgrade their own devices. If this happens, a lot of the product life cycle stuff that I mentioned before - manufacturing and distribution specifically - falls away.  Embed Quote

No it is not possible to make electronic gadgets without any toxic materiel.. but when they become unworthy for you you can recycle them for to at electronic recycling companies and their recycling process is completely environment friendly.. just laptoplobster.com does in UK, so many other companies in different nation provide recycling for the electronic gadgets.. also they provide cash for old electronic gadgets..  Embed Quote

No I don't think it is possible to build 100% environment friendly electronic gadgets. some of part will be containing toxic materiel but doing recycling will help to save the environment. some companies are doing e-waste recycling. Like if you want to go with the laptop recyling then http://sell-your-laptop.co.uk is good place for your. you will more options if you want to sell yor old tablets and phones also. but i don't think it is next to impossible to build a 100% envrionment friendly electronic gadgets,  Embed Quote

Like others are saying, it is not possible.  The current components are not "environmentally friendly".  The best way to dispose of a computer/electronic is to have it recycled by a professional.  This will reduce the "footprint".  I have used these guys before.  http://www.universalrecyclers.com/  Embed Quote

http://blog.ausgefallene-ideen.c...here you can have a look at the almost 100% recyclable laptop. ;) But the main problem is, that until now it is not possible to build a totally recyclable CPU or display, which hasn't impact on the environment. note: pay attention with spilling coffee on it :-/   Embed Quote

First off, I have no idea what this question means. Are you asking if a lizard surfing walls is dangerous? (It certainly could be, for the lizard!) If you could rephrase it to something more intelligible, then that would be great. I'm going to assume you're not a native English speaker though so I'll try to assume you're wondering if a lizard you saw is dangerous.For further identification it would help if you told me where you were from, but to answer your question, most lizards are NOT dangerous and their bite will NOT harm you. In fact, their first reaction towards you isn't to bite at all, but to flee. Lizards are very good for controlling bugs around your house and many can be quite friendly!The only lizard that presents any kind of severe danger to humans is the Komodo Dragon. They reach the length of a human and one bite will kill you, but they only live on a couple islands north of Australia. Other large lizards are capable of inflicting wounds if provoked, but none of them are fatal.So in summary, no, the lizard you saw is not dangerous :)  Embed Quote

column9: For example Typhoid Mary famously poisoned many people or the Great Chicago Fire was started by O'Leary's cow (yes I know it's an urban legend and not a person but you get the idea).
column10: When I saw this question, I thought of an incident that happened that involved the destruction of just one tree. So, of course, this incident can't compare with accidents that caused large scale loss of human life, or massive destruction of nature. Still, there is something about it that resonated for me, when I saw this question.In 1964, a graduate student was given permission to study an ancient Bristlecone pine tree among a grove of such trees in what would later be designated Great Basin National Park, Nevada.
