The tree may have been as much as 5000 years old, but seems to have been definitely over 4000 years old. One of the oldest living organisms in the world. It's name was Prometheus.What exactly happened is disputed, but the Forrest Service seems to have given the student permission either to cut down the tree entirely, or cut sections from it. There may have been a failure  at the time to understand how old this particular tree was.  At any rate, ultimately, the entire tree was cut down and destroyed.Because the damage involved just one tree, to me it seems more stunning (or easier to grasp the tragedy of), somehow, than more widespread destruction. You can read more about this story here:The Prometheus StoryPrometheus (tree)  Embed Quote

column9: For example Typhoid Mary famously poisoned many people or the Great Chicago Fire was started by O'Leary's cow (yes I know it's an urban legend and not a person but you get the idea).
column10: In most manmade disasters that cause lots of damage, the accidents happen because of multiple systems failing at once, all of which makes it difficult to attribute the disaster to one person.  On the other hand, there are some man made disasters where the immediate cause can be traced back to one person, even if other causes may have played role.If you are talking about loss of life, then the most damage traceable to a mistake by one person is the Tenerife airport disaster.  On March 27, 1977, the Royal Dutch Airlines pilot, Jacob Veldhuyzen van Zanten, was taxiing KLM Flight 4805 down Runway 30 at Gran Canaria Airport in Tenerife in the Canary Islands.  Air traffic control gave Captain Veldhuyzen van Zanten some instructions that advised him to take a right turn after taking off, but did not explicitly grant him clearance to take off.  Unfortunately, the captain misinterpreted the instructions from air traffic control to mean that he had been given clearance to take off, even though another plane was still in the way.  Veldhuyzen van Zanten couldn't see the other plane ahead because of a foggy runway and, as a result, KLM Flight 4805 crashed during takeoff into a Pan Am flight that was still on the runway.  The resulting collision killed 583 people.  Fans of Breaking Bad might remember Walter White mentioning the Tenerife airport disaster at a school assembly in the first episode of the third season.  Ironically, before becoming the primary cause of the Tenerife airport disaster, Captain Jacob Veldhuyzen van Zanten was such a well-respected pilot and flight instructor for Royal Dutch Airlines that the company featured him prominently in one of its ad campaigns.  When executives at KLM found out about the collision, they immediately wanted Captain Veldhuyzen van Zanten to chair the accident investigation, without realizing that the captain was the primary cause of the accident himself.If you're talking about property damage instead of loss of life, then the most damage traceable to a mistake by one person is probably the Exxon Valdez oil spill.  At the time the Exxon Valdez ran aground, the captain of the ship, Joseph Hazelwood, was below deck sleeping off a hangover.  The third mate tried to prevent the ship from colliding with a nearby reef, but the ship's radar was not working.  Nobody got killed, but 11 million gallons of oil spilled into Prince William Sound, Alaska, damaging approximately 1300 miles of coastline and 11,000 square miles of ocean.  According to the International Tanker Owners Pollution Federation Limited, total costs from the Exxon Valdez oil spill have been estimated to be as much as 7 billion dollars.  Joseph Hazelwood never captained another ship again, but got a job working as a maritime law consultant for the law firm that represented him.  Embed Quote

column9: For example Typhoid Mary famously poisoned many people or the Great Chicago Fire was started by O'Leary's cow (yes I know it's an urban legend and not a person but you get the idea).
column10: "In 1893, Michael Ahern, the Chicago Republican reporter who wrote the O'Leary account, admitted he had made it up as colorful copy." - this is from the very same Wikipedia article. There is no consensus on whether Mrs. O'Leary's cow actually started fire by kicking the lantern.Since we are here, may I mention an even more fictionalised scenario? Behold: General D. Ripper, the man, who has singlehandedly brought the end to the human civilisation as we know it by being completely and utterly batshit insane.P.S. I am sure there will be plenty of good answers here, so I am just having a wee fun for the sake of PURITY OF ESSENCE!  Embed QuoteAnswered in thirty minutes.

column9: I'm extremely interested in scientific sources that positively link exposure to Agent Orange as a causative factor for serious health problems.http://www.johntreed.com/agentor...
column10: My understanding was that the intended active ingredients in Agent Orange itself were toxic but no more dangerous than many other types of herbicides in use at the time - and, I might add, now.  It's important to remember that all chemicals - including water - are toxic, but it is simply a matter of dosage.  Pesticides and herbicides tend to be more toxic than many other types of compounds, but it's important to remember that the exposures to these types of chemicals tend to be limited and heavily regulated.  I'm not saying that 2,4,5-T and 2,4-D (the two herbicides in Agent Orange) were "safe" or ought to have been used, but it's worth pointing out that thought 2,4,5-T has been banned*, 2,4-D continues to be one of the most widely used herbicides in the world.   However, when we refer to "Agent Orange" we are actually referring to what was shipped to and dropped on Viet Nam, and in that we deal with the actual mixture, not just what was intended.  The major source of toxins is now supposed to have actually been the enormously negligent contamination of delivered agent orange with tetrachlorodibenzodioxin (TCDD), which is an  extraordinarily toxic compound of the family commonly known as dioxins and a persistent organic pollutant.  I believe it is TCDD that is the source of the vast majority of liability claims from Agent Orange.  TCDD exposure's effects have been widely known due to the aftermath of an industrial accident in Seveso, Italy, in 1976 where about 1 kg of TCDD released over 18 square km of area caused high levels of adverse health effects.  Yeah, this stuff is very toxic. This disaster was so prominent that many industrial safety regulations in the EU are named after it. * this is a common fate for many pesticides once used in the world and is by no means restricted to 2,4,5-T, though I have no idea of its toxicity relative to other banned substances; as toxicity data has gotten better and people's tolerance for toxins has become lower, many pesticides have been slowly restricted in use or banned completely. For another very recent example, look to ethylene bis(dithiocarbamate)s or EBDCs, a fungicide family which was recently banned in Europe  Embed Quote

column9: I'm extremely interested in scientific sources that positively link exposure to Agent Orange as a causative factor for serious health problems.http://www.johntreed.com/agentor...
column10: Agent Orange was a 1:1 mixture of 2,4-Dichlorophenoxyacetic acid and 2,4,5-Trichlorophenoxyacetic acid.As for 2,4,5-Trichlorophenoxyacetic acid: 2,4,5-Trichlorophenoxyacetic acid & Embryotoxic effects in mice treated with 2,4,5-trichlorophenoxyacetic acidIt's somewhat surprising, somewhat depressing, that the country on this planet, which preaches any other nation to review their history most, lacks exactly this.  Embed Quote

column9: I'm extremely interested in scientific sources that positively link exposure to Agent Orange as a causative factor for serious health problems.http://www.johntreed.com/agentor...
column10: Plenty of birth defects - even generations later, example among Vietnamese immigrants in the US. Case for some international court.  Embed Quote

column9: I'm extremely interested in scientific sources that positively link exposure to Agent Orange as a causative factor for serious health problems.http://www.johntreed.com/agentor...
column10: Further to Anonymous's answer, I found the wikipedia article: 2,4,5-Trichlorophenoxyacetic acid very informative in this matter.  Embed Quote

Talking about the other uses of phosphoric acid is irrelevant. Citrus extracts are used to clean soap scum, does that make oranges unsafe?  And salt water will corrode steel beams given enough time, are you worried about salt eating through your stomach? The fact is, the phosphoric acid in sodas is far too small to have any measurable adverse affect. I'd worry much more about the impact of the sugar and caffeine in the same beverage.  Embed Quote

The dose makes the poison. Even pure water can be fatally toxic if consumed far in excess of reasonable levels (eg multiple gallons in a sitting). Small amounts of phosphoric acid are harmless -- the body even uses phosphorous as an essential nutrient. Coke is actually a pretty powerful acid irrespective of the phosphoric acid content, because carbonated water is quite acidic. Soda will literally dissolve teeth away to nothing if left in contact for days or weeks. But the amount of time it spends in your mouth is too short for much acid attack to occur. (Yes, you should drink soda quickly instead of sipping it.) Saliva contains dissolved minerals that repair minor amounts of acid damage, so acidic beverages are fine to drink in moderation. Your body will quickly heal itself. Once the soda is swallowed, it mixes with stomach acid (hydrochloric acid) which is much stronger than any acidic beverage you would consume. And yes, the acid in your stomach is about as strong as commercial strippers/cleaners. The acidic soda actually dilutes the more-acidic stomach acid!  Embed QuoteAnswered in fifty-six minutes.
Both the concentration and absolute amount of acid should be taken into account in order to determine the actual efficacy.  Embed Quote

Phosphoric acid helps remineralize your teeth, which are made of calcium phosphate. This is why citrus sodas and juices make my teeth hurt if I hold them in my mouth too long, but Coke doesn't.  Embed Quote

column9: Will a venomous snake be sick if injected with its own/another snake's venom?
column10: The Naked Scientists had an episode covering this question [1]. Here is an excerpt:I did ask a snake venom researcher and he said you can also find snake  venom antibodies in snakes to their own venom, to a certain extent. They  kind of have their own antivenom built (in). Possibly because they have  exposed themselves at low level. I don’t know how protective that is so  there’s two mechanisms there why a snake doesn’t poison itself.The cobra is apparently a special case, though. Cobras produce a venom of which the principle component is neurotoxin. These neurotoxins bind to the surface of muscle cells at a receptor target. The cobra receptor serving as a target for the toxin has a different structure than the one in mammals [2].[1] Can snakes die from their own venom?[2] Why the cobra is resistant to its own venom?  Embed Quote

column9: As I understand it, scientists start off with a statistically significant sample population of an animal (such as a rat or rabbit). They then administer a calculated dose of the substance being tested such that 100% of the sample population will die.They then take a second sample population of the same animals, and administer a somewhat lower dose, measuring what percentage of the population dies as a result.They keep diminishing the dose, administering to new sample populations of the target animal, until, several sample populations and hundreds of dead animals later, a particular dose kills 50% of the population.This dose is the Lethal Dose 50, or LD50.1. Have I understood the process correctly?2. What is the experimental justification behind this particular method?3. Why all the killing?4. What does this test tell us that we can't know by other means?
column10: It has been said that the difference between a drug and a poison is dose. The point of establishing the LD50 is to find the therapeutic window which is the region in where you'll have the clinically desired result but not the clinically undesired effect.The knowledge of the EC50 is obvious. If you're not dosing the drug above the efficacious dose, you're not doing anything.You could try to figure out the Maximum Tolerated Dose (MTD). However, it's rather difficult to measure in animal studies. Were the mice extra jumpy because of the side effect or because the food was a bit weird. You may have a guess at what the MTD is and when you go into clinical trials, you will never start at a concentration above that. However, if patients aren't getting the appropriate response, you may need to escalate the dosage pass the MTD.What are suitable alternatives? You could potentially run a Cytotoxicity assay. Won't tell you anything about harmful metabolites, blood related issues, cell-specific effects, transport errors, and clearance. Maybe a CYP450 panel? Doesn't even give you that much information asides an idea that the drug gets metabolized in a certain route.The LD50 is a clear endpoint. The animals either dies or it doesn't. You don't even need to kill 100% of the animals to figure out the answer. This information is incredibly valuable because while you're doing your dose escalation, you know that you should never ever come even close to the LD50 and if the science requires you to go anywhere remotely close to that point to get the clinical response you want, that's when you look at Go/No Go list and circle No Go. During the R phase, one can look at the ratio between the LD50/ED50 to establish a Therapeutic index. A large therapeutic index is a powerful indicator that you'll have a decent compound to start human trials. A small therapeutic index suggests that you'll have a narrow window and you'll be better off with a new lead.  Embed Quote

YES DON'T DO IT.Lead acid batteries - the kind non-electric cars have - have lead and concentrated acid. Does this really need explanation?Rechargeable batteries are especially dangerous. Most of these rely on the unusual electrochemical properties of metals like nickel or cadmium or even mercury. Do any of these sound like a good idea to eat?The least dangerous in comparison are "ordinary" batteries or alkaline batteries, where the worst thing that could happen is you chew them and the acid gel or alkali gel corrodes soft tissue in your mouth and gullet and stomach lining. Or that the whole darn thing gets into your stomach and the strong acid of your stomach juices dissolves the plastic and metal casing and all that leaks out anyway.Also easily forgotten is that batteries - even when "drained" - contain a store of chemical energy. That is what they were built for! Now imagine if all that energy were suddenly released in a one fell swoop chemical reaction. That's right - major heat production. Now imagine suddenly applying lots of heat to soft tender inner organs. Also bad.In summary - eating a battery means a long and painful death by some combination of metal poisoning, chemical burns and sheer stupidity.  Embed Quote

Well, most dietary batteries are the 20mm lithium batteries given their viable size to be swallowed. Not only will they kill you, just chewing them will remove the cap locking inside them, causing them to begin leaking; it will burn your tongue and food pipe to the the point of no repair, including forming large holes.So not only do batteries kill you, chewing them might make you a puppet.  Embed Quote

I cannot believe someone asked this question?I also cannot believe the 2 responders so far have not asked why you asked?So I will..Why do you ask?If you have a child that just swallowed batteries, you need to get to an emergency center ASAP.All of the above info is true and eating a battery is deadly. If it has been chewed, you would already know things are serious as the reactions would have started immediately.If they were swallowed whole, you have time to get to a hospital and have the stomach pumped.I hope this was a theoretical question though. If someone you know has swallowed a battery I really hope they got medical attention and are doing well.  Embed Quote

Besides containing toxic chemicals, batteries are significantly sized chunks of metal and hard plastics. Having those going through the soft tissue of your digestive tract is both painful and dangerous. It could either cause a blockage or could tear the lining of the stomach or intestines. Either could potentially be fatal.  Embed Quote
The stuff in batteries is POISON.  Draw your conclusion hence.  Embed Quote
I tried it  Embed Quote

Enzyme Catalysis is responsible for Benzene's toxicity.Cytochrome P450 is a large and diverse group of enzymes catalyze the oxidation of Organic Compunds. In humans they are present primarily as membrane associated proteins.They are located either in the inner membrane of mitochondria or in the endoplasmic reticulum of cells.Cytochromes P450 catalyze the addition of a single oxygen atom to the benzene ring forming benzene oxide which is an unstable epoxide which further reacts to give other biproducts .The biproducts of the reactions are toxic as they are not excreted readily and can interact with DNA to produce harmful mutationsThis explains why Benzene is toxic.Benzene despite being very stable undergoes metabolism because of the catalyst which forms a complex which is very stable.Thus the transition state is stabilized which lowers the energy of activation which now makes the reaction kinetically feasible  .Benzene oxide being a highly unstable epoxide immediately undergoes reaction to form several products such as quinones,phenols etc.Enzyme Catalysis in the liver cells**Cytochrome P450 is denotes as CYPMechanisms which have been commonly postulated as being responsible for benzene toxicity.Two mechanisms have been commonly postulated as being responsible for benzene toxicity. Initial biotransformation of benzene takes place primarily in the liver. Most models postulate that cytochromes P450 catalyze the addition of a single oxygen atom to the benzene ring forming benzene oxide. Some of the benzene oxide becomes conjugated to glutathione via glutathione-S-transferase (GST), forming a pre-phenyl mercapturic acid that is then further biotransformed to phenyl mercapturic acid. The remaining benzene oxide is conjectured to be removed by two main pathways. At high benzene doses, most benzene oxide spontaneously rearranges to form phenol. The rest is converted to dihydrodiol intermediates by epoxide hydrolase, which are then converted to catechol by dehydrogenases. A second path that could lead to catechol is addition by P450 of another oxygen atom to phenol. Alternatively, the second OH-group may be attached across the benzene ring from the first, creating hydroquinone. P450 may add another oxygen atom to catechol converting it to 1,2,4-trihydroxybenzene. Hydroquinone can be oxidized probably via a peroxidase-catalyzed reaction, to p-benzoquinone. Catechol and benzenoxide may also be converted to trans-trans muconaldehyde which involves an opening of the benzene ring. A detoxication product of trans-trans muconaldehyde is muconic acid.Other phase II conjugation pathways are also extremely important in benzene metabolism and toxicity: e.g. extensive glucuronidation and sulphation of phenols Sources:A Mechanistic Modeling Framework for Predicting Metabolic Interactions in Complex MixturesCox, 1991; Medeiros et al, 1997; Ross, 1996; Snyder and Hedli, 1996; Yardley-Jones et al, 1991).Cytochrome  Embed Quote

While you are correct that benzene is quite stable in and of itself, benzene's toxicity is mainly a result of how it is metabolized after it enters the body.In the liver and bone marrow benzene is enzymatically oxidized and can give rise to an array of possible metabolites, primarily to benzene oxide, then off to polyphenols, hydroquinones and benzoquinones, the latter which are capable of wreaking havoc in the liver, bone marrow and cell nuclei.It has been suggested that the genotoxicity occurs through free-radical generation, which induces DNA strand breaks, and protein inhibition, leading to erroneous replication. This would explain why it is such an aggressive carcinogen.Sources:The fate of benzene-oxideAdvances in Understanding Benzene Health Effects and Susceptibility  Embed Quote

First, the cold temperature would end up freezing your stomach. Then it would warm and you have two choices, either do nothing, in which case the pressure will perforate your internal organs and perhaps collapse your lungs, or you can open your throat and continuously belch nitrogen gas during which you may suffocate as it would displace all the oxygen which is normally headed to opposite direction. Eventually your stomach would cool enough and the gas would slow and there would just be a steady flow of vapor escaping from your dead mouth.  Embed QuoteAnswered in seventeen minutes.

This is not a hypothetical: last year a student in UK did exactly this.Warning over liquid nitrogen drinks after girl loses stomach - TelegraphIt froze her stomach, then expanded rupturing it - but she was taken to hospital and survived with her stomach removed.The bar was serving cocktails with liquid nitrogen as a regular feature on their menu, but this was an unfortunate accident.  Embed Quote
This is similar to what happened in the last episode of Grey's anatomy: S09 E22The episode shows how the medical team tries to save a girl who did just that, along with some other cases.  Embed Quote

Anonymous's answer is correct.Anonymous' answerBy the way, survivors report intense pain...http://news.yahoo.com/blogs/look...http://www.wpi.edu/news/19989/ni...You may win the Darwin award.  Embed QuoteAnswered in twenty-seven minutes.

I doubt you would be able to drink it at all. Liquid nitrogen would usually be stored in a pressurized container with thick walls. You can transfer a small quantity to a cup, but then most of it would evaporate even before it hits the cup. As soon as you try to take a sip, as it comes into contact with your lips and your tongue, it would evaporate at a very high rate and build up pressure in your mouth making it impossible to swallow. And btw, in case it does manage to touch your tongue, then it would make it brittle like wafers! So the next moment, you try to move your tongue, it would just shatter and break into pieces and fall!! Now this is as good as being dead. Somehow if you manage to swallow it, it would freeze your entire internal system and you'd be dead within seconds. And if you try to move, all your internal organs being brittle due to the extremely low temps, would crack and break like a biscuit.So the answer in short--- That's probably the last thing you'd ever do!  Embed Quote

In Gordon's Bay Australia, I was stung by a box jellyfish whilst swimming alone in what initially appeared  to a beautiful deserted beach under a bright azure sky. The kind of day you want to write to someone about even on a post card.I must tell you something of the pain. The pain attacks your body at a speed that is so fast it cannot be measured. Already your lungs are paralyzed and your stomach is turned upside down. Simultaneously your tongue is trapped and quickly dries out, while your jaw slams shut and your eyes squeeze tight. Your ears go deaf. Your muscles tense in an attempt to combat the pain; then they release succumbing to its awesome power. Gravity informs your body that it is a force not to be taken for granted. Your heart strains too hard and so with the rest of your body. Every nerve ending alerts you, in the manner most suited to it, that you are being attacked. Only your consciousness works well, or well enough to remind that you are just alive. It always obeys pain. You make rash decisions as fear takes control. You miss your last allies: strength and hope as the neurotoxin enters the your body and introduces consciousness to absolute pain.Absolute pain is life's only true enemy. Only absolute pain can defeat life. It is clever and treacherous. It has no decency, respects no law or convention, shows no mercy. It attacks your blind spot, which it finds with infallible ease. It begins by sending a lightening strike through your entire body and then your mind after the damage has been done. One moment you are feeling calm, self-possessed, and happy. Then pain, without any disguise, commands your attention like you have never be called before. You don't even have time to make a  childish desperate prayer of "please, please, please!". However, disbelief tries to deny pain its authority. But disbelief is poorly armed and easily overpowered. Reason comes in an attempt to defend you; it hopes that by demanding what the cause of the pain is, it will overcome its awesome might. For less than a moment you are assured. Reason is fully equipped at dealing with almost everything; however, it is no competition in the face of pain. Pain is faster than the speed of light..there is nothing quicker than the awareness of the toxin in your body.  It wipes reason out of existence, and anything that finds itself in its path. The neurotoxin makes the matter difficult to put into words. For pain, real pain, takes away your foundation to think clearly as you are brought face to face with your maker; memory is destroyed as you are confined to that moment. A micro-second of absolute pain seems like an eternity. There are no words to accurately express the depth and breadth of pain.  It is beyond measurement, despite any scientists definition (who I can assure you have no experience of such pain). The least you can do to express the sensation is wince in silence, at best scream in agony. In my case, I screamed hoping my voice would chase the pain away.You are defeated without having the chance to put up a fight. It's almost impossible to swim, as a sense of calm courses through you body informing you to just breath in the warm water and the pain will go away.In desperation you look around you to see where the attack came from; but there were no signs of anything above the surface., because the Box Jellyfish is almost completely transparent in water and very delicate. A shrimp could easily pierce their body and consequently they have developed an exceptionally potent poison in order to prevent any foreign object penetrating them. The tentacles are armed with up to five thousand nematocysts, or stinging cells. Certain chemicals on the surface of fish, shellfish and humans activate these. The wound itself leaves a red line, tracking where the poison entered the skin and inflaming the area around it...in my case my foot was so swollen it looked like an inflatable foot..and in a short period of time the red line corrodes the skin and muscle underneath it, leaving just bone as a result of the hemotoxin.After a tremendous panic and flailing in the water, I reached the shore and walked 1 mile home and blindly sort refuge with a bag of peas on my couch in the loneliness of my apartment with faint notion of a rational thought that pain would realize it was an unwelcome guest. For forty eight hours of insanity and the fear of the continuous suffering I was then finally able to summon the strength to pick myself up and get to a hospital...(picture below is of a fatal sting and the box itself) To explain the notion of corrosion see the following linkhttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hem... For a medical definition of how the toxin effects consciousnesshttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neu... further details of box jellyfish toxin:http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubm... Gordon's Bay  Embed QuoteAnswered in thirty-two minutes.

Hi All,In December 2010 I was stung by an Irukandji box jellyfish in Malaysia. A bit of a different experience to Mark, however still a good story :)We were staying on Langkawi Island in Malaysia at the end of 2010. On one afternoon we decided to go on a sunset cruise, one which has a net off the side of the boat so you can have a 'spa' as they call it in the very warm ocean water.After having a great time for about 15 minutes, I noticed I had been stung (three marks) on the abdomen (just above the hip). At first I thought it was just a normal sting, so the captain ran vinegar on it and I wasn't very worried (I was going to get back in the water). It stung a bit, but not more than a blue-bottle which sting us a fair bit in Australia (nb: I am Australian)Thirty minutes later and my back began cramping with excruciating pain. It started from my kidney area (back only at the start) and moved up to my neck. The pain felt like every muscle in my back was cramping and I could do nothing to release it. As the pain got worse, so did my mental state. I think of myself as a pretty pain-tolerant guy but this pain made me go very weird.I thought that I was going to die. I began screaming at the boat staff to get me to a hospital ASAP. Luckily, I managed to get on a speed boat back to the port and get taken immediately to a hospital. I think it's important to note that I wasn't intentionally doing any of this, the pain was so severe and my mental state so convinced my end was looming, I literally went crazy.After getting to the hospital, I had to walk some distance, and I noticed that as I walked it didn't feel 'better' but was less intense. My mental state was so fragile, that after being told by the Langkawi Doctor that "there aren't any dangerous jellyfish in langkawi" so we'll just "give you a few injections" I literally ran away from the hospital (when my girlfriend went to the bathroom). I was delirious and hallucinating as I ran away from the hospital and I still cannot explain why I was acting that way.So after I had run away from the hospital, we were driven back to my resort (Berjaya - the other end of Langkawi island!). I was still in excruciating pain, however, I was convinced I could 'fight it'. To cut a long story short, two hours later of rediculuous pain and still more weird behaviour I needed pain killers. So back to the hospital we went (another 30 min ride). This time my 'head' was back to normal and I had one anti histamine injection and two pain killing injections. The pain lessened a bit, but was still very sore. I was mentally and physically drained and asked to leave the hospital with some pain killing tablets.That night in bed, (6 hours after the sting and after the injections above) I was still very sore, but mentally I was 'back'. The next day I didn't move from bed (except for a failed 100m walk where I grew to exhausted to keep going) and the next day I managed to walk to the hotel's beach and lay on a daybed and read/sleep.For one month after the sting, I still had weird shooting pains in my back. So, that's what it was like for me being stung by a jellyfish. Not nice!  Embed Quote

In the following video, one can see (live) the effect of the stinging by only one box jellyfish's tentacle - one can then try to interpolate and imagine the pain caused by the  real encounter with such an animal. That is scary.  Embed Quote

In regard to David's comment, above, it's worth noting that one of the officially recognized symptoms of an Irukandji sting is a 'strong feeling of impending doom'. I can't think of anything worse.  Embed Quote

I was stung once by a Portuguese Man o'war. Luckily I was only crouching in shallow water holding a small child (who was not stung fortunately). It was like a hot poker burn, and showed up as several red lines on my arm and thigh. I started to feel difficulty in breathing and a heavy arm, so I gathered up the children and went to hospital. Africa in the seventies: I had to queue (scared) for one hour and a half to try and get the right remedy, and finally decided that the breathing cramps were subsiding and went home with no treatment.  It hurt very much, like a bad burn, for some time.  Embed Quote

You are all welcome to visit us on the Black Sea. We have jellyfish here but you can get tangled in their tentacles (щупальци) and come out of it with just a strong stinging feeling that lasts about a day along with the welts. It doesn't cause you to fear getting back in the water, although swimming at night with the glowing jellyfish is not my favorite pastime personally.  Embed Quote

The difference is that the latter is more accurate and pedantic, with less potential for ambiguity.  The former is basically shorthand for the latter in everyday speech....we all know that "cause" is commonly used to mean that it contributes to, and therefore increases the chances of, something happening.It is probably more accurate to say that "smoking increases the risk of lung cancer" than to say that it "causes lung cancer," since, obviously, not everyone who smokes gets lung cancer.  But only a lawyer for a tobacco company would deny that smoking causes lung cancer on this technicality.  Embed Quote

There is no such thing as things "causing cancer". Lots of things increase the risk of developing cancer in your lifetime such as smoking, excessive drinking, asbestos  etc. Some things might increase your risk so much that there is almost a causative effect, but even then, it's still an increase in chances of developing cancer.  Embed Quote

I would put this in terms of "increase the risk of cancer" is more general, and "cause cancer" is more specific to individual cases of cancer.I can't think of any chemical, virus, or other factor that causes cancer in every single person exposed to it. Not every smoker gets lung cancer; not every woman who inherits a mutation in the BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene gets breast or ovarian cancer. However, there are lots of things that, if you're exposed to them, increase the risk that the exposure will cause cancer in you specifically.So: smoking increases the risk that you will get a lung cancer that was caused by smoking; inheriting a mutated BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene increases the risk that you will get a breast or ovarian cancer that was caused by the mutation.Does that make sense? Happy to clarify if not :)  Embed Quote

To me causes cancer implies:Substance goes into your cells and mutates your genes and activates a variety of oncogenes resulting in cancerTo me increases the risk of cancer implies:Substance has been statistically correlated with an increase of cancer.Essentially a classic causation vs. correlation argument.  Embed QuoteAnswered in fourteen minutes.

column9: Is it better for the environment?
column10: This is a difficult question deserving of a complicated answer, which should start by disambiguating the term "organic".Organic farming can refer to a method intended to simulate biological systems in the natural world. In this sense, organic food is inherently grown without chemical pesticides, herbicides, fertilizers, etc. In addition, organic farmers promote complex interactions between plants, animals, and ecosystems that are not found on industrial farms, whether conventional or certified USDA organic. Such interactions may include utilizing rotational grazing instead of feeding grain to livestock, or using multiple crops in the same space instead of separating them. In short, this method of farming uses systemic, holistic approaches, rather than input substitution. Organic food in this sense is better for you and for the environment.Conversely, organic food may also refer to food labeled as such according to USDA standards, and whether this food is better is less obvious and can depend on the situation.For example, USDA organic certification mandates that cattle receive 30% of their diet from grazing. While their remaining diet may include certified organicgrain, cattle’s digestive systems evolved to process grass, and feeding themgrain causes health problems and results in beef that contains fewer nutrientsimportant to human health (such as vitamins and Omega 3 fatty acids). In thiscase, grass-fed beef may be better for you than organic beef.Another example involves non-certified organic polyculture as compared to certified organic monoculture. USDA organic standards allow monocultures, that is, large areas populated by a single crop type. Monoculture crops can produce a myriad of detrimental environmental effects, including stripping the soil of its nutrients (which can in turn result in less nutritious food), disrupting ecosystems, and jeopardizing biodiversity. Is organic monoculture better for the environment? Perhaps yes, if compared to conventional monoculture, and perhaps not, if compared to a non-certified polyculture that does not use chemical inputs.Farmers that practice organic agricultural methods in the first sense may choose to not certify their products as USDA organic for several reasons, including the cost of certification or disagreement over the value of USDA standards. I once met a dairy farmer who implemented many environmentally sustainable practices on his farm, but chose not to pursue certification because he thought it was cruel to not treat dairy cows with antibiotics when their udders were infected. USDA organic certification also does not address some important concepts in sustainable eating such as the nutritional and environmental costs of shipping food long distances, or the benefits of eating seasonally.While USDA organic certifications do not necessarily equate to healthier or moreenvironmentally friendly food, the standards are relatively new (the OrganicFoods Production Act passed in 1990) and are still being revised (amendments to the act including stricter standards on the treatment of livestock, among other things, will take effect this July). Several states and countries have organic certifications that differ from USDA standards, some of which attempt to more tightly embrace the emulation of natural plant and animal systems.Food may also be labeled according to other terms, such as “all natural”,“environmentally friendly”, or “Earth Friendly, Farm Friendly”. While theselabels may be accurate, they are not monitored or enforced by a governing body and there are no legally mandated national standards to which they must adhere. In fact, the “Earth Friendly, Farm Friendly” label is condoned by anorganization (the Center for Global Food Issues) partially funded by Monsanto that is anti-organic, and the Union of Concerned Scientists advises avoidingproducts with this label (according to their publication Earthwise).In sum, organic food is usually better for you and for the environment. However,in order to know for sure you must know the practices used when growing a particular food item, and because of ambiguous labeling this is often difficult.  Embed Quote

column9: Is it better for the environment?
column10: It depends on what food it is (see http://www.ewg.org/foodnews/summ... [1]) - but in general, fruits from the Rosaceae family (apples, peaches, nectarines, and strawberries), have the highest levels of neurotoxic pesticide contamination. However, most non-organic vegetables (except celery) do not contain such dangerous pesticides, so they probably aren't much more risky.The Rosaceae trees are also sprayed with neurotoxic herbicides that the USDA doesn't even measure - like paraquat and ziram - see What crops are most likely to be contaminated with ziram? Or paraquat?I haven't found any studies on the negative effects on people who consume the fruits yet (they also depend on the extent to which exposure to pesticides in food contributes to blood levels of pesticides in food), but there are studies that have found neurotoxic effects in people who simply live near fields that have been sprayed with pesticides (listed below). In that case, until we learn more, there is definitely good reason to advise caution with eating non-organic fruit from the Rosaceae trees if you naturally eat a lot of fruit.I don't think that you should worry about an increased risk of cancer (see Are we exposed to more carcinogens now than any other time in history?) or decreased lifespan at all. But there is a risk that all the pesticide residue could make you dumber if you eat a lot of fruit (this is more relevant for vegetarians/vegans than for most others). Most pesticides are quite selective by acting on the nervous systems on the pests, so they naturally have selective effects when consumed by people too.Here is a list of pesticides in the most contaminated fruitApples: http://www.whatsonmyfood.org/foo...Nectarines: http://www.whatsonmyfood.org/foo...Peaches: http://www.whatsonmyfood.org/foo...Pears: http://www.whatsonmyfood.org/foo...Strawberries: http://www.whatsonmyfood.org/foo...Celery: http://www.whatsonmyfood.org/foo...Almonds: http://www.whatsonmyfood.org/foo...[1] Note that the EWG site should only be seen as a rough source, and is somewhat misleading, as it counts the total number of pesticides inside. In reality, many of the "most contaminated" vegetables actually contain a lot of the more benign pesticides like the neonicotinoids. Also, note that the neurotoxic organophosphate Azinphos methyl will be banned by the EPA in mid-2012.=====So what's up with some of the pesticides I mentioned? Some of them have nasty neurological effects that have been demonstrated in people who simply live near areas where pesticides are sprayed (effects such as significant increases in one's risk of Parkinson's Disease, and yes - even decreases in intelligence). Many of these effects are not effects that you can capture through mortality data in animal (or human studies), and were only discovered in the last few years, so any conclusions (prior to 2010) about the safety of such pesticides are now moot.Now, do these effects transfer to consumers? We don't know yet. But we *do* know that they *do* apply for people who simply *live* near areas where pesticides are sprayed. Also - you can't get rid of pesticides by washing your produce: http://www.reddit.com/r/askscien... . And the major route of exposure to organophosphates (in children) is through food (see http://ehp03.niehs.nih.gov/artic... )Keep in mind that humans are especially vulnerable to neurological effects (there aren't really any animals that naturally develop Alzheimer's or Parkinson's - so any neurotoxicity will be underreported in most animal studies, and completely glossed over in lifespan studies. They often develop plaques but with no clear evidence of mental decline). See http://news.harvard.edu/gazette/... and Are there any animals that don't get Alzheimer's Disease?With that said - I'm not totally sure if pesticides do that much damage to the brains of most people, give... (more)Loading...

column9: Is it better for the environment?
column10: Frankly, I don't believe there's any convincing evidence thus far to support the claim that organic food is way better than "conventional" food.A review article analyzing a total of 240 studies was recently published in the Annals of Internal Medicine: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubm...For those interested in the short and sweet version, here are some links for you:http://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/0...http://www.usatoday.com/news/hea...http://www.latimes.com/health/bo...http://www.washingtonpost.com/bl...For those interested in the longer and nerdier version, I did a brief read of the paper, and apparently various analyses showed the following (my personal thoughts are in italics):No association between organic vs. conventional diet in the development of eczema, wheezing, serum IgE levels or other atopic conditions in children.Lower levels of pesticide metabolite levels in the urine of children on organic diets. Sounds scary. But realistically? What's the objective measurement here? You need a lot more data to prove this is clinically significant. If the level at which harm is seen is X and children on organic diets have 0.2X and children on conventional diets have 0.4X, does it really matter? Can you even prove it's due to diet, not other factors? Another study showed that household use of pesticides, NOT diet, predicted urinary insecticide levels.One study actually showed that consumption of organic meat in winter was a risk factor for infection with Campylobacter bacteria. So...this meat is more expensive, and it might cause greater rate of infection? Where exactly is the so-called benefit of being organic here?6 studies "found no consistent differences in plasma or urine carotenoids, polyphenols, vitamins E and C content, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, antioxidant activity, ability to protect against DNA damage, immune system markers, or semen quality between participants consuming organic and conventional diets" Again, not seeing any real benefits of spending lots of money for the organic label here...151 studies reported that harvesting or processing methods were the same for both organic and conventional foods; the rest didn't actually describe harvesting or processing methods. I find it rather difficult to believe that in the studies that did not report these methods, they were significantly different; if they were, any researcher worth their salt would've realized it would be an awesome conclusion to report."We did not find significant differences in the vitamin content of organic and conventional plant or animal products" So...maybe shopping for organic food only doesn't necessarily enhance vitamin intake...?A few studies found that organic milk and chicken had higher levels of omega-3 fatty acids. However, several studies showed that the season of sampling and brand affected these levels at LEAST as much as the farming method. Seriously, if you're that worried about omega-3 intake, you can get a year's supply for about $10 at Amazon or Costco. Much more cost-effective if you ask me.No difference in protein/fat between organic and conventional milk.Some studies showed higher levels of pesticide residues in conventional produce. Each study had a slightly different level of what was considered "positive", though. If you look at studies examining the prevalence of contamination exceeding maximum allowed limits, two studies showed no difference, and one actually showed 6% in organic vs. 2% in conventional...Prevalence of E. coli contamination in produce was 7% in organic vs. 6% in conventional. Of the 5 studies examining this, 4 showed higher risk for contamination among organic produce."differences in the prevalence of bacterial contamination between organic and conventional animal products were statistically insignificant" Interesting part: if you look at just pork, 65% of organic pork was contaminated with E. coli vs. 49% of conventional."No significant differences were found in the ascorbic acid content of cabbage (3 studies), carrots (3 studies), potatoes (3 studies), or tomatoes (8 studies); beta-carotene content of tomatoes (3 studies); or protein content of wheat (6 studies) when grown organically versus conventionally."I should note some of the problems with research in this field:Over half of studies don't actually list what on earth their standard for considering a product "organic" was. Why is this a problem? Well, European Union has one, many European countries have country-specific additional standards, the International Federation of Organic Agriculture Movements has another, and the U.S. Dept of Agriculture has yet another. They all have slightly different requirements.Some papers have really, really small sample sizes. Like...only 6 study subjects. It's kind of impossible to rely on such a study for a generalized view of humanity.Some papers have really, really short time periods. Like...only 2 days. It's kind of impossible to rely on such a study for a generalized view of longitudinal health outcomes 10, 20, 30 years down the line.Data analyzing produce can come from specialized experimental farms, which can control for factors such as weather, geography, etc; however, almost a third came from commercial farms that have no control over these factors, which may affect study results.There are no long-term studies of populations subsisting more on either organic or conventional foods, isolating this difference as the only variable. This is basically impossible at this time and for the near future for obvious logistical reasons.Hope this helps.  Embed QuoteThis answer is not a substitute for professional medical advic... (more)Loading... Via  Austin Conlon,  Mickael Bergeron Neron, and  Kovács András.

column9: Is it better for the environment?
column10: No, organic food is not nececssarily better for you.In my opinion, there is a lot of utter tosh talked about organic food by its producers, wholesalers, retailers, consumers and political promoters. And it shouldn't need to be said that most of these people have either commercial or ideological motives for extolling the virtues of organic produce. Because of this, their claims about its supposedly superior taste and nutritional value, its lower environmental impact, and so on, should be treated with no less circumspection and objective skepticism than they encourage us to apply to the counter-claims of their non-organic opponents. While some of the claims of the organic lobby may contain a grain of truth, they might still not be true in all circumstances, without exception. And it is relativiely easy to cherry-pick one's data, selecting that which supports one's viewpiont and ignoring that which does not. All successful marketing campaigns employ the dark art of 'creative  statistics'. Other claims for the benefits of organic food are flatly contradicted by the available evidence, and one suspects that those who repeat them and believe them are simply doing so because they have become dogmas and articles of faith within the 'wholefood movement', and to question them is regarded as dangerously heretical. But we must not let profits and politics obscure hard scientific data. Take just a few such claims about organic food, already repeated on here: Firstly, that organic food is more nutritious than conventionally produced food:[The] London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine examined 162 papersthat compared organic and conventionally produced food. They concluded that there was no evidence to back up claims that organic food is more nutritious. http://www.newscientist.com/arti... (subscription required for full article, but the research cited is below)'Our review indicates that there is currently no evidence to support the selection of organically over conventionally produced foods on the basis of nutritional superiority.' - Alan Dangour, London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine’s Nutrition and Public Health Intervention Research Unithttp://www.lshtm.ac.uk/news/2009...Secondly, that organic food carries less risk of bacterial or other contamination:Organic broiler chickens are three times as likely as conventionally-bred poultry to be contaminated with a bacterium that causes food-poisoning, say Danish vets. http://www.newscientist.com/arti...[By] shunning science, organic producers could be increasing consumers' risk of contracting Escherichia coli and other food-borne diseases....In theory, organic food could be more prone to microbial contamination due to the absence of preservatives and the use of manure as fertiliser....Studies carried out on organic and conventional produce by Minnesota farmers in 2004 found that E. coli contamination was 19 times greater on organic farms which used manure or compost less than 12 months old...Another extra risk factor in organic production is the avoidance of fungicides, which can lead to the growth of moulds and increased risk of mycotoxins such as aflatoxin and ergot in crops.http://www.newscientist.com/arti...Thirdly, that food irradiation is dangerous and degrades the nutritional value of foods: There is no evidence that food irradiation is harmful to consumers, and also no evidence that it affects the nutritional quality of food.See preceding link.Fourthly, that organic foods are inherently safer than conventionally produced foods because they are not treated with synthetic agrochemicals and additives:In contrast to the popular perception that chemical residues in food are the major source of food contamination, recent food-borne disease outbreaks have demonstrated that microbial hazards are much more significant for food safety (Cliver, 1999). The risks due to pesticide residues and food additives are relatively minor, compared with both acute and chronic effects caused by microbiological and other naturally occurring toxicants (Fig. 3) (Cliver, 1999). ... In the past decade, outbreaks of human diseases associated with the consumption of raw vegetables and fruits, or unpasteurised products originating from them, have significantly increased in number (Beuchat & Ryu, 1997; Keene, 1999)....consumers’ demand of minimally processed foods has had an apparent adverse influence on food safety (Zink, 1997)....Furthermore, there is no evidence that toxic hazards such as pesticides have had a major impact on total cancer mortality (Fisher & Worth, 1995); populations with diets rich in fruits and vegetables have a substantially lower risk of many types of cancer (Centers for Disease Control, 1999), despite the use of synthetic agrochemicals in conventional farming. Hence, the benefits may outweigh the risks....But neither is the organic label a seal of food safety. Organic refers only to a product that has been produced in accordance with certain standards throughout the production, handling, processing and marketing stages; it does not refer to the characteristics and properties of the finished product. The asserted health benefits are impossible to quantify and do not seem, as yet, to compensate for the increased price. ....Summing up, no hard evidence currently exists to support or refute claims that organic food is healthier and safer than conventional food, or vice versa, and assertions of such kind are inappropriate and not justified....The main health-promoting properties of food, however, lie in their ability to provide the human organism with carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins, minerals, fibre and protective factors needed for growth, repair, reproduction, energy and good health. Plants produce these complex nutrients from water, air, soil and sunlight. How well they do so is under the influence of many environmental and genetic factors, and the type of agriculture is only one variable.- Faidon Magkos, Fotini Arvaniti and Antonis Zampelas, Laboratory of Nutrition and Clinical Dietetics, Department of Nutrition and Dietetics, Harokopio Universityhttp://journals.cambridge.org/do...Regarding this last point, I recall reading about a scientist who was strongly pro-organic foods. [1][2]. He believed all the hype and propaganda put out by the wholefood industry, and set out to win the debate for organics by conducting research into the comparative toxicity of organic versus conventionally produced foods, with regard to the levels of carcinogens found in both, from either man-made or naturally occuring sources. The results he found shocked him, and completely reversed his previous beliefs: he discovered that organic foods contain many times (in some cases, thousands of times) more carcinogens than conventionally produced foods! He concluded that this was because the specific genetic varieties of crops chosen for organic agriculture are precisely those that produce the highest levels of natural fungicides, herbicides and pesticides, as these crops will be the most resistant to disease and infestation, and so produce the highest yields and least wastage from crop damage. The irony for organic farmers is that many of these naturally occurring substances are hugely more carcinogenic than the synthetic agrochemicals used in conventional agriculture!   Finally, this research article refutes many of the common claims made by proponents of organic food, particularly concerning claims that organic farming methods do not use any harmful chemicals (false) and are more 'sustainable' (false) and environmentally friendly (false). It makes interesting reading, and also contains an extensive list of references to related scientific ressearch:http://www.gene.ch/gentech/2001/...In summary, when you subtract all of the ideological rhetoric and commercial self-interest that currently distorts their arguments, the claims of organic proponents that 'organic is best' simply don't stand up to impartial scientific scrutiny. This doesn't mean that conventionally produced food is any safer or healthier (though some would argue that it is, at least in some cases). It simply means that organic food has yet to be proven superior in these respects. So continue to consume organic food if you want to, and if you can afford its typically higher prices (though many poorer people cannot, which is probably why organic food consumption has become something of a status symbol of the middle-classes in recent years). I'm willing to concede that some of it may even taste nicer than the conventional alternatives, though there is research that also refutes such claims.(Taste is subjective, of course, and I also wonder how much of this is psychological, with people convincing themselves that it tastes better simply because they have a pre-conceived belief that it should.) Just don't fool yourself into believing that it is any healthier or safer for you, because the jury is still out.[1] I have been wracking my brain to recall his name, so far to no avail, but his research is quite famous. Can anyone help?[2] I'm not sure if this is the same guy, but his research has uncovered more-or-less the same facts: http://texasbot.tripod.com/lovej...  Embed Quote

column9: Is it better for the environment?
column10: From what I understand, there isn't really any hard evidence to suggest that organic food is better for your body.  Organically grown food is without a doubt better for the environment and communities surrounding where the food is grown.  Embed Quote

column9: Is it better for the environment?
column10:
“Consumers may choose to buy organic fruit, vegetables and meat because they believe them to be more nutritious than other food. However, the balance of current scientific evidence does not support this view” – source: http://www.food.gov.uk/foodindus...    “There is little scientific evidence to prove that organic food is better in quality than conventional food”.  Source: http://www.organicfacts.net/orga...

column9: Is it better for the environment?
column10:
Kali Albright's answer is very thorough and accurate. Outside of the the US and Canada, some organic certification processes may be dubious. 
  
 Katie is also correct that few long term studies show a nutritional benefit to organic products. But the studies showing the environmental benefits grows stronger each day. 
  
 My general rules of thumb are:
 Buy products grown in season, which tend to have the most time to have accumulated nutrients and is usually also grown closer to home. 
  
 If you can find local and certified organic, bonus! I love supporting my local farmer and his family's health. 
  
 From a nutrition point of view, cook vegetables as minimally as possible and save any cooking fluid for soup. 
  
 Try and have as many colours of the rainbow on your plate from veggies and fruit which will increase the likelihood of an array of vitamins, minerals and antioxidants. 
  
 Regardless of organic or not, use good food safe sanitation practices at all times.  Embed Quote

column9: Is it better for the environment?
column10: That organic is better for the environment is a no-brainer (assuming you didn't buy organic apples from New Zealand instead of non-organic ones from your native UK!) Better for human nutritional health? Intuitively, it feels like 'as nature intended' ought to be. I think the 'better' gap may be pretty small for some foods, but fairly significant for others. A very new UK study of cows' milk discovered the organic to be far healthier than non-organic, in terms of fat composition. There are other factors too. Can you get all the pesticide residues out of your non-organic carrot, even if studies claim the nutritional quality matches organic? And what of other factors like freshness? Non organic veg straight from the field of a neighbouring farm is likely to have a lot more vitamins in it than something organic that has been kicking around in the retail system for days on end. But like for like, organic is surely the best.  Embed Quote

column9: Is it better for the environment?
column10: Organic food is decidedly better for your body, the body of old Ma Earth, and society (organic farmers make a better living). What follows comes from the Organic Consumers Association:Beyond Frankenfoods and Toxics: OCA’s Ten Reasons to Buy OrganicOrganic foods and products are the fastest growing items in America's grocery carts. Thirty million households, comprising 75 million people, are now buying organic foods, clothing, body care, supplements, pet food, and other products on a regular basis. Fifty-six percent of U.S. consumers say they prefer organic foods.Here are 10 reasons why you should buy organic foods and products:1. Organic foods are produced without the use of Genetically Modified Organisms (GMOs). Consumers worry about untested and unlabeled genetically modified food ingredients in common supermarket items. Genetically engineered ingredients are now found in 75% of all non-organic U.S. processed foods, even in many products labeled or advertised as “natural.” In addition the overwhelming majority of non-organic meat, dairy, and eggs are derived from animals reared on a steady diet of GM animal feed. Although polls indicate that 90% of Americans want labels on gene-altered foods, government and industry adamantly refuse to respect consumers’ right to know, understanding quite well that health and environmental-minded shoppers will avoid foods with a GMO label.2. Organic foods are safe and pure. Organic farming prohibits the use of toxic pesticides, antibiotics, growth hormones, nano-particles, and climate-destabilizing chemical fertilizers. Consumers worry about pesticide and drug residues routinely found in non-organic produce, processed foods, and animal products. Consumer Reports has found that 77% of non-organic produce items in the average supermarket contain pesticide residues. The beef industry has acknowledged that 94% of all U.S. beef cattle have hormone implants, which are banned in Europe as a cancer hazard. Approximately 10% of all U.S. dairy cows are injected with Monsanto and Elanco’s controversial genetically engineered Bovine Growth Hormone, banned in most industrialized nations. Recent studies indicate that an alarming percentage of non-organic U.S. meat contains dangerous antibiotic-resistant bacteria.3. Organic foods and farming are climate-friendly. Citizens are increasingly concerned about climate-destabilizing greenhouse gas pollution (CO2, methane, and nitrous oxide), 35-50% of which in North America comes from our energy-intensive, chemical-intensive food and farming system. Organic farms and ranches, on the other hand, use far less fossil fuel and can safely sequester large amounts of CO2 in the soil (up to 7,000 pounds of CO2 per acre per year, every year.) Twenty-four billion pounds of chemical fertilizers applied on non-organic farms in the U.S. every year not only pollute our drinking water and create enormous dead zones in the oceans; but also release enormous amounts of nitrous oxide, a super potent, climate-destabilizing greenhouse gas.4. Organic food certification prohibits nuclear irradiation. Consumers are justifiably alarmed about irradiating food with nuclear waste or electron beams, which destroy vitamins and nutrients and produce cancer-causing chemicals such as benzene and formaldehyde. The nuclear industry, large food processors, and slaughterhouses continue to lobby Congress to remove required labels from irradiated foods and replace these with misleading labels that use the term "cold pasteurization." The USDA and large meat companies have promoted the use of irradiated meat in school lunches and senior citizen facilities. Many non-organic spices contain irradiated ingredients.5. Consumers worry about rampant e-coli, salmonella, campylobacter, Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), and fecal contamination in animal products coming out of the nation’s inhumane and filthy slaughterhouses. The Centers for Disease Control have admitted that up to 76 million Americans suffer from food poisoning every year. Very few cases of food poisoning have ever been linked to organic farms or food processors.6. Consumers are concerned about billions of pounds of toxic municipal sewage sludge dumped as “fertilizer” on 140,000 of America’s chemical farms. Scientific evidence has confirmed that municipal sewage sludge contains hundreds of dangerous pathogens, toxic heavy metals, flame-retardants, endocrine disruptors, carcinogens, pharmaceutical drugs and other hazardous chemicals coming from residential drains, storm water runoff, hospitals, and industrial plants. Organic farming categorically prohibits the use of sewage sludge.7. Consumers worry about the routine practice of grinding up slaughterhouse waste and feeding this offal and blood back to other animals, a practice that has given rise to a form of human mad-cow disease called CJD, often misdiagnosed as Alzheimer’s disease. Animals on organic farms cannot be fed slaughterhouse waste, manure, or blood—daily rations on America’s factory farms.8. Consumers care about the humane treatment of animals. Organic farming prohibits intensive confinement and mutilation (debeaking, cutting off tails, etc.) of farm animals. In addition to the cruel and unhealthy confinement of animals on factory farms, scientists warn that these CAFOs (Confined Animal Feeding Operations) produce enormous volumes of manure and urine, which not only pollute surface and ground water, but also emit large quantities of methane, a powerful climate-destabilizing greenhouse gas.9. Consumers are concerned about purchasing foods with high nutritional value. Organic foods are nutritionally dense compared to foods produced with toxic chemicals, chemical fertilizers, and GMO seeds. Studies show that organic foods contain more vitamins, cancer-fighting anti-oxidants, and important trace minerals.10. Consumers care about preserving America’s family farms, world hunger, and the plight of the world’s two billion small farmers. Just about the only small farmers who stand a chance of making decent living these days are organic farmers, who get a better price for their products. In addition study after study has shown that small organic farms in the developing world produce twice as much food per acre as chemical and GMO farms, while using far less fossil fuel and sequestering large amounts of excess CO2 in the soil. Yields on organic farms in the industrialized world are comparable to the yields on chemical and GMO farms, with the important qualification that organic farms far out-produce chemical farms under extreme weather conditions of drought or torrential rains. Of course given accelerated climate change, extreme weather is fast becoming the norm.For all these reasons, millions of American consumers are turning to organic foods and other organic items, including clothing and body care products--part of an overall movement toward healthy living, preserving the environment, and reversing global warming.http://www.commondreams.org/view...  Embed Quote

column9: Is it better for the environment?
column10: If you are trying to eat healthy, you already know that you should be including plenty of fruits, vegetables and lean protein in your daily diet.  But what about eating organic foods?  Are they healthier?  What constitutes organic food?  And will there be a noticeable difference in your overall healthy if you eat organic foods?Proponents of organic foods say that it is healthier, safer, better tasting and better for the environment.  Most often, organic food is significantly more expensive than non-organic foods.  Although the demand for organic foods has dramatically risen in recent years, there is very little evidence that shows positive proof that eating organic foods has a material difference in your overall health.  There is very limited information on the actual health outcomes of consuming organic foods over regular food.What constitutes organic food?  In order to be considered organic, crops must be grown without the use of pesticides, synthetic fertilizers or bioengineering.  Organically raised animals used for meat must be given organic feed and be free of steroids, growth hormone and antibiotics.Because there is not enough evidence to show non-organic foods as being unhealthy and dangerous, the actual health benefits of eating organic foods are not conclusive.  And at this point, there is not enough evidence to show a significant health benefit of eating organic foods over conventionally produced foods.  So eating organic or non-organic foods comes down to personal preference. When eating organic fruits and vegetables, the amount of pesticide residue is dramatically reduced and when eating organic meat, you are not running the risk of ingesting growth hormone or antibiotics.                                                     For more Health and Fitness Tips Follow me on Twitter @JackKenefick or on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/OrangeC.... You can also check out my blog post on this at http://www.balanced-life-fitness... along with many other blog post on Fitness and Health!  Embed Quote
