Let's start with some very basic chemistry. The carcinogenicity of epoxides originates from the strained nature of the three membered ring. Due to the number of electrons (6) in the valence shell, oxygen prefers to bond with two partners to achieve a full octet. Oxygen also has two lone pairs of electrons. A normal atom bonded to four entities typically assumes a tetrahedral geometry that minimizes repulsion of each moiety by maximizing the angle between them (109.5°). The two highly repulsive lone pairs of oxygen, however, push the two oxygen-bonded atoms together, distorting the tetrahedral geometry. For example, the H-O-H bond angle of water is a smaller 104.5°. The C-O-C bond angle of an epoxide, however, is even smaller at 61.5°. This highly non-ideal angle arises due to the additional constraint of the C-C bond length. The incredible strain on the epoxide ring reduces the stability of the molecule. Through reacting with other molecules, epoxides can relieve the strain and thus achieve greater stability. This reactivity can wreak havoc in a biological system, where processes compatible with life often require controlled changes to molecular structures. Let's look at a common example. The pro-carcinogen benzo[a]pyrene, a major mutagen in cigarette smoke, becomes metabolized by the body's P450 system to produce a carcinogenic epoxide:Once formed, the carcinogen tends to intercalate into DNA (the aromatic region  can Pi stack with the nitrogenous bases) and react at the epoxide region to form a covalent bond at guanines. This inclusion distorts the structure of DNA, causing errors in DNA replication (G --> T transversion). If these mutations occur in a gene encoding a molecule regulating the cell cycle, cancer may arise. All images taken from Wikipedia.  Embed Quote

Corn Syrup is different than High Fructose Corn Syrup. Let's start with that and move down the line.Corn is a very starchy grain. Starches are, in essence, nothing but very long strands of the same molecules that, when shorter, are known as sugars.Two so-called polysaccharides, amylopectin and amylose, are mostly important to us. Here's some small imagery to look at:AmyloseAmylopectin.Corn syrup is made by milling yellow corn and creating a starchy paste. That paste is then injected with α-amylase which breaks the starch (loooong chain of saccharides, remember) into shorter strands called oligosaccharides. Oligosaccharides have somewhere in the ten sugar molecules in a row.Next those oligosaccharides are injected with glucoamylase. That turns the oligosaccharide into maltose by breaking it into even smaller links. Still we have precisely the same stuff in the mix, only broken into smaller links. Here's the so-called ß-maltose:Looks familiar? Should, it's just a smaller, broken off, part of the Amylopectin. And here's 4-O-α-D-Glucopyranosyl-D-glucose, also a maltose:Looks familiar, too? Should, it's just a shorter version of Amylose.NOW it gets interesting. What you have right now is Corn Syrup. That's the stuff they put into all the candy because the loose -OH you see dangling there has a curious love for this:β-D-fructofuranulosyl-(2→1)-α-D-glucopyranoside. Also known as "table sugar". Chemically table sugar is 1 part glucose (the stuff you see linked above) and 1 part fructose. Because two sugars, fructose and glucose, are involved we call those things "disaccharides".So, from starch (a polysaccharide) to oligosaccharides, to maltose, to a disaccharide and then back with another disaccharide, and that's the stuff you get in candy. It makes candy either hard or soft, either very sweet or tart, depending on how you mix, form, and work it. It's very useful.Why's that stuff bad? For the same reason a cup of sugar, eaten with a spoon, would be bad. It's lots of carbohydrates and that's not good for you, simple.Now, what people cry about, however, isn't Corn Syrup. It's the so-called "High Fructose Corn Syrup".Let's go back to the maltose. And let's have a look at Glucose:If you tilt your head, squint, and relax your eyes you will see a schooner (it's not a sailboat). If you tilt your head the other way you see... 1/2 maltose.Imagine, though, you were to add an enzyme to the maltose above. Consider further that it's Xylose isomerase and does something that is best written down in a non-scientific way as D-xylose <-> D-xylulose. Makes sense? No? That's cool, all you need to know is that the stuff above (not the schooner, the 1/2 maltose) turns into this:It's more or less a game of chemical musical chairs and by winning one H and kicking the dude in the head who tried to sit down before the end of the song we gain ... fructose.Fructose, like glucose, is a so-called mono-saccharide. In table sugar (look back up if you forgot how it looks) one glucose and one fructose are married to each other. That's the republican option, no same-molecule marriages here. So when you chomp into something with table sugar in it, say a nice piece of cake, you chomp into 50% glucose and 50% fructose.In "high fructose" corn syrup, however, more glucose molecules become fructose than stay glucose. About five percent for the food stuff, up to 45 percent for other uses. HFCS55, therefore, has 45 percent glucose and 55 percent fructose.Why is THAT bad, you ask? Glad you did. Some very disputed studies claim that fructose is worse than glucose because it triggers a different insulin response (search my answers for links that debunk this claim for what it is - unscientific).But what really makes HFCS bad is its ubiquity. When you eat a cup of sugar or a bag of gummy bears you more or less know what you're getting yourself into. With bread, yogurt, beer, fruit salads, sausages, lunch meats, or similar you don't expect to eat the equivalent of a quarter cup of the crystalline stuff. Yet, sadly, you do. HFCS alone is not proven to be bad for you. It being in everything, however, makes for a bad diet.  Embed Quote

You're really asking about two different products here.Corn syrup is mostly glucose, along with a few other sugars.  As John Coupland says, it interferes with the regular pattern that sucrose would create as it crystallizes, making the result smoother.High fructose corn syrup is corn syrup that has been modified to turn some of the glucose into fructose.  Sucrose (table sugar) is also a combination of glucose and fructose, in just about the same proportions.  That gives them comparable levels of sweetness (plain corn syrup is less sweet), and very similar health effects.  That is, both are sources of calories and no other nutritional value.  They have similar effects on blood insulin.HFCS receives a lot of attention because HFCS is cheaper than sugar, so it appears in a lot of goods.  (It might make it slightly tastier, but only slightly and only in some applications.)  HFCS is also a little easier to handle in factory settings than sucrose is.  HFCS is very common in highly processed foods, and those should be minimized in your diet.Replacing the HFCS with sugar does not make it the slightest bit healthier.  HFCS just happens to appear in many inexpensive sources of empty calories with no nutritional value.  Embed Quote

It prevents the sucrose crystalizing so readily so you don't get a grained caramel.  There are lots of other questions on the supposed healthfulness of HFCS. My take is it is metabolized very similarly to sucrose.  Embed Quote

In general, as Andy Lemke said, sucralose IS safe to consume. First off, let's discuss the toxicity of sucralose. According to an Australian Commonwealth study, the LD50 (the dosage at which bolus administration of the given drug is deadly to 50% of the subjects) is upwards of 16,000 (mg of splenda)/(kg body weight * day). In other words, if I weigh 150lbs, ~68kg, my LD50 would be around 16000*68 = 1088000 mg/day of sucralose, or 1.088 KILOGRAMS of sucralose per day. Granted, this is based off of rat data, but their physiology is close enough for me to draw a correlation [1].The standard package of Splenda contains about 1 gram of the active ingredients (I'll negate the content of preservatives, perhaps some real sugar, etc) [2]. Extrapolating from the numbers above: I would need to consume roughly 1.09 thousand packets of Splenda before I was at a 50% risk of dying. Of course, those numbers are based off of rats, and it's entirely likely that the amount of sucralose in a given packet of Splenda is actually less than 1 gram. The point is, small amounts of Splenda are not toxic. Ok, that said, there are a few biochemical issues I should address. 1) You don't absorb much of the sucralose (as with any other 'fake' sugar) - generally 20-30%, which is less than a quarter of the compound [3]. The most obvious result of this is that sucralose is a diarrhetic: it pulls water from your blood so that it can be complexed within the lumen of the small/large intestines. Caffeine has a similar effect. Just be sure to drink some water after you've had your coffee and you should be fine on this note.Secondly, the molecules that do get absorbed are mostly excreted from the blood via the kidneys. This leaves very little of the active ingredient in your bloodstream to actually affect a response. If we look at the makeup of sucralose versus sucrose (natural sugar), we see that the chloride groups impede the sugar's ability to bind and function as other sugars do:Sucrose, versusSucraloseNotice the structure is structurally identical, but chemically different. This is the main reason why, even if absorbed, the sucralose doesn't do much. However, because there are so many hydroxyl groups (-OH), there are likely a few bacteria in our GI tract that would try to metabolize the compound. In general, if the bacteria is somehow successful, you end up with potentially toxic metabolites, but so few and in such dilute concentration that they are likely lost via excretion (urine or feces). I couldn't find any proof of this, as it is extremely unlikely, but should a certain bacteria see enough of the compound (sucralose), it's possible that a few strains of that given bacteria with a mutant active site can actually break down the compound. This would likely be toxic to the bacteria, possibly causing a bit of GI distress, such as bloody stool, if the bateria lyses itself and causes an inflammatory response. I do want to state again that this is very unlikely, and I have no proof; just pure speculation.EDIT: Thanks to Ben Stortz for keeping me honest - I screwed up a few of my numbers. I have bolded the new values to reflect the changes. My message, however, remains the same: it would take a largely impractical amount of Splenda to cause any sort of acute toxicity.[1] http://www.nicnas.gov.au/search/...[2] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spl...[3] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suc...  Embed QuoteVia  Jarrod Cugley.

Generally speaking, there have been many studies which show that Splenda is safe.  However:...a Duke University study shows that at Sucralose consumption levels of 1.1–11 mg/kg (below the FDA 'safe' level), a 12-week administration of Splenda exerted numerous adverse effects, including reduction in beneficial fecal microflora, increased fecal pH, and enhanced expression levels of P-gp, CYP3A4, and CYP2D1, which are known to limit the bioavailability of nutrients and orally administered drugs. This study has been the subject of some controversy, with experts on both sides of the argument....http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spl...  Embed Quote

column9: Please be specific. Diet, nutritional supplements, sleep, stretching, meditating, etc.
column10: This is a very broad question because the endocrine system is only partially interconnected and the interaction between endocrine organs is complex. This is kind of what you are looking at:the endocrine systemA lot of control is exerted by the pituitary gland at the base of the brain. The pituitary releases hormones into the circulation that regulate other endocrine organs like the thyroid, adrenal glands and also growth hormone and ADH (important for fluid balance). There are some broad recommendations that can be made for endocrine health.1. Adequate sleep. Chronic sleep loss affects growth hormone secretion, thyroid function, and adrenal secretion of cortisol. This also decreases leptin production. Leptin is a hormone released by fat cells that suppresses the appetite. Chronic sleep deprivation is related to weight gain, glucose intolerance, and a higher risk of type 2 diabetes.Medscape Log In2. Avoid being overweight. This leads to insulin resistance and the pancreas has to make and release more insulin to lower blood sugar. This leads to type 2 diabetes and also a higher risk of cancer because insulin is a growth promoter.National Cancer Institute3. Exercise. This should include resistance exercises to increase muscle mass. Increased muscle mass lowers insulin resistance and lowers insulin levels. It's all good.Muscle Mass Knocks Out Insulin Resistance4. Diet. There's a lot of stuff out there about diet or supplements and the endocrine system and I'm not sure how much of it is valid. A lot of it sounds pretty kooky. Certainly, having iodine in the diet is needed for thyroid health. Iodine is necessary for adequate production of thyroid hormones that exert important control over metabolism. In America, iodine was added to salt, starting in the early 1900's because there was iodine deficiency causing goiter and thyroid dysfunction. In other parts of the world, iodine deficiency is associated with poor growth and mental retardation. Otherwise, it's hard to separate dietary confounding variables from weight and exercise. For example, people who drink a lot of alcohol and eat a lot of meat also tend to be overweight and more sedentary. Rather than recommending that certain foods be avoided, it may be more reasonable to recommend avoiding obesity and to have a diet that includes daily fresh fruits and vegetables.  Embed QuoteThis answer is not a substitute for professional medical advic... (more)Loading... Via  Ben Mordecai.

column9: Please be specific. Diet, nutritional supplements, sleep, stretching, meditating, etc.
column10: Well, this one is endless.The endocrine system works best with a balanced life - 1. One must eat a balanced diet (ref Old and New Food Pyramid with Pictures), eat regularly, avoid too much of fasting & feasting; exessive reliance on alcohol & tobacco.2. One must ensure regular (at least 5 days in a week) and effective (30 minutes each day - something that tires you) exercise - a mix of aerobic and weights with some time spent on stretches.3. A Relaxed mind - among 3 legs of healthy lifestyle, stress control is most important. Hypothalamus (in the brain) and Pituitary control the endocrine system. Enough, refreshing sleep (upto 8 hours each night) is a must for a relaxed mind and body.Ref: Lack of Energy: Could That Be One of Your Adrenal Fatigue Symptoms? The entire stress chemistry (see below) also begins in the hypothalamus when the body identifies a threat (real or imagined). Stress management, negative thought stopping & relaxation techniques are much more important that the earlier two.Now, few important, specific endocrine problems:1. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus - The importance of healthy Lifestyles can not emphasized more when it comes to Diabetes. Those who do not pay attention to diet, exercise and stress management end up with gradually increasing medicine doses.2. Hypothyroidism - exercise is very important.3. Poly Cystic Ovarian Syndrome - closely linked to the above mentioned both hence maintaining healthy lifestyle (esp diet & exercise) go a long way in weight management and controlling symptoms4. Hyperthyroidism - In addition to the common ones, cabbage is to be avoided as it is a goitrogen.5. Osteoporosis - if severe (as compared to age and co-morbidities) Parathormone is evaluated. Calcium intake &/or supplements are indicated as per medical advise.6. Obesity and diabetes - studies have shown that staying awake through the night is a risk factor. The effects of nocturnal life on endocrine circadia... [Life Sci. 2003] 7. Pre Menstrual Syndrome (PMS) - dysregulation of hormones cause water retention that is blamed for most of the symptoms. It has been proven that conscious reduction of salt reduces severity of symptoms, remarkably.The answer is not exhaustive but covers common endocrine problems  Embed QuoteThis answer is for general informational purposes only and is ... (more)Loading... Via  Ben Mordecai.

By and large we can, and in small quantities we do (due to the production of fusel oils from protein metabolism by yeasts in beverages).  However, these molecules are not as palatable as ethanol, many are more dangerous (they are usually CNS depressants much more powerful than ethanol and with lower toxicity thresholds) and frankly the organisms that produce these molecules tend to not produce molecules that we also want to eat.  The most prominent butanologens are clostridia, for example, and they produce butanols as a product in the stable phase (i.e., after being calorically restricted compared to the phase in which there is exponential growth).  During their growth phase they produce butyric acid, which smells (and therefore tastes) foul.  Many clostridia also produce other nasty molecules that are very toxic to humans, botulism being the most prominent but by no means the only instance. Other organisms might produce things like acetone alongside the butanols.Historically, a good reason that this wasn't the case is probably also that most of the organisms that produce propanols, butanols and other diols in significant quantity are obligate anaerobes.  They die upon exposure to oxygen, so there is very little chance that they might have been domesticated in the same way as sourdough mothers, yogurt lactobacilli, bakers and brewer's yeasts or ginger bugs might have - there's simply no way to handle them without relatively precise equipment not available before early modern times.  Even their spores would die exposed to open air.  When you consider that a great deal of the wine and beer in the old days soured due to impingement of air and the consequent growth of acetogens, it should be pretty obvious that old fermentation vessels would not be able to support obligate anaerobes.  Embed Quote
Perhaps the concentration for dangerous toxicity is lower than that which would cause drunk?  Embed Quote

Typically, no. Immunity typically refers to the development of antibodies specific to a particular pathogen. However, there is no such thing as an antibody for most chemicals (generally those that do not appear as antigens on pathogenic organisms or viruses). In fact, many chemicals tend to bioaccumlate; that is, your body does not readily excrete them. Repeatedly taking small does of such a chemical--like lead or DDT, for example--will actually deliver a rather large cumulative dose that could be lethal.To extend the example, being periodically exposed to specific antigens could induce immunity (some vaccines work in similar ways), but being periodically exposed to most chemicals would not.For more details about the actual nature of immunity, the Wikipedia article is pretty good (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imm....  Embed Quote

Perhaps not a chemical, but one of the more bizarre things that I've heard in recent years is of a woman who injected small dosages of horse blood over time to become immune to it's deleterious effects.  The lengths that people go to because of art...At any rate, here's a link to the article:http://www.wired.co.uk/news/arch...  Embed Quote
Its possible to become immune to iocane powder, if small amounts are taken regularly over several years  Embed Quote

I think you can take tiny doses of arsenic without dying, and then become less likely to die with the same dose that would kill someone who didn't take the arsenic.  This is a staple of older murder mysteries.Don't try it at home, though.  The small dose of arsenic is still bad for you.I think the murder-mystery plot device ran along the line of "innoculating" the murderer, serving arsenic-laced soup at a dinner party, everyone gets terribly sick but the murderer pulls through.  Today, they'd be able to test your bones to see that you'd been taking arsenic for years, plus they'd have you on the store camera buying the poison.  Or you'd be stupid and charge it on your credit card.  Or something.  Embed Quote

Thick, loose skin, and a fat layer that's damn near American.The honey badger's subcutaneous layer of fat is one of the things which may protect it from snake venom; it serves as a barrier which diffuses and slows down the absorption of venom. Encasing this fat is a loose coat of fur which is difficult to get ahold of. This helps the honey badger evade the grasp of its predators and combatants - it can twist and turn in its skin, continuing to bite and claw, even when held.Additionally, the honey badger's skin is thick and tough, which makes it nearly impervious "to the stings of bees, bites of dogs, and fangs of snake"[1]. Even if an attacker were to successfully penetrate its thick skin, honey badgers have a certain natural immunity to many venoms.Finally, honey badgers are badass.[1] Jana M. Vanderhaar and Yeen Ten Hwang, Mellivora capensis, Mammalian Species <http://www.jstor.org/stable/3504524>  Embed QuoteVia  Kevin Moore.

As David Urquhart has said, cyanoacrylates are commonly used to close wounds.The brands used in the ED in which I work are Dermabond or Histoacryl.However, your question states:- 'to use as a temporary stitch', it is pretty difficult to remove from wound edges after use and would make Suturing of the wound more awkward.The other downside of the commercially available superglue type products is that some of them contain a dye which could lead to 'tattooing' of the wound.Tissue adhesive is unsuitable to use for 'accidentally inflicted' deep wounds (surgical incisions are slightly different), is not ideal over joints, shouldn't be used near the eye and not for wounds which are heavily contaminated or where there is the possibility of tendon or nerve damage or foreign body.Any bite wounds shouldn't be closed initially due to the infection risk.I remember vividly, 'gluing' the head of a cantankerous old woman in ED with the assistance of a colleague known, colloquially as 'Mark Duck.'She spent 10 minutes moaning, complaining and telling us we were slow and useless. Her constant barracking led to a moments inattention. As we tried to step away to admire our artistry, we realised that my latex glove was firmly attached to her head (much like the comb on the head of a cockerel- but the other way round) I extracted my hand from the glove and we retreated very rapidly to the store cupboard, giggling.The moral of the story:- yes, you can use superglue but use it with caution.  Embed Quote

Cyanoacrylate is the generic name for cyanoacrylate based fast-acting adhesives such as methyl 2-cyanoacrylate, ethyl-2-cyanoacrylate (commonly sold under trade names like Super Glue and Krazy Glue), and n-butyl cyanoacrylate (used in veterinary and skin glues). The related compound 2-octyl cyanoacrylate is a medical grade glue; it was developed to be non-toxic and less irritating to skin tissue. Cyanoacrylate adhesives are sometimes known as instant glues. The abbreviation CA is commonly used for industrial grades. (1)While they can be effective in closing very superficial wounds under low tension (meaning the wound edges do not tend to pull apart), super glues can also irritate tissues. The wound strength of acrylate glue-closed wound on day one is only 10-15% of a suture-closed wound. Super glue is also more likely to become brittle and fracture particularly in areas of higher tension. (2)The 2-octyl cyanoacrylate  was formulated to correct some super glue deficiencies as wound closure material, It is less reactive than the other super glues and degrades slower, making it less irritating.When implanted in deeper skin tissues, all super glues can cause inflammation, tissue necrosis, granulation (excess formation of blood vessels that actually impedes wound healing) formation and wound breakdown.The problem with Dermabond vs Krazy Glue is the price:  Dermabond costs over $20 per one time vial, whereas Krazy Glue is approximately $2-3.References:http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cya...http://emedicine.medscape.com/ar...  Embed QuoteVia  David Urquhart.

Yes, I do it all the time. I have a chronic condition I seem to have inherited from my dad where I get painful cracks near my fingernails during winter. The only thing that I've found that works effectively is to superglue the cracks shut.One of the original experimental uses of superglue was to seal battle wounds in the Vietnam War.I would prefer to use the medical (or veterinarian) grade glue but both are prohibitively expensive.  Embed Quote

"Yes" unless your skin has an extreme allergic reaction.In yet another race against Emily Altman (who has actual understanding) ...Wikipedia reports:"Cyanoacrylates"http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/C...(Follow the link for the references.)":Some rock climbers use cyanoacrylate to repair damage to the skin on their fingertips. Similarly, stringed-instrument players can form protective finger caps (in addition to calluses) with cyanoacrylates.CA glue was in veterinary use for mending bone, hide, and tortoise shell by at least the early 1970s. The inventor of cyanoacrylates, Harry Coover, said in 1966 that a CA spray was used in the Vietnam War to retard bleeding in wounded soldiers until they could be brought to a hospital. Butyl cyanoacrylate has been used medically since the 1970s outside the US, but, due to its potential to irritate the skin, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration did not approve its use as a medical adhesive until 1998 with Dermabond. Research has demonstrated the use of cyanoacrylate in wound closure as being safer and more functional than traditional suturing (stitches). The adhesive has demonstrated superior performance in the time required to close a wound, incidence of infection (suture canals through the skin's epidermal, dermal, and subcutaneous fat layers introduce extra routes of contamination), and final cosmetic appearance.:"  Embed Quote

column9: I've recently been wronged by someone, in a very humiliating and public way. To get back at that person I decided to pull a little prank on them. I was planning to slip something into their drink to make them nauseated, but nothing more. It has to be something they can drink, not something I can put into their food. I definitely do not want to kill them, but at least make them feel as humiliated as I did that day. So far I have poinsettia sap and ipecac syrup but I'm hoping for something with less flavor.If anyone has any help, I would really appreciate it.
column10: This is a very bad idea.  An individual's response to a toxic substance will vary widely.  What might make one person nauseous might induce a much more severe reaction in another.  Furthermore, you can never be certain of the purity of the toxin--especially something you prepare yourself from plant material.  While you may think you are giving them just enough to make them a little sick, you might instead be putting them in the hospital.Then there are the legal aspects.  This is assault and you can be arrested and convicted and serve jail time for what you might regard as an innocent (or not so innocent in your case) prank.  Nor could you ever tell your victim that you poisoned them--to admit such an assault would leave you in their power.  All they would have to do is tell the police and you would be in a lot more trouble than you can imagine.Don't do it.Find another way to get even.  Better still, forgive and walk away.  Embed Quote

column10: I used to work for the company that manufactured Sharpies. column9: "Is Sugar Toxic?" by Gary Taubes, published April 17th 2011: http://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/1...
column10: "Toxic substance" is bandied about in this NYT article and by the speaker it references because it is an ill-defined term. "Toxic" in general usage could be anywhere on the spectrum of real poisonous character. Water can be a deadly substance in sufficient dosage. A better rubric is the LD50, or median lethal dose, of a substance. LD50 is defined as "the dose required to kill half the members of a tested population after a specified test duration" [1] A really poisonous substance, such as ricin, has a really low LD50 (22 µg/kg if injected) [1]. A very safe substance, such as water, has a very high LD50 (90,000 mg/kg in this case) [1].So, guidelines on what is considered "toxic" are somewhat subjective. It's generally accepted that a substance is toxic if its LD50 is below 2,500 mg/kg when consumed orally [2]. Since we're talking about sugar here, inhalation and skin exposure aren't of concern.Sugar comes in various forms. Table sugar is sucrose, whose LD50 is 29,700 mg/kg [1], far above the 2,500 mg/kg threshold for toxicity. The NYT article mentions high-fructose corn syrup, which in sodas is usually 55% fructose and 42% glucose [3]. The LD50 for fructose and glucose is 25,800 mg/kg [4,5], so high that it's not reported on most toxicity reports for those substances.So, no. All qualitative assessments and voluntary health concerns aside, sugar cannot be considered toxic by any stretch of the imagination.References:1. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Med...2. http://www.ehs.uci.edu/programs/...3. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hig...4. http://kcp.pdn.ipublishcentral.c...5. http://www.tradezone.com/tradesi...  Embed Quote

column9: "Is Sugar Toxic?" by Gary Taubes, published April 17th 2011: http://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/1...
column10: This seems as though somebody took the definition of "toxic" to an extreme. Sugar can only be viewed as "toxic" in the same light as oxygen can be viewed as "toxic". Both serve much more important benefits which outweigh risks of overdosing. Sugar is held together by glycosidic bonds, each of which is easily hydrolyzed in the presence of a single water molecule to release individual glucose (or glucose + fructose in the case of table sugar) molecules, all of which are easily converted into energy and valuable metabolic intermediates within the body by key enzymes. Any undergraduate student who has taken a general biology course in today's day and age would have covered Glycolysis, the process I summarized above. Furthermore, glucose being a water-soluble molecule makes it very hard to overdose on (I can only imagine this happening through a super concentrated IV injection, which would kill you based on a rapid change in cellular hypotonicity before any actual "poisoning" results). To put it in basic terms, if you take in more glucose, you will pee more out. Or maybe your body will convert some to fat. Of course, if you have some type of chronic metabolic malfunction, perhaps the situation will change for you. But the problem here lies within your body, not within the way a normal person reacts to sugar.Breathing in atmospheric oxygen results in oxidation within the body. Does that make you want to stop breathing? Glucose is the primary energy source that fuels a human brain. I suspect some of the people who have answered before me , especially saying things such as "sugar is toxic in the same way cigarettes are", more than likely could use a little more glucose in their brains, or perhaps an updated undergraduate-level education in a science, before confusing the Quora community with such garbage.Now for a caveat: binge-consumption of sugar on a consistent basis will eventually start messing with your body's glucose-regulation, which is a very complicated hormonal-controlled mechanism. Throwing this off at a large enough degree will result in serious health problems. My credentials: I am doing my doctorate research in a lab which is funded by the American Diabetes Association, and we probe the metabolic regulation of blood glucose on a daily basis. I study all these hormones and receptors.  Embed Quote

column10: Sugar has the following properties:* Most people eat a lot of it so its got social proof on its side.* If you aren't actively vigilant, you'll be ingesting a lot of it due to social factors. * It can create irreparable harm to your body.* You have huge billion dollar industries invested in you eating it. They pay billions just in advertising products that have sugar in them. * Its so readily available that you'll be fighting it for the rest of your life. Seems pretty toxic to me.  Embed Quote

column9: "Is Sugar Toxic?" by Gary Taubes, published April 17th 2011: http://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/1...
column10: Sugar is toxic in the same way as cigarettes are - one cigarette won't kill you but keep smoking them for years and they may. Same with sugar, keep eating it every day and you have a high chance of developing cardiovascular disease, type 2 diabetes, some types of cancer and other illnesses. So yes sugar is toxic, not in the same way that arsenic is, it won't kill you immediately but over time it will cause a lot of ill health and death due to diseases that might not directly be attributed to sugar. Sugar is OK in moderation but keep it as a treat food once or twice a week.  Embed Quote

The bite of a Komodo dragon enters toxic proteins and/.or bacteria into another animals blood stream, and that animal might die. If another animal eats the dead one, the toxins/bacteria do not enter their blood steam, but their digestive system. Any toxic proteins would probably be digested and thus completely harmless, the bacteria might cause food poisoning, but not death (in a healthy adult animal)  Embed Quote

It was a sunny Sunday morning in the summertime of 2006 in Redwood City, California, and the Mrs. was back East with her gal pals for a weekend of recharging her batteries and reconnecting with old friends.I was holding down the fort with the munchkins (boys 4 and 1 3/4), and in the interest of creating a morning diversion, we began to make preparations for a walk in the local hills.  Sunscreen on, snacks loaded, water filled, stroller out - you know the drill.I grabbed a pair of old shoes from the garage, and hastily threw them on over my bare feet, and continued my charge around the house to build momentum to get out the door.  About a minute later, I realized that there was some wiggling in the toes of my right shoe, and just as I was about to take my shoe off, I felt a prick on the tip the 2nd toe of my right foot - not painful, but it got my attention.I took my shoe off on the outside steps, and dumped it out, discovering a jet black inky spider with a body the size of an engorged pea.  I instructed my son to grab his bug-catcher which was conveniently nearby, and I dumped the spider into the clear container for inspection.Imagine my horror when I rotated the container and got a glimpse of a distinct reddish/brown hourglass figure on the belly of the black black spider.  OK, I reasoned, I'd lived in those parts for the better part of nearly 4 decades, and I'd NEVER heard of anyone seeing (let alone getting bit by) a black widow spider, so presumably this is just a copy-cat spider that is harmless.Well, I suppose before heading out for a walk, I ought to be safe and call the urgent care and see what they think. After being reassured that there was "no way" I had been bitten by a black widow, the attending physician confessed that she was looking at information on Google (!!!) and started to ask me questions about what it looked like.After 20 minutes on the phone (with the boys starting to melt down), and getting on the Internet myself, I began to experience my first tell-tale symptom -- a slight cramping in my lower right leg.At this point, the doctor changed position entirely, and strongly recommended that I get medical attention immediately.OK, kids, time to pile into the wagon.  We're heading to the ER.Ten minutes later, I walked through the doors at the ER at Sequoia Hospital in Redwood City, CA, with holding the hands of my two boys, along with the bug catcher."30 minutes ago, THIS spider, bit me on THIS toe, and now THIS leg is cramping."The otherwise bored doctors and nurses who were numbed by their predictable flow of blunt trauma, heart palpitations, and other mundane dramas rapidly appeared out of the woodworks and collectively shouted a big "Yah!!!".  This, they thought, was soooo cool.Note: Capturing and bringing in the actual spider was by far the smartest thing I did all day, as it brought me instant celebrity and credibility, as the bite itself was completely and somewhat disappointingly unremarkable.It was delicately but firmly suggested that I make some phone calls and line up some child-care, as soon I'd be all jacked up full of morphine and other things that would make me a less-than effective father.I was able to get ahold of my neighbor friends, who gamely dropped what they were doing, and came to pick up my boys.  We had a long discussion about how to orchestrate the movement of cars and carseats, including me driving their car home, which was completely naive given how F-d up I was about to become.By now the cramping had migrated into my groin area, and I was beginning to wonder what was in store.  I was told that an anti-venom does indeed exist, but it's kept in Arizona, and is highly toxic in and of itself, so they don't fly that in unless I was otherwise at risk (toddler, elderly, poor immune system).  So, my fate was to get jacked up on opiates and survive the onslaught of the neurotoxin from the spider which would otherwise cause tremendous pain and cramping for the next 6 hours.At this point I texted (SMS) my wife (who was on her way to the airport to come home from Boston): "Hey there. I'm in the ER.  Got bitten by a black widow.  Love ya."  So much for a relaxing end to her fun getaway.Several hours of mental bliss later, I was discharged from the ER, and picked up by my Dad, who took me to the pharmacy to pick up my meds (vicodin for pain, muscle relaxants). I was slurring words, and otherwise out of it, and happy to get home to relax.The next 48 hours were literally a blur.  I barely remember any of that time, and mentally, lost track of days and hours.  It freaked my wife out when I said I thought my Mom had spent the night so I guess I was hallucinating.We assumed at the time, that the meds were the culprit, but now later, we're pretty sure the delerium was a byproduct of the neurotoxins.The medical literature suggests that recovery happens within 3 to 5 days.  Nights 3 and 4 and 5 were complete disasters for me.  For some completely unknown reason, I was sweating profusely at night.  As in, literally soaking through my sheets and changing my sheets 3 times on one night and twice the next.  Wet, not damp.Specifically, I was leaking sweat out of my legs.  I'd wipe them off, and they'd bead up immediately.  It was freaky, to say the least.Also, I was having trouble concentrating, or being coherent for up to 5 days.  Sleep was next to impossible, and I was getting worn down. I later learned my wife was doing her own Google searches to see what the risks were of permanent brain damage. And, I think my life insurance was promptly renewed shortly thereafter.The doctors switched me over from vicodin to valium (one makes the pain go away, one makes you not care about the pain).  Finally, I got a decent night sleep on Thursday, and a good one on Friday.  I awoke on Saturday morning (Day 6) feeling like a human being for the first time, and proceeded to clean the garage like a freakin' maniac.Upon further inspection of my shoe in question, I discovered that the spider was harboring an egg sac inside my shoe.  How rude of me to put my foot in there.  She was actually quite restrained in waiting so long to bite me, and it turns out that these deadly creatures are incredibly passive.  This is why it's so rare that a bite happens, as in fact, I discovered, these spiders are everywhere in the area where I was living.If this happens to you, hang in there, and ride it out.  You will get better, but it takes some time.When I returned to work, my co-workers had decorated my cubicle with all sorts of Spiderman memorabilia and delighted in my misery.  All in good fun.  Embed Quote

About ten years ago I was cleaning out a storage shed. I had reached in behind a door frame and felt something bite. I pulled my arm out and saw the spider still on my arm. I dropped her in a mason jar to take her with me to the ER and went inside to call my wife. I did a little research on what to expect and figured that I had a couple of hours before I started exhibiting symtoms so we went out for dinner. I was fine during dinner. The site of the bite was slightly red and the weirdest thing was that in a ring around the bite about 1.5 inches across my skin was sweating. No where else but that little area. I was starting to have cramping in my stomach by the time we checked into the ER. The nurses/Dr.s were pretty skeptical about my diagnosis until I produced the spider. They told me that while anti-venom did exist, the side effects were worse than what I would experience if I just rode it out. They started me on narcotics and muscle relaxants. By this point, my entire body was experiencing random spasms. The worst was in the abdomen. It would spasm and lock up for 30 seconds before releasing. This repeated in a bell curve for better part of 6 hours. 30 seconds of cramping followed by two minutes of relaxation at the beginning and the end while the peak in the middle was 30 seconds of cramping, 30 seconds relaxation.. By morning I was better with the spasms receding. They discharged me and I was fine (albeit) tired.  Embed Quote

Being an emergency physician in California, I've treated several black widow bites over the years. Given the number of black widows that I see around my own house, I'm surprised that we don't see black widow bites on a weekly basis. Instead, I only have a handful of cases after over 20 years in full time clinical practice. This just tells me that they are very shy and are generally loathe to bite humans. Nevertheless, I've witness some pretty severe symptoms with widespread muscle cramps and nausea. Whether we have access to the anti-venom or not, we treat each symptom on it's own with whatever medications we can that will help. Unfortunately, the anti-venom is not available as easily as rattlesnake antivenin and in many cases, by the time you receive the anti-venom, the patient is frequently over the worst part of the syndrome already. Nevertheless, if you are bit by any spider or insect, I recommend catching it (ideally without squishing it) and bringing it in with you so that a positive ID can be made. I DO NOT recommend trying to catch any venomous snake for the same purpose as I have seen a number of people come in to the ED after having been bit on the hand by a snake that they thought was dead. (take a picture with your cell phone instead!)  Embed Quote

1973 Tucson AZ.  Low rent grad student housing.  Maximillian, my 140 pound bullmastiff was allowed out in the fenced yard.  He could come and go as he pleased via an old wooden screen door that he had figured out how to open.  Max was a sweetie.  He lived with another dog and three cats.  The youngest cat had been weened too early and had chosen Max as a surrogate mother.  The cat used to curl up on Max's back for naps.About sundown Max came in the house and proceeded to rest his head in my lap.  He needed comforting.  As I watched, his face started to swell.  His eyes were swelling shut and his breathing was becoming ragged. Of course pets plan their mis-adventures for the worst times.  A Saturday evening.  I had visions of taking the dog to an emergency vet hospital.  The kind where they make you slide hundred dollar bills in a mail slot in the door before unlocking.  Fortunately I had the phone number of just such an after hours vet.  When I explained the dog's symptoms, and told him that I had seen many black widows near the foundation of the house, we both concurred that he had probably been investigating something near the house and stuck his nose into a web.  Upon inspection I found what looked like a bite on his nose.The vet asked if we had any anti-histamine meds, which we did.  Then he asked for Max's weight.  Since Max weighed 140 pounds, the vet recommended doubling the human dosage.  Max took pills beautifully.  All I had to do was pretend they were dog treats and he would gulp them down without a hesitation.I stayed up with him that night and by about 3 am, he was breathing normally.  By noon the next day he still had some swelling and his eyes were puffy, but he was OK.From then on, about once a week I took my bottle gas propane torch and a flashlight out spider hunting around dusk.  Black Widows like to be close to the ground, and they hunt at dusk.  They build webs from the ground up about a foot onto the house foundations.  We never had them inside the house, but I used to smoke a half dozen in an evening with my torch.  Max lived another decade, and achieved the status of best dog I ever had.  Embed Quote

I worked Terminix for over 2 years , from Marin to the Oregon border. Under houses. I was bit only once; as I am highly allergic to bee stings I expected a visit to the hospital. But, alas, no, everything turned out fine. My muscles and bones ached...horribly.I sweated and was sick. The bite area was red and raised for a week or so and itched. Beautiful insects, David Quammen has a great essay on them.Not as bad being bitten by thousands of fleas in Hupa. Under a house of a Quebecer, my white tee shirt became black within minutes. Then, biting. I collapsed and my temp rose, I drove back to Eureka to the er, vision doubled and sick as a dog. Fleas are also interesting, not pretty, barbaric and wehrmachtian with their metal mandibles and plates. Athletic. All the stories here give me goose-bumps. So so glad to not be under houses.Glad the author is doing better.  Embed Quote

I grew up in Southern California.  I was bitten on the palmar surface of my right hand, with fang marks seen by a physician on the callused skin overlying the third metatarsal head (where the "bird flipping" finger meets the palm of the hand).  The doctor told me the calluses had prevented the spider from envenomating me, and after a bit of observation, I went home.  The calluses were from picking cantaloupes.My youngest brother wasn't so lucky.  He was swimming in my parents' above-ground pool.  We used to sun ourselves on the roof of a garage nearby and lounge around on webbed chairs between dips in the pool.  He must have gotten the spider wound up in his swim trunks.  When he jumped into the pool the spider bit him.  Multiple times.He would up in the hospital doped up and getting several calcium injections.He said it was the worst pain of his life.  Embed Quote

Very familiar from our SoCal residence era with the brown recluse and the black widow spiders but the latter has some curative effects.Working on a hobby car that had sat undisturbed for ~ a year and a half, Ifelt the prick reaching behind the (transverse) engine and thought itwas just a rough casting from the engine block.I went to work the next day feeling a little queasy and by midafternoon, was on the edge of upchucking so told my secretary I washeading for home.I was still miles away when I pulled off of the road and bailed out to vomit.I crawled under the covers at home and barely got up for nearly 48 hours.When I did, I checked vitals and found my blood pressure and pulserate way below my normal; under 100mm systolic, 50-60mm diastolic and arate of a little above 50.One thing that struck me was my pulse was rock solid and regularinstead of arrhythmic which it had been since a chemical poisoning inthe 70s from gassed-off Teflon.On my inner right forearm, I had what seemed to be a bruise but some2" across, perfectly round and with precisely defined edges. In themiddle was the tiniest point of a bite.I went back to the car with a good light and found the web and myattacker who I paid back with a death sentence for a bad couple of days.It was more than two years later that I noticed my arrhythmia was backand shortly thereafter got bitten again but with only milder sideeffects and a pale circular 'bruise.'Voila! My circulatory system was back to normal again.The third time (we had the widows all over), no nausea, faintyellowish bruise mark and my lowered BP, pulse and slowed heart ratepersisted for many years.My VA cardiac specialist took notes when I described this to him andwill investigate whether any research has been done on widow venom formedicinal use.For some reason, I'm not interested in personally playing with arecluse to see if they might have any positive influence on the body.  Embed Quote

I was bitten when I was ten. I saw the spider that bit me quite clearly and it was definitely a black widow. I got a welt on the back of my hand and I had cold like symptoms for a few days (or maybe I had a cold) but other than that, nothing happened. I didn't tell my parents because I got bitten when I was someplace I wasn't supposed to be. I was down by an old quarry where I guess a kid had drowned once (which was why I wasn't supposed to be there) and some friends and I were investigating an old tree trunk and I stuck my hand in a hole, felt a hard pinch and pulled my hand out and there she was sitting on the back of my hand.  As she crawled off and into the messy remains of her web I could see the red hourglass on her belly.  I just watched her climb back into the hole at the base of the trunk.  I remember thinking that she was pretty. Now I think they are kind of cool and pretty, I've taught my kids how to avoid them, but we still admire them from afar, and marvel at how many asian cockroaches they can eat! No need to spray poison here.  Embed Quote

I come from spider country where you learn to identify and fear these little beasts.  I was reaching into something that hadn't been cleaned in a long time.  It was a surprising little pin prick sting, how could such a tiny critter actually make you feel some pain.  I guess fingers are sensitive.I called poison control.  They told me I should stay put and it wasn't worth sending an ambulance.  Call back in half an hour if there is a problem.  Is it so crazy in North County San Diego they can't afford to do a welfare call on a Tuesday night?  Chances are you'll be fine they said, two times out of three they don't inject any venom.  That wasn't very comforting.  It was very late and I was so tired I wasn't sure I could stay up.  One of my old relatives had suffered permanent neurological damage from one of these spiders.  I must have fallen asleep.  Nothing happened.  I ate a breakfast burrito the next morning.  Embed Quote

Oh yeah, baby!The only way I could explain the beautiful, and life altering, experience of being bitten by one of those wicked little black widows would be to say that I would rather have been strung up naked by my toes, in the middle of the town square, have my naked body slathered in honey, and then have an entire battalion of honey-starved Winnie the Pooh bears set loose to devour me at their pleasure.  I know it wouldn't be pretty, and I know that images of this situation will haunt your dreams for many nights to come.I can assure you that the black widow bite was just as horrific.  That little farging   ice-hole of a bastage spider bit me on the knee.  My knee swelled up to the size of Quasimodo's head.  My skin became so white and pasty that I could have given the Pillsbury dough boy a run for his money.  Every time I tried to walk, I cursed the God's of black widow spiders.  The pain was horrific.I eventually received an anti-venom.  Can anyone say 'Nectar of the Gods'.  So here's what it was like- enormous swelling at the site of the bite.  Vomiting, a fever from hell, body aches that are hard to describe.  Headaches that gave me tunnel vision.But the absolutely worst, most god-awful consequence of it all was that I couldn't do the horizontal-hula with my wife for a week.  Need I say more?  Embed Quote

I was getting chickens out if my pin and I reached inside as I came out there was a black widow running toward me, I jumped freaked out a little then a few minutes passed and I am feeling a server burning pain and redness on my elbow! I'm so scared! It may of bit me! My son drew a a circle around it it has been burning now for 2 hours like a cigeratte burn on the skin! I just don't know if it bit me and am horrified! I called our small town dr office they said wait it out or come get antibiotic! Help! How do I know for sure?  Embed Quote

column9: I have used www.ewg.com/skindeep, but have found that it is difficult to tell how dangerous or safe one product is versus another. Additionally, I have read a number of articles that say EWG overstates the danger (including a survey of toxicologists: www.toxicology.org/pr/AreChemicalsPR.pdf) in order to promote their own advocacy.
column10: One way to determine the safety of chemicals is by reading their MSDS (Material Safety Data Sheets). Specifically, look for the reported LD50 or LC50 values (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Med...), which is the amount of the chemical required to kill half of the given population of organism (typically rats). You can somewhat extrapolate the LD value to the body mass of a human. Other information in the MSDS is also useful.You can obtain MSDS sheets for many chemicals by simply googling the chemical name and appending MSDS to your query.  Embed Quote

column9: I have used www.ewg.com/skindeep, but have found that it is difficult to tell how dangerous or safe one product is versus another. Additionally, I have read a number of articles that say EWG overstates the danger (including a survey of toxicologists: www.toxicology.org/pr/AreChemicalsPR.pdf) in order to promote their own advocacy.
column10: An excellent and comprehensive source of information is the book: Dying To Look Good, by Christine Hoza Farlow. This guide is conservative, but that is a good thing. The most dangerous substance in an oil refinery is benzene, but 100 years ago it was used as after shave. In 100 years from now, what will they be thinking about the chemicals we smear on our bodies today?  Embed Quote

As usual in toxicology, carcinogenicity is linked to 2 particular mechanisms : mutagenic effect, proliferating effect.Carcinogenicity is the results of thoses 2 effects.In diesel exhaust, there are two main components which are less retrieved in others combustion engines. Suspended particles containing PAHs (polycyclics aromatics hydrocarbures), and nitrogen dioxide.PAHs seem to be more proliferating than mutagenic (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubm...)They induces intracellular signaling pathway which can lead to cell dedifferenciation and proliferation (like NFkB). But PAHs are mutagenic too.Nitrogen dioxide is mainly mutagenic. As ususally, the mechanism is by damaging the DNA, chemical modification of the basis, induction replication and traduction errors.This mechanism is common for all the chemical reactive substances which can access to DNA (membrane permeability to the substance)  Embed Quote

column9: http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/...
column10: The consumption of 'alcohol based hand gel' (hand sanitiser) is a relatively common problem in English hospitals.We admit a number of patients to the wards who use the opportunity to drink the sanitiser, it is readily available on all of our wards to attempt to reduce the incidence of hospital acquired infection.A patient of ours was recently found to have consistently raised blood alcohol levels despite being unable to leave hospital because of serious liver problems. After investigation, he was found to be drinking the hand sanitiser which was available in great quantities. EDIT:-the patients who tend to consume this in hospitals are usually substance dependent alcohol users and they are usually likely to drink large quantities.The products usually contain high percentages of ethanol and isopropanol. The toxic effects are reported by the poisons information centre as follows:-EthanolSevere and potentially fatal2000-4000 mg/L (200-400 mg/dL, 43.4 - 86.9 mmol/L) - Respiratory depression, hypotension, loss of protective airway reflexes (risk of aspiration), hypothermia, incontinence, coma, hypoglycaemia (particularly in children) which can lead to seizures. Polycythemia has been reported.Cardiac arrhythmias including atrial fibrillation and atrioventricular block have been recorded. Myocardial infarction has been reported after a large acute ingestion (Gowda RM et al, 2003).Metabolic acidosis may be present and may be severe. The degree of acidosis cannot, however, be predicted by blood ethanol concentrations (Zehtabachi et al, 2005). A ketoacidosis may be present particularly following an ethanol binge in patients with a history of chronic ethanol abuse and malnutrition (Peces R, 2008).Isopropanol :-Gastrointestinal: Burning sensation in mouth and throat, nausea, vomiting, dysarthria, acetone on the breath, abdominal pain, gastritis, haematemesis, melaena.CNS: Ataxia, headache, dizziness, drowsiness, stupor, hallucinations, areflexia, muscle weakness. In severe poisoning CNS and respiratory depression may occur leading to deep coma, cyanosis, convulsions.Cardiovascular: Initially tachycardia. In severe cases myocardial depression may develop leading to bradycardia, hypotension and dysrhythmias.Other complications may include hypoglycaemia or hyperglycaemia, red blood cell haemolysis, ketonuria, renal tubular acidosis, hepatic dysfunction, rhabdomyolysis, and bronchopneumonia.Obviously these effects are usually only seen in patients who have consumed large quantities so all but the most determined would not have them.  Embed Quote

column9: http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/...
column10: Alcohol-based sanitizers containing 60–95% ethyl or isopropyl alcohol are used in many health care institutions as a primary infection control measure (1).  Even a 1-ounce bottle ingestion of a high ethanol content product may pose a hazard if ingested by small children. A 1-ounce ingestion of a hand sanitizer containing 62% ethanol by a 20-kg child may result in a blood ethanol concentration of >100 mg/dL (4). Typical alcohol related intoxication can be lethal in the range of >=400 mg/dL, although death has occurred at lower levels (2). Acute ethanol intoxication can lead to several serious life-threatening clinical consequences includinig hypothermia, central nervous system and respiratory depression, cardiac dysrhythmias or arrest, hypotension, nausea and vomiting, acute liver injury, myoglobinuria, lactic and ketoacidosis, and hypoglycemia(3). The primary therapy for severe ethanol overdose is primarily provided with airway protection, respiratory support, and addressing associated metabolic disturbances. Hemodialysis is effective at removing ethanol but is usually unnecessary if the airway is protected, there is no other severe organ injury present, and the patient is responding to supportive measures for cardiovascular and metabolic systems. Alcohol dehydrogenase inhibition with fomepizole is contraindicated in hand sanitizer ingestions, because toxicity from ethanol or propanols will be prolonged without added benefit (4). Ref 1.     Am J Health-Syst Pharm—Vol 65 Dec 1, 20082.     Crit Care Resusc 2003; 5:106–1083.     Eur J Intern Med 2008; 19:561–5674.     Critical care medicine 2012; 40 (1):290 -294  Embed Quote

column9: http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/...
column10: According to that article it is not safe with a sizable portion of drinkers being hospitalized. Drinking alcohol in general is not considered safe in many situations.Although I must say that the aloe-infused vintages may be a good mixer when muddled with mint and lime juice, creating a manojito.++++=Do NOT try this at home!  Embed QuoteAnswered in thirty-two minutes.

column9: http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/...
column10: The question should be "How unsafe is drinking...?"Any substance that is not marked as potable by the manufacturers is UNSAFE. How unsafe? is immaterial. We have had patients dying with 1 teaspoonful of floor disinfectant.  Embed Quote

column9: http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/...
column10: I just read an article that explains why you would ask such a ridiculous question http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/....  My answer is please don't.  Life is too valuable to waste it on such foolishness.  Embed QuoteAnswered in thirty minutes.

This just hit the news today (April 17): Poison Feared in Letters Sent to Obama and Lawmakers. Per the NYTimes story:Poison Feared in Letters Sent to Obama and LawmakersThe Federal Bureau of Investigation said on Wednesday that a letter addressed to President Obama appeared to contain the poison ricin.The letter was intercepted at a screening facility outside the White House, the Secret Service said.It was received on Tuesday — similar timing to a letter addressed to Senator Roger Wicker, Republican of Mississippi, that tested positive for ricin. The letter addressed to the president had similar markings and was similar in appearance to the one addressed to Mr. Wicker, according to a law enforcement official.In a statement, the F.B.I. said that the letter to the president contained “a granular substance that preliminarily tested positive for ricin.” The bureau also said that ricin had been discovered at another mail screening facility.I've seen a few news stories mention that ricin was featured on Breaking Bad, but nobody has speculated about a direct connection yet (i.e., the possibility that whoever sent the poison learned about it from Breaking Bad).It seems likely that Breaking Bad has created more awareness about ricin than any other media format, event, etc.  Embed Quote

No,it hasn't. Ricin has been used as a plot device in a number of books and films prior to its airing on Breaking Bad. And, because of its relative toxicity to the amount required, it will be used again. Breaking Bad simply capitalized upon the fearsome nature of the poison and its rarity (along with demonstrating Walter White's chemical abilities) to enhance its narrative. Frankly, ricin is an exceptionally difficult poison to use. Since even minute quantities can injure or kill people, it is hard to employ and its symptoms and the speed of its efficacy would lead medical examiners to search for a toxin as a reason that a person abruptly died or was sickened. I would suggest that the questioner study the case of Georgi Markov, a Bulgarian dissident living in London, whose death was caused by ricin. A report of his death and its suspected was one of the most popular segments in the CBS news magazine 60 Minutes and it was aired several times by the network. This case was almost certainly the inspiration for the storyline in Breaking Bad. Reference:Markov's umbrella assassin revealed  Embed Quote

column9: Foods that are toxic to dogs include chocolate, coffee, grapes and a long list of otherwise unrelated foods. Why are they all toxic? What the difference between us and them that makes these foods toxic to them?
column10: Humans are very exceptional omnivores, capable of consuming a much broader range of substances than a dog.Dogs are scavenging predators which only since their relationship with humans began to adapt to being able to consume starches, which appears a distinguishing difference between wolves and dogs.While we often see animals like dogs as having amazing physical advantages to us humans, such as natural athleticism, flexibility and senses we have our own advantages. This includes the ability to consume with enjoyment a host of substances which are poison to our pets. We have a GI tract and biochemistry which has adapted to be able to extract nutrition from marginal foods, to shrug off many toxins, and a sense of taste which informs us in detail about what we are eating. Lets face it, a dog can eat poo and like it - and will happily chomp down on any number of substances which can't even vaguely be considered safe to eat. We've got them outclassed in terms of an anatomy designed to survive on just about anything. Our GI tract is proportionally much longer (and cats, obligate predators, shorter) than dogs, and the microbial flora more extensive. Our jaws can grind from side to side. Our saliva contains digestive enzymes. We're like Alien as far as dogs are concerned holy crap.Our stomachs are relatively small and pass food off to our intestines after a few hours. A Dog's stomach is folded like an accordion to expand to hold a mass of food which is digested over a period of about 24 hours. Our intestines excel at absorbing nutrients and water. A dog with diarrhea can die very quickly compared to a human, as they are unable to compensate for the loss of water and electrolytes. In short, compared to dogs we are amazing eating machines. Of course, we have to admire their enthusiasm for food, themselves. Dogs and Humans, foodie friends.  Embed Quote

column9: Foods that are toxic to dogs include chocolate, coffee, grapes and a long list of otherwise unrelated foods. Why are they all toxic? What the difference between us and them that makes these foods toxic to them?
column10: coffee and chocolate are both toxic because they are very close to the same thing, and they are also toxic to us in high-enough doses.  Suspect we killed off the people who were super-sensitive to caffeine...  there was no reason to give coffee to dogs, and they don't have natural access to chocolate, so there could be no path for evolutionary adoption.  Face it, lots of the things we like but aren't good for us (which is the relationship of dogs to chocolate) are killing us too, now.  The grape thing is new, and I'm not sure what it is. Onions and garlic have the same compounds, so that's not two different toxic substances, it's two delivery systems for the same things.  Dogs won't eat onions in the wild, I'll bet.So I suppose some of the problem is that domestic dogs have access to foods they'd never attend to in the wild.  Grapes don't grow where dogs can get to them, outside of cultivation.Might also be an element of all the filler we put into commercial dog food, teaching dogs to eat stuff they might otherwise reject in the wild.  Embed QuoteAnswered in twenty-eight minutes.

column9: How many cigarettes can you eat before you die?
column10: Yes, you will get nicotine poisoning.  Approximately 30-40 cigarettes should do you in if you are not already a smoker."Sixty milligrams of nicotine (the amount in about 30-40 cigarettes), has the potential to kill an adult who is not a smoker if all of the nicotine were absorbed. This figure is ~120 mg in chronic  cigarette smokers, smoking an average of 20 non-light cigarettes  delivering ~1.7 mg of nicotine each daily. One cigarette's-worth of  nicotine is enough to make a toddler severely ill. In some cases  children have become poisoned by topical medicinal creams which contain  nicotine.[1][1] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nic...  Embed Quote

column9: How many cigarettes can you eat before you die?
column10: YES!  Eating just ONE cigarette would kill a child or light weight adult non-smoker.  The LD (lethal dose) for nicotine is 0.5-1mg/kg for humans.  So, if someone weighs 150 pounds, that's 68 kilograms, then their lethal dose would be between 34 and 68mg.  1 American cigarette typically contains 15-25mg of nicotine. (Source:  Clinical Toxicology of Commercial Products by Gosselin, et al, 1984)The Viola Yee's response incorrectly claimes 30-40 cigarettes is lethal.  The confusion arises from the source's (wikipedia's) data.  The Wikipedia entry references the Washington Post article to quantify how much nicotine is in each cigarette.  The Post article describes its nicotine "As measured using a method that mimics actual smoking, the nicotine delivered per cigarette".  Here's the important part: cigarettes typically DELIVER 0.5-2.5mg nicotine/cigarette when smoked however they CONTAIN 15-25mg/cigarette.  A very important difference!Considering nicotines popularity & toxicity, the low occurrence rate of accidental deaths is stunning.  If you smoke or wear nicotine patches be aware that just ONE could KILL a curious child or even a foolish teenager.  Embed Quote

column9: How many cigarettes can you eat before you die?
column10: well, eating all kind of garbage can make you die :)  Embed Quote

Assuming that one would look "older" before one dies, it does. Living in places with polluted environments such as Mumbai and Beijing, one has a probability of dying 12 to 5.5 years earlier than one's countrymen living in relatively less polluted areas of one's country.Beijingers will live 5.5 years less and Mumbaikars 12 years less (than their respective countrymen elsewhere)  Embed Quote

The water is collected and then treated to remove as much waste as possible.  Then the cleaned water is released into a nearby river.For example, Denver applies nine different cleaning processes and removes 95% of the pollutants.  Their process produces "biosolids" (clean and/or composted poop) which is sold as fertilizer.  They also generate and capture methane during the process, and use the methane as fuel to create electricity.  Then the water is returned to the South Platte River.1. Bar screens remove objects ranging from children's toys to false teeth. 2. Grit basins remove larger solid wastes. 3. Primary clarifiers remove smaller solid wastes. 4. Aeration basins enable millions of microorganisms to digest the organic waste remaining in the water. 5. Secondary clarifiers allow the microorganisms clump together and settle to the bottom. After  further processing to kill harmful organisms, these biosolids will go  to enrich Colorado farmland. 6. Chlorination and de-chlorination processes provides final wastewater treatment. 7. Digestion involves anaerobic digestion by microbes of solids into biosolids and methane. 8. Outfalls are where the cleaned wastewater pours into the South Platte River. 9. Biosolids (our brand is METROGRO® ) are applied to our METROGRO Farm and privately-owned farms and incorporated into the soil either by tilling or applying them to  the soil surface depending on the land's slope or erosion potential. 10. Methane gas from the digestion process is used to generate electricity at our facility Not every city produces biosolids and electricity, but screening, settling ponds, aeration, and digestion steps are usually present.Here is a photo I took of the sewage treatment facility for a small town in Alberta, population of about 1200 people.  I don't know if they will hit the 95% removal achieved by Denver.Quoted from their Page on Denver Metrowastewater  Embed Quote

They utilize mechanical wastewater treatment plants that separate waste solids and nutrients from the water. The water is returned to the environment. Some of the waste and nutrients are reused in the plant. The remainder may be suitable to be used for agriculture or disposed of in some other way.  Embed QuoteAnswered in forty minutes.

column9: Who are the worst polluters of earth, air and water internationally?
column10: In my opinion it must be BP, the scale of their oil spill disater was epic and the amount of damage it caused, not to mention the cost to clean it up, is humoungous.  Embed Quote

column9: With millions of tons or garbage that flows into the sea everyday and the constant dumping in the sea, if one were to drain the oceans away, how polluted of a picture would we observe on the seabed?
column10: Google "ocean receding before tsunami" --> images. You can see how polluted the shore line is. As to oceans themselves, it is up for debate as to how much pollution actually reaches it, how much is decomposed naturally and how much settles down on the seabed. An indicator would be amount of pollutants found in seafood. The levels of cadmium, aluminum, chromium, lead, silver, mercury, and titanium in fish and mammals has consistently increased over the years.This article refers to the intake of heavy metals by people from approx  1800-1990:http://bmb.oxfordjournals.org/co...Another indicator would be the levels of heavy metals found in whales. The reason is that whales travel 50K+ miles, from the poles to the tropics and are mammals themselves. There is overwhelming evidence that the amount of toxic metals in whale tissue has increased too:http://articles.boston.com/2010-...I could go on about these statistics, but we know less about our ocean beds than we do about the lunar surface. Given that seafood is the main source of protein for at least 700 million people, this is a very serious issue that does not get as much attention as say, deforestation or global warming.  Embed Quote

I guess it depends on what is in the sink or shower.  Some soaps  or cleaners  may not be very healthy for animals or humans.  But if you are asking  if you can drink  water from the faucet  in the sink or shower, then  I  do not think  that would be a problem.  Embed Quote

The air contains many pollutants which can cause asthma, heart diseases and respiratory infections, problems breathing. Strokes are also common in countries where pollutant levels are the highest. The risk of lung cancer is also increased because nitrogen oxide concentrations are high.  Embed Quote

This is because rain pulls down the air particulates with it to the ground.Particulate matter under 2.5 micrometers in diameter, also known as PM2.5 or "fine" particles, are generally accepted to be the most severe type of air pollution, since "Because of their small size (approximately 1/30th the average width of a human hair), fine particles can lodge deeply into the lungs" [1]. In fact, the US bases the majority of its Air Quality Index (AQI) measurements solely on the quantity of PM2.5 in the atmosphere.How do these fine particles get removed from the air? From [2]:In general, the smaller and lighter a particle is, the longer it will stay in the air. Larger particles (greater than 10 micrometers in diameter) tend to settle to the ground by gravity in a matter of hours whereas the smallest particles (less than 1 micrometer) can stay in the atmosphere for weeks and are mostly removed by precipitation.[1] http://www.epa.gov/pmdesignation...[2] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Par...  Embed Quote

It may be due to the fact that air pollution is measured in terms of concentration of harmful gases like sulphur oxides, carbon oxides and when rainfall happens as per the reaction H2O(l) + CO2(g) = H2CO3(aq) carbon dioxide gets converted to carbonic acid and similarly sulphur dioxide gets converted to  Sulfurous acid and these precipitates as liquid. So their  concentration is reduced in atmosphere. And hence leading to reduction in air pollution levels.  Embed Quote
SO2 and nitrogen oxides are reduced in the same way like CO2.  Embed Quote

column10: Bhopal  Embed Quote

Some amount of cleanup would be "possible", but it certainly would not be efficient, nor ultimately effective. This is because:-The patch is very large (300,000-6,000,000 square miles), and there are actually 5 patches in the world's oceans (see 5gyres.org)-The debris is quite diffuse and is distributed throughout the water column down to great depthsand-The debris breaks down into smaller and smaller pieces. You would have to decide what mesh-sized net you wanted to use, but you would be inadvertently catching sea life of the same size range, something I assume one would want to avoid.The only solution is to reduce the amount of plastic pollution entering the oceans. As with many things, it is far superior to address the cause, rather than try to fix the damage. So much debris is entering the oceans as we speak that even if there were a method to clean up the patch, it would immediately be replenished.  Embed Quote

1The NOAA leads efforts to research, prevent, and reduce the vortex, but cleaning it isn't simple - especially because the vortex(es) are moving, and the pieces of plastic very small. I wrote a bit about it here: (Trash Vortexes, Garbage Patches, Or Floating Islands Of Waste? Why Marine Debris Is Bad News - Curiousmatic)Basically, attempts to clean could cost between 100 and 500 million a year - and using nets could kill more ocean wildlife. So it's definitely complicated, to say the least. You might be glad to hear, though, that there was an IndieGogo campaign to test the feasibility of an invention/concept that would remove vast amounts of plastics using floating booms. It was funded, and is currently in preliminary testing phases - aaand you can check that out here: The Ocean Cleanup - Boyan Slat  Embed Quote

column9: What should one do if entrapped in an area with polluted & contaminated water. Survival Techniques.
column10: If you are in a north American desert, the groundwater and wellwater may be full of borax and salt. You will need to distill it, by putting it in a solar still or putting clean hot stones into the water container and covering it with a plastic sheet or glass pane, and letting the purified water drip into a bowl or cup hung in the center of the container. The distilled water is safe to drink and use in the garden. Barrel cactus can be eaten in emergency, but it will give you diarrhea if you gorge on it. Prickly pear leaves can be cooked and eaten if one is careful to cut away all the spines. Prickly pear fruit is very sweet and can also be eaten if spines are removed carefully and completely.If you are in a place that is contaminated due to flooding, filter the available water by straining it through 4 layers of clean cloth and then boiling it for 5 minutes.This will kill the microbes, but not gasoline/petroleum and chemicalcontaminants, you will need to distill the water to get rid of those. If water smells like sewage or sulfur, it may be contaminated by a leaking septic line.You can distill it, but even handling is somewhat unwise, and another water source should be found if possible.  Embed Quote

column10: It is held in place with cables, flotation devices, and, of course, the rocks it's on. No one wants it to slip off the rocks into the nearby deep water.  [1]It is full of fuel and other toxic materials that have to be removed carefully to avoid environmental damage.  When that is complete, the ship itself will be removed.  It was thought that the ship might have to be cut up if they could not get it off the rocks in one piece.The winning bidder for the salvage, Titan-Mioperi, intends to remove the wreck intact.  This is definitely preferable to minimize environmental damage to the area.Salvage operations began only this week—June 15, 2012.The process will involve the construction of a platform below sea  level and attaching watertight chambers called caissons to the ship’s  side that’s above water.Two cranes attached to the platform will then pull the ship upright,  aided by the water-filled chambers. Once the ship is up on the platform,  more caissons will be attached to the other side of its hull. [2][1] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cos...[2] http://blogs.sun-sentinel.com/so...  Embed Quote

column9: Who's responsibility should this be and are there any feasible methods for clearing it up?
