I had a group of exchange students from Beijing this spring, and the one thing they most enjoyed about being in Cambridge was the air quality.  It was wonderful to them to be able to run outside in our clean air.  I think it's because there's almost always a lot of wind.Cambridge, MA Air Quality shows that Cambridge has been improving fairly rapidly in most aspects of air quality in the last decade, as it's switched over from being a city of light industry to businesses and high technology.  The water quality is also quite good, as 2012 Annual Drinking Water Quality Report indicates.  Embed Quote
Pretty much non-existent. Maybe when Mass Ave is jammed up you get more than a whiff of car exhaust, but otherwise I've never had a problem with air quality.  Embed Quote

Added to that, when I lived there, the city of Cambridge had this water quality report mailed to your home in which it extensively detailed the contents of its tap water and I can tell you from experience that it was reassuringly good and that the city of Boston, barely double the size in its official limits, should make a benchmark of it.I miss the cleanliness of Cambridge, though it can be a pretty dull place at times.  Embed Quote

column9: SCIENCE FOCUS: DEAD ZONES
column10: One cause is fertilizer runoff. Agricultural fertilizers run off into coastal areas (say where the Mississippi empties into the Gulf of Mexico. The excessive plant nutrients causes excessive algae to grow. Algae can use up oxygen at night, die and decompose which uses oxygen, and even block sunlight from plants, depleting oxygen. This results in an area with little oxygen, and so little life. Decaying organic matter like sewage or manure (which also contain these nutrients) can also consume oxygen due to aerobic bacteria.  Embed Quote

column9: Source of question:Freedom Industries files for bankruptcyFreedom Industries Chapter 11 Filing Reveals Owners' StrategyNew Accusations Against Freedom Industries in West Virginia Spill
column10: Yes - for several reasons.  First, the company meets the requirements to file for chapter 11 bankruptcy protection under the United States Bankruptcy Code.  If a party does not feel that the company meets the requirements, there are avenues laid out in the Bankruptcy Code for that party to assert a challenge to the propriety of the bankruptcy filing.  The Bankruptcy Code also sets forth the right for a party to seek to have a bankruptcy case dismissed "for cause" and sets forth what constitutes "cause" for those purposes. Moreover, there are many historical examples of companies that have done significant damage to communities - whether environmental, financial, or otherwise.  Bankruptcy is designed to allow a breathing spell and to get representatives of all of the stakeholders (meaning the various groups of people who are impacted by the company's operations) to have a say in how the company's assets and liabilities are addressed.  This organized process governed by a set of rules and customs developed over decades offers a far superior alternative to the options which would exist outside of bankruptcy.  Embed Quote

column9: Facts about pollution in China are often censored by the Communist Party of China (the government). How bad is it really?
column10: "How bad is pollution in China" is a rather broad question. It really depends on what you're asking. It is in China that I've seen some of the clearest, starriest nights I have ever seen in my life. It is also in China that I've seen some of the thickest smog. It is in China that I've seen some of the clearest, most translucent rivers, as well as some of the most polluted.Pollution takes on many forms, and China is a very vast country.If you're talking about CO2, the invisible gas that's going to cause global warming and a type of pollution, USA's per-capita CO2 emissions is about 3 times that of China. Yes, China is the number 1 carbon emitter in the world, but the USA isn't far behind, and China's population is much larger. You don't notice it in either country because, well, CO2 is invisible and quickly goes up there and does some damage to the entire Earth. The CO2 is not going to cause health problems in either case, but will quickly destroy the Earth by warming it up if continued. On the upside, China is making much faster progress on implementing alternative energy solutions and has comparatively excellent public transportation and ability to quickly alter infrastructure, so my prediction is that China's per-capita CO2 emissions will rise a bit but still eventually stabilise at a level much less than that of the USA.If you're talking about dust and smog, China's dense cities tend to be quite bad and I'm sure you've seen the pictures. Beijing has frightening levels of dust and smog right now, though I've seen worse in other countries before. This is a big issue for human health since so many people live in those cities. As for China's natural and less-populated areas, especially Gansu, Xinjiang, Tibet, Qinghai and most of northern and western Sichuan, the air is generally crystal clear and pristine. So one needs to be more specific about location to analyse this question.If you're talking about chemical pollution into rivers, it highly varies. There's a lot of it downstream and very little of it upstream.In short certain types of pollution are a significant problem in parts of China, but the question is a bit too broad to answer meaningfully beyond that.  Embed Quote

column10: An unscientific answer.Pollution in Beijing was really bad. The dust and smoke in the air sometimes made it hard to see buildings a few blocks away from my company's office which was on the 33rd floor. It was as if there was a grey/tan cloud enveloping the city.  Embed Quote

More info and links are available in a post at my blog:http://bit.ly/i3bnEHChina has been the number one carbon emitter since 2006, and its emissions are increasingly dramatically every year. column9: The Gowanus is a 2 mile long canal that runs through Brooklyn NY roughly from Brooklyn Heights through Cobble Hill and Carroll Gardens before ending in Red Hook.  Over 100+ years, the area has been heavily polluted, to the point that it almost looks like it has been witness to an oil spill (which it has over a century's worth of poor waste management).  How do waste management systems deal with such heavy sludge?  What is the proper way to dispose of such a waste and what is the timeframe to undergo such a project (assumming full political and economic cooperation)?
column10: The proverbial eyesore of New York, not to mention the nose offender is quite a challenge. The last of its kind that still remains, I understand, and a truly king sized problem. Wikipedia tells me that this is the terrain:This is how it looks in the daylight:This digitally enhanced version of the above photo superimposed on a much older black and white picture of the same spot is even more interesting:Now there are two distinctly different problems in this water body:1) Oil and grease2) Sewage and organic wasteFirst problem: Condition 1 prevents the treatment of condition 2. The biological treatment that sewage requires is made impossible by heavy oil sludge, because it envelops and kills the microorganisms that would accomplish the task.Polluting oil appears in two ways: free floating and emulsified. If it is in the latter form, it has to be converted to the former by adding catalytic resins and then letting the oil separate from the water by settlement and flotation. As for floating oil, it depends on the scale. Medium to medium large scale layers are best attacked by these beasts, otherwise called drum skimmers:Essentially these are free floating boats that are normally worked by compressed air, but electrical versions are also available. The drums have a specially prepared oleophilic surface, where floating oil sticks well. The drums are rotated at medium speed, and scrapers take off the oil layer that they bring up continuously. This collects in the chamber behind the drum and is pumped off by a reciprocating pneumatic pump operated by the same compressed air supply. The collected oil is then taken by authorized recyclers who have been permitted to do so by the EPA or the local pollution control authority.On a large scale it requires sludge dredging, though. Like this:One has to be careful in dredging, however. Dredge too deep or dredge in the wrong place and you open up a major Pandora's box. There may be areas of deep slime where the really offending stuff has since acquired a layer of clay and / or sand on top. It is better to let these lie, or even consolidate on top with more sand or even concrete. It is called capping, and prevents the sludge underneath from escaping. Here is how a capping operation looks:As for dredging, large scale operations end up looking like this, so one has to also think where and how best to dispose of the offending muck.Just like a cap operation, it may well be necessary to construct a secure landfill pit, where one dumps the slime, and lets it dry in layers before topping it up again in phases till it contains as much dried sludge as it can hold. Then it is finally sealed off and planted over, like so:If it is done well, it can really transform the place. These are the before and after pictures as the Golden Horn estuary in Turkey was being dredged to restore it to its former pristine glory, and pictures of how it looked later.Now let us come to the other part, or sewage.  If it was a case of raw sewage stream that could be trapped for processing, I am rather partial to these:It is called a primary clarifier, where the sewage is fed to the central well and allowed to percolate to the outer ring where the sludge settles on the bottom slope and the bottom scrapers (or squeegees) scrape it and direct it to the central well. Using reciprocating plunger pumps, the sludge is then sucked out. Here is what a multi piston reciprocating plunger looks like:... (more)Loading... The proverbial eyesore of New York, not to mention the nose offender is quite a challenge. The last of its kind that still remains, I understand, and a truly king sized problem. Wikipedia tells me that this is the terrain:This is how it looks in the daylight:This digitally enhanced version of the above photo superimposed on a much older black and white picture of the same spot is even more interesting:Now there are two distinctly different problems in this water body:1) Oil and grease2) Sewage and organic wasteFirst problem: Condition 1 prevents the treatment of condition 2. The biological treatment that sewage requires is made impossible by heavy oil sludge, because it envelops and kills the microorganisms that would accomplish the task.Polluting oil appears in two ways: free floating and emulsified. If it is in the latter form, it has to be converted to the former by adding catalytic resins and then letting the oil separate from the water by settlement and flotation. As for floating oil, it depends on the scale. Medium to medium large scale layers are best attacked by these beasts, otherwise called drum skimmers:Essentially these are free floating boats that are normally worked by compressed air, but electrical versions are also available. The drums have a specially prepared oleophilic surface, where floating oil sticks well. The drums are rotated at medium speed, and scrapers take off the oil layer that they bring up continuously. This collects in the chamber behind the drum and is pumped off by a reciprocating pneumatic pump operated by the same compressed air supply. The collected oil is then taken by authorized recyclers who have been permitted to do so by the EPA or the local pollution control authority.On a large scale it requires sludge dredging, though. Like this:One has to be careful in dredging, however. Dredge too deep or dredge in the wrong place and you open up a major Pandora's box. There may be areas of deep slime where the really offending stuff has since acquired a layer of clay and / or sand on top. It is better to let these lie, or even consolidate on top with more sand or even concrete. It is called capping, and prevents the sludge underneath from escaping. Here is how a capping operation looks:As for dredging, large scale operations end up looking like this, so one has to also think where and how best to dispose of the offending muck.Just like a cap operation, it may well be necessary to construct a secure landfill pit, where one dumps the slime, and lets it dry in layers before topping it up again in phases till it contains as much dried sludge as it can hold. Then it is finally sealed off and planted over, like so:If it is done well, it can really transform the place. These are the before and after pictures as the Golden Horn estuary in Turkey was being dredged to restore it to its former pristine glory, and pictures of how it looked later.Now let us come to the other part, or sewage.  If it was a case of raw sewage stream that could be trapped for processing, I am rather partial to these:It is called a primary clarifier, where the sewage is fed to the central well and allowed to percolate to the outer ring where the sludge settles on the bottom slope and the bottom scrapers (or squeegees) scrape it and direct it to the central well. Using reciprocating plunger pumps, the sludge is then sucked out. Here is what a multi piston reciprocating plunger looks like:The recovered sludge is then put into one or more of these things, called anaerobic biodigesters. Apart from processing the sludge, it generates a good amount of biogas that can easily meet a part of the energy requirements of the processing facility.The final sludge that comes out is nearly as black as oil muck, and has to be put out in sludge drying beds like these. Once it is dry, it becomes organic manure par excellence for any horticultural use, and could presumably used to make the same terrain in and around the canal lush green.But all this stuff needs land to build upon, something which is very scarce in and around the New York area. Besides, the problem in Gowanus now is more that of a CSO (Combined Sewer Overflow) during the rains rather than a direct continuous raw sewage stream. And so, I propose the other solution. It is very cost effective and has negligible initial cost as well as operating cost: Hydroponic floats of the vetiver grass strain that goes by the botanical name Chrysopogon Zizanioides.This so called wonder grass is originally native to southern India but is now known the world over. It has certain very exceptional properties:1) Exceptionally long root system. Five meter roots have been recorded.2) Non self propagating and so non invasive. Produces sterile seeds.3) Has exceptional slope and soil stabilizing as well as binding properties4) Grows fast, needs no special care and is immune even to surface fires5)Takes up high amounts of P and N nutrients as well as some heavy metalsThis is how C. Zizanioides roots look when they are fully grown:These hydroponic vetiver floats are being used in Australia (and Indonesia)And a close up view of a hydroponic float:Yeah, they will just float on the water and pull up all the organic nutrients and heavy metals, leaving just clear water behind. And they look good on the landscape too. Once they have done their job, they just need to be replaced with new young plants.This video suggests how it is done:And this video demonstrates the other property of vetiver: erosion control and soil stabilization. If necessary, this property too can be used to fix the slope along the canal banks. Or they can be planted all around the secure landfills that are used to bury the dried oil muck. C. Zizanioides has excellent ability to prevent landfills from leaching out and contaminating the surrounding areas during rains.I have not included an option that already exists in the Gowanus system but seems to be presently broken: the option of dilution / free flushing of the canal. If one flushes regular seawater down the channel, the muck goes out to the open sea. Although the sea is a so called "infinite sink" in theory, in practice this stuff will not disperse evenly across the entire body. It will dilute but still be a problem for local aquatic life. What it does is that it washes the Augean Stables, Hercules fashion. It does not attack the problem at its root.Time scale? Given the size and severity of the problem, a decade seems reasonable. Expense? If one builds future inflation and cost escalation, some USD 350 million to 450 million is the estimated range.  Embed QuoteVia  Betsy Megas.

column10: What is pollution? All the water on Earth must have passed through the bladders of various beasties many times over the millions of years. Think about it: The oceans are full of fish piss. Is that pollution? Why does it not bother us? Well, water evaporates, forms clouds, falls as rain. We drink mainly rainwater, and water from rain. Another factor: This morning we were out walking in the local wildlife sanctuary. The water there is treated sewage plant effluent. There are big signs saying "Don't touch the water. It's sewage effluent." Yet the water is full of waterbirds and fish and otters and frogs and many other things. It's not hurting them. I've watched my dog drink from muddy puddles in the road with no ill effect. Are we really that much weaker than these creatures? Or is the notion of pollution a bit overblown? Maybe we need a bit of pollution to strengthen our immune systems for maximum health and resistance. Evaporation, clouds, rain. That is the absolute best water treatment technology.  Embed Quote

column9: What are the benefits and drawbacks of the superfund? How could it be improved?
column10: The statutory regime is underfunded (i.e. there is no "Superfund" left) and has carve-outs which limit its effectiveness regarding substances like oil and sewage.  But, clever lawyers (including those that work for EPA) find ways to work around these problems.  Aside from this, the CERCLA statute is vague and unclear regarding statutes of limitations and really not geared toward the sort of mega-sites that people want to see cleaned up.  So, companies pay to clean up and then litigate amongst themselves endlessly.  A lot of the criticisms you mention in your post are overblown.  Tons of articles have been written about how EPA, as an agency, has been captured by industry which has used science to stymie laudable attempts at public health. Maybe some of these are accurate.  But, cleaning up really polluted sites presents huge engineering challenges and, by nature, is going to take time -- maybe more time than it took to pollute the sites in the first place.  And cleaning a really polluted site to greenfield standards just doesn't make economic sense.  Embed Quote

column10: It's not always a direct kg/kg conversion, because in order to produce some plastics the oil molecules must have extra atoms included. For example PVC is polyvinyl chloride, which by mass is over half chlorine. But polypropylene or polyethylene are more common and are pretty close to mass parity from hydrocarbons."Of the more than 200 billion pounds of plastic the world produces each year, about 10 percent ends up in the ocean [source:Greenpeace]. Seventy percent of that eventually sinks, damaging life on the ocean floor [source:Greenpeace]. The rest floats; much of it ends up in gyres and the massive garbage patches that form there, with some plastic eventually washing up on a distant shore."http://science.howstuffworks.com... So if we believe Greenpeace (not usually a good idea) that's 3 million short tons of floating plastic added to the world's oceans every year, or about 20 million barrels of oil. Some or most of this would end up floating back onto beaches. No way to know what percent ends up in the Garbage Patch.  Embed QuoteVia  Anonymous.

column9: Since phosphates were removed from dishwasher detergents last year our dishwasher sucks.  I read in an article from NPR that you can add TSP (trisodium phosphate) from the hardware store to your dishwasher detergent to replace the phosphate, but also that the phosphate was removed from consumer detergents because of concerns about algae bloom.  Doesn't algae bloom come mostly from agricultural runoff, esp nitrogen fertilizers and animal manure?  And if it does indeed turn up around sewage outflows not contaminated with agricultural runoff, wouldn't my septic tank and leach field disperse any phosphate residue into the ground before it gets to the bottom of the watershed?  I live at several hundred feet of elevation above any running water
column10: The septic system will not treat the TSP and it will (over time) accumulate into the water table.  This will cause algae bloom downstream.  Embed Quote

There really aren't a lot of resources that come to mind, but you never know how technology will turn out. Yes, there are landfills currently being mined for minerals such as recycled Chromite, recycled Silica, and recycled Iron Oxide substitute. The landfill is a hazardous waste landfill in Ohio that accepted spent foundry sand from steel manufacturing from 1967 to 1994. A Pennsylvania company, Alexander Mill Services International, Inc (AMSI) has developed a process to recover some portions of the foundry sands. More information on this process can be found in the December 2011 edition of Industrial Minerals Magazine."Foraging for foundry sands", pages 52-55.Also, gold is currently recovered from electronic waste (ewaste) in several 3rd world landfills. Much of this ewaste is processed illegally with little to no pollution controls.  Embed Quote

column9: Myth #1 Conventional medicine and the healthcare system helps                 sick people.                    Perhaps the                 biggest health myth  today is the public's misconception that mainstream                  medicine and the healthcare system helps sick people. Nothing could                  be further from the truth.                       The freedom of people to choose natural healing,  alternative medicine                 and methods of disease prevention  could soon be threatened by corporate                 lobbyists who will  do anything to protect their wealth at the expense                 of  your health.                    Promoters of                 conventional  medicine claim that all the drug studies, approvals,                  surgical procedures,  all other treatments are based                 on  scientific evidence.  But is it really science? What passes for  "science"                 today is a collection of health myths,  half-truths, intellectual                 dishonesty and  fraudulent  reporting to help serve higher interests. Science is not really science anymore.                    90 percent of                 all diseases  (cancer, diabetes, depression, heart disease, etc.)                 are  easily preventable through diet, nutrition, sunlight and exercise.                  None of these solutions are ever promoted by conventional  medicine                 because they make no money.                    No pharmaceuticals                 actually cure  or resolve the underlying causes of disease. Even                  "successful" drugs only manage symptoms, usually at the                  cost of interfering with other physiological functions that will                  cause side effects down the road. There is no such thing as a  drug                 without a side effect.                    There is no                 financial incentive  for anyone in today's system of medicine (drug                  companies, hospitals, doctors, etc.) to actually make patients well.                  Profits are found in continued sickness, not wellness or  prevention.                    Almost all                 the "prevention"  programs you see today (such as free                 mammograms or other  screening programs) are nothing more than  patient recruitment schemes  designed to increase revenue and sickness. They use free screenings                  to scare people into agreeing to unnecessary treatments that  only lead to further disease. Mammography is a very good example. Chemotherapy is another. Nobody has any                 interest in your health except you. No  corporation, no doctor, and                 no government has any desire  to actually make you well. This has                 served the  short-term financial interests of higher powers in the                  west very well. The only healthy, aware, critically thinking individuals                  are all 100% free of pharmaceuticals and processed  foods.YTH #2 Vaccines prevent diseases and increase immunity.                                                                  The term                     "immunization",  often substituted for vaccination,                     is false and  should be legally challenged. Medical research                     has  well established that the direct injection of foreign proteins                      and other toxic material (particularly known  immune-sensitising                     poisons such as mercury) makes  the recipient more, not less,                     easily affected by  what he/she encounters in the future. This                     means  they do the opposite of immunize, commonly even preventing                      immunity from developing after natural exposure.                         The actual                     frequency of  health problems has been estimated by authorities                     to  be possibly up to 100 times, or more, greater than that reported                      by government agencies. That difference is due to the lack  of                     enforcement or incentive for doctors to report  adverse effects.                     With the anti-vaccination movements  now exposing the truth on                     the internet, the medical  community is now on high alert, defending                     their  claims and being told by vaccine manufacturers that they                      must never let their patients (or parents) think that the risks                      could outweigh the benefits, when in reality, it is  precisely                     the opposite that is true.                          The benefit risk ratio is an important  decision in anyone deciding                   whether to vaccinate or  not. Contrary to popular belief and marketing,                    childhood diseases in a developed country are not as dangerous                    as we are led to believe. Catching a particular disease does  not                   mean you willdie from it. Vaccines were actually introduced at a time when                    diseases had already declined to a low risk level. This fact is                    proven, scientifically.                          The main advances in combating   disease over  the last 200 years have been better   food and clean drinking  water...not vaccines. Improved sanitation, less overcrowded   and better  living conditions also   contribute. This is also borne out   in  published peer reviewed research which prove that vaccine did not save us.All vaccines contain sterility agents, neurotoxins, immunotoxins, and carcinogenic compounds. Some examples include formaldehyde, a carcinogen found in almost every vaccine,  neurotoxins such as monosodium glutamate, potassium                 chloride, thimerosal, sterility agents such as Triton X-100, octoxynol-10, polysorbate 80, and immuntoxins such as neomycin, monobasic potassium phosphate, sodium deoxycholate to name a few of many. It is no coincidence that the more educated you are, the less chance you will vaccinate which contradicts the misconceptions of many health  professionals who      profess that parents don't vaccinate because they are  under-educated,     poor or misinformed. Those who become fully informed  of the dangers of   vaccines never see them in the same light again, as  their motives then   become clear.                           MYTH #3 We must all focus on lowering bad cholesterol.                          Perhaps one                 of the biggest  health myths propagated in western culture and certainly                  in the United States, is the misuse of an invented term "bad                 cholesterol"  by the media and medical community. Moreover,                 a  scientifically-naive public has been conned into a fraudulent                  correlation between elevated cholesterol and cardiovascular  disease                 (CVD). Cholesterol has not been shown to  actually cause CVD. To                 the contrary, cholesterol is  vital to our survival, and trying to                 artificially lower  it can have detrimental effects, particularly                 as we age.We have become a culture so obsessed with eating foods                        low in cholesterol and fat that many health experts are now    questioning the consequences. Could we really maintain a dietary     lifestyle that was so  foreign to many of our ancestral populations    without any ill effects on our health? Many researchers are now    concluding that the answer to that question is "NO." Current data is now    suggesting that lower cholesterol levels predate the development of    cancer.The 'noddy-science' offered by marketing men to a generally                        scientifically-naive public has led many people to    believe that                     we should replace certain food choices    with specially developed                     products that can help    'reduce cholesterol'. Naturally this                     comes at a    price and requires those who can afford it to pay                        maybe four or five times what a 'typical ordinary' product might                        cost. But is this apparent 'blanket need' to strive  towards                       lowering our cholesterol justified? And,  indeed, is   it healthy?The cholesterol itself, whether being transported                     by    LDL or HDL,                     is exactly the same. Cholesterol is    simply a necessary ingredient                     that is required to  be   regularly delivered around the body for                     the    efficient healthy development, maintenance and functioning                        of our cells. The difference is in the 'transporters' (the    lipoproteins                     HDL and LDL) and both types are    essential for the human body's                     delivery logistics to    work effectively. Problems can occur, however, when the LDL particles are both                        small and their carrying capacity outweighs the  transportation                       potential of available HDL. This  can lead to more   cholesterol                     being 'delivered'  around the body with   lower resources for returning                      excess capacity to the   liver. MYTH #4 Medical screening and treatments prevent death.                          Even though the medical community advocates  for regular screenings                     for those with illnesses,  they may bring little benefit and                     may actually pose  harm to your health. This applies to almost                     every  type of medical screening for cancer and several other                      diseases. Medical screening carries an immense risk in itself,                      not only due to the damage inflicted by screening  techniques                     on the human body, but by the very nature  of medical follow-up                     protocols. These protocols  usually encourage patients to enter                     deeper into more  invasive techniques, which further cripple                     health  and lead to a very high percentage of fatalities.                          In a Swedish study of 60,000   women, 70  percent of    the mammographically detected tumors weren't   tumors at  all. These "false    positives" aren't just financial and   emotional  strains, they may also    lead to many unnecessary and   invasive  biopsies. In fact, 70 to 80 percent    of all positive   mammograms do not, upon biopsy, show any presence of cancer.                          A prostate (PSA) blood test looks for  prostate-specific                    antigen, a protein produced by the  prostate gland. High levels                    are supposedly associated  with prostate cancer. The problem                    is that the  association isn't always correct, and when it is,                    the  prostate cancer isn't necessarily deadly. Only about 3 percent of all  men die from prostate cancer. The                    PSA test usually  leads to overdiagnosis -- biopsies and treatment                    in  which the side effects are impotence and incontinence. Repeated biopsies   may spread cancer cells                    into the track formed by  the needle, or by spilling cancerous                    cells directly  into the bloodstream or lympathic system.News coverage                     of many  diseases focus too much on treatments and not enough                      on prevention, a trend that could prove risky in the long run                      for most people who don't understand how to take care of  their                     health.                           The biggest single type of story we usually  hear about on the                     news involves treatment, and  narratives lend themselves much                     better to that kind  of story. Stories about prevention, about                     people  exercising and eating right, just don’t make great                     copy.                         If our current                     treatment  approach to health continues, hundreds of years from                      now, mankind may look back at today’s “modern medicine”                      and think: “How could they have been so primitive in ideology                      and so wrong? What lack of humanitarianism in government  allowed                     the medical industries to kill people with  economically driven                     false beliefs and ideas? Why  didn’t government stop them?                     Who were the people in  charge of protecting those citizens?                                                    Preventive                     education  demands increased funding for research into new dietary,                      physical activity, behavioural, socioeconomic, environmental                      and medical approaches for the prevention of chronic  disease.                     Children who grow into teenagers and then  adults require more                     accountability for their own  well-being through health conscious                     decisions which  are motivated by proper practical and theoretical                      applications. They need to know that treatment modalities and                      pharmaceutical applications may not save their health in the                      future. Substantial political and financial  contributions are                     also imperative to invest in  prevention more effectively to                     regulate revisions  and mandate policies which affect the governing                      bodies of health and education. Any procrastination or failure                      to resolve these matters in the next decade will only lead to                      the further deterioration of human health and  healthcare systems.                     Proper leadership and effective  communication regarding these                     preventive measures  may still reverse screening/treatment trends                     and  consequently reverse this thinking to ultimately promote                      a healthier aging population.MYTH #5 Fluoride prevents tooth decay.Water fluoridation is a hoax.  Drinking any                 amount of fluoride is dangerous to your  health and has NEVER been                 proven to prevent tooth decay.  It's actually the biggest scientific                 fraud ever to be  promoted by national and international Governments.                  Fluoride has been linked to osteoporosis, cancer, auto-immune diseases,                  and even very small concentrations can disrupt DNA  repair enzymes                 by 50%.  The fluoride added to our water is a waste product of   aluminum and    phosphate fertilizer processing. And it’s not even calcium   fluoride    that appears naturally in water, but sodium fluoride, which is a    whole   different thing--and loaded with bad news.  In fact, sodium fluoride has no good news. Except for a few suspect      reports by the people selling the stuff, study after research study      proves that sodium fluoride does not protect our teeth, and it does a      number on our bones. And on other body parts, too, including our  thyroid     gland.  - Fluoride was found to be an equivocal carcinogen by the                                                    National Cancer Institute  Toxicological Program.   - Drinking fluoridated water will double the number of hip                         fractures for both older men and women.     -  Infertility in women was found to increase with water                          fluoridation.                       Food and Drug  Administration (FDA) scientists reported                         a close  correlation between decreasing total fertility rates                          in women between ages of 10 and 49, and increasing fluoride                          levels.                           - Fluoride has never been found to   effectively reducing tooth decay by any notable margin.                         No causation or even correlation was found between the level of  fluoride                         in water and dental caries in any  study.  Fluoride also attacks the pineal  gland. The pineal controls our  inner     clock, provides good sleep, works with our adrenal glands to  handle     stress, keeps the thymus gland fed and cared for, and  communicates 24/7     with the rest of the endocrine system about how  things are going.     Fluoride calcifies our pineal gland into a  non-functioning rock.                          -                          The government classifies sodium fluoride as  environmentally     hazardous waste. Anybody handling it must wear  HazMat protective gear.     Dumping it into rivers is a crime.                          Much of                     the original  proof that fluoride is safe for   humans in low doses                      was generated by A-bomb program   scientists, who had been secretly                      ordered to   provide "evidence useful in litigation"                      against   defense contractors for fluoride injury to  citizens.                       The first lawsuits against the U.S.  A-bomb program were not                       over radiation, but over  fluoride damage, the documents show.                          It seems that the healthiest  people on the planet right now are those that have deviated from the  norms of conventional medical quackery, and have migrated towards  natural health. The proof is in the pudding. Find the healthiest 5  people you know and you'll find they typically don't subscribe to the  health myths promoted by mainstream medicine. Your longevity and aging  gracefully depends on it.                                          Marco Torres is a research specialist, writer and     consumer advocate                                  for healthy lifestyles. He holds     degrees in  Public         Health     and                     Environmental Science  and       is a         professional     speaker on topics                    such   as   disease           prevention,     environmental toxins  and health     policy.Okay I am skeptik about the first two, but the last one is really bothering me the most...The water full of carcinogen..? Could it be true?

column10: Wood smoke in large quantities is definitely not very healthy, however it is a cornerstone of toxicology, often ignored by those fanatically opposed to a substance that "the dose makes the poison".It is possible to find "scientific evidence" to "prove" nearly any point, and those with extreme views often do so..  IMHO this seems to be the case with Mr. Harris.It is true that traditional fireplaces, open fires, and old fashioned wood stoves DO emit combustion byproducts that are hazardous, especially in large quantity - how much is a "problem" can be debated, but less is probably better.However, a MODERN controlled combustion stove that meets the EPA standards that have been in effect since the late 80's, and that is operated properly, puts out an amount of pollutants on about the same order, and of similar type, to any fossil fuel burning appliance.This comes with the added bonus of much greater efficiency and heat output from the wood.  Those byproducts that Mr. Harris objects to, are actually FUEL, and a secondary combustion or catalytic combustor equipped stove is specifically designed to burn those gasses and particles and make them into heat.  The resulting emissions are largely carbon dioxide and water vapour, which aren't a huge problem.In addition, since wood is a renewable fuel, that is mostly locally produced (at least in comparison to fossil fuels) it is "carbon neutral" and does not contribute to "Greenhouse Gas" and global warming the way that fossil fuels do...  Embed Quote

column9: I don't think they're completely inert - it's quite possible that they have dyes that could get absorbed into the bloodstream.
column10: No. Fibers as they are insoluble and inert; if ingested, they just pass out of your digestive system. Colored plant-derived fibers (eg cotton) have already been treated to be colorfast thus will not leach out even when subjected to stomach acidity (equivalent to 0.1N HCl). Artificial fibers (eg nylon, spandex) have already dyes built into the textile thus will not leach out at all.  Embed Quote

column10: Well yes, you do, but not in such a magnitude as suggested in the image there. There are 2 pieces of information about that image that should immediately suggest this is a less than reliable source. Firstly, it is from Facebook, town of scammers and fraudsters. Secondly, 'According to a research'.With any kind of claim like this, the best thing to do before reposting it is to quickly Google the argument outlined. I just searched for 'benzene poisoning air conditioning' and the first result was from Snopes. [1] This immediately suggests that the claim presented in the image is not entirely true, as Snopes is a site that examines commonly-held myths and urban legends.The article quotes almost exactly the text of the image included in the question context. It lists the date of this as May 2009. The article begins by listing actual research by the American Cancer Society about the dangers of Benzene and its links to cancer. The Snopes article then provides an extract from a scientific study carried out by a South Korean university [2] that seems to refute some of the claims made in the image.A short summary of the study's findings is that it is not the dashboard of the car that emits the highest level of Benzene, but actually the fuel. In addition to this, they found that Benzene levels were higher in older cars, refuting the claim that the 'new car smell' is partly to blame. Finally, they found Benzene levels to be higher during winter, casting doubt on the claim that air conditioning elevates the level. [2] [1] http://www.snopes.com/medical/to...[2] http://www.sciencedirect.com/sci...Edit: Just realised that this is my 200th answer here on Quora. Thought I'd point that out.  Embed Quote

column9: what foods/substances can we be reasonably sure (from substantial and respectable clinical trials) cause cancer? In terms of foods and everyday objects (rather than chemical names)?
column10: The classifications are various but the substances are more or less the same.This is the link to the list by International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC): http://monographs.iarc.fr/ENG/Cl...They are classified in 5 groups:Group 1: Carcinogenic to humans (107 agents)Group 2A: Probably carcinogenic to humans (58 agents)Group 2B: Possibly Carcinogenic to humans (249 agents)Group 3: Not classifiable as to its carcinogenicity to humans (512 agents)Group 4: Probably not carcinogenic to humans (1 agent)  Embed Quote

column10: Most likely notSee this paper (http://potency.berkeley.edu/pdfs... ) from a top toxicology websiteMisconception 4: Human exposures to potential cancer hazards are primarily to synthetic chemicals.Contrary to common perception, 99.9% of the chemicals humans ingest are natural. The amounts of synthetic pesticide residues in plant foods, for example, are extremely low compared to the amounts of natural “pesticides” produced by plants themselves (Ames et al., 1990a; Ames et al., 1990b; Gold et al., 1999; Gold et al., 1997b; Gold and Zeiger, 1997). Of all dietary pesticides that humans eat, 99.99% are natural: these are chemicals produced by plants to defend themselves against fungi, insects, and other animal predators (Ames et al., 1990a; Ames et al., 1990b). Each plant produces a different array of such chemicals. On average, the Western diet includes roughly 5,000 to 10,000 different natural pesticides and their breakdown products. Americans eat about 1,500 mg of natural pesticides per person per day, which is about 10,000 times more than they consume of synthetic pesticide residues (Ames et al., 1990b). Even though only a small proportion of natural pesticides has been tested for carcinogenicity, half of those tested (38/72) are rodent carcinogens; naturally occurring pesticides that are rodent carcinogens are ubiquitous in fruits, vegetables, herbs, and spices (Gold et al., 1997b; Gold et al., 1992) (Table 2).Cooking of foods produces burnt material (about 2,000 mg per person per day) that contains many rodent carcinogens. In contrast, the residues of 200 synthetic chemicals measured by United States Federal Drug Administration, including the synthetic pesticides thought to be of greatest importance, average only about 0.09 mg per person per day (Ames et al., 1990a; Gold et al., 1997b; Gold et al., 1992). In a single cup of coffee, the natural chemicals that are rodent carcinogens are about equal in weight to an entire year’s worth of synthetic pesticide residues that are rodent carcinogens, even though only 3% of the natural chemicals in roasted coffee have been adequately tested for carcinogenicity (Gold et al., 1992) (Table 3). This does not mean that coffee or natural pesticides are a cancer risk for humans, but rather that assumptions about high-dose animal cancer tests for assessing human risk at low doses need reexamination. No diet can be free of natural chemicals that are rodent carcinogens (Gold et al., 1999; Gold et al., 1997b; Gold and Zeiger, 1997)  Embed QuoteAnswered in thirty-one minutes via  Anonymous.

column9: Why not invest the money *fixing* those things, then evaluate the results?
column10: If the other excellent answers here don't convince you, here's another point worth considering - the same efforts we make to investigate the mechanisms behind cancers are also likely to greatly contribute to our understanding of why cells age and die.Being personally opposed to aging and/or dying, cancer or no, I'm wholeheartedly in admiration of the people who devote their lives to the painstaking and methodical accumulation of knowledge of this sort. And there's more - tissue cloning and regeneration technologies, again closely linked with cancer research might one day unlock some pretty sweet biotech... Lets all have steak without hurting cows. How about choosing what age you want to remain for the rest of your practically immortal lifespan? Regrowing damaged limbs and organs? Reviving species we have driven to extinction? Sure what I'm talking about is science fiction - so was Jules Verne's electrically powered underwater submersible in that rather lengthy novel he wrote back when. And sure there are potential horrors as well as the benefits. That's the funny thing about increasing knowledge, it unlocks doors that we as societies must choose to open or not. So far it's worked out, for those of us at least who are happy that air conditioning, ipads and social networking sites like quora exist even despite assault rifles, sarin gas, and daytime talk shows.  Embed Quote

column9: Why not invest the money *fixing* those things, then evaluate the results?
column10: While it might be convenient to believe the many carcinogenic industrial chemicals and foods, introduced into the environment since the Industrial Revolution might be highly correlated with increasing cancer rates, unfortunately cancer's story is more complex. Each cancer's evolution is as unique as the individual who is unfortunate enough to possess the uncontrolled growth. Factors like genetics, tobacco, alcohol, physical inactivity, obesity, and randomness, are important factors in human cancers. Mutations in a wide variety of either cell replication and suppressor genes (and their associated proteins) have also been correlated with a wide variety of cancers. In terms of treatments, the basic 3 (surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy) still remain, but significant refinements have been made over the last 50 years, especially in the areas of targeted chemicals, which can mitigate a wide variety of malicious gene expressions, and minimize collateral damage. One striking observations is while many animals are susceptible to cancer, mole rats are not. A reference link to their unusual capability is found below.http://www.nature.com/nature/jou...A link to a potentially useful new book with a moving "detective like" story (The Cancer Chronicles) describing some of the latest Cancer research is provided below. In addition the Great Courses has recently released a fairly detailed course (see link below) on the intricacies of Cancer.http://www.amazon.com/The-Cancer...http://www.thegreatcourses.com/t...For those interested in the more technical details, the updated classic (The Hallmarks of Cancer: The Next Generation) by  Hanahan and Weinberg might provide an illuminating summary (see link below)http://download.cell.com/pdf/PII...Lastly, another useful and entertaining book on cancer is The Emperor of All Maladies by Mukherjee (see link below).http://www.amazon.com/gp/aw/d/14...  Embed Quote

column9: Why not invest the money *fixing* those things, then evaluate the results?
column10: While modern environment and behavior have resulted in an increase in the prevalence of cancer, cancer has been a part of the human condition throughout our evolutionary history.  For example prostate cancer has been found in a 2000 year old Egyptian mummy http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ijpp... and bone cancer has been reported in a 120,000 year old Neanderthal fossil Fibrous Dysplasia in a 120,000+ Year Old Neandertal from Krapina, Croatia. In many ways the increase in cancer can be explained by better detection of cause of death and an increase in overall life expectancy.  We could eradicate all environmental and behavior causes and still not eradicate cancer because spontaneous genetic mutations will still occur.  If we want to extend the average human life span we need to understand and address the fundamental causes of cancer and find methods for ensuring the fidelity of genetic replication.  Embed Quote

column9: Why not invest the money *fixing* those things, then evaluate the results?

column9: Why not invest the money *fixing* those things, then evaluate the results?
column10: From the question, with emphasis added: Don't we already know that genes, smoking, pollution, inactivity and poor diet are the culprits?Why not invest the money *fixing* those things, then evaluate the results? We can't "fix" genes without knowing exactly what the difference is between a good gene and a broken gene. If we are to fix genes, we need a clear understanding of what it means to say that genes are "broken," and what types of breakage cause cancer. That said, we are investing money in gene therapy, and we probably will be doing so for the foreseeable future. Those investments are guided by what we learn as we investigate the root causes if cancer.  Embed Quote

column10: Nothing. Causes. Cancer.Cancer is evolution. Cancer is inevitable. column9: Why not invest the money *fixing* those things, then evaluate the results?
column10: See my answer toWhy can't science give us answers to questions like "Why doesred wine often give people headaches?"This is a lot like that situation, except that the stakes are much higher and so much more science has been done.Tobacco and other carcinogens cause cancer in some people.  But they don't cause cancer in everyone who could get it.  And our current knowledge says some genes increase your chances of getting cancer but don't guarantee that you'll get cancer.  There are interactions between, at least, genetics and carcinogens.  Maybe diet and exercise change general health that also interacts with genetics and carcinogens.  Maybe all these interact with stress.  And maybe there are viruses or bacteria involved.  Maybe when the interactions are known, we can do more to prevent cancer.  But, also, maybe we can use that knowledge to improve treatment.  Identifying the genetic signature of your own personal cancer can now help find the best drug to treat it.  Knowing how your cancer is created by, nourished by, retarded by, or destroyed by all these other factors could save your life.  Embed Quote

column9: Why not invest the money *fixing* those things, then evaluate the results?
column10: The question reflects a legalistic or punitive, not scientific, point of  view. You think we can solve the problem by identifying and  exterminating the guilty party. That's not how science works.The term risk factor means there is a statistical correlation between the variables you mentioned and cancer, not necessarily that they cause it. There may be a third variable, called a confounder, that causes both. Correlation does not show causation. To validly say A causes B, we need to know the the sequence of events (etiology) that lead from A to B. Then we will know enough to do something about it.Applying statistics about groups to individuals is called an ecological fallacy. The Wikipedia article has an excellent mathematical proof. It was illustrated by a 1950 paper by William S. Robinson in which he pointed out there is positive correlation between state literacy and immigrant population percent by state. A naive interpretation would be that immigrants are more literate than natives, yet tests on immigrants showed they have below average literacy. The explanation is immigrants are not randomly distributed. They prefer urban states, which have above average literacy. They lower, not raise, the literacy of their adopted states. A naive interpretation of the correlation led to a conclusion that was 180 degrees incorrect.  Embed Quote

column9: Why not invest the money *fixing* those things, then evaluate the results?
column10: You miss out the fact that viruses cause cancer. To the best of our knowledge 20% of cancers (can't remember if that is types or incidences) are cause by virusesRous in 1951 extracted virus from a chicken cancer and later won a Nobel prize for it. In fact during the 50's, 60's and 70's there were three conflicting theories about what caused cancer: Viruses, the environment and genetics.  The evidence for each was weak and as a result of perusing all three different approaches we came to a much better and fuller understanding of cancer.  Embed Quote

column9: I heard it was really bad for your hair and I want to know if this is a true claim.
column10: Sodium lauryl sulfate [SLS] and sodium laureth sulfate [SLES] are the lathering agents in soap and shampoo—they make the bubbles.  Every few years “natural” soap and shampoo marketers target SLS and SLES as caustic agents to convince potential buyers to switch brands.  Their efforts are working as I have recently witnessed my friends with no science background discussing the topic.  Because of this, I have watched the videos and read the propaganda written by unqualified authors using bits and pieces of outdated studies that have been taken out of context.  It makes me chuckle.I was first introduced to SLS and SLES bashing in the late 90s when I was taking chemistry courses at UT. One of my professors worked in the soap industry and we had lengthy conversations about chemicals found in soaps, shampoos, and detergents.  SLS and SLES are benign lathering agents with no documented general risks or adverse effects.  Both have been studied rigorously by independent agencies.  Because of the “electric” pull and the size of the molecule, it does not enter the skin and end up “in your system.”  This is true for most other ingredients in shampoo as well. SLS and SLES don’t grow on trees but they are derived from nature.  Because the process of doing so occurs in a lab, they are known as chemicals.  However, there is a difference between chemicals derived from nature and those constructed by man.  Any ingredient with a number in the name is synthetic (manmade) and in large quantities can become a health hazard.  1,4 Dioxane (synthetic chemical carcinogen) and quaternium-15 (a formaldehyde releasing preservative) are ones to watch for. In addition to synthetic chemicals (again, usually has a number in the name), watch out for “fragrance” on a product’s ingredient list.  Under FDA law, a manufacturer does not have to disclose ingredients labeled as “fragrance” to protect against knockoff perfume formulations.  Ingredients used to scent shampoos, soaps or detergents are not disclosed to any governing agency and that is where known cancer causing agents may be purposefully hidden. There are movements in the US to change the “fragrance” protection law but the US Cosmetics, Toiletry and Fragrance Association (CTFA) has strong lobbyists who are paid well by a 60 billion dollar industry.  The EU has banned over 1100 chemicals from personal care products because they may cause cancer, birth defects or reproductive problems.  The US has banned only 9. In the meantime, you can protect yourself by avoiding synthetic chemicals and products that contain “fragrance” on the ingredient list.  Switching brands frequently might also help to reduce continued exposure to the unlisted ingredients.  Alone, the "natural chemicals” in shampoo, such as SLS and SLES, are not going to harm you but the fragrance might. Check out my blog.  Nurse Gail - Gail Ingram is a NYC nurse sharing her perspective on health care and wellness.  Embed Quote

column9: I heard it was really bad for your hair and I want to know if this is a true claim.
column10: Sodium Laurel Sulfate and Sodium Laureth Sulfate are foaming agents. The are what make you soaps, shampoos, toothpastes and other detergents foam up.  I've read a few completely different explanations of this chemical. It seems that it may not be carcinogenic, however it may mimic estrogen and effect hormone production which can lead to increased cancer risk, but I'd have to say that at this point my personal research on the topic is inconclusive.  Some things I've read suggest that length of exposure is the biggest issue, as well as ingestion.  There are alternatives to shampoos with SLS and SLTS, check out, among others John Masters Organics.  Embed Quote

Per wikipedia:The radiation produced by a microwave oven is non-ionizing. It therefore does not have the cancer risks associated with ionizing radiation such as X-rays andhigh-energy particles. column9: If so, what would that be?  My Canadian jar contains:Sugar, modified palm oil, hazelnuts, cocoa, skim milk powder, whey powder, soy lecithin, vanillin.Ref: Comment in this answerAnonymous' answer to Is Nutella in any way healthy?
column10: Possibly this question derives from recent US class action suits. You might think this was about dangerous ingredients or some terrible threat to the health of American children.In fact, the suits alleged that manufacturer Ferrero misrepresented the product as "part of a healthy breakfast" in its advertising.   Ferrero says you should eat their spread with fruit, milk, and other healthy foods, which seems pretty reasonable.  Ferrero lost ("Only in America"!) and paid out a bunch of Euros.Nutella's main ingredients are plainly marked on the label as required by law:  sugar (a 37 g serving is 22 g of sugar! - that's almost 60%), palm oil (fat, 11 g or 30%), hazelnuts (a bit of fat, and a bit of fibre), cocoa, skim milk, and some bits such as vanillin and lecithin (an emulsifier).  Carcinogenic?  Nah.  Nutritious?  Uh...  If you're curious, 22g of sugar is 3 heaping teaspoons.Nutella claims that a slice of toast with their spread compares nutritionally to a slice of toast with jam, which nobody considers unhealthy.   However, Montreal paper La Presse pointed out that a spoonful of store-bought chocolate icing – which was half the price of Nutella – had fewer calories, half the fat and less sugar than the same quantity of Nutella.  So save money, spread chocolate icing on your breakfast bagel, and munch away.  Embed Quote

column9: Which one is the best alternative to the other, and why?Petro-chemical polymer, or Stainless steel?
column10: I have different preferences for different situations. I use all three, but only non-BPA Nalgenes.  Here's the Wiki on BPAs:"BPA is controversial because it exerts weak, but detectable, hormone-like properties, raising concerns about its presence in consumer products and foods contained in such products. Starting in 2008, several governments questioned its safety, prompting some retailers to withdraw polycarbonate products. A 2010 report from the United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) raised further concerns regarding exposure to fetuses, infants, and young children.[2] In September 2010, Canada became the first country to declare BPA a toxic substance.[3][4] The European Union, Canada, and recently the United States have banned BPA use in baby bottles.[5][6]"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bis...  Let's look at 1) Camelback2) Non-BPA Nalgene3) Stainless steel or glass or ceramic1. Camelback has become my absolute favorite for hiking/backpacking/ any physical activity because it's really nice not to have to root around for your water source while you're moving.  It's light, it's safe (non-BPA) and it's easy to fit in a pack.  Downside: you have to clean it carefully, doing a final rinse with alcohol to sterilize and evaporate any leftover water drops that could mildew in the water line.2. Nalgene bottles (non-BPA) are nice because they are light and easy to clean.  We still use one 1-litre bottle for collection/sterilization with a Steri-Pen for cooking and filling the Camelbacks.  Downside:  water tastes funny after it has been in one, especially after a long time or if the bottle has heated from the sun, etc.This is of special concern to me as the parent of a child (see above).  The jury's still out, I may be wrong, but the early research is concerning enough for me to not take undue chances, especially during my son's main growing years.3. Stainless steel/glass/ceramic is my favorite for everyday desk and daypacks/lunchpacks.  It's heavy, but if you don't have to carry it far it's not an issue.  The water simply tastes the best from these non-leaching containers. Steel is the obvious choice for children's lunchboxes/packs because it's non-breakable and dishwasher-safe for sterilization.  Embed Quote

column9: Which one is the best alternative to the other, and why?Petro-chemical polymer, or Stainless steel?
column10: I don't have an opinion on BPA, but for convenience I like a combination of Platypus collapsible bladders (1 and/or 2 liter) which tuck away in the pack when I don't need to have water in them. (They are designed for hydration systems, but I use them just to hold water.) While hiking, I prefer to drink from a 500 cc Nalgene bottle rather than a hydration system because I want to know the amount I am drinking either to make sure I am fully hydrated or to ration water on a long dry stretch - hydration systems usually don't let you know easily how much you are drinking)   So I usually bring 2-3 Nalgene 500 cc wide-mouth bottles for collecting water, for drinking on trail and for convenience. The wide mouths (esp. on the square bottles) make it easy to pick up water from a lake or a shallow stream (small mouths are a pain unless you always use a filter that fits the small mouth).  In winter or over high passes, the wide mouths also allow you to put in some snow periodically to replenish water you are drinking.  I have one round 500cc Nalgene which has the ounce (and cc) measurements printed up the side, which is useful when doing trail cooking (e.g., measuring 8 oz for  my morning oatmeal and 12 oz for evening soups).  I also typically carry one or two square widemouth 500 cc Nalgenes which are wrapped in black 10-mil plumbers tape and are each fitted with a clip that attaches  easily to a PALS strap on my shoulder harness.   (Picture shows the bottle with clear duct tape securing the clip - I now prefer the black tape both for warming and because it is a bit stronger).  The black tape warms up the water, mostly good in winter to melt added snow but also slightly saving fuel if I use it for cooking (if I want water to stay cool, I can put it inside the pack). If you plan to use this in winter, fashion the clip so the bottle hangs with the threads faced downward (the threads will freeze tight if carried upright). If you can carry water forward of your center of gravity it slightly helps you hiking balance. You didn't ask about this, but I will gratuitously add: (1) a folding bucket is a great addition because you can draw plenty of water quickly and then get away from the water's edge (important in our Sierra Nevada mosquito season); and (2) a 17 ounce Platypus bottle is a great way to carry olive oil to add calories to most any dinner or for field-making hummus or tabbouleh (olive oil otherwise likes to leak). Though once used for olive oil, you won't be using it for water.  Grainger.com has a good selection of wide-mouth Nalgene bottles in a variety of sizes and shapes (and with ounce measurements). Platypus bladders are available at REI. PS: a one-ounce Nalgene gives you a way to measure out the olive oil without getting a measuring cup all oily and nasty. Sorry, way too much information is response to a shorter question.   Embed Quote

Don't forget that if the water bag is above 8 liters in volume it can be used as a portable shower, which for me is an important thing.  Embed Quote

column9: I have used www.ewg.com/skindeep, but have found that it is difficult to tell how dangerous or safe one product is versus another. Additionally, I have read a number of articles that say EWG overstates the danger (including a survey of toxicologists: www.toxicology.org/pr/AreChemicalsPR.pdf) in order to promote their own advocacy.
column10: One way to determine the safety of chemicals is by reading their MSDS (Material Safety Data Sheets). Specifically, look for the reported LD50 or LC50 values (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Med...), which is the amount of the chemical required to kill half of the given population of organism (typically rats). You can somewhat extrapolate the LD value to the body mass of a human. Other information in the MSDS is also useful.You can obtain MSDS sheets for many chemicals by simply googling the chemical name and appending MSDS to your query.  Embed Quote

column9: Are the risks negligible? Or is it like ingesting 3rd-person smoke?
column10: Jaques Grové's answer is not correct. Smoking foods, as cooking them over a wood or charcoal fire, does produce chemicals that are known to be, in some circumstances, carcinogenic.What is not known, and therefore makes the answer wrong, is the amount of those chemicals that will cause a cancer in humans. There are many chemicals that are, in the lab, demonstrably carcinogenic, but only in enormous doses do they show any affect in living beings. Further, some test animals are not good models for human health because those animals react differently than do humans. Some chemicals known to cause cancer in some animals have simply never been proved to do so in humans.The best, that is, the most accurate thing that can be said is that smoked foods might be a problem, in some circumstances, at some level of ingestion, for some people. A categorical 'yes' or 'no' is not only uncalled for, it is unsupported by research.Unless one is consuming vast quantities of smoked foods, daily, then there's likely little risk from consuming smoked foods, at least according to the latest research.  Embed Quote

Hmm... you know, I can't say anything concrete here, but something that inhibited a critical piece of transcriptional/translational machinery would technically be genotoxic but not carcinogenic (in humans). Perhaps some classes of antibiotics would apply. At the very least, there have been substances identified to be genotoxic in cells but not shown to be mutagenic. I would say anything that isn't directly acting on DNA or interfering with DNA repair enzymes is a good candidate for being a noncarcinogenic genotoxin, but I'm sure there will be caveats.  Embed Quote

I've found this since i asked the question :http://www.pnas.org/content/72/1... So I think the answer is widely yes, there are lots of way for a substance to be carcinogen and not mutagen (immunosuppressor, growth hormone, etc...), even if the intervention of a mutation (so a mutagen) is necessary at one time at less in the process of cancer.  Embed Quote

The difference is that the latter is more accurate and pedantic, with less potential for ambiguity.  The former is basically shorthand for the latter in everyday speech....we all know that "cause" is commonly used to mean that it contributes to, and therefore increases the chances of, something happening.It is probably more accurate to say that "smoking increases the risk of lung cancer" than to say that it "causes lung cancer," since, obviously, not everyone who smokes gets lung cancer.  But only a lawyer for a tobacco company would deny that smoking causes lung cancer on this technicality.  Embed Quote

There is no such thing as things "causing cancer". Lots of things increase the risk of developing cancer in your lifetime such as smoking, excessive drinking, asbestos  etc. Some things might increase your risk so much that there is almost a causative effect, but even then, it's still an increase in chances of developing cancer.  Embed Quote

I would put this in terms of "increase the risk of cancer" is more general, and "cause cancer" is more specific to individual cases of cancer.I can't think of any chemical, virus, or other factor that causes cancer in every single person exposed to it. Not every smoker gets lung cancer; not every woman who inherits a mutation in the BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene gets breast or ovarian cancer. However, there are lots of things that, if you're exposed to them, increase the risk that the exposure will cause cancer in you specifically.So: smoking increases the risk that you will get a lung cancer that was caused by smoking; inheriting a mutated BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene increases the risk that you will get a breast or ovarian cancer that was caused by the mutation.Does that make sense? Happy to clarify if not :)  Embed Quote

To me causes cancer implies:Substance goes into your cells and mutates your genes and activates a variety of oncogenes resulting in cancerTo me increases the risk of cancer implies:Substance has been statistically correlated with an increase of cancer.Essentially a classic causation vs. correlation argument.  Embed QuoteAnswered in fourteen minutes.

Yes, but not in the way the question is implying. When there is a correlation shown in studies, it's usually negative; that is, coffee is associated with a reduced risk rather than an increased risk of various cancers. Much of the evidence suggests that coffee consumption is neutral at worst and protective at best.For instance, coffee consumption has been shown to be negatively correlated with colon cancer [1, 2] and pancreatic cancer [3] in some studies. With other types of cancer, such bladder cancer, its unclear whether there is a negative correlation or not, and its negative connection to pancreatic cancer is also unclear [4]; however there certainly doesn't seem to be a positive correlation in such studies. Like I said, neutral at worst.There's also a possible protective effect against liver cancer [5]. Despite some of the evidence being somewhat unclear, I take solace in it and my decision to consume coffee with a reckless abandon. (Though moderation is prudent, I suppose)[1] http://ukpmc.ac.uk/abstract/MED/...[2] http://aje.oxfordjournals.org/co...[3] http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/d...[4] http://ukpmc.ac.uk/abstract/MED/...[5] http://www.sciencedirect.com/sci...  Embed Quote

Coffee is one of the best sources of antioxidants. Given that antioxidants are intimately involved in the prevention of cellular damage -- the common pathway for cancer, aging, and a variety of diseases, anything that counteracts free radicals should then have a negative correlation to cancer.  Embed Quote
"Living" correlates with cancer ;)  Embed Quote

column9: I love eating roasting broccoli with lots of olive oil and drizzling some lemon juice on it later. Problem is it's only really delicious if you let it cook at 400 F for a while till some of its florets are browned, near black and caramelized. Is this bad for me?
column10: Broccoli is low in saturated fat and very low in cholesterol. It is also a good source of protein and many minerals, including calcium, iron, magnesium, potassium, manganese and phosphorus. Broccoli is also a good source of dietary fiber. Broccoli contains vitamin A, vitamin C, vitamin E and vitamin K as well as the B vitamins riboflavin, vitamin B6 and folate. It is also high in selenium, a mineral known to reduce free radicals and support a healthy immune system.Does it lose nutrients when roasting? Of course, but enough nutrients are retained to still make it a powerhouse source of vitamins and minerals. To prevent some nutrient loss storing vegetables in the refrigerator, until ready to cook, should help retain nutrients.  As far as being carcinogenic, when cooked more than a few minutes, broccoli's antioxidants aren't as adept at knocking out carcinogens that cause cancer. http://www.npr.org/blogs/thesalt.... But as far as them being carcinogenic themselves when browned, they present a far lesser risk than browned/burned meat. http://www.foodrevolution.org/as...In my opinion, keep raw broccoli to snack on, but for dinner, roast it.I toss broccoli stems (halved lengthwise) and florets in a bit of olive oil, salt and pepper, roast them at 425° for about 20 minutes. When they're done and partially browned take them out, and while still red hot, sprinkle with a bit more olive oil, lemon and fresh grated parmigiano.  Embed Quote

Lots of foods contain acrylamide. Here are a few especially common examples:Potatoes: chips, French fries and other roasted or fried potato foodsGrains: bread crust, toast, crisp bread, roasted breakfast cereals and various processed snacksCoffee; roasted coffee beans and ground coffee powder. Surprisingly, coffee substitutes based on chicory actually contains 2-3 times MORE acrylamide than real coffee [1]The amount of acrylamide in foods can vary[11]Here is some data on the amount of acrylamide contained:Acrylamide in Foods: Micrograms per ServingWater, 8 oz., EPA limit 0.12Boiled Potatoes, 4 oz.<3Old El Paso Taco Shells, 3, 1.1oz.1Ore Ida French Fries (uncooked), 3 oz.5Ore Ida French Fries (baked), 3 oz.28Honey Nut Cheerios, 1 oz.6Cheerios, 1 oz.7Tostitos Tortilla Chips, 1 oz.5Fritos Corn Chips, 1 oz.11Pringles Potato Crisps, 1 oz.25Wendy’s French Fries, Biggie, 5.6 oz.39KFC Potato Wedges, Jumbo, 6.2 oz.52Burger King French Fries, large, 5.7 oz.59McDonald’s French Fries, large, 6.2 oz.82[2]The amount of acrylamide in a large order of fast-food French fries is at least 300 times more than what the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency allows in a glass of water. Acrylamide is sometimes used in water-treatment facilities.[2]Grilling vegetables can produce acrylamide too:Food	 Acrylamide level in parts per billion (ppb)	Asparagine level in milligrams per gramAsparagus**	 ND* or <10 (frozen, canned, grilled)	41-820 (raw)Carrots	61 (grilled)	3.2 (raw and dehydrated)Onions	70 (grilled)	3-5 (raw)Potatoes	114 (roasted)	6.6-16.0 (raw)Broccoli	235 (canned)	179-393 (raw)Plums and Prunes	31-188	16-116 (raw)Coffee beans	179-351 (roasted)	0.33-0.97 (raw and dried)Cocoa beans/Chocolate	24-909	9-31 (both raw powder and roasted beans)Wheat/breads	27-364	20-215 (fresh wheat) 2-5 (fermented and non-fermed)[3]Monsanto uses it in pesticides under the brand name Krilium, so it could make its way into non-organic food that relied on those pesticides.[6]In terms of its prevalence, in the U.S.:The top 20 foods by average acrylamide intake by the U.S. population are as follows:French Fries (made in restaurants)French Fries (oven baked)Potato ChipsBreakfast CerealsCookiesBrewed Coffee... (more)Loading...
Coffee contains acrylamide and Starbucks is required by Proposition 65 to post signs in its stores in California that coffee contains carcinogens.French fries also contain acrylamide.  Embed Quote

This is an interesting conversation, but before we get out the pitchforks and head down to the local fast-food purveyors, check this Quora conversation:  Toxicology and Poison: How dangerous is acrylamide?  Embed Quote

column9: Seeing as the majority of inexpensive plastic bottles contain Bisphenol A (BPA), and we're all well aware of their impacts and how dangerous they are, then, how dangerous is ... welll ... everything else that is either stored or contained in plastic?- Are plastic pill containers dangerous since the medication inside is contained around a plastic bottle?- Is BPA only dangerous if it is injested? Or is it equally as dangerous if handled regularly?- Are there any other similar plastic chemicals in other items that are dangerous as well?I think I'm better getting my hands on a fully glass bottle and using my own water from now on :)
column10: No, the majority of inexpensive plastic bottles do not contain BPA. Most are made of PET, HDPE or PP. Polycarbonate (PC) is the bottle material that contributes BPA. It is not an inexpensive material, and therefore not used in disposable situations.The FDA continues to look at the BPA situation, but just recently as last month, again, decided that the material is not dangerous enough to change any regulations over it.Look at it this way: BPA has been in the food chain and studied for over 50 years, and is still considered "safe". Yet some would have us throw it all away for a new (undecided) material that does not have this track record. Is that a smart decision, or does it suggest to you that in say, 10 years, we may discover that this new material is unsafe, and off we go again with a newer, also untested material?  Embed Quote
