column10: How many people die every year from bad cuts due to broken glass, or glass shards that get into the skin and cause badly infected wounds that won't heal? How many diabetics lose a foot to gangrene because of a glass shard? Is that really outweighed by those harmed by BPA?I can tell you. In Philadelphia alone, 39 out of 243 children surveyed needed professional medical intervention due to an injury from broken glass. see (Reported incidence of injuries caused by street glass among urban children in Philadelphia)  Both in England and the US, broken bottle glass has been reported to be the leading cause of lacerations, accounting for 15–27% of all lacerations seen in an urban emergency department. (see http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubm... , and Armstrong AM, Molyneux E. Glass injuries to children. BMJ 1992;304:360). Glass is not a solution- it is a problem.Now, you might argue that littering and pollution are the real dangers. But even from my own personal experience, I've been injured by little shards of glass in my home months later even when I thought I've carefully swept up broken glass. Luckily, even though the infection from one of those times was severe, I didn't need to get antibiotics for it, just a tweezer, some alcohol, a lot of pain and pus, and time. A diabetic neighbor of mine was not so lucky- a stray flake of glass in her home went unnoticed and she lost part of her foot. It doesn't mean I don't have lots of glass around in my home- I know it's a danger. I just don't use it everyday if I can avoid doing so. You are better off with polycarbonate or HDPE plastics, which are almost unbreakable compared to glass. Nalgene brand plasticware has been a virtual de-facto standard in chemistry labs I've worked in due to its safety and lack of contamination of experiments. But don't expect to put them in the microwave, dishwasher, or the oven: all materials have a suitable and appropriate use.see also: Beauty: How dangerous are parabens, sulfates, and phthalates in everyday beauty products?  Embed Quote

I don't care what research can support their position. I have two words for you: Herd immunity (I'll explain it further down).Viruses and bacteria are programmed to make more mistakes during their replications, inducing more versatility in their genome, making it harder for our natural immune system to keep up with them. In the past, survivors of mass outbreaks were those people who were lucky enough to have the right predisposition in their immune system to either overcome an infection or be naturally resistant to a strain or virus. All others would be subject to being wiped out. This is nothing more than an act of natural selection. Those better fit to survive will continue existing and procreating, others are removed from existence. As medicine progressed, we began understanding how the immune system recognizes these microscopic invaders, and began formulating essentially a jump-start serum that would create a profile, if you will, of a specific invader in your immune system. This is analogous to a "Wanted" sign with the picture of a culprit in Western movies. Your body receives a way to identify the intruders, meaning that if the actual bacteria or virus does come along, your body can recognize it faster and get rid of it. By practicing this in a widespread manner, we develop what we refer to as "herd immunity", where we have a large concentrated population of individuals who have gained this advantage over an infectious agent. In order for the agent to replicate, it needs a host. If all the hosts are resistant, the agent will eventually run out of energy, and, without a means to replicate, will be eliminated from existence. This is how smallpox was eradicated (even though strains are still being preserved in the CDC). So here's my point: humans are the most sophisticated species because we can specialize, communicate, and apply innovations broadly across our population. Vaccinations are no different. If you want to continue living as a part of a species that, with its vast potential, can bend the laws of natural selection, go on and take advantage of these services. If you want to be skeptic, no one is going to stop you from taking your chances against the forces of nature. You can find out what natural selection has in store for you.Now for a caveat: herd immunity works wonders when everyone is vaccinated. If there are people among the "herd" who refuse vaccinations and become infected, that virus or bacteria has the potential to develop new mutations within your body, and it most likely will. This will result in essentially a new form of the virus, and it is likely that the current vaccine in play will no longer be effective, meaning you would be a walking biological weapon, so to speak: a massive threat to society. You are now a danger to the entire herd. The genius of our species can bend the laws of natural selection. The stupidity of our species can completely undo the work of many brilliant minds. It's so sad to think about.  Embed Quote

Many believe that the benefit, lowered risk of the infectious disease, doesn't outweigh the cost, perceived higher risk of toxicity, to their child.The Wikipedia article has a good summary of the major concerns people have had, mostly related to autism risk: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vac.... Some of the hypothesized mechanisms for serious side effects are mercury toxicity from the preservative thiomersal (now removed from most vaccines even though no link was established), aluminum from adjuvants, and immune system overload. Most/all of the serious risks have only been established via anecdotes and isolated studies that have not been reproduced despite follow up studies. However, it's true that less serious side-effects (e.g., soreness) are well-known to occur as a result of vaccinations sometimes.It is worth noting that the vaccine controversy is an excellent example of the tragedy of the commons. Much of the benefit from vaccines is from herd immunity. That is, when a child is vaccinated, other children that come into contact with that child are also protected because they can't be infected by the vaccinated child. This is especially helpful because some members of the population, such as the very young and very old, cannot be vaccinated.If one parent decides not to vaccinate their child out of toxicity concerns, this isn't a problem, but if many people make this decision, then many children may fall ill, including those whose parents could not even opt for vaccination if they wanted.  Embed Quote

I feel that I am in a unique position to answer this question. My oldest daughter is one of the few children who could not be vaccinated due to a real severe reaction to vaccines. I have a medical background and I always believed in vaccinating. When she was 8 weeks old, I had the routine shots done. This was in 2003, and if I am not mistaken there were EIGHT vaccines she was given that day. MeaslesMumpsRubellaDiptheriaTetanusPertussisPolioHepatitis B. She was a healthy child, born at term, healthy weight, no issues, no risk factors that I knew of. I was an excited and happy first time mother and proud of myself for taking good care of her. Right after the appointment, my daughter became fussy and would not be comforted for the next hour or so. This did not phase me, I knew shots made babies fussy. Maybe 2 hours after the appointment, she began to have seizures. The fussiness became full blown non-stop screaming, with her back arched in a horrible way. She was later diagosed with encephalitis, and she was screaming like that because of the pressure of her swollen brain inside her skull. We are very, very lucky that we were able to control her reaction and that she has no long term effects today from that reaction. It was one of the scariest things, as a parent, I have ever gone through! On the advice of our doctor, after this reaction we decided to go to a separated / delayed vaccine schedule to lessen the chance of a second reaction. The next time she had a vaccine (and it was even IPV / polio, one that according to my doctor, "no one could possibly be allergic to!") she broke out in so many red welts she looked like a tiny lobster. She had to be hospitalized and given courses of steroids to bring THAT reaction under control. So two strikes, and we were out. A whole team of allergists and our pediatric group conferred on her case, and they told us that even if we wanted to try more vaccines with her, they would not be willing to do it. It was just too dangerous. So, she is now unvaccinated. We also have a younger daughter, and she is fully vaccinated. She had a mild reaction to DtP once - her arm swelled up and caused a few hair raising hours of screaming that triggered all those bad memories for me. But it was just that, and it went away. Otherwise, no problems. I'm of 2 minds on the vaccine issue. First, I really need everyone to vaccinate their kids if they can. Because my daughter can't be, and if you choose not to just to prove what a hipster you are or to show how green you are or something, you're really, seriously, putting her (and other very sick kids) at risk of serious stuff. I think the vaccine / autism link has been well and truly shown to be false, and people who still believe it is true are seeing what they want to see. It really, really bothers me when people find out my daughter isn't vaccinated and then treat me (or her) like we're stupid or negligent because of it. They do this because there are a lot of stupid and negligent parents out there who aren't vaccinating. Be a good parent. Protect your kids. If not yours, protect your communty. On the other hand... I feel like I have no right to tell people they should vaccinate when we haven't. And we haven't because we experienced what they're all afraid of. So we're kind of the proof that yes, bad things sometimes do happen with vaccines. Also one of the things our doctors have assured us is that with modern medical care, getting measles or mumps is going to suck... but it won't kill my daughter. Even scarier diseases like diptheria or pertussis? Now that she's not an infant, and assuming we got medical care ASAP (which of course we would) her chances of survival are excellent. So when non-vaxers make the claim that the diseases that are vaccinated against generally aren't deadly: I believe them. I think they are only very dangerous if you are a fetus (rubella,) infant (pertussis,) or otherwise severely compromised in the immune department. Now, to me that's not a very good reason not to get a vaccine. But maybe to someone else it is. Maybe their child has risk factors for severe reactions like my daughter's that I don't know about. Who am I to judge? I don't know every person's back story, so I try not to say anything. That said, in a general sense? If (g)your child is healthy? Please, please go get them their shots. You will be protecting your child in a way that I can't protect mine. Trust me, from one mother to another, that is an incredibly hard thing to say, that you can't protect your child. I can't. You can. So do it. And in doing so, offer a measure of protection to the other children in your community who cannot be proteced by vaccines because of reactions, or AIDS, or cancer, or whatever else. I won't make the choice for you, but if you choose to do so? Thank you from the bottom of my heart.  Embed Quote

There is a group of epidemiological economists, predominantly Tomas Philipson of University of Chicago who argue that low vaccination rates are due to the perceived diminishing marginal returns from vaccination. The foremost paper in this area is Economic Epidemiology and Infectious Diseases. Philipson argues that we have perceived benefits of vaccination based on the incidence and severity of disease. As incidence of a disease increases, the marginal benefit of prevention is great and so many people take action to prevent disease. Conversely, as diseases become more rare, our perceived marginal benefit for vaccination decreases, and so do vaccination rates. In essence, our behavior (whether or not to take a preventive action) changes in response to the prevalence of the preventable disease. So, to over-simplify things a bit... people don't get vaccinated (or get their kids vaccinated) because these diseases are rare.  Embed Quote

Here are some of the reasons that parents choose not to vaccinate or only partially vaccinate their children:Possible (but real) reactions to vaccines: there is a small chance that a vaccine will cause a reaction (ranging from fevers to rashes to seizures) in the childPerceived (but unreal) risks of vaccines: there are still many people who believe that the MMR vaccine causes autismToxic ingredients in vaccines: vaccines currently include ingredients such as formaldehyde, aluminum, and mercury. While the amount of these ingredients have decreased over time (and are absent in some cases), many parents would prefer to not introduce toxins into their children's bloodstreamsBelief that there are some salutary effects of disease: some feel that exposure to illness as a child builds a healthier immune system later in lifeUnknown long term effects of vaccination: it may take many years to discover the long term effect of a vaccine. Case in point - there are long term risks of the chicken pox vaccine that are just coming out: http://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/2...Skepticism of the motives of vaccine providers: some feel that vaccine providers are driven by profit rather than by a genuine interest in the public good.Skepticism of the public health system that recommends vaccinations: some feel that vaccine requirements (in schools, camps, etc.) pushed by the government are infringements of liberty by entrenched bureaucracies in bed with the drug companiesA sense that we over vaccinate. Vaccines in the US are given for diseases that are rarely deadly (chicken pox) or pretty much not an issue in the US (polio).I think that the complexity of this issue is illustrated by the chicken pox vaccine. It has clearly been shown to reduce death by chicken pox in children from about 100 a year to about 10 per year in the US. However, how many of that difference of 90 came from people who didn't provide (or have access to) proper hospital care for their children? Use of the vaccine seems to increase longer term morbidity in people with weakened immune systems. What if, in 25 years, an additional 500 deaths per year are caused by use of the vaccine? Is it worth it then? If the vaccine costs about $100 for a series and there are about 4.5M children per year, it will cost about half a billion dollars  to vaccinate. Could that money be put to to use to save lives in a better way or is the lost productivity that parents incur when they have a child sick with chicken pox worth it? Tough questions.  Embed Quote

column9: I've read that coal-burning is a source of Hg in fish... and also that there is naturally-occurring Hg in the ocean... where is the Hg in fish today coming from?
column10: The mercury found in fish comes from both anthropogenic (human-made/induced) and "natural"sources. However, it should be noted that "natural" mercury emissions are accounted as including re-emission of both anthropogenic and "natural" deposits, and that re-emission of previously anthropogenically-attributable mercury has been estimated to account for 50% of all "natural" land and ocean emissions into the atmosphere (Lindberg et al. 2007, pg. 20). So, mercury vapor entering the atmosphere from an open field would be counted as a "natural" emission, even if that mercury had been deposited in that field as a result of a nearby coal-fired power plant.Mercury cycles through the environment, so the question of where the mercury found in fish comes from depends on how many steps back you go. The short version is that mercury in fish comes from what they eat, including plants, crustaceans, and other fish. Mercury bioaccumulates up the food chain, which is why top predatory fish have higher concentrations than those at the bottom of the food chain. The mercury bioaccumulating up the food chain (and the one of major concern to human health) is methylmercury (MeHg), which has been converted from inorganic mercury by bacteria living at the sedimentary level. This methylmercury is then taken up by the marine food web, and also explains why bottom-dwelling animals tend to have higher mercury concentrations than you would otherwise expect.The mercury in sediment has settled from the water. Mercury enters the water from atmospheric and terrestrial deposition. There is run-off from surface deposits, direct dumping, settling of mercury-laden atmospheric particulates, mercury-laden rain, etc. A 2002 paper by Mason and Shau (see bottom of comment reference) estimated that atmospheric deposition into the oceans accounted for around 15.4 times that of surface deposition.According to a 2010 estimate by Pirrone et al., annual "natural" emissions to the atmosphere (including re-emission of anthropogenic emissions) totalled 5207 megagrams (5,207,000 kilograms), while annual anthropogenic emissions totalled 2320 megagrams (2,320,000 kilograms). The study found that "fossil-fuel fired power plants, ferrous and non-ferrous metals manufacturing facilities, caustic soda production plants, ore processing facilities, incinerators for urban, medical and industrial wastes, cement plants and chemicals production facilities" released significant amounts of mercury into the atmosphere, and that "fossil fuel-fired power plants are the largest point sources of mercury released to the atmosphere" (Pirrone et al. 2010, pg. 4726). It's also important to note that mercury concentrations are higher near their source, so fish living in an area close to coal-fired power plants are likely to have higher concentrations than those that are not. Deposits in sediment and elsewhere may also endure for a long time, so closure of a plant or other point source may not reduce risk for years or decades. My doctoral thesis, Fish Consumption, Mercury Intake, and the Associated Risks to the Kuwaiti Population, considers the past presence of a nearby chlorine and bleach processing plant that had used mercury cathodes as a possible contributor to mercury concentrations in fish in the Arabian Gulf, though the plant closed in the 1970s.I'll have a look for historical databases on mercury concentrations in fish and let you know if something comes up. For which region were you looking for information?- Mey AkashahReferences:Akashah, M. (2010), Fish Consumption, Mercury Intake, and the Associated Risks to the Kuwaiti Population, Harvard School of Public Health.Lindberg, S., et al. (2007), “A Synthesis of Progress and Uncertainties in Attributing the Sources of Mercury in Deposition," Ambio, Vol. 36, No. 1, pp. 19-32.Mason, R.P. and Sheu, G.R. (2002), "Role of the ocean in the global mercury cycle," Glob. Biogeochem. Cycles, Vol. 16, pg. 093.Pirrone, N. et al. (2010), "Global mercury emissions to the atmosphere from anthropogenic and natural sources," Atmos. Chem. Phys. Discuss., Vol. 10, pp. 4719–4752.  Embed Quote

column9: I now work with teenagers in Peru and will start working with teens in Colorado this fall.
column10: Get them involved in their own education. When I worked with my teen group in Peru, we used a series of hands-on activities to teach the ABC method. In English, it's the Abstinence, Be Faithful and use Condoms method. In Spanish, ABC stood for Abstinerse, Brindar fidelidad and Con protección. The purpose of our project was to prevent HIV through the use of peer educators.With the help of a really supportive school district, a great obstetra from the health post, a health-conscious mayor and some pretty awesome parents, we taught 40+ teens how to conduct activity-driven training sessions focused on how to prevent HIV that they then conducted with their own classmates. Every activity involved the full participation of the audience, and all the sessions were similarly structured to answer the following questions: What is HIV?What does it do to the body?How is it transmitted?How can we prevent it?Here are some examples of the activities we used. What is HIV? -> El Rompecabeza del VIH (HIV Puzzle)Students were given either a letter or a description, and they had to match them to each other. Once put together, the instructor would explain what the difference was between HIV and AIDS. What does it do to the body? -> El Sistema Inmunológico (The Immune System)This activity demonstrated how HIV attacks the immune system and leaves the body vulnerable to opportunistic infections, using some small drawings on cards and a volunteer. How is it transmitted? -> Si da, no da (Yes it's transmitted this way, no it's not)This activity required the students to guess what activities could put you at risk for HIV infection and which ones could not. Once all the cards were placed under "Sí da" or "No da," the instructor went through the different cards one-by-one and asked the participants whether they thought it was in the right spot, guiding them to the correct conclusion. Once the ways HIV was spread were identified, they could then talk about how to prevent transmission.  How can it be prevented? -> La Carrera del Condón (Condom races)Instructors demonstrated the correct way to use a condom, and then the participants lined up to do a condom relay. Each member of each team would have to correctly put a condom on a green banana and then race back to tag the next team member. The first team to have everyone correctly place a condom on the banana won. This activity helped to involve every teen in the room to try to use a condom without having to worry about being singled out. When everyone had to do it, the teens were less likely to freeze with embarrassment.  There were many other activities that we conducted, depending on the group or time allotted. But the educational sessions always centered around first understanding WHY it was important to abstain or use condoms before addressing HOW to practice these techniques successfully. Once the teens learned how to conduct the activities, it was up to them to create the lesson plans and develop the materials they would need, as well as hand out the pre and post tests to measure how much their audience learned.  In addition to the educational sessions. The teenagers also worked on some media projects to help raise awareness of condom use, abstinence and fidelity. They made "radio spots" that were then broadcast over the town's loudspeaker, wrote skits for town gatherings, and painted murals. They even made a telenovela, a short fiction film that they wrote and starred in themselves that told the story of three friends and how they learned to prevent HIV. We were always careful to pause and ask them their thoughts, opinions and ideas on how best to make the message resonate with their peers.    Full disclosure: I have no idea if the use of peer educators helped to increase condom use overall in our community. But I do know that I saw a massive transformation in some of the peer educators. Over the course of the two-year project, I watched some really shy kids, terrified of asking those embarrassing questions, develop into confident, knowledgeable young adults who were interested in learning more about health in general. Some of them even went on to coordinate educational sessions with adults in their own neighborhoods. I don't know if it was the most effective way to teach condom use and abstinence, but I think it was worth doing. NOTE: For those interested in the specifics of some of our activities, you can message me directly.  Embed Quote

column9: I now work with teenagers in Peru and will start working with teens in Colorado this fall.
column10: Even Abstinence is not 100% sure form of birth control. If you don't agree ask Joseph and Mary!  Embed Quote

column9: I've heard a lot about the radioactive waste being very difficult to properly dispose of - but some people deny this. Of course there are also other risks associated with nuclear power beyond just properly disposing of waste. What's the truth?
column10: The truth is that it is an engineering problem. With poor engineering, storage and management will be difficult and perhaps dangerous. With proper engineering, storage of nuclear waste will be safe.Same thing with flying planes. Flying is safer (on a per-mile basis) than driving. This is a result of proper engineering.   Embed Quote

column9: I've heard a lot about the radioactive waste being very difficult to properly dispose of - but some people deny this. Of course there are also other risks associated with nuclear power beyond just properly disposing of waste. What's the truth?
column10: It's true that radioactive waste needs to be handled carefully. It needs to be stored in a safe location for many years until it has spent itself. At that point, though, it can be handled safely. (I think it's on the order of ten years.)However, nuclear fuel is extremely efficient. You can generate a lot of power with a small amount of it. So you don't generate a lot of waste. And much less mining is needed for a given amount of power. Mining is a dangerous activity, so reducing it increases overall safety.Another safety issue: with proper engineering (container units, safety procedures, etc.) a meltdown is a relatively safe event—such as Three Mile Island, where the containing unit worked properly and no one was killed.This is all based on reading a book The Health Hazards of Not Going Nuclear, along with a visit to a canceled nuclear power plant near Seattle (mostly built, never operational). I might be getting some details wrong.  Embed Quote

column9: I've heard a lot about the radioactive waste being very difficult to properly dispose of - but some people deny this. Of course there are also other risks associated with nuclear power beyond just properly disposing of waste. What's the truth?
column10: Just look how many people are dying every year on a nuclear plant, then compare the same figure for a coal plant for example.In June 2012, Forbes published an article that reported average death rates per TWh of produced energy, and where TWh stands for terrawatt hours (http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/K...)The study shows that there is a death rate of 15 per TWh produced in the United States coal plants, and this figure reaches 170 in the case of China. Then in comparison, the average death rate is 0.09 per TWh produced on a Nuclear plant and across all countries having a nuclear plant (not just United States).You can compare to other power plants (oil, natural gas, solar, wind, hydro, ...), the nuclear plant is always the safest regarding of the death rate per TWh produced.This does not prove all points regarding the safety of a nuclear plant but it definitely provides a good indication.The Forbes articlehttp://www.forbes.com/sites/jame...  Embed Quote

column9: I've heard a lot about the radioactive waste being very difficult to properly dispose of - but some people deny this. Of course there are also other risks associated with nuclear power beyond just properly disposing of waste. What's the truth?
column10: There is no such thing as "safe energy."  You’d be asking for gasoline that doesn’t burn. Just as a reminder: seven workers were injured — one with third-degree burns over 90% of his body — in Myrna, Georgia, in an explosion in a coal-fired power plant.  A cleaning chemical interacted with coal dust and caused ignition.  The press made no big deal of the coal-dust accident, nor does anybody normally write blaring headlines about hundreds of coal-mine accidents, refinery accidents, oil-well accidents, and natural gas explosions that regularly kill or maim the people who work to deliver energy to us.Nothing that involves a high concentration of energy and a low concentration can ever be completely safe. Energy is the ability to do work, and it may end up doing work you don't want it to do. Now here's the real problem: You feel you have been lied to, that somebody promised you breeder reactors are completely safe, or that other kinds of reactors are completely safe or something. Well, somebody lied to you all right, when they told you that any power generation could ever be completely safe.Read up on 'loss of blade' accidents for windmills, dam failures for hydro, and how coal releases radiation (lots of it) and other toxins (lots of them). Read up on what chemical compounds are used in solar cells, or just how hot a commercial sterling solar engine is at the mirror's focal point. Look at the political consequences of breeders, but also at the political consequences of the existing fuel oil demand. Look at the environmental consequences of nuclear, but also at the environmental consequences of big oil. Find out how even wave and tide, if scaled up to produce tens or hundreds of gigawatts, means thousands of small boat accidents a year, and probably many aquatic species will inevitably become extinct and whole ecologies will likely follow. For any power source, read up on where it is to be located, and the human costs of sending the power to where it is to be used.  Embed Quote

column9: I've heard a lot about the radioactive waste being very difficult to properly dispose of - but some people deny this. Of course there are also other risks associated with nuclear power beyond just properly disposing of waste. What's the truth?
column10: Asking whether nuclear power is safe is the wrong question. The right one is: Is it safer than the alternatives?Bottom line, humanity isn't suddenly going to stop consuming vast amounts of energy. This energy needs to be available as cheaply and safely as possible, but in evaluating those properties, it's important to include all the effects.Coal, oil and gas are the main alternatives to nuclear in most locations. While seen as safer, the reality is quite a bit more complicated. There's no risk of a large scale meltdown scenario with fossil fuels, of course, but large quantities of radiation, mercury and other harmful substances, including C02, are released and do need to be considered when comparing total safety and cost with nuclear energy.Unfortunately, I haven't seen a full and solid comparison. You can get an idea by looking up studies on the by-products (e.g. nuclear waste and coal ash) by the EPA and others. A simple answer is not forthcoming, however, and it seems that every comparison is severely biased by whomever is conducting it.When comparing, it's also important to consider the type of nuclear power plant being proposed (when talking expansion). Modern nuclear reactors are significantly safer than the 30-40 year old reactors that dominate the US nuclear production facilities. Fast Breeder Reactors and Pebble Bed Reactors are two types it might be worthwhile to read up on.The distributed nature of the damage and cost of fossil fuel consumption makes it much more politically acceptable than nuclear, so it's doubtful that any change (whether or not it would make sense) will occur in the West any time soon.For a discussion on the costs of coal, see e.g.http://solveclimate.com/blog/200...The EPA also carried out a study on the dangers of coal ash (search for EPA coal ash study).  Embed Quote

column9: I've heard a lot about the radioactive waste being very difficult to properly dispose of - but some people deny this. Of course there are also other risks associated with nuclear power beyond just properly disposing of waste. What's the truth?
column10: Nuclear power is extremely safe.  According to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics it's actually safer then the real estate industry.  Here's the deal with waste.  First off, it isn't waste.  96% of the energy is still left in Spent Nuclear Fuel to be used at a future time.  Here's the other key:  Nuclear Power Plants are the only power plants that sequester ALL of their waste and contain it in large steel casks.  Contrast this with a coal or natural gas plant which dumps its waste into the atmosphere during the course of normal operations.  Embed Quote

column9: I've heard a lot about the radioactive waste being very difficult to properly dispose of - but some people deny this. Of course there are also other risks associated with nuclear power beyond just properly disposing of waste. What's the truth?
column10: In light of the present situation in Japan, I will try to broach the subject of "safety" in a more delicate manner. The fact is, most energy-technology advances that mankind has harnessed since the start of the Industrial Revolution have carried a potential risk to human health. Nuclear power has, considering the years of continous delivery of energy and the few incidents of potential and/or realized danger to a population-- been one of the safest.Now consider the coal industry to feed Fossil-Fueled Steam Plants that are in daily use by the many thousands throughout the world. In the process of mining the coal to feed the plants, and for other heating or propulsion applications, there have been many, many deaths --going back to the late 1800's. A mine collapse or fire -- black lung disease, and so on. Even with the advent of the automobile, there were accepted risks by the users of this new transportation mode. They wore goggles to protect the eyes, "car coats" to protect themselves from the elements, and when there were accidents they were often very serious, if not fatal. Yes-- modern manufacturers have made the automobile much safer than in those days, but there is still risk attached to each and every use of the automobile-today.My point here is that there has never been an incorporating of a technology that would improve the living conditions of the masses, that did not have a price of increased risk attached to that incorporation. Will alternative energy sources prove to be statistically safer than Nuclear Power (for the same power output)?Possibly in 20-30 years. But for now let's just consider the fact that the record shows Nuclear Power to have caused far, far less death and injury than any other large-scale method of power generation Man has ever devised.  Embed Quote

column9: I've heard a lot about the radioactive waste being very difficult to properly dispose of - but some people deny this. Of course there are also other risks associated with nuclear power beyond just properly disposing of waste. What's the truth?
column10: Granted, there have been a few unfortunate incidents with nuclear power in the past, and these generated a fair amount of bad publicity, fed by typically alarmist and ill-informed media coverage (because fear makes for hot news, and newspapers with headlines shouting 'We're all going to die!' always sell better than ones that calmly tell their readers 'Don't panic!'). The public perception of the technology is therefore somewhat distorted, and sometimes bordering on hysterical (and the less informed people are about nuclear power, the more hysterical they tend to be). But it must be remembered that lessons were learned from those incidents, and nuclear power technology and the standards and practices that govern it have been continually improved and refined over the last few decades (the same cannot be said for other forms of power generation, incidentally). As an example of this, there is now a design of nuclear reactor that has the benefits of being far cheaper to build, far simpler in construction and operation (and therefore less prone to technical problems than more complex designs) and inherently safe, because it is self-moderating: it can never run out of control and trigger a meltdown, because the hotter the fuel gets, the less reactive it becomes. This is the Pebble Bed Reactor, and it promises to be able to provide cheap, safe, clean energy, without posing many of the same risks as more conventional reactors (not least of which is that of potentially providing the basis for nuclear weapons development by certain hostile regimes...) Pebble bed reactor  Embed Quote

column9: I've heard a lot about the radioactive waste being very difficult to properly dispose of - but some people deny this. Of course there are also other risks associated with nuclear power beyond just properly disposing of waste. What's the truth?
column10: The expected damage done by nuclear plants is less than other power plants, but the variance is higher. The potential of a Chernobyl-like incident scares people.  Embed Quote

column9: I've heard a lot about the radioactive waste being very difficult to properly dispose of - but some people deny this. Of course there are also other risks associated with nuclear power beyond just properly disposing of waste. What's the truth?
column10: No nuclear power is not safe.Professional risk assessors (insurance companies and investors) do not believe it is.  In jurisdictions such as USA and Canada, there is legislation which specifically limits liability amounts of nuke accidents (Price–Anderson Nuclear Industries Indemnity Act and Nuclear Liability Act respectively).  Insurance underwriters have long thought the nuke plants are not safe enough to insure without caps on liabilities.  Fukushima is a good example of why this is.  2 years later clean up is ongoing, radiation continues to pour into the sea and estimates stand at decades of clean up at cost of $150 billion plus.Private investment into nukes is also tanking in free markets - Nuclear sending shock waves through Wall Street .  Investors no longer see nukes as a safe bet.  Construction, operation, refurbishment and decommissioning costs are nearly impossible to control.Nuclear waste will be lethal for as long into the future for 250,000 years.  That's about as long back in history to the time Neanderthals were living in caves - in other words far before any semblance of human civilization as we know it existed.  What legacy does this leave to the future generations?Certainly carbon is also a risk, but this chemical can be absorbed back into the biosphere in a manner which is not deadly toxic to all life.  Embed Quote

column9: I've heard a lot about the radioactive waste being very difficult to properly dispose of - but some people deny this. Of course there are also other risks associated with nuclear power beyond just properly disposing of waste. What's the truth?
column10: Let's start with what most can agree on: 1) human error leading to systematic failure will always be possible; 2) disaster, when it does happen (and it will again), is not comparable to, say a wind turbine blade falling off -- nuclear accidents poison entire regions for generations; 3) energy coal has terrible human health effects, and more per year than nuclear if that is the metric you choose for comparison; 4) *nothing* is purely and inherently "safe" -- today's cheeseburger will kill me, eventually.None of that makes electricity generated by boiling water via nuclear fission a wise energy choice -- even given climate change's forcing our hand to get away from fossil fuels.Professionals in nuclear energy will disagree, as they have a lot invested in the -- yes, advancing -- technologies involved. The majority of them do no live near the Davis-Besse power plant, which, in 2002, was discovered to have a giant hole in the reactor head eaten away for years by dripping acid. Postponed NRC inspections (delayed at the request of the operator) failed to bring this near-catastrophe to light. You can joke that "We almost lost Toledo" isn't that much of a concern, but it is to we Ohioans.Davis-Besse Nuclear Power Station (image of hole in reactor head)Professionals in nuclear energy think anti-nuclear activists are ignorant of the technology and cost-benefit and risks involved, questions on which they all come down in favor of nuke power; they call our concerns "irrational" despite having no sound, long-lasting solution for managing the enormous, massive amounts of waste generated. So let's set all that aside and look disinterestedly at the economics of it.If nuclear power were both safe and cost-effective, wouldn't countries all over the world be building new plants? Yet even in France too much trepidation about it in the private sector prevents new investment. Here in the U.S., we aren't seeing new construction despite the Price–Anderson Nuclear Industries Indemnity Act which since 1957 has given federal protection to only this one means of energy production.  That act alone ought to answer the question: How safe can nuclear energy be if no company will invest in it without a federal guarantee that "coverable accidents" will have cleanup funded by the U.S. government.If nuclear power is safe, private insurers would insure construction and operation of plants.  They've never had to.The risk of major disaster is so high, nobody in industry would ever touch nuclear power without this federal giveaway.We don't even need to bring up the terrorist scenario argument; in summer 2011 a nuclear power facility in Nebraska flooded, caught fire, and was shut down thanks to nothing more than severe flooding of the Missouri River. It's still shut down. As of fall 2012, it's still closed, AFAIK.Here is what we in the nuclear safety community say when comparisons with coal come up. No nukes, no coal, no kidding:http://www.nirs.org/factsheets/n...UPDATE: "[I]n the US from 2002 to 2012 over 50,000 megawatts of wind were deployed. Not one megawatt of power from new nuclear reactors was deployed, despite subsidies estimated to be worth more than the value of the power new reactors would have produced. Similarly, it took 40 years globally to deploy 50,000 megawatts of solar PV and, recently, only 2 ½ years to deploy an equal amount. By some estimates, another 100,000 MW will be built by the end of 2015. Already, renewables and distributed power have overtaken nuclear power in terms of megawatt hour generation worldwide."MORE HERE: Page on Nirs  Embed Quote

column9: I've heard a lot about the radioactive waste being very difficult to properly dispose of - but some people deny this. Of course there are also other risks associated with nuclear power beyond just properly disposing of waste. What's the truth?
column10: No, because technologies and people that use them are not separate entities.With every technology there are economic and social difficulties. To ensure that nuclear tech is properly handled, properly engineered, you need to have a concerned citizenry that's capable of enforcing safety measures.Chernobyl did not have the right social organization around it, so it was engineered and handled poorly. Uranium mines can be in any country and developing countries aren't capable of enforcing safety measures on them. Even in developed countries like Australia, France and Germany there are noticeable problems with uranium mining, mostly caused by economic forces. An interesting documentary on that is "Uranium Is A Country" http://topdocumentaryfilms.com/u...Current nuclear technology requires too many things to go right. A safe technology should be stupid simple to setup safely and require little or no government oversight to maintain safety. Oversight slowly crumbles against financial motivations.There are new nuclear technologies in development that are simpler and recycle waste from current nuclear plants. The current waste has a ~10,000 year half life and after use in new plants it will have a ~500 year half life. We'll probably be building such powerplants if only to ease the nuclear waste problem.Safety problems can crop up in any industry that depends on complex engineering, perfect maintenance and economics for it. The airline industry has worn down regulation on regional flights in the USA and safety has suffered as a result. With energy technology few people ever see the environmental damage, (power-plants and mines are in sparsely populated areas) which makes it that much easier to get away with it.Nuclear can be compared with coal and oil in it's safety record and engineering and management complexity required to maintain safety. But compared to solar and wind the old technologies are a safety headache.  Embed Quote

This to me was one of the most shameful pieces of public health history of the US.  I still can't believe that doctors and nurses actually participated in this atrocity.The Tuskegee syphilis experiment (also known as the Tuskegee syphilis study or Public Health Service syphilis study) was an infamous clinical study conducted between 1932 and 1972 in Tuskegee, Alabama by the U.S. Public Health Service to study the natural progression of untreated syphilis in poor, rural black men who thought they were receiving free health care from the U.S. government.http://www.npr.org/programs/morn...http://www.cdc.gov/tuskegee/time...  Embed QuoteAnswered in four minutes.

These might be outside the scope of the question, but they were performed in the interest of health:Human experimentation performed by Nazi Germany on concentration camp prisoners: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naz...Human experimentation performed by Japan's Unit 731 on prisoners in the Second Sino-Japanese War: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uni...  Embed Quote

Right up there with the Tuskeegee Syphilis experiment in my opinion - perhaps even worse, though it was not quite as coldly systematic over such a sustained period of time - was the use of Zyklon B as a delousing agent on primarily Mexican immigrants along the Texas border (El Paso specifically) in the 1920s and 1930s.Zyklon B - or Cyclone B in English - is a pelletized form of hydrocyanic acid developed and initially manufactured by DEGESCH company in Germany. Though Zyklon B was initially conceived as a pesticide, it is severely toxic to all forms of animal life, a fact which was later put to one of the most infamous uses in history by the Nazis, who used Zyklon B as the primary poison in the gas chambers at Dachau, Auschwitz, Bergen-Belsen and elsewhere.However, the toxicity of Zyklon B to humans was well-known prior to its use by the Nazis. That's what makes the fact that it was knowingly used to spray down immigrants entering El Paso from Juarez, as described in Ringside Seat to a Revolution: An Underground Cultural History of El Paso and Juarez, 1893-1923, so odious.In 1917, Woodrow Wilson signed into law the Immigration Act - http://library.uwb.edu/guides/US... , and the U.S. Public Health Service published a "Manual for the Physical Inspection of Aliens" (there was also a "Manual for the Mental Inspection of Aliens" -http://www.dnalc.org/view/11482-... - and a few other official publications). All of these developments were brought about by the rising fears spurred by the eugenicists of the day over cross-border infection by "aliens." as well as by a more general desire to keep anyone "defective" out of America. Listed reasons for barring entrance included, at various times, people with such conditions as "arthritis, asthma, bunions, deafness, deformities, flat feet, heart disease, hernia, hysteria, poor eyesight, poor physical development, spinal curvature, vascular disease of the heart, and varicose veins." Elsewhere, "imbeciles, idiots, feeble-minded person, persons of constitutional psychopathic inferiority (homosexuals), vagrants, physical defectives, chronic alcoholics, polygamists, anarchists, persons afflicted with loathsome or dangerous contagious diseases, prostitutes, contracts laborers, all aliens over 16 who cannot read" were all to be prohibited entry into the USA.Those last two - contract laborers and aliens over 16 who cannot read - were aimed squarely at the nation's southern border immigrants. As a result, U.S. Public Health Service Agents deloused a reported 127,123 Mexicans in a zealous effort to comply with the new regulations. And, by "deloused," that means (in addition to "bathing" the immigrants (harsh scrubbing, often in either kerosene or vinegar), the Public Health Agents sprayed the clothes of these 100,000+ immigrants with Zyklon B.Unfortunately, the gaseous form of Zyklon B can be absorbed directly through the skin - that's one of the reasons the Nazis used it - and it is fatal - not just toxic, but FATAL - to humans when absorbed through the skin at a concentration of 50 ppm or above. While there are no known records of living people actually being directly sprayed with Zyklon B (of which I'm aware, at any rate), what kind of exposure resulted from putting back on one's clothes after having them sprayed heavily with Zyklon B? In the above-linked book, the author laments that he has only oral and anecdotal histories and evidence for the results of such routine, widespread use of such a deadly toxin, but he estimates that all effects taken together (birth defects, cancers, deaths) "may well run into the tens of thousands." Of human beings. I'd say that's got to rank as one of the worst abuses in the name of "public health" in this country's history, at least.  Embed Quote

column9: During an episode of "The Infinite Monkey Cage" on BBC Radio 4; "What Don't We Know?" geneticist Steve Jones basically says:"If a human only ate raw food, he or she would die within three months."Is there any evidence to back that claim?
column10: Yes. In fact, cooking is a relatively recent phenomenon. The first somewhat well-accepted evidence for cooking comes from the presence of burnt bones and tools at Zhoukoudian, China, between 300,000 and 500,000 years ago in what was probably a very late H. erectus site. Thus, all hominids before a certain date probably ate entirely raw food. ("Hominid Use of Fire in the Lower and Middle Pleistocene" by Steven R. James, Current Anthropology (1989) gives a good, if outdated, review of the origins of cooking and other fire use.) In fact, until recently, there were Inuit groups that went through multiple seasons in a year eating almost nothing but raw, frozen, or fermented meat.To be clear, though, there have been no modern human populations other than today's raw-foodists who have gone entirely without cooking. Anthropologists like Richard Wrangham use this as evidence that cooking may be an obligatory human behavior, controversially claiming that "people who choose a 'raw-foodist' life-style experience low energy and impaired reproductive function" ("Cooking as a biological trait", Wrangham, 2003).There are a few disadvantages to not cooking:Parasites: It's easy to underestimate how big of a problem parasites are, even today. Billions of people worldwide are infected by parasites, many from either unclean water or improperly prepared food. Parasite larvae tend to spend a lot of time embedded in animal tissues (like muscle) and plants, while adult stages will spend a lot of time in animal organs. Infestation with parasites is a major cause of malnutrition and death worldwide, and without proper regulations, transmission through raw food is distinct possibility, while thorough cooking will kill most parasites. The Inuit mentioned above probably have a smaller chance of getting parasites due to the climate, but protozoan and helminth infections were and continue to be a problem among many Inuit. The human digestive tract is resilient, but going for years eating nothing but unregulated raw food will take its toll.It's hard to eat raw food: Or at least, for a good part of hominid history it was. Early hominids specialized to eat tough plant matter had enormous jaws and huge sagittal crests to attach the powerful muscles needed to grind their food. (To be fair, much of the reduction in jaw size since then was caused by changes in the content of diet rather than the preparation.) Chewing this tough plant material caused many hominids' teeth to be worn down to the gums. (Again, to be fair, much of this was caused by the fact that for a long time, teeth were used as tools, which caused a lot of wear.) These early hominids also probably had digestive tracts better equipped to deal with raw food. The point is that if you are committed to eating raw food, it's not guaranteed that there will always be soft raw food available, and eating tougher food without cooking it takes a lot of effort. Some people believe that cooking has caused such a dramatic reduction in jaw size that it's a major cause of orthodontic malocclusion today ("The adaptive value of dental crowding", A. V. Lombardi, 1982).To give a dramatic illustration, take a look at the enormous molars on this jaw of P. boisei, a hominid specialized to eat tough plant matter:In the past, people who ate only raw food would probably have a somewhat shortened life-span due to the disadvantages outlined above. But these are mostly negated by the advantages that modern raw foodists have:Reduced exposure to parasites: Because of food regulations in the developed world, it's much less likely that you'll get many of the common food parasites than it was before, although you still have to be careful.Unprecedented access to a variety of foods: Sure, when you're living on the African savannah, living off of raw food may be tough, but in America, we import and grow food from all over the world. Surely, anyone can find enough foods to meet their nutritional requirements and suit their tastes - at least if they're willing to pay enough. And we've developed techniques and foods that make things much easier to eat than the tough plant matter our ancestors used to eat.Health: I know far too little about raw food diets to make any claims about their health benefits, but practitioners of these diets claim, among other things, that it preserves vitamins and enzymes. (As with any other dietary advice, take the claims with a grain of salt and look at what the evidence says.)In short, it should be made perfectly obvious that humans can survive on raw food alone, based on the fact that thousands, if not millions, of people have done it and are doing it. Whether or not this is desirable is up to you to decide.  Embed Quote

column10: Yes. Anecdotally, there are a number of adherents to the 'raw food diet' and I similarly doubt all hunter gathering societies cooked their food (in fact, I bet very few did). Also, babies don't die from breastfeeding for three months... More generally, we are the only species which cooks its food and I find it difficult to believe we are so differentially adapted to this behavior that unlike the other myriad of species, we would die on a raw food only diet.There are clearly some benefits of cooking (a wider range of foods become edible, and parasites might be killed) but that doesn't mean it's necessary to survive.  Embed Quote

Probably not. There are a few things that make a disease a good candidate for eradication, and HPV doesn't quite fit the bill.What makes a disease a good candidate?1. The disease is highly visible. Small pox, for example, was a pretty tough disease to hide. The signature rash appeared all over the body in a spiral pattern, starting with the extremities and working their way around. You can see in the image below that the rash concentrated in some of the most visible places: the head, hands and feet. You couldn't miss it.  Image from: CDC Smallpox | Smallpox Overview2. The symptoms are unique. Many diseases look alike. It's much harder to beat a disease if it's not easily identified. The rash for small pox was characteristic. For the most part, people knew what it was and -- most importantly -- what to look for.  3. There is a short incubation period. This is the period of time between the moment a person is infected and the onset of symptoms. Measles, for example, is highly visible and has a characteristic rash, but it has a fairly long incubation period (10-12 days), and a person can become contagious before the symptoms are apparent. The shorter the incubation period, the faster cases can be identified and contained. 4. It is transmitted human-to-human. That is, there isn't something that carries the pathogen (the thing that causes disease) from person to person -- or a "vector" -- and no other animal can serve as a host. Yellow fever, for example, can live in both humans and monkeys, and is spread by mosquitoes. So if we did end up successfully eliminating yellow fever in humans, it's possible it could reemerge via the monkey-mosquito route if we let our immunity wane. Image from: A List of Some Vector Diseases 5. There is an effective method of preventing transmission. More often than not, this refers to an effective vaccine that provides lifelong immunity. With smallpox, one shot could protect most people for the rest of their lives. 6. It is stable. This means that it doesn't change easily. Viruses, especially, are prone to antigenic drift (changing little by little over time) or antigenic shift (changing in a big way very quickly). If the pathogen continues to morph, you're aiming at a moving target. Image from: Rule of 6ix: November 2011 Some other factors to consider for a good eradication candidate: 7. There are sufficient resources. Eradication has a HUGE return on investment, but the investment is pretty substantial. Significant resources need to be poured into eradication programs for them to work. Billions of dollars have been spent on the polio eradication campaign, and now the disease is only in three countries. But if resources were to be scaled back, polio could easily spread across the globe again. Concentrating those resources is critical.  8. There is enough political will. The world is increasingly interconnected. People can literally fly around the world in a single day. It takes massive coordination from the world's governing powers to make sure that everyone works in tandem. So ... how does HPV measure up against these characteristics?Highly visible? | No. Most people with HPV don't even know they are infected and show no symptoms. Unique symptoms? | Yes and no.  As I mentioned, most HPV infections result in no symptoms. Some strains of HPV can cause genital warts, however, and these are pretty characteristic. I'll spare you a graphic picture, but they are likened to cauliflower. Short incubation period? | No.  The incubation period varies widely, depending on the HPV sub type, but all estimates are long, typically ranging from one month to years. Human-to-human transmission? | Yes. Humans are the only known, natural hosts of HPV. Effective prevention method? | Yes and no. We have safe and effective vaccines; however, the vaccines can only protect against 2 or 4 HPV sub types (depending on the vaccine brand). Both vaccines prevent the two types of HPV responsible for the vast majority of HPV-related cancers, and one of the vaccines prevents the two sub types responsible for nearly all genital warts. But there are more than 100 different sub types of HPV, and roughly 40 that affect the genital area. We have no practical way to prevent the other subtypes. Even condoms don't fully protect against HPV. Is it stable? | Fairly so, yes. HPV is a double-stranded DNA virus, so it doesn't change as much as an RNA virus might. Sufficient resources? | Probably not. To start, HPV is REALLY, REALLY common. Nearly all sexually active adults become infected with HPV at some point in their lifetime -- in large part, because many people don't even know they are infected and so continue to spread it. What's more the vaccine requires three doses, months apart, to provide full protection. Tackling HPV would require massive, and I mean massive amounts of money and manpower. Political will? | Unlikely. People don't like talking about sexually transmitted infections, least of all politicians. Eradicating the four sub types included in the HPV4 vaccine would take nearly universal vaccination in every country on the planet, and there would still be 96+ sub types left circulating. Perhaps if we were able to develop a universal HPV vaccine that protected against every sub type for life, eradication would be feasible. But given the technology and biological considerations that we have today, HPV is just not a reasonable candidate for eradication. Sources: Disease EradicationPage on Cdc about MeaslesThe Principles of Disease Elimination and Eradication Page on PolioeradicationPage on Cdc about HPVViruses and Evolution  Embed Quote

Some strains of HPV are responsible for plantar warts.  Other strains are responsible for genital warts.  Other strains are responsible for cancers.It is not likely that all strains could be eradicated for the reasons already stated by Robyn Correll, however, it is conceivable we could eradicate the strains responsible for most (not all) of the cancers and genital warts.  With the currently licensed vaccines being extremely effective and preventing infection from the strains responsible for 70% of cervical cancer and 90% genital warts transmission could be interrupted if enough of the population were to be vaccinated. With the number of other strains it would reduce but not eliminate the disease burden.  Embed Quote

HPV transmission could be interrupted if infections were visualizable.Applying vinegar and checking for color change is being proposed as a low-tech way to detect precancerous cervix surface cells. While it's unlikely so simple a reagent would work for early-stage HPV infection, suppose there were an easy and cheap test, let's say using fluorescent antibodies. Then people might start demanding this test before contact.  Embed Quote
HPV is very preventative no doubt but you cannot eradicate it since it is associated with social stigma.  Embed Quote

After a DVD is received at a distribution center, it is cleaned and sanitized before being put back into distribution. Even if they were not cleaned, a particular distribution center only services a single geographic area. It's unlikely that a discs going through a single distribution center could spread a pathogen around the entire country. In the case of the flu, this isn't an issue anyway. The flu virus can only survive for 2 to 8 hours on a hard surface. Generally, there is more than 8 hours of elapsed time between the time a customer puts a DVD in the mail and it is opened by the next customer.See How long can influenza live on hard surface?(Edit: Quora Content Review removed the portion of the question specifically asking about spreading it across the country which is why I brought up the limited geographic area covered by a distribution center)  Embed QuoteAnswered in twenty-five minutes.

Interesting thought, but this is virtually impossible. The influenza virus has a very limited lifespan on hard surfaces such as a digital video disk. The CDC estimates a surface life between 2 to 8 hours [1]. Of course, this isn't near enough time to remain viable for infection of the next customer (or even a worker at the Netflix warehouse). [1] Preventing Seasonal Flu Illness  Embed QuoteAnswered in twenty-six minutes.
No. We clean every disc that comes back using an alcohol solution.  Embed Quote

column9: Source: http://thinkprogress.org/yglesia...Seems like there should be a market for some sort of competition with this level of stagnation, when compared to population growth.
column10: A few items to consider that may shed light:1. those "monopolistic" U.S. medical schools did in fact double their numbers to accommodate demand in the past, while residency positions have been steadily increasing all alongIn the 1970's, the number of students graduating from medical school in the U.S. literally doubled, in anticipation of greater need for their services:Meanwhile, residency positions have continued to steadily increase:2. the "monopolists" themselves recognize a looming physician shortage and have been trying to increase residency slotsControl over the supply of physicians ultimately rests with the federal government, which funds much of medical residency training. It is, however, heavily influenced by medical organizations - especially the Association of American Medical Colleges (AAMC).The current official position of the AAMC, however, is that we are indeed heading towards a shortage of physicians in the U.S., and they have urged the DHHS (Department of Health and Human Services) to increase their funding ceiling for residency positions. Here are the AAMC's own projections:As for specialty societies, there are strict prohibitions on discussion of resident manpower issues by centers around the country, precisely because of the risk of monopolistic behavior (or its appearance). The U.S. Department of Labor would agree with the coming undersupply of physicians:All these groups have a major challenge: changing the number of medical school or residency slots will bear fruit in 10+ years. It is not easy to predict a market demand that many years away.3. meanwhile, there has been a huge rise in "physician extender" professions such as Physician Assistants (PA) and Nurse Practitioners (NP)Physician productivity has gone up tremendously with the rise over the last decade of professions that act as "physician extenders" such as PA's:and of NP's:Canada is now taking a serious look at growing its own PA and NP workforces as well.4. the physician shortage in the U.S. may in fact be mostly a shortage of general practitioners (and possibly an oversupply of specialists)Total supply of physicians has risen only slowly in the U.S. since 1990 - but the same can be said of most advanced countries:Where the U.S. is drastically different from other OECD nations is in the number of general practitioners we have:5. at the same time, there is also a maldistribution problem in the U.S. - an oversupply of doc's in desirable locations, and terrible undersupply in other areas.The federal government has recognized this for a long time, and has taken some measures to try and alleviate this maldistribution:6. bringing in international medical graduates (IMG's) has been a help for some time now... column9: Source: http://thinkprogress.org/yglesia...Seems like there should be a market for some sort of competition with this level of stagnation, when compared to population growth.
column10: While I understand the historic importance and popular conception of the AMA, the conspiracy theories that abound regarding doctor pay and artificial limiting of spots seem a bit absurd. This issue is not that simple. And this comes from a guy who would love to see more doctors trained even if his future salary "suffered".First, a little mythbusting: the AMA does not accurately represent the American physician community, and whether it ever has is quite questionable. A quick look at their membership numbers from 2010 confirms this: only ~216K out of 814K+ licensed physicians were AMA members (~26%). To take a page from the site in the question details, a whopping 77% of doctors say the AMA does NOT represent their views. http://thinkprogress.org/health/...Anywho, let's answer the question. Skip to the bottom for summarizing statements if you're the impatient type.=== Part 1: Spots ===It's difficult to increase the number of spots at existing teaching institutions. Here are some reasons why:Cadavers cost money. A LOT of money. Running an anatomy lab with adequate safety/sanitary precautions, preservation capacity to keep a dead body in reasonable condition for months/years, and enough supply of bodies to educate med students at a reasonable ratio of 1 body for every 4-6 learners is no easy feat. Cremation/burial of the bodies needs to be taken into account as well. If you think anatomy labs can be sidestepped by using advanced computer simulations, you are mistaken. If you disagree, think about how comfortable you'd feel knowing your surgeon had only been trained with bodies on a computer screen.Physical space is limited. For lectures, sure, just shove more people into an auditorium and it'll work. Not so for clinical rotations where students join teams of physicians to learn the craft of patient care. I work in the largest medical center in the world, and hospital space is STILL tight; there are only so many students that can learn in a single hospital without their presence becoming a legitimate barrier to good healthcare. We have to share space with attendings, residents, nurses and their students, physical therapists and their students, respiratory therapists and their students, pharmacists and their students, etc. Oh, and patients. And their families.Residency limitations. Even if you increased the number of spots per med school, that really doesn't fix the problem. You'd also have to increase the number of residency spots, where every freshly minted physician spends 3-8 years honing their skills. Guess what all those spots are funded by? Medicare. Ouch. Those are not fun legal waters, friend. Even so, residency positions have been growing, just not at an ideal rate.This has more to do with the funds available to Medicare than the AMA--Medicare money has effectively been growing smaller every year, making it very difficult to increase spots given that each spot requires, at minimum, a few hundred thousand dollars. I support the assertion that more doctors would be great--but where would the money come from? Also, I'd like to see more convincing proof that the AMA is to blame for this "cap" (...which has been growing?) than a citation-less argument in a Forbes article from an author whose main goal is pageviews.Building a new med school is no easy feat. It will need hospitals nearby. Not just that, those hospitals have to be willing to serve as teaching grounds for students/residents--an endeavor that will cost them. Building a brand new hospital sizeable enough to have all the specialties needed to teach med students adequately? That's at least a few hundred million green ones you'll need to scare up. Again, where would the money come from? More taxes? In our current political environment especially?Assuming we have these hospitals, there need to be physicians willing to teach med students. Given how much ove... (more)Loading...

column9: Source: http://thinkprogress.org/yglesia...Seems like there should be a market for some sort of competition with this level of stagnation, when compared to population growth.
column10: I agree with Dr. Anonymous and Jae Won Joh with almost everything they’ve explained in their answers (the answer is, as they’ve outlined, multifactorial).Some of it is logistics – limited by the number of medical schools, the number of spots in those medical schools, and the pre-determined number of residency positions available to train those graduates.But let me add my perspective as a current medical resident: on a personal level, the decision to go into medicine requires a large personal sacrifice. The training is long and costly – the hours long and brutal – the documentation and paperwork and fear of litigation are ever overshadowing the reward of excellent patient care and healing. You have to have enormous psychological and physical reserve to survive a tough residency.People look at me wide eyed with a combination of respect and disbelief when I tell them what I do, and how little I sleep. If you calculate my hourly wage (divide my salary by the number of hours I work) it is well below minimum wage. That’s for the next 5-7 years at least. I could make more money doing literally anything else. And I graduated at the top of my class from college and medical school. You get the picture.But at the end of the day, as hard as it is – what I get to do with my days is a gift. It’s a privilege that I even have the opportunity to do what I do. And, yes – I’m one of the crazy ones who actually believes I can change the system, and heal a few people along the way too.Our country needs more doctors – in particular, we need more generalists. That means we have to create both economic and lifestyle incentives for people to go into those fields. We also need more physician extenders (those Nurse Practitioners, and Physician Assistant) who can prevent basic, preventative health services to a wider population at a cheaper cost. These extenders can also share the increasing workload of hospital residents (as our hours are restricted more and more), making our lives easier during the day and helping us focus on learning the highly technical skills that set us apart as MDs.Doctors are expensive to train and pay, bottom line. We need to train more people to do it -- but we also need to be sure we're training people with the right motivations, expectations, and above all, a commitment to high quality care.  Embed QuoteVia  Mircea Goia.

column9: Source: http://thinkprogress.org/yglesia...Seems like there should be a market for some sort of competition with this level of stagnation, when compared to population growth.
column10: I posed this question to José Espada, the financial aid officer at the Indiana University School of Medicine, where I happen to work. Espada has 20 years' experience dealing in the financial aspects of medical student admissions and the resulting medical-resident matching process.In his view, the answer to the question is very basic: there are limited funds for training medical residents. It is important to know that, for the most part, training hospitals rely on federal dollars to fund their residency programs. In our state, residency programs are supported by Medicaid.To put it simply, as federal funds for graduate medical education (GME) shrink, so will the supply of physicians.Groups like the American Academy of Family Physians have been aware of the problem for some time:http://www.aafp.org/online/en/ho....Of course, physician groups are lobbying for change: http://medicalxpress.com/news/20...And the Affordable Care Act would reform how federal funds for GME are distributed: http://www.im.org/AcademicAffair...Is the GME funding problem being properly addressed by the feds? That sounds like another question for Quora.  Embed QuoteVia  Mircea Goia.

column9: Source: http://thinkprogress.org/yglesia...Seems like there should be a market for some sort of competition with this level of stagnation, when compared to population growth.
column10: To answer this question, one should consider the implied elements to it: first, that there are not enough doctors and, second, that there is a level of control over these numbers that can be maintained. To the former, there is unquestionably evidence that there are physician shortages.  To the latter, I do not think it's necessary to bring up monopolies, since there are too many forces in the system to result in monopolistic control. A more direct and more pragmatic answer arises by simply considering the cost/benefit seen by prospective doctors considering entering medicine.  The number of physicians is dictated by the balance between the attractiveness of being a practicing physician -- compensation, respect, autonomy -- and the forces working against this -- medical school timeline/costs, malpractice insurance costs, intrusion by healthcare reform, and uncertainty in the future of medicine. In order for us to train more physicians, we have to address both sides and to some degree this must be done simultaneously. If the government determined it was sufficient priority to add more physicians, it could seek to reduce the hurdles to becoming a physician (offering tax breaks, subsidies, etc., to med schools and students) and reduce the challenges to being a physician (e.g., regulate healthcare insurance and medical malpractice in favor of physicians).  But in an era of increased pressure/noise for government to be smaller, this centralized planning approach does not have many supporters.  Other sources of "control" in the number of trained physicians could be medical schools and healthcare systems, both of which have a vested interest in the number and quality of physicians. However, each of these operates independently, which limits their collective ability to raise the number of physicians. To the extent that these independently motivated entities concur on the lack of physicians, there will be movement to sway the cost/benefit in favor of more physicians.  Free market forces will otherwise determine what moves each entity makes in affecting the number of physicians.  Embed QuoteVia  Mircea Goia.

column9: Source: http://thinkprogress.org/yglesia...Seems like there should be a market for some sort of competition with this level of stagnation, when compared to population growth.
column10: The reason why it is so hard to become a doctor is because the AMA restricts the number of applicants and schools that can create doctors so wages can remain artificially high.Cross-post from Hacker News: http://news.ycombinator.com/item...This seems to be the case with most monopolistic markets, where the gatekeepers keep the supply low to artificially inflate the price and generate excess profits ( see Ivy League schools / Dentistry / Microsoft / Standard Oil / Glencore ).This is due to the fact that those who control the gate or have benefited from the gate ( high salaries / respect ), are highly incentivised to keep that gate firmly closed whilst the majority suffer with "smaller" costs like increased insurance premiums and aren't particularly motivated to change the status quo until the pain becomes too great to bear ( terrible healthcare system / massive gas prices / terrible software ).Once a threshold of pain suffered by the majority is reached, the system will tip and the status quo will change ( see pegged currencies - Black Wednesday / the fall of Microsoft to Apple ).The worst enemy of monopoly is itself.The system will eventually self correct - whether out of disgust and anger on the part of the majority ( Standard Oil ) or through reasoned discourse ( the former is much more likely ).And that is why we don't train more doctors, even though it is ludicrously obvious that we need more of them.Update:Perhaps some rebuttal on Lazlo B. Tamas's and Jae Won Job's wonderful answers is in order ( they do raise some good points - I have nothing against them ) :DLaszlo B. TamasMonopolistic Schools/ResidenciesUniversities as a cohort aren't monopolistic necessarily, they try to serve market demand just like any other "company".Indeed that doubling you speak of is the universities serving the market.The rise in the number of graduations is in correlation to the number of applications.The sharp stagnation the questioner refers to occurred after the number of applications leveled off ( gradual gradient ) after the mid 70s. However, the applications once again cycled up - Why did the universities not respond with a corresponding increase in supply (graduates)?It is because the limiting reagent is the number of residencies, not the schools. Jae Won Johconspiracy theories that abound regarding doctor pay and artificial limiting of spots seem a bit absurd. I don't believe it's a conspiracy or anything nefarious in any way shape or form.I do think it's just a simple case of mixed incentives - like investment bankers who take risk and get the upside without the downside ( you know how that goes ).Just look at the graph above from the same site you got your AMA info from. That's 20 years of American population and GDP growth without any increase in the number of graduates. Are you seriously stating that there are no artificial limitations that cap graduates below market demand? a whopping 77% of doctors say the AMA does NOT represent their viewsWhether or not they represent the "views" of doctors is not relevant. The question is this: Is there a market shortage?The graph above seems to indicated there is, along with the above market rates US doctors receive compared to other OECD countries....
