column9: Source: http://thinkprogress.org/yglesia...Seems like there should be a market for some sort of competition with this level of stagnation, when compared to population growth.
column10: There are a lot of complicated things going on as described in the other answers, but there's also a very simple incentive underlying it:Most of the people deciding how many new doctors to train are already doctors. If fewer new doctors are trained, existing doctors make more money. I'm not saying it's a conspiracy, or even a conscious decision. But it's still a strong economic incentive for most of the people involved in the decision, so it's not at all surprising the decision has gone this way.Even if you remove the economic part of it, there's also a matter of pride that works the same way. Imagine you're a doctor - you worked hard to get your job, you know how important your job is, you know lots of other people with this job that you think highly of, and you believe you do much better at the job than some random borderline med school candidate. Therefore you're conservative in who else you think should be allowed to be a doctor. This is a very reasonable point of view, not at all malicious and certainly not a conspiracy. But it leads to there being fewer doctors than the market would produce otherwise, so if we want more doctors we need to recognize it and account for it.  Embed Quote

column9: Source: http://thinkprogress.org/yglesia...Seems like there should be a market for some sort of competition with this level of stagnation, when compared to population growth.
column10: This is a good question. There's several reasons for it.One reason is that back in the 1970s and 1980s, it was predicted that there would be too many doctors in the US. This upset some doctors and the AMA, which feared income would go down. AAMC, which represents med schools, was put under pressure to shrink the class sizes nationwide. In 1994, the Journal of the American Medical Association predicted a surplus of 165,000 doctors by 2000. For years the official position was that an "oversupply exists or is immediately expected." The LCGME in the 1980s realized that there were 2 new doctors for every one that retired, and lobbied both schools and the government to reduce the number of seats. Existing schools shrank their class sizes, and the federal government cut the budget to control the number of residencies. When the population increased more than expected due to immigration and higher life expectancy, and more doctors started retiring at a younger age, they realized their mistake. AAMC has asked schools to increase enrollment by 15%, but this is harder to do now because of budget issues; every new student needs more professors, dorms, cadavers, financial aid, etc. Many alternatives are popping up to address the issue; more DO schools, Caribbean medical schools, more PAs and NPs etc.  Embed Quote

column9: Source: http://thinkprogress.org/yglesia...Seems like there should be a market for some sort of competition with this level of stagnation, when compared to population growth.
column10: I will try to answer the question regarding the Indian scenario.Here we have two main entities providing medical schools (called medical colleges in India) and training hospitals: Government colleges and private non-profit colleges.The private colleges are managed by few Trustees, most of which are corrupt politicians or top beaurocrats/businessmen associated with them. These private colleges recieve lots of subsidies on every infrastructure required to run these institutes. In return, they are regulated by the Government bodies to keep the fees low, so that the student  can afford to study there. However, the greedy Trustees take huge sums of money from the medical aspirants for admission to these colleges. For example, the capitation fees can range from 25 lakhs to 5 crore rupees (40,000$ to 8,00,000$) depending on the college and the degree offered. And these are under the table transactions which everyone is aware of, but is not on paper. Now, the amount of capitation fees (nee bribe) will depend on the forces of demand and supply in play. If the Government colleges and their student enrollment are increased, it would result in lower bribes to these private institutions, which are wholly owned by the politicians and their friends in the name of various trusts. So, the politicians have an incentive to NOT increase the number of seats in the Government colleges. Thus, Indian government spends a very miniscule part of its GDP on healthcare; lesser still in healthcare education. Infact, the actual number of Government residencies have gone down since the past decade, and the chances of them increasing substantially are very low, atleast in the near future.  Embed Quote

column10: In India there is a factory which makes doctors. I mean you give the capitation fee and get admission in any medical college. It has become a business nowadays. It is no more a noble profession and I feel very sorry about the whole scenario.  Embed Quote

column9: This is a follow-up question to Blood Donation: Why can't men who have had gay sex donate blood?.
column10: It's not ethical to lie in this circumstance because you destroy more than you create when you tell this lie.The lie you tell lessens the integrity of the blood screening system, and makes it more difficult for the standard to change to include donations from gay men.It also lessens your own integrity because you are committing a political act under the auspices of doing something selfless.Currently, only 37% of the US population is eligible to donate blood, and only 10% do so [1]. By lying to include yourself in the population of blood donors, you decreased the perceived need to expand the blood supply by reviewing outdated rules. You also help to overstate the percentage of the currently eligible population that is donating.What you create - one pint of blood for someone to receive - is unlikely to make the difference between life and death for an individual anyway. The average transfusion is 3 pints, and the chances of a blood shortage are very low. Plus, half the blood supply is separated and not given as whole blood anyway.A more appropriate way to deal with this discrimination is to work to rescind this outdated rule. Gays that openly flout this rule actually hurt the chances of it being changed.[1]: http://www.americasblood.org/go....  Embed Quote

column9: This is a follow-up question to Blood Donation: Why can't men who have had gay sex donate blood?.
column10: Note: Updated after a long discussion with my current boyfriend who is a bio researcher and said, "This is a public health issue.. not everything is about gay rights, sweetie" and some more research into the FDA policy. ----------------There are two main goals for our blood banks: make sure there is enough blood on hand for transfusions, and make sure that blood is as safe as possible. In the early 1980s there were cases where people received tainted blood transfusions and contracted HIV. HIV tests weren't as reliable, and the main group of HIV+ people were men who'd had sex with men (MSM). In order to safeguard the blood supply, the FDA decided to exclude all MSM from being allowed to donate blood. Last year the FDA reviewed this policy and found that allowing all MSM to donate blood would increase the likelihood of HIV being in the blood supply by 500%. The FDA decided that this was not a risk worth taking, and so continued the current policy. There are alternatives to this policy, for example only allowing people who have not had male-male sex within the past year (this ensures that HIV is more likely to be found by testing) which would increase the likelihood of HIV being in the blood supply by 60%. Any decision on the ethics of donating blood must be made with this in mind. It is entirely unethical to increase the likeliness of someone contracting HIV from being transfused your blood. You have said that you are sure that you're clean (HIV-). As long as you and your sex partners have been tested every 3 months, and haven't had new sex partners in that time (to re-start the 3-month window), then it can be said that you belong to a subgroup of MSM who has reduced their risk of HIV to that of the rest of the population. Since you are then not increasing the chance of someone contracting HIV from being transfused your blood, it is ethical for you to lie and give blood. Some personal examples... 1) Once I was old enough to donate blood I started donating blood every few months. Then in college I (gay) got a boyfriend, and he and I were no longer eligible to donate blood. When the blood drive came on campus, though, we went with our friends and donated blood together. By having a closed circle of people we'd had sex with (me and him) we knew that there was no likelihood of being HIV+, and so we felt it was entirely ethical to donate. The years have passed, the boyfriends have changed, and while I am still HIV- and am tested when it makes sense to, I no longer donate blood. I haven't convinced myself if it's ethical in my specific case (I feel I am not increasing anyone's likelihood of contracting HIV, but I am a member of a high risk class). 2) Also in college, a long time straight friend of mine joined us in bed. "You guys seem to enjoy this sex with men, that beer tasted good, sure I'll give it a try." Isn't college fun? The FDA question asks, "Have you had sex, even once, with another man since 1977?" Well yes he did, one time, 10 years ago. Nobody's risk of contracting HIV is increased from his actions, and so he finds it ethical to lie every time he donates blood, and will continue to do so for decades to come. ----------Further reading from the FDA, though it doesn't seem to have been updated with the stats from the last time the FDA deliberated on this in 2010: http://www.fda.gov/biologicsbloo...  Embed Quote

column9: This is a follow-up question to Blood Donation: Why can't men who have had gay sex donate blood?.
column10: I think unnecessary lying is unethical.Unless your blood is absolutely needed to save someone's life, it is not necessary for you to lie. You do not need to give blood. Hiding your sexual orientation does nothing to overturn the ban - so your action isn't even opposing the ban. Instead of giving blood, educate the population and protest against the ban.  Embed Quote

column9: This is a follow-up question to Blood Donation: Why can't men who have had gay sex donate blood?.
column10: Lots of interesting stuff here. Just wanted to add into the mix this article: http://www.slate.com/id/2257655/...which brings into question these policies based on the relative risks of allowing various populations to donate blood. The author notes that though MSMs are more likely to be HIV-infected than others, the majority of those who are infected know that they are carrying the disease. However, among black men, who were less likely to be infected than MSMs, but more likely than the general population, the majority of infected individuals did not know that they were infected. Assuming that a person who knew that he or she had HIV would not try to donate blood, this makes the relative risks from the MSM and the black populations comparable. If this is the case (and I admit, I have not checked the math), blood from a gay man (especially one who has been regularly tested) would fall within a range of risk that the FDA has implicitly deemed acceptable. I don't see anything unethical about that.  Embed Quote

column9: This is a follow-up question to Blood Donation: Why can't men who have had gay sex donate blood?.
column10: "Ethical" is one of those slippery words. Very seldom do people saying it mean the same thing that everyone hearing it reads. It's often used interchangeably with "moral" or "right/correct" and the confusion around meaning engenders a lot of debate.I really rather like the delineation here as it rings true: http://ww.scu.edu/ethics/practic...so I'm going to use it as a basis for my answer. What, then, is ethics? Ethics is two things. First, ethics refers to well-founded standards of right and wrong that prescribe what humans ought to do, usually in terms of rights, obligations, benefits to society, fairness, or specific virtues. Ethics, for example, refers to those standards that impose the reasonable obligations to refrain from rape, stealing, murder, assault, slander, and fraud. Ethical standards also include those that enjoin virtues of honesty, compassion, and loyalty. And, ethical standards include standards relating to rights, such as the right to life, the right to freedom from injury, and the right to privacy. Such standards are adequate standards of ethics because they are supported by consistent and well-founded reasons.Secondly, ethics refers to the study and development of one's ethical standards. As mentioned above, feelings, laws, and social norms can deviate from what is ethical. So it is necessary to constantly examine one's standards to ensure that they are reasonable and well-founded. Ethics also means, then, the continuous effort of studying our own moral beliefs and our moral conduct, and striving to ensure that we, and the institutions we help to shape, live up to standards that are reasonable and solidly-based. There are those who will zero in on the word "honesty" in that first paragraph and if that is the sole determinant? Then lying is unethical.But the reason I like this definition is that it focuses on the bigger picture as well as the smaller elements. There are societal standards *and* personal standards.  The article suggests (and I concur) that at times, a society's standards can be unethical or become corrupted.  In such a case, one's own moral code of conduct trumps that of the standards set by the society.In this case, it sounds as if you have decided that the good of donating blood and the lives that may save outweighs the out-moded standard of denying someone the opportunity to donate blood simply by virtue of their sexual-orientation. If I believe (as I do) that the standard is wrong, then yes - I believe that someone lying about their sexual partners in that instance is ethical.So yes, by that rationale it is ethical. Honest? No. Ethical, yes.  Embed Quote

column9: This is a follow-up question to Blood Donation: Why can't men who have had gay sex donate blood?.
column10: I'm not going to address the question of whether lying is ever ethical, but I do think the current regulations are arbitrary, no longer do anything significant to prevent HIV and other testable pathogens, and on the other hand are unlikely to change in the foreseeable future as it's a government mandate subject to national politics, so that the argument that one should concentrate on getting them changed does not make sense. (I don't think donating as a political statement makes sense either.)Nucleic acid testing (a term encompassing both DNA and RNA) with PCR amplification can detect even a single instance of viral genetic material in a whole sample. Some of the sources cited above are from before the nucleic acid testing era. The only problematic one is Anon User quoting a 2010 FDA review as saying 500% but not giving details for interpretation or the source. That user does link a 2006 FDA conference, and skimming the PDF of that so far seems to support the contention that risk is insignificant.  Embed Quote

column9: This is a follow-up question to Blood Donation: Why can't men who have had gay sex donate blood?.
column10: A gay person without STIs who lies about being gay, actually reinforces negative stereotypes of gay people having AIDS and other STIs, as that's one less clean gay person for a charity to deal with. You would be the perfect example to prove the stereotype wrong.You're only one person, but you alone could overturn prejudice that could install more prejudice in others, if left untouched.Don't lie. It's not worth it.  Embed Quote

column9: This is a follow-up question to Blood Donation: Why can't men who have had gay sex donate blood?.
column10: I've donated blood at least 50 times over 30 years. There is a long questionnaire, and some of the questions seem to be pointless. There are plenty of opportunities to lie. But I don't. Nobody should. The blood banks set up the screening to protect both the donors and the recipients. The ban on MSM donors might be outdated, but it's the job of the FDA to review the science and make that decision. The system errs on the side of caution, and I think that's wise, because of the potential consequences to the recipients.If you have problems with the ban, there are much more prudent things to do. The blood bank I used had an out for people who felt peer pressure to donate, but knew they shouldn't: mark a checkbox and your donated blood would not be used. Very discreet.If you are donating because you want to help make sure there is adequate blood for people who need it, you can encourage others to donate. I have run office blood drives, and got many people to donate for the first time.If you think the ban is wrong-headed, find a way to pressure the FDA. I'm sure there are groups already doing that.In any case, please, nobody should lie on those forms, about any of those questions. To answer your question directly, yes, it is unethical. Even if you think you should be an exception to the rule. You don't know all the research and reasoning that went on behind the scenes to decide which questions to include. (And it's ongoing: the list of questions changes over time.) The integrity of the blood supply is too important--the people who need the blood are already taking enough risks.  Embed Quote

column9: This is a follow-up question to Blood Donation: Why can't men who have had gay sex donate blood?.
column10: Unethical to lie in any situation, especially one involving the transfer of blood from one person to another.  Embed Quote

column9: This is a follow-up question to Blood Donation: Why can't men who have had gay sex donate blood?.
column10: No.  Embed Quote

column9: This is a follow-up question to Blood Donation: Why can't men who have had gay sex donate blood?.
column10: No.  Not ethical.  Just don't donate.  If an emergency happens, then the Red Cross can come begging hat-in-hand.  Until then, they can just work with what they've got.  Embed Quote

column9: This is a follow-up question to Blood Donation: Why can't men who have had gay sex donate blood?.
column10: It is unethical to lie to the Red Cross about something that could potentially endanger someone's life, regardless of your sexual orientation or how clean you think you might be. Some STIs have long incubation periods during which they will not show up on a test.  Embed Quote

column9: This is a follow-up question to Blood Donation: Why can't men who have had gay sex donate blood?.
column10: Things I find that lead to unethical outcomes:Reciprocity (Golden or Silver Rule)ConsequentialismAppeal to Imagined Authority (aka The Bible, Quran, Book of Bob)WINNING (A shiny new version of Thelema)Kind of depressing isn't it? (since these are pretty much the kinds of ethical systems we have to work with)Reciprocity is, in my opinion, only sufficient as a first approximation.  You should definitely subject yourself to any judgement that you would impose on another.Would you give your loved one, your child, or yourself blood from a gay person?Yes, I would.  You clearly would.  What about other people?  I think we can unequivocally say that there are people who would, sadly, not make this choice.And however ignorant, irrationally fearful, bigoted, and/or small-minded that choice might be; we have to consider if we would want others to take away a similar choice from ourselves (under different circumstances obviously).Sometimes I think this is the right answer (for example, with the abolition of slavery).What are the consequences of this action?  I think some others have made a pretty good argument that the blood supply is relatively ok without your donation and, it's possible, by tricking the system you are harming the greater cause.Fair enough, I think, but it's not certain.On what Authority do you undertake this action?  Personal vendetta?  They are wrong and I'll show them?   I think my reservation here would be that you are proposing a form of secret 'Civil disobedience'.  But I think that Civil disobedience really needs to be an open, collective act with an expectation of consequences for it to be effective or legitimate (or risk vigilantism).Counterpoint, the underground railroad.WINNING, or Do As Thou Wilt, or perhaps these are opposites?Is there a better resolution possible, more in line with your True Will (whatever that might mean to you) - or is this a more base desire, shorter-sighted?There is one final consideration I would give, one that seems more reliable than the others, and that is Informed Cooperation (if not consent).  When we impose our will on others, we owe them, at the very least, their say in the matter.  We might choose to ignore it in the end, but they should have it and they should be aware of it.I would propose that an action is not ethical when it is imposed on an independent being without at least knowing their will (and having a reasoned and well-evidenced justification for ignoring it if need be).[if someone is incapacitated or incapable of expression then they are not fully independent, where their will is reasonably inferable action may be justified; this applies to infants and children to the degree they are capable]On this point I think we fail because those subjected to your choice would not be informed of it so you lack either consent or an informed subject.So I would say this is probably not a highly ethical action.  Sorry.However, I do fully support overturning the ban - I would rather see a risk assessment methodology that more accurately reflects the risk and mitigation factors fairly for all blood units and I do not believe it does today.  Embed Quote

column9: This is a follow-up question to Blood Donation: Why can't men who have had gay sex donate blood?.
column10: No, lying is not ethical whether you are gay or straight. If you do not like the policy then do not donate blood through that organization. This is not a gay rights issue and not an avenue for activism.  Embed Quote

column9: http://mv-voice.com/news/show_st...My wife and I were looking at an apartment in the area and it's not clear from the article whether air filters are really a solution.
column10: First, I'm not an expert (medical, legal, environmental, etc.) on TCE, the following is not legal or medical advice, and I offer no guarantee that any part of my answer is correct.I am, however, someone who has lived just outside the MEW Superfund plume area for many years, and has followed this issue on an informal basis for a while.As I understand it, the problem is that TCE in groundwater migrates through the soil and into the air. If there is a structure built on the surface, then the TCE will accumulate in the air inside the structure. This problem is especially acute for homes, since people spend so much of their lives in their homes, but it can be a problem for workplaces as well.Interestingly, TCE in the air outside of structures is apparently not a problem (TCE is detectable, but at the same level elsewhere in the Bay Area). It sounds like Google and Symantec are circulating outdoor air into their buildings in order to mitigate TCE buildup. But note that this "ventilation" is not the same as "air filtration". I've never heard that filtering air is an effective way of removing TCE.For homes, the only recommended solution I've ever heard is a "vapor barrier": a TCE-impermiable barrier between the soil and the house. Obviously, that's very difficult to install under an existing building. I think only buildings built in the late-90s or later will have them, and that's only a very few buildings in the area (and basically none of the apartment buildings).I personally would not live in a home inside the MEW plume area, though I'm perfectly comfortable living a couple hundred yards outside it, and walking/driving through the plume area on a regular basis.  Embed Quote

column9: What was your concentration? How did you know you wanted to go into Public Health? How did you finance it? What was your prior education & work experience?What is your personal story leading up to, during, and after the MPH?
column10: I did my Masters in International Health which was public health with a focus on developing countries. I also did this in Australia, so I'm not sure how helpful my answer is going to be but I'll give it a shot for the A2A. I realised I wanted to do International Public Health after a brief stint volunteering in a community based cataract screening and surgery project in Orissa, India. I had previously completed a Bachelor Degree in Human Biology and was in a soul destroying job in a pharmaceutical company, the sole purpose of which was to fund my then expensive taste in clothing (I'm writing this in an man's second hand shirt) and weird obsession with fake nails (ew, gross I know) - things have changed. I went to India not because I had any particular interest in India (now I love it and a little piece of my soul will always reside there) but because I had a crappy day at work and a volunteer thing popped up on my screen and my 21st birthday was coming up and my parents said that I could go on a trip instead of having a party if I wanted. And I applied. I was blown away. First by just how awesome India was, my little slice of Orissa was like a little slice of heaven. But then about the health issues people were facing. What I took issue with though was not the clinical aspect. I wasn't say, super interested in being able to treat a specific child for a specific problem. As a cultural outsider who did not speak the language I really didn't see that as my role. But I was interested in issues of access and equity and resource distribution and epidemiology and initiatves that changed the health of entire communities, of prevention. Rather than returning to the bowels of the pharma industry I thought it better to get the skills I was going to need in my new area of passion. But I also needed experience. So I studied my Masters of International Health at Curtin University (which is in Western Australia) by distance while I worked at the International Centre for Diarrhoeal Diseases Research, Bangladesh (ICDDR,B) on a child health project overseen by the WHO. The Australian government pays for my education. They also paid me to work in Bangladesh for that year. Sweet deal huh? The organisation helped me to conduct my Masters dissertation research which was on the care-seeking behaviours of mothers in the first three days after their baby was born in an area where we were running a Village Health Worker project. I loved it. I worked for that organisation for another year, then moved to South Sudan where I worked on am HIV and Gender Based Violence Project for returning refugees. My Masters helped me get my foot in those doors but a key component was contacts. You really would struggle to get anywhere in development work without contacts and I had been getting progressively better at putting myself out there to make them (self-promotion is an uncomfortable thing for an Australian).l then decided that aside from the skills I got from the Masters I needed other skills. I felt strange telling people how things should be done without any knowledge of how one would do them on the ground. I decided to get my training in nursing and midwifery because of that (I did not have the time nor the patience for a med degree!). And as I suspected, reading an article on how to stop post-partum haemorrhage is significantly different from actually trying to stop someone from haemorrhaging.  The break to do this study wasn't all advantages though. I am only now re-enetering public health development work and am doing it at an entry level (HIV and Tuberculosis Public Health Officer in Botswana).  My only tip with a Masters degree is that it isn't about the degree. Reading a bunch of papers to write your own paper should not be the point and will get you no-where. You have to make connections. Which means you have to network. Which means that you attend every event/lecture/afternoon tea that has even the remotest connection to the field you are interested in. And then you go an ask people a whole bunch of questions and see if they need an RA. And you seek out volunteer work and internships. Make the degree work for you.  P.S. If you haven't already its time to develop an intellectual crush on Hans Rosling and Paul Farmer. Enjoy!  Embed QuoteVia  Ming Law.

column9: What was your concentration? How did you know you wanted to go into Public Health? How did you finance it? What was your prior education & work experience?What is your personal story leading up to, during, and after the MPH?
column10: I earned my MPH in 2001 from UC Berkeley. My background was as a biology undergraduate who had spent 3 years doing bench science molecular biology research. As much as this was a wonderful experience (at UCSF and University of Washington), I was interested in population level determinants of disease so pursued an MPH. An MPH by definition is quite broad in its requirements and emphasis, and it is incumbent on the individual to pursue their own nitch. That having been said, I think it is important not to delay pursuing an MPH because you are not sure of you own specific interest. I went in to an MPH with an interest in infectious diseases, and within the first year found a new focus in social determinants of health. My main point here is to not close yourself off to possible interests that you may not know about prior to enrollment - exposure to a variety of areas of practice and research is fundamental to most MPH programs.An advantage of doing an MPH is the flexibility to purse either an applied or research career based on the degree. In addition to switching from an interest in infectious disease to social determinants of health, I also switched from wanting an applied career in public health to being interested in research. If interested in research, of course, it is essential to pursue a doctorate following the MPH. The good news about PhDs in public health is there is much better funding and you generally don't have to take many loans.My concentration was Epidemiology/Biostatistics, which was great. It was essentially a focus on a methodological toolkit that could be applied to various problems. I generally am of the view that subject specific content can more easily be pursued on ones own, and the more technical content of epidemiology and biostatistics is more easily aquired in the formal academic setting (although of course this can be learned through self-study as well if you have the inclination). I wasn't that enthralled by calculus in undergrad, but applied statistics is a whole other thing - I became totally enthralled.The MPH is a big money maker for schools of public health, so there are few opportunities for funding. The best bet is to get a position as a research assistant that will pay for living expenses and depending on the institution, some coverage of tuition. I'm now an Assistant Professor and hire research assistants for 10-20 hour a week positions that pay about $15/hour but also cover a portion of tuition. You will put yourself in the best position for these positions if you have some programming experience in R or SAS or Stata, but there are a variety of positions that are available. Look for postings for positions at Schools of Public Health that you are interested in applying to, or contact Professors doing research in areas that you are interested in. In addition to helping to fund an MPH, working with a research group is invaluable in learning how Public Health research is done. For me, earning an MPH allowed me to have a switch in my career trajectory, and begin to acquire a statistical analytic toolkit, as well as understand theories of disease causation, which were invaluable to me being able to pursue work that was most aligned with my interests. The curriculum is somewhat of a remarkable balance of intellectual and practical application to improving health. If that suits you, you should pursue it. As I once overheard a physician say, if you really want to help people - don't become a physician - study public health.After getting my MPH, I ended up going on to get my doctorate in public health at Harvard, and am now an Assistant Professor at Stanford. So this is a fairly traditional very academic track. But my colleagues in my MPH program have done a number of diverse pursuits, and in almost all cases have found very fulfilling work, ranging from working at Indian Health Services, to medical school to research assistants to environmental advocates.  Embed QuoteVia  Ming Law.

column9: What was your concentration? How did you know you wanted to go into Public Health? How did you finance it? What was your prior education & work experience?What is your personal story leading up to, during, and after the MPH?
column10: I decided to get an MPH while I was serving in the Peace Corps as a community health volunteer in Peru. I had a bachelor of journalism with little (ok, no) background in science. But my skills in communication seemed to translate pretty well to health education, as I could quickly research topics I knew little about and then translate the information into something that was easy to understand. I spent two years working with community health workers and teen promoters on the prevention of HIV, diarrheal diseases, respiratory infections, dengue, malaria... I loved it. So when I was getting ready to go back to the States, I looked at the different MPH programs around the country. Many are more research-based, but given my background, I wanted more of a practical focus. In the end I applied and went to Tulane University in New Orleans for their health education and communication program. About halfway through my studies, I discovered I had a strong interest in epidemiology (in a nutshell: the study of how diseases appear and move through populations). My advisor encouraged me to explore other departments, and I ended up taking about as many courses related to epidemiology as I did in health education. I was fascinated and found I was most comfortable when I worked with the two concentrations in combination. My experience was enriched a lot by being in New Orleans. It's a wonderful but in some ways still-struggling city, where many of the public health concerns I learned about in the classroom were right there in my neighborhood. Instead of a research thesis, we were required to complete 300 hours of practicum. I did mine at the New Orleans Health Department and also volunteered at a safety-net clinic. Being a part of the health community there not only complemented my studies, but also helped confirm that I was in the right field. So that's the good stuff. The financing was the hard part. My program was expensive, with very few opportunities for scholarships or grants. I and most of my friends financed our education with student loans. For me it was worth it. Even after graduating, I'm still fascinated by current  research and bore (or sometimes horrify) my husband and friends with health-related trivia. Studying public health made me healthier. More in tune with what's going on in our world and more knowledgable about how policy and environments can affect how healthy we are. But that's me. I'd be interested to see how my experience differed from others here on Quora.  Embed QuoteVia  Ming Law.

column9: What was your concentration? How did you know you wanted to go into Public Health? How did you finance it? What was your prior education & work experience?What is your personal story leading up to, during, and after the MPH?
column10: I received my MPH in 2006 with a concentration in environmental public health. I was teaching environmental science in high school at the time and my thought was that the degree would improve my teaching but would also give me additional opportunities outside of teaching and would give me the skill set I need to have a positive impact on the environment.I found that the degree on its own didn't have a lot of teeth; I read a lot of books and wrote a lot of papers but I didn't come out of the program with any tangible skill set. If I had focused on biostats it would have been a different story but the environmental concentration gave me the opportunity to do environmental compliance work.It turned out I hated that work; it's basically writing reports showing that your company isn't doing anything wrong. It's a lot of "I" dotting and "T" crossing.  Most of the jobs that I have seen for environmental related work tend to veer towards government/industrial environmental compliance - other environmental jobs seem to require a background in environmental engineering or industrial ecology.If I had complimented my MPH with another degree, like a masters in environmental engineering or law then maybe I could have had greater opportunities within the environmental field - I am currently looking into a data analytical program to compliment my knowledge with learning to use large data sets for urban sustainability.My caution for anyone interested in an MPH is simple; on its own it probably won't expand you into a ton of opportunities - use it to improve your quantitative skills or complement it with another degree to really stand out.  Embed Quote

column9: What was your concentration? How did you know you wanted to go into Public Health? How did you finance it? What was your prior education & work experience?What is your personal story leading up to, during, and after the MPH?
column10: It is important to know which field of Public Health interests you since there can be many concentrations in it like, Global Health, public policy, health policy, epidemiology, biostatistics, maternal and child health, etc. It is also important to know that for some concentrations in public health,further  education is necessary for better paying jobs. Public health is an incredibly vast field but in order to get an MPH one should do a little bit of studying in what interests you in public health.  Embed Quote

The decision to stop use of lime juice in the drinking water brought on board merchant marine and navy ships in the U.K. (and maybe Europe) was a terrible policy decision. Why did they need lime juice?By adding lime juice to the drinking water, the condition of scurvy, due to Vitamin C deficiency, was almost entirely eradicated. Prior to this discovery, the ships' crews often became ill, suffered permanent impairment, and even died from scurvy. Lime juice changed all of this.Knowledge of Vitamin C was centuries in the future. This finding was based on observation, and correlation, not scientific causation as we know it now. Yet a 100% correlation was quite adequate: A bit of citrus juice daily ~~> no more scurvy.Progress reversedDue to an odd confluence of factors, about 100 years after the initial discovery of the relationship, policy makers decided that citrus fruits were detrimental to sailors' health, and caused scurvy! Somehow, the loss of life due to scurvy had not been documented, or maybe forgotten? Limes, lemons, all citrus fruit were disallowed in any form on ocean going vessels. Potatoes and meat were said to be effective for scurvy. Scurvy returned, quickly. Scurvy prevalence was worse the second time around, as there were far fewer foodstuffs containing any Vitamin C in ships' larders, compared to 150 years earlier! In the earlier days, citrus was often taken on as food store even without the knowledge of its benefit in preventing scurvy.I am fetching some citations for this, then will enter it as an answer.  Embed Quote

There are probably hundreds of these but the following came to my mind fairly easily:Ignoring Ignaz Semmelweis's discovery of antiseptics:Ignaz Philipp Semmelweis (July 1, 1818 – August 13, 1865) (born Ignác Fülöp Semmelweis) was a Hungarian physician of German extraction now known as an early pioneer of antiseptic procedures. Described as the "savior of mothers", Semmelweis discovered that the incidence of puerperal fever could be drastically cut by the use of hand disinfection in obstetrical clinics. Puerperal fever was common in mid-19th-century hospitals and often fatal, with mortality at 10%–35%. Semmelweis proposed the practice of washing with chlorinated lime solutions in 1847 while working in Vienna General Hospital's First Obstetrical Clinic, where doctors' wards had three times the mortality of midwives' wards. He published a book of his findings in Etiology, Concept and Prophylaxis of Childbed Fever.Despite various publications of results where hand-washing reduced mortality to below 1%, Semmelweis's observations conflicted with the established scientific and medical opinions of the time and his ideas were rejected by the medical community. Some doctors were offended at the suggestion that they should wash their hands and Semmelweis could offer no acceptable scientific explanation for his findings. Semmelweis's practice earned widespread acceptance only years after his death, when Louis Pasteur confirmed the germ theory and Joseph Lister, acting on the French microbiologist's research, practiced and operated, using hygienic methods, with great success. In 1865, Semmelweis was committed to an asylum, where he died at age 47 after being beaten by the guards, only 14 days after he was committed.Source: Ignaz SemmelweisAllowing thalidomide to go on sale without adequate testing:Thalidomide was released into the market in 1957 in West Germany under the label of Contergan. Primarily prescribed as a sedative or hypnotic, thalidomide also claimed to cure “anxiety, insomnia, gastritis, and tension". Afterwards it was used against nausea and to alleviate morning sickness in pregnant women. Thalidomide became an over the counter drug in Germany around 1960, and could be bought without a prescription. Shortly after the drug was sold, in Germany, between 5,000 and 7,000 infants were born with malformation of the limbs (phocomelia). Merely 40% of these children survived.The statistic was given that “50 percent of the mothers with deformed children had taken thalidomide during the first trimester of pregnancy.” Throughout Europe, Australia, and the United States, 10,000 cases were reported of infants with phocomelia; only 50% of the 10,000 survived. Those subjected to thalidomide while in the womb experienced limb deficiencies in a way that the long limbs either were not developed or presented themselves as stumps. Other effects included: deformed eyes, hearts, alimentary, and urinary tracts, and blindness and deafness.Source: Thalidomide  Embed Quote

Ronald Reagan's gutting of our mental health system: Almost ten years after Ronald Reagan left office as president, the legacy of his administration continues to be studied. What is almost indisputable is that the changes in public policy that were implemented during the 1980s were sweeping and marked a turning point in American domestic policy. Faced with increasing competition from overseas, American business found it necessary to alter the social contract. This would require a realignment of the political economy so as to weaken labor unions and the social safety net. In Reagan, the Right found a spokesman capable of aligning conservatives, centrists, and working class whites. With this coalition, Reagan was able to bring about a number of reactionary changes in public policy (Alford, 1988).-- http://www.sociology.org/content...Unlike his "trickle down" economic policies, this change actually did what it was intended to do as outlined above. It shifted the burden of community health from a social compact to the individual, increasing needless suffering among the poor while enhancing personal and corporate gain among the wealthy.  Embed Quote

Fairly likely. Larry Brilliant discussed this issue during a 2006 TED talk. In the talk, he said that he had done a study with top epidemiologists. In that study, 90% of them said they thought there would be a pandemic within their children's or grandchildren's lifetimes, where: 1 billion people would get sick165 million would dieThere would be a global recession and depressionand there would be $1-3 trillion cost to the economyAnd it's easy to see why. There are a few facets of modern society that make a devastating pandemic not only possible, but likely. 1. We've dramatically increased our global population size. Simply put, there are just more of us now. More of us to get infected. More of us to spread the infection. Source: Human Conditions 2. We're moving to central locations. So not only are there more of us, but we're moving to places where we are in closer proximity, increasing our risk of spreading diseases to more people, at a faster rate. This is particularly true in slums, where sanitation services are lacking and many people occupy a small geographical space. While the percent of urban populations living in slums has gone down, it's still very high in parts of the world.Source: The Economist3. (The most important factor): We're traveling farther, faster and more often. It used to take days, weeks, months to circumnavigate the globe. Now it takes about a day. Very few diseases show symptoms in that short period of a time, so someone could be infected with a virus or bacteria, jump on a plane and infect someone else halfway across the world in a matter of days. Number of days required to travel the entire distance around the world Source: The Dutch Jules Verne SocietyThe internationalization of Starbucks and McDonaldsSource: Vancouvered Weblog Globalization allows us to share goods and diseases. Trends in international tourism Source: Introduction to TourismOnly until recently has international travel been feasible for large numbers of people. Traveling has made it easier for diseases to spread farther and more quickly, and it's become more difficult to contain them. To illustrate: Let's say someone is infected with a novel strain of the flu, one that is spread from human-to-human-to-human. It's not a strain included in the flu vaccine, and antivirals aren't very effective at treating it. The first case pops up in -- say -- a farmer in northern India. That farmer goes to sell goods in New Delhi and comes into contact with another young man. That young man (now infected but not yet showing symptoms) flies out two days later to visit family in England, and sits in the middle seat on a tightly-packed airplane. He's very chatty and talks the entire duration of the flight, sharing his respiratory droplets (and consequently the influenza virus) with his seat mates as well as the flight attendant. Upon arriving, the young man goes into the crowded streets of London to visit his family, while his new friends and the flight attendant continue on to their next flights to New York, Rio de Janeiro and Paris, bringing the virus with them ... Within three weeks, the virus is spreading exponentially on 5 different continents, and health officials are only beginning to notice. Image from Ready to Take Your Business Global?  You can see how quickly a disease can spread with a little help from modern aviation.  This all assumes a couple things, of course. First, we wouldn't have an effective method of treatment or prevention (i.e. a vaccine) right away. In some cases, standards that medical interventions are required to meet in most countries prior to distribution can be expedited in case of emergencies. But it still takes years (or months, if we're really, really lucky) to develop, test and approve a new vaccine or treatment. In that time, the disease can continue to spread.  ... (more)Loading... Fairly likely. Larry Brilliant discussed this issue during a 2006 TED talk. In the talk, he said that he had done a study with top epidemiologists. In that study, 90% of them said they thought there would be a pandemic within their children's or grandchildren's lifetimes, where: 1 billion people would get sick165 million would dieThere would be a global recession and depressionand there would be $1-3 trillion cost to the economyAnd it's easy to see why. There are a few facets of modern society that make a devastating pandemic not only possible, but likely. 1. We've dramatically increased our global population size. Simply put, there are just more of us now. More of us to get infected. More of us to spread the infection. Source: Human Conditions 2. We're moving to central locations. So not only are there more of us, but we're moving to places where we are in closer proximity, increasing our risk of spreading diseases to more people, at a faster rate. This is particularly true in slums, where sanitation services are lacking and many people occupy a small geographical space. While the percent of urban populations living in slums has gone down, it's still very high in parts of the world.Source: The Economist3. (The most important factor): We're traveling farther, faster and more often. It used to take days, weeks, months to circumnavigate the globe. Now it takes about a day. Very few diseases show symptoms in that short period of a time, so someone could be infected with a virus or bacteria, jump on a plane and infect someone else halfway across the world in a matter of days. Number of days required to travel the entire distance around the world Source: The Dutch Jules Verne SocietyThe internationalization of Starbucks and McDonaldsSource: Vancouvered Weblog Globalization allows us to share goods and diseases. Trends in international tourism Source: Introduction to TourismOnly until recently has international travel been feasible for large numbers of people. Traveling has made it easier for diseases to spread farther and more quickly, and it's become more difficult to contain them. To illustrate: Let's say someone is infected with a novel strain of the flu, one that is spread from human-to-human-to-human. It's not a strain included in the flu vaccine, and antivirals aren't very effective at treating it. The first case pops up in -- say -- a farmer in northern India. That farmer goes to sell goods in New Delhi and comes into contact with another young man. That young man (now infected but not yet showing symptoms) flies out two days later to visit family in England, and sits in the middle seat on a tightly-packed airplane. He's very chatty and talks the entire duration of the flight, sharing his respiratory droplets (and consequently the influenza virus) with his seat mates as well as the flight attendant. Upon arriving, the young man goes into the crowded streets of London to visit his family, while his new friends and the flight attendant continue on to their next flights to New York, Rio de Janeiro and Paris, bringing the virus with them ... Within three weeks, the virus is spreading exponentially on 5 different continents, and health officials are only beginning to notice. Image from Ready to Take Your Business Global?  You can see how quickly a disease can spread with a little help from modern aviation.  This all assumes a couple things, of course. First, we wouldn't have an effective method of treatment or prevention (i.e. a vaccine) right away. In some cases, standards that medical interventions are required to meet in most countries prior to distribution can be expedited in case of emergencies. But it still takes years (or months, if we're really, really lucky) to develop, test and approve a new vaccine or treatment. In that time, the disease can continue to spread.  Second, it assumes we aren't able to detect the epidemic in its early stages. Going back to our demonstrative anecdote, say we were able to detect the disease while it was still just in the area around New Delhi. Local health officials could alert clinics and hospitals to watch out for the disease and isolate those who were sick, and track down people who were potentially exposed and quarantine them to ensure that they aren't sick, but more importantly, won't continue to spread the disease. If an epidemic is caught in its infancy, public health officials can prevent the disease from spreading too far, too quickly, but it takes a good early detection system with international support to make that happen. We're definitely making improvements in this area. There are some programs out there working toward early detection for early response, such as Innovative Support To Emergencies Diseases and Disasters (INSTEDD) and HealthMap. But these programs are still young in their development.  Embed QuoteVia  Lisa Linnet.

A devastating global pandemic is very unlikely.BackgroundIt's worth starting out with an example of what a disease is up against (taken from my answer to Pandemics: If society started collapsing due to a global pandemic killing more than half of the world's population within a year or two, what would you do when you realized what was really happening?Edit). For that example, the SARS epidemic of 2003 compared to the Spanish Flu epidemic of 1918 is very instructive.SARS was more infectious and deadly than the Spanish Flu.  SARS occurred in a much, much more globally interconnected world with infected people getting on jets and landing on the other side of the globe hours later.  Spanish Flu occurred in a world without passenger planes.SARS killed fewer than 1000 people world-wide (916).  The Spanish Flu killed as many at 50 million people.The SARS epidemic killed 0.000013% of the global human population.  The Spanish Flu killed 3% of the global human population.The SARS epidemic lasted seven months from beginning to end.  The Spanish Flu lasted two years.The SARS epidemic killed an extraordinary number of health care workers compared to the general populace.  The Spanish Flu was much more weighted to the general populace.In short, a vastly more deadly disease was contained in a much shorter time with a tiny percentage of the casualties through the amazing workings of our world-wide public health system.  The average person had virtually no chance of getting it.Our public health system world-wide is exceptional and under-appreciated. For something to overwhelm it as you suggest would be off-the-charts unlikely, so unlikely that I would be looking at War of the Worlds explanations before I believed it to be true.[1]In the above example, the World Health Organization (WHO) took or was granted coordinative control of outbreak management by the vast majority of jurisdictions for world-wide information dissemination.Each country had a national body which engaged directly with WHO and local efforts.  (There was tremendous back-and-forth on this in Canada, as the vast majority of cases were in downtown Toronto, so it was quite reasonable for Ontario's public health organization to have direct responsibility.)In general, health jurisdictions within each country established their own outbreak management teams.  For example, in British Columbia, this fell to the BC Center for Disease Control.Public and Acute Health Practitioners -- highly trained, highly credentialed, front-line experts -- were of course in the forefront of the effort, identifying cases and establishing protocols.There were several tactics used in the fight against SARS:Quarantine - individuals who were exposed but were not yet sick were separated from people who weren't exposed, usually in medical facilities but often in their homes [2]Isolation - individuals who were already ill were separated from those not already ill in medical facilities [2]Interventions - These ranged across the spectrum from the individual to the global.  The largest was WHO world-wide travel advisories. [3]  These travel advisories took billions out of the world's economy, around $1 billion from Toronto and Ontario alone.  The smallest were treatments which had been proven successful in reducing the severity of the illness and preventing death.Sequencing of the Virus - Determining the genetic heritage and markers of the disease allowed more effective testing, separating those with SARS from those expressing symptoms similar to SARS but not caused by it. l4]What could get past this highly evolved system of protection?So what are the characteristics of a disease that could successfully bypass the extraordinary system of communicable disease prevention and wipe out half the population of the earth?Much more infectious than SARS - Measles is 5-6 times as infectious as SARS, which typically only saw three people infected by each infected person. [5]  A higher rate of infection would spread the disease much more widely much more quickly.Similar vectors but longer lasting than SARS - SARS was spread dominantly by airborne vectors through sneezing, but the virus also lingered on surfaces and there were many cases that occurred due to contact with a surface containing the virus. SARS can last for hours on surfaces and days in human waste. [7] If that were days and weeks, many more people would be infected by every surface that any SARS suffered sneezed upon, and likely a billion could have been infected by human waste in parts of the world with poor sanitation.Much longer incubation period than SARS with infectiousness - SARS had an incubation period of 10 days, meaning that less than two weeks after exposure a person would be exhibiting full-blown symptoms.[6]  A longer incubation period would allow infected people to transmit the disease much more broadly before being isolated. Notably, one group of SARS patients had a much longer incubation period.[6]Much less severe initial symptoms than SARS - SARS was very debilitating quickly, and typically patients died after weeks of illness. A slower onset of symptoms would allow the infected to avoid isolation for much longer and infect many more people.[6]Much higher eventual lethality than SARS - SARS had an overall fatality rate of 14-15% of those infected, skewing heavily to the very old, the very young and the previously ill. [6]  To kill 50% of the human population despite attempts to treat the illness, untreated lethality would have to approach 100%.Same starting point as SARS - SARS originated in China. A disease with the characteristics above could spread worldwide through manufactured goods [8]Greater resistance to heat and disinfectants than SARS - Common disinfectants and temperatures of only 56 degrees Celsius will degrade the SARS virus to the point where it cannot infect others.[9] Higher resistance to both heat and common disinfectants would prevent sterilization.A disease with the above characteristics would spread much more rapidly and include consumer goods and produce from China as a key vector of the spread of disease in addition to infected individuals. This would rapidly spread to other manufacturing centres.  It is possible that a disease with the above characteristics could cause a global pandemic that wipes out half the world's population, overcoming all of the extraordinary public health and communicable disease surveillance measures the world and countries have in place.  But it's still unlikely.References:[1] Mike Barnard's answer to Pandemics: If society started collapsing due to a global pandemic killing more than half of the world's population within a year or two, what would you do when you realized what was really happening?[2] http://www.marc.org/emergency/pd...[3] http://www.who.int/mediacentre/n...[4] http://news.nationalgeographic.c...[5] http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/news...[6] http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchi...[7] http://www.abc.net.au/news/2003-...[8] http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article...[9] http://enhs.umn.edu/current/5103...  Embed Quote
Chances are high and the political, economic, knowledge and technology systems for early detection, and early response are not in place right now.  Embed Quote

column9: While of course it would be difficult to prove causality, it seems like something of an obligation to let the restaurant know when you become sick after eating there (particularly if you suspect a particular dish).   Based on recent experience, it does not seem to be an area that restaurant staff -- even at otherwise well-run places -- are typically prepared to handle with a specific protocol.
column10: My old mentor, Francois, once (totally scientifically incorrect) made the joke that food borne illnesses are the original viral marketing for restaurants - nothing gets a restaurant into the news faster than a few diners keeling over from a bug.Let's play a typical phonecall about a food borne illness, hit the buzzer a few times, analyze, and then move to a wider analysis of this topic.Ring Ring"Allo, this is Pom Patapom's Pancake Place, how can I make you full?""This is Parry Hotter, I ate at your place last night and now I am so sick I can barely walk""I am very sorry, Sir"bzzzzztAs much as you'd want to hear this line, you won't. Why? Because the history books are full of great restaurants who didn't get diners sick but were "very sorry", a statement that can and will be used against the restaurant in a court of law. Anything that can even remotely be construed as an admission of feeling guilty can cost potentially millions. Most lawyers smile when I say that, some claim they could get me off that rap, and the father of all food borne illness lawsuits, William Marler (Food Poisoning Lawyers and Attorneys) gets a little dribble of saliva whenever he hears it - it's a "won case" to quote him.So let's rewind..."This is Parry Hotter, I ate at your place last night and now I am so sick I can barely walk""We are not aware of any other cases at this point, Mr. Hotter, were there other members of your party who also are now suffering from symptoms that could be food related?""No"InterludeBy now, let's hope he used his credit card, we know which table and what was served. We can see what overlapped and what didn't. That's what cover reports and reservation computers are for."I see here your party had the cod, the steak, and two pork chops. Which meal did you have, Mr. Hotter?""I had the Cod. Listen, I don't want to do this, I am sick and I have to hit the head soon, I just want to...""Mr. Hotter, we'll do anything in our power to find if there is anything wrong with our food. We have no had any other complaints and if we could just take a second and narrow this down, I'd be forever in your debt."Interlude and MoreIf no one else got sick we're more or less done here. From now on out it's just making the diner feel good. We need to take his phone number, address, and name, because if another call comes in then we do have a problem, need to contact Mr. Hotter again, and make him whole.The respondent now calls the chef. If that's me, I'll drive in, secure all ingredients with potential contamination, and wait if there are more reports. If that's the case I'll contact the CDC, which I am obligated to do by law, the purveyor, and will call all affected diners to reimburse them, offer them assistance and a meal on the house if they feel like coming back.From here my effective and responsible reaction is to work hard to contain, inform, and cooperate. The CDC and the state health dept. work with me to make sure MY kitchen is clean, the former is not a law enforcement or regulatory agency so they're taking notes and advise, the State Health people are the ones with the law in their hands.My contact to the diner ends at this point. I have to be careful if there is no actual illness and I am prohibited from contacting them if there is until an official investigation is underway. Talking to diners could be construed as witness tampering if there's a state's case against me or my purveyors.All in all we're in a bind here. We get accused and sued for food borne issues quite a bit, extremely rarely with merit. So we have to be careful what we say and how we say it. If there is merit we're even less likely to be able to contact the diner. We try to be as forthcoming and supportive as possible, however, wherever that is not a bad idea.  Embed Quote

column9: While of course it would be difficult to prove causality, it seems like something of an obligation to let the restaurant know when you become sick after eating there (particularly if you suspect a particular dish).   Based on recent experience, it does not seem to be an area that restaurant staff -- even at otherwise well-run places -- are typically prepared to handle with a specific protocol.
column10: The best way for the restaurant to handle it would be to take down the customers name and number and advice them to call the local health department. In all likelihood it isn't that restaurant that caused the illness as most people are feeling ill right after the meal. Although possible 8-24 hours is more likely. The Health Department will try and determine what other foods have been consumed in the past three days and if other complaints have been received. This approach does two things. Lets the customer know they are serious about food safety and secondly weeds out those just trying to get a free meal.   Embed Quote

column9: While of course it would be difficult to prove causality, it seems like something of an obligation to let the restaurant know when you become sick after eating there (particularly if you suspect a particular dish).   Based on recent experience, it does not seem to be an area that restaurant staff -- even at otherwise well-run places -- are typically prepared to handle with a specific protocol.
column10: Simple. Tell the truth, tell the complete truth, tell it early, say you're fixing the problem, and let the news cycle move onto the next thing.This rule works well in most PR cases. Any amount of spin, diversion, and dishonesty will be discovered in the Internet Age. My go-to example: If Bill Clinton had admitted his affair on Day One, he would never have been impeached.  Embed Quote

column9: Portugal has decriminalized all drugs for the last 10 years.  Before that, their drug problem had been spiraling out of control.  They decided to treat drug addiction as a public health matter, not as a criminal matter.  And apparently it is working in most cases. Would this work in the US?
column10: Decriminalization - or better yet, full legalization - would "work" everywhere, so long as we are clear about what we mean by "work."Legalization will not eliminate all problems related to drug use.  And legalization may lead to an increase in some kinds of use.But legalization will eliminate a large range of negative outcomes that result directly from prohibition, not from drug use per se.  Prohibition generates violence because in underground markets, participants resolve their disputes with guns rather than lawyers.  Prohibition generates corruption.  Prohibition harms drug users by raising prices, reducing quality control, and creating the risk of arrest and incarceration. Prohibition harms civil liberties and encourages racial profiling. Prohibition impedes the use of drugs as medicine.  Prohibition breeds violence, corruption, and insurrection in supplier countries.  Prohibition creates disrespect for the law.Thus legalization will work in the sense that it will eliminate all these negatives of prohibition, with the only possible cost being a modest increase in drug use.  And even that effect of legalization is a benefit, not a cost, to the extent that drug users can and do use drugs without causing harm to themselves or others.  Embed Quote

column9: Portugal has decriminalized all drugs for the last 10 years.  Before that, their drug problem had been spiraling out of control.  They decided to treat drug addiction as a public health matter, not as a criminal matter.  And apparently it is working in most cases. Would this work in the US?
column10: This way of phrasing the question is misleading. Decriminalizing drugs isn't something that works or doesn't work. Not having a law against something isn't a policy experiment, it's the default position. The proper way to ask this question is: how has drug prohibition worked?With over 100 years of data to look at, the answer is quite obviously: drug prohibition has been a complete disaster.Fighting the drug war at home and abroad costs vast sums of money. A huge percentage of our citizens are incarcerated because of drugs. The drug war has ravaged inner cities, warped our foreign policy, and helped prop up violent regimes all over the world.Meanwhile, it has been mostly ineffective in its only conceivable objective: eliminating the harmful effects of drug abuse. It's impossible to know just how many more people would be on drugs if they were legal, but we do know that despite our best and worst efforts, lots of people still use them, in many cases causing a great deal of harm.Drug prohibition, then, is an extremely expensive government program with vast and wide-ranging harmful side-effects that has largely failed to accomplish its objective. It doesn't make much sense to ask whether getting rid of that policy would 'work', but it would almost certainly make the world a better place.  Embed Quote

column9: Portugal has decriminalized all drugs for the last 10 years.  Before that, their drug problem had been spiraling out of control.  They decided to treat drug addiction as a public health matter, not as a criminal matter.  And apparently it is working in most cases. Would this work in the US?
column10: http://www.thecuttingedgenews.co... is a good summary of the progress of the 'war on drugs' while answering the question from an opposing direction the points are relevant.Would decriminilisation work? depends in how you define work really, would there be less harm to individuals and society and financial benefits combined with a reduction of stigma and easier access to treatment, then yes.However this does not address the moral argument which is why drugs are illegal in the first place, so those who believe non-state approved drugs are wrong and bad will not be happy, given the USA is a country where moral decisions often outweigh the facts (for example evolution) there is space to argue decriminilisation might result in extremist groups taking the law into their own hands as they currently do with abortion.  Embed Quote

column9: Looks like a tick. Should I get it checked out?
column10: Marc is correct. This is a tick. Furthermore, it is a 'hard tick' of the family Ixodidae. Although I'd like a better image, based upon what I can discern from the tick's morphology, it appears most consistent with an adult deer tick (or close relative) of the genus Ixodes. It does not appear to have fed appreciably (if at all), and this conclusion is further bolstered by your statement that you picked it off in the shower. I invite you either to 1) send it to me or 2) capture a few better digital images and upload those securely to me for evaluation. I can advise you as to the kind of tick, the approximate duration of feeding, and the potential risk that the tick may present. I'd also need to know the geographic area where you encountered the tick. For more insight on this, visit my resources at IdentifyUS  Embed Quote

column9: Looks like a tick. Should I get it checked out?
column10: Yes, definitely a tick. Can't tell the species or even the family, but I don't think it's too dangerous (if it were, you probably would have gotten symptoms by now).Irrelevant sidenote, just a pet peeve: this isn't an insect. If it's got 8 legs, it's a chelicerate, i.e. a spider, scorpion, mite, tick, etc. Insects have 6 legs (except those that are legless). But I understand the ease of just calling all of them insects :P  Embed QuoteAnswered in twenty-seven minutes.

One takes a course in epidemiology (or a closely related area like statistics). Then one finds a position that involved (at least partly) epidemiology. I've ended up doing a little (psychiatric, mostly) epidemiology. I wouldn't recommend my route though (degree in psychology) and I would not describe myself as an epidemiologist. Most people I know who describe themselves as epidemiologists have taken a masters in epidemiology (or epi, as they call it.)  Embed Quote

For those who do not know, Epidemiology is the study (or the science of the study) of the patterns, causes, and effects of health and disease conditions in defined populations.  Basically, you're a detective, looking at diseases and what cause them.Epidemiology is so broad in its focus that many disparate science and medical professionals enter (or wander) into the field. Based on what I've read, you typically enter into epidemiology by a few different routes (or all of them together):Receive your Medical Doctorate and the pursue your residency as a public health expert (epidemiologist).  This would make you both a practicing physician and an epidemiologist.Receive a Graduate Degree (PhD or Masters) in something like Public Health, Epidemiology, Veterinary Sciences, Pharmacology and then (as I mentioned) transition into a the field from there.  See Also:Becoming an EpidemiologistU.S. Bureau of Labor StatisticsBecome an Epidemiologist: Education and Career Roadmap  Embed Quote

This probably depends on where you are located geographically. However, there is no one 'right' answer. In the US, there are a growing number of schools of public health which offer graduate programs in epidemiology (MPH, MSPH, PhD). A graduate degree in epidemiology is probably the 'best' way to become an epidemiologist who would be recognized as such. It used to be in the US that you could get a degree in some other field and then get experience and call yourself an epidemiologist, while this remains valid in many parts of the world where epid programs may not exist - this is no longer really the case in the US.  Embed Quote

column9: Some say that adding fluoride causes more problems than it fixes, what is the consensus?
column10: After researching this the last two weeks, I reached the conclusion that there is a correlation between fluoride and fewer cavities. But many of the studies proponents have used over the years are problematic in that they did not account for other possible factors like income, diet, hygiene, etc. The Newburgh study, which really launched the whole fluoridation movement, has been  discredited to a large degree by Paul Connet's (et al) recent publication, The Case Against Fluoride (http://www.amazon.com/Case-Again...). No clinical scientific studies have ever been done to reach beyond correlation to some level of proof.Further eroding any certainty about the "healthy goodness" of fluoride is the fact that most developed countries have rejected fluoridation of public water, and their dental health is none the worse for it -- in fact it is frequently better than the U.S.So the claim of efficacy is shaky. However, there are many sources of fluoride besides tap water, so it's pretty difficult for anybody studying a population to have a truly clean control group to compare to a fluoridated population.As to potential harm, there is a wealth of information linking fluoride to all kinds of ills (http://www.fluoridealert.org/f-s...). I don't think anybody disputes that extreme doses cause skeletal fluorosis. And there are many signals that this is not altogether benign in its effects on the human body; for example, the recent moves (January 2011) by federal agencies to reduce exposure by lowering the maximum concentrations in water supplies (FDA), and phasing out the use of sulfuryl fluoride as a pesticide--both out of concern of over-exposure to fluoride compounds.Finally, perhaps the most important question that's not asked here regards the morality of mass medicating the population without informed consent, and without a reasonable non-fluoridated option.I lay this all out in a recent post on my blog: http://lucidstreams.com/2011/02/...  Embed Quote

column9: Some say that adding fluoride causes more problems than it fixes, what is the consensus?
column10: There have been studies suggesting that it does. The topical effect of fluoride in water is minimal, and you are better off just getting it from toothpaste, etc.  Embed Quote

column9: Some say that adding fluoride causes more problems than it fixes, what is the consensus?
column10: There are no double blinded, properly conducted studies to substantiate the claim that adding fluoride to water helps prevent cavities.The four paragraph excerpt below is from the article "Fluoride Follies" by Donald W. Miller, Jr., MD http://www.lewrockwell.com/mille...On its 60th anniversary proponents still have not proved that the hypothesis fluoride [put in public water] prevents cavities and is perfectly safe is true. The first part of the hypothesis, at least, has biological plausibility. Fluoride prevents cavities by combining with calcium in dental enamel to form fluoroapetite, which increases the resistance of teeth to acid demineralization. And fluoride inactivates bacteria that damage teeth by interfering with their enzymes. But biological plausibility alone is not sufficient to prove efficacy. Epidemiological evidence is required to do that. A debate open to well-informed opponents of fluoridation, if the CDC and ADA ever agreed to hold one, would show that existing epidemiological evidence does not prove that fluoride prevents cavities.In evidence-based medicine, systematic reviews (meta-analyses) are considered to be the best, most "scientific" evidence. A systematic review of water fluoridation studies, published in the British Medical Journal in 2000, found, as the chair of the Advisory Group that commissioned the review puts it, "The review did not show water fluoridation to be safe. The quality of the research was too poor to establish with confidence whether or not there are potentially important adverse effects in addition to the high levels of [dental] fluorosis." He adds, "The review team was surprised that in spite of the large number of studies carried out over several decades there is a dearth of reliable evidence with which to inform policy." The case for fluoride does not stand up to careful evidence-based scrutiny.Evidence that "fluoride [put in public water] does not prevent cavities and is not safe" (the null hypothesis) is more convincing. If a court of law held a trial on fluoride's safety and efficacy, the anti-fluoridationists would win. The judgment in their favor would most likely be beyond a reasonable doubt, or at least on a more likely than not basis. In a courtroom the pro-fluoridationists would not be permitted to employ ad hominem attacks that focus on the character of the opposing witness instead of the evidence, and dogmatic assertions on the safety and efficacy of fluoride would be subject to cross examination.Proponents of fluoridation will not willingly admit they are wrong. As Tolstoy puts it, "Most men can seldom accept even the simplest and most obvious truth if it would oblige them to admit the falsity of conclusions which they have delighted in explaining to colleagues, have proudly taught to others, and have woven thread by thread into the fabric of their lives."See also http://www.fluoridealert.org/lim... byDr. Hardy Limeback, BSc, PhD, DDSAssociate Professor and Head, Preventive Dentistry University of Toronto  Embed Quote
