Short answer : 0.6 - 2 €/m3 depending on the technology used and the source of energy.Desalination is a very energy intensive process, so the biggest proportion of water costs come from energy. Thus a cheap source of constant supply of energy is needed. It is common to have a power plant nearby, to supply cheap steam or electricity and to take advantage of the cogeneration concept. Nuclear energy is also a good supplier of energy of such plants.The most economic desalination plants operate now with electric driven processses and more specifically reverse osmosis. The most important developments that made possible a relatively cheap production of water were in the following areas:energy recovery techniques, mainly from the brine using pressure exchangers. better materials in the membranesNowadays there are plants that produce 800,000 m3/day of potable water quality at that cost.  Embed Quote

For drinking water and home use it is recommended to keep levels under .5 ppm (parts per million).  Levels higher than .5 ppm cause staining and other undesirable effects.  If you have a high iron content you will probably need several stages of filtration to solve the problem.  A common system set up to handle between 2-8 ppm of both ferric and ferrous iron is as follows: First a sediment filter. (Preferably a 5 micron 20" cartridge filter)  Second an oxidation iron filter. (Preferably manganese green sand with aeration)  Third a water softener.  (Preferably a back washable cation resin using salt) Lastly a drinking water unit.  (Preferably a reverse osmosis unit) Many homes with under 2 ppm of iron do well with just a water softener.  Sometimes iron bacteria can be present in the water and that will cause staining as well.  Check the water closet in the back of toilets as this is a common place for bacteria to multiply.  Use iron out or rust out chemicals to get rid of staining.This is just a guide.  Always seek professional help with your water needs.  GL.  Embed Quote

The first step is to determine the form of iron.  As suggested, particulate iron (undissolved) will be removed by most cartridge filters - although smaller oxidized colloidal particles have been observed to pass through 0.45 um cartridges.  Insoluble iron would be expected in oxygen rich water sources.If iron is primarily soluble, as would be expected from reducing environments common to natural waters (particularly low-oxygen containing groundwaters), then an oxidation step before filtration is needed.  The two main ways of oxidizing iron is by aeration or chlorine, with chlorine being the most common choice.  The chlorine is injected before filtration (with some lag time) which oxidizes the soluble iron into a precipitate which can be removed with regular cartridge filters.  Embed Quote
There are quite a few home filter system that will remove iron from your drinking water. Take a look at these, to start: http://search.waterfilters.net/s...  Embed QuoteAnswered in fourteen minutes.

Find your local water treatment specialist. You can search "Water Treatment Companies". Most will come out and do a free water test, make recommendations and you will receive a free and professional education on iron removal!  Embed Quote

Anonymous gives a phenomenal answer that is a great reference for most people.  However, his $1000 price tag is pretty high for many people in some places of the world where rainwater is an invaluable source of water.  Steps 1-5 are essential and there is really no sense in trying to cut corners there (although you can leave the screens off the gutters if you are willing to be especially vigilant about cleaning them).However, when it comes to treating water, it is possible to find some more low-cost alternatives.  I wholeheartedly agree with James's caveats regarding chlorine (though I'm less concerned about trihalomethanes than unappetizing/nauseating water).  Some other options for good filtration include:1.  Ceramic filters.  These are a highly accessible technology in most communities where I've worked and often build nicely off of local potting knowledge.  Alternatively, in most medium sized towns, they sell candle filters that are easy to use and just need to be changed regularly.  In many cases, people mix very low doses of chlorine to ensure that the filter is working correctly.2.  Bio-sand filters.  These often require a specialist to build and install (the sieves to sort out the size of sand for the different layers are typically special orders, so people won't buy them unless they are building many bio-sand filters) and a training to ensure that they are used correctly.  However, in areas where they are available, they are a great way to produce reliably clean water.3.  SODIS.  Solar disinfection is one of the easiest and cheapest methods of water treatment, but it is also very easy to do it wrong and drink dirty water.  The idea is to put the water in transparent plastic containers (most places I've worked have a surplus of old plastic bottles from bottled water and soda, so these are freely available) and leave them in the sun for 24-72 hours (depending on local conditions).  The sun will provide a free source of UV radiation to treat the water, though the bottles may need to be regularly replaced so that the plastic won't degrade.If $1000 is a reasonable sum for you, then just follow James's answer in its entirety.  However, if you are looking for ultra low-cost water treatment systems, they do exist.  Embed Quote

Really excellent and informative answers above; thank you! The question could be from a camping/backpacking viewpoint too, so I included a link to a very informative site: Trailspace.com .  Great study on different purification techniques' efficacy for camping.:http://www.trailspace.com/articl...   Embed Quote

Any rainwater that's collected should be treated by:Boiling it for 10 minutes (actually bringing it to a boil is usually enough, but why take chances?)Adding small amounts of chlorine bleach to the water (The ratio is usually a teaspoon for a gallon; however you should also boil it)Adding hydrazine tablets to the water.Using a commercial filter to strain the water is also good idea (Again, to be safe boiling the water before drinking it or cooking with it is never a bad idea)Frankly, given the fact that rainwater can collect bacteria from whatever vessel that it is stored in, boiling it before using it to drink, cook or brush your teeth is always the best idea.  Embed Quote

Clean capture of rain. The best thing to do is to start with a clean collection process. What are you collecting off of. The ideal is to collect from a clean roof. Ideal there would be no trees taller than your roof so they won't be a lot of plant debris.If you are able to sweep your roof, do so. Have rainwater pass through a few sizes of wire mesh which are each to clean. Setting this up well with start you off with cleaner water. Remember, you might be one of those dumb guys out in the rain fixing the poor gutters and cleaning the screens! Always clean them after the first rains and before any big rains! Lantagne, Robert Quick, and Eric D. MintzAuthor Credibility & Qualification:Daniele S. Lantagne, Dr. Robert Quick, and Dr. Eric D. Mintz work for the Foodborne and Diarrheal Diseases Branch of the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Lantagne is an environmental engineer with more than 10 years of experience in water treatment. She has evaluated and implemented household water treat- ment options in more than 30 developing countries, first as a lecturer with the MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering and with her own consulting firm, and for the last three years with the CDC. Medical epidemiologists Dr. Quick and Dr. Mintz, who also work at the Center for Global Safe Water at Emory University, have been with the CDC for more than 15 years. Both were involved in the initial cholera epidemic investigations that led to the development of the Safe Water System, and have been evaluating and implementing the Safe Water System since 1995.I realize this is in the context of the developing world, so there may be better alternatives in the "developed" world. Plenty of Reverse Osmosis (RO) systems are available to handle rain water run off.  As long as you have a pump to boost line pressure to 60 psi you can pass water through a four stage system.  Stage one is a 5 micron sediment filter to handle sand and debris.  Stage two is a carbon block filter to remove organics (taste and odor).  Stage three is the membrane (usually TFC - Thin Film Composite) which is bacteria resistant.  And stage 4 is activated carbon filtration or use of a UV light.  The problem with RO systems is the rejection of water through the membrane.  Although they are rated to remove 99% of impurities, they reject 3 gallons of waste water for every clean gallon of water they make.  You could just recirculate the rejection water back into the collection barrels, but the impurities could build up there.  I would use the rejection for grey water purposes like watering the lawn or flushing toilets.  It is fairly cost effective around $250 - $400 for this type of system.  Some systems have built-in (purity) conductivity meters for peace of mind.  Be prepared for filter changes every 6 - 12 months and a membrane change every 1-2 (up to 5) years.  Embed Quote

Wastewater treatment in general has several steps, some intrinsically more expensive than others.1. Removing Debris2. Removing Suspended Organic Molecules3. Disinfection4. Removing other chemicals (optional, depends on region and regulations)Here is my best guess at a cheap option for each of the first 3 steps.1. Removing debris: usually done by a mesh screen. Afterwards settling tanks allow dense material (sludge) to settle and light material (scum) to rise and be skimmed off the top of the water. These can either be incinerated (cheap, polluting, can produce power), landfilled (kind of expensive), or used as feedstock for gasificiation (high capital costs, "clean" efficient power generation capabilities);2. Removing suspended organics: After the solids have been removed the WW goes to aeration basins where activated sludge breaks down suspended organic molecules. Areation is energy intensive.3. Disinfection is accomplished either through chlorination (medium-high maintenance, possibly dangerous) or UV (safe, high maintenance).4. Removing other chemicals such as ammonia tend to involve more areation basins, and can cost roughly equal to the original aeration.That being said, wastewater treatment is generally a pretty expensive, albeit important, enterprise. It requires a great amount of infrastructure, capital, and oganization. Depending on the actual implementation, costs for certain things (such as chlorination, landfilling, energy prices) can vary widely. At the same time there is a certain physically/technologically attainable minimum energy cost that is hard to get past.Brown and Caldwell newsletters are generally a good way of staying up-to-date on new technology and methods: http://www.bcwaternews.com/  Embed Quote

Engineered Ecosystems for Waste Management                    Organic wastes from human and animal habitations can accumulate in, and  endanger the environment. Engineered ecosystems research for waste  conversion has led to the development of Vermiculture Technology at Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay.  This process overcomes the problems associated with conventional  methods such as solid state composting, activated sludge, and extended  aeration in which bio-energy gets dissipated. It engages an ecology  consisting of soil, plants and soil micro and macro-organisms including  geophagous earthworms. The process obtains synergy between  photosynthesis and respiration, so that bio-energy of wastes is fully  utilized.http://www.visionearthcare.com/t...I don't know if this is cheapest but still giving you an alternative  Embed Quote

I believe you could circulate air inside an airtight suit like astronauts wear and then pass the air through a condenser to collect the moisture. column9: Is there any truth to the conspiracy theorists' rhetoric that it causes cancer or that its benefits were just a marketing campaign launched by the aluminum industry.
column10: I presume you are a mother, and you are concerned about the heatlth of your children, so here is what we know so far:I. Water fluoridation was first introduced in Grand Rapids, MI in 1945. Previous research by the National Institute of Health showed that mottled enamel is very resistive to carries, and that’s how they got the idea of adding fluoride to drinking water.It was the first city in the US (and the world) to have water fluoridation (You can read more here; The story of water fluoridation: http://www.nidcr.nih.gov/oralhea...).II. Water fluoridation reduces dental caries because fluoride has a cariostatic effect; by making the enamel more resistant to acids (locally, and systemically while teeth are being developed), and by interfering with the metabolism of the bacteria that release these acids.III. Three additives are used in the USA:Sodium fluorideSodium fluorosilicateFluorosilicic acidIV. Safety/cancer: It's been almost 66 years since fluoride was added to drinking water, and so far, there has been no substantial evidence that there is a link between water fluoridation and cancer. No study (as far as I know) showed any potential health risk for water fluoridation.Most of these studies were descriptive epidemiological studies, which can help in deciding whether there is a convincing association with cancer or not. Case controlled studies are required to find out if there is direct assoiciation.The Community Water Fluoridation has an excellent list of studies and books to read on this matter:United States Public Health Service Review of Fluoride: Benefits and Risks, 1991http://www.health.gov/environmen...There have been over 50 human epidemiology studies of the relationship between water fluoridation and cancer. Epidemiological studies of fluoride usually attempt to identify statistical associations between cancer rates and county- or city-wide patterns of water fluoridation. Expert panels which reviewed this international body of literature agree that there is no credible evidence of an association between either natural fluoride or adjusted fluoride in drinking water and human cancer (LARC, 1982; Knox, 1985). Interpretation of these studies is limited by the inability to measure individual fluoride exposures or to measure other individual predictors of cancer risk, such as smoking or occupational exposure.The NCI study identified no trends in cancer risk which could be attributed to the introduction of fluoride into drinking water. The study examined nationwide moronity data and incidence data from counties in Iowa and the Seattle, Washington, metropolitan area. There were no consistent differences in the trends in cancer mortality rates among males and females living in counties having initiated relative mortality rates from cancer, including cancer of the bones and joints, were similar after 20-35 years of fluoridation as they were in the years preceding fluoridation. In addition, there was no relationship between the introduction and duration of fluoridation and the patterns of cancer incidence rates, including those of the bone and joint, and the subset of osteosarcomas (Appendix E). For example, there were 91 observed cases of osteosarcoma in the fluoridated areas, when 93 cases were expected based on rates in non-fluoridated areas.Institute of Medicine Dietary Reference Guidelines, 1997 (very extensive information from page 288-313):http://www.nap.edu/openbook.php?...Australian GovernmentAustralia's National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) conducted a systematic review published in 2007, that considered recent evidence relating to the efficacy and safety of fluoride interventions, with an emphasis on widespread public health initiatives. The council found that:Community water fluoridation is beneficial for reducing dental caries (tooth decay).Water fluoridation at optimal levels does not affect the risk of bone fractures.There is no clear association between water fluoridation and overall cancer incidence or mortality.The reviewed studies do not suggest an increased risk of adverse health effects at optimal fluoridation levels.http://www.nhmrc.gov.au/guidelin...University of YorkA systematic review of public water fluoridation* was released in 2000 by the National Health Service (NHS) Centre for Reviews and Dissemination, University of York, United Kingdom. Based on the best available research they found that:Community water fluoridation reduces tooth decay.Fluoridation is still effective even with the use of many other sources of fluoride.There is no clear association between fluoridation and bone fractures or cancer.There appearsto be no difference between benefits from natural and artificial fluoridation.There is an association between the water fluoride concentration and the occurrence of dental fluorosis.No clear evidence of other potential negative health effects were found.http://www.york.ac.uk/inst/crd/f...My personal advice: if you have some worries about water fluoridation, then simply stop drinking it. Bottled water is usually fluoride free, and many water filtration systems help too. Besides, tap water usually has chlorine taste that I find very unpleasant. Nowadays, most toothpastes come with fluoride, and topical fluoride is very effective at reducing dental caries. If you follow a good dental hygiene program, then you don’t have to worry about having  dental caries because there is no fluoride in your drinking water. Don't forget that your food also contains fluoride.For further reading, I recommend the following:National Academy of Sciences on Fluoride in Drinking Waterhttp://www.cdc.gov/fluoridation/...CDC: Community Water Fluoridationhttp://www.cdc.gov/fluoridation/...  Embed QuoteThis answer is not a substitute for professional medical advic... column10: Deionized, distilled, or RO water is very pure and contains almost no dissolved solids, so you are right. Drinking  this water exclusively can cause health problems if you are not replacing the electrolytes sodium and potassium in your system that this pure water will be flushing out. But this happens over time with relatively large quantities of this water an exclusive basis... if you are observing a regular diet and consuming this for short periods, ie a diving excursion, it shouldn't be an issue that you need be concerned about. If you were running a marathon, and drinking RO water... different story. Here is a link that talks about it: http://www.livestrong.com/articl... In the meantime, have some snacks with sea-salt on them while you're on the boat and your deficiency problem is solved...  Embed Quote

It is really location dependent. In many instances economies of scale give the advantage to having centralized treatment, but this is only efficient if the treatment plant is physically lower than the surrounding city. In locations that are separated by hills or are lower than existing water treatment plants a decentralized solution is more cost effective.How will this change in the future? As stricter regulations are adopted, treating water will be increasingly expensive. The capital required to build these additional treatment processes may be too much for decentralized systems to handle efficiently, so it would be more cost effective to pump the water to the larger treatment plant. Because of this we would be likely to see more centralization. New technologies for water treatment are slow to be adopted because of the large costs and political risk involved, and are often only put into place when tightening regulations force the agency to change.EDIT: this is looking at it from the waste water side. From the water supplier side change 'lower' to 'higher' and vice versa.  Embed Quote

It seems like as the price of petrolem goes up, so will the transport of water and waste. Everything will be affected by that. Decentralized systems are likely provide a cost advantage over trusting the main water grid. So as we use more wells, and better yet, rain water, we will seek better decentralized options for treatment prior to drinking. If it becomes more difficult to pipe waste water elsewhere. The real upside is contaminating less water. By switching to composting toilets and altering a few behaviors we could use less than half the water which makes processing much easier. People will likely learn more about the different kinds of water water and how each can be a resource instead of a burden. By switching to non-toxic soaps, you can feed your garden kitchen water, and laundry and shower water too. Composting toilets use no water at all! But urine can be run from urinals to drop irrigation in gardens.  With a little creativity there is no "waste water".  Embed Quote

I agree with the other comments regarding economy of scale. However it is possible to treat waste water to a very high standard on a small scale. Problems arise where the maintainance, and skills required to maintain such things aren't available locally (within the household). Though if such things where to become more common, less people would expect anything that can be flushed, to just disappear. Realistically rainwater harvesting, and storage. As well as some grey water recycling,could vastly reduce the use of potable water, for such things as irrigation, and flushing WCs. Many householders should be able to maintain this sort of system. Failures might be inconvenient, but are less likely to be polluting.Edit:I had not thought of the fresh water side, that is more tricky. Short of collecting and boiling rainwater, this is more difficult. To extract, and treat water to potable standards, on a small scale, is possible. Here lack of maintainance, or failure could have serious health consequences. Not to mention the use of some possibly unfriendly (if used incorrectly) chemicals, some that could also be a bit bangy. This seems like a bit of a nightmare, unless you have a source of good clean water, that requires only filtration, and disinfection.  Embed Quote

It all comes down to cost-effectiveness. In most situations, it will be cheaper to build a large, centralized system. However, with better technology today, it is possibly to have more efficient small-scale systems. Smaller, decentralized systems also have cheaper build-outs. Because of this, they tend to work better in rural areas where people are more spread out. With that in mind, it would be less likely to build a decentralized water network in densely populated urban areas. I think that a decentralized network could have a smaller impact on the environment and, in some cases, a smaller cost. For these reasons, I see this as a highly intriguing question. I would like to see more research done on comparing large centralized networks with large decentralized networks. While centralized networks almost exclusively have to be managed centrally, a decentralized network could be managed by a single entity or by smaller, local management groups. It absolutely depends on the location, but I think that we will see more decentralized water management in the future.  Embed Quote

column9: If not, why not?
column10: There is the only one catch in reverse osmosis that does not allow those devices to be practical on less than industrial scale:This process requires that a high pressure be exerted on the high concentration side of the membrane, usually 2–17 bar (30–250 psi) for fresh and brackish water, and 40–82 bar (600–1200 psi) for seawater.To give you an idea, you already break a sweat pumping up bike tires — and that's just 60 psi. And for reverse osmosis, we are talking about 10-20 times that much.While it is possible to achieve pressure amplification through the use of mechanics (levers) or hydraulics (pipes with changing cross-section), those methods will lead to either impractical size of the device (by my estimate, briefcase-sized for mechanical approach), or the impractical water output (by my estimate, a couple drops of water per minute from a flashlight-size device for hydraulic approach).  Embed Quote

column9: If not, why not?
column10: Salt water is a solution, not an ordinary mixture. Basically, there are ions (electrically charged atoms) moving between molecules of water - it's all mixed at a molecular level. In case of huge molecules, like proteins, it is possible to mechanically separate them from water - but only because they are hundreds of times bigger (heavier) than water molecules.The filter described in the TED talk probably works by filtering out macroscopic - and microscopic, but not atomic-sized - contaminants floating in water; I actually use such a water filter at home (probably not so effective, though). It's a good example of a cheap technology that can be used right now to give people safe drinking water.But this technology does not make filtering salt water into drinking water possible - and it won't evolve into one that makes it possible, just because of physical constraints. A different approach is necessary... Distillation, or freeze distillation. Or some form of chromatography, maybe (but my knowledge is limited to the name in this case).EDIT:I want to correct this. There IS a technology that allows to "filter" salt water into drinking water, without evaporating (distilling) or freezing it - it works only by applying pressure. See "reverse osmosis" on Wikipedia (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rev...).I haven't heard about this technology before, and learning about it is kind of like seeing an airplane fly after being told that nothing heavier than air can do it... A real eye-opener.A portable device using this technology would still consume energy (but much less than in case of distillation), and be compilcated more than just a filter, but it seems sensible to make it.  Embed Quote

column10: Quick answer for now:promotes the formation ferric hydroxide floc.2Fe(2+) + Cl2 + 6H2O --> 2Fe(OH)3 (s) + 2 Cl- + 6 H+Notice Fe(2+) changes to Fe(3+).Soluble ferric bicarbonate also forms the Fe(OH)3 solid.  Embed QuoteAnswered in sixteen minutes.

The most obvious answer is cost. High-volume RO systems are expensive to install and the membranes themselves need constant maintenance and replacement after a decade or so. A tiny 1gal/min system to cost up US$10K and it only gets much more complex and expensive as you scale up. The process itself is very energy-intensive, almost 10 times the energy cost of non-membrane treatment (which is usually already provided by municipal treatment if the beverage company has a tap water hookup). Even with a well-water source, reverse osmosis is usually not competitive with alternatives like conventional filtration or disinfection.Additionally, the product beverage may call for water with a certain salt content that would have been lost during RO. Recall a certain brand of beer that says "It's the water!"? Permeate coming directly off the reverse osmosis process actually tastes terrible and is quite corrosive (to pipes...and stomach lining!) because ultrapure water is "hungry" for salts. Salt solution or the original feed water are usually added back after RO to make the permeate drinkable.  Embed Quote

I'm surprised to hear you feel that companies don't use reverse osmosis water in their products.  It has been part of the standard process for water we use in all Bosco syrups we manufacture.  We draw water from a well, which we then filter through a RO process.  To address Joshua Phalen's point, it is a slow process, and we address that by having large holding tanks to store processed water.  Water isn't the primary ingredient in our syrups, and perhaps it would be a different story for products like beverages that consist of mostly water.Anonymous has some great points, too, though we believe RO provides better output for what we're doing.Then there are manufacturers who draw from municipal water sources.  If that's the case, the water is already treated and processed, so there may not be any need for adding the RO step.  Embed Quote
Beverage companies do use reverse osmosis to produce 'purified' bottled water. If you see the word purified on the label it's RO water  Embed Quote

I would say that the main 2 reasons more beverage companies don't use reverse osmosis are the following:As mentioned before, costs. Yes, RO systems can be expensive and need constant maintenance.It takes a long time to produce RO water which could slow down production. Many plants use silo's to hold RO water in reserves and for current production so that they always have a constant flow.  Embed Quote

column9: My goal is mostly to get the pH of the water to about 7.4 instead of its current level near 8.0, for all faucets in the house, including shower/bath water.
column10: As someone who worked in water treatment for about 10 years, I think you best solution may be a Reverse Osmosis (RO) Drinking Water System.     It will depend on the composition of the water, but from my experience RO will reduce HCO3 and CO3 by a magnitude of 1 to 2.  It will not remove CO2 gases and you may run the risk of other complication of chemistry trying to reduce pH.  If you have well water with an alkaline pH of 8, it is most likely due to Calcium Carbonate.  This limestone permeate is greatly reduced in RO filtration.   There is data all over the internet saying RO filtration has little impact on pH concentrations.  I'm sure it is true in some circumstances.  As far as the thousands of tests I have personally done in New England, I have regularly seen a pH of 8 reduced to 7.4.  You may get unlucky and have a water condition that makes it difficult to reduce your pH.  I would get your water tested by a professional.  An analytic testing lab can tell you the amount of Calcium Carbonate in your water.  In my opinion, you can buy a small RO drinking water system for testing under $100.  You get about a gallon an hour that is stored in a 3-5 gallon tank.  Hopefully you get the results that you need.  The cost of purchasing a whole house RO filter are prohibitive.Not for Reproduction Via  Anonymous.

column9: How would it age? Would it be sterile and age mostly like urine? Or would the food waste in the water begin composting? How would composting food interact with the nitrogen rich urine and life would bloom? Would solids form? Would gasses be given off like a biodigestor? Gasses we could use for lighting or cooking. How would the ration of water to urine affect the changes?
column10: It will depend on the concentration, and also the amount of oxygen available.Low quantities of urine will be broken down in the same way as other organic matter. Depending on how much oxygen is present, then it could be anaerobic, or aerobic. Aerobic will result in little gas, and some solids will form, mostly bacteria. Anaerobic will result in smelly gasses like hydrogen sulfide, and possibly methane. Though they are unlikely to be in any great quantity, at least in a dilute urine solution. Ammonia could also be released, and that is very smelly indeed.With greater concentrations of urine, it is more likely to act like urine. Though at what concentration I do not know. Maybe someone else can answer that?  Embed Quote

One of the most fascinating and innovative methods that come to mind involve replicating the ecological services provided by wetlands. While one may not consider the use of plants as a technology per se it is a process that has served us for millennia that we are only just beginning to understand and incorporate into our towns and cities. Professor of urban design and landscape architecture at MIT, Alan Berger researches restructuring of local ecosystems to perform ecological services. One example of a restoration project is a partnership between his company P-Rex (http://www.theprex.net/) and regional officials of Lazio in the provence of Lativa, Italy to use restored wetlands to clean up the Pontine Marshes. http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/20...Alan Berger - Systemic Design (c) Can Change the WorldThe conventional way of dealing with the problem would be to build water treatment plants that cover nearly 300 sq. miles. The solution proposed by Alan Berger would require just under one sq. mile of restored wetland using winding channels, slowing down the water speed to less than a mile an hour, to clean up the toxins in the Pontine Marshes. What's novel about these constructed wetlands as opposed to similar systems is that the end result is a beautiful landscape that can provide economic as well as ecological value to the surrounding area.To answer Aseem's question, the plants that are often used for water purification are Typhas and Phragmites (cattails and the common reed), which are invasive species. With a shift to promoting biodiversity, companies will use up to 200 species suited to all climate types and often include plants indigenous to the area. Other plants include Yellow Iris (Iris pseadacorus), Simplestem Bur-reed (Sparganium erectum), Water Soldier (Stratiotes aloides),  European Frogbit (Hydrocharis morsus-ranae), European White Waterlily (Nymphaea alba), and Eurasian Water-milfoil (Myriophyllum spicatum) are included. However there's more to it than selecting the right plants. You need to reconstruct and seed a healthy ecosystem which also includes selecting non-predatory fish and supporting bacteria. That way the system will hopefully be sustainable on it's own and more energy can be put into reducing the pollution in the first place.A slightly unrelated but very impressive project is the Sahara Forest Project. Led by Michael Pawlyn, Charlie Paton and Bill Watts, it uses biomimicry to generate fresh water and reverse desertification using greenhouse desalination techniques in combination with concentrated solar power. Incredible Sahara Forest Project Moves From Concept To Reality With Major Development Deal  Embed Quote

Engineered Ecosystems for Waste Management                   Organic wastes from human and animal habitations can accumulate in, and endanger the environment. Engineered ecosystems research for waste conversion has led to the development of Vermiculture Technology at Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay. This process overcomes the problems associated with conventional methods such as solid state composting, activated sludge, and extended aeration in which bio-energy gets dissipated. It engages an ecology consisting of soil, plants and soil micro and macro-organisms including geophagous earthworms. The process obtains synergy between photosynthesis and respiration, so that bio-energy of wastes is fully utilized.http://www.visionearthcare.com/t...  Embed Quote

Here,  the Vancouver Landfill is a great place to go to see Bald Eagles.  Especially in the winter, in between salmon runs. In February 2011, 1400 Bald Eagles were counted at the dump by a wildlife biologist.  [1]I admit, that's about triple the usual winter number.  But still, there are usually quite a few there.  Most of them go elsewhere in the summer and we are left with about 20 nesting pairs.  If you came right now (Feb 2013) I could spot about a dozen for you while driving at 100kph down the highway.[1] Urban Eagle Sightings  Embed QuoteVia  Dan Wyrick.

This strategy forms part of a trend in urban design which seeks to turn people's focus towards themselves in space, relating to their environment and people around them. The hypothesis runs that the more you manage people with things like pedestrian crossings, roadside fencing, elaborate signage etc., the more you disable them and disengage them from where they are and what they're doing.There's some evidence for this, particularly associated with Dutch experiments to eliminate the sidewalk/pavement distinction (pavement/road for British readers). This produces slower driving with fewer accidents. However, it's very expensive to do - unlike simply removing the bins! But the underlying thinking is the same. Make people responsible for themselves in space, and they start to behave in more complex, interactive ways.Retrofitting cities this way is fiendishly complex to do systematically, but it's quite cheap just to remove signage, clutter, furniture, waste bins. And it looks nicer. We don't know yet, however, what the effects of doing this piecemeal are - so doing it for three streets, while the remaining 2,000 stay as they were.  Embed Quote

column9: I've heard answers ranging from "the DPW digs up every pee cake spot before the end of the event" to "the lake bed fills up every year and totally eliminates any trace of urine w/o any negative consequence".
column10: From an extremely strict LNT standpoint, no. The chemicals in your urine count as traces, and the acidity of urine reacts with the alkalai playa.From a more realistic LNT standpoint, it's not that big a deal. There are much worse things to worry about in terms of preserving the playa and not leaving a trace. Micro-moop is the worst, small particles that won't break down but are extremely hard to remove, like carpet fibers, astroturf shedding, sequins. From the standpoint of being a courteous participant, it's pretty undesirable and we would all prefer that you try to hold it and get to a potty. And if you aren't able to hold it, try to spread it around as much as possible so that it dries up quickly rather than making a nasty puddle.  Embed Quote

column9: I've heard answers ranging from "the DPW digs up every pee cake spot before the end of the event" to "the lake bed fills up every year and totally eliminates any trace of urine w/o any negative consequence".
column10: DPW does not dig up pee cake spots. Generally the urine from a single person does not make any sort of cake spot.DPW does dig up some cake spots from leaking evap ponds, which is a lot more water than the urine coming from the same camp members. People use about 1-2L of water washing dishes and stuff per day. People pee about the same amount normally (probably the lower end of this on the playa, of course). But the showers people take use 2-6 more liters per person, which is why evap-ponds get overloaded.The total output of urine and other waste has already been asked about: Burning Man: What is the total amount of urine produced at Burning Man each year?It's not nearly enough to fill the lake.  Embed Quote

column9: I've heard answers ranging from "the DPW digs up every pee cake spot before the end of the event" to "the lake bed fills up every year and totally eliminates any trace of urine w/o any negative consequence".
column10: From a LNT standpoint, the best thing to do is to find a relatively open piece of playa away from people and installations, and then pee while running backwards naked.  This distributes the chemicals in your pee, and avoids a muddy spot that some poor barefoot sucker might step in later.  Embed Quote

column9: I'm thinking about the kind of dust that might be produced by sawing, grinding, sanding, and welding metals in a machine shop setting. If so, what can I do to protect myself? For example, irrigate my nose daily, wear a mask, or get the air more ventilated.
column10: Steel and aluminum dust will not cause horrible diseases like silica or asbestos dust do. The lungs can handle a certain amount of normal dust without any lasting harm, although all metal dusts are irritants. Large amounts of airborne metal dust are a sign the machine shop was improperly set up, and should be overhauled. A dust mask will not protect you against very small particles, so it's always best to just keep the dust out of the air in the first place. There are government standards in every developed country for maximum allowable airborne metal dust in the workplace, and dust controls such as wet machining equipment or negative pressure areas must be in place to get levels low enough for safe long-term exposure. There is also some evidence linking aluminum exposure to Alzheimer's, but it's far from proven.  Embed QuoteVia  Ben Mordecai.

column9: I'm thinking about the kind of dust that might be produced by sawing, grinding, sanding, and welding metals in a machine shop setting. If so, what can I do to protect myself? For example, irrigate my nose daily, wear a mask, or get the air more ventilated.
column10: The type of dust you speak of is generally much too heavy to become airborne in the sense that you could 'breathe' it.  Having run a machine shop for many years, I've never had to do any machining process on stainless or aluminum that produced an airborne powder.  Generally, outside of sanding, the chips are much larger than beach sand.  If you were sanding it, you'd have to actually put your mouth in the outgoing side of the process to get some in there before it fell to the ground.There may be some very fine grinding process that could produce breathable aluminum or stainless dust, but odds are that would be a process done with coolant which would remove the possibility.  Stainless and aluminum are gummy metals and don't tend to turn to powder easily like, for example, brass or iron.What you should be much more worried about in a machine or welding shop is breathing in welding fumes, especially from fluxes, and aerosolized coolants.  Wood dust, on the other hand, is light and quite prone to end up airborne and I have known many woodworkers who have had health issues as a result of exposure.  Even being somewhat careful, I'd say my experiences with wood dust in a production shop were 'unpleasant' to 'dangerous'.  Embed Quote

column9: I'm thinking about the kind of dust that might be produced by sawing, grinding, sanding, and welding metals in a machine shop setting. If so, what can I do to protect myself? For example, irrigate my nose daily, wear a mask, or get the air more ventilated.
column10: Yes, continuing exposure to fine airborne dust of every kind is best avoided. There are two approaches to this, eliminating dust at the source, and eliminating it at the intake. I'd start with stopping it at the source. Cutting and machining metals with a lubricating coolant will improve the quality of the work, make your tools last longer, and eliminate airborne dust. Do this first. For operations which must be done dry, arrange for dust collection. Be careful of fine aluminum powder. It can be hazardous! Finally, protect yourself with a dust mask. Your nose and lungs will thank you for it in the long run, no matter how sweaty you feel underneath it.  Embed QuoteVia  Ben Mordecai.

column9: I'm thinking about the kind of dust that might be produced by sawing, grinding, sanding, and welding metals in a machine shop setting. If so, what can I do to protect myself? For example, irrigate my nose daily, wear a mask, or get the air more ventilated.
column10: For complete information on questions of this type, one should always refer to the Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) Database.Now, you are talking about stray particles created in your work environment, not piles of the stuff being flung about with shovels.  So the following does not strictly apply to your situation.  However, for aluminum metallic powder, the MSDS has this to say:Appearance: silver-gray powder. Danger! Dust may form flammable or explosive mixture with air, especially when damp. Reacts violently and/or explosively with water, steam or moisture. May ignite or explode on contact with moist air. May cause eye and skin irritation. May cause respiratory tract irritation. Air sensitive.Target Organs: Lungs, eyes, skin.Potential Health Effects     Eye:          May cause eye irritation.      Skin:          May cause skin irritation. Low hazard for usual industrial handling.           No sensitizing effects known.      Ingestion:          May cause gastrointestinal irritation with nausea, vomiting and           diarrhea.      Inhalation:          May cause respiratory tract irritation. May cause respiratory           difficulty and coughing.      Chronic:          Aluminum may be implicated in Alzheimer's disease. Inhalation of           aluminum containing dusts may cause pulmonary disease.So basically, it would seem to be a Bad Idea to expose yourself to aluminum dust on a regular basis.  A dust mask would be a wise choice.  Get one that will filter the correct size of particles.MSDS Aluminum Metallic Powder: Page on Iastate.edu  Embed QuoteVia  Ben Mordecai.

column9: I'm thinking about the kind of dust that might be produced by sawing, grinding, sanding, and welding metals in a machine shop setting. If so, what can I do to protect myself? For example, irrigate my nose daily, wear a mask, or get the air more ventilated.
column10: I work for a company that manufactures industrial air pollution control equipment, and I have received many inquiries concerning aluminium and other airborne dust. Although breathing aluminium dust is not advisable for health reasons, there are much greater dangers associated with sanding, cutting, grinding, deburring and finishing of aluminium parts. The most serious risk arises when aluminium and steel (or stainless steel parts) are worked on in the same area. Mixing aluminium and steel dust creates a potential for combustion (an explosion or a fire) when an ignition source (a spark) ignites the airborne or settled dust particles. To mitigate this risk, ferrous and non-ferrous metals should not be operated on in the same area and the different dusts should be collected using separate dust collectors or downdraft tables. An alternative way to capture combustible dusts such as Aluminium, Titanium, Magnesium etc. is to use a wet dust collector which safely captures combustible dust and complies with all NFPA and OSHA standards. To specifically answer your question, above all else, make sure that you are not breathing in any fumes from stainless steel welding. Although all welding fumes are toxic and cause health problems, fumes from welding on stainless steel produce Hexavalent Chromium, a known carcinogen which can cause lung cancer, immunity disorders, neurodegenerative disorders... Hexavalent chromium. Welders working on stainless steel must use a fume extractor with a HEPA filter to comply with OSHA standards.My suggestions relating to your question:Capture dust and smoke at source with the correct air filtration equipment If not feasible, ventilate the shop with ambient air cleaners/ exhaust systems Workers exposed to the aluminium dust should wear masks/ respirators  I have linked to some videos below on the hazards of combustible dust:Shameless plug :D  Embed Quote

column9: I'm thinking about the kind of dust that might be produced by sawing, grinding, sanding, and welding metals in a machine shop setting. If so, what can I do to protect myself? For example, irrigate my nose daily, wear a mask, or get the air more ventilated.
column10: It can be harmful for you if you are welder and breathe in the gases produced by it on regular basis. You should try to wear a mask that saves you from it.  Embed Quote

column9: This image from 2010 shows the Southern California coastline, particularly near river mouths, littered with bottles, cans, tires, shoes and shopping carts (Source: Beaches awash in garbage after series of storms). The question is one of politics, this question is about practicality. That is, no one wants to take their family to the beach or go to the beach with friends and see trash covering the beach (as shown in the picture of above).There is considerable research covering the American municipal waste system (collection, transportation, disposal), and the research shows that the American waste system really has not change since the early 1900s. As you can see from the image above, America's waste system cannot accommodate American consumption, which is problematic because consumption is tied to GDP growth, and Americans (and to a larger extent, the world) have become economically growth-oriented. America needs a waste system that can accommodate economic growth in a manner acceptable to the American majority.Other related considerations:Americans produce more than one trillion pounds of municipal solid waste annually; highest in the world.America recycles 34% of municipal solid waste [trash]. Highest recycle rate in 40 years, but still kind of low.America could recycle up to 80% of its municipal solid waste.Current waste system is littered with equipment and machinery that add to the increasing costs of management of municipal solid wastes.Trash trucks are costly and they litter (I know, weird right?).Businesses pay $11.5B annually for litter.80% of ocean trash originates on land.While American households account for most of the new electronics market, they only contribute about 26% to the electronics recycling market. Indeed, 74.1% of the electronics being recycled in the America originate from business and commercial entities.Over 3 million tons of e‐waste discarded in 2009 in the US. Worldwide: 20 to 50 million metric tons of e‐waste disposed worldwide each year. E‐waste is still the fastest growing municipal waste stream in the US.
column10: It's a process, but I think Americans are changing and will continue to change. We need constant, ongoing education of our children and of consumers. People need to be trained how to properly dispose of trash. People need to learn the aesthetic pleasures of a trash free environment.And in addition to that, we kind of need to give ourselves a break. Storms do a lot of damage, and take things that were never meant to be trash and sweep them into places where they look ugly. But it's still a very small portion of the entire waste stream.We will recycle more and more of our waste as it becomes more economically viable. These things will happen. So I'm not that worried about trash disposal over the long term. There will come a time when we mine old waste disposal sites. People will compete to own them for the value of the trash. Meanwhile, things might look ugly from time to time, but it is not a problem I really worry about.  Embed QuoteAnswered in forty-one minutes.

column10: I think Americans are selfish and self-centered, but they have immense pride. The trick is steering them by that pride. Look at the campaigns against smoking. When cast as the worst health care crisis in the world, (which it probably is not) politicians and activists have been given a wedge to pry into the cracks of America's love of smoking. Every celebrity who dies of lung cancer is held up as a blood sacrifice taken by the evil cigarette companies. Characters like Joe Camel are demonized as sirens luring children to their doom. If ecologists want to reduce waste and reform America's waste system, they have a lot if work cut out for them. If they can frame their argument in a way that it emotionally hooks people, and stirs their pride, they will be a lot more successful. No one cares that trash kills Tawny Owls. If trash killed Elizabeth Taylor, that's a crisis!  Embed Quote

column10: I have adopted a 2.5 Mile stretch of a community trail system in a typical American small town, picking up refuse and waste along the way for the last 7 years.  Based on my experience the answer to your question is an emphatic "NO".   Embed QuoteAnswered in twenty-six minutes.

column9: It was interesting to walk around in offices and streets of Tokyo; and observed the density of trash cans is extraordinarily low compared to the U.S.A. where there is a trash can on every block and corner.
column10: Fomr my experience and based on what I've been told, it's because Tokyoites are very community minded and refuse to litter. I hung out with some locals one week. If they had trash (for instance, an empty beverage container), they would carry it in their hands until they did find a public trash can, and then carefully place it in the appropriate recycling section (and all trash cans had separate bins depending on which type of material could be recycled from the trash at hand). If that section was full? They'd keep carrying it until they found one that wasn't, further down the road (or at home/work). (Tokyoites also take their recycling very seriously.)Heck, even when it comes to smoking, they're responsible. They carry portable ashtrays so they can smoke without ashing or leaving cigarette butts on the street. (These ashtrays can be securely sealed, so no worries about making a mess or any odors.)Contrast this with New York, where littering is common and trash bags are officially left on sidewalks. The finest sanitation department in the world and trash cans every three steps wouldn't help.  Embed Quote

column9: It was interesting to walk around in offices and streets of Tokyo; and observed the density of trash cans is extraordinarily low compared to the U.S.A. where there is a trash can on every block and corner.
column10: I had the same experience living in Nagoya for 3 years.People just carry their trash until they can find a trash can, for example at the subway station.In my country Indonesia, trash cans are everywhere but the streets are covered in trash. So I guess the amount of trash can doesn't correlate with cleanliness.  Embed QuoteAnswered in thirty-seven minutes.

column9: It was interesting to walk around in offices and streets of Tokyo; and observed the density of trash cans is extraordinarily low compared to the U.S.A. where there is a trash can on every block and corner.
column10: I think it depends on what state you are in.  Here in Hawaii there are a fair number of trash cans.  There were less in Washington State when I went there earlier this year and you could walk for miles and not see a single one in Utah.  Embed QuoteAnswered in sixteen minutes.

column9: It was interesting to walk around in offices and streets of Tokyo; and observed the density of trash cans is extraordinarily low compared to the U.S.A. where there is a trash can on every block and corner.
column10: Besides the obvious answer that it isn't as culturally acceptable in Japan to litter as the USA, there is a couple other reasons I can think of.In Japan, people don't tend to eat / drink on the go. This eliminates one source of garbage that is common in the USA.Another reason is staff working at stores often will clean the street in front of their shops everyday.  Embed Quote

column9: I'm looking for vendors that provide solutions that sense when a trash bin or compactor is full and send an alert to the waste collector to collect it, instead of collecting it following a schedule.
column10: BigBelly Solar is the leader for this type of M2M technology.  Embed Quote

column9: Is a half-eaten sandwich litter? How about a toothpick?
column10: It seems to me that for the littered object to be considered litter it must either cause health concerns or be of nuisance. Plus the litterer (litteree?) must dispose of the object wilfully and not by accident. A half-eaten sandwhich, possibly, and quite definitely if thrown away on private property. A toothpick, probably not, unless it is infected with, say, anthrax or something that's really bad for people's health.  Embed Quote

Very basic! Essentially a hole in the ground, in developed nations environmental law requires them to be lined to prevent lequids entering water sources. However in poorer nations and older sites they may not be, which isn't a problem depending what rock they sit on. Waste is then dumped in the hole until full or until it's licence runs out then they are usually sealed. You can draw the gas off that is produced as the rubbish breaks down, you can then use this gas to produce electricity our just burn it. They don't smell as much as you'd think!Landfill sites vary in size, they can be big enough to be seen from space as in the fresh kills site in new jersey or they can be a few hundred metre squared. You have all manner of trucks bringing waste in with large compactors then to level the surface, this allows dumper trucks to since on the surface. Your bin at home will probably smell worse than a well managed landfill, because they're out in the open. Landfill sites in Europe are heavily legislated, and require sealing after they have been closed. This is done with a huge series of water tight rubber sheets which then get between five and ten metres of soil dumped on to to allow shrubs etc to grow.Big ones are managed the same as small ones, except more staff to compact and man the weighing station. They don't require a lot of staff on a day to day basis, other than to collect any windblown litter. Unless it is a hazardous waste landfill which are more complicated, but essentially the same process.  Embed Quote

Modern landfills are impressive engineering structures that offer state-of-the-art protection to the natural environment, while providing a vitalservice to governments, businesses and residents. They are managed and operated meticulously, providing a safe and effective option for their community’swaste.Many incorporate state-of-the-art systems including: Bottom Liners — isolate and contain the waste from the surrounding environment.Leachate Collection Systems — removes any liquids that form in the bottom of the landfill.Gas Collection Systems — when bacteria in the landfill break down the trash, methane gas is produced as a byproduct of this process. Methane gas is highly flammable and can explode or burn, therefore it must be removed. This is done by embedding a series of pipes within the landfill, which allow the gas to be either vented or burned.The waste is managed each day by compacting it into layers and covering it with six inches of soil or an alternative daily cover to control odor andlitter. Once a landfill is full, as part of the environmental protectionprocess, a final cover is placed over the area. This cover generally consistsof several layers of clay or HDPE plastic, along with a final layer of topsoilthat is capable of supporting vegetative growth, leaving the area beautiful andnatural.To see a helpful landfill diagram, click here: http://www.advanceddisposal.com/...  Embed Quote

That completely depends on what their individual needs are. If they are a doctor office and they have 6 rooms for patients and a big office with a few garbage cans, they will need at least 10 garbage bags a day (changing the garbage every day). If they are a contractor they might need 30 a day and some days even more! For the actual pricing of garbage bags, I'll let you do the math. You can check out http://www.plasticplace.net for some great prices on trash bags.  Embed Quote

column9: I admit, I'm a pretty sheltered young American without ever stepping foot in another country. How is waste dealt with in other countries? Are they all put in dumps? Burned?
column10: In rural Mexico there are dumps. Trash is buried. Positive things I've noted include:Because recycling is cost effective (you can bring plastic or aluminum to a center and be paid by weight), recycling happens. It may happen before the trash gets to the dump, or after. In any case, the trash is sorted through and anything of value is removed and taken to centers.Other things of value are removed and used. Old tupperware becomes a pot for a plant. Discarded shoes are snagged and used until unusable. Waste to some is not waste to all. Etc.My suspicion, based only on empirical evidence, is that in rural, less economically developed areas there is a lot less waste in dumps.Unfortunately, due to ignorance about the negative effects of burning trash, a lot of waste is simply burned, including styrofoam and plastics. Rural dumps would see a lot more trash if people stopped burning it.  Embed QuoteAnswered in forty-three minutes via  Anonymous.

column9: I admit, I'm a pretty sheltered young American without ever stepping foot in another country. How is waste dealt with in other countries? Are they all put in dumps? Burned?
column10: The sort of garbage dumps in Mexico as shown by Anonymous are common enough in India as well. Scenes like this in fringes or urban areas are ubiquitous.And just as common are rag pickers like these - mostly children and women. A marginal, nearly subhuman existence on the very fringes of society which barely notices their existence and doesn't really care if they live or die.The discarded plastic that they pick up from these dumps is purchased at a ridiculously low price by the myriad small time producers of cheap plastic toys and other items by recycling, and often enough these have a toxic effect too.The remaining stuff goes mostly into landfills. And this happens all over the world. You can refer to my this earlier answer about landfills: Som Bhatta's answer to What's so bad about landfill?  Embed QuoteVia  Anonymous.

column9: I admit, I'm a pretty sheltered young American without ever stepping foot in another country. How is waste dealt with in other countries? Are they all put in dumps? Burned?
column10: In the UK people are trying to push for recycling, generally speaking rubbish gets collected weekly and people separate their recycling (plastic, cardboard, bottles etc) which gets collected weekly, or every other week.For businesses it is a bit stricter, eco-friendly businesses are popular so to be seen as against this does not do well for your success. You can even get companies dedicated to Business Waste Collection & Waste Disposal & Recycling Management. There are also 'dumps' where waste that is too large or there is too much of it can be put which are away from residential areas and controlled by the local council. Fly tipping is a criminal offence and causes great problems with wildlife.Although where I live it is commonplace for people to leave unwanted goods by their house or a public bin in case someone else would like it, so this is recycling in a way.Hope this helps!Jeff  Embed Quote

column9: I admit, I'm a pretty sheltered young American without ever stepping foot in another country. How is waste dealt with in other countries? Are they all put in dumps? Burned?
column10: India mostly has landfills. The concept of recycling hasn't yet gotten any popular or even government machinery support.Couple of interesting articles on the issue:http://articles.latimes.com/2012... http://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/0...  Embed Quote

column9: I have seen at least 2 trucks on fire and two more smoking while driving on the freeway the past few years. What's in our trash that creates these fires?
column10: When organic materials breakdown they generate gases and heat. If they are compressed then the gas and heat can't escape. This is why it's common for landfills to actually explode.  Embed Quote

column9: It always seems odd that bin collections take place at around 7 or 8am which is the exact time everyone is on the school run or heading to work. So why do they not arrange the collections for post 10am?
column10: It is a primarily aimed at businesses. Traditionally some shops produce waste that gets smelly and has to be cleared quickly, places like fishmongers, grocers, butchers and restaurants. The places are cleared before the sun comes up.One of the problems waste collectors have is removing stuff that isn't junk, so they like to work when no one is around, leaving things like kids bikes by bins.No work can be done before 7 a.m. because this contravenes noise nuisance regulations. In urban areas councils are paranoid about bird droppings which accumulate during the night.Roads can also be cleared of dead animals.Refuse collectors work to the same weekly or two weekly schedule, the idea being that you get the same crew and collection at the same time.If the bin collection really is a problem for you, try writing to the council, they are a public service. You can get your collection time changed or have special collections. They often arrange later collections for the elderly.The general idea is that the town is cleaned up before people are awake and start anew.One of the traditional perks of being a binmen is that you finish your round and then go home, although this isn't the perk it was in the seventies, most bin collection is put out to tender.You make some valid points. It wouldn't cost any more to make collections in the afternoon.  The service is run by your local council and the admin don't get that many complaints, they will probably listen to you.  Embed QuoteVia  David Bain.

column9: Considering that trash is collected once in two days in apartment dumpsters by the trash compactors, what methods are used to get rid of them. Who quantifies the nature of recycle-able items? are they really recycled?In Japan, I've noticed that separate trash cans are provided for articles that are recycle-able and for junk. Considering such a set up is not available here in America. What happens to all our trash?Are they all dumped into land-fills?  (details on the size of these if possible)How much is being done to optimize trash degradation and land-fill usage ?
column10: People sometimes call in for junk removal service, which pretty much assures proper disposal and recycling. One such company is Green Clean Junk Removal Trash & Junk Removal, Rubbish Garbage Removal Los Angeles, New York | Green Clean Junk removal  Embed Quote

column9: I personally recycle my electronics but I was wondering the reason for this symbol because I had thought this symbol was intended for poisonous items such as CRT monitors.
column10: Almost all electronic items (and particularly their batteries) contain varying amounts of toxic metals and substances (not to mention non-renewables). Safe recycling is therefore very important.  Embed QuoteAnswered in forty-one minutes.

column9: I personally recycle my electronics but I was wondering the reason for this symbol because I had thought this symbol was intended for poisonous items such as CRT monitors.
column10: Because throwing your electronics anywhere is dangerous. Read this article Making the Tablet PC Eco-Friendly for more information about Electronic Waste. What is e-waste, what are its negative effects, how and where to dispose it properly and etc are some of the topics.  Embed Quote

column9: I personally recycle my electronics but I was wondering the reason for this symbol because I had thought this symbol was intended for poisonous items such as CRT monitors.
column10: Electronics have a "Don't throw in the trash" symbol because it needs to be treated in a different manner as compared to other garbage during disposal. E-waste contains various toxins and hazardous components like mercury, lead, cadmium etc, which need to be disposed of in an environmentally responsible manner. If handled improperly, they can lead to severe environmental pollution as well as cause serious health conditions. It is found that electronic waste accounts for 40 percent of the lead and 75 percent of the heavy metals found in landfills. Once old and unused electronics are thrown in a landfill, it leaches into the ground and contaminates soil and water, and eventually having adverse effects on the eco-system and human health, including permanent disabilities, asthma, psychological and neurological damages and even affect bone development. It also poses severe repercussions for those who lives in vicinity of the places where e-waste is dismantled, recycled or burnt.  Embed Quote

column9: I personally recycle my electronics but I was wondering the reason for this symbol because I had thought this symbol was intended for poisonous items such as CRT monitors.
column10: Its the mercury and other chemicals you find in electronics that makes them hazardous to just throw away. You can either contact your city sanitation department to see if they can schedule you for pick up or you could go with a private hauler like Green Clean to haul your electronics away for you. http://www.greencleanjunkremoval...  Embed Quote

column9: I personally recycle my electronics but I was wondering the reason for this symbol because I had thought this symbol was intended for poisonous items such as CRT monitors.
column10: TL;DR:European law, WEEE directive - can't sell it in EU otherwisevirtually all electronics contain potentially toxic ingredientssome components can be recycled at varying costa landfill has a tendency to aggregate all electronics and can damage the environment with enough pollutants per sq mWEEE(Waste Electrical and Electronic Equipment) directive.It is an EU law that passed in 2003 followed by RoHS (controlling hazardous substances like lead, chlorines, mercury, etc.)Many manufacturers simply add the sticker anyway as a gesture of good faith even if it isn't necessarily recognised in the US. But it isn't just as simple as putting a sticker on the product, you would need to fill in some pollution declaration forms, or if you're refurbishing or handling old/damaged equipment a 'waste transfer' notice.Any repairman would tell you they could scrap almost everything from old electronics, with the possibility of reuse.And chemicals contained by PCBs can slowly leak in time and potentially react to form other nasties in landfills.It is your responsibility to separate e-waste, as this statement from Cisco states: http://www.cisco.com/web/about/c...Not all electronic products can be made RoHS compliant. CRTs and Lithium batteries are inherently out of category, because they cannot be manufactured without some lead at least. In order for a product to comply, all of its subparts and manufacturing processes must comply. There are small exceptions. Exemptions can be made for integrated circuits that have a quartz clock source - very important because a lot of digital circuits tend to work with this.Mercury  is very uncommon today in household electronics, and is phased out even for  industrial use. it is present in minute quantities(ug) in CF lights, but if one such bulb is broken it is less of a hazard than breaking an old fashioned medical thermometer that contains concentrated liquid mercury.other  chemicals: hexafluoride, halides, halogens, etchants, acids and salts  (in batteries). Cadmium batteries have seen a decline, but sometimes CdS  is used as a semiconductor material in solar cells.In  recent times, plastics have began to be questioned for safety as well  as some cleaning chemicals used for PCBs/PWBs that are similar to BPA,  now a proven carcinogen. Since the casing for electronics is not  regulated in any way, some plastics may emit in time amounts of  plasticizers or bonders that may be toxic, especially under high  temperature (hair drier for instance).There are of course other examples.Normally, these chemicals are not present in large enough quantities to cause a health concern, but a landfill may include a disproportionate amount of electronics that can change the problem. This also increases the likelihood of ground water contamination.  Embed Quote

It goes to the Recology dump facility in South San Francisco across from the Candlestick Park:http://maps.google.com/maps?q=ca...Compost goes to some farms later, most stuff gets recycled, and the rest ends up in a landfill nearby.San Francisco switched to single-stream recycling a few years ago and now boasts one of the highest recycling rates in America.You can find more info at RecologySF site: http://www.recologysf.com/index.phpInterestingly, a lot of the recycled products end up going to China:Yet recycling has economies of scale and the transport can be virtually free—filling up the containers that came to the West full of clothes and electronics and would otherwise return empty to China. See the (shorter) writeup in The Economist:http://www.economist.com/node/93...And the big report on trash/recycling that specifically takes a deep look at San Francisco facilities:http://www.economist.com/node/13...  Embed Quote

column9: I've lived in Manhattan for 7 years, and not only have I never had a garbage disposal in any of the 6 apartments in which I've lived, but I've also never been in any apartment in Manhattan that has had one! Why??!!
column10: Historically many American municipalities banned using their sewer systems to dispose of food waste due to concern that it could clog and otherwise damage the systems or overtax treatment facilities. New York City was one such place and the ban remained in place until 1997. When a bylaw was passed allowing them after a study by the NYC Department of Environmental Protection determined that they would not harm the system. Although 50% of American homes have garbage disposals in the 14 years they have been legal in New York obviously not a lot have been installed as a retrofit.  Embed Quote

column9: I've lived in Manhattan for 7 years, and not only have I never had a garbage disposal in any of the 6 apartments in which I've lived, but I've also never been in any apartment in Manhattan that has had one! Why??!!
column10: Also many coop boards and landlords dont allow for them even though the city does.  Embed Quote

column9: If people get fined for fly-tipping, dropping cigarette butts or even chewing gum, why has recycling not become a standard way to treat household and business waste yet? What are we waiting for?
column10: I'm not 100% sure, but it is actually enforced in a lot of places nowadays. In the UK (where we're based) it is enforced and we have separate bins to do so, throwing recyclables in to a regular waste bin is a no go.However the reason this is not enforced everywhere or on a stricter scale at the moment is probably because it would be very hard to do so, making sure ever person in a country recycles in their own home would be extremely hard to enforce or prove. Other than that I don't see any other reason that it shouldn't be.  Embed Quote

Whether charged directly or taxed by a municipality, everyone is charged for their trash.  In order to maintain environmental standards and dispose of materials properly, there is quite a large infrastructure that needs to be maintained.  The question is, "SHOULD" people be charged... Unless you take the appropriate steps to dispose of your material properly yourself, someone else must do that, so yes, people should be charged for their trash.  Embed Quote

column9: Please explain your answer.
column10: If recycling continued to 100%, trash pickup in my area would not change at all except that the truck noise would be reduced by one half (one less pickup).Currently, residents put out two identical containers onto the street except that one container is blue (the recycle container).  I may go weeks before I need to put out the actual trash container since much of my waste goes into the recycle container.At 100% recycling, I would have one less truck making noise each week otherwise there would be no noticeable difference.  Embed Quote

My first meta quora question.  I would argue that you can never truly throw out a trash can - you can simple relocate it to a place where it serves as a slightly lesser version of it's original self.  Unless it goes to a trash compactor, in which case it's pretty much game over.  Embed QuoteVia  Joseph Turian.

A few questions: how big is the trash can? Is it missing a part? Or is it broken or infested? If the trashcan is intended for internal use, not outdoor trash pickup and is not broken or infested, you can donate it to a number of local second hand stores: goodwill, salvation army, etc. You could also just leave it on the curbside with a "free" sign and see if anyone takes it. This kind of foraging is common in San Francisco. This would be my first choice. You might also consider repurposing it--to a mop bucket, or a storage container for tools. If you are really set on throwing it out, a sign written on scrap paper indicating it is trash seems the least wasteful and most effective.  Embed Quote
Haven't you ever seen Russian dolls?  Find a bigger trash can :)  Embed Quote

Ian...I made our trash can look like trash by placing it inside a large green sack tied closed at the top and left it at the curb (called swale here in Florida). It vanished with the huge trash truck that picks upon misc. on Fridays.  Embed Quote
