column9: Metals, that people throw out in their waste bin.
column10: In Ireland, they now weigh people's trash and charge people an amount based on that weight. The result is that people are encouraged to recycle and compost more and throw fewer things out. The program has been a success — in terms of reducing the amount of things that get thrown out.[1] Another option would be to better compensate people for the value of the waste material they recycle.A combination of both approaches may be fruitful and effective in some areas.[1] In Ireland, Carbon Taxes Pay Off  Embed Quote

Modern sanitary landfills use layers of clay and plastic to create a leak-tight (and reasonably air-tight) seal around the trash. This means that the oxygen required for biodegradation is very quickly consumed, and the vast majority of waste in the landfill will not decompose for hundreds of years. It's not even really supposed to decompose -- sealing it minimizes outgassing and leakage.A rarer style is waste-gas-reclamation landfills, which pump air through the trash to allow decomposition, and then collect the ensuing methane for combustion in a small power station. Primarily these landfills look for microbial decomposition to release methane.There is going to be a lot of fungus in a landfill -- mold spores and the like are unavoidable -- but I'm not aware of them being used deliberately to accelerate decomposition. But it's possible that it is and I haven't heard of it; I'm not a sanitation engineer.  Embed Quote

The role of fungi in industrial waste management is best when directed in two ways. Firstly, fungi is used in decomposition of vegetable matter in industrial-scale composting. Fungi decompose cellulose and gradually lignin, components of tree and leaf matter. Oxygen is required for this type of composting. There are other microbes at work as well. In anaerobic composting, bacteria work on a wet slurry to make methane from animal and plant wastes, a different process. In vermicomposting, red worms are used to speed up the decomposition of vegetable matter, they keep conditions ripe for fungi and bacteria by oxygenating and allowing the substrate to hold moisture better than traditional composting methods. There are some landfills that divert vegetable matter towards composting, but using fungi for decomposing styrofoam and more long-lasting wastes is at best in the realm of study currently.The second use of fungi in waste management is quite interesting and exotic. Paul Stamets (a rock star among mycologists), has demonstrated the ability of fungi to clean up unwanted industrial wastes. He has engineered oyster mushrooms to completely clean up land-based oil and diesel fuel spills in weeks as well as using another type of mushroom to attack and filter E. coli from farm runoff. In the first demonstration, some piles of toxic diesel fuel waste were made, many teams tried to clean up their pile. Some used specialized enzyme treatments, some used reactive chemicals, some sponge-like mechanisms, Stamets inoculated the pile with his mushroom, and three weeks later there were thousands of harvestable (edible) mushrooms living off the hydrocarbons. Some time later grass was growing in the pile. Meanwhile, the other piles remained toxic wastes. In the second demonstration, sand bags of innoculum were placed at the runoff sites of the farm, and downstream the rate of E. coli and other diseases was shown to be negligible after a few weeks. The fungus actually grabs on to these harmful bacteria and uses penicillin-like compounds to destroy them. (penicillin is a fungus). Fungus is truly remarkable.  Embed Quote

column9: If so, why are there not more of them?
column10: I would say: Yes, they are safe.WtE-plants are basically just large combustion ovens and based on thoroughly tested technology.The dangers of combusting waste is in what comes out through the chimney, given the right (or maybe more correctly the wrong) conditions, pollutants like dioxins may form during the combustion process. Other pollutants from the waste itself are also released. To avoid these emissions WtE-plants continually monitor temperatures in the combustion chamber and also have filters and scrubbers to remove pollutants from the exhaust.The main reason that there are not more plants is their cost. WtE-plants are expensive and for them to be cost effective they usually need to be quite big. WtE plants also need to deliver their energy to consumers, and you will usually find them close to cities or areas where they can deliver energy in the form of heat, i.e. to district heating systems. Just delivering power in the form of electricity usually gives the plant low efficiency and building a WtE plant to do only this is usually not cost effective.Building a WtE plant is a large investment and a cheaper option is to just make a landfill for your waste.  Embed Quote

column9: If so, why are there not more of them?
column10: Well I'm not quite sure what you mean by 'safe'. You certainly wouldn't want to be walking around one blind-folded if that's what you mean. They are certainly safe for the environment, or at least safer than there alternatives. There processes certainly have an element of danger, with incineration and super heated steam turbines there's certainly risk of injury - but not to their environment. A lot of post-processing of fumes occurs, where they are cooled filtered, there's a bit more info on the way they work here http://www.rabbitgroup.co.uk/env...Why there aren't more of them? Well that's a question of money I suspect. They cost quite a lot to build and maintain - so people aren't exactly queueing up to build them. There's also the issue of their effectiveness not being uniform, people could end up with a poorly functioning facility - whereas recycling facilities of say, bottles, are relatively standard across the board.  Embed Quote

column9: If so, why are there not more of them?
column10: I heard and read they really safe and even helpful for environment. Successful operation of Waste-To-Energy is always depends on the Design. Economic success depends on accurate recovery projections, a good power purchase agreement, relatively high natural gas prices, with subsidies and tax credits where available.Read more Waste-to-energy plants - how they workThat is why there arent many waste to energy plants  Embed Quote

column9: What was your concentration? How did you know you wanted to go into Public Health? How did you finance it? What was your prior education & work experience?What is your personal story leading up to, during, and after the MPH?
column10: I did my Masters in International Health which was public health with a focus on developing countries. I also did this in Australia, so I'm not sure how helpful my answer is going to be but I'll give it a shot for the A2A. I realised I wanted to do International Public Health after a brief stint volunteering in a community based cataract screening and surgery project in Orissa, India. I had previously completed a Bachelor Degree in Human Biology and was in a soul destroying job in a pharmaceutical company, the sole purpose of which was to fund my then expensive taste in clothing (I'm writing this in an man's second hand shirt) and weird obsession with fake nails (ew, gross I know) - things have changed. I went to India not because I had any particular interest in India (now I love it and a little piece of my soul will always reside there) but because I had a crappy day at work and a volunteer thing popped up on my screen and my 21st birthday was coming up and my parents said that I could go on a trip instead of having a party if I wanted. And I applied. I was blown away. First by just how awesome India was, my little slice of Orissa was like a little slice of heaven. But then about the health issues people were facing. What I took issue with though was not the clinical aspect. I wasn't say, super interested in being able to treat a specific child for a specific problem. As a cultural outsider who did not speak the language I really didn't see that as my role. But I was interested in issues of access and equity and resource distribution and epidemiology and initiatves that changed the health of entire communities, of prevention. Rather than returning to the bowels of the pharma industry I thought it better to get the skills I was going to need in my new area of passion. But I also needed experience. So I studied my Masters of International Health at Curtin University (which is in Western Australia) by distance while I worked at the International Centre for Diarrhoeal Diseases Research, Bangladesh (ICDDR,B) on a child health project overseen by the WHO. The Australian government pays for my education. They also paid me to work in Bangladesh for that year. Sweet deal huh? The organisation helped me to conduct my Masters dissertation research which was on the care-seeking behaviours of mothers in the first three days after their baby was born in an area where we were running a Village Health Worker project. I loved it. I worked for that organisation for another year, then moved to South Sudan where I worked on am HIV and Gender Based Violence Project for returning refugees. My Masters helped me get my foot in those doors but a key component was contacts. You really would struggle to get anywhere in development work without contacts and I had been getting progressively better at putting myself out there to make them (self-promotion is an uncomfortable thing for an Australian).l then decided that aside from the skills I got from the Masters I needed other skills. I felt strange telling people how things should be done without any knowledge of how one would do them on the ground. I decided to get my training in nursing and midwifery because of that (I did not have the time nor the patience for a med degree!). And as I suspected, reading an article on how to stop post-partum haemorrhage is significantly different from actually trying to stop someone from haemorrhaging.  The break to do this study wasn't all advantages though. I am only now re-enetering public health development work and am doing it at an entry level (HIV and Tuberculosis Public Health Officer in Botswana).  My only tip with a Masters degree is that it isn't about the degree. Reading a bunch of papers to write your own paper should not be the point and will get you no-where. You have to make connections. Which means you have to network. Which means that you attend every event/lecture/afternoon tea that has even the remotest connection to the field you are interested in. And then you go an ask people a whole bunch of questions and see if they need an RA. And you seek out volunteer work and internships. Make the degree work for you.  P.S. If you haven't already its time to develop an intellectual crush on Hans Rosling and Paul Farmer. Enjoy!  Embed QuoteVia  Ming Law.

column9: What was your concentration? How did you know you wanted to go into Public Health? How did you finance it? What was your prior education & work experience?What is your personal story leading up to, during, and after the MPH?
column10: I earned my MPH in 2001 from UC Berkeley. My background was as a biology undergraduate who had spent 3 years doing bench science molecular biology research. As much as this was a wonderful experience (at UCSF and University of Washington), I was interested in population level determinants of disease so pursued an MPH. An MPH by definition is quite broad in its requirements and emphasis, and it is incumbent on the individual to pursue their own nitch. That having been said, I think it is important not to delay pursuing an MPH because you are not sure of you own specific interest. I went in to an MPH with an interest in infectious diseases, and within the first year found a new focus in social determinants of health. My main point here is to not close yourself off to possible interests that you may not know about prior to enrollment - exposure to a variety of areas of practice and research is fundamental to most MPH programs.An advantage of doing an MPH is the flexibility to purse either an applied or research career based on the degree. In addition to switching from an interest in infectious disease to social determinants of health, I also switched from wanting an applied career in public health to being interested in research. If interested in research, of course, it is essential to pursue a doctorate following the MPH. The good news about PhDs in public health is there is much better funding and you generally don't have to take many loans.My concentration was Epidemiology/Biostatistics, which was great. It was essentially a focus on a methodological toolkit that could be applied to various problems. I generally am of the view that subject specific content can more easily be pursued on ones own, and the more technical content of epidemiology and biostatistics is more easily aquired in the formal academic setting (although of course this can be learned through self-study as well if you have the inclination). I wasn't that enthralled by calculus in undergrad, but applied statistics is a whole other thing - I became totally enthralled.The MPH is a big money maker for schools of public health, so there are few opportunities for funding. The best bet is to get a position as a research assistant that will pay for living expenses and depending on the institution, some coverage of tuition. I'm now an Assistant Professor and hire research assistants for 10-20 hour a week positions that pay about $15/hour but also cover a portion of tuition. You will put yourself in the best position for these positions if you have some programming experience in R or SAS or Stata, but there are a variety of positions that are available. Look for postings for positions at Schools of Public Health that you are interested in applying to, or contact Professors doing research in areas that you are interested in. In addition to helping to fund an MPH, working with a research group is invaluable in learning how Public Health research is done. For me, earning an MPH allowed me to have a switch in my career trajectory, and begin to acquire a statistical analytic toolkit, as well as understand theories of disease causation, which were invaluable to me being able to pursue work that was most aligned with my interests. The curriculum is somewhat of a remarkable balance of intellectual and practical application to improving health. If that suits you, you should pursue it. As I once overheard a physician say, if you really want to help people - don't become a physician - study public health.After getting my MPH, I ended up going on to get my doctorate in public health at Harvard, and am now an Assistant Professor at Stanford. So this is a fairly traditional very academic track. But my colleagues in my MPH program have done a number of diverse pursuits, and in almost all cases have found very fulfilling work, ranging from working at Indian Health Services, to medical school to research assistants to environmental advocates.  Embed QuoteVia  Ming Law.

column9: What was your concentration? How did you know you wanted to go into Public Health? How did you finance it? What was your prior education & work experience?What is your personal story leading up to, during, and after the MPH?
column10: I decided to get an MPH while I was serving in the Peace Corps as a community health volunteer in Peru. I had a bachelor of journalism with little (ok, no) background in science. But my skills in communication seemed to translate pretty well to health education, as I could quickly research topics I knew little about and then translate the information into something that was easy to understand. I spent two years working with community health workers and teen promoters on the prevention of HIV, diarrheal diseases, respiratory infections, dengue, malaria... I loved it. So when I was getting ready to go back to the States, I looked at the different MPH programs around the country. Many are more research-based, but given my background, I wanted more of a practical focus. In the end I applied and went to Tulane University in New Orleans for their health education and communication program. About halfway through my studies, I discovered I had a strong interest in epidemiology (in a nutshell: the study of how diseases appear and move through populations). My advisor encouraged me to explore other departments, and I ended up taking about as many courses related to epidemiology as I did in health education. I was fascinated and found I was most comfortable when I worked with the two concentrations in combination. My experience was enriched a lot by being in New Orleans. It's a wonderful but in some ways still-struggling city, where many of the public health concerns I learned about in the classroom were right there in my neighborhood. Instead of a research thesis, we were required to complete 300 hours of practicum. I did mine at the New Orleans Health Department and also volunteered at a safety-net clinic. Being a part of the health community there not only complemented my studies, but also helped confirm that I was in the right field. So that's the good stuff. The financing was the hard part. My program was expensive, with very few opportunities for scholarships or grants. I and most of my friends financed our education with student loans. For me it was worth it. Even after graduating, I'm still fascinated by current  research and bore (or sometimes horrify) my husband and friends with health-related trivia. Studying public health made me healthier. More in tune with what's going on in our world and more knowledgable about how policy and environments can affect how healthy we are. But that's me. I'd be interested to see how my experience differed from others here on Quora.  Embed QuoteVia  Ming Law.

column9: What was your concentration? How did you know you wanted to go into Public Health? How did you finance it? What was your prior education & work experience?What is your personal story leading up to, during, and after the MPH?
column10: I received my MPH in 2006 with a concentration in environmental public health. I was teaching environmental science in high school at the time and my thought was that the degree would improve my teaching but would also give me additional opportunities outside of teaching and would give me the skill set I need to have a positive impact on the environment.I found that the degree on its own didn't have a lot of teeth; I read a lot of books and wrote a lot of papers but I didn't come out of the program with any tangible skill set. If I had focused on biostats it would have been a different story but the environmental concentration gave me the opportunity to do environmental compliance work.It turned out I hated that work; it's basically writing reports showing that your company isn't doing anything wrong. It's a lot of "I" dotting and "T" crossing.  Most of the jobs that I have seen for environmental related work tend to veer towards government/industrial environmental compliance - other environmental jobs seem to require a background in environmental engineering or industrial ecology.If I had complimented my MPH with another degree, like a masters in environmental engineering or law then maybe I could have had greater opportunities within the environmental field - I am currently looking into a data analytical program to compliment my knowledge with learning to use large data sets for urban sustainability.My caution for anyone interested in an MPH is simple; on its own it probably won't expand you into a ton of opportunities - use it to improve your quantitative skills or complement it with another degree to really stand out.  Embed Quote

column9: What was your concentration? How did you know you wanted to go into Public Health? How did you finance it? What was your prior education & work experience?What is your personal story leading up to, during, and after the MPH?
column10: It is important to know which field of Public Health interests you since there can be many concentrations in it like, Global Health, public policy, health policy, epidemiology, biostatistics, maternal and child health, etc. It is also important to know that for some concentrations in public health,further  education is necessary for better paying jobs. Public health is an incredibly vast field but in order to get an MPH one should do a little bit of studying in what interests you in public health.  Embed Quote

I have an MPH from Yale, and did the application/school-research/acceptance/more-research/decision thing at Yale, UW, & Harvard for the MPH and the same at Berkeley, Harvard, JHSPH, UW, Columbia for a related PhD (Environmental Health Sciences). I've also been in the field for ~ 7 years, and would be happy to answer if you'd mind clarifying a bit about what your criteria are.  Embed Quote

The Colorado School of Public Health offers MPH degree in various areas of studies. We offer students practice-based learning. Students are immersed in the current public health issues and are equipped with the resources and guidance to help them tackle these significant matters. Students are also connected to employers who impact public health locally and globally.  Embed Quote

It is as an exciting time for an MPH as new apps for mobile diagnosis and screening are becoming available. As we create these we will be looking for experts in Public Health policy and distribution.  Embed QuoteVia  Siddharth Singhal.

Traditional public health settings such as local health departments, state health departments and local community-based organizations are an option. (not sure about the nursing license though)International organizations like Red Cross and the World Health Organization too can be considered. Other options can be a program manager at health departments, health information specialists for the federal government, research associates for pharmaceutical companies, health promotion specialists for corporations, and other mid-level management positions across a diverse range of institutions.The ideal way is to go for some internships which gives field experience.  Even though the pay is less, entry is easy and in most cases nursing license is not required.  Embed QuoteVia  Siddharth Singhal.

column9: http://www.organicconsumers.org/...I care about my health and I have heard a lot of really bad things about Monsanto. This does not sound good.
column10: No.  There are extremely, exceedingly, vanishingly small health risks with GM foods. If you are not massively allergic to soy, the vast majority of GM foods are as healthy as any other food.  The hysteria about health is vastly overblown.  (If you are allergic to soy, consider the paleo diet.)Regarding Monsanto as a major agribusiness corporation, you can certainly choose to boycott them.  However, they will at best provide the seeds for a fraction of Whole Food's fruits, vegetables and grains.  Why would you boycott Whole Foods over that?  Just pick from the vast majority of foods that they will have that are not touched by Monsanto.  Embed Quote

Something's rotten in the state of Denmark. Why on earth would any charity want to be involved with a company that obviously is choosing the profits of a small few over the well-being of the many?)
column10: Monsanto does not market seeds that won't reproduce.  The technology is available but to date no biotech firm has made commericial use of GURT (Genetic Use Restriction Technology) or terminator genes as they are also called.  Some might even argue the GURTs would allay certains fears of those who don't care for GMO crops.  All of my soybeans are GMO and much of the corn on my farm is as well.  It all produces viable seed.  Heck, if our combine gets rained on during harvest I'll find seeds sprouting in the nooks and crannies of the machinery and that's tough to clean out because the roots cling to everything.  For more on this technology check out Terminator 2: My Mission is to Protect You  Embed Quote

column10: This question has a faulty premise. The seed Monsanto sells is not sterile. The seed we sell is either hybrid or varieties, all that seed produces viable seed. The seed from hybrids is not self replicating though so while it produces viable seed, the lack of uniformity makes it undesirable to save for subsequent seasons. Hybridization has been used for decades before biotech was on the market for the increased vigor it offers. With our biotech products, farmers sign a licensing agreement not to replant. You can read a farmers' thoughts on that here http://thefarmerslife.com/biotec... One of the things the blog post above does so well is to explain how farmers analyze the potential seed sources and choose whether to purchase seed annually or to buy seed which allows them to save the seed produced. As far as the way it is discussed with others, I think the explanation previously left provides many of the points.  Embed Quote

Consuming genetically modified foods may be harmful, but they have benefits as well. You must first consult a medical expert before consuming any such foods just to be safe! Eat healthy and stay healthy!Disadvantages of Genetically Modified FoodsToxinsA study conducted in Philippines revealed that when an individual consumes GMO foods their bodies develop antibodies to BT toxins that are found in the foods. This leads to allergic reactions, some of which can actually be life threatening. So make sure that you consume these foods with care and consult your doctor. This is major problem since the safety of GMO foods have not been tested on humans, the researches were conducted on animals and the products were sold in the market.Cancer ThreatExperts are concerned of the connection between the consumption of GMO foods and an increased cancer risk; studies find that genetically engineered material can increase the occurrence of tumors. This greatly increases the risk of developing cancer.Super Pests!This is no joke! The genes used to make the crops resistant to pesticides can be transferred on to pests that feed on them. This can make the pests pesticide resistant as well, which may create a very huge problem for farmers.source: Genetically Modified Foods (GMO Foods)  Embed Quote
Lack of science literacy in the general public.  Embed QuoteAnswered in six minutes.

column9: Why is everyone so upset?
column10: There are a variety of complaints against them, mainly in the areas of  Genetically Modified Foods, Growth Hormones, Pesticides, and Herbicides.My two biggest objections, based on what I know of their practices, are:They've designed and sell seeds that bear sterile fruit so that farmers will have to buy more seeds for subsequent crops. (This is mostly tied to their "Round-up Ready" products.)They have a VERY litigious track record around patent enforcement claims. They've been known to sue (or merely threaten to sue) farmers who are adjacent to other farms that have used Monsanto products and seeds on the grounds that the adjacent farms may be infringing on Monsanto's patents. Referring back to point #1, if a farmer uses Monsanto products and then tries to plant non-Monsanto in following seasons, attorneys will again show up demanding evidence that the fields are completely free of patented Monsanto seeds.A number of well-publicized documentary films have covered the practices of the corporation. Whether you agree or not, these are good places to understand why people take issue with the company.http://www.foodincmovie.com/http://www.thecorporation.com/Update 2/23/12Just spotted this story online: http://www.readersupportednews.o...300,000 Organic Farmers Sue Monsanto in Federal CourtHundreds of citizens, (even including NYC chefs in their white chef hats) joined Occupy the Food System groups, ie Food Democracy Now, gathered outside the Federal Courts in Manhattan on January 31st, to support organic family farmers in their landmark lawsuit against Big Agribusiness giant Monsanto. (Organic Seed Growers & Trade Association v. Monsanto) Oral arguments were heard that day concerning the lawsuit by 83 plaintiffs representing over 300,000 organic farmers, organic seed growers, and organic seed businesses.The lawsuit addresses the bizarre and shocking issue of Monsanto harassing and threatening organic farmers with lawsuits of "patent infringement" if any organic farmer ends up with any trace amount of GM seeds on their organic farmland.  Embed QuoteAnswered in sixteen minutes.

column9: Why is everyone so upset?
column10: Monsanto is toying with mass extinction in order to turn a profit.  Other answers have covered how Monsanto is creating its own arms race between herbicides, genetically-modified crops, and superweeds.  Since those answers have been posted, new research has shown that Monsanto pesticides may be responsible for the near-extinction of honeybees.  When a link was discovered between Monsanto pesticides and the recent massive die-off of honeybees (Colony Collapse Disorder) Monsanto bought the agency that did the research to suppress the findings.  Monsanto Blamed For Bee Population Collapse, So It Buys Bee Research FirmAre Monsanto Genetically Engineered Seeds Killing Off Honeybees?Though it may seem far-fetched, they may actually be developing artificial bees to pollenate crops should honeybees actually become extinct in North America.  Should honeybees become extinct, most food crops would not become pollenated, which would disrupt Monsanto's agribusiness market, and also probably cause a massive famine.  Robotic Bees to Pollinate Monsanto CropsJust as insidious is their legislative manipulation.  The current director of the USDA, which determines safety standards for agricultural products, is a former director of Monsanto.  In early 2013, the US Congress passed a budget bill which included a provision (known as the Monsanto Protection Act) which pre-emptively bars federal courts from placing injunctions on the sale or use of Monsanto products.   The bill does not name Monsanto specifically, but was written in coordination with former Monsanto employees in the Obama administration. So even if their products are found unsafe in a civil suit (or presumably even in a criminal prosecution), Monsanto is still permitted, by a specific act of Congress, to sell their products in America.  What's The Monsanto Protection Act And Why Is It All Over Facebook?Full Text of the just passed Monsanto Protection Act  Embed Quote

column9: Why is everyone so upset?
column10: They want to patent the building blocks of life; DNA [1, 1a] for commercial purposes and have a pretty hideous track record of corporate responsibility. In fact, corporate responsibility and accountability is to Monsanto what Kryptonite is to Superman. This is evident in their total lack of giving a damn in trying to re-market a country they successfully (by their soul-less standards) 'deployed in' some time ago [2]. Personally I'd put Monsanto up on the mantelpiece of the worst, most evil corporations in the world, right beside Union Carbide and BP.But you have no reason to be upset unless you eat food, or have an aversion to slow death from poorly - barely tested 'products' rushed to market. Oh, and their business model is monopoly, in that for the last 10,000 years farmers kept back some seeds from their crops to plant the next. This is clearly inefficient. In the Monsanto business model their crops will be sterile - good for one crop only. You want another? Buy more Monsanto (c) Seedz (TM). This will surely be only good news for the Third World. [1] http://www.greenpeace.org/intern...[1a] Lest you find Greenpeace too 'pinko' for your trust (and I confess - I do half the time) here is a more neutral source: http://www.genomicslawreport.com...[2] http://www.globalpost.com/dispat...  Embed QuoteAnswered in twenty-five minutes.

column9: Why is everyone so upset?
column10: My basic problem with them is they are actively pursuing, and forcing us to pursue, a course which could easily lead to death by starvation for an awful lot of people.Thanks to Monsanto, over 96% of the US corn crop is genetically identical. Over 93% of the US soy crop is genetically identical. So, what happens if a new fungus shows up that this corn or soy is particularly susceptible to? We lose that crop. All of it. Lets say it's corn. The US will then buy corn from other sources, of course. There won't be enough, since we wiped out the Mexican corn industry with NAFTA, but we'll buy all we can. And we'll buy other grains in great quantities to make up for the short fall. As will other countries. Africa and the poor countries in Asia and Latin America will be shit out of luck, because prices will be too high for them to compete. Poor Americans, who live on diets comprised largely of cheap packaged foods made possible by high fructose corn syrup will also be SOL. Of course, Monsanto can produce a GMO seed that is resistant to the new fungus. So we're really only looking at how many people will starve to death in about 8 months. And we're only looking at it happening once every 10 or 20 years or so.  Embed Quote

column9: Why is everyone so upset?
column10: Well considering the majority of answers on here are repeating the same claims made by greenpeace, motherjones, and fear-based opined documentaries, I will attempt to give you a more comprehensive answer to why the hate against Monsanto has developed to an all-time high. First lets start with the main thing Monsanto has been doing wrong in their business operations before I refute the nonsense surrounding RR crops and other GM crops. The one bad thing about Monsanto is that they are extremely paranoid about their patents. This causes them to sue in every situation they spot patent infringement, including individual farmers that intentionally, or unintentionally misuse Monsanto products. There is a good reason for this, but to me the patent infringement by independent farmers is negligible, Monsanto is simply worried that if they let the small cases of patent infringement grow, they won't be able to make the case if a hypothetical future has farmers simply replanting elevator seed and profiting off of past Monsanto traits and their hybrids. The cost of developing GM traits is extremely expensive, protecting this investment is a #1 priority at every level of business operations. Unfortunately they have chose to treat small farmers like they would a rival corporation. As a business manager, I would limit farmers' patent infringement in a different way, one that doesn't require litigation, but I can't say what Monsanto is doing is unethical or immoral, because, as almost every case of patent infringement brought by Monsanto, has seen the courts rule in their favor. (Remember that when a farmer takes seeds he produced from Monsanto seeds and plants them the next year without consent from Monsanto, he/she is knowingly participating in illegal activities. Farmers know this not only because of Monsanto, but because that is the way all seed companies are able to protect their intellectual property. Farmers rarely use this planting practice not only because it is illegal, but also because it is largely unprofitable). But hey, Monsanto recently took a $1 billion settlement from a 'bigger and badder' ag-business giant, Du-Pont, because the latter had willingly infringed on the former's patents that it had licensed. In that case, the little guy (Monsanto is 1/3 the size of Du Pont) defeated the wrong-doer. Now, lets really discuss GM products, and the one trait that gets the most criticism, Roundup Ready (RR). In order to produce the amount of yields U.S. farmers have seen in the past few decades, a revolution in farming has happened at many different levels. One of these was the introduction of glyphosate-resistent seeds. Glyphosate was less chemically-harmful than other pre-RR herbicides, leading to its wide-adoption by farmers once Monsanto had developed the RR-resistant seeds. Simply put RR seeds have been directly responsible for the decline in harmful chemicals that were being put into our soils by pre-glyphosate herbicides. Furthermore, and in my opinion, much more significantly, other types of GM seeds work to limit the pests that ruin crops (such as rootworm/corn borer, etc), this has lead to the widespread decline of pesticides used by crop-farmers in the U.S. Genetically modified foods are replacing the previously huge need for pesticides and herbicides, boosting yields, and making modern major-crop agriculture more environmentally sustainable than it ever has been before. Although anti-GM advocates may have valid concerns about some effects of GM products, this technology is revolutionary and is one of the main reasons countries like India and China are not suffering from widespread famine, as well as being one of the main reasons the world's poorest are receiving more calories and nutrients per person than ever before. Outside of their role in limiting the amount of pesticides and herbicides needed on a field, GM products have: Decreased the arable area needed to produce a certain yieldDecreased the amount of irrigation needed to produce a certain yieldDecreased the amount of fertilizer needed to produce a certain yield. The GM revolution was the needed appendix to the Green Revolution in world-wide agriculture production that occurred between the 1950s-1980s. GM products have increasingly helped to limit the amount of chemicals and needed natural resources (water for example) that are required to grow a certain amount of food. The Green Revolution is credited with saving billions of people from starvation. While this also produced some limited but unwanted effects of environmental degradation and pollution, GM technology brings the promise of a near-future that sees widespread major crop production become perpetually environmentally sustainable. Like any technology, GM technology does not always produce the desired outcomes (i would mention some, but too many overblown and less-than-significant examples have been produced in the above replies), but its failures are dwarfed by its accomplishments. Remember that.  Embed Quote

column9: Why is everyone so upset?
column10: I agree with many of the reasons already posted and would like to add another very important point.   GMO crops contain very little of the natural nutrition that the organic crop it was derived from once contained.   At the same time GMO corn contains unnatural additives like chlorides and formaldehyde.   Here is a comparison of GMO corn and organic corn from 2012.Which would you rather serve your family?  For example you would need to eat over 400 ears of GMO corn to get the same calcium as one ear of organic corn.  Over 20 ears to get the same amount of potassium. Over 50 ears to get the same amount of magnesium as one ear of organic corn.  Etc.  You might as well be serving your family a tennis ball or some sawdust bread.   This gives a whole new meaning to “corn fed farmer”.    Is this where we want to go as a nation?  We have chosen to allow a corporation to monopolize our nutrition for profit.  We have granted them the legal right to attack strains of plant life that have sustained us for thousands of years.   Our health as individuals and a society is at risk.  Embed Quote

I am feeling much better staying away from anything agriculture tainted like wheat, soy, milk, and processed things. column9: Just a bit curious about the sequencing platforms used and the tools used for analysis.
column10: The short answer: They use everything.In terms of hardware, they've got the "standard" Illumina's for high-throughput sequencing, but if you go on their tour, you'll see they've even got a Pacific Biosciences sequencer.  PacBio sequencers are pretty new, still experimental, but Monsanto got one early on.In terms of software, they also make use of everything.  Products down the pipeline may use more refined or standard software packages (either commercial or in-house), but at the earlier stages, all the academic open-source stuff is used too.  Embed Quote

column9: Just a bit curious about the sequencing platforms used and the tools used for analysis.
column10: At the 2012 Sequencing, Finishing and Analysis in the Future meeting in Santa Fe, New Mexico, Monsanto presented their transgenic plant pipeline, sequencing thousands of plasmids per year and finishing these sequencing data using software from CLC bio. To ensure that only high quality plasmids get transformed into plants, a number of requirements had to be met for the finishing software used by the Monsanto researchers. Other than the finishing tools, Monsanto’s also decided to make CLC bio the ‘one-stop shop’ for bioinformatics tools across their entire organization. Flexibility, user-friendliness, ability to customize, as well as execute algorithms in a high-throughput fashion were on the list of requirements. http://www.patexia.com/feed/mons...  Embed Quote

column9: Some claims have said that it will increase packaging prices slightly. That's not a reasonable or justifiable excuse. People have a right to know what they are putting into their bodies, regardless of whether or not the producers claim it to be safe.It would be great to have a Monsanto employee answer this one, even if they must do so anonymously. Do you have any ethical qualms about the company you work for?
column10: You are the reason Monsanto opposes labeling.If there weren't people running around implying to everyone that eating genetically modified organisms might be dangerous, then Monsanto wouldn't especially care whether its products were labeled that way or not.  It would just be one more bit of fine print that almost nobody reads.But because of people like you, Monsanto correctly assumes that if they were forced to label products, some consumers would try to avoid them.  Consumers would interpret a legal requirement to label GMOs as a government endorsement of the idea that eating GMOs might be dangerous or unhealthy.  And that would hurt Monsanto's profits, which is a good reason for a business to oppose something.As it happens, Monsanto is also correct regarding the safety of genetically modified organisms.  "Genetically modified organism" isn't a meaningful category of food.  One modification has nothing to do with another modification.  It's theoretically possible for a genetic modification to result in new proteins that cause negative health effects, but then again natural food can be unhealthy or dangerous too.  News flash: castor beans are 100% all natural, and if you eat a hearty meal of them, you will die in agony regardless of whether those beans were grown organically on a local farm by a smiling, socially-conscious farmer.  Genetically modified castor beans might be safe to eat though, if the genes could be altered to prevent the plant from producing ricin.Natural and safe simply have nothing to do with each other. This is why food safety testing exists; genetically modified or not, people check to make sure our food is safe.   Here's a short paper on how this applies to GMOs, from that noted reactionary institution, the University of California: Page on Ucdavis.  Embed Quote

column9: Some claims have said that it will increase packaging prices slightly. That's not a reasonable or justifiable excuse. People have a right to know what they are putting into their bodies, regardless of whether or not the producers claim it to be safe.It would be great to have a Monsanto employee answer this one, even if they must do so anonymously. Do you have any ethical qualms about the company you work for?
column10: The craze of non-Celiacs trying to eat "gluten free" diets should be sufficient evidence that consumers are often not scientifically-literate enough to tell whether or not food is bad for them. Labeling only adds value when the benefits to informed people outweigh the number of poor decisions made by uninformed people. That threshold hasn't been shown to exist for GMO food. People have wide misunderstandings about the safety and prevalence of GMO foods, and requiring labeling of something with no peer-reviewed evidence of harm to humans is a waste of resources, label space, and mind-space. The very real danger is that consumers will pay less attention to things that clearly matter, like calorie intake, and more attention to poorly-substantiated claims of harm by activist groups.  Embed Quote

Do you have any ethical qualms about the company you work for?
column10: I'm going to chime in here on this one, on a personal level.First and foremost, the laughable thing here is not Monsanto employees, but the utterly ill-informed people that think they are somehow entitled to say things like Monsanto employees have sold their souls... whatever that means. That is what is laughable.   My wife works at Monsanto.  She's not the devil incarnate, nor one of his minions.  She is not a careless scientist who thinks nothing of what she is doing and how it affects the world.  The fact is, people don't understand Monsanto.  They think they do because of subjective websites they've visited or subjective documentaries they've seen.  I won't debate what they do or don't do because I don't have the direct knowledge to do so.  But I will say this:  Monsanto employees listen to what is being said about them.  They hear the various information and apparent scientific evidence that is used against them.  And they shake their heads knowing that such information is taken out of context and spun, spun, spun for whatever objective the parties that be would like to "accomplish".  Heck, even Monsanto's biggest critic, who basically started the anti-Monsanto movement, has publicly apologized and recanted everything he ever said about them.  Why?  Because he actually learned the truth about their practices.  His name is Mark Lynas.   Time to call out the anti-GMO conspiracy theory Honestly, I listen to the critics of my wife's very own program and listen to her shake her head and pinpoint and elaborate on the little snippets of science and information taken completely out of context.  It's frustrating.  For me as her husband, to see such elitists, like the person who wrote this question obviously, to look down on someone that is actually doing some great things for this world.Monsanto doesn't cater to such elitists because it is utterly futile.  They likely don't want to label their foods with some GMO logo, that many uneducated people might see as some warning, because it would be them saying that their products are dangerous and deserve such a warning, which just isn't true.  I wonder if critics rely on medicine, which is chemically engineered by human scientists? I wonder if they consume foods that aren't sprayed by various protective substances created by human scientists?   These are moot points to the critics, though because in the end, it doesn't matter to them.It's laughable.  I don't know how critics, like the person who wrote this loaded question, can look themselves in the mirror and judge anyone like that.  If you want to ask a question, ask a question.  Don't taint it, or Quora, with your close-minded comments and judgement on a subject you clearly know nothing about beyond what you've read on the internet or seen on some subjective documentary.  Embed Quote

column9: Some claims have said that it will increase packaging prices slightly. That's not a reasonable or justifiable excuse. People have a right to know what they are putting into their bodies, regardless of whether or not the producers claim it to be safe.It would be great to have a Monsanto employee answer this one, even if they must do so anonymously. column10: There are three reasons:1) To limit liability 2) Because they fear that it will reduce sale of their products3) To discourage regulation of their productsThey don't really know that their products do not cause harm.  They likely believe the products are safe, but they know there is a long history of products once thought safe being determined to be harmful, sometimes decades later, resulting in lawsuits.  If their GMO products are marked to differentiate them from otherwise identical but none GMO products it becomes a lot easier to identify a correlation between the products and an adverse effect.  If the products are not marked, it becomes virtually impossible to establish any such correlation.  Monsanto limits their liability by preventing an evidence chain.  It is a prudent legal strategy.Monsanto fears that if two products are side by side and one is labeled as GMO and the other is not, that the product labeled GMO will have a disadvantage in the market place.  They would have to then spend greater amounts of money marketing the product.Monsanto knows that if there is no way to distinguish between a GMO and a non-GMO product, on the shelf, it becomes almost impossible to impose regulations on the GMO product.  Regulations impose costs, so it is a prudent financial strategy.  Embed Quote

column10: For the past 10,000 years, human beings have been genetically modifying both crops and animals.That process is typically called agriculture.Lab-based modification – versus field-based modification – is, I would agree, different, but there is no persuasive evidence that shows that it is riskier.If you want to take issue with Monsanto's product history with chemical pesticides and pharmaceutical treatments (like growth hornones) to increase livestock productivity, go for it. If you want to take issue with some of Monsanto's reported business practices related to seed modification, I'm with you. The fact of GMOs, though, is a bit of a distraction that takes focus from far bigger challenges to the food supply, food safety, health, and nutrition.With that said, there is nothing whatsoever stopping individual consumers from demanding insight, voluntary consortiums offering non-GMO certification, and businesses participating – just as with movements like organic, fair trade, and countless other initiatives. For those seeking shopping guidance, here are some resources I found with a quick Google search:http://www.nongmoshoppingguide.com/http://www.nongmoproject.org/fin...http://www.wholefoodsmarket.com/...Given the already available information for those who want it, there is no apparent benefit from mandatory labeling.  Embed Quote

column10: Because they would have to label just about everything in the store. 85% of the food in the US is basically corn and soy. Aside from organic and free range alternatives, all the chicken, beef, and pork in this country is fed genetically modified corn and soy. All the farm raised fish, too. Everything that contains high fructose corn syrup is GMO. Monsanto corn is engineered for two purposes - resistance to pesticides, and high starch content to make it more suitable for producing HFCS. And we all know how pervasive HFCS is in American processed foods. Ironically, corn wouldn't have to be labeled, because we don't eat GMO corn in kernel form. It's basically inedible because of the super high starch content. Corn eaten whole in the US comes from Argentinian seed stock (which we sold them decades ago and they now sell back to us). I'm not sure what GMO soy is being used for, or what it's engineered for other than pesticide resistance. Soy has always been a manufacturing material in the US - Ford used soy based paint and plastics for years, and was the largest soy farmer in the Western hemisphere for a long time - so it may be geared towards that. Or it may just be Roundup resistant. We do know that US soy is linked to breast cancer, while Asian soy seems to prevent breast cancer. But that could be the fact that US soy products tend to be highly processed, while Asians eat it in more natural form. As for Monsanto employees, that's a loaded assertion you're making. And it misses the point. Arguments about the health risks and benefits of GMO foods are loaded with emotion, and can be seen from different perspectives. The real danger Monsanto, and the company's legal strategy regarding their intellectual property, presents has nothing to do with the food on our shelves. Monsanto has created monocultures for corn and soy, basically setting us back 5,000 years. If a disease that targets GMO corn shows up, we lose over 90% of our crop. That's the danger. It isn't the result of people selling their souls. It's the result of letting chemists and lawyers and bio-engineers take over the agriculture industry.  Embed Quote

column9: Some claims have said that it will increase packaging prices slightly. That's not a reasonable or justifiable excuse. column10: A number of reasons:Labeling is expensive. The sheer number of different products that contain GMO (by any definition) is significant. It might actually be simpler to label the foods that don't contain GMO, which basically what we do now, though inconsistently.What's GMO and what isn't isn't well defined. For GMO labeling laws to be enforced would require giving some body broad discretion to decide what is and isn't genetically modified. This is both undemocratic and creates a lot of uncertainty for businesses, as well as the usual opportunities for rent seeking and regulatory capture.You might expect that if some information is good, more is better. Yet people don't always make better decisions when given additional information. When the additional information is irrelevant, as GMO status is, it almost certainly results in worse consumer choices.There's a very understandable fear that arbitrarily marking certain foods as GMO could stigmatize them and put them at a competitive disadvantage. After all, you don't put warnings on things that are safe, and the medium is the message.Identifying GMO foods can be, and is being, accomplished voluntarily through various apps, websites, non-profit, or by the supermarket in-house. There doesn't seem to be any compelling reason why it can only be done by government mandate.It sets a dangerous regulatory precedent, shifting the burden of labeling from what consumers need to know to what consumer might want to know. What's next, marking the political donations of the company that makes it? The number of food-miles it traveled? Perhaps you want to know if the company that processes it gives its employees same-sex marriage benefits. Any of this stuff might be interesting, but it'd be important to only a small segment of the population. The bottom line is that there's an infinite number of things we might want to know about our food and where it came from. Given the limited attention span of consumer and the limited room on labels, there's clearly diminishing margins of return, and you have to draw a line somewhere.Opposing GMO labeling isn't a big priority to Monsanto, after all. Millions might seem like a lot to you, but according to their annual financial report for 2012, last year Monsanto took in 13.5 billion dollars in revenue.  Embed Quote

column10: If organic food suppliers think organic is superior, why not they write a single benefit of the organic food on the package?I am actually in support of label, i.e., providing more information. But a priory, people have unsupported beliefs. If the labels were neutral they would be beneficial. I care about the planet, so I eat GMO. You care about your own health more than the planet for that impractical 0.01% chance that GMO might cut your expected age by 2 days, so you eat organic. This would have been fine with me. If it were neutral.For now, I would like the labels to be detailed. I do not like the labels to be organic or GMO, but a detailed information. For an example, instead of saying organic, one must say.1. This food required 20% more land to produce, so caused more deforestation.2. The food did not use artificial pesticides, but used natural pesticides. It is not known whether natural pesticides are any safer.Instead of saying GMO, one could say:1. The plant was modified to produce 20% more vitamin A than naturally found.2. The plant was modified to be pest resistance which required 20% less use of pesticides.3. The plant was modified to require 20% less land area, therefore saved some trees and also helped keep the prices low.Rather than just listing food by organic or by GMO, it is better to just list the scientifically established facts. Personally, I have never seen any producer of organic food to write a single benefit of being organic, which tells me a lot.It is just sad that elitist people want to misguide the public. Personally, all the top science loving people I know, they prefer GMO over Organic. Labeling just GMO or Organic helps when common people are equally educated too.  Embed Quote

column10: The answer to this question is basic capitalism.  Monsanto has come to dominate the "back end" of industrial agriculture.  They dominate the seed and chemical market for the major commodity crops like corn, soy, canola, cotton, and sugar while the public is generally unaware.If GMO labeling were to pass, some, but not all consumers, would make an informed choice to avoid GMOs, and this would create alternative markets.  Currently, Monsanto has a monopoly on industrial seeds and chemicals.  Even if 10% of consumers started avoiding GMOs this would spell bad news for Monsanto shareholders and their stock prices.  Thus, the decision to spend large amounts of money to defeat labeling.  Embed Quote

column10: Because Monsanto believes it's cheaper to lobby politicians than to make their case in the court of public opinion. What they spend on lobbying would barely pay for a single television ad campaign. To some extent, the company is right and its stance is understandable. As Ryan has noted, the general American population does not have a particularly high degree of scientific literacy. And of course, Monsanto funds lobbying efforts because the potential profits make it well worth its while. And of course, in the back of their minds, I think Monsanto knows that they might lose the argument if they put it to the people. Not just because Americans are not scientifically literate, but because while GMO foods have not been "proven" to be dangerous or harmful yet, neither is there much evidence to show they are completely safe in the long-term. Part of this is simply that GMO foods have not been available for a long period of time, relative to a human lifetime. Things that look safe now, might turn out not to be -- and Monsanto knows this. Rather than risk losing customers like me who might choose not to take the risk, Monsanto would rather make it virtually impossible for me to avoid GMO foods. I'm not saying that you should need to show without any doubt whatsoever that GMO foods are safe for long-term consumption before bringing to market. But personally, I think consumers have the right to know. And the argument that a labeling requirement damages the brand because it automatically implies there's something wrong with GMO foods? Well, we label most other ingredients -- salt, sugar, various oils, wheat, corn, etc. That doesn't seem to have hurt sales at all. So I think that argument is bull.  Embed Quote

I think there are two pieces of information that may be helpful - stated strategy & the ag sector.If you look at the Gates Foundation website, it says "As a foundation, our goal is to ensure that all people—no matter where they live—have the chance to live a healthy, productive life. We're focused on using grantmaking and advocacy to help solve complex, entrenched problems that affect billions of people, including the AIDS and malaria epidemics, extreme poverty, and the poor state of American high schools."Businesses play a crucial role in helping to solve these problems, and we believe we can have the most impact on businesses by encouraging them directly to dedicate expertise and money to these problems. We publicly praise companies that are doing good work and try to persuade others to step up. Sometimes we make grants to for-profit companies to give them incentives to join the work. (Read more about our work with for-profit entities.)"From a humanitarian point of view, farming and the ability to feed one's self or one's family is one of great interest and Gates has several agricultural projects. One project that engages Gates Foundation and Monsanto together is on water efficient maize for Africa project. The project aims to find ways to provide greater stability in corn production in the wake of drought, which Africa has experienced many times. You can learn more at http://www.aatf-africa.org/wema/ about that project.  Embed Quote

column9: Why is it being seen as 'outrageous', 'dangerous' and betrayal? I'm curious about the details.
column10: Basic info: it's a provision in the Agricultural Appropriations Bill (AKA: HR 993) that passed through Congress last week. It's disliked because it protects biotech companies like Monsanto from litigation over their questionable practices/products. Per RT's report on the matter (the second quote does a good job explaining the negative sentiments) - http://rt.com/usa/monsanto-bill-...With the president’s signature, agriculture giants that deal with genetically modified organisms (GMOs) and genetically engineered (GE) seeds are given the go-ahead to continue to plant and sell man-made crops, even as questions remain largely unanswered about the health risks these types of products pose to consumers. ***James Brumley, a reporter for Investor Place, explains a little more thoroughly just how dangerous the rider is now that biotech companies are allowed to bypass judicial scrutiny. Up until it was signed, he writes,“the USDA [US Department of Agriculture] oversaw and approved (or denied) the testing of genetically modified seeds, while the federal courts retained the authority to halt the testing or sale of these plants if it felt that public health was being jeopardized. With HR 933 now a law, however, the court system no longer has the right to step in and protect the consumer.”  Embed QuoteAnswered in fourteen minutes via  Bhashkar Sharma.

column10: The relationships are likely due to the fact that many political appointees for FDA (The Food and Drug Administration) come from the food and drug industries and wish to be either employed or re-employed  by those industries when they complete their terms in office. Since  recommending or pursuing aggressive agendas against these businesses would harm these desires, they simply avoid pressing the industries too hard during their tenures.Also, the food and drug industries are major campaign contributors and , as such, have access to many high level members of Congress and the Executive Branch. This "access" allows them to "clarify" certain elements of teh policies in manners which public advocacy groups cannot. It also gives them allies (and potential future lobbyists) who have access to government even after they retire or leave public service.The food and drug industries, like the defense industries, energy companies and the financial industry simply have a vested interest in maintain their access to the power centers of American government. Not really a conspiracy; simply "business as usual."  Embed Quote

Carter that sought to manipulate food prices in the USSR. His effort was an abject failure as spelled out in this Foreign Affairs Magazine article:Lessons of the Grain EmbargoThe biggest problem is that grain -- like petroleum -- is a fungible commodity. If Country X won't sell it to Country A, Country Y will, perhaps with a price premium added. Worse, Country Z may buy Country X's product, then sell it to country A, also at a premium. The result is that Country X loses.  Embed Quote

It's misleading to compare genetic engineering to hybridizing. Hybridizing occurs only between closely related species, and the opportunities for radically different results are limited. You cross two food species, each known to be safe, and you're likely to get something that is also safe. There are no untested genes in there.When you incorporate a pesticide gene from a bacterium, or an antifreeze gene from a fish, you're adding genes very much unlike the ones already found there. Few genes are isolated in their effects: the cell is a bubbling cauldron of chemical reactions and introducing a new one causes unpredictable cascade effects down the line. It can create all kinds of new compounds, and we don't even know what they are.And even just the direct causes are worrying. When the gene is drawn from a non-food species, you have absolutely no idea whether it's something humans can eat or not. It will be tested in animals, but you can't test what happens when it accumulates over decades of human consumption. Still, humans have eaten novel foods all through their existence, and it's not entirely unreasonable to test things and pronounce them safe-enough, IF those tests are conducted properly. And frankly, I have no reason to believe that they are being conducted properly.The big agribusinesses have demonstrated themselves to be a right bunch of dicks in this area. Most obviously despicable is the case where Monsanto sued Percy Schmeiser, whose carefully-bred strain of canola was contaminated with Monsanto's proprietary genes, via pollen from another farm. GMOs that were not tested on humans have leaked into the human food chain, despite promises to the contrary. They fight against labeling, so that customers can't choose for themselves. They use misleading marketing to encourage farmers to replace their strains with Monsanto's strains, which have more genes in them to ensure that the results are sterile, so farmers must pay Monsanto every year and have usually lost the original stocks if they don't want to go back to it (and may well find them contaminated if they have). Those "terminator" genes serve absolutely no food purpose; they are there solely to ensure Monsanto's products.There are still more concerns, like the fact that GMOs are always designed to be grown in vast monocultures. There are severe environmental concerns associated with that style of growing food; it may not be sustainable no matter how safe the GMOs themselves are. Genes are introduced to make plants resistant to herbicides, meaning that your food is being doused with poisons, and it's of small comfort to know that the plant is safe. And weed resistance to those herbicides is springing up faster than the ag businesses claimed it would, so now we've got an extra gene in the food with zero benefit.But mostly, it's the fact that Monsanto is a bunch of dicks. It is conceivable that GMOs, like other technologies, can be used judiciously and carefully to improve overall food production. But Monsanto has frequently not been either judicious or careful, and are placing short-term profits over the long-term interests of people who eat food. The technology in the abstract may be beneficial, but the implementation of it justifies people being extremely wary of it.These are not problems that face hybrid crops. Hybrid crops do not rely on massive investments up front, and therefore do not encourage short-term profit taking. The genes from hybrid crops can't introduce novel genes into separate gene pools any more than they already were. The companies that push GMOs have motives that make them potentially dangerous, and have not shown themselves to be responsible in proportion to the risk.  Embed QuoteAnswered in forty-one minutes.

The big agribusinesses have demonstrated themselves to be a right bunch of dicks in this area. Most obviously despicable is the case where Monsanto sued Percy Schmeiser, whose carefully-bred strain of canola was contaminated with Monsanto's proprietary genes, via pollen from another farm. GMOs that were not tested on humans have leaked into the human food chain, despite promises to the contrary. They fight against labeling, so that customers can't choose for themselves. They use misleading marketing to encourage farmers to replace their strains with Monsanto's strains, which have more genes in them to ensure that the results are sterile, so farmers must pay Monsanto every year and have usually lost the original stocks if they don't want to go back to it (and may well find them contaminated if they have). Those "terminator" genes serve absolutely no food purpose; they are there solely to ensure Monsanto's products. Let's just analyse this passage from your argument, shall we?  Monsanto sued Percy Schmeiser because he was pirating seed.  Some of the Roundup Ready seed from a neighbour's farm had fallen into his field, and he found that when he sprayed his own crop with weedkiller it still grew the next year.  So he saved it and started growing his own Roundup Ready crop without paying royalties for several years.  Hardly a case of accidental contamination.  So Monsanto - quite rightly - took exception to this and sued him.  He lost in a court of law.  Monsanto have never sued any farmer whose crop was inadvertently pollenated by a GM variety, and have even offered to help to clean up after such an event.The 'terminator' technology you talk about has never been sold to anyone.  That's right:  it never made it out of a laboratory.  Yet this myth keeps on being uncritically absorbed and equally uncritically regurgitated.  Garbage in, garbage out.  Most hybrids don't produce viable seeds either and have to be bought year after year.If you're wondering why I'm writing this, I'm neither pro nor anti-GM:  each application has to be taken on its own merits.  What I am sick of is people disinterring the same old zombie arguments, and these people are almost exclusively anti-GM, and they seem to have little new, interesting or even truthful to offer as an argument.  If you're going to write drivel, make it original drivel, at least new if not very interesting, will you?  Embed Quote

column9: Of course. But I'm not inclined to have a pointless debate. I respect that there are views other than mine.
column10: I see each of these institution, in their own way, as adding great value to our society. Google has been particularly transformative in recent years. Each of these institutions had opponents who spread rumors which are often vicious and unfounded. And none of these companies is perfect and without mistakes. Some of them are even arrogant mistakes, I suppose. But I have the deepest respect for those who manage Google, Morgan, and Monsanto and I truly believe it is easier for some to take pot shots at them than it is for the leaders of these remarkable institutions to offer so much to so many.  Embed Quote

column9: I just read this article and the claims are horrific.  Is this factual?  Monsanto products - PCB's, polystyrene, plutonium production, DDT, Dioxin, Agent Orange, Roundup, Bovine Growth hormone and Terminator seeds.http://gmo-awareness.com/2011/05...
column10: Your question appears to involve intent.  From what I have read over the years, Monsanto is not some massive, evil organization doing everything in it's power to poison or fatten-up the population of the world.Sure, Monsanto is a chemical company and an agricultural biotech company.  Sure, Monsanto controls more than half of the seed produced in the world.  Sure, Monsanto has a dedicated and stellar legal team.  Sure, Monsanto has political influence in every country where it has products sold.All that means is that Monsanto is a company.  Companies don't sell health.  Companies sell anything that makes money.  For half of it's history, Monsanto sold plastics and ag chemicals.  For the other half, it sold seeds and GMOs.  Maybe in the next 50 years, solar panels will look profitable?  Maybe lightweight munitions for drones?  If it sells at a decent profit, Monsanto will look into it.I do not believe that Monsanto disregards the health of the people who directly buy their products.  The warning labels that farmers and farm workers see are detailed and explicit.  Monsanto even assists with proper handling and safety training for all of the chemicals that it sprays on agricultural fields.  The same goes for Agent Orange.  The pilots and loadmasters were all trained on proper safe handling and loading of the defoliant.  Monsanto protects it's customers.As far as the communities where Monsanto has plants, Monsanto has settled and paid damages for every case that it could not win in court.  And almost two dozen of the over 30 superfund sites associated with Monsanto are cleaned up now.  Monsanto takes care oF their communities.So, no, I do not think that Monsanto has a disregard for health.  That specific policy would not be profitable.  Embed QuoteVia  Catherine Goodman.

column9: I have a big problem with genetical manipulated food cause I fear about the environment and secondly about my security - we eat so much chemical and unnatural stuff I'm sure genetical manipulated food just has to be checked and then it can be eaten. But still I don't want it. So, my problem is not about Monsanto. What is evil about Monsanto in your opinion/what do you think why people are convinced it is evil?Please try to be neutral and if you think everyone who is against Monsanto is an idiot, don't say it like that.
column10: They are destroying our food supply because it's a sound short-term business strategy. They have turned our corn and soy crops into near genetic monocultures. Over 90% of those crops are genetically identical. That's very bad news if a fungus or bacteria they are susceptible to comes along. They have made it basically impossible for farmers to save seeds. Traditionally, a farmer kept the seeds from the best plants of each harvest so hey could be planted the next spring. That's how crops became hardier, or gave higher yields year over year. It's also how new varieties were created. That can't happen any more. Farmers who save seeds will be sued by Monsanto - without fail - and they will either lose or go bankrupt winning. The options are to buy seed from Monsanto, or buy it from the Argentinians. Most buy from Monsanto, because industrial food manufacturers aside from Birdseye and Green Giant (and the like) have no interest in Argentinian corn, and because once your crop is cross pollenated by Monsanto crops they own your ass anyway. So the only way change will be introduced into the corn or soy crops is if Monsanto develops those changes in their labs. They have, for all intents and purposes, cornered two of the most important crops in the world. If they screw up, or even if they don't screw up but something bad happens anyway, we're looking at starvation on a massive scale throughout the Third World, because the first world will buy all the food that would have gone to Africa and the poorer areas of Latin America. The risk they are exposing us to is unconscionable.  Embed Quote

column10: The whole GM crop / Monsanto thing puts me in a similar position to nuclear energy as done presently.There are very good reasons to be vehemently opposed to both, they're just not the reasons the more vocal opponents put forth most of the time.To stick with the question: I don't think GM crops are inherently bad. Speeding up the classical process of breeding new crop varieties could potentially solve some of the most pressing problems the world is facing now in the not-so-long-run.It's not like they're breeding Frankenstein's-Monster-like-plants, really. The real problem is with Monsanto's (and their peers) business model of controlling what farmers can grow, and how, and making GMOs that don't aim at being a better drop-in replacement for crops people grow, but at maximizing Monsanto's profit and only working well in semi-industrial farms is that it's ambition is to eliminate competition and introduce a single point of failure into a traditionally diverse and robust system.And then there are their atrocious business practices. I may be a bleeding-heart pinko-commie-old-world-liberal, but for example suing dirt-poor farmers struggling to survive for millions just doesn't strike me as the right thing to do…  Embed Quote

The effects of this are evil:The seed has to be bought again each season, which means that one bum crop in a country like India will typically cause one of two things: bankruptcy or farmer suicide. If you care for more reasons, there is that pesky matter of long term health studies that will never be performed.
