column9: Monsanto recently acquired the Climate Corporation for $930 million.  Is it worth the price?Monsanto Buys Climate Corp For $930 Million
column10: In order to answer this question, you have to have an understanding of both companies and why they are a good fit for each other.  Briefly.Climate.com is a high tech insurance company for farmers.  They sell insurance about rain and moisture levels for a farmer based on sophisticated climate models and data history.  This level of insurance can vary to very small areas of a field.  They have the capacity to make recommendations about which type of seeds to plant and when based on history, etc.  The cost of the insurance is higher for farmers that are making poor choices, but advising is built into the model.Monsanto was formed in 1901.  They have been involved in a lot of activities including the production of DDT.  However, that's a long time and a lot has changed.  There have been a lot of sales and acquisitions.  See wikipedia (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mon...) for more info.  For better or for worse the company Monsanto now is primarily a seed company, a herbicide company and a research company in these areas.  (Perhaps they should have changed the name?)  They also produce Golden Rice in an effort to prevent Vitamin A deficiency and death in children.GMO seeds.Imagine for a moment, that a farmer in Iowa wants to grow corn.  Over thousands of years he has figured out how to grow corn from the best seeds he has available for corn in Iowa.  Yet, Monsanto collected seeds from all over the world, and created a new seed that increased productivity.  The next goal was drought resistant and herbicide resistant.The acquisition is a good fit.  You have a multinational seed company that wants to become involved with technology and better serve their market.  You have a technology company based out of Silicon Valley / San Francisco that has climate modeling with farmers as their target market for selling an insurance product.  Both companies can benefit from the assets and strengths of the others including knowledge and flexibility.Is it worth it?  The cost of a Starbucks Latte isn't worth it to me, but the cost of the acquisition is clearly worth it to Monsanto.  Monsanto has an image and PR problem.  Climate.com is a high tech start up growth firm looking to hire.  Once they were acquired, they become a Monsanto subsidiary.  However, in order for this acquisition to be meaningful Climate.com has to still function as a company.  Current executives need to be retained and new employees have to remain interested in the company despite the image problem of working for "Monsanto."Disclaimer:  My husband is one of those that formerly worked at Climate.com.  I've learned more about Monsanto in the last few months than my entire life.  I believe there is a lot of misinformation that exists about a legacy company.  Embed Quote

column9: Monsanto is now trying to collaborate with Nepali company CG to sell GM seeds in Nepal. There're many voice on internet against this decision. The activists are claiming that Monsanto seeds are bad for poor farmers.I wanna know why?
column10: The Monsanto seeds are not bad.  They ought to make crops bigger and more efficient.  But it's not that simple.The complaint is that farmers have to now BUY seeds with cash, instead of saving seeds for free like they used to.  And the cash goes off-shore to Monsanto instead of to other farmers in your neighborhood.Farmers who do save seeds might have lower yields (perhaps) but much more genetic diversity.  Some traditional strains have been culitivated and perfected for hundreds if not thousands of years.  They have been carefully selected to grow in the local micro-climate.  And of course culturally it is important to have local specialties in YOUR village that are better than what those other people grow over there in THEIR village.  Heirloom tomatoes come in hundreds of tasty shapes, sizes and colours.  Modern tomatoes are not the same.  Modern tomatoes ship better, but they don't taste better.  That's just an example of the downside of the loss of genetic diversity.And all of those complaints started long before GM seeds were introduced.  Now we have GM crops.  They will spread (by pollen) their new genetics and "pollute" the genetics of the local seed-saver crops.  Because the genes are patented, the farmers can't save seeds from the GM crops, and they can't allow pollination from GM crops into their own fields.  That's a tough one!"Dilip Paudel, who has been working at the testing station, said  all　foreign hybrid seeds are unsuitable for Nepal because they have not  been bred for local conditions."Here at the National Maize  Research Program…we have good varieties of maize that have been tested  here," Paudel said. "They’re open pollinated varieties, not hybrids."Paudel said those types have proved successful in Nepal, "whereas  GMOs can be dangerous because they’re brought from the outside and  they’re a risk." [1]I'm not against GM seeds.  Maybe they are a good solution for the sophisticated farmer that is growing in North America.  But the GM seeds have not been tested in Nepal. So I agree there is a risk and it could prove to be bad for farmers in Nepal for any number of reasons, and Monsanto is profit-oriented first, and not overly concerned about the impact the seeds might have on local agriculture.  [1] Agronomists suspect GM seeds behind Nepal crop failure | Environment | DW.DE | 14.09.2010   Embed QuoteAnswered in forty-five minutes.

column9: After seeing much complaints about Monsanto here: What's so bad about Monsanto?If every possible person in the world planted Monsanto GM products from reused seeds on public lands, could they make it such a wide spread crop that it would:1) make it completely unfeasible to sue every planter2) completely ruin their profits and possibly the company3) force governments to address Monsanto's questionable business practices?
column10: What you are basically asking is for people to deconstruct the institution of plant intellectual property (IP).  So a hypothetical yes to #1; no to #2 because of hybrid corn; #3 is a loaded statement, and what's more likely to happen is government will reform IP, some way or another.Patent theory would also suggest that private investment and research would be substantially curtailed if people ignored it.  Innovation would continue to happen, but mostly through public investment, and therefore likely at a slower rate.This isn't a complete hypothetical.  Argentina decided not to protect Monsanto's patent on RoundUp Ready, after farmers did exactly as you stated (Argentina probably has the highest percentage of soybeans planted as GMO, at at least 98%).  A lot of private companies have thus been reluctant for the past decade to invest new biotech research into Argentina (not surprisingly, Monsanto even making attempts to pull out completely from breeding there).  However, it can be difficult to determine the exact effects of this action.Other notes:Regarding #2: Hybrids provide an inherent form of variety protection.  Replanting seed from hybrid corn produces inferior seed the next generation.  It's how the private seed industry expanded in the first place (in the 1930's in the US), even absent intellectual property rights.  Considering hybrid corn constitutes the most important section of every major seed company, Monsanto nor any other company would be completely ruined.A signal of weak protection for intellectual property would likely have knock-on effects in other industries, particularly biotech and pharmaceuticals.  Embed Quote

column9: After seeing much complaints about Monsanto here: What's so bad about Monsanto?If every possible person in the world planted Monsanto GM products from reused seeds on public lands, could they make it such a wide spread crop that it would:1) make it completely unfeasible to sue every planter2) completely ruin their profits and possibly the company3) force governments to address Monsanto's questionable business practices?
column10: Could civil disobedience ruin Monsanto? Perhaps. You'd have to turn political awareness into a change in intellectual property law in most countries. Specifically, you'd need rulings that: Protect a farmer from license liability if GM seeds show up naturally. Create liability for "polluting" a field with GM seeds on the part of the "originating" farmer. Disallow "owning" biological strains. Changing law is slow. In the short run, with tens of thousands of "pirated" GM seeded farmers... It's pretty cheap to sue. Up front costs are not trivial but quite doable. Early wins pay for wider lawsuits. Laws and precedents today makes wins likely. So dozens of suits leads to hundreds of suits lead to thousands. Suits are a sales tactic. If Monsanto can't collect before planting through marketplace sales they'll collect after planting through litigation. And with each suit will be an offer to settle if the farm chooses to become a Monsanto licensee forever. Since "leakage" is guaranteed, so is litigation. There may be diminishing returns once everyone has switched to Monsanto GM seeds, but that is decades away. Now every GM farmer with a non-GM neighbor is lining up Monsanto salesmen and lawyers for negotiation. In other words, when you buy Monsanto seeds for yourself, you're signing up your whole region.    Public sentiment is on Monsanto's side. Unlike RIAA's fiasco suing small children, Monsanto would be suing businesses worth billions. Monsanto has a lobbying advantage over opponents. Monsanto is large with a single voice where the opposition and small farmers are scattered, lightly organized, and underfunded.  So your plan to spread Monsanto GM seeds everywhere is likely to make them more profitable, more powerful, and have greater reach before public policy changes to limit their reach.  Embed QuoteAnswered in sixty minutes via  Paul Núñez.

column9: After seeing much complaints about Monsanto here: What's so bad about Monsanto?If every possible person in the world planted Monsanto GM products from reused seeds on public lands, could they make it such a wide spread crop that it would:1) make it completely unfeasible to sue every planter2) completely ruin their profits and possibly the company3) force governments to address Monsanto's questionable business practices?
column10: In addressing the inquiry, "If every possible person in the world planted Monsanto GM products from reused seeds...” For just this part of the question alone, I would simply say NO!     There is a lot to say on the subject, but a short answer would be that GM seeds are mutilated and they have built in herbicides. They are also made to work with external herbicides. Monsanto's seeds are particularly made to work with Monsanto brand chemicals.  The Roundup brand is one of the herbicides that they make. In using these products, some farmers reported at least two things. First, some crops won't grow without the chemicals. Second, tons of chemicals douse the plants during their time in the fields.      So this means people eat herbicides on the outside and on the inside of the final product whether it is made from natural or unnatural components.  If everyone planted these monster seeds/crops, they could ruin the major foods for the entire earth; extinct, never to return. Like other plants, GM plants cross pollinate. Healthy plants in the neighborhood will, without a doubt, be contaminated so the second and future generations of seeds and crops will not be pure. There is already a high percentage of organic and non-organic food contamination sold in stores; including high end health oriented grocery stores. A small percentage of GM is acceptable in some places.      With this in mind, a higher percentage of DNA in healthy people will be changed. Yep. It’s true. There has been reportings of DNA changes in people. There have also been reportings that so much Roundup is used on a daily basis that it is in our air, water, and urine. Never mind the high percentage already in our food. We eat, drink, and breath Monsanto and other companies like them. As a result, more seeds planted will mean more allergies, cancer, celiac, birth defects, and other health issues. Think about it. If everyone planted those seeds, then we would all be contributors to mass destruction. Mass suicide?      Also, if this happens, Monsanto would still hold world power as they may continue to manufacture ways to make their frankenfoods produce better in places where people need help with growing food; poverty, deserts, etc. Also, if they continue to hole a patent on crops that are planted intentionally and those that are accidental, people will still have to do business with Monsanto to live. If the people win law suits against Monsanto, then this will stop.     If Monsanto and their affiliated companies unleash the suicide seed, then we would all be kissing Monsanto’s back end for the rest of our days. Those things cross pollinate too. They will kill any chance of saving seeds for replanting. Suicide seeds only live once. If you plant a crop, it will produce seeds, but the new seeds will be sterile. Monsanto gave a weak/un-solid promise to now use these suicide seeds out of context. I don’t believe them. Money is the bottom line. Anyway, This means that EVEYONE will have to continue to buy seeds from Monsanto for each crop.     Monsanto is already a multi-billion dollar company, but this will definitely give them world domination. People all over the earth will starve because this is very expensive. In America we may have choices of alternative crops, but some other places thrive on wheat, rice, corn, etc. Now, if GM crops were the majority choice for food, the Monsanto can continue to come up with more chemicals to keep away bugs and weeds that have become immuned to their previous herbicides. There was a reporting where a particular weed became a super weed and grew about seven feet tall with a base about the width of a wrist. People will pay to spray weeds rather than walk for hours to pull them. They will save time and money on hired manual labor. It is a vicious cycle.      Some folks/companies who are aware of this very real world possibility are putting heirloom seeds in vaults. We should all be prepared in case the future is a dim one. On a positive note, I think the world will get together and stop this madness. Whether things are good or bad, you can choose to be healthier by purchasing organic foods and heirloom seeds for certain types. Overview - If real food disappears/becomes short in supply, you don't want to plant Monsanto seeds. Not even in desperation. Heck no. You want to plant real food that will be free of GM contamination, free of pesticides and herbicides, and free of DNA manipulation. You want to live. You want the people, animals, and other beings of the world to live. Say NO to GMO and learn more about the subject. The education can help you survive.  Embed Quote

As Joey McLaughlin says, Monsanto doesn't do farming. They produce seeds.If you want to know if the thing you're eating was grown from Monsanto seeds... if you bought it at the grocery store, you can just basically assume that the answer is "yes". If it wasn't, it was probably produced by DuPont, which is essentially the same thing as far as a question like this is concerned. (That is, they're a giant agribusiness and they produce GMO seeds. Monsanto is bigger and thus the poster child for anti-GMO, but DuPont is little different.)What you probably really want to know is if it's genetically modified. And the answer is that if what you've got in your hand is a vegetable, then probably not. There were some GMO tomatoes, and there's a little bit of GMO sweet corn out there, but most vegetables are conventional hybrids.The GMOs show up primarily in soy and maize (not sweet corn, but the corn used to make industrial products). This is the vast majority of vegetables grown in the US, but you don't get them on your plate. They're used to feed livestock or turned into other products.If your goal is to avoid Monsanto products, just because you hate them (and they are some mighty dickwads), your only solution is to (a) go to your local farmer's market, and (b) ask the farmer.  Commercial produce is nearly certain to be the product of big agribusinesses, and they nearly always use the most productive seeds they can get; i.e. the hybrids that the major seed companies produce. That's how they got to be the major seed companies.Because of that, local producers also use a lot of Monsanto seeds. If you want to know for sure what seeds were used, you have to ask the farmer. They'll probably be the ones charging the most, though you may find that their products are the tastiest. (Breeding for productivity means not breeding for taste.)Oh, and it means you need to avoid pretty much anything with commercial meat (even the organic products are made with non-GMO Monsanto seeds) or any processed foods, which will almost certainly contain corn or soy byproducts (oils, corn syrup [high fructose or otherwise], etc etc etc).  Embed Quote

If you really want to tickle your nerd-fancy, find a lab (biohacker spots can probably achieve this) and run a simple molecular test.In GMO engineering, herbicide tolerance is the main trait introduced into crops, which include resistance to Monsanto's Roundup Ready herbicide. The three genetic elements that are most commonly introduced include the camV35 promoter, the ESPS gene, and the NOS terminator. The camV35 promoter is derived from the cauliflower mosaic virus, which allows expression of the introduced transgene. The ESPS gene allows the plant to become resistant to Roundup, a proprietary herbicide from Monsanto -- it kills "unwanted" plants whereas GMO plans survive. It's mechanism of action is that Roundup inhibits the gene product of ESPS such that amino acid synthesis is shut down and the plant dies. The transgenic version of ESPS, however, is slightly different in structure from the endogenous version, and therefore is resistant to Roundup. Finally, the NOS terminator (nopaline synthase) allows for termination and regulation of the ESPS transgene and is originally cloned from Agrobacterium tumefaciens.Very simply the steps are...Extract DNA from your GMO food in question. There are many commercial kits available. This one should do.Once you have your DNA, PCR for camV35, ESPS, and NOS. Here are some magical primers!camv35-F ccgacagtggtcccaaagatg 158bp productcamv35-R agaggaagggtcttgcgaaggNOS-F gaatcctgttgccggtcttg 225bp productNOS-R gcgggactctaatcataaaaaccESPS is left as an exercise to the readerUse standard PCR conditions with the Tm of the primers. Multiplex reactions probably make this easier3.  Visualize PCR products on a gel along with appropriate controls.4.  If you see a band, then voila - it's probably GMO food.5.  And if you want to beat a dead horse, there are ELISA kits for detection of ESPS at the protein level.  Embed Quote

If it was taken from a Monsanto research facility. Otherwise, there is no chance your food was produced by Monsanto. Monsanto is in the businesses of seed production, herbicides, and intellectual property related to genetic material and biotechnology traits -- not food.  Embed Quote

column9: Monsanto's goal is to cure hunger for the world because we are slowly overpopulating it, do you think it will solve the problem, or something of the other?
column10: HaHaHa! Monsanto's goal is to cure hunger? Sorry to burst your bubble with reality, but Monsanto's goal is to make money.  Embed QuoteAnswered in five minutes.
A description of some past and current products:Monsanto's Dirty Dozen  Embed Quote

What problems?  What's wrong with the current system?<The rest of the answer was written before edits to the question details.>Farmers sign agreements which are licenses (think of a software license), agreeing not to clean and replant seed.  These agreements are protected by patent law (for the technology, and often for the seed as well).  In the United States, there is also a weaker form of protection is called plant variety protection.  (See: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pla...) This allows the replanting of seed the purchased acreage, and most conventional varieties fall under this protection.  Prior to the extensive full-patenting of biotech traits, all varieties were released under this model.  To my knowledge, all public varieties are still released under PVP.  The PVPA was instrumental to encouraging private investment into self-pollinated, non-hybrid crops such as soybeans.For the most part, the business model and intellectual property law works, though I'd argue the IP laws could use some updates.  Farmers can choose to plant cheaper seed that may be conventional, PVP, or even ex-PVP.  Many farmers choose to take one of these routes.  There are also many competitors with different pricing and marketing strategies; traits are shared through licensing and royalty agreements.  Farmers complain about seed prices, but seed demand is not inelastic.  A good example was Monsanto's Smartstax, which bombed in its first year of sales, largely because it was overpriced Monsanto growth falters as SmartStax yields, pricing raise questions   : Business.A very interesting situation will be the expiration of Roundup Ready 1 on soybeans in 2015.  Roundup Ready Soybean Patent Expiration.  We will likely see many farmers cleaning and planting RR1 seed rather than purchasing from Monsanto or its competitors.  I also expect breeders to incorporate their trait even more extensively than current practice.  Embed Quote

They might try not outright lying to their customers, and/or delivering a well-defined, value-adding product without undisclosed strings attached. Optimally working in concert with the majority of their clientele to advance their interests. As opposed to those of the biggest 5% (or so) of the clientele. And economically killing everyone that isn't able or willing to work quite like that.Oh: If they managed to not get known as the company starving peoples and obliterating ecosystems, cultures, and whatever gets in the way of a tidy profit, that might help their image tremendously, too.  Embed QuoteAnswered in thirty minutes.

column9: Why are they fighting being labeled? and they are the manufacturers of agent orange used in Vietnam.

column10: First, it is illogical to assume that a corporation cares about anything good or bad.  Corporations are made up of people.  As a farmer, I purchase Monsanto products as well as many other companies in the agriculture industry.  Everyone I have interacted with from the company seems incredibly genuine and sincere about the business they are in of using science to better meet the needs of the global population.  I have had the opportunity to tour their research facilities, to see the attention to safety along with innovation.Some  may disagree with their focus, but I think it's pretty hard to question the integrity, honesty, and passion of those that work there.  Embed Quote

column10: Corporations are typically only concerned with profit.  If Monsanto decided that care for the consumer, farmer, or community would increase their profit, then they would care if their product did harm.Monsanto products do not specifically harm humans.  At best, RoundUp is mildly toxic to humans, and only in concentrated applications.  Monsanto crops, GMO in nature, have not been found to be harmful to humans.Monsanto products HAVE been shown to be harmful to the environment, especially to native species and marine/aquatic ecosystems.  Embed Quote

column10: The question is based on a faulty premise if you are saying because of their involvement with agent orange, they don't care. Monsanto only produced agent orange during a time of war when it was required to by the US government. The government accepts all liability assumed with the use o f the product. If you'd like more info, its available at Agent Orange: Background on Monsanto's InvolvementOn the other topic, Monsanto's employees (I am one) are involved in agriculture. For many of us, we work there in part due to our passion that come with providing food for our families and communities. A farmer can't keep them outGMOs nearby will cross pollinate Monsanto's products trespass onto farmer's properties. Monsanto: Can Farmers sue Montsanto when their genetically modified organisms contaminate their crops?More Farmers Sue Monsanto Over GMO WheatThe farmers contend that Monsanto failed to take steps to make sure the genetically engineered plants didn't contaminate regular wheat through cross-pollination, mixing of seeds or other means. Because the wheat industry uses a system that gathers and commingles wheat from thousands of farms for sales and shipping, the farmers contend Monsanto should have known that it would be virtually impossible to prevent the Roundup Ready wheat from infiltrating the non-genetically engineered wheat supply."Monsanto knew, or should have known, that the existence of genetically-engineered wheat – commingled with the general wheat supply – would cause significant disruptions in the wheat export market, and that such a situation could involve huge disruptions in the wheat trade while imposing additional costs on U.S. wheat farmers and specifically Pacific Northwest soft white wheat farmers. These costs eventually would detrimentally impact worldwide prices for Pacific Northwest soft white wheat, causing significant financial damage to wheat farmers," attorney Benjamin Schwartzman wrote in the lawsuit.The farmers say the discovery of the genetically engineered wheat growing in Oregon has diminished prices for all soft white wheat because of the loss of export and domestic markets, and that it has also increased costs for growers who must go through extensive testing to prove the wheat from their fields isn't contaminated with genetically engineered wheat before they can sell to some buyers.They are asking for compensatory and punitive damages in an amount to be determined at trial, and they want a judge to order Monsanto to decontaminate the farmland and transportation and harvesting equipment of all affected farmers.Even GMOs just tested can't be controlled:Kansas Farmer Sues MonsantoThe modified wheat was discovered when field workers at an eastern Oregon wheat farm were clearing acres and came across a patch of wheat that didn't belong. The workers sprayed it, but the wheat wouldn't die. It was then sent to a university lab in early May.Tests at Oregon State University confirmed the plants were a strain developed by Monsanto to resist its Roundup Ready herbicides that were tested between 1998 and 2005. At the time, Monsanto had applied to the USDA for permission to develop the engineered wheat, but the company later withdrew that.  Embed Quote

I'm not a scientist of any kind, but I did have some interesting conversation with a geneticist friend who worked on genetically engineered crops. It's an ongoing discussion in China, since a lot of people have some really hilarious idea about transgenic crops (such as if you eat genetic engineered food, you'll gene will change...) So I went to ask my friends just what exactly is the harm of genetically engineered crop. And this is a summary of our conversation, it could very well be wrong, I have no way to know, since I really know nothing about this subject. 1, genetically engineered food is safe. Consumption of such food doesn't have any known negative effect on human health. 2, the problem with genetically engineer food is not with safety, but much more complicated and sinister, it's about company monopoly. Unlike natural crops or vegetables, most transgenic food is designed not to produce viable seed. That means if Chinese population (since at the time we're mostly talking about transgenic food in China) relay on foreign seed, they'll have monopoly on one of the most important resources. And that is the real problem for genetically engineered crops, it could impact on a country's livelihood, make it dependent on foreign seed import (unless we have our own genetic crops). I guess with Monsanto, it makes America dependent on a large company, that could be very bad indeed.  Embed Quote

No. The crops currently sold by Monsanto have been through rigorous testing and regulatory vetting processes to determine their approval for food and feed. It is important to note that a few of the other answers here are focused on GMOs and that is certainly part of the discussion, however, it is only a part. The company has a number of crops that have been enhanced with biotechnology but there are also a significant number of crops that Monsanto has enhanced through traditional crop breeding (think Gregor Mendel) or advanced molecular breeding (more precise and yet is still within the same crop species). There are miniature sweet bell peppers, broccoli, melons, etc that have not undergone any biotech changes. On the crops using biotech, a vast number of advances have been made within those crops through breeding and then there are selected traits added to provide a specific effect (insect resistance, disease resistance, herbicide tolerance, abiotic stress resistance or quality improvements). The details are best discussed by scientists, but lots of scientific bodies have weighed in soundly supporting the science as safe once all the tests are run (toxicity, allerginicity, environmental impact, etc), reviewed and regulatory bodies approve them. Some of the countries involved have put their safety guidelines on the web, here's a list of some to use in your review UK Food Standards Agency - GM foodsEuropean Food safety Authority (EFSA) FAQ on genetically modified organismsFood Standards Australia New ZealandHealth Canada Genetically Modified (GM) Foods and Other Novel FoodsUSA Food and Drug Administration Statement of Policy - Foods Derived from New Plant VarietiesJapanese Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare Food Produced by Recombinant DNA TechniquesAdditionally, I have a reply to another question that asked about objective sources of information that may be helpful -- see Genetically Modified Organisms (GMO): What are some good (unbiased, scientific) sources of information about the safety of GMO products?  Embed QuoteVia  Jesse Lashley.

Monsanto crops are not harmful to humans in general.  While some people and physicians have reported adverse effect to GMO presence in a daily diet, there are no specific links to crops from Monsanto or any other agricultural company and human disease.There are two caveats, however.  The majority of Monsanto crops are grown for seed or feed, not for human consumption.  These crops are designed for long-term storage or non-human nutrition.  They don't taste good, either.  Monsanto does have several lines designed for human consumption, and those are not specifically dangerous to humans.Also, Monsanto does produce RoundUp, an herbicide which has some mild toxicity in mammals during application, and severe toxicity on marine organisms.  Improper exposure to this chemical during or shortly after application to crops can cause some illness.  Since Monsanto holds the patents on RoundUp Ready crops, this may lead to the idea that Monsanto crops can directly cause illness.  This has not be proven, however.  Embed QuoteVia  Jesse Lashley.

David SuzukiUnknown. Each is different. GMO foods are a recent creation and relatively untested. This question is kind of like asking are peanuts safe. Peanuts are safe for some but now we know they can kill others. Thats why peanuts are always labeled.The companies pushing GE foods are mainly the pesticide companies led by Monsanto. Their tests report their products are safe. But tests by the pesticide companies run less than 90 days. The tests are on rats not humans. The results are controlled and released by the pesticide companies that may be influenced by their profit motive in the same way the tobacco companies were influenced to say cigarettes were not addictive and did not cause cancer. This is why independent research is so important.Do Seed Companies Control GM Crop Research?A number of studies from outside the industry show issues. Independent tests longer then 90 days on GMO maize showed tumors in rats. This was published and still available in the prestigious journal 'Food and Chemical Toxicology'.		 	 	 														Long term toxicity of a Roundup herbicide and a Roundup-tolerant genetically modified maize 									These tests were criticized:Hyped GM maize study faces growing scrutinyMany scientists feel that there is a a lack of science , dearth of research and far too much control by the pesticide industry:Scientist: GM Food Safety Testing Is "Woefully Inadequate"The pesticide companies use deception and threatening in their tactics to researchers, farmers, academics and government officials.Monsanto Threatens to Sue Vermont if Legislators Pass a Bill Requiring GMO Food to Be LabeledGMO 'Right to Know' campaign in CT fails — Lawsuit threatenedDocumented Deceptions of No on 37 CampaignResearchers respond to harassment by the pesticide industry:Seralini and Science: an Open LetterSome history. Why the FDA does not regulate or require research on GE foods.Genetically modified crops are the result of a technology developed in the 1970s that allow genes from one species to be forced into the DNA of unrelated species. The inserted genes produce proteins that confer traits in the new plant, such as herbicide tolerance or pesticide production. The process of creating the GM crop can produce all sorts of side effects, and the plants contain proteins that have never before been in the food supply. In the US, new types of food substances are normally classified as food additives, which must undergo extensive testing, including long-term animal feeding studies. If approved, the label of food products containing the additive must list it as an ingredient.There is an exception, however, for substances that are deemed “generally recognized as safe” (GRAS). GRAS status allows a product to be commercialized without any additional testing. According to US law, to be considered GRAS the substance must be the subject of a substantial amount of peer-reviewed published studies (or equivalent) and there must be overwhelming consensus among the scientific community that the product is safe. GM foods had neither. Nonetheless, in a precedent-setting move that some experts contend was illegal, in 1992 the FDA declared that GM crops are GRAS as long as their producers say they are. Thus, the FDA does not require any safety evaluations or labels whatsoever. A company can even introduce a GM food to the market without telling the agency.Such a lenient approach to GM crops was largely the result of Monsanto’s legendary influence over the US government. According to the New York Times, “What Monsanto wished for from Washington, Monsanto and, by extension, the biotechnology industry got. . . . When the company abruptly decided that it needed to throw off the regulations and speed its foods to market, the White House quickly ushered through an unusually generous policy of self-policing.” According to Dr. Henry Mill... (more)Loading...

It depends on what you consider "harmful".Any answer I may be able to give would just come off as short or incomplete, so I'll just link this documentary (exquisitely narrated by Jeremy Irons) on genetically engineered crops and their harmful effects on human society.Seeds of Freedom  Embed Quote

We don't know.Monsanto and any supporters of Genetically Modified Organisms (GMO) will tell you that they are not harmful and perfectly safe to eat. They'll cite studies and propose the USA as a perfect case-study of a large population routinely eating and consuming GMO without ill effects.The most extreme opponents will tell you that these foods are harmful and that the American large corporations that make them don't want you to know, and they may propose a conspiracy theory about what these companies are doing.The reality is probably somewhere is the middle: there are no long term studies about these foods. And, probably most damning, no long term studies done by truly independent sources, as well as a very strong opposition by these corporations mentioned above to have such studies. The reason is simple: they could be liable for any potential harm that they cause, plus people would be scared away from their products. Neither thing is good from a business perspective.However, Monsanto is not necessarily an evil company. Their business is to sell herbicides and seeds and they should be expected to do anything in their power to make their business successful. On the other hand, the FDA, whose job is to protect the American consumers, has been perceived by some as too quick to accept the assurances of safety of all GMO producers. The FDA had initially proposed an introduction to the American market with GMO labeling (similar to the EU), but after initial studies found that items like baby food and sodas would need labeling, it gave in to pressure from the Food Industry Lobby. This is what strengthened the conspiracy theories out there.Many people argue that GMO crops saved humanity from impending calamity by increasing yields and allowing farmers in the third world to feed more people than ever before. But others argue that modern growing techniques are also greatly responsible, without the need for stronger and stronger pesticides or herbicides.And then, there's the issue of patent infringement, which is the tool Monsanto and other companies have used to force farmers to buy their seed and drive out of business anyone who interferes with their profits. This has nothing to do with the quality of their seeds or whether its harmful, but it does cast these companies in a bad light.The combination of a Lobby powerful enough to force the US Government to eliminate even labeling of GMO food, plus the lack of serious studies by independent parties, plus the strong-arming of farmers to buy new seed each time they plant (even though this is something farmers had never done before) creates the image of a company capable of doing anything to maximize its profits, including harming its customers. Could they be hiding something? They could. But we know that it is very hard to keep those secrets for long. Not allowing serious studies to find out either way is a better strategy.Personally, I think that what is truly harmful is the type of farming that these companies propose. They invented RoundUp, a very powerful herbicide and then, they created seeds that could survive RoundUp so that crops could be routinely sprayed with it. This is what most Americans ate for the past decade.It doesn't stop there, however. Mother Nature is very resourceful and we have RoundUp-fast weeds that are causing problems to all farmers (GMO or not). So the answer is to spray crops with a cocktail of RoundUp and other similarly tough herbicides, while using the latest "version" of their seeds, which resist all of them. Monsanto and their likes are educating farmers about these crops today and they are no planning on changing the strategy. If a new super weed emerges, they'll come up with a new herbicide to add to the cocktail and a few more genes to tweak in their seeds.I don't think this is a sustainable strategy in the long term, and I also believe that it is harmful for all of us. Having a bunch of nasty super weeds growing all over the country cannot possibly be viewed as a "necessary evil". The strategy, however, is driven by a small group of guys whose only driver is to make sure the company meets the next Quarter's numbers. I don't think it's very smart of the rest of us to let them decide how we grow crops indefinitely.In closing, Monsanto's seeds and the crops they produce may or may not be harmful for people, but the strategy that the company is currently following is not sustainable in the long term and is already having adverse effects on the environment. It may, if there's a long period between the appearance of a new super weed and its corresponding fix, hinder our ability to grow enough food to meet our needs. But then it'll be too late to try to go back to "normal".  Embed Quote

Regardless of the discussion here the math is simple.As land to clear dwindles, and the crop yield growth falls, we will still need to grow 70% more food by 2050. That’s what the UN’s Food and Agriculture Organization figures is necessary to feed the 9 billion humans expected by mid-century.Last century’s technology will not be enough. Remarkable gains from the Green Revolution during the 1960s--petrochemical fertilizers, pesticides, irrigation, and improved strains--are now nearly tapped out. One of the next "revolutions" on the horizon, genetically modified (GM) crops whose genes have been altered with DNA from other plants or animals. It is battling controversy even as it slowly spreads around the world.Scared Of Genetically Modified Food? It Might Be The Only Way To Feed The WorldThe evidence for the paranoia so far?So far, there is no conclusive evidence, but no major studies have found genetically modified plants pose a great danger, particularly when compared to the toxic chemical and destructive farming practices we employ today (a recently trumpeted French study [PDF] showing tumors in experimental rats fed GM food was shown to be seriously flawed). Yet those risks have kept countries in Europe and Africa (except South Africa) almost completely GM-free for decades.Scared Of Genetically Modified Food? It Might Be The Only Way To Feed The WorldIt gets worst when factless propaganda influences in desicions that could have potentially save MILLIONS of lives. For example, in 2002 Zambia, where three million people are facing food shortages, rejected thousands of tons of free maize from America because some of it is genetically modified. Are you kidding me?I can't use better words than Penn & Teller to say this:"Unless you and yours are starving, you need to SHUT THE FUCK UP"  Embed Quote

In short, yes,  Monsanto's products are harmful to humans to eat, but the reasons go far beyond the GMO debate.This questions specifically asks about Monsanto, so I will address Monsanto's products and not make this about GMOs in general.  There is a difference.  Monsanto does not design products to help humanity.  They design products for profit.  They are creating products that are used in vast monocultures, and the ingredients that are processed from Monsanto's crops are some of the worst things humans eat.  Lets name a few:-high fructose corn syrup-hydrogenated fat -corn chips-factory farm feeds that are used in CAFO operations worldwide-White sugar form GMO sugar beets (most likely what you are eating is the label just says (Sugar)-Roundup ( It's not on the label, but if you eat GMOs, you eat Roundup )In the past Monsanto has been responsible or irresponsible for such atrocities as:-Agent Orange-DDT-RBGH ( Growth Hormone for Dairy Cows.You will often hear people make the comment that Monsanto has to prove their products are safe.  Wrong!  Monsanto has a revolving door with its executives and the government.  See the chart below:These are scary places for a company like Monsanto to have high levels of influence.Humans are cutting down South American rain forests to grow more GMO soy to feed animals.  This in the long term will be more harmful than eating the stuff directly.  If Monsanto continues to push its crops this will be all the rain forests:In the short term, you will most like experience little problems form eating Monsanto's GMOs, aside from the fact that GMOs are mostly in the most highly process and unhealthy foods to begin with.  At best you will experience no obvious problems.  At worst you will have mild allergic reactions, stomach aches, and generally feel unwell.  When I consume GMOs without knowing (I avoid them when I know they in something), I feel pretty awful, but I eat so little processed food that it is hard to tell if it is the processing or the GMOs.In the long term it is a big enormous question.  While I think the above is enough to say these products are harmful Let's talk briefly on the GMO aspects.There are 2 types of GMO crops on the market:1) Roundup Ready crops -  Monsanto scientists found bacteria that was resistant to Roundup near one of their factories and someone at the company had a brilliant thought that sounded somethings like this: "Let's put this in the food supply, so we can make more money!"  They inserted DNA from this bacteria into soybean DNA and when you spray the soy with Roundup the soy lives and every other plant in the field is supposed to die.  The plant drinks the Roundup and the majority of Americans eat it.  Roundup is a mass chelator.  It kills plants by binding nutrients.  When you ingest it, it does the same to you.2)  Bt Crops -  Bacillus thuringiensis is a naturally occuring bacteria that makes the stomachs of insects bust open.  When gathered up and put into a solition in a spray bottle, it can be used as a relatively safe insecticide.  However, it clearly says on the bottle, "Do not ingest."  Monsanto had the brillant idea to genetically engineer crops to create this bacteria themselves.  It worked, and now Bt corn makes this bacteria in concentrations 1000 times greater than naturally occurring.  A Canadian study found Bt in the blood of 93% of pregnant women and 80% of their unborn fetuses.Since the introduction of GMOs in the food supply in 1996, there has been a huge spike in chronic illness in Americans. Europeans barely eat GMOs and have significantly less chronic illness. Not proof, but a strong correlation.There are almost no independent studies to support the safety and validity of Monsanto's crops. Monsanto has been ruthless in their assurance that universities stay away from testing their products and the government and Monsanto have a revolving door.  Embed QuoteVia  Jesse Lashley.

column9: What would be the equivalent of "open source" for genetically modified seeds?  Can they be only free as in beer, and not free as in speech? What open source contributions have been made for production of GM seeds?
column10: This may not be entirely accurate, but it reflects the "de facto" state of the industry.I'll start off with the exception: Glowing Plants: Natural Lighting with no Electricity.  These guys are part of the growing "synthetic biology" community that is hoping to make molecular biology more open-source to the public.  They're running into a lot of regulatory problems.On to the seed industry:All GMOs are currently either highly regulated (those under research and undergoing regulatory approval) or are under patent protection (but "deregulated").So there are no "open-source" GMOs.But patents expire.  One of the most important events (genes), Monsanto's Roundup Ready 1 (RR1) in soybeans is coming off patent in 2015 in the United States, and the trait will be free-to-use after that.  Roundup Ready Soybean Patent ExpirationBut the legal landscape is more complicated than that.  Many countries still regulate RR1, so the expiration applies only to a few countries.  Also, while the individual gene has a utility patent, many plant varieties are also protected under utility patents and softer IP protection including plant patents (since 1930) and "plant variety protection" (since 1970).  http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pla...Keep in mind a lot of seed genetics (germplasm) are already open-source.  The USDA germplasm system (GRIN) is a free-to-request system for research purposes; they'll even pay the shipping costs (Request Germplasm).  I don't exactly know what the decision will be regarding GMOs.  For soybeans, the USDA collection made a decision not to maintain GMOs years ago (I worked at the soybean germplasm collection).  I can foresee some centralized collections of GMOs in the future, but I imagine there would some level of isolation/separation from the current collections.  Embed Quote

column9: What would be the equivalent of "open source" for genetically modified seeds?  Can they be only free as in beer, and not free as in speech? What open source contributions have been made for production of GM seeds?
column10: I've asked Richard Stallman about this, he said he didn't know how free software ideas could be applied. The closest to open-source projects would be the iGem competition's bioBricks library, parts are available in-vitro for participants, and online in a database (Main Page - parts.igem.org). Most of the parts are poorly tested or poorly annotated, in my experience of searching the database. If you actually have an idea, you can find lots of information through academic articles, which you then would need to cross-reference with a patent search or (have a lawyer if you're serious about commercialization) contact the authors.  Embed Quote

I lived in DeKalb, IL which is one of the locations of Monsanto.  When I first arrived in DeKalb, there was no Monsanto corporation there.  We had DeKalb Genetics of which Annie Glidden played a big part.  Annie Glidden was a quirky personality who was one of the pioneers of the day in Agriculture.  According to her great niece who I once heard speak at my church, she never married and she was known to keep farm equipment in her living room.  Agriculture was her life. She had a degree in agriculture.  She went to College when it was not customary for women to go to college.  She was involved with the DeKalb Agricultural Association which was later to become DeKalb Genetics.According to an article published by the Northern Star, Annie lived from 1865 to 1965. http://northernstar.info/campus/...Here is a mural which depicts Annie Glidden on the side of a buiding which is on historic Lincoln Highway in DeKalb, IL.  Annie pictured as a child.A closeup of the mural, which is larger than life like Annie.Also, her uncle, Joseph Glidden, was one of the inventors of barbed wire.DeKalb seed corn was known around the world, and the symbol of the flying corn was recognized by farmers in the United States as well as third world countries.  I do not think DeKalb seed had the same unfortunate reputation as the company Monsanto which bought them out.  I feel a little sad that such a tradition of helping the farmers of the world was perverted when Monsanto purchased the company in 1998.  The current political climate with Monsanto and genetically altered products is pretty horrifying.Women with non traditional careers should be able to be proud of the Annie Glidden legacy rather than ashamed.  She is one of those independent spirits I will forever remember.  If she had not been so involved with the DeKalb Agricultural Association, there might have never been a DeKalb Genetics.  DeKalb high yielding seed corn positively impacted the lives of many people around the world.  Embed QuoteAnswered in eight minutes.

column9: Everything I personally hear about the company is negative. Yet it has >20,000 employees. That is not a small number and I want to hear their side of the story.
column10: There are a variety of things that make working at Monsanto great, just like many other workplaces that develop long-term employees. I will list some but may come back later as this is a bit of a brain storm. Working in agriculture is a passion for many of us. There are only so many industries where you really get to work at making the world a better place & agriculture is one. We love working with farmers, knowing our efforts are helping to feed our families and communities. It's amazingly rewarding to talk to farmers in the developing world & hear how much better their lives are cause they have access to improve seeds & agronomic practices. Here in the US we also receive great feedback from farmers who appreciate the benefits our products offer. As employees we have the ability to pursue innovation whether that is in science or in communications approaches, etc. that innovative thought has led to important breakthroughs, particularly in science. We can also be challenged in our career paths by developing various skill sets and choosing different fields. For instance, someone with a research background can later work in product marketing getting a vastly different view of our business. And contributing their unique experience & expertise elsewhere. Frequently these are short tenures as the new info & energy then helps drive innovation in the person's primary field of interest. Monsanto has a very diverse employee base and all have opportunities to do well. This article from BlogHer shares some of that from my perspective as well as some colleagues http://www.blogher.com/hearing-w...There is a long list of awards the company receives based on everything from encouraging health & wellness to the diversity policies to IT. http://www.monsanto.com/careers/... You can see that and more on the career section of our website http://www.monsanto.com/careers/...  Embed QuoteVia  Anonymous.

column10: I don't understand why you seem to be suggesting that liberals are unilaterally against the production of genetically modified crops. Just because they scare the hippie down at your local farmer's market doesn't mean that liberalism is ideologically opposed to the concept. In fact, generally, progressives are the first to embrace new advances in technology, and want the growth of new technological industries (particularly one in which the U.S. is poised to further expand its superiority in over other countries) to take place unhindered by the federal government, so long as such a product is safe for consumption. As such, I am not surprised that Obama appointed someone who shares his vision for a world in which genetically modify crops have the net impact of providing cheaper, healthier, and more accessible food. In fact, he listed fomentation of the expansion of GMO crops as a component of his green initiative. I think the notion that Obama hired this man as a "F*** you" to his base is nothing short of preposterous.  Embed Quote

column10: Michael Taylor is an attorney and politician.  Since he has shifted from positions in the federal government and served as an advisor/officer for Monsanto several times, my assumption would be that he would create policy favorable to Monsanto.  The question is: does this decision show contempt for the majority of President Obama's supporters?  No.  The President did promise transparency.  This situation is transparent, even to the casual observer.  He promised a reduction in cronyism in Washington.  He may have made this choice based on Taylor's experience, but the President must have known the connections behind this appointment.  This was a tactical decision that reeks of Beltway cronyism. I do not consider the idea that all Obama supporters are anti-GMO, pro-Organic, anti-corporation, or anti-Monsanto.  These camps probably make up about 1/3 of Obama's "base."  These camps also would never vote Republican, so the President and Democratic Party have very little to lose with making this appointment.  So, yes, to these specific Obama supporters, this decision displays strong contempt for their ideals.  Embed Quote

column10: Definitely unilaterally against Monsanto's antics, but also unilaterally against the reckless adoption of GMO's before they are truly proved safe.   And effective and economical tool.  The evidence in thus far is far more disturbing than reassuring.  Monsanto's RoundUp ready crops are fast forwarding the evolution of 'superweeds' that are also glyphosate (roundup) herbicide resistant.  The result is farmers now trapped into having to use ever greater quantities of this toxic herbicide (google glyphosate for various studies on its environmental dangers).  Production costs go up, crop yields go down, and our environment is increasingly contaminated with a substance whose short term consequences are becoming increasingly clear, and whose long-term consequences are frighteningly unknown.   Considering that roundup ready crops are at present the poster child for the benefits of GMOs, this should give us all pause.      I haven't even begun to address the various possible dangers of genetic contamination  here, but despite the  best efforts by companies like Monsanto to snuff genuine research,  there are studies out there that show the potential dangers of GMOs.    The precautionary principle should apply to something as fundamental as the genetic health of the biosphere.   So, to supposedly pragmatic progressive Shane below, your pragmatism needs some refurbishing, and that hippie down at the farmer's market is more like the fool on the hill in the Beatles' great song, and we'd better start listening to him some!  Embed Quote

From the World Food Prize website:Building upon the scientific discovery of the Double Helix structure  of DNA by Watson and Crick in the 1950s, Van Montagu, Chilton, and  Fraley each conducted groundbreaking molecular research on how a plant  bacterium could be adapted as a tool to insert genes from another  organism into plant cells, which could produce new genetic lines with  highly favorable traits.The revolutionary biotechnology discoveries of these three  individuals —each working in separate facilities on two  continents—unlocked the key to plant cell transformation using  recombinant DNA. Their work led to the development of a host of  genetically enhanced crops, which, by 2012, were grown on more than 170  million hectares around the globe by 17.3 million farmers, over 90  percent of whom were small resource-poor farmers in developing  countries.The combined achievements of the 2013 World Food Prize Laureates,  from their work in the laboratory to applying biotechnology innovations  in farmers’ fields, have contributed significantly to increasing the  quantity and availability of food, and can play a critical role as we  face the global challenges of the 21st century of producing more food, in a sustainable way, while confronting an increasingly volatile climate.Not everyone gets hysterical over GMOs.Improving the Quality, Quantity and Availability of Food in the World  Embed QuoteAnswered in twelve minutes.

That Monsanto is focused on agriculture and provides farmers in the US and around the world seeds for various crops from grains to vegetables. These seeds are steadily being improved through the use of conventional breeding, advanced breeding and sometimes biotechnology. The improvements Monsanto delivers includes high quality crops, crops that can better withstand various weather extremes and pests, etc. The company also offers a crop protection product portfolio, the leading product there is Roundup which many of us use at home to control unwanted grass and weeds that come up between sidewalks, etc. To better understand the company, first many need to undertake an effort to truly understand agriculture and that effort needs to go beyond what mass media and pop culture have to say. Many of the things asserted as fact are not in fact true but the misunderstanding is easily perpetuated because so few in the developed world have connections to rural life and farming. You can get to know more through talking with farmers who use the company's products (several of whom are active online there is a question here Who are some farmers who document their methods online?). There is also a lot of information on the company's website http://monsanto.com or blog http://monsantoblog.com.  Embed Quote

While it seems like a straight-forward question, this question seems a bit hard to answer as different herbicides can have different benefits -- both for farmers and for the general public. Let me start with the big picture though and see what I can offer that may be helpful. Controlling weeds is an important part of farming for a couple of reasons:Limiting resource use - when you let weeds grow uncontrolled in your field or garden, they use water, fertilizer, etc that could otherwise be available for the crop you are growing for food. Since our environmental resources like water are finite, good stewardship of them is something that ways heavily on the minds of farmers and is something that the rest of us need to be conscious of as well. Protecting the crop yield -- competing with weeds for water, nutrients and sunlight can make it hard for crops to yield as well. In the case of something like beans, you can get fewer pods to set on the plant and fewer beans in those pods to fill out. Those things are costly since farmers usually get paid on how much they grow and if yields were typically lower, supply and demand indicates food would be more expensive for all of us. Ability to harvest -- some weeds can become so large that uncontrolled areas of a field may not be able to be harvested with machinery. Big losses there which could again effect food prices for all of us and potentially on farm profitability. Quality at harvest -- many crops are destined for food grains and some seed can be mixed in right in the field. I especially remember how much this impacts a crop like rice or wheat where the small pieces of grain can be similar in size and shape to weed or grass seeds. When I go to the grocery to but rice, I like it to be all rice, not for me to have to sort through grains and pull the weed seeds out. Crops that have similar size weed seed contaminate them are discounted and so a farmer has lost some of his earning potential if he doesn't control weeds. Weeds go to seed & increase your problems in the future -- when you let weeds and grasses grow, they will begin reproducing either by seed or from their roots / rhizomes. This means more weeds next year and the likelihood of bigger losses. Farmers tend to think both short-term & long-term so they keep it in mind that handling a small problem now is a lot easier than controlling a big problem later. Over years, fields can have fewer and fewer weeds appear and it means farmers can control weeds more easily. There are a few ways to control weeds. Physical control -- In my garden, I tend to simply pull weeds up by the roots or use a hoe on them. But when you move to larger fields this means running a plow to control weeds before starting the crop or a cultivator during the season to pull weeds up. Plant competitors -- Some farmers find planting cover crops or keeping the field in production in the off season with crops like winter wheat can be helpful as these will compete with unwanted weed species and provide a well-known plant to control. Herbicides for no-till or minimum tillage -- Some farmers find it better to use herbicides instead of plowing as the soil structure gains the ability to hold water better and earthworms develop the soil's health, etc. this is something that has been growing for decades in the US and a benefit we all realize from this is the soil tends to help better filter water so you don't have runoff. Controlling specific weeds & grasses or broad-spectrum control -- there can actually be dozens of types of weeds in a field. Some are broadleaf weeds, others are really grasses depending on the impact what is growing can have & how many species there are, farmers will decide whether to use something that controls a very few weeds or a wide range. The farmer will also consider what is planted nearby, whether there is water nearby, etc.Some herbicides leave a zone of protection in the field & others work based on contact only -- when you first plant a field, knowing what weeds you had there last year, a farmer may want to put out a herbicide that leaves the field protected for a week or so, something that will give the crop they are planting a chance to get ahead of weeds. Other times a farmer may want to just get rid of the weeds that are there. Different herbicides offer different advantages based on the use.As I talked through all of these, it is interesting to me now that I realize there are products and practices that fit all of these examples in conventional, organic and biotech / GMO fields. Hope my answer helped a bit.  Embed Quote

More often than one thinks as many levels of government have been mandated to reduce the amount of garbage that goes to landfill. There is the ‘carbon tax credit’ issue, such as: who has or leaves the biggest carbon footprint? From government down to private industry there is pressure to reduce your carbon footprint or one pays for with increased taxes, fines (in some cases), and/or be chastised by your peers and competitors by losing out on bids to those that do. Cities need to find ways to divert garbage from landfill out of necessity in many cases as there is no land to put the garbage in and many sites thought suitable have to go through lengthy environmental impact assessments, studies, and levels of approval for the considered sites to be deemed appropriate. This being the case the garbage that one puts out on the curb will get a primary sort, usually for metals, plastics, paper products etc. that will be recycled and other, wet garbage, will get diverted and trommeled  (a rotating sieve for sizing or screening) and then either composted, incinerated, and/or, finally landfilled. A City is best off to promote recycling at a grass root level to avoid unnecessary burden on the taxpayer. If you live in a community that recycles it is far more cost effective in both the long and short term for you as a taxpayer, but more importantly, as a member of this planet. Hopes this helps. Gord.  Embed Quote

This question isn't very specific, but i can offer one relevant example from my life that may help.    When i worked for the EPA, my job consisted of identifying and making recommendations for pollution prevention and energy saving opportunities at a large industrial manufacturer of channel strut and channel strut accessories.  They had an 8 or 9 step e-coating paint line in which they dipped 20ft sections of channel strut into huge tanks filled with water and various chemicals before baking them dry.        They had just finished installing an ultra-filtration system to continuously clean and remove contaminants from the tanks and recycle the water and the (expensive) chemicals. Before the filters, they would have to completely drain the tanks every so often and refill them. The filters saved literally hundreds of thousands of gallons of water per year and reduced waste water production.  Needless to say, the company saved buckets of money because of their water saving technique.   So my vague answer to this vague question is: a whole hell of a  lot!  Embed Quote

column9: Monsanto recently acquired the Climate Corporation for $930 million.  Is it worth the price?Monsanto Buys Climate Corp For $930 Million
column10: In order to answer this question, you have to have an understanding of both companies and why they are a good fit for each other.  Briefly.Climate.com is a high tech insurance company for farmers.  They sell insurance about rain and moisture levels for a farmer based on sophisticated climate models and data history.  This level of insurance can vary to very small areas of a field.  They have the capacity to make recommendations about which type of seeds to plant and when based on history, etc.  The cost of the insurance is higher for farmers that are making poor choices, but advising is built into the model.Monsanto was formed in 1901.  They have been involved in a lot of activities including the production of DDT.  However, that's a long time and a lot has changed.  There have been a lot of sales and acquisitions.  See wikipedia (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mon...) for more info.  For better or for worse the company Monsanto now is primarily a seed company, a herbicide company and a research company in these areas.  (Perhaps they should have changed the name?)  They also produce Golden Rice in an effort to prevent Vitamin A deficiency and death in children.GMO seeds.Imagine for a moment, that a farmer in Iowa wants to grow corn.  Over thousands of years he has figured out how to grow corn from the best seeds he has available for corn in Iowa.  Yet, Monsanto collected seeds from all over the world, and created a new seed that increased productivity.  The next goal was drought resistant and herbicide resistant.The acquisition is a good fit.  You have a multinational seed company that wants to become involved with technology and better serve their market.  You have a technology company based out of Silicon Valley / San Francisco that has climate modeling with farmers as their target market for selling an insurance product.  Both companies can benefit from the assets and strengths of the others including knowledge and flexibility.Is it worth it?  The cost of a Starbucks Latte isn't worth it to me, but the cost of the acquisition is clearly worth it to Monsanto.  Monsanto has an image and PR problem.  Climate.com is a high tech start up growth firm looking to hire.  Once they were acquired, they become a Monsanto subsidiary.  However, in order for this acquisition to be meaningful Climate.com has to still function as a company.  Current executives need to be retained and new employees have to remain interested in the company despite the image problem of working for "Monsanto."Disclaimer:  My husband is one of those that formerly worked at Climate.com.  I've learned more about Monsanto in the last few months than my entire life.  I believe there is a lot of misinformation that exists about a legacy company.  Embed Quote

column9: Basically looking for insight into how areas without sewage handle this.
column10: National parks and wilderness areas are not synonymous.  Wilderness areas are created by Congress and mechanical intrusion is pretty much prohibited. In most wilderness areas there are no latrines - you are on your own!  There are many books and guides on how to handle your human waste when traveling in backcountry and wilderness.  In developed areas and the front-country of national parks, human waste is usually handled in one of 4 main ways: 1)sewers, 2) septic systems, 3) composting toilets, or 4) mechanical pump out by trucks.  Embed Quote

Typically it consists of keeping adequate sanitizer (typically chlorine or bromine) levels in the water, brushing and vaccuming the pool walls and floor regularly, cleaning the waterline (and skimmers or gutters) with an appropriate cleaner regularly, and cleaning the deck area near the pool with a general disinfectant/anti-bacterial cleaner.  Embed Quote

Pool maintenance doesn’t have to be a chore — but it DOES have to be done. Regular care keeps the water clean and balanced, and your equipment functioning properly. With today’s technology, pool maintenance is easier than ever, and should take about 10 minutes a week.The first and most basic step is cleaning. The dirt and debris that inevitably end up in your pool not only make it uninviting, but they can clog and damage your pool’s filtration system as well. The big floating debris can be quickly and easily scooped out with a skimmer, while heavier sediment can be managed by an automated pool cleaner. There are several types of automated cleaners — and each does the work while you sit back and enjoy your pool.The second part of pool care is maintaining the chemical balance in your pool. Chemistry is key to keeping your pool clean, as well as making it a safe, pleasant environment for swimming. Chemicals like chlorine are used to keep algae and bacteria under control, while chemicals like muriatic acid keep the pH levels of your pool’s water balanced. You'll need test strips and a drop kit to check and maintain chlorine and pH levels. It also is important to keep a consistent volume of water in your pool; a lower-than-normal level can make your chemicals too intense and a higher-than-normal level can dilute them and make them ineffective. Improper water levels will also have detrimental effect on filtration and circulation.http://www.swimmingpool.com/main...  Embed Quote

These arrangements come instant in a container with guidelines on their utilization. Generally pool shops have water testing office's that Analise examples of water that you acquire. A hefty portion of them offer this administration gratis and will additionally exhort you on the materials needed in the wake of testing. High force implies clean the channel. not finishing so means puting strain on the pump and the water course is lessened and the filtration framework won't keep up wit prerequisites. Cleaning EquipmentPool Cleaning EquipmentAlong with the joy, excitement and long lost relatives that come with pool ownership there are also the maintenance challenges. There are many tools and items available to make your pool owning experience less troublesome. Even if you have an automatic cleaner, you will need the basic equipment. Telescopic pole, skim nets, pool brushes and a test kit are a must for any pool owner. The following is a glossary with descriptions of swimming pool and spa cleaning equipment.Telescoping PoleTelescoping PoleThe first thing you need. Tele poles, as they are called, come in a variety of lengths and quality. The best ones are made from fiberglass, but most are aluminum. They usually extend and then twist lock in place. Most tele-poles have 2 holes at the end that are designed to accept a wide range of accessories that we will discuss below.Concrete Pool Vacuum HeadVacuum HeadsVinyl Liner Vacuum HeadThe easiest way to make a dirty pool look good is a good vacuuming. All pools need to be vacuumed on a regular basis. The vacuum head attaches to the pole, and then a vacuum hose is attached to the vacuum head. The pole and vacuum head are then lowered into the pool. Click onto “How to Vacuum My Pool” for more information. There are two different types of vacuum heads. One has wheels and is weighted for concrete pools (left). The other is designed for vinyl lined pools, and has brushes instead of wheels (right).Vacuum HoseVacuum HoseIn order to vacuum debris from the pool walls and floor, you will need a vacuum hose. The vacuum hose connects to the vacuum head and telescoping pole (both above). Then, lowered into the pool. You then need to fill the vacuum hose with water, and then plug the end into the skimmer suction hole or a dedicated vacuum line. The water and debris are pulled into the filter pump basket via the swimming pool vacuum hose. After you vacuum, you will need to clean the basket and backwash the filter. For more information, Click Here.Leaf TrapLeaf TrapsThe leaf trap is a canister that is placed at the end of the vacuum hose just before the pool skimmer. Inside the canister is a large basket that will trap the leaves and debris before the “pool trash” gets to the pump. Great for leaves, acorns, pebbles and palm tree debris.Skimmer NetSkimmer NetsLeaf RakeThe most popular pieces of equipment around the pool are the skim net (left) and leaf rake (right). The skim net is a flat mesh net that attaches to the tele pole. It should be used on a daily basis to remove debris floating on the pool surface before it can sink to the floor. The leaf rake is also a mesh net, but is much deeper. Great for scooping debris from the pool floor for a quick cleaning before guests arrive for instance.Pool BrushesOne of the most overlooked maintenance steps of pool care is brushing. Swimming pools should be brushed at least Pool Brushonce per week. Brushing removes algae and other films and dirt on pool walls and pool floors that can’t be removed by vacuuming. A weekly brushing will avoid “slimy” walls and slick film that is common with pools and spas. There are several types of pool brushes. Stainless steel is perfect for plaster or concrete pools. Stainless brushes should not be used on vinyl pools. Plastic bristle brushes can be used on any type of pools, and are ideal for above ground and vinyl pools. There are also brushes designed for getting into pool corners and steps. Don’t forget to brush your pool weekly!!Leaf BaggerLeaf BaggerOne of the best inventions for swimming pool cleaning since the telescopic pole is the Leaf Bagger. Sometimes called the Leaf Master, The Leaf Bagger is a jet style vacuum that uses water pressure from your garden hose to create a Venturi affect. The high pressure water pushes the debris into a large bag. The leaf bagger is ideal for a quick spot clean or cleaning a pool floor full of leaves. Available with a leaf  bag, or a very fine mesh bag.Stain MasterStain MasterThe Stain Master is a siphon driven device that can siphon muriatic acid from a bottle on the pool deck to a stain on the pool surface. Sometimes called the Acid Wand. Perfect for small localized stains. Rust stains, leaf stains, acorn stains. Read directions, and follow all safety guidelines.Pumice StonePumice StoneAnother method for removing localized stains on concrete pools is the pumice stone. Pumice is a light porous glassy lava stone that can be rubbed over a pool stain to remove it. You can get a pumice stone that can attach to your tele-pole or a pumice stone that has a handle you can swim with. Works great on cement stains, berry stains and paint.Tile BrushTile BrushesA clean tile band is a very important part of the way your pool looks. As part of your weekly maintenance schedule, you need to scrub the tile band with tile cleaner and a non abrasive brush. Tile brushes come in a variety of and shapes, or you can just use a plastic bristle brush.  Embed Quote

Your opening question is at best two problems, at worst a red herring.Problem #1, a "first world" problem, hygiene in public bathrooms and an attempt to not waste water.  Solution: auto-flushing toilets.Problem #2, a "bottom billion" problem, no toilets.  Solution: toilets, septic tanks, and the trillions of dollars of infrastructure to treat all that waste.For #1, apparently enough people fail to flush that auto-flushing is the new normal.  For #2, no toilet means no flushing, leading to a whole lot more hygiene issues...I'm working with one company, Tansa Clean, that is aiming to solve #2, in a different way than the Gates Foundation, or the Indian government.  Big problem in need of many solutions, unless you have a spare trillion to donate. :)  Embed Quote

But it is a good idea to change your gloves and wash your hands between touching money and preparing food. Many patrons complain to the local health department if they see food workers using the same gloves to prepare food and handle money.Hand Washing & Glove Use for Food Workers - Questions and AnswersI don't know the rules in your area. Somebody at the store has assuredly passed a test on it. They may be following the rules; they may just be cutting corners.The main requirement to change gloves is when you go from handling raw meat to handling finished products. There's no raw meat in a Subway; everything is ready to eat. In the rules above, they're not allowed to touch ready-to-eat food with their bare hands, and so they wear gloves.   (You also have to change gloves when the gloves are torn or dirty.)As I said, rules vary from place to place, but there's nobody going to require them to switch gloves in the middle of the assembly process, even if it involves several pieces of equipment.
