Wastewater treatment in general has several steps, some intrinsically more expensive than others.1. Removing Debris2. Removing Suspended Organic Molecules3. Disinfection4. Removing other chemicals (optional, depends on region and regulations)Here is my best guess at a cheap option for each of the first 3 steps.1. Removing debris: usually done by a mesh screen. Afterwards settling tanks allow dense material (sludge) to settle and light material (scum) to rise and be skimmed off the top of the water. These can either be incinerated (cheap, polluting, can produce power), landfilled (kind of expensive), or used as feedstock for gasificiation (high capital costs, "clean" efficient power generation capabilities);2. Removing suspended organics: After the solids have been removed the WW goes to aeration basins where activated sludge breaks down suspended organic molecules. Areation is energy intensive.3. Disinfection is accomplished either through chlorination (medium-high maintenance, possibly dangerous) or UV (safe, high maintenance).4. Removing other chemicals such as ammonia tend to involve more areation basins, and can cost roughly equal to the original aeration.That being said, wastewater treatment is generally a pretty expensive, albeit important, enterprise. It requires a great amount of infrastructure, capital, and oganization. Depending on the actual implementation, costs for certain things (such as chlorination, landfilling, energy prices) can vary widely. At the same time there is a certain physically/technologically attainable minimum energy cost that is hard to get past.Brown and Caldwell newsletters are generally a good way of staying up-to-date on new technology and methods: http://www.bcwaternews.com/  Embed Quote

Engineered Ecosystems for Waste Management                    Organic wastes from human and animal habitations can accumulate in, and  endanger the environment. Engineered ecosystems research for waste  conversion has led to the development of Vermiculture Technology at Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay.  This process overcomes the problems associated with conventional  methods such as solid state composting, activated sludge, and extended  aeration in which bio-energy gets dissipated. It engages an ecology  consisting of soil, plants and soil micro and macro-organisms including  geophagous earthworms. The process obtains synergy between  photosynthesis and respiration, so that bio-energy of wastes is fully  utilized.http://www.visionearthcare.com/t...I don't know if this is cheapest but still giving you an alternative  Embed Quote

The best thing to do with wastewater is not produce it.In case it should be produced, separate different kind of uses. That will identify contaminants.For solids removal, just let the water be quiet and solids will fall separated from water. This solution needs surface invest (if you build a big basin) or earthwork invest (if you decide to build it vertical)For inorganic chemicals removal, electrodeposition.For organic chemicals removal, aireation.For desinfectation, use solar aproach, like ozone, UV.I higly recommend to use re-naturalization systems. One if this processes is an artificial forest. That forest gets food from water, reoxigenizes it and the plant grows. Cuting the plants and burning them, you can generate electricity to power above mentioned technologies.  Embed Quote

This strategy forms part of a trend in urban design which seeks to turn people's focus towards themselves in space, relating to their environment and people around them. The hypothesis runs that the more you manage people with things like pedestrian crossings, roadside fencing, elaborate signage etc., the more you disable them and disengage them from where they are and what they're doing.There's some evidence for this, particularly associated with Dutch experiments to eliminate the sidewalk/pavement distinction (pavement/road for British readers). This produces slower driving with fewer accidents. However, it's very expensive to do - unlike simply removing the bins! But the underlying thinking is the same. Make people responsible for themselves in space, and they start to behave in more complex, interactive ways.Retrofitting cities this way is fiendishly complex to do systematically, but it's quite cheap just to remove signage, clutter, furniture, waste bins. And it looks nicer. We don't know yet, however, what the effects of doing this piecemeal are - so doing it for three streets, while the remaining 2,000 stay as they were.  Embed Quote

column9: It's kinda concerning when you see this in Chinatown:
column10: It's based on a sliding scale of penalty points for violations that dictates what grade a restaurant receives. Less points are better. Page on NycThe scale goes like this 0-13 points is an A grade. 14 - 27 is a B grade while 28 or more is a C grade. A "Critical health hazard" such as keeping food at an unsafe temperature warrants 7 points. That qualifies a restaurant for an A grade! Think about how dangerous that can be. A restaurant can fail something like that and still be an "A" on paper. A restaurant that is C is almost unheard of. I've never seen one (that I can recall) and I've never eaten at one to be certain. That's a ton of violations. If a major violation is 7 points that means they have received the equivalent of 4 major violations. Arguably there shouldn't even be a C grade. Why would you allow a restaurant to remain open with that many violations?  Embed QuoteAnswered in fifteen minutes.

column9: Garbage is made up of tons of different items. Yet, it always smells the same to me with a unique "garbage" smell. Is there one item or component of garbage that has a strong smell and always overwhelms the others? Or is it just that the combination of those different smells is what I identify as the smell of garbage? Or do lots of items smell the same when they decompose?
column10: Lets see if I remember my waste management class... The strongest smelling compound from organic decomposition is Hydrogen Sulfide. This is similar to the smell you may notice around sewers. Combine this with the decomposing organic fatty acids found in food waste, and we get a recipe for garbage odor.Additionally, the bacteria (methanogens) that decompose the waste have similar metabolisms, so they release methane and a few other trace gases that generally combine in the confined space of your plastic garbage bag/trash can to create a mixture of different gases (syngas). The methane in garbage actually has no smell, despite some people claiming that it's the methane that makes your farts smell. At more advanced landfills, this methane is actually used to create energy.Perhaps more info than you wanted, but hope this helps  Embed Quote

column9: This is a follow-up question to What happens after water goes down the drain of a domestic sink? What processes does it go through, and where does it end up?.
column10: If you have a sewage treatment plant the effluence is evaporated before taken to the land fill.  How ever long it takes to evaporate, condense into a rain cloud, rain or snow back to the ground, drain into the aquifer and get pumped back into the water system.  This time is unknowable.  Embed Quote

column9: This is a follow-up question to What happens after water goes down the drain of a domestic sink? What processes does it go through, and where does it end up?.
column10: There are so many variables that go into this question that you cannot give a precise answer. It is all going to depend on how the treated wastewater is discharged. Is it discharged into the river that you get your drinking water from? Then it is relatively quick. Is it discharged and treated in the soil from a septic tank ultimately combining with the groundwater? If it is going back to groundwater you add in all kinds of other variables, such as the permeability of the soil, confining layers, etc. If the area is also served by drilled wells you may need to take into account any drawdown the wells may contribute. Domestic wells probably would not contribute as great as say a golf course irrigation well.  Embed Quote

column9: Like if you're eating outside.  They'd need to stay a bit and actually lay eggs, right?  Or does mere contact by a fly render food unsafe?  What is the real entomological/food-safety answer here?
column10: Yes, flies landing on your food for only a brief moment still is unsanitary and a health threat.  Let me explain why, in blunt and disturbing detail...Flies land on feces. They touch it with their feet, the underside of their bodies, and are in such overall close proximity to it that they pick up additional particulate matter in the air (the tiny particles of feces that drift in the air and form a smell, the same little pieces of floating feces that go up your nose and get detected). When flies land on your food, even if just for a second or two, ask yourself this:  how long do you consider short enough for pieces of feces to touch your food and not bother you?  The answer is probably somewhere close to "zero seconds" I'd guess, right?Flies likewise land and wallow around in rotting dead animal carcasses. They crawl all over garbage dumps, inside trashcans with baby diapers and liquifying rotted raw meat and other disgusting stuff, in sewers and gutters, and all manner of horrible places you'd rather not think about.Then the flies buzz over to your sandwich and take a quick little walk with their filthy feet, flutter their wings real fast to make sure and shake plenty of vile particulate matter onto your food, and probably take some little bites of your food with their horrible feces-and-rotten-garbage-tainted mouths. I say "take some bites of your food," but of course flies don't have teeth -- so they just vomit on your food quickly, so the digestive jusices in the vomitus make the food break down and the fly sucks it back up. They suck the vomitus and food up through their little proboscis and mouth, which has all kinds of germs and particulate matter from the garbage and feces.They do this fast, too. Very fast. And maybe when they land and take off quickly again, they just got scared off before they had a chance to finish sucking up their vomit from your food. And those little sticky fly feet that cling to walls and corpses and piles of crap? Sticky poop-and-germ-covered feet, all over your food.So yes, flies landing on anything you touch or eat are a sanitation threat. You can catch germs or get some infection. You may get hepatitis, or pink eye, or a stomach illness like dysentery, or some other form of sickness. Or maybe you won't get enough to get ill, and so you only eat up little bits of fly vomit and feces and garbage particles... lucky you!:(Another perspective, however, is this:  flies are everywhere. Particulate matter from feces and garbage is in the air all the time, and when you smell the scent of poop or rotten meat, that's because little particles float into your face and up your nose, and probably you even taste it a bit when you smell it (there's not all that much difference between smell and taste, ya know).You eat food in restaurants that almost surely had some bugs land on it, that was probably on some kitchen surface bugs touched. You get processed foods at the grocery store that literally have legally allowable amounts of rat feces and hair in them.  You eat and touch little poopy particles and gross garbage particles and things flies and roaches and other creepy little bugs touched, every single day. The only real difference with flies landing on your plate of food is that you SAW IT HAPPEN instead of it being this hypothetical gross thing that took place far away out of your sight and that you can ignore and put out of your mind and pretend didn't happen.  Meaning you should probably worry less about that fly on your bread than the smell from your bathroom at home, if you wanna feel grossed out about what it's really exposing you to.But still, you could counter-argue that just because some other exposure to feces and germs happens at other times to varying degrees, that doesn't change the fact that flies on your food also cause such exposure and is a definite, non-hypothetical exposure happening right there in front of you. So yes, every exposure is one more chance of eating germs or particulate matter that might be responsible for making you ill. And there's no doubt that it's unsanitary.  Embed Quote

column9: Like if you're eating outside.  They'd need to stay a bit and actually lay eggs, right?  Or does mere contact by a fly render food unsafe?  What is the real entomological/food-safety answer here?
column10: Well, that's an interesting question. I'll be very careful with my answer, and I'd ask everyone to read it fully before making up their mind about it.Flies touching food are obviously a sanitation threat, which should not be deemed acceptable by any means, but you have to understand that this is just one of the things that may happen to your food, and that several factors - temperature, time, and many many others - affect the outcome of it.If you see a place full of flies, your best bet is not to eat there. Not only because of the flies, but because any place that is full of flies probably exposes your food to other sources of risk.Now, being very practical about it: you may not have seen the fly touching your food. People speak close to the food, or by your side at the table, and their saliva is a tremendous contaminant (which may be as effective or worse than a single fly). Or your food may be touched by something else that was contaminated. Some people use gloves and for some reason, forget to change gloves when they should (which make them worse than a clean washed hand). All of which takes me to the second part of my argument.A few years ago I owned a small food company. I had certified people working for me and my company was constantly monitored by the local sanitation authority. The thing that I found most interesting under food sanitation rules is that it seems that there are two schools. One looks to completely eliminate all possible threats, and advocates a totally sterile and sanitized environment, and is very popular with the media. The other school takes a more practical approach and is very effective in terms of food safety, but allows for some kinds of compromise that while technically correct may surprise some people.There's a concept in food industry called HACCP (hazard analysis critical control point), which is used to analyze threats such as this one with a very practical mindset. It focus on the critical points where contamination or degradation may happen. The goal is to control quality and safety at these critical points. This framework was created to insure food safety for really critical situations, such as supplying astronauts with food for a trip to the moon.Most people don't know but under this system some things may be deemed acceptable. For instance, industrial juice is allowed to have some small percentage of "non fruit" parts. Yes, you're reading it right: your industrial juice may have bits of worms and insects that happen to be inside of the fruit when it was processed. It's pure statistics, as it's economically impossible to guarantee that every single fruit was not contaminated by a small bug. But the number is very small, and the pasteurization process just kills anything that may be left there. You'll drink it and you'll never know.In the US, there's also the Food Defect Action Levels (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The...). It states the contamination level that is technically acceptable (if you don't believe me, go and read it; it states very clearly the reasons why it's acceptable, and all the economic and health tradeoffs involved).The same thinking applies to flies and to every other possible source of contamination. Bacteria are everywhere. Food safety rules take this into consideration. So (from a strictly technical point of view) it's different if it's single fly, or a lot of flies, and if the food was cooked before or after contamination. If a fly touches a piece of meat, and the meat is cooked, and if it passes the lab tests for known contaminants, it will be deemed safe for consumption - and you'll never know the difference.  Embed Quote

column9: Like if you're eating outside.  They'd need to stay a bit and actually lay eggs, right?  Or does mere contact by a fly render food unsafe?  What is the real entomological/food-safety answer here?
column10: Flies are a source of disease and cross contamination. When a fly lands on your food it does two things: It regurgitates to help digest what it wants to eatIt defecates. Yum! There is no sure way to determine the amount or the type of pathogen the fly has transferred to your food, so it is consumer beware.I have shut down food establishments due to the number of flies present because they pose an imminent health threat to the public.  Embed Quote

column10: In much of the world restaurants are open air and exposed to flies who connect the garbage cans to your plate.Whatever is rotting in the garbage is what is being deposited on your plate.You probably notice those insects that are bothering you more than your food but both can make you ill.80% of all Western visitors to India get dysentery,mostly from the food.This question is important because it is obviously ignored by those who design and operate hotels and restaurants in much of the world.Add to this the routine by comedian George Carlin on how he and his friends got immunity by swimming in the sewer-infested Hudson river and that people today in the US are overprotected and over-sanitized.So the flies that are everywhere are more likely to be a problem to Americans.Flies landing on your food can kill you.They do not have to lay eggs,all the have to do is transmit the disease from the nearest rotting garbage to your plate.  Embed Quote

column9: I've heard answers ranging from "the DPW digs up every pee cake spot before the end of the event" to "the lake bed fills up every year and totally eliminates any trace of urine w/o any negative consequence".
column10: From an extremely strict LNT standpoint, no. The chemicals in your urine count as traces, and the acidity of urine reacts with the alkalai playa.From a more realistic LNT standpoint, it's not that big a deal. There are much worse things to worry about in terms of preserving the playa and not leaving a trace. Micro-moop is the worst, small particles that won't break down but are extremely hard to remove, like carpet fibers, astroturf shedding, sequins. From the standpoint of being a courteous participant, it's pretty undesirable and we would all prefer that you try to hold it and get to a potty. And if you aren't able to hold it, try to spread it around as much as possible so that it dries up quickly rather than making a nasty puddle.  Embed Quote

column9: I've heard answers ranging from "the DPW digs up every pee cake spot before the end of the event" to "the lake bed fills up every year and totally eliminates any trace of urine w/o any negative consequence".
column10: DPW does not dig up pee cake spots. Generally the urine from a single person does not make any sort of cake spot.DPW does dig up some cake spots from leaking evap ponds, which is a lot more water than the urine coming from the same camp members. People use about 1-2L of water washing dishes and stuff per day. People pee about the same amount normally (probably the lower end of this on the playa, of course). But the showers people take use 2-6 more liters per person, which is why evap-ponds get overloaded.The total output of urine and other waste has already been asked about: Burning Man: What is the total amount of urine produced at Burning Man each year?It's not nearly enough to fill the lake.  Embed Quote

column9: I've heard answers ranging from "the DPW digs up every pee cake spot before the end of the event" to "the lake bed fills up every year and totally eliminates any trace of urine w/o any negative consequence".
column10: From a LNT standpoint, the best thing to do is to find a relatively open piece of playa away from people and installations, and then pee while running backwards naked.  This distributes the chemicals in your pee, and avoids a muddy spot that some poor barefoot sucker might step in later.  Embed Quote

Open the tank and watch the mechanism as you flush; the handle lifts the flapper, and the rushing water keeps it open until the tank empties.  The flapper should flop back to seal the hole by gravity. Sometimes it gets hung-up or doesn't seat right; that's why jiggling the handle helps. Often the flapper just needs replacing.Sometimes the chain length needs to be shortened. You can do so by hooking a lower link to the handle.If there something wrong with handle mechanism.  And if you need to remove it from the tank. The nut holding it is a left-hand thread, so it loosens opposite to a standard right-hand thread. This can be a source of frustration and potential damage for the unsuspecting fix-it man.The toilet handle is a left-hand thread because the direction of lever action would loosen a right-hand thread over time.  Embed QuoteVia  Alexander Wilde.

column9: Water is sterilized by boiling it.
column10: No. Most bacteria die at 165 degrees F (about 74 degrees C).  When you boil water, you are killing any bacteria in it.**Freezing, on the other hand, doesn't kill bacteria, it just prevents them from multiplying.  As soon as the water warms, the bacteria will begin multiplying again.So, if you divide a pot of water in half, and you freeze half (stopping reproduction), and leaving the other half at room temperature (where any bacteria will multiply like nobody's business), the frozen water will certainly have less bacteria in it than the room temperature water -- but this is not the same as killing the bacteria.**Note that while it will kill bacteria, boiling alone will not eliminate dead bacteria/toxic waste products produced by the bacteria.  Embed Quote

column9: Water is sterilized by boiling it.
column10: Boiling will kill the majority of bacteria but some will need to go to a higher temp to get complete kill - eg; the bacteria and toxin that cause botulism need to get to at least 121C - what is called a Botulinum Cook. Long life milk in asceptic packaging is heated to about 140C for less than half a minute to kill all bacteria, spores and toxins in it. Some bacteria like hotter temps than others. Freezing does not kill most bacteria it simply makes them dormant (asleep) and when thawed they start dividing again. There will be less bacteria due to loss of structure, but not a huge amount.  Embed Quote

column9: My girlfriend is terrified of drinking soda from a can because she thinks it is too unsanitary.  I know people have told me to worry about the handling and storage of it, but I'm inherently skeptical of people who reason with "I heard" rather than actual facts.  Does anyone know the actual answer to this?
column10: Thanks for this question, I haven't seen one like it yet. You have raised some reasonable questions and thoughts about this issue. Sure, it's possible that someone with a cold or flu touched some soda cans at a store and left some germs on it.  But if it's in a cooler and on metal, the odds are rather remote that she would get sick from that (not a very hospitable environment for germs to survive). Overall, I think it's very remote that she would get sick from drinking soda from the can.  We have an immune system and if her's is healthy, she should be able to fight off lots of bacteria and viruses. Does she realize that she has millions or billions of bacteria in her mouth? Plus our bodies are also covered in bacteria all the time, many of which keep us healthy!   I'm actually more concerned about the soda, because there's nothing healthy or nutritionally good about soda! They have refined sweeteners (artificial sweeteners are no better), plus salt, caffeine, acids, colors, etc.  A soda will often spike blood glucose and that will trigger insulin and weight gain. Soda's also use up vitamins and minerals during digestion; they have to take those from other areas as soda's usually have no useful vitamins or minerals included.  The sugar can also contribute to inflammation and digestive problems because refined sugars feed the unhealthy bacteria in the digestive tract and that can actually lower her immune function. http://www.news.harvard.edu/gaze... http://www.endsicknessnow.com/to... I hope that's helpful! :)  Embed Quote

column9: The mouth is supposed to be one of the dirtiest places on the body besides the hands. If you are certain they don't have an STD, is tongue dancing on a backdoor any dirtier from a purely sanitary standpoint? Are there certain germs you should worry about or is your mouth pretty adept to fighting most these germs off?
column10: The bacteria found in the mouth are quite different from those in the intestines. While it is certainly possible to acquire an STD from kissing, there's a far greater chance of acquiring other diseases from the anus (though STDs are still possible). There are many bacteria -- E. coli, for instance -- that behave well in the lower intestines. The behave quite badly, however, in the upper part of the digestive tract. They can lead to infection and death. There are more bad actors in the instestines than in the mouth.Steps can be taken, of course, to cleanse the anal area and the rectum to minimize the dangers. If that's what you're into, then you should be insisting that those steps be taken. Fecal matter is not food; it is not clean. There are valid medical reasons why feces are kept out of water supplies and the food chain. Going directly to the source of those feces can be dangerous.Does a good washing before anilingus remove bacteria?  Embed QuoteAnswered in twenty-eight minutes.

column9: Do you ever open a door and notice a really worn out spot where everybody grabs it? Yeah, I try not to grab it there. I wouldn't call myself a germaphobe, but as I teach my kids the secrets of navigating this crazy world, I'm trying to be as wise as possible.Are there any studies that show where the most germs are and aren't in situations like this?Any tactics/strategies to avoid being contaminated by Mr. Public McNasty Hands?
column10: So, you aren't terribly likely to pick up infectious germs from a dry door handle. But, as Ben pointed out, there is more likely to be more bacteria in "high traffic" areas of the door.Here is an ergonomic study that analyzed wear patterns on doors: http://www1.coe.neu.edu/~yilin/I...It looks at door usage according to the type of door, and according to the size and gender of the door-opening-person. The only signiﬁcant factors they found were that:Body size determines the vertical position of where people push on a door.Hinge side determines for horizontal position Taller people touch higher on the door, while all touch the door either in the central third or towards the free-swinging side of the door.Incidentally, if you happen to be much taller or shorter than the average door-user in a particular building, you are already naturally avoiding most of the germs!  Embed QuoteVia  Paris Vega.

column9: Do you ever open a door and notice a really worn out spot where everybody grabs it? Yeah, I try not to grab it there. I wouldn't call myself a germaphobe, but as I teach my kids the secrets of navigating this crazy world, I'm trying to be as wise as possible.Are there any studies that show where the most germs are and aren't in situations like this?Any tactics/strategies to avoid being contaminated by Mr. Public McNasty Hands?
column10: To answer the question the way that it is asked, the higher hand traffic the door has, the higher on average the presence of bacterial colonies are, at least according to the results from this isolated experiment. http://www.google.com/url?sa=t&s...It stands to reason that you can minimize your contact with the bacteria by touching the lower traffic areas of the door. However, this does not speak to whether or not such a practice would be statistically relevant to actual disease prevention. More important than how you handle doors is how well you maintain personal hygiene, like hand washing after the restroom and before meals.   Embed QuoteVia  Paris Vega.

As a Secaucus resident and Managing Editor of eSecaucus.com, I'll try and answer this honestly: it's the marshes.The train station is on the outer edge of town where the swampland the town was originally built on still remains relatively undisturbed.Marshes and swamps stink in general due to the release of gaseous organic and inorganic molecules, including sulfer.  Embed Quote

column9: Indian railway is considering to install the so called bio-toilet in trains.Accoridng to this news article:  IIT-Kanpur flushes railway bio-toilet plan - The Economic Times "The bio-toilet uses 'cold-active' bacteria collected from Antarctica and other low temperature areas to treat waste, turning it into water and gas that are disinfected before being expelled from the train"How are these bacteria which is a foreign species in our environment going to affect it? What are the potential bio-hazards?What are the designers should take care of when building this?
column10: I don't think this is a big worry.Bacteria of many different kinds are used all the time in manufacturing, food, environmental projects, pet care and many other areas. For example, sometimes bacteria are introduced to "digest" oil spills. The bacteria obviously is not native to the lake or ocean or they wouldn't need to add it.I'm 99% sure that the specific bacteria will probably die if there is nothing around to sustain it's existence or when it is outside the range parameters for it to grow and propagate.Using bacteria for projects like the toilets is often much safer and more environmentally friendly than chemicals or high power disinfectants. Chemicals can stay around a lot longer and their toxicity can be far reaching (both geographically and in time).  Embed Quote
Hot water, as it is the heat which kills the bacteria on your hands.  Embed Quote

column9: Compared with toilets in New Zealand, Australia and I assume Britain.
column10: 1) A bigger 'pond' means fewer skid marks.2) And the US uses 'flush/push out' to empty the bowl. The Commonwealth model uses a 'syphon-assisted/pull out' model. The flush-push seems to need more time to achieve vacancy and does it using a heavy, long inflow to get a whirl going. As Jim Gordon's answer mentions, the new US technology uses less water, but is less effective as a result.3) There's a social component to the phenomenon, too. It's what looks right, both the view into the 'clean' bowl, and how much water is actually needed to achieve an acceptable look.Some cistern systems allow the user the choice of using less water to flush urine, because the bowl looks 'clean' earlier.Where's a hydrodynamicist when you need one? I've added 'hydrology' to the topics.  Embed Quote

column9: Compared with toilets in New Zealand, Australia and I assume Britain.
column10: What you seem to have observed is old technology, old environmental practices.  The new ones don't hold as much water.  You may have to flush twice to clean the bowl, which uses as much water as an old one.  Embed Quote

column9: I'm wondering if there are any reusable container circulation systems used by food vendors, anywhere.I'm thinking of a system where consumers take reusable containers from food vendors(cafeterias, restaurants) and return them after they're done. This system would be similar to a bag circulation system where consumers would return to the cafeterias with their containers, and receive a discount for using the container. If you know of anything similar- please tell me about it.
column10: I know that the UC Davis Whole Earth Festival uses reusable dishes for all foodservice at the event. When you buy a plate of food from a vendor, you pay the price of the meal plus a nominal deposit on the plate (I think it's $1). When you return the used plate to a central dish return, you get your deposit back.Sounds like the Willamette Valley Music Festival used real dishes as early as 2002 (source: http://darkwing.uoregon.edu/~rec...)Page 9 of this pdf has some more case studies of festival situations: http://ecoclub.com/library/epape...As for take-away re-usable containers, the Davis Food Coop (along with many other Cooperative Groceries) sells bulk food and dry goods. You can bring in any clean container, weigh the empty container so you have a Tare weight, and then fill your box/plate/jar with bulk food. When you check out, the cashier asks you the Tare weight, then weighs the container.  Embed Quote

column9: Update: To clarify - public toilets are often overused and under-maintained. Whilst it is laudable to have great public toilets everywhere, this (at least for now) comes at very high overheads, or require significant levels of public education.
column10: I have visited areas that have pay public toilets, usually a quarter and once a dime.  It seemed to me a great idea and for a quarter I was happy to pay.  I have been to places that did not have public toilets and seen people squatting in the ditch taking a dump.  I prefer first world sanitation for sure.  But, it was not that long ago that there was no public sanitation anywhere in the world.  We seemed to get by just fine as long as we progressed.  Chamber pots being tossed from the windows in the morning to the gutters and side walks below.  It was not the sewage that caused disease, but the pests that live near us like the rat and the flea.  I am a plumber and deal with peoples waste on a regular basis. Not so bad. Imagine a world with out written laws or voting then that is a world that gives me the creeps.  Embed Quote

column9: Including, ahem, kitchen counters and your lap?  If not, what prevents this?  If so, what is the potential danger?For reference:
column10: I'm not sure that there has ever been any published research in this area, but in general, as long as the litterbox is kept clean there is very little danger of spreading germs.  Urine in a healthy cat is sterile and as long as the cat doesn't have diarrhea it is unlikely that the cat will get any feces on it's feet.  It is especially unlikely that a cat will get feces on its feet if you use a clumping litter since it immediately sticks to the feces and dehydrates it very quickly.  The only germs that can survive dehydration are in spore or oocyte forms.  The major danger in this area is from Toxoplasma gondii. Kittens are the most likely to shed oocysts of Toxoplasma.  This parasite infects cats that eat infected meat, such as mice or other uncooked meat (like beef).All in all, your kitchen counters are in much more danger from your uncooked food.  Embed QuoteVia  Anonymous.

column9: It freaked me out the other day. I felt kind of disgusted after shaking his wet hand, in a doctor's office where I'm supposed to feel clean.
column10: Because, although he's making an effort, he's probably in a hurry and does not fully understand the CDC's instructions on the proper use of hand sanitizers: Handwashing: Clean Hands Save LivesApply the product to the palm of one hand.Rub your hands together.Rub the product over all surfaces of your hands and fingers until your hands are dry.This document also notes that thorough handwashing is still the best way to make sure your hands are clean.   Next time he does this, maybe you could reach over and get some of the sanitizer for your own hands, and use it until your hands are dry.  You'll feel cleaner then.  Embed Quote

column9: Sponges are known to be a top home of bacteria, so I am curious if it is more sanitary to use my hands. At the same time I am curious if I rinse dishes with my hands to remove any remaining food immediately after eating off of them, how sanitary these dishes are after they dry.
column10: You have 3 issues with dishes at home. First, you should wash your hands prior to starting. Second, you need to make sure you're using a clean sponge. Some people will use a cloth towel instead since this can be thrown in the wash. The last issue to address is most people don’t perform a sanitizing step. Is this really necessary at home, probably not. However, you are better off allowing your dishes to air dry and not dry them with a towel.If you follow these steps I would feel fairly comfortable with the cleanliness of the dishes.  Embed Quote

column9: Assuming using soap and shampoo
column10: Conserving water on board ship is a necessity.  This is how we were taught to take showers in the Navy.Bare in mind we did not have much hair and the need for shampoo was not there.  Get in the shower and wet your entire body.  Turn off water and soap up your self.Turn on water and rinse off.  If you were caught taking a long shower it was termed ans taking a "Hollywood"This is very efficient but not very pleasing.  The shower is what wakes me up in the morning.  I now do a modified version of this that includes hair washing and I don't turn the water off.  I now take a three minute shower as opposed the the one minute.  Five minutes if I shave.  My shower head uses 2.6gmp so I am using 13 gallons on a typical shower.  Embed Quote

column9: Considering: Close neighbors, indoor/outdoor cats, smell, noise or anything that might not seem obvious.
column10: I have around 19 chickens now. I put a lot of thought into how to raise them in ways which minimize negative aspects. See more of my thoughts about chickens here:http://www.quora.com/Brian-Fey/a... Negative:Fence: I had to built a really good fence to keep my dogs and other predators out. People could say, "Boy I sure would like some of those fresh eggs you got."Shit:  Their shit is not a negative if you can put down enough "litter" to cover the floor well, you can harvest that for your garden. We use massive amounts of pine needles. Sawdust or oak leaves could work. Whatever biomatter is free for you. Or you can have someone with a garden haul it away from free, but the best use of energy is to use it right there. Food : If you don't have a source of food for them, then you have to buy commercial food which can have weird stuff in it. But if you have a number of them which is balanced to your kitchen waste, then they can eat your garbage. I plan to capture and dry many invasive grasshoppers this year so I can feed them that all year long.  Butchering: If you raise them for meat, then you have to process the chickens. De-feathering is a pain. That is why I don't raise chickens for meat, just for eggs. Rabbits are a much easier choice to raise for meat. Rabbits: What makes rabbits an efficient animal to raise?Noisy? If you want to have a cock, then they make noise. However at the home scale it is unwise to have a cock at all. Contact your local farm and either buy pullets, or laying hens. Hens mostly just make cute little noises. I can't think of many real negatives. I think almost all houses should have some hens. Healthy better eggs! And they eat all food waste. 70% of the houses in the little town of Yotatiro near me have chickens!  Embed Quote

column9: Considering: Close neighbors, indoor/outdoor cats, smell, noise or anything that might not seem obvious.
column10: Once I had as my pet a Rhode Island Red hen in my yard. I named her Henny Penny. I was excited to have her eggs. I thought she was exotic and beautiful. I never did have any pet before her. I did not experience any negative aspects of raising her and her sister in my yard until one sad day when I awakened to find nothing but feathers. The rest of what was left was hard to find. Until I took a walk down the driveway. What I saw made me cry.Neighborhood dogs and other critters may want to enjoy dining on chickens that don't belong to them -- just as the dogs did mine, each in its own way. How do you keep a hen safe might just be the next Quora question...  Embed Quote

column10: I have been raising free range chickens on my property for nearly a decade now.  I am not sure how my example compares to "back yard", due the fact I have a couple of acres. I have never lost an animal due to sickness.  I have lost them to raccoons, neighbors dogs, and raptors.  My cats and dog gets along just fine with them.  Once in a while the poop from them gets messy, like if they get in my shop.  One hen decided my tool bench was where she wanted to lay her eggs.  When I have to leave town for a few days I fill all the waters and leave plenty of food.  I think they are easier to take care of than cats.  But, if I had to ahve them in pens, that would be more care needed.  I have to say the positive out weighs the negative by many factors.  If I had to be in town with limited space and close neighbors, then I would say the negative would be lawn destruction, bigger areas reduce this.poop in a small area, if they like being on the back deck.penned birds need more careloss due to getting outside yard, dogs and raccoons.  Embed Quote

Although they look nice pecking around the yard, they don't interact with you like a cat or dog does.They tie you down, even compared to a cat or dog. column10: A big negative that people don't think about is that chickens will destroy gardens and flower beds. They will peck holes in the veggies, eat the herbs down to the ground, and scratch out the seedlings. They see mulch as their personal playground. And if you have neighbors, they will also visit your neighbors and destroy their garden.Chickens are great animals to have, but a good fence is your friend for many reasons.  Embed Quote

Lemon juice seems to inactivate some bacteria, see Inactivation by lemon juice of Escheric... [Int J Food Microbiol. 2013] but the lemon juice must really be concentrated.It isn't suitable for HIV prevention used as a vaginal douche after exposition to HIV positive semen, since the amount needed to keep the vaginal pH acid after semen is ejected into the vagina causes too much local barrier problems.Preclinical evaluation of lime juice as a topi... [Retrovirology. 2008]Six-day randomized safety trial ... [J Acquir Immune Defic Syndr. 2008]  Embed QuoteAnswered in twenty minutes.

The reason that pure lemon juice may kill some bacteria is that it has a very low pH when super-concentrated... as in, it is very acidic. Some bacteria may not be able to grow under such conditions and thus could be rendered inactive or dormant until conditions improve. Killing it is much less likely since the acidity of the environment does not really inhibit any major processes involved with bacteria metabolism or replication (i think?). Now if it was a type of acidophilic bacteria (read: likes acid) then the lemon juice would probably just make things worse by helping the bac grow and proliferateSo in other words... lemon juice isn't exactly the best of options. For disinfectants, use alcohol, and for antiseptics (on human tissue) best to use saline solutions. And for cooking... heat is your friend, and the freezer too if you are planning to store it for long term use. remember... 4-70 degrees Celsius is where you do not want your food to be in for the long term, since bacteria grows the fastest during this period.  Embed Quote

Antibacterial EffectsLemon juice is highly antibacterial--part of which can be owed to its high acidity. Research has shown the contents of lemon juice are able to neutralize and kill some types of bacteria in as little as 15 minutes, while others may take up to three hours to take effect. According to Health Guidance it was found that lemon juice applied to raw oysters can kill 92 percent of the bacteria present in the oysters in just 15 minutes.source: Health Benefits of Fresh Lemon Juice  Embed Quote

Flies associated with toilets tend to be psychodids or phorids.  If the former, then you likely need to clean drains nearby.  If the latter, then you likely have a broken sewage pipe or other leakage.  Collect one or more and submit them for evaluation. See: identify.us.com for info  Embed Quote

I have known these flies to be called drain flies.  Usually they are associated with sink drains.  I have never heard of them in toilets. I might expect that you have a bad wax ring under the toilet allowing them to enter the space and bother you.  Pulling the toilet to make sure the drain is intact would be my advise.  Other wise caulk around the base of it.  Put some bleach in all your drains to kill their habitat.  These bugs are really hard to get rid of.  The good news is that they are harmless.  Embed Quote

column9: Assuming there is no sewage system or septic tank in place: Is there a cost effective sanitation alternative for a relatively small community of people (100 or less) living off grid? I'm guessing composting could be a solution, but I don't know if having too many people makes the volume too high / go over the natural limits.
column10: Composting Toilets are the way to go! I live off the grid and have built 6 composting toilets. They completely eliminate water waste, remove the need to transport human waste and have nearly no moving parts. Having separate pee spots makes it easy to not overload the system with too much liquid.What are some tips for building composting toilets?What are some tips for improving the use of composting toilets?  Embed Quote

column9: Assuming there is no sewage system or septic tank in place: Is there a cost effective sanitation alternative for a relatively small community of people (100 or less) living off grid? I'm guessing composting could be a solution, but I don't know if having too many people makes the volume too high / go over the natural limits.
column10: As Brian Fey stated, composting is the best solution. As to "going over the natural limits," a good number of composting toilets will clearly be needed, but you'd need a lot of toilets in any case. If you can afford it, urine-separating seats (that drain the urine into a container separate from the solid waste) make the composting much easier and pleasant. Urine can be diluted in a 1:6 ratio with untreated water and then used as fertilizer or it can be poured undiluted over sawdust or similar matter and composted separately from the solid waste. The advantage of separating them are: reduces the volume of uncomposted material that is a contamination risk (urine is quite safe to handle), makes it easier to keep the compost evenly moist rather than drowned in liquid at the bottom,  and reduces the smell that fresh waste would produce (the unforgettable "latrine" smell is due to the combination of urine and feces). Here's a page with some details: About composting toilets. For some examples of urine separating seats, see Ecovita Products & Tools.  Embed Quote

column9: Were there any codes of conduct? Special places? Were there many health issues related to hygiene?Not even sure if I am asking about few hundred years ago or one to two thousands.
column10: In antiquity, toilets were built right next to the kitchen sink so that both utilities could share the drainage system running underneath and conserve water for flushing (water used to prepare food could be dispensed by pouring it down the toilet).If you were lucky, you may have lived in one of the houses that had running water. In that case, the toilet would most likely be in a dedicated room next to a bathtub so you can relax while taking care of business. An upper class toilet. Notice the wheel on the side to make it resemble a chariot.You would still have to pour water down the drain yourself to push the excrement away. Everyone else had to clean up as best they could using a sponge or a Pumice soaked in brine! If you were really unlucky and your house had no drainage system at all, you would go outside and use the nearest public toilets and clean up with the communal sponges (maybe bring your own?). If you didn't want to go outside, you could use a chamber pot and throw the excrement away carefully somewhere in the yard, in the same place all the other household garbage would go. Neighboring houses usually shared a place for all that. I highly doubt people would throw stuff like that on the street. In any case, everyone would try and schedule their bowel movements for when they could go to the public baths, the place they would be most comfortable in. Public baths were extremely popular, most cities had more than one, they could be public or private owned, and where affordable to everyone. Unlike what the word "bath" implies, they were much more than just a place to clean up. They had toilets, warm baths, cold baths, barbers, masseuses, communal areas, even libraries. Baths were so important for daily life, some of them would be luxurious beyond our imagination, like Diocletian's baths, with a capacity for 2,500 people:The Baths of Diocletian.Those who lived in the country used a chamber pot every single day, I suppose.  Embed Quote

column9: Were there any codes of conduct? Special places? Were there many health issues related to hygiene?Not even sure if I am asking about few hundred years ago or one to two thousands.
column10: Romans used it in kind of like what today we might call a public latrine type of setting, I believe.   I don't know anything about codes of conduct,  per se,  but I don't also think there were really health-related issues for it because they had also developed something like a sewage system,  probably using aqueducts or something like that I would say.  Wasn't like raw sewage was out in the streets I don't believe.    Romans and Greeks also used public baths, kind of like we might today call saunas,  spas , bathhouses,  which evolved into hammams as they say in Turkey or "schvitzes" as they say in eastern Europe.  And bathing at these places was done probably fairly regularly (though of course not on a par with today where people can perhaps take at least one perfunctory basic sort of shower in a private stall in their home once x day in many cases).   I believe through Roman expansion they also helped introduce the idea of the "baths",  the public bathing places.   Though how quickly these caught on,  how widely used they were, etc,  likely varied from province to province within the places significantly influenced (or outright occupied) by the Empire.  Embed Quote

column9: Were there any codes of conduct? Special places? Were there many health issues related to hygiene?Not even sure if I am asking about few hundred years ago or one to two thousands.
column10: In England, specifically in Shakespearian times, people had large rooms with a seat at the far end, with a hole in the seat and a bucket underneath. The servants would then empty the bucket's contents out onto the street: if the house was two or more stories, they would just throw it out the window and onto the unsuspecting pedestrians below. If, in the middle of the night, you had to go but didn't want to walk all the way to the bathroom, you could go in a little pot, which you would then push under your bed, and the servant would collect it in the morning. How could they deal with the smell, you may ask? Well, cleanliness was not as appreciated, you may say, as it is today. In fact, most people only took baths once or twice a year. (And this was only for the rich people – the average bloke would be lucky to have a bath once every 3 or 4 years!) Fun fact (as if this isn't gross enough): the reason why the bathrooms were so big was because people believed the strong smell of the pee and what-not would kill any diseases on their clothes. You guessed it, the bathroom was also a closet. So not only did you smell horrible, did the streets smell horrible, but your clothes smell horrible too.  Embed Quote

column10: It should. The alcohol is the active ingredient in most hand sanitizers. You might find that it dries your hands a bit though - I don't think either of those oils are particularly easy on your skin.  Embed Quote

column9: I'm thinking of making some with 65-70 percent alcohol in an atomizer with some essential oils (eucalyptus or tea tree oil).Will this work?
column10: 65-70% alcohol is far too strong you risk irritating and drying the skin on your hands, reduce it to 25% and 75% distilled water. Eucalyptus and tea-tree oil are antiseptic, antiviral and a bactericide*. I would  include cinnamon bark and clove essential oils as well though. They are stronger essential oils and will give a more effective blend.This particular blend of oil is a very strong skin irritant and you do need to make sure it is thoroughly mixed. Clove oil can actually be caustic* (burning). Mix 1 part of the entire mix with at least 10 parts alcohol. Leave in the alcohol overnight. Then mix with the distilled water. Make sure you use amber bottles or opaque bottles. These aren't just for decoration, but to make sure that the sunlight doesn't break down the molecules in the essential oils and cause them to be inactive. Personally instead of an alcohol spray, I'd rather mix a few drops of those essential oils into a perfume free hand lotion. The cream will still be antiseptic and antiviral but not so harsh on your hands, especially during winter. *The Directory of Essential Oils - Wanda Sellar  Embed Quote

column9: For example, with automatic toilets, automatic hand dryers, automatic sinks, and those really annoying automatic paper towel dispensers, have any studies been done on how effective they are on say, sick days taken?
column10: Some of the no-touch devices are not just ineffective, but studies show they can also be counterproductive. One problem is that these gadgets involve plenty of new components - providing extra surfaces for the bacteria to grow. Here is some research done on electronic faucets and air dryers.1. This is a Johns Hopkins study on electronic faucetsLatest Hands-Free Electronic Water Faucets Found To Be Hindrance, Not Help, In Hospital Infection Control - 03/31/2011As a result of the study, conducted over a seven-week period from December 2008 to January 2009, Johns Hopkins facilities engineers removed all 20 newer faucets from patient care areas and replaced them with manual types.2. Here is a study at the University of Westminster that shows how conventional paper towels reduce the bacteria after washing, while air dryers increase it. A comparative study of different hand drying methods3. The conclusion of a research done at Mayo Clinic: ElsevierTherefore, this makes paper towel drying, during which little air movement is generated, the most hygienic option of hand-drying methods in health careAlso see:Warm air hand dryers increase bacteria on handsHands-free faucets not necessarily better, say scientists  Embed Quote

column9: For example, with automatic toilets, automatic hand dryers, automatic sinks, and those really annoying automatic paper towel dispensers, have any studies been done on how effective they are on say, sick days taken?
column10: Actually they don't.  Long story short, automatic faucets have more parts inside.  Bacteria get trapped inside and then gets in the water and on your hands.  A study found that automatic faucets are filled with more germs than manual faucets.  All the information is here: Automatic Faucets Are Covering Your Hands In Germs  Embed Quote

column9: This pertains to the franchise as a whole (ex. the total number of fines/amount of those fines for every McDonald's in the world).
column10: Publicly available information on this topic is substantially biased by the fact that  fake allegations of gross sanitary violations at McDonalds is a constant feature of Urban legends,deliberate fraud,and tabloid news. What I am saying is that there is a difference between tabloid news and reality,and that there have been world-wide urban legends about rats,fingers,worms,and such at McDonalds. All of these were disproved,some were fraud,but the tabloid coverage lingered.Quora should be more than links to news sites.Much so-called news in America is direct ads or propaganda. In my opinion the real life experience and research of Quora users is as valid as links .The genuine conditions under which fast food chains have repeated unsanitary conditions are 2: there is no proper supervision and quality control,or it is simply a derelict,failed chain.Those that meet this criteria are Arby's, Hardee's, and Dairy Queen,In a number of news reports McDonalds had more cleanliness infractions than Hardees,which contradicts personal experience and common sense.The above reasons are given as to why McDonalds being the focus of allegations of unsanitary conditions may not be accurate.I do not own stock in McDonalds,was never an employee,and would only be a patron in the event of nuclear war.  Embed Quote

column9: There seems to be an increased in use of sanitization products (eg: hand sanitizers, automatic soap/towel dispensers, automatic flushing on toilets). Is there a correlation between this and the increase in allergies due to an under exposure to bacteria?
column10: While there certainly is a correlation, direct causation has yet to be proven. This idea has been popularized as the "Hygiene Hypothesis", and it is just that: one of the best guesses that we have in science for the time being.It seems that treating people with pinworms and the like is on the up-and-up in clinical trials for various immune conditions, in an attempt to provide the immune system with a chew toy (and thereby prevent it from manifesting negative effects on our bodies), but the major failure of this theory is that much of the population growing up in the same sanitary conditions have no significant allergies.Personally, I wouldn't read too much into this per se. While the idea has some validity, it clearly doesn't encompass the multifactorial etiology of allergies, e.g. genetic susceptibilities. We'll find out if soon enough in the years of research to come--immunology's one of the current hotbeds of funding/work. :-)  Embed Quote

column9: There seems to be an increased in use of sanitization products (eg: hand sanitizers, automatic soap/towel dispensers, automatic flushing on toilets). Is there a correlation between this and the increase in allergies due to an under exposure to bacteria?
column10: While the theory noted above exists, I personally think it's wrong.  The immune system historically has been exposed to numerous antigens, and "over sanitization" likely doesn't make a big impact on the overall number of allergens to which the immune system is exposed.  Allergens-- unlike bacteria-- access mucous membranes in the mouth, respiratory system, and eyes exceedingly often compared to other microorganisms that are eliminated via hand sanitization.  This is because allergens float around in the air in large quantities.Increases in allergies are more likely to result from environmental exposures that likely change from time to time.  During some seasons, allergen production is more robust than other seasons.  Is ragweed more pronounced now than it was before?  This question is just one example of many other questions that, if probed, are more likely to find the real cause for why allergies are more prevalent.As noted above, genetics certainly could explain this, but  evolutionary biology indicates that millions of years are required for significant changes to occur in a species' genome.  So I gather that in our lifetime, there won't be enough genetic changes to explain a change (i.e., increase) in allergies.*DiscaimerThe information on  this Web site is provided  by me  for educational purposes only. It is  not a substitute for  professional  medical care, and medical advice and  services are not being  offered.   If you have, or suspect you have, a  health problem you should  consult  your physician.   I provide  information to you as a service for   educational purposes but am not  responsible for information provided in   these or other Web sites.  Embed Quote

column9: I tend to get warm when flying and feel kind of dirty from all the germs in/around the plane. What are some helpful tips to address these two points of discomfort?
column10: Dress in layers. Wear natural fibers. Drink enough water. Carry and use antibacterial hand wipes if the germs really bother you.  The wipes are more refreshing than a straight shot of Purell. Use a damp paper towel to wash your face midflight. Make sure the air vent above your seat is open and properly oriented to blow on you the way you like to be blown on!Bring an extra t-shirt and socks; change when you begin to feel skanky. And if all else fails, just remember: that shower at your destination will feel really good.  Embed QuoteAnswered in twenty-six minutes.

column9: I tend to get warm when flying and feel kind of dirty from all the germs in/around the plane. What are some helpful tips to address these two points of discomfort?
column10: A change of clothes when you get off the plane is great. Just a change of t-shirt / vest underneath your shirt will make you feel fresher. I've found wearing a wicking long sleeve top while you are flying can help you feel less grim. Drink plenty of water while you are in flight as feeling fully hydrated will also help you feel less fatigued after a long flight.Just as an aside (from my flu researcher sister), most respiratory infections on a flight happen at disembarkation in the time between the plane's aircon being swiched off, the doors being opened and you exiting the plane. So don't worry about the germs while you are flying, it is as you land you should feel concerned.  Embed QuoteAnswered in thirty-one minutes.

Oh no. Very few British houses would have had indoor plumbing of any kind at that time. Such large-scale public projects only really began in the later half of the 19th century. Before that, all water was carried in, and all waste was carried out.As for toilets, a house like that would have had chamber pots, which were occasionally built into closets, but were more normally simply kept out of sight under beds or in special cupboards. These large round or oval enamelled metal pots were often quite elaborately decorated to deflect from their true purpose, and sometimes had lids on them.Each day, the housemaid would have emptied this 'bedroom wear' into a slop sink, which emptied into an open cesspool set some way from the house, or she would have taken them to the street drain in the nearest street to be emptied. Either way, the cesspit was the eventual destination.The women of the house would have used such arrangements exclusively, but the men would probably have used outhouses during the day, which emptied into those same cesspools.The cesspools were emptied at night by the 'Nightsoil' men, and the material was often taken to be spread onto nearby fields as fertiliser. These men were also referred to as the "Midnight Mechanics", in the Manchester area.If you are near to the North of England, I suggest a visit to Pockerley Old Hall  which is set in the grounds of the Beamish open-air museum (which is worth a visit, in itself) . It is a recreation of a modestly well-off rural household of the eighteen hundreds, and tries to give an idea of what domestic life would have been like in such a household, back then..  Embed Quote

If some kind of incredible sexual revolution takes place and desocializes embarrassment and taboos between the sexes, then I'm thinking that restrooms will become sexless, with communal restrooms in public places open to both males and females.I'd envision also perhaps nanomachines or slow-release chemicals in urinals and toilets that constantly disinfect and sterilize used areas. Toilets would be less collectors and more converters - perhaps resembling those in the International Space Station, which separate water from waste and recycle it for later use.Real-time semi-intrusive advertising would also appear in restrooms, I think, as soon as people are socialized into thinking that this is perfectly normal and fine.  Embed Quote

column9: My washing machine is broken and I'll need to hand wash clothes. Which cleanser should I use - Hand soap, dish soap, or regular clothes detergent? Will clothes detergent be abrasive on my skin? What is the correct motion - twist, foot stomp (grape stomping style), rub together, slap on a rock (Indian style)? How do I avoid the clothes getting warped?
column10: How to Wash Clothes by HandPut on older clothes; clothes that if splashed with water and detergent, won’t be a worry.Be sure to check labels on all clothing and use the correct water temperature.Find, clean and fill a large and clean bucket, basin, sink or bathtub with water. Then, add your favorite dish detergent. (Dish detergent is better because it is not so harsh on clothes or hands.) Depending on the clothes washed—if delicate, use cool water, if regular clothes are used, warm water.Place your clothes into the soapy water. Make sure that the clothes are covered well with the soap solution.Allow the clothes to soak for at least 10 minutes.With your hands or a brand new toilet bowl plunger – (or clothes plunger—some stores have them)—wash or agitate the clothes for several minutes, using gentle but firm motions.Drain the water. Remove the clothes one by one—squeezing them gently and then placing them one by one in an empty sink, a bath tub or a clean, dry place.Rinse the clothes well in clean water. Often, this process takes at least two rinses so that all the soap is removed. Squeeze gently the water from each garment and then hand up everything on a clothes rack or on plastic hangers; being especially careful with delicate items not to pull or squeeze too harshly.Thanks,Susan Smith  Embed Quote

This answer can vary from place to         place. Most drains are either connected to a sanitary sewer system or septic         tank.          The sanitary sewer carries the wastewater to a treatment plant where it is         processed to reduce and/or remove the wastes. If you are on a wastewater system, all of the drains in your     house are connected to a single pipe that leads to the street. The pipe in     the street collects the wastewater from all the homes in your area and takes     it to a larger pipe that collects wastewater from other streets. The wastewater     then flows into still bigger pipes that connect various neighborhoods. Think     of a large tree with your house at the tip of a branch near the top. Like     the tree branches that are bigger nearer the ground, the pipes in the wastewater     collection system are larger and contain more liquid as they near the wastewater     treatment plant. Here, the wastewater is treated and cleaned so that it can     be put back into the environment without harming anything. After processing, the treated water         may be released to the groundwater or surface water. A drinking water     distribution system looks the same but in this case the drinking water goes     from the treatment plant to your home. 	A septic         tank is just a small underground treatment plant that relies upon bacteria to         "eat" domestic wastes. The clean water is then discharged back into the         surrounding soils (the drain field).  Embed Quote
nothing  Embed Quote

I know of a study that shows that washing can be effective at removing bacterial and viral pathogens. That study is at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubm...However, that study merely shows that you can remove pathogens if present. To show that washing is important, you'd also need to know that there may be pathogens to wash off. I'm not familiar with any formal studies, but you can see the frequency of outbreaks traced to strawberries here: http://outbreakdatabase.com/site...You'll see that outbreaks are not common, but consider the following: when they do happen, they can be very nasty organisms. And there are always some outbreaks which are too small in scope to be recognized as such.I haven't addressed pesticide residue at all in the answer. While that be another reason to wash, I am not aware of any studies that show that washing at home makes a meaningful difference in the amount of pesticide residue. I'm not saying that washing won't help with pesticides - I just don't have proof that that's the case.  Embed Quote
I would rinse any fresh produce before eating.  However, strawberries should be rinsed just before consuming. If you let them sit, wet, in the fridge, they will spoil faster.  Embed Quote

Wash, scrub, then 1 part vinegar to 3 parts water rinse. http://bites.ksu.edu/blog/145034...and a good safety sheet http://www.ext.colostate.edu/saf...I do not and most others in the field do not recommend washing prewrapped/prewashed items as there is a greater risk of the consumer contaminating the product then what might have been originally on it.With the vinegar rinse, personally I would only use it on products such as cantaloupe, apples, etc. Maybe lettuce, spinach if I was going to have a vinaigrette salad dressing with it.As for all fruits and vegetables it is important to rinse them off. In the grand scheme of foodborne illness, strawberries have been a pretty low risk item. But with any item you want to try and was off pesticide residue, critter residue, etc.I would have to disagree with Jim Seidman on outbreaks not being common, they are. What was uncommon recently was that strawberries were contaminated with e. coli which was traced back to deer and we just had the first known outbreak of listeria associated with cantaloupe. We have just recently had a number of "sprout" outbreaks also.  Embed Quote

First, realize that a 'disease' is a pathological manifestation or response to infection or to other physiological burdens.  Consequently, a 'disease', itself, cannot be transmitted.  Instead, the infectious agent can be transmitted.  Infection is not the same as disease.  The bacteria (Borrelia burgdoferi) that causes Lyme disease in human beings and some other animals causes no such burden in ticks or in certain other mammals.  Now, if an bird or mammal ingests an infected tick, will that animal become infected, and will the bacteria pose risk to those that eat the meat or eggs?  The answer is 'unlikely' for both scenarios. Transmission (of the agent of Lyme disease) from the tick is almost invariably via tick bite. It can on rare occasions be acquired via a blood transfusion or tissue / organ graft.  Acquiring infection by ingesting a tick would be an incredibly rare event, and would require that the bacteria enter a wound in the mouth. Now, what of a person eating meat or eggs of an animal that is infected? Whereas the bacterial agent of Lyme disease is most abundant in the skin, a few of them may be in other tissues. Even though the risks of acquiring this infection by eating infected animal tissues are vanishingly tiny, all you'd need to do would be to cook the food.  That will eliminate such risk.  Embed QuoteVia  Anonymous.

column10: I think your question refers to the causes and drivers of HD? If so, I've written several articles about this issue.  The SAD (Standard American Diet) is one of the worst in the world, and we are exporting it to other countries!  That diet is high in processed/junk/fast foods, high in refined carbs, salt, fats (especially veggie oils from frying), preservatives, and chemicals, now in the thousands. Many are not disclosed on food labeling.  This diet helps to spike blood glucose and inflammation, both are detrimental to health and arteries.  Plus, those foods lack quality nutrients or balance (vitamins, minerals, fiber and antioxidants). In fact, those processed carbs like wheat and sugar take vitamins and minerals from other areas to complete digestion, creating a deficit. It's been known for several years that the worst LDL particles (small, dense ones), are driven by wheat and sugar, not cholesterol or saturated fats!  In addition, refined veggie oils (high in omega-6) can quickly oxidize in the body, which also triggers arterial inflammation. The only oil I recommend is EVOO (Extra Virgin Olive Oil) because it has a set of unique antioxidants and anti-inflammatories. It's great for salads or dressing veggies but frying will destroy the delicate antioxidants.  Smoking, inactivity, stress and a lack of sleep also add to weight, inflammation and compromise immune function. Taken together, we have the perfect storm of a bad diet and other habits which contribute to weight gain, hypertension, diabetes, systemic inflammation and athero! It's so bad, they are finding early athero in young people in their teens and 20s!  Here's are some links for more info and source material: 3 Shocking Myths About Heart Disease http://www.sott.net/article/2425...  Embed Quote
