column9: What was your concentration? How did you know you wanted to go into Public Health? How did you finance it? What was your prior education & work experience?What is your personal story leading up to, during, and after the MPH?
column10: I did my Masters in International Health which was public health with a focus on developing countries. I also did this in Australia, so I'm not sure how helpful my answer is going to be but I'll give it a shot for the A2A. I realised I wanted to do International Public Health after a brief stint volunteering in a community based cataract screening and surgery project in Orissa, India. I had previously completed a Bachelor Degree in Human Biology and was in a soul destroying job in a pharmaceutical company, the sole purpose of which was to fund my then expensive taste in clothing (I'm writing this in an man's second hand shirt) and weird obsession with fake nails (ew, gross I know) - things have changed. I went to India not because I had any particular interest in India (now I love it and a little piece of my soul will always reside there) but because I had a crappy day at work and a volunteer thing popped up on my screen and my 21st birthday was coming up and my parents said that I could go on a trip instead of having a party if I wanted. And I applied. I was blown away. First by just how awesome India was, my little slice of Orissa was like a little slice of heaven. But then about the health issues people were facing. What I took issue with though was not the clinical aspect. I wasn't say, super interested in being able to treat a specific child for a specific problem. As a cultural outsider who did not speak the language I really didn't see that as my role. But I was interested in issues of access and equity and resource distribution and epidemiology and initiatves that changed the health of entire communities, of prevention. Rather than returning to the bowels of the pharma industry I thought it better to get the skills I was going to need in my new area of passion. But I also needed experience. So I studied my Masters of International Health at Curtin University (which is in Western Australia) by distance while I worked at the International Centre for Diarrhoeal Diseases Research, Bangladesh (ICDDR,B) on a child health project overseen by the WHO. The Australian government pays for my education. They also paid me to work in Bangladesh for that year. Sweet deal huh? The organisation helped me to conduct my Masters dissertation research which was on the care-seeking behaviours of mothers in the first three days after their baby was born in an area where we were running a Village Health Worker project. I loved it. I worked for that organisation for another year, then moved to South Sudan where I worked on am HIV and Gender Based Violence Project for returning refugees. My Masters helped me get my foot in those doors but a key component was contacts. You really would struggle to get anywhere in development work without contacts and I had been getting progressively better at putting myself out there to make them (self-promotion is an uncomfortable thing for an Australian).l then decided that aside from the skills I got from the Masters I needed other skills. I felt strange telling people how things should be done without any knowledge of how one would do them on the ground. I decided to get my training in nursing and midwifery because of that (I did not have the time nor the patience for a med degree!). And as I suspected, reading an article on how to stop post-partum haemorrhage is significantly different from actually trying to stop someone from haemorrhaging.  The break to do this study wasn't all advantages though. I am only now re-enetering public health development work and am doing it at an entry level (HIV and Tuberculosis Public Health Officer in Botswana).  My only tip with a Masters degree is that it isn't about the degree. Reading a bunch of papers to write your own paper should not be the point and will get you no-where. You have to make connections. Which means you have to network. Which means that you attend every event/lecture/afternoon tea that has even the remotest connection to the field you are interested in. And then you go an ask people a whole bunch of questions and see if they need an RA. And you seek out volunteer work and internships. Make the degree work for you.  P.S. If you haven't already its time to develop an intellectual crush on Hans Rosling and Paul Farmer. Enjoy!  Embed QuoteVia  Ming Law.

column9: What was your concentration? How did you know you wanted to go into Public Health? How did you finance it? What was your prior education & work experience?What is your personal story leading up to, during, and after the MPH?
column10: I earned my MPH in 2001 from UC Berkeley. My background was as a biology undergraduate who had spent 3 years doing bench science molecular biology research. As much as this was a wonderful experience (at UCSF and University of Washington), I was interested in population level determinants of disease so pursued an MPH. An MPH by definition is quite broad in its requirements and emphasis, and it is incumbent on the individual to pursue their own nitch. That having been said, I think it is important not to delay pursuing an MPH because you are not sure of you own specific interest. I went in to an MPH with an interest in infectious diseases, and within the first year found a new focus in social determinants of health. My main point here is to not close yourself off to possible interests that you may not know about prior to enrollment - exposure to a variety of areas of practice and research is fundamental to most MPH programs.An advantage of doing an MPH is the flexibility to purse either an applied or research career based on the degree. In addition to switching from an interest in infectious disease to social determinants of health, I also switched from wanting an applied career in public health to being interested in research. If interested in research, of course, it is essential to pursue a doctorate following the MPH. The good news about PhDs in public health is there is much better funding and you generally don't have to take many loans.My concentration was Epidemiology/Biostatistics, which was great. It was essentially a focus on a methodological toolkit that could be applied to various problems. I generally am of the view that subject specific content can more easily be pursued on ones own, and the more technical content of epidemiology and biostatistics is more easily aquired in the formal academic setting (although of course this can be learned through self-study as well if you have the inclination). I wasn't that enthralled by calculus in undergrad, but applied statistics is a whole other thing - I became totally enthralled.The MPH is a big money maker for schools of public health, so there are few opportunities for funding. The best bet is to get a position as a research assistant that will pay for living expenses and depending on the institution, some coverage of tuition. I'm now an Assistant Professor and hire research assistants for 10-20 hour a week positions that pay about $15/hour but also cover a portion of tuition. You will put yourself in the best position for these positions if you have some programming experience in R or SAS or Stata, but there are a variety of positions that are available. Look for postings for positions at Schools of Public Health that you are interested in applying to, or contact Professors doing research in areas that you are interested in. In addition to helping to fund an MPH, working with a research group is invaluable in learning how Public Health research is done. For me, earning an MPH allowed me to have a switch in my career trajectory, and begin to acquire a statistical analytic toolkit, as well as understand theories of disease causation, which were invaluable to me being able to pursue work that was most aligned with my interests. The curriculum is somewhat of a remarkable balance of intellectual and practical application to improving health. If that suits you, you should pursue it. As I once overheard a physician say, if you really want to help people - don't become a physician - study public health.After getting my MPH, I ended up going on to get my doctorate in public health at Harvard, and am now an Assistant Professor at Stanford. So this is a fairly traditional very academic track. But my colleagues in my MPH program have done a number of diverse pursuits, and in almost all cases have found very fulfilling work, ranging from working at Indian Health Services, to medical school to research assistants to environmental advocates.  Embed QuoteVia  Ming Law.

column9: What was your concentration? How did you know you wanted to go into Public Health? How did you finance it? What was your prior education & work experience?What is your personal story leading up to, during, and after the MPH?
column10: I decided to get an MPH while I was serving in the Peace Corps as a community health volunteer in Peru. I had a bachelor of journalism with little (ok, no) background in science. But my skills in communication seemed to translate pretty well to health education, as I could quickly research topics I knew little about and then translate the information into something that was easy to understand. I spent two years working with community health workers and teen promoters on the prevention of HIV, diarrheal diseases, respiratory infections, dengue, malaria... I loved it. So when I was getting ready to go back to the States, I looked at the different MPH programs around the country. Many are more research-based, but given my background, I wanted more of a practical focus. In the end I applied and went to Tulane University in New Orleans for their health education and communication program. About halfway through my studies, I discovered I had a strong interest in epidemiology (in a nutshell: the study of how diseases appear and move through populations). My advisor encouraged me to explore other departments, and I ended up taking about as many courses related to epidemiology as I did in health education. I was fascinated and found I was most comfortable when I worked with the two concentrations in combination. My experience was enriched a lot by being in New Orleans. It's a wonderful but in some ways still-struggling city, where many of the public health concerns I learned about in the classroom were right there in my neighborhood. Instead of a research thesis, we were required to complete 300 hours of practicum. I did mine at the New Orleans Health Department and also volunteered at a safety-net clinic. Being a part of the health community there not only complemented my studies, but also helped confirm that I was in the right field. So that's the good stuff. The financing was the hard part. My program was expensive, with very few opportunities for scholarships or grants. I and most of my friends financed our education with student loans. For me it was worth it. Even after graduating, I'm still fascinated by current  research and bore (or sometimes horrify) my husband and friends with health-related trivia. Studying public health made me healthier. More in tune with what's going on in our world and more knowledgable about how policy and environments can affect how healthy we are. But that's me. I'd be interested to see how my experience differed from others here on Quora.  Embed QuoteVia  Ming Law.

column9: What was your concentration? How did you know you wanted to go into Public Health? How did you finance it? What was your prior education & work experience?What is your personal story leading up to, during, and after the MPH?
column10: I received my MPH in 2006 with a concentration in environmental public health. I was teaching environmental science in high school at the time and my thought was that the degree would improve my teaching but would also give me additional opportunities outside of teaching and would give me the skill set I need to have a positive impact on the environment.I found that the degree on its own didn't have a lot of teeth; I read a lot of books and wrote a lot of papers but I didn't come out of the program with any tangible skill set. If I had focused on biostats it would have been a different story but the environmental concentration gave me the opportunity to do environmental compliance work.It turned out I hated that work; it's basically writing reports showing that your company isn't doing anything wrong. It's a lot of "I" dotting and "T" crossing.  Most of the jobs that I have seen for environmental related work tend to veer towards government/industrial environmental compliance - other environmental jobs seem to require a background in environmental engineering or industrial ecology.If I had complimented my MPH with another degree, like a masters in environmental engineering or law then maybe I could have had greater opportunities within the environmental field - I am currently looking into a data analytical program to compliment my knowledge with learning to use large data sets for urban sustainability.My caution for anyone interested in an MPH is simple; on its own it probably won't expand you into a ton of opportunities - use it to improve your quantitative skills or complement it with another degree to really stand out.  Embed Quote

column9: What was your concentration? How did you know you wanted to go into Public Health? How did you finance it? What was your prior education & work experience?What is your personal story leading up to, during, and after the MPH?
column10: It is important to know which field of Public Health interests you since there can be many concentrations in it like, Global Health, public policy, health policy, epidemiology, biostatistics, maternal and child health, etc. It is also important to know that for some concentrations in public health,further  education is necessary for better paying jobs. Public health is an incredibly vast field but in order to get an MPH one should do a little bit of studying in what interests you in public health.  Embed Quote

I have an MPH from Yale, and did the application/school-research/acceptance/more-research/decision thing at Yale, UW, & Harvard for the MPH and the same at Berkeley, Harvard, JHSPH, UW, Columbia for a related PhD (Environmental Health Sciences). I've also been in the field for ~ 7 years, and would be happy to answer if you'd mind clarifying a bit about what your criteria are.  Embed Quote

The Colorado School of Public Health offers MPH degree in various areas of studies. We offer students practice-based learning. Students are immersed in the current public health issues and are equipped with the resources and guidance to help them tackle these significant matters. Students are also connected to employers who impact public health locally and globally.  Embed Quote

Pretty much anything but fresh water, nitrogen, and oxygen counts as pollution these days. Hydrocarbons vary a lot. Some are worse than others. Methane is a potent greenhouse gas, benzene is a carcinogen, and butane and pentane cause smog. On the other hand, ethylene is naturally produced by plants and heavier petroleum products like mineral oil and vaseline are safe enough to eat/drink. Unfortunately, hydrocarbons are usually mixes of very-toxic compounds and not-so-toxic compounds. So when you spill them, you don't know whether the spill will biodegrade, or cause air pollution, or whatever else. That's why it's safer to assume that all hydrocarbon spills are bad, just to be safe.  Embed QuoteAnswered in thirty-three minutes.

The most commonly found aerosol particles are Ammonium nitrates and Carbon particles in the size range of (PM 2.5-PM 10). They can cause lung injury, Asthma, COPD, Airway inflammation and many such disorders.  Embed Quote

column9: Does somebody keep track reliably of the air quality index?I am curious to know how it compares with that of Beijing.
column10: I only know of one survey, that is the EPI study conducted jointly by Yale and Columbia university in the US. They study and rank environmental pollution, air quality etc. across nations. You can check out their website here: HomeThey have found Vietnam air pollution among the worst in the world – specifically ranking 123rd, one of the 10 worst nations. Meanwhile, China rank only at 116th.As somebody who has lived 20 years in Ho Chi Minh City, I can attest to the degrading air quality. Now we officially has smog, what the UK had back in the Industrial Revolution of 1700s. Ha Noi's highway and industrial zones are equally bad.However, regions such as Da Nang, Nha Trang or Da Lat – the beach and seaside areas – do have better air quality, the same way as Guilin in China.  Embed Quote

This is a very subjective question. Yes they're over regulated, if you feel you're doing too much work for any sort of public gain. Agriculturalists often feel over burdened when regulations are made far outside the current industry best practices. One example is the recent egg laws to prevent salmonella initiated after the outbreak in 2010. Salmonella is everywhere, but since the law was initiated the increased surveillance has found no more salmonella in eggs. The food is no safer from a farmer's perspective as they already do everything they can to keep their eggs safe for consumers.On the other hand, if something bad happens environmentally, human nature is to look for ways to prevent this from happening again. Regulation often seems to be a sensible answer. And from that perspective, as air and water quality readings improve to an acceptable level, regulation was needed. My opinion:Somewhere in the middle there is a balance, and America is great because everyone has an opportunity to make their case for where the middle is. A blanket answer is hard to pinpoint. There are some (okay, many) areas I think could be less regulated with no risk for food safety or animal welfare. There are other areas (okay, few) where agriculture needs to be regulated more to improve animal welfare or food safety.  Embed Quote

There is no future for agriculture in the U.S.. The farm value of agricultural production in 1997 was US$ 120 billion and expenditures were US$ 189 billion, It reminds me a communist environment. Definitely, it does not work. Some farmers or companies can even get some money, but there is much corruption and vertical integration. I don´t think they can compete with Brazilian farmers in the coming years because there are no rules here, forcing the Brazilian farmers to adopt sophisticated levels of productivity and specialization. A good opportunity for U.S. farmers is to buy land in Brazil and doing here what they do best: a lot of productivity, because they have, at least for while,  the best technological expertise in agriculture.  Embed Quote

column9: And if so, do they clear out certain types of pesticides better than others?Pesticides are a much bigger concern than people usually think they are (as a result of several studies that came out this year) - see http://www.longecity.org/forum/t... and Alex K. Chen's answer to Is organic food better for you? for details
column10: Apparently nothttp://blog.al.com/frugalmom/200...A total of twenty-eight harvests were made including sixteen of lettuce, four of strawberry, four of tomatoes, and four control lettuce batches. Each batch was divided into seven treatment groups. One group was analyzed in an unrinsed state as received from the field; one group was rinsed under tap water for one minute. The five remaining groups were individually treated with either FIT®, Fruit & Vegetable Wash Organiclean, Vegi-Clean, or a 1% solution of Palmolive® and then rinsed under tap water for one minute. In the case of the control lettuce batches all seven-treatment groups were processed in an unrinsed state to ensure that each group contained statistically equivalent pesticide residue levels.A total of 196 samples were processed. Detailed statistical analysis showed that in all cases at least one group was different from the rest. Pairwise comparison showed that the group that was different was the unrinsed produce. There is little or no difference between tap water rinsing or using a fruit and vegetable wash in reducing residues of the nine pesticides studied. The removal of waxes and/or dirt from the produce was not examined as part of this study.If you did not take the time to read all of the mumbo-jumbo written above, here is the quick answer: there was NO difference in the levels of pesticide found on the produce! It did not matter if you washed it with any of the special washes or with watered down soap: they had the same effect as washing with plain old tap water for one minute.Also, some pesticides, particularly neonicotinoid pesticides, are systemic pesticides that are present throughout the entire plant. See examples belowImidacloprid can be applied to many vegetables (including tomatoes and leafy greens) right up to the day they’re harvested.Thiamethoxam was first approved as a seed treatment for corn in 2002, and thiamethoxam products that are applied to the soil have since been approved for use on most vegetable and fruit crops. See a photo of seed corn treated with this chemical.Clothianidin is used as a seed treatment on canola, cereals, corn and sugar beets, and as a soil treatment for potatoes.Dinotefuran can be applied to soil or sprayed on leafy greens, potatoes and cucumber family crops.Read more: http://www.motherearthnews.com/o... (though neonicotinoid pesticides do not appear to be the worst pesticides for humans so far)  Embed Quote

column9: http://cleantechconcepts.com/?p=... Costs?Toxicity?Long term effects on the soil?
column10: It is expensive in relation to other conventional soil amendments per square feet. Once you apply it you can't get rid of it, therefor it should only be used if the area is consistently deficient in water retention. If you dump to much in a heavy soil mix, you will have to fight with various diesases in you turf and landscape. I have seen cases where to much was applied and when the crystals expanded they pushed plant material out of the ground. Some manufacturers make various sizes. I find that a product called Aqua-smart to be the best because partial size is about the grain of sand and is easier to incorporate in the soil.It seems to last about 3-5 years, I have not heard about any long term toxic effects, most manufactures of these products don't have any difinative answers when asked. I think more reaserch needs to be done.It's great to use in sandy soils or where irrigation coverage is spoty and not efficient. It will aid in seed germination for overseeing turf, it will establish bedding and ornamental installations quickly especially in dry areas. It's great for reducing watering needs for container gardens and and raised planters.Use it wisely.  Embed Quote

column9: http://cleantechconcepts.com/?p=... Costs?Toxicity?Long term effects on the soil?
column10: Potassium bicarbonate is a fungicide. You may use it for organic farming in the US. It is generally considered safe to use. The FDA and EU allow it in nourishments too, if I am not mistaken. However, you may also use it as a PH regulator. In the latter case, it has high benefits for acidic soils as decreases the natural solution of AL4+ and other soluble elements. This effect maybe advantageous for acid-sensitive cultivations. Withstanding, if you over do the PH regulation, the solution other necessary elements might be effected (P, S, Fe and others). However, this holds true for any PH regulation method and substance. Thus, it cannot  be considered a disadvantage of only Potassium as such.  Embed Quote

column9: (not inclusive of PM2.5 and brominated flame retardants here, which are also two big concerns)
column10: I mostly focus on chronic effects, since these are the effects that others almost always ignore. So I'm not concerned about CO, but I'm more concerned about neurotoxic non-lethal VOCs.Overall though, the possible neurotoxic effects are the most worrisome. The increased risks of cancer from any of these is very small (see Are we exposed to more carcinogens now than any other time in history? ). One chart here: Loads of EPA Factsheets over at https://www.google.com/search?su...CDC factsheets at http://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/substan... (CDC often has different MRLs than EPA)Concerning:benzeneformaldehydestyrene (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sty... ) [1]. Also, http://www.epa.gov/iris/subst/01.... http://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/mrls/pd... shows 0.02 ppm MRL (or 367 ug/m^3)acetaldehydes (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ace... ) - 7x common indoors than outdoorsxylenes (adds another CH3 group to toluene): http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xyl... - NFPA 2. EPA technical factsheet says that very little is known about chronic effects. 100 ppm produces long-term neurological effects in rats. An MRL of 0.05 ppm has been derived for chronic-duration inhalation exposure. Also see  http://www.epa.gov/iris/subst/02.... 100 ppm = 467 mg/m^3, 0.05 ppm = 234 ug/m^3toluene (anything above 34 ppm (or 138 mg/m^3) carries a risk of neurotoxicity - see  http://www.epa.gov/iris/subst/01... ). http://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/toxprof... shows that lvls in suburban outdoor air are 1.3-6.6 ppb, avg lvls in indoor air are 8 ppb. MRL is 80 ppb (or 325 ug/m^3). 8000 ppb is usually needed for odor detection of toluene. Non-carcinogen.n-hexane (http://www.epa.gov/iris/subst/04...  ). 30 ppm definitely has chronic effects ( see  http://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/toxprof... ), and effects probably exist for an undetermined concentration well below that. http://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/mrls/pd... establishes 0.06 ppm (or 228 ug/m^3) as MRL.See http://www.lenntech.com/calculat... to switch between ppm and ug/m^3Chronic Effects Debateable:ethylene glycol (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eth...). But low vapor pressure and tends to settle down within 10 days. See http://cfpub.epa.gov/ncea/iris/i... . Not a carcinogen, and low-level chronic neurological effects appear to be limited (http://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/toxprof... )butyl ether (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Met... )Chronic Effects Unknown:2-pentylfuran, decanol, propenoic acid (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acr... ), acrylonitrile (acute toxicity very high)Little evidence of chronic effects:Propylene glycol (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pro..., NFPA 0 )vinyl acetate - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vin... .  http://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/toxprof... shows limited toxic effects, non-carcinogenacetone (http://www.epa.gov/iris/subst/01... ), but can potentiate n-hexane toxicity (http://www.epa.gov/iris/subst/04... )It does appear that linoleum does not seem to be as unsafe as the others - the others have something problematic in them though.====[1] http://www.epa.gov/chemfact/styr...Humans — The RfC was calculated from an epidemiological study (U.S. EPA 1994).  Fiftyworkers with an average exposure duration of 8.6 years to concentrations ranging from 10 to 300ppm (43 to 1278 mg/m ) were given a battery of neurophysiological tests for CNS dysfunction.3     For dose comparison purposes this has been calculated by multiplying 370 mg/m  by2                      30.024 (the 80 minute [1.33 hour] breathing rate, 1.66 m  [standard 8-hour breathing rate,310 m ], divided by the assumed adult body weight, 70 kg and assuming 100% absorption) to3obtain the dose in mg/kg (U.S. EPA 1988b).Increases in reaction times and decreases in memory/concentration correlated to both exposureconcentration and duration of exposure.  Urinary metabolite concentrations of mandelic acid andphenylglyoxylic acid correlated to exposure concentration and depressed CNS function.  Basedon these data the U.S. EPA (1994) calculated a chronic RfC for styrene of 1 mg/m  (0.23 ppm).3Human volunteers exposed to 370-591 mg/m  (85.1-135.93 ppm) for 80 minutes had alterations3in visual suppression and saccade (rapid, intermittent eye movements) tests when compared tounexposed controls (U.S. EPA 1994).  The concentration of 370 mg/m  is roughly equivalent to38.88 mg/kg over the 80 minute period .2Boat builders occupationally exposed for an average of 10.8 years to 50-140 mg/m  styrene3showed alterations in the vestibuloocular reflex (U.S. EPA 1994).  Other occupational studieshave linked styrene exposure to hearing loss (138 mg/m  for 8.6 years) and decreased visuomotor3accuracy (25 ppm for 4.9 years) (U.S. EPA 1994).  Longer reaction times have been reported inseveral occupational studies with exposure concentrations ranging from 9 to >150 ppm anddurations of days to years (U.S. EPA 1984).====A chart that plots indoor vs. outdoor distributions (though it's far from representative):VOCs present in much higher levels in indoor air than outdoor air (on the first chart):Toluene: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tol...Hexane: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hex... Not toxic per se, but its metabolite is.Pentane: appears innocuous (NFPA 1)Limonene: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lim...Methylene Chloride: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dic... (least toxic of the chlorohydrocarbons, though has some effects)(it goes on, but the chart makes it impossible to compare levels of the truly worrisome VOCs...)Second chart:Benzene (uh oh)Undecane, nonaneEucalyptolacetic acid (butyl ester)alpha pinenebenzothiazoleethyl acetate(millions of other decane isomers)... Decane is NFPA 1VOCs present in higher levels in outdoor air than indoor air (in first chart):hexadecaneoctadecanenaphthalenepentadecane  Embed QuoteAnswered in two minutes.

column9: (not inclusive of PM2.5 and brominated flame retardants here, which are also two big concerns)
column10: VOCs are difficult to isolate in measurements, so usually a emission permit will simply specify a substitute such as PM2.5 and mercury rates as being indicative of VOC removal success. In most cases removal of VOCs is accomplished simultaneously with efforts to remove particulate matter and acidic gases such as SO2 and NOx. Common methods to remove these compounds (and thus VOCs) include combustion control (low NOx burners), wet scrubbers, and fabric filter dust collection systems (baghouses). At times dust collection equipment such as baghouses are supplemented with sorbent or activated carbon injection to control elements such as mercury (formerly treated as a VOC by the EPA). Samuel DalSantoBaghouse.comParticulate FilterAir PollutionVolatile Organic Compounds  Embed Quote

column9: Detectable, but undisclosed concentrations of fission byproducts, including Cs137, have already been measured in California's rain water and air.   How do measured levels of decay count-per-minute translate into airborne concentrations that residents are breathing?  What are the pharmacodynamics of inhaled and ingested Cs137 particles?
column10: Cesium is soluble and metabolized like potassium, leaving the body in an average of several weeks. It does not form insoluble particles, or concentrate and remain in organs. This is very different from strontium-90 that can be incorporated in bone, or from plutonium or radon daughters which can stay in the lung indefinitely and be a cancer risk, even though those alpha emitters have no external exposure hazard, and not that high toxicity even on oral ingestion.Cesium-137 risk is mostly from regularly eating produce grown in a zone with radioactive cesium remaining in the soil.  Embed Quote

column9: Detectable, but undisclosed concentrations of fission byproducts, including Cs137, have already been measured in California's rain water and air.   How do measured levels of decay count-per-minute translate into airborne concentrations that residents are breathing?  What are the pharmacodynamics of inhaled and ingested Cs137 particles?
column10: Radiation expert Jonathan Links answered this question during a live Q&A on WashingtonPost.com:"In fact, the State of Maryland has been able to detect I-131 in air and rainwater. BUT it's important to appreciate just how good/sensitive our radiation detectors are these days, and detecting or measuring per se is not the same thing as public health risk. With respect to "units," 1 Bequerrel = 1 decay per second; 1 Curie = 3.7 10^10 decays per sec.I-131 and Cs-137 particles can be inhaled or ingested. Their distribution in the body and clearance from it (toxicokinetics) depends on the specific physico-chemical form; their effects on the body (toxicodynamics) depends on the kinetics and doses. I-131 is mainly a thyroid threat; Cs-137 can have a broader distribution in the body."Check out the rest of this Q&A about radiation in the United States: http://wapo.st/hhFCZk  Embed Quote

Note: There are lots of articles - the two most convincing ones (both released in 2011) are about the brain.An excellent summary here: http://blogs.discovermagazine.co... (from What are the health risks to an adult of living within a half-mile of a freeway?)Sources I collected earlier:Source 0http://ehp.niehs.nih.gov/wp-cont...Source 1http://www.sciencedaily.com/rele...Paper at http://dx.doi.org/10.1289/ehp.10...This is the first to explore the physical effect of freeway pollution on brain cells. The authors found a way to recreate air laden with freeway particulate matter inside the laboratory. Whether in a test tube or in live mice, brain cells showed similar responses:Neurons involved in learning and memory showed significant damage. The brain showed signs of inflammation associated with premature aging and Alzheimer's diseaseNeurons from developing mice did not grow as wellFrom the paper:Neuropathological findings consistent with these cognitive changes have been reported based on comparisons of samples collected from Mexico City and control cities (Tlaxcala and Veracruz), which represent extremes in ambient PM. Brains of children and young adult accident victims showed a higher prevalence of diffuse amyloid-β peptide deposits, activated glia, and oxidized DNA in residents of highly polluted Mexico City compared with subjects from control cites (Calderón-Garcidueñas et al. 2008)Source 2http://www.sciencedaily.com/rele...In a learning and memory test, mice were placed in the middle of a brightly lit arena and given two minutes to find an escape hole leading to a dark box where they feel more comfortable. They were given five days of training to locate the escape hole, but the mice who breathed the polluted air took longer to learn where the escape hole was located. The mice exposed to polluted air also were less likely to remember where the escape hole was when tested later.Paper at http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/mp.201...Results showed clear physical differences in the hippocampi of the mice who were exposed to polluted air compared to those who weren't.The researchers looked specifically at branches that grow off of nerve cells (or neurons) called dendrites. The dendrites have small projections growing off them called spines, which transmit signals from one neuron to another.Mice exposed to polluted air had fewer spines in parts of the hippocampus, shorter dendrites and overall reduced cell complexity."Previous research has shown that these types of changes are linked to decreased learning and memory abilities," said Nelson.In other studies, several of the co-authors of this study from the Davis research center found that chronic exposure to polluted air leads to widespread inflammation in the body, which is linked to a variety of health problems in humans, including depression. This new study found evidence that this low-grade inflammation is evident in the hippocampus.In mice that breathed the polluted air, chemical messengers that cause inflammation -- called pro-inflammatory cytokines -- were more active in the hippocampus than they were in mice who breathed the filtered air."The hippocampus is particularly sensitive to damage caused by inflammation," Fonken said."We suspect that the systemic inflammation caused by breathing polluted air is being communicated to the central nervous system."‎"Male mice exposed to reaerosolized nPM for 10 weeks (3 days/week, 5 hr/day; 150 hr total)"that's a pretty realistic exposure too===http://www.sciencedaily.com/rele... (Air Pollution Linked to Cognitive Decline in Women)http://www.sciencedaily.com/rele... (Even Moderate Air Pollution Can Raise Stroke Risks)===Some articles that focus on exposure, rather than health effects:http://www.citeulike.org/user/In...http://www.citeulike.org/user/In...http://www.citeulike.org/user/In...==(http://www.sciencedaily.com/rele... )Prenatal exposure to environmental pollutants known as polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) can adversely affect a child's intelligence quotient or IQ, according to new research by the the Columbia Center for Children's Environmental Health (CCCEH) at the Mailman School of Public Health. PAHs are chemicals released into the air from the burning of coal, diesel, oil and gas, or other organic substances such as tobacco. In urban areas motor vehicles are a major source of PAHs.The study found that children exposed to high levels of PAHs in New York City had full scale and verbal IQ scores that were 4.31 and 4.67 points lower, respectively than those of less exposed children. High PAH levels were defined as above the median of 2.26 nanograms per cubic meter (ng/m3).  Embed QuoteAnswered in one minute.

column9: Do diesel vehicles really produce this much PM pollution? Or could it be something else? Like direct injection spark ignition technology?
column10: I'm not sure what you meant when you wrote: "roadways so full of particulate matter pollution". I will assume that it is something that you can both see and smell, perhaps best described as road haze.There are numerous sources of particulate matter that are not directly related to the exhaust of a gasoline powered car. Among them are dust from tires, brakes and the road itself. Diesel engine exhaust, of course, remains the greatest source of visible particulate matter. Progress has been made to greatly reduce diesel exhaust PM and there is still a long way to go. In any case, I think we are stuck with the substantial dust pollution from the abrasion of tires, brakes and roads no matter how clean the combustion process becomes. In this regard, cabin air filters are a great idea.  Embed Quote

column9: (not just for temperature - but I'm also curious about indoor air pollution)And does this apply even if there are no pressure differences between indoor air and outdoor air?
column10: This is a tricky question, because there's actually a lot of variables here, mostly when you're talking about pollution.The short answer is yes, it will make a difference especially for temperature, but probably not enough to really matter for the carrying of pollutants. If you're assuming that you have an air conditioner on, then I would say that the amount of air the air conditioner is pulling in is probably vastly greater than the amount of air that would be exchanged by diffusion or convection through a doorway, so difference in temperature between inside and outside wouldn't make that much difference overall.If you assume that there is no machine drawing in or expelling air from inside the building, you're still left with a few different possibilities.I assume that you mean this for a real-life scenario.  In that case, it's not possible to have a uniform pressure system, because there's just too much going on.  Since your house, in general, is not airtight, you can't even have uniform pressure in a single room.  Even a beam of sunlight streaming through the window will heat the air in its path, changing the density and causing convection currents.Convection currents are the main driver for movement of particles in air.  Pure diffusion of these particles would make it take years before you could smell an air freshener you plugged in on the other side of the room.With this in mind, a big temperature difference will drive faster convection.  However, there are two caveats to this.  First, the range of temperatures that you are likely to experience in your house/outside isn't really all that large. It won't drive crazy convection on a small scale.  Second, most indoor air pollution comes from sources inside your house, to the degree where, except on the smoggiest of days, your house is the net pollution creator.The physical result of this is that if your house is 70 degrees when it's 30 out and you leave the door open, yes, you'll probably feel a little more airflow than if it's 70 inside and out (or, God forbid, 30 inside and out) and you leave the door open. That airflow will contain pollutants, probably, but it will generally be fresher than the air it's replacing from inside your house. So the net flow is probably actually pollutant-negative.  Embed Quote

column9: (not just for temperature - but I'm also curious about indoor air pollution)And does this apply even if there are no pressure differences between indoor air and outdoor air?
column10: Yes and no.  In the case of parts of your house that retain heat (think chimneys and crawl spaces and attics), yes, the heat history of those places tend to influence how they suck air in or blow it out, and the present difference between indoors and out enters in.  For example, if it got really cold last night, you'll get cold air coming in through your chimney, whereas if it didn't get so cold, the chimney will not suck in as much new air.  Ditto for your crawl space.  Ditto for your attic.Otherwise not so much, because you are dealing with simple convection through windows and gaps.  You'll feel more of a change indoors if the temperature differential is high, but that isn't because more air is moving, it is just because what air is moving is of a different temperature.  Embed Quote

It is a wonderfully varied field. It all depends upon what you have trained for and what you can excel at. There are Environmental Health Nurses, Environmental Health Educators, Industrial Hygienists, Environmental Health & Safety professionals, and Sanitarians or Registered Environmental Health Specialists.Almost all of them have a general knowledge of environmental health, EHS usually lean more towards safety and compliance, Nurses tend to stay closer to the medical end, IH’s are similar to EHS but in my experience tend to be more process oriented. REHS is usually trained as a generalist and can do education to Hazardous spill response, communicable disease investigation, and your public health nuisance complaints.I enjoy the variety. I’ve been on both the regulatory and private side of the field. I do enjoy the public service better, feel like you have a greater impact. There is much to be said about the private sector especially in the present climate of hate of government employees.Even if you don’t want to generalize a great deal, say you just wanted to do food safety education and inspections there is the ability to get down that specific in this field.  Embed QuoteVia  Alex K. Chen.

Depends upon what you mean by environmental health. As indicated by the previous post, it is an extremely varied field which may include the following job positions:Public health inspectors, including food, restaurant, and sanitation inspectors;Private sector regulatory compliance professionals. These typically include OSHA; EPA compliance staff and professionals;Environmental toxicologists;Occupational Toxicology;Industrial hygienists - who anticipate, recognize, evaluate, and design controls to occupational hazards;Environmental remediation and field study personnel. Which may perform duties such as soil and groundwater sampling; andEnvironmental health professionals in labs who perform analysis of a wide variety of samples.It most likely when you first enter the field you will get out and do a lot of field work and will be outside or in manufacturing facilities. It's great to get that experience in when it's early in your career. It adds perspective.Depending upon your interests it may be possible that you will work almost entirely indoors managing EHS software for the collection of compliance information and corrective actions.At some point in your career, typically after 5 -10 years of experience, you should consider professional certification such as a CSP, CIH, CHMM, or the like.  Embed Quote

column9: More specifically, I am referring to mesopredators like coyotes which are partially filling niches that have been left empty due to the extirpation of large predators like wolves, bears, and cougars.
column10: tl;dr - When mesopredators are overabundant, the results are not good for prey species diversity.Mesopredators are mid-ranking predators in food webs. They may be preyed upon by top (apex) predators, and may also compete with them for prey in lower trophic levels. Typical mesopredators in much of America include cats, raccoons, and skunks. What constitutes a mesopredator varies between communities; coyotes may be top predators in some communities and mesopredators in others.The mesopredator release hypothesis proposes that as populations of top predators decline, mesopredators begin to increase as they are less likely to get eaten by top predators, and also no longer have to compete with top predators for prey in lower trophic levels.A major prediction in some formulations of the hypothesis is that as mesopredator populations rise, there will be more pressure on prey species. Some of them may go extinct, leading to a drop in biodiversity. The hypothesis remains controversial in part because it discusses top-down effects in trophic cascades - the effects top predators have in structuring communities - while ignoring bottom-up effects - the control that producers and primary consumers might have on higher trophic levels. It's not a universally accepted hypothesis.(A typical mesopredator. Note the guilty look in its eyes.[1])Obviously, humans don't like having top predators like wolves wandering around cities and suburban areas, so top predator populations tend to decline pretty precipitously in areas undergoing human development. In addition, because about 90% of energy is lost at each trophic level, top predators need more area to subsist. Since human development tends to fragment natural environments, it especially hurts apex predators.But testing the mesopredator release hypothesis and its effect on prey abundance and health is tough. Ecologists tend to frown upon shooting all the top predators in an area; it's not a great strategy to test how ecosystems get ruined by ruining more ecosystems. And because the hypothesis has not been extensively tested, it's still controversial.The classic study on this is Crooks and Soulé's "Mesopredator release and avifaunal extinctions in a fragmented system," published in Nature in 1999. Based on the disappearance of coyotes (the apex predator) in southern California, the study concluded that the number of coyotes in a land fragment was positively correlated with bird abundance and diversity, and the number of mesopredators was negatively correlated with bird abundance and diversity. The results were (mostly) highly statistically significant. The study also identified domestic cats as especially problematic species in SoCal, especially since they thrive far above carrying capacity due to "nutritional subsidies" from their owners.(taken from Crooks and Soulé, 1999)A mathematical model for mesopredator release is proposed in Courchamp et al. "Cats protecting birds: Modelling the mesopredator release effect" (in Journal of Animal Ecology, 1999). The system of differential equations can result in a number of different states, but in general it seems like top predators have a positive effect on ecosystems, and their elimination can hurt prey abundance. (The study says little about diversity, since it uses one "generic" species to represent each trophic level.)"Trophic control of mesopredators in terrestrial ecosystems: top-down or bottom up?" by Elmhagen and Rushton (in Ecology Letters, 2007) examined the decline of lynx and wolf populations in large swaths of Sweden on the rise of the red fox to dominance, while also studying the effect of the productivity of the land, a bottom-up effect. The authors concluded that the top-down effect of mesopredator release was amplified in areas of high productivity; in short, the top-down and bottom-up effects interact.A few other important studies:"Song sparrows, top carnivores, and nest predation: A test of the mesopredator release hypothesis" by C. M. Rogers and M. J. Caro (in Oecologia, 1998) was a study of the effect of the elimination of large canids and felids in southern Michigan on nest-destroying mesopredators like raccoons. It supported the hypothesis by showing that the reintroduction of coyotes helped song sparrow nests succeed."Positive Effects on Game Species of Top Predators by Controlling Smaller Predator Populations: An Example With Lynx, Mongooses, and Rabbits" by Palomares et al. (in Conservation Biology, 1995) was not experimental but showed a similar result; game species like rabbits tend to be more abundant in areas with top predators."Cascading Effects of the Loss of Apex Predatory Sharks from a Coastal Ocean" by Myers et al. (in Science, 2007) is one of the major studies documenting the effect in marine communities. Reduction in large shark populations on the East Coast of the U.S. is correlated with in increase in populations of smaller elasmobranchs (rays, skates, small sharks), which has led to the decimation of many commercially important shellfish populations.There have been dozens more studies on mesopredator release, almost all of which seem to confirm that it has a negative effect on prey. A comprehensive review is Prugh et al.'s "The Rise of the Mesopredator" (in BioScience, 2009). The evidence for the mesopredator release hypothesis seems pretty strong, although I wouldn't be shocked to discover some kind of unintentional confirmatory bias at work. I'd like to see more work along the lines of Elmhagen and Rushton's study, seeing how these top-down effects interact with bottom-up effects.The irony of all this is that many people persecute top predators on the premise that they compete with humans for game species. The reality is that killing off top species will likely hurt game species rather than help, thus throwing the ecosystem's health off balance. The implications of the mesopredator release hypothesis suggest that if humans need to develop more land, we'll somehow need to figure out how to do that without causing even more fragmentation. Either that, or we'll have to coexist with the top predators - and I don't see that happening.[1] I found this photo on some random site on the Internet, but it has been traced back to Corey Arnold: http://www.coreyfishes.com/ If you are Mr. Arnold or someone affiliated with him and want this image removed, contact me and I'll take it down immediately.  Embed QuoteVia  Anonymous.

column10: Most consumers don't like the thought of pesticides on food. However, even more intolerable is the thought of insects having partially eaten the food.  Modern pesticides are so potent that farmers are down to spraying teaspoons per acre. Also note, that there are naturally derived pesticides (like Spinosad) that are sprayed on many organic crops because the rules of organic say they can, and because pest pressure is so heavy on farmers. Put yourself in their shoes: pretend you have an apple farm and you've been farming it for a few years. Last year about 5% of your trees had insect damaged fruit, but this year it's 25%. What do you do? What is your first inclination? What do you think will happen next year if you continue to use no pesticides?  Embed Quote

Maneb is used on a wide variety of food/feed crops, including fruit and nut crops, vegetable crops, field and forage crops, grapes, field crop seeds, and others; ornamental plants in nurseries and greenhouses; and sod farms. There are no residential uses, and no agricultural uses that could result in exposure to maneb in residential settings(from http://www.epa.gov/oppsrrd1/REDs...)Bolded part is wrongSee this study (journal article is linked): http://www.sciencedaily.com/rele...That epidemiological study didn't examine farmers who constantly work with pesticides but people who simply lived near where farm fields were sprayed with the fungicide maneb and the herbicide paraquat. It found that the risk for Parkinson's disease for these people increased by 75 percent.Now a follow-up study adds two new twists. Once again the researchers returned to California's fertile Central Valley, and for the first time have implicated a third pesticide, ziram, in the pathology of Parkinson's disease. Second, instead of looking just at whether people lived near fields that were sprayed, they looked at where people worked, including teachers, firefighters and clerks who worked near, but not in, the fields.Also, atrazine (which is a triazine herbicide)In 2006 the EPA concluded that the triazine herbicides posed "no harm that would result to the general U.S. population, infants, children or other... consumers."[4]Yet...Some studies suggest that even the concentrations meeting U.S. federal standards may be dangerous, with implications for human birth defects, low birth weights and menstrual problems.[1] Findings from further studies released in early 2010 have tended to support the conclusion that even low doses can increase health risks, leading to calls for further testing and renewed EPA evaluation of atrazine's safety.[21]In August 2009, Atrazine was prominently featured in the New York Times as a potential cause of birth defects, low birth weights and menstrual problems when consumed at concentrations below federal standards.[1] A Natural Resources Defense Council's Report on Atrazine suggested that the EPA is ignoring atrazine contamination in surface and drinking water in the central United States.[22]===Also, the September 11 aftermathSee http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chr...Whitman appeared twice in New York City after the September 11 attacks to inform New Yorkers that the toxins released by the attacks posed no threat to their health.[27] On September 18, the EPA released a report in which Whitman said, "Given the scope of the tragedy from last week, I am glad to reassure the people of New York and Washington, D.C. that their air is safe to breathe and their water is safe to drink." She also said, "The concentrations are such that they don't pose a health hazard...We're going to make sure everybody is safe."[28] Later, a 2003 report by the EPA's inspector general determined that such assurances were misleading, because the EPA "did not have sufficient data and analyses" to justify the assertions when they were made.[29]A report in July 2003 from the EPA's Office of Solid Waste and Emergency Response gave extensive documentation supporting many of the inspector general's conclusions, and carried some of them still further.[30] Further, the report found that the White House had "convinced EPA to add reassuring statements and delete cautionary ones" by having the National Security Council control EPA communications after the September 11 attacks.[31] And the result of that? http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hea...An ongoing Pennsylvania State University/Monmouth University study reported that respiratory illnesses grew by more than two hundred percent in the year and a half after the September 11 attacks. (This was the first study that monitored police officers at the Ground Zero site. It was published in the "Journal of Occupational and Environmental Medicine.") In this study of 471 police officers, 19 percent of the officers in October 2001 experienced shortness of breath; 44 percent of the officers experienced shortness of breath in April 2003. The percentage of the 471 officers coughing upphlegm increased from 14 percent in October 2001 to 31 percent in 2003.[20]A 2006 medical study of fire fighters reported that those personnel who inhaled Ground Zero air essentially lost 12 years of lung function.[20] Additionally, a Mount Sinai report found that 70 percent of recovery and rescue workers reported an increase in debilitated respiratory function between 2002 and 2004.[20][21]A 2008 report by New York City's Department of Health indicated that up to 70,000 people might have long term health problems due to the dust. The findings were the result of the city's health registry of September 11 first responders, residents, and others.[22]  Embed QuoteAnswered in one minute.

column9: "Here is what we know from a scientific point of view: There is no amount of wood smoke that is good to breathe. It is at least as bad for you as cigarette smoke, and probably much worse. (One study found it to be 30 times more potent a carcinogen.) The smoke from an ordinary wood fire contains hundreds of compounds known to be carcinogenic, mutagenic, teratogenic, and irritating to the respiratory system. Most of the particles generated by burning wood are smaller than one micron—a size believed to be most damaging to our lungs. In fact, these particles are so fine that they can evade our mucociliary defenses and travel directly into the bloodstream, posing a risk to the heart. Particles this size also resist gravitational settling, remaining airborne for weeks at a time."

column10: First off, as a professional mold mitigation contractor, IICRC certified master water restorer, and applied microbial remediation specialist, I never recommend trying to clean mold off of or out of highly porous surfaces. No product is %100 effective, and the more porous a material is the more unlikely it becomes that all mold spores can be removed. In situations where we come across moldy mattresses, we dispose of the mattress. If the customer wants us to clean it anyways, we get a limitation of liability form signed so that they are aware that by not allowing us to work to our industry standard, they will be assuming the liability for any future issues that arise from microbial growth.Vinegar is not really effective or recommended as a fungicide or biocide. You could pour a 50/50 bleach water solution onto the upholstery, which would likely ruin it. It is an EPA recommended method. I personally don't recommend it though. Bleach is not proven to be effective either, and it will only really have a strong effect on previously cleaned, non-porous surfaces. A cushion is not that at all. Whatever liquids you apply, unless you are using some mechanical force to inject it into the cushions, there is no real way to ensure that it is going to come into contact with the entirety of the affected materials. A bigger problem is that most mold spores are hygrophobic. When you start applying liquids, they start reacting. Some, by releasing spores, some by excreting mycotoxins. Any surface, porous or not, that we apply a microbial solution to must first be thoroughly HEPA vacuumed to reduce the spore count. An abundance of mold spores is no less a potential hazard than an area of active mold growth. They are allergens, some are toxic, and all will take root and grow if suitable conditions return.So, if re-upholstering or "junking" the car are not options, and you really must try to clean the mold of of the upholstery and out of the cushions, I would have your car's upholstery professionally steam cleaned by an outfit that has experience dealing with mold. Many carpet cleaners run a water damage service on the side and have the experience, and so the the big outfits like Service Master or Servpro. The scope of work I would recommend is this:1. Thorough HEPA vacuuming of all surfaces in the car.2. Ultra Low Volume Fog with MDF-500, Sporicidin, or some other product specifically labelled as an EPA registered FUNGICIDE. (Very important.)3. Steam clean all upholstery in the car. Multiple passes on all affected areas. Rinse should have an antimicrobial product, or follow cleaning with another ULV fog.4. Dry the car thoroughly. Preferably, mechanically with air movers and dehumidification. It is critical that the upholstery be completely free of excess moisture.Anything less than that, and I wouldn't be confident that the mold remediation was effective. The stuff is tougher to kill than most give credit, and spores left behind can ensure the problem will be ongoing. I warn against band-aid solutions. Not stopping this thing dead in its tracks will cost more in the long run than having it done by experts.  Embed Quote

column9: Does anyone know:- What type of cavity insulation is environmentally preferred, and also better for human health?- And what would be the best solution for a building that is already in place (which would perhaps need the insulation to be injected into the cavity)?Many thanks for helping!David
column10: Well, there are a couple of options, but no simple answer.There's at least one company (http://www.bondedlogic.com/) that makes insulation from recycled denim. So the material itself is just cotton. Insulation can also be made from cellulose which can also be made from recycled materials. Both are available as batts or loose for blowing into an existing cavity.The thing is that both denim and cellulose are flammable so in order to use them as insulation, they have to be treated with chemicals so they can't catch fire. They also have to be treated with chemicals to prevent the growth of mold. Of course, the old stand-by is fiberglass. Some companies are starting to use recycled glass to make the fiberglass. Fiberglass doesn't require chemical treatment to prevent fire or mold, but it does need a binder chemical to hold it together in batts. These binders often contain formaldehyde. If you're going to use the loose insulation to fill a cavity, it doesn't need a binder, so no formaldehyde.I used the recycled denim in my own house. I like the idea that the insulation was made from something that was going to be thrown away otherwise. The fire-retardant chemicals used are not really that bad, as I understand. Plus, once they're sealed up in the walls, I don't think much will seep through to the living space.  Embed Quote

column10: There are quite a few. There is pump and treat. The treatment would be determined by the site and contaminant. You could have air striping, reverse osmosis, filters, introduction of biological agents such as bacteria, activated carbon, other chemicals to neutralize or bind with the contaminant for removal. Many of these options are used in combination with one another. The pumping is used to prevent the plume from spreading further. If it isn't a deep water contamination sometimes curtain drains similar to leachate pipes in landfills are used to contain it. Treatment can be done either on or off-site. If onsite the clean water is can be irrigated back on the site with sprinklers or similar to eventually return to the aquifer, pumped into a return well, or disposed into a sanitary sewer. If offsite, the contaminated  water is brought to a certified treatment facility for disposal. The very last resort, if it cannot be cleaned, is to try to contain the plume and forbid the use of the aquifer for irrigation and potable use.   Embed Quote

This is entirely possible but it's likely that the other effects of that particular contaminant that will influence the animals more profoundly.  There is quite a bit of research that has been conducted with this polutant suggesting that it may have endocrine disrupting effects.  This could result in masculinization or feminization of entire groups of animals making reproduction extremely difficult at best.  While cognitive decline may influence humans and other animals alike, I've yet to be convinced that animals that actually have the ability to solve complex problems presented to them by human researchers actually "need" this ability in their daily lives.  Many animals (especially caching animals like birds and squirrels) have extensive associative abilities but to actually survive, they may not need them.  Especially if all individuals were affected by the polutant equally and the entire population is affected.  For example, I did a summer of field work trapping small mammals (field mice, shrew and the like).  To do this research, I would set out live traps that I've baited with some soft bedding, a bunch of seeds and sometimes even a little peanut butter (if I knew my overnight guest would be a pregnant female). It was basically a nice cozy place to sleep without the possibility of being picked off by a predator and a 5-star meal.   I would usually catch the same bunch of animals over and over and by the end of the summer, I honestly believed that the mice would look back at me, give me a thumbs up and say "see you tomorrow night".  At one of my sites I had what I believed was a herd of squirrels that would come along, open up all my traps (by lifting an aluminum lever), eat my food and jet.  So after a few nights of this, I basically decided I, a mere mortal human, would outsmart the squirrels.  Night after night, I increased the number of steps and the complexity of movements required to get into the traps.  I failed miserably.  They got through 8 or 9 steps to be able to lift that little lever.  All this to say, squirrels are f-ing smart, they can remember a whole lot of sh&t and a sequence of it but is it required for survival, maybe not necessarily.  Embed Quote

The most common VOC dangers in clothing come from dry-cleaning chemicals and cheap anti-wrinkle treatments.Avoid cheap wrinkle-free shirts if you have a formaldehyde allergy, and don't accept clothes from your dry cleaner that have a chemical smell and you'll be fine.  Embed Quote

In rural regions it is very common to drink water straight from the well with no purification or disinfection. Also, these wells can be surrounded by agricultural areas which have pesticides applied to them. Another reason can be that these wells are not as deep as a well used by a water purification plant. A deeper well can have less pesticides in its water because there is a greater chance of the pesticides getting trapped or breaking down as it soaks through the earth.  Embed Quote

column9: What are the benefits and drawbacks of the superfund? How could it be improved?
column10: The statutory regime is underfunded (i.e. there is no "Superfund" left) and has carve-outs which limit its effectiveness regarding substances like oil and sewage.  But, clever lawyers (including those that work for EPA) find ways to work around these problems.  Aside from this, the CERCLA statute is vague and unclear regarding statutes of limitations and really not geared toward the sort of mega-sites that people want to see cleaned up.  So, companies pay to clean up and then litigate amongst themselves endlessly.  A lot of the criticisms you mention in your post are overblown.  Tons of articles have been written about how EPA, as an agency, has been captured by industry which has used science to stymie laudable attempts at public health. Maybe some of these are accurate.  But, cleaning up really polluted sites presents huge engineering challenges and, by nature, is going to take time -- maybe more time than it took to pollute the sites in the first place.  And cleaning a really polluted site to greenfield standards just doesn't make economic sense.  Embed Quote

column9: As in, levels below those needed to produce any physiological effects?Personally, I'm far more worried about particulate matter and other VOCs. Some of them accumulate and some of them do long-lasting damage to cell membranes and DNA. Meanwhile, CO is nontoxic to plants and doesn't do damage to cell membranes/DNA. It's acutely toxic (just because it takes up hemoglobin slots that oxygen would otherwise take up), but people have already adopted safety measures for the acutely toxic things. They just systematically underestimate the risk from the things that aren't acutely toxic, but that can do long-lasting damage.Yes, I know that sublethal doses of CO can be bad. But these are related to oxygen deprivation and not the effects of CO itself. To the extent that CO doesn't significantly depress the body's usage of oxygen, I don't worry about it as much as I worry about the VOCs and particulate matter.But, I'd really like to see anyone else who might say something else.
column10: In the UK, in Post-Mortems (autopsy) we do not routinely screen for Carbon Monoxide in the blood (COHb) , we do not know how big a problem it is. A good document is the Effects on health of prolonged exposure to low concentrations of carbon monoxide - to me it seems we are tolerant to low levels (concentrations)  of Carbon Monoxide over short periods, the real issue comes with low levels over a greater period. The drive for better insulation in the home, fuel efficiency and airtightness in building I personally believe means this issue will grow in importance. At he moment I campaign hard to just get Working Smoke Alarms and Working Carbon Monoxide Alarms into homes, but I think they will come a time, where we will have Wifi or Zigbee enabled Alarms and our iPad's (Tablets) will graph the CO in our homes over time.  Embed Quote

Yes it does.  The Vancouver Aquarium adopted four sea otters after the Exxon Valdez spill (1989), and three of them have died of cancer (IIRC).  Other animals were adopted by various zoos and/or monitored after that spill and there have been quite a few reports on their poor health.The human workers who helped in the clean-up have also had adverse health effects.[1][1] http://www.adn.com/evos/stories/...  Embed Quote

column9: Worst meaning most hazardous to the humans exposed
column10: Imagine a city hospital rating only a few percent of a city's people healthy.Imagine your child dying because the food he ate, the water he drank and the ground he played on, were all toxic.Imagine women and children being poisoned to death by the air inside their home.Imagine corporations pumping toxins into wells at night and then proving impossible to be located.Just some of the upbeat reading in non-profit The Blacksmith Institute's 2006 report "The World's Worst Polluted Places - The Top Ten"."The Scale of the ProblemThere are grisly side effects to many of the early advances of industrial society – and often those who do not see the benefits are the ones who suffer the most.The richer countries can afford to enforce high standards of environmental protection (although we continually see that the insidious effects of very low levels of pollution are often worse than expected). However, in many other countries there is not the understanding, the commitment or the resources to apply similar levels of protection.The problems are often made worse when industrial (or mining or similar) facilities close down, normally because they are no longer making enough money for the owners (who may be private or public but are often hard to track down). Whatever employment opportunities existed – usually meager – are immediately lost, leaving contaminated workers, buildings and surrounding fields as an unwanted legacy. In the worst cases, the operators of noxious facilities have gone to considerable lengths to avoid having to deal with their dung. There are many cases of sludge being trucked away to end up in fields and wetlands, of midnight dumping to sewers and even of toxic wastewater being pumped down wells in frightening displays of “out-of-sight” management.The cumulative scale of these problems is immense. Work by WHO and the World Bank has produced estimates that perhaps 20% or more of the premature deaths worldwide are related to environmental factors.Dirty water and polluted air are the two biggest issues and WHO also notes lead (Pb) as one of the major environmental risks.The real tragedies, however, are often at a local scale, where the contamination can be hundreds of times greater than global standards. In these communities impacts can be immediate and deadly as well as indicating slower poisoning.Examples can be found in all of the Top Ten and in other sites nominated for listing. In every location, legacy pollution levels exceed all local and international standards for toxic substances.A particular concern in all these cases is the accumulation and long lasting burden to the environment and to the bodies of people most directly affected. Closing a factory or putting treatment on a discharge will stop the immediate cause and prevent further contamination. Despite the immense value these steps add, they do little to deal with what has already been released to the environment.For this reason, a key focus of Blacksmith’s work and a fundamental criterion for identifying the World’s Worst, is the nature of the pollutants. The biggest concern is heavy metals, such as lead, chromium and mercury; and long lasting chemicals such as the “Persistent Organic Pollutants” or “POPs’. These are generated and released from a wide range of processes and industries, although there are a number of main “known offenders” and common patterns."The PDF linked below has detail on each site and further locations.http://www.blacksmithinstitute.o...  Embed QuoteAnswered in eleven minutes.

column9: I rent a townhouse, which is physically connected to three other townhouses, so I'm looking for techniques I can apply inside my home and outside doors and windows. My management company is supposed to spray for them twice yearly, but they keep getting in.
column10: It is important to realize that brown recluse spiders pose far more risk to creatures of their own size (or smaller) than to people or pets. Occasionally, homes may be 'with' hundreds or even thousands of these spiders, yet the human residents won't likely be bitten. I mention this mainly so folks better understand that the actual risks are low, and accept the inevitable - that they can share their environment with a few creatures that they'd otherwise find undesirable.  A few spiders may offer greater benefit than risk.  With this said, there are means to reduce the abundance of these and other spiders.  For those already in the home, a vacuum cleaner can be a useful tool. Installing and maintaining screens and door sweeps and caulking up penetrations in the foundations and walls can reduce the frequency that pests will enter.  Adhesive traps will help monitor and remove some pests that are wandering about in the home. Pesticides can certainly be of value, but it frequently makes sense to have these selected and applied by a licensed professional.  Embed Quote

column9: I rent a townhouse, which is physically connected to three other townhouses, so I'm looking for techniques I can apply inside my home and outside doors and windows. My management company is supposed to spray for them twice yearly, but they keep getting in.
column10: Brown Recluses do not respond well to spraying.  There is some speculation that most sprays actually alter the Recluses on a neurological level and make them aggressive.  Recluses also seem to like to eat dead insects and spiders, so, when you do spray, you are feeding them.  From what I have read, the best way to get rid of recluses is to A) remove habitats, B) remove food sources, C) use sticky traps.  Sticky traps seem to work very well for Recluses since when one gets stuck, others show up to try and eat it.  You should also look at points of entry and try and seal the house better.  Door and window seals, attic and basement vents, other random gaps around electrical and plumbing.  Great Stuff is great stuff for filling these holes.  Embed Quote
