column10: The EU (or EEC) has long had legal powers to deal with environmental issues relating to water. Its first legislation in this area was in about 1975. I remember as a child in the 70s being discouraged from drinking tap water in European countries. Now you wouldn't give it another thought. This site gives something of a historical overview: http://ec.europa.eu/environment/...  Embed Quote

column9: Yes it's monitored and controlled, in most countries. But I think that it passes through too many pipes and tubes compared to bottled water. Am I wrong?
column10: Where do you think that most bottled water comes from? Sadly, bottled water is not made by chipping away bits of pristine arctic glacier, it's just water that travels though pipes and taps. The only real difference is that most bottled water is filtered a bit, to improve it's flavor, but in terms of overall safety or quality there is little difference and some sources suggest that many brands of bottled water may be less safe/clean than typical tap water.  If you are worried, you can buy a home filter system, and as long as it is properly maintained it should provide you with decent tasting water for less money than buying bottled water. It will also result in less waste.  Embed Quote

Well, since the question didn't specify any sort of air fresheners, I'm going to assume that you mean some sort of odor mask. I would include things like Febreeze, Glade, Lysol, etc. in this group. If I'm mistaken please let me know.With this in mind, Alex K. Chen referenced a good article regarding some of the top-selling air fresheners and their toxicity. However, I would like to take this one step further and mention that any aerosol can be toxic. There are two factors to consider. 1) First off, you want to consider the active ingredient(s). The entire point of a masking agent is to overwhelm your olfactory receptors [1] with a high concentration of a chemical that smells "good." The issue here is twofold. First off, if you're in a room of concentrated Lysol (let's say) spray, then your supply of oxygen is low. This would be an extreme, but it would be toxic in the sense that it would deprive you of oxygen. The more likely scenario is that you overuse the product and end up with some of the active ingredients actually entering your bloodstream (the nasal endothelium is relatively easy to cross, as it is thinner than some other external barriers [2]—a thin layer of mucus and then a few thin layers of cells before you hit blood vessels). In this case, you have an aromatic compoundAbove is the basic structure of benzene, the most basic aromatic compound (C6H6). Since it is relatively small and non-polar, it can cross the blood barrier easily. A quick Google search shows one of the active chemicals in Febreeze as Granted, in biochemistry, size does matter. But if you take the time to look carefully, you would notice the symmetry present in the structure (Febreeze, apparently, uses the beta form). The hydroxyl groups (-OH) are hydrophilic, making even more likely to permeate the bloodstream, as electrochemical forces would be pulling the Beta-CD into the blood. I don't currently have access to all the articles I would like, but if a molecule like this were to enter the brain, it would interfere with special sub-processes of the brain (I think they're called pi-electron fields?). At any rate, large molecules like the ones above can easily capture free electrons and hold them, meaning they would disrupt cellular metabolism in any organ in the body, though none as pronounced as the brain. On top of this, it is likely that there are ways for the above molecules to use their hydroxyl groups to bind to neurons and interfere with normal functioning. I can't back this up right now, so I'm just going to toss it out there as a semi-logical conclusion. 2) The other thing to consider with any aerosol is the propellant used. CFCs had their claim to fame with air conditioners and refrigerators a few decades ago, so now one commonly used propellant is compressed carbon dioxide. Holding down on the trigger allows some of the CO2 out, which allows it to expand. This has the effect of cooling whatever container you're holding (if you've ever used a computer keyboard cleaner, you've felt this). As the gas expands, it gains kinetic energy, taking it from the exterior, thereby cooling the exterior. A propellant such as CO2 isn't necessarily toxic on its own, but many abuse it—I've seen a few people sit and snort a bottle of keyboard cleaner (before they introduced the bitterant compound). Of course this is toxic: you lose oxygen, your brain gets dazed, and you get a mild high. OK, so looking back at the answer I see it is somewhat long-winded, but there was a reason for that. ALL air fresheners are toxic to some degree. If you use them as directed, and make sure to have plenty of ventilation, you are not at risk of developing cancer or anything like that. However, should you lock yourself in the bathroom and spray off an entire bottle, you may well find yourself passing out and in serious trouble. I hope this helps![1] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olf...[2] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olf..., http://ajrcmb.atsjournals.org/cg...[3] http://www.accepta.com/specialit...[4] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Car...  Embed QuoteVia  Anonymous.

Practically all the top-selling onesIn 2008, Anne Steinemann of the University of Washington published a study of top-selling air fresheners and laundry products.[8] She found that all products tested gave off chemicals regulated as toxic or hazardous under federal laws, including carcinogens with no safe exposure level, but none of these chemicals were listed on any of the product labels or Material Safety Data Sheets. Chemicals included acetone, the active ingredient in paint thinner and nail-polish remover; chloromethane, a neurotoxicant and respiratory toxicant; and acetaldehyde and 1,4-dioxane, both carcinogens. A plug-in air freshener contained more than 20 different volatile organic compounds, with more than one-third classified as toxic or hazardous under federal laws. Even air fresheners called "organic," "green," or with "essential oils" emitted hazardous chemicals, including carcinogens.In 2009, Stanley M. Caress of the University of West Georgia and Anne C. Steinemann of the University of Washington published results from two national epidemiological studies of health effects from exposure to air fresheners. They found that nearly 20 percent of the general population and 34 percent of asthmatics report headaches, breathing difficulties, or other health problems when exposed to air fresheners or deodorizers.[9]Also see http://healthinmotion.wordpress.... and http://www.sciencedaily.com/rele...Given that such research was quite recent, we don't even know the toxicity of many of the untested ones.So what are some alternatives?Removing the source of an unpleasant odor will decrease the chance that you will smell it. Ventilation is also important to maintaining indoor air quality and can aid in eliminating unpleasant odors. Simple cleaners such as white vinegar and baking soda, as well as adsorbents like zeolite, are effective at removing odors. Some house plants may also aid in the removal of toxic substances from the air in building interiors.[10][11]Maybe. Some websites say that a good solution is to put baking soda on the carpet and then to vacuum it up. But then http://diy.stackexchange.com/que... disagrees.  Embed QuoteAnswered in seventeen minutes via  Anonymous.

In general, they affect behaviour in ways that make the insect want to avoid going to heavy metal-infected areas willingly. For example, caddisfly larvae in an uninfected area of a pond won't fight hard to take over the areas held by larvae in an infected part, even if they can easily survive under high toxicities. In terrestrial insects, they may avoid chewing on plants containing too high levels of heavy metals, or going to carcasses with too high concentrations (although there are specialists for all cases).This is all to avoid the stress caused by the heavy metals. Even if they have resistance, that resistance usually comes at a cost (e.g. producing more metal-binding proteins), and it's pointless to needlessly burden oneself with such things.  Embed QuoteVia  Alex K. Chen.

column9: How do you think the environmental legislations should be adapted ? Is eco-design a possible solution? http://sci-env.ch/l%E2%80%99effe...
column10: Yes it is!Every pesticide/or other substance before it's placed on the market is tested for the environmental impact. Basically we know toxicity of every pesticide placed on the market. But once used pesticide doesn't disappear from the environment. It stays in the soil, water, plants etc. in (I hope) small doses.What we don't know is toxicity of  mixture of pesticides/other pollutants present in the environment. The effect may be unpredictable.The effects of two chemicals, when given together are often additive, that is, the combined effect of two chemicals is predictable based on the known toxicity of both compounds.2+2=4The combined effect of the administration of two compounds may be greater than the sum of the two effects; this is called synergism. 2+2=10So how environmental legislations should be adapted?1. I think the organic farming should be promotes as much as possible. There are natural ways to deter pests. 2. Biotechnology- create new cultivars resistant to pests.3. Introduction of bioassay to standard studies of drinking water and treated waste water.  Embed Quote

You don't necessarily need a device to measure indoor pollutants. The actual amount of pollutants is very low compared to outdoor pollution like vehicular exhaust or a coal-fired power plant. However, the best way to measure indoor pollution is to compile data on the things in your building that cause pollution, like fiberboard or carpet glue. A site like this can give you a good idea of what to look for: http://altered-states.net/barry/... It's really that simple. Know the causes, find a cure. Indoor pollution can be very simple to manage. Good luck.  Embed Quote

Yes, it seems that at the very least there is a substantial danger of significantly reduced nutrient absorption in intestines of mammals based on a recently published paper.Nanometer scale, nanoparticles are typically less then 100 nanometers.A nanoparticle is incredibly small and we are literally surrounded by them in our immediate environment.   You and I are currently consuming about 100 trillion nanoparticles (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nan...) every day.  A nanoparticle is generally classified as being between  1 and 100 nanometers in size.  Although they appear in the natural environment on Earth, industrial use of nanoparticles has been skyrocketing with absolutely no checks or balances of how potentially damaging they can be to living organisms.   The chemical content of man made nanoparticles are also far more exotic and potentially hazardous.  We expect can expect a rather large increase in nanoparticle use and production,  the National Science Foundation estimates that the worldwide need for nanotechnology workers will rise from the current 20,000 to two million.  This means the work product from this increase may push human consumption intended or unintended by logarithmic proportions. No long term testing has taken place, yet nanoparticles are used in a staggering number of products from beer production, cosmetics, scratch-proof glasses, batteries to popular stain-repellent khaki pants.  Nanoparticles pass through living cells rather easily and can accumulate in the body in a number of locations.In the landmark paper "Oral exposure to polystyrene nanoparticles affects iron absorption" published in the journal Nature Nanotechnology by lead researchers Gretchen Mahler, assistant professor of bioengineering at Binghamton University and Michael L. Shuler, the James and Marsha McCormick Chair of the Department of Biomedical Engineering as well as the Samuel Eckert Professor of Chemical Engineering in the School of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering at Cornell University.Abstract:The use of engineered nanoparticles in food and pharmaceuticals is expected to increase, but the impact of chronic oral exposure to nanoparticles on human health remains unknown. Here, we show that chronic and acute oral exposure to polystyrene nanoparticles can influence iron uptake and iron transport in an in vitro model of the intestinal epithelium and an in vivo chicken intestinal loop model. Intestinal cells that are exposed to high doses of nanoparticles showed increased iron transport due to nanoparticle disruption of the cell membrane. Chickens acutely exposed to carboxylated particles (50 nm in diameter) had a lower iron absorption than unexposed or chronically exposed birds. Chronic exposure caused remodelling of the intestinal villi, which increased the surface area available for iron absorption. The agreement between the in vitro and in vivo results suggests that our in vitro intestinal epithelium model is potentially useful for toxicology studies.http://www.nature.com/nnano/jour...Scanning electron microscope image of polystyrene nanoparticles, roughly 100 nanometers in diameter, which are readily detected with the analyzer. In an interview with Physorg, Professor Mahler stated:"We thought that the best way to measure the more subtle effects of this kind of intake was to monitor the reaction of intestinal cells. And we did this in two ways – in vitro, through human intestinal-lining cells that we had cultured in the lab; and in vivo, through the intestinal linings of live chickens. Both sets of results pointed to the same thing – that exposure to nanoparticles influences the absorption of nutrients into the bloodstream.  What we found was that for brief exposures, iron absorption dropped by about 50 percent. But when we extended that period of time, absorption actually increased by about 200 percent. It was very clear – nanoparticles definitely affects iron uptake and transport."http://www.physorg.com/news/2012...There is absolutely no doubt that nanoparticles have a tremendous value and some remarkable use cases.  In fact there are very novel studies using nanoparticles as a cancer protocol. However the proverbial genie is out of the bottle and with absolutely no restrictions or oversight on who is producing nanoparticles and in what quantities and with no safety protocols we are all facing a very dangerous impact to human health.  Embed QuoteAnswered in three minutes.

Nanosizing a poorly soluble crystalline particle can have a number of impacts.  I'll pick two in regards to the impact on human health.  Nanosizing a poorly soluble crystal in some cases can increase the solubility of the compound above the value for a normal (micron or larger) sized crystal.  A second impact of nanosizing can be a more rapid absorption of the compound by a biological system (typically the lungs or intestinal tract).  These effects can be considered beneficial in pharmaceutical drug development when the drug is poorly soluble.  Thus, the same amount of drug delivered in a tablet or inhaler (for example) when nanosized may be more effective than as a "large" crystal.  But if the nanosized crystal is some sort of toxin these same effects of nanosizing may increase the health hazards of the large crystals.  Embed Quote

column9: Some might jump to a quick 'Yes,' but further contemplation would reveal that all sorts of industrial materials like lead were in far greater circulation several decades ago than they are now. Still, the question is worth asking.
column10: Most likely notSee this paper (http://potency.berkeley.edu/pdfs... ) from a top toxicology websiteMisconception 4: Human exposures to potential cancer hazards are primarily to synthetic chemicals.Contrary to common perception, 99.9% of the chemicals humans ingest are natural. The amounts of synthetic pesticide residues in plant foods, for example, are extremely low compared to the amounts of natural “pesticides” produced by plants themselves (Ames et al., 1990a; Ames et al., 1990b; Gold et al., 1999; Gold et al., 1997b; Gold and Zeiger, 1997). Of all dietary pesticides that humans eat, 99.99% are natural: these are chemicals produced by plants to defend themselves against fungi, insects, and other animal predators (Ames et al., 1990a; Ames et al., 1990b). Each plant produces a different array of such chemicals. On average, the Western diet includes roughly 5,000 to 10,000 different natural pesticides and their breakdown products. Americans eat about 1,500 mg of natural pesticides per person per day, which is about 10,000 times more than they consume of synthetic pesticide residues (Ames et al., 1990b). Even though only a small proportion of natural pesticides has been tested for carcinogenicity, half of those tested (38/72) are rodent carcinogens; naturally occurring pesticides that are rodent carcinogens are ubiquitous in fruits, vegetables, herbs, and spices (Gold et al., 1997b; Gold et al., 1992) (Table 2).Cooking of foods produces burnt material (about 2,000 mg per person per day) that contains many rodent carcinogens. In contrast, the residues of 200 synthetic chemicals measured by United States Federal Drug Administration, including the synthetic pesticides thought to be of greatest importance, average only about 0.09 mg per person per day (Ames et al., 1990a; Gold et al., 1997b; Gold et al., 1992). In a single cup of coffee, the natural chemicals that are rodent carcinogens are about equal in weight to an entire year’s worth of synthetic pesticide residues that are rodent carcinogens, even though only 3% of the natural chemicals in roasted coffee have been adequately tested for carcinogenicity (Gold et al., 1992) (Table 3). This does not mean that coffee or natural pesticides are a cancer risk for humans, but rather that assumptions about high-dose animal cancer tests for assessing human risk at low doses need reexamination. No diet can be free of natural chemicals that are rodent carcinogens (Gold et al., 1999; Gold et al., 1997b; Gold and Zeiger, 1997)  Embed QuoteAnswered in thirty-one minutes via  Anonymous.

There's recent reports of baby food having toxins: http://www.wddty.com/infant-form.... Many people now use aerosol sprays around the house. Vinyl floor coverings, plastic linings of canned foods, etc., continue polluting for a long time. And tests of humans show toxins in our blood.Perhaps more importantly, we know cancer rates, childhood illnesses (asthma, diabetes, allergies) have rocketed since 1940's (some would say since the 1900's). Something is causing this. Maybe it is not environmental chemicals, but that does seem plausible.  Embed Quote

column9: How much flying is "too much" flying?
column10: Radiation is one of the most well understood physical phenomena out there. Whether you receive radiation from flying or not isn't as relevant as the total exposure you're getting during the time in the air. Here is a snippet from the EPA:For a typical cross-country flight in a commercial airplane, you are likely to receive 2 to 5 millirem (mrem) of radiation, less than half the radiation dose you receive from a chest x-ray. People in the United States receive an average of 360 mrem of radiation per year from natural and man-made radiation sources, which includes cosmic radiation exposure during commercial flights. Below is an infographic which I find extremely useful when drawing comparisons between various radiation sources. Study it. Basically if you stick with the typical activities in blue and green, you should be fine (as far as radiation is concerned).http://www.epa.gov/radtown/cosmi...http://xkcd.com/radiation/source...  Embed Quote

column9: How much flying is "too much" flying?
column10: It might depend on whether or not you're unfortunate enough to fly through a solar storm (which can increase radiation dose levels by up to a thousand times) or near a lightning charge or a terrestrial gamma ray flash. The latter effect actually might be more important given that commercial airplanes are struck by lightning an average of 1-2 times a year. Which could be significant for airline pilots. It also may depend on whether or not you're flying at high latitudes (which are exposed to more solar radiation). http://terra2.spacenvironment.ne... shows that high-latitude flight exposes you to around 1.5X-2.5X the amount of radiation at low altitude flight most of the time, but during solar storms, the ratio actually can drastically increase at high latitudes.http://www.sciencedaily.com/rele... shows no DNA damage (in mice) from consistent long-term exposure to radiation at levels 400 times greater than background levels. Most flights will expose you to levels 18 times higher than background levels of radiation (on a uSv/second basis), which probably pose little risk. So if you're not flying during a solar storm and at high latitudes at the same time OR you're not unlucky enough to fly next to a lightning charge or gamma-ray flash, it appears that the levels are mostly safe (see Radiation: What are some radiation exposure rates (in radiation units per second) of various activities, and how do they compare with the radiation exposure rate connected with a higher risk of cancer?). Even then, flying in the middle of a solar storm might not expose you to unsafe amounts of radiation. http://www.intechopen.com/downlo... shows that (during a solar flare) maximum radiation exposure levels were less than 400 times greater than background levels.Also, keep in mind that not all cosmic radiation is the same, and some radiation is significantly more high-energy than other radiation.==There does seem to be an apparent increased risk of cancer in flight attendants and pilots, but right now, we're unsure whether this is due to radiation (either from cosmic rays or from terrestrial lightning/gamma ray flashes) or to their stressful lifestyles (with all the jet lag). One possible factor: if your occupation involves frequent flying, then your chances of being exposed to at least one such solar storm (or lightning discharge/gamma ray discharge event) can drastically increase.For some more resources about that:http://www.nasa.gov/topics/aeron...http://www.dailymail.co.uk/healt...http://ashsd.afacwa.org/docs/rad...Stewardesses could be up to five times more likely to contract breast cancer.And cabin crew of both sexes are three times more likely to suffer the deadliest form of skin cancer.Four studies published today add weight to the warning that greater exposure to cosmic radiation could be the cause of the higher rates.http://aflen2008.wordpress.com/2...After a review of 20 relevant epidemiological investigations, Ott and Huber (2006) reported that crew members and frequent flyers may be at higher risk of developing cancers of the skin (e.g., malignant melanoma, basalioma, etc.),prostate cancer, or leukemia.Do note, however, that the vast majority of the studies above seem to be done on Scandinavian and Canadian flyers, who may be exposed to more radiation than other flyers, since more cosmic radiation does tend to fall into the high latitudes due to the nature of Earth's magnetic field, and in particular, they are more likely to fly at high latitudes during a solar storm, which is the riskiest combo by all (the nature of Earth's geomagnetic field is such that solar storms increase radiation flux the most at high latitudes.) But - as the study below shows - the latitude at which people fly might actually not be so relevant.After all, flying near a lightning discharge can *significantly* increase your dose of radiation in a one-hit event. See http://news.ufl.edu/2009/12/07/l...Scientists at the Florida Institute of Technology, University of California, Santa Cruz and the University of Florida have estimated that airplane passengers could be exposed to a radiation dose equal to that from 400 chest X-rays if their airplane happens to  be near the start of a lightning discharge or related phenomena known as  a terrestrial gamma ray flash.Since each commercial airplane is hit by lightning by an average of once per year, this could potentially significantly increase the radiation dose experienced by airline pilots, frequent fliers, or people who are simply unlucky.==Things could actually change in the next 50 years, as http://news.sciencemag.org/scien... showsIf you thought the outlook for Earth's climate looked bleak, don't look up. A new study suggests that space weather—the hail of energetic particles above our atmosphere—is set to worsen in coming decades. The grim forecast suggests that astronauts and frequent flyers will face greater radiation hazards and could rule out a crewed mission to Mars before 2050.Lockwood's group found that in times of low solar activity, there seem to have been more GRCs reaching Earth. This wasn't too surprising: low activity means the solar system's shield—the heliosphere—would have been weaker. The researchers also found that low solar activity seemed to bring fewer SEP events. But to their surprise, there was a caveat: Although fewer, the SEP events appeared to be far more intense. The worst time for SEPs appeared to be at times of "middling" solar activity—precisely the transition period we are thought to be entering. The results were published last month in Geophysical Research Letters.How dangerous is this? One problem could arise for frequent flyers, because the thin air at high altitudes offers less protection from space weather. Currently, someone could take up to five long-haul flights every year that go near the poles—where GRCs and SEPs are channeled most—without exceeding the recommended limit on radiation exposure. But in coming decades, Lockwood explains, that safe number could drop to two. "I wouldn't want to be on a plane when an SEP event went off," he says.GRC - galactic cosmic raySEP - solar energetic particlehttp://www.met.reading.ac.uk/use...  Embed Quote

Don't have a definitive answer, but it seems that white absorbent kitchen paper (also, I believe known as paper towels) are OK to use.But only if labelled microwave safe.Here's what I found. These seem to be reputable resources.Nothing here about the release of nasty chemicals, but am hoping these Web sites help a little. ---"12.	Never use recycled paper products in microwave ovens unless they are specifically approved for microwave use. Recycled paper towels, napkins and waxed paper can contain metal flecks which may cause arcing or ignite. Paper products containing nylon or nylon filaments should be avoided, as they may also ignite. "   From 55 Microwave Safety Tips---"Many white paper towels are fabricated with plastics, and are not microwave safe. Even some paper plates can be harmful. Plain paper is safe, but plastic coated paper is generally not microwave-safe. "Are you eating cancer?--"Microwave plastic wraps, wax paper, cooking bags, parchment paper, and white microwave-safe paper towels should be safe to use. Do not let plastic wrap touch foods during microwaving."Cooking Safely in the Microwave Oven Fact Sheet--"Wax paper, oven cooking bags, parchment paper and white microwave paper towels are safe for microwave use."Microwave Cooking  Embed Quote

column9: Background:Why Radiation and Contamination Is Like Comparing Apples and OrangesWhy does it make no sense to compare in-flight radiation exposure and ingesting radioactive isotopes? It is wrong to compare internal emitters with external emitters, ie, ingesting radioactive isotopes versus in-flight exposure or background radiation. It is like comparing warming oneself near a fire versus eating a red hot coal.  Physicians for Social Responsibility in the United States recently issued a statement asserting “there is no safe level of radionuclide exposure, whether from food, water or other sources. Period.”  There are a number of different types of radiation, including cosmic radiation from space, terrestrial radiation which is emitted by radioactive elements in the ground, and man-made radiation such as that released by the detonation of an atomic bomb or by nuclear reactors in meltdown.Essential DifferenceFurther to the ATCA briefing, "San Francisco Rainwater: Radiation 181 Times Above US Drinking Water Standard" many have pointed out that the University of California at Berkeley "Rainwater Sampling" chart shows even at the peak finding of 20.1 Becquerels per litre, someone would have to consume 134 litres of that water in order to have the same exposure to radiation as they would receive by taking a flight from San Francisco to Washington, DC.  With respect, we consider this comparison to be utterly misleading.  Why? If living beings are exposed to radioactivity indirectly versus if they ingest something radioactive, the total effect is remarkably different.  Radiation and contamination are not the same thing! Taking a flight will expose one to cosmic radiation not radioactive contamination. When radioactive isotopes enter into water, crops, milk that leads to radioactive contamination.  Contamination occurs when material that contains radioactive isotopes is no longer contained. It is important to remember that radiation cannot spread or get "in" or "on" people; rather it is radioactive contamination that can do precisely that.  Here lies the essential difference between the two. ATCA: http://www.businessinsider.com/s...UC Berkeley: http://www.nuc.berkeley.edu/Rain...Radioactive ContaminationIt is important to note that exposure to radiation -- like standing in front of a microwave oven where the seal has been damaged or an X-Ray machine -- does not result in direct contamination of any living being, because they become contaminated only through direct contact with radioactive isotopes or by being in areas where the contaminated material is already present.  Radioactive contamination and radiation exposure occur only if radioactive materials are released into the environment as the direct result of a nuclear accident, an event in nature -- such as ground radiation with radioactive isotopes -- or an act of war involving nuclear devices or radioactive isotopes. Such a release may expose living beings and contaminate their surroundings and their environment.  Radioactive contamination occurs when radioactive material is deposited on or in an object or a living being. Radioactive materials released into the environment can cause air, water, surfaces, soil, plants, buildings, people or animals to become contaminated. A contaminated living being has radioactive materials on or inside their body.Ionising RadiationIf humans ingest radioactive elements, those "hot coals" stay with us. Particularly nasty radioactive elements include radioactive iodine. Radioactive iodine is also readily absorbed by the body and becomes incorporated within it, and is therefore difficult to eliminate from the body. The radiation it emits can cause cancer over a period of time.  Fast moving photons (gamma rays), electrons (beta rays) and helium nuclei (alpha particles) can crash into other molecules and change their structure.  Beta particles may ionise molecules they hit, damaging DNA in cells, and disrupting their normal activities.  If this happens to a DNA molecule, the damage is caused to the genetic information, and this may turn the cell cancerous.  Ionising radiation has the power to break molecular bonds in living tissue causing damage, even in small doses, it can cause cancer in humans and other living beings.  If a lot of radioisotopes are ingested, the result would be radiation sickness and possibly death.Properties of RadioisotopesChemical properties of radioisotopes are extremely important when determining the effect that a specific radioisotope will cause. Chemical properties determine the rates of absorption, rates of metabolism and even where the isotope will be deposited. Radiation exposure potential is also determined by the type of emission from the radionuclide. Emissions that are not very penetrating while not externally a hazard become a very serious hazard when incorporated into the living body.  Alpha and beta radiation will not penetrate even a few layers of skin; however, if a radioisotope that emits alpha or beta radiation is absorbed into the body and deposited in or near radio-sensitive cells, alpha or beta particles do not have to travel very far to damage the body's cells permanently.  ConclusionA living being exposed to radiation is not necessarily contaminated with radioactive material. A living being who has been exposed to radiation has had radioactive waves or particles penetrate the body, like having an X-ray or going on a long flight. For a living being to be contaminated, radioactive material must be on or inside of their body. A contaminated living being is exposed to radiation released by the radioactive material on or inside their body. An uncontaminated living being can be exposed to radiation by being too close to radioactive isotopes or another contaminated living being, place or object.[STOPS]
column10: " 20.1 Becquerels per litre"aka 2 banannas (conservatively).  Kidding aside, there are so many variables that it is extremely hard to quantify in layman's terms.  There is radiation type (alpha, beta, gamma, neutron), energy (constitutes calculated absorption values), metabolic variables, etc to consider for each type of contamination.  In the case of the contaminated water, I'd be more concerned with what isotope it is contaminated with.  In the Berkeley article, Iodine 131 was the 20.1 Bd/L measured isotope.  This is higher than many safety limits and is a concern.  Embed Quote

column9: I've been wearing one on my bicycle commutes in Beijing and it turns grey / brownish surprisingly fast.  How can I figure out when the best time to replace it is?  I am torn between wanting not to be spending a lot of money on these filters and not wanting to breathe this air. A sentiment I suspect shared by the asker of Are there any particulate filters for the consumer market ?At the moment, moving out of Beijing is not an option so let's just throw that out now.
column10: The longer a mask is worn the more particles will get trapped (or loaded) onto the filters in the mask.  Breathing resistance (airflow resistance) increases as a function of the loading.  At some point it will be very difficult for you to breath easily through the filter part of the mask and you will just be sucking air around the face seal.  You'll want to replace the filter before you reach that point.  Unfortunately, this is difficult to judge as changes in breathing resistance are a function of the size and concentration of particles in the air and the design of the pollution mask (i.e., it varies model to model).  If the mask is a NIOSH certified N95 respirator, NIOSH recommends that the device be changed out after 8 hours of continuous or intermittent use. http://www.cdc.gov/niosh/npptl/t... http://annhyg.oxfordjournals.org...  Embed QuoteVia  Russell Stadler.

column9: POLLUTANT EXPOSURE Taxi: over 100,000 pt/cm3Bus: just under 100,000 pt/cm3Cycling: 80,000 pt/cm3Walking: just under 50,000 pt/cm3Car: 40,000 pt/cm3Measure is: ultrafine particles counts per cubic centimetre http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/healt...http://www.sciencedaily.com/rele... showss that pollution really *is* something to worry about
column10: In school buses, yes, when the rear windows are closedSee http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.atmo...The results presented in Fig. 2 indicate that, in general, exposure to pollutants from the bus's own emissions were higher at the rear of the cabin than at the front when windows were closed, consistent with the findings of other bus studies ( Solomon et al., 2001).Fig. 2 also shows there were detectable SF6 concentrations outside at the front of the bus at times during most of the runs, although these concentrations were much smaller than the concentrations inside the bus. Apart from a “background” concentration of SF6 below 10 ppt (Geller et al., 1997), which was below our detection limit, we were aware of no additional sources of SF6 other than our injection of the tracer gas in the tailpipe. Therefore, these results show that the bus's exhaust was able to reach the sampling line located at the front (outside) of the bus, for example, when the bus was idling (e.g., at a red light or a bus stop) and the wind was blowing from the rear to the front of the bus.The results presented in Fig. 3 show there were no significant differences between measurements at the front of the cabin, at the rear of the cabin, and outside the bus when the windows were partially opened. This results from greater mixing and higher ventilation rates inside the bus when the windows were partially opened, as shown by ventilation rate measurements we conducted for each bus as a function of speed and window position ( Fitz et al., 2003).  Embed Quote

column9: On a few recent hikes in Marin we noticed that the delicious blackberries were woven in with the similar looking poison oak effectively preventing us from foraging.  Is the oak using the thorns of the berry bush or is the berry bush using the poison of the oak for protection? Or is something else entirely going on there?
column10: A regrettable coincidence (or is it?). Poison oak imitates the leaves of the blackberry? And according to online sources it is true they often grow together. I wouldn't think blackberry benefits from this because the plant's reliant on foragers who snack on its berries... if I am correct... Oak is the opportunistic partner in this common scenario. Also, both poison oak and blackberry tend to overgrow clearcut areas (for instance under powerlines where it is sprayed heavily with herbicides). Both plants are helping to regrow the forests by curing and nurturing the soil and protecting young saplings.  Embed Quote

Richard Petit expressed perhaps the biggest reasons. Another contributing factor: there's a near permanent inversion layer that sits above LA. This is due to constant high pressure systems that gives the region its famously sunny weather but also prevents smog from rising out.  There's a daily onshore flow which comes in every afternoon.  This blows much of the smog inland until it pushes up near the foothills and mountain areas. So contrary to the belief that LA as a whole has poor air quality, the air near the westside and coastal areas are quite good. It's just inland where it tends to be awful.  Embed Quote

If you look at this image:you see that the Los Angeles Basin is bordered on the west and southwest by the ocean that provides an on-shore flow and the mountains on the east and north. Add in a few million gas powered vehicles, the smog is heavier than air so it does not rise out, and there you have it, L.A. air. "I don't trust air that I can't see" we used to say.I once heard that when the Spanish explorers first arrived in L.A. they saw a cloud of smoke hovering over the basin from the campfires of the indigenous people. I don't know if it's true but it stands to reason and means that smog of some kind has always been there.  Embed Quote

Well, the basic answer is because there are so many polluters in LA. Not going into any technical details, the amount of pollution is interconnected with the GDP. So if the pollution is high then you can be sure that recession is not there in the near future. But at the same time, when all the developing countries are observing an increase in pollution day by day due to inefficient energy usage, developed countries are reducing the pollution because of availability of latest technology and ample capital. So there may exist a possibility that LA still needs some development.  Embed Quote

column9: As a person who lives by my ability to think well, I was reading some stuff about lead exposure that gives me the heebies. It seems that lead is quite a bit more bioavailable that I thought via several routes, especially inhalation even of elemental lead dust.I am a hobbyist shooter and my favorite indoor gun range (which has recently shut down) was cited and fined for inadequate lead controls. Also, I did a home improvement project perhaps six months ago involving quite a bit of paint stripping and, regrettably in retrospect, was pretty cavalier in terms of personal protective equipment and dust mitigation.I looked up the EPA guidelines, and they are quite stringent. As a chemist, I know that such guidelines can sometimes be silly in how paranoid and conservative they are - in an academic experimental setting, chemists are usually grossly out of compliance and, when an accident happens, blood tests tend to show no heavy metal exposure above baseline levels. On the other hand, when one looks at ordinary people's interactions with lead, they are often a lot less careful than me - cleaning lead-fouled guns with solvent and bare hands on YouTube, for example. While they do not report or admit to health problems from this, I wonder if they are experiencing subclinical or even clinical (but unreported) lead poisoning.Any practical data points? Measured blood levels or symptoms correlated with detailed types/levels of exposure? How severe must lead exposure be to cause concern for an adult?
column10: To be honest, I think lead is one of the chemicals for which even the EPA guidelines may not be stringent enough (aka it's one of the chemicals for which there really should be no minimum safe exposure). Lead is truly truly nasty stuff due to its chronic and insidious neurological effects. I'm less concerned about EPA guidelines for chemicals whose effects are more acute and less neurological.Even low levels of lead can lead to long-term damage in IQ. The effects are obviously stronger in children, but given the stark magnitude of the effects at such low exposures, I wouldn't even want to expose myself to any of the stuff even when no longer a child.See Intellectual Impairment in Children with Blood Lead Concentrations below 10 μg per Deciliter — NEJMThe findings of this study are startling and counter-intuitive: at lower concentrations of lead in the blood – below 10 µg/dL - children tested for IQ at ages three and five, showed a greater decline in IQ for a rise in blood lead from 1 to 10 µg/dL, than those whose blood lead level went from 10 to 20 µg/dL.“The blood lead concentration was inversely and significantly associated with IQ. In the linear model, each increase of 10 µg per deciliter in the lifetime average blood lead concentration was associated with a 4.6-point decrease in IQ (P=0.004), whereas for the subsample of 101 children whose maximal lead concentrations remained below 10 µg per deciliter, the change in IQ associated with a given change in lead concentration was greater. When estimated in a nonlinear model with the full sample, IQ declined by 7.4 points as lifetime average blood lead concentrations increased from 1 to 10 µg per deciliter.”Also Lead Poisoning: The Ignored ScandalAccording to the Centers for Disease Control, parents should be concerned if their children’s blood lead concentration exceeds five micrograms per deciliter, but studies have found that even infinitesimally low levels—down to one or two micrograms per deciliter—can reduce a child’s IQ and impair her self-control and ability to organize thoughts.I once got my blood lead levels checked and I had levels of 1 ug/dL. Average in the U.S. is 2 ug/dL. I'd say that getting a blood test for lead is probably a good idea. If it's at 1 or 2 ug/dL, I wouldn't worry too much (inasmuch as it would be difficult to get it lower). Anything higher though, and you'd never know what shit it could do to your brain.  Embed Quote

column9: As a person who lives by my ability to think well, I was reading some stuff about lead exposure that gives me the heebies. It seems that lead is quite a bit more bioavailable that I thought via several routes, especially inhalation even of elemental lead dust.I am a hobbyist shooter and my favorite indoor gun range (which has recently shut down) was cited and fined for inadequate lead controls. Also, I did a home improvement project perhaps six months ago involving quite a bit of paint stripping and, regrettably in retrospect, was pretty cavalier in terms of personal protective equipment and dust mitigation.I looked up the EPA guidelines, and they are quite stringent. As a chemist, I know that such guidelines can sometimes be silly in how paranoid and conservative they are - in an academic experimental setting, chemists are usually grossly out of compliance and, when an accident happens, blood tests tend to show no heavy metal exposure above baseline levels. On the other hand, when one looks at ordinary people's interactions with lead, they are often a lot less careful than me - cleaning lead-fouled guns with solvent and bare hands on YouTube, for example. While they do not report or admit to health problems from this, I wonder if they are experiencing subclinical or even clinical (but unreported) lead poisoning.Any practical data points? column10: Most people with clinically relevant lead intoxication are:-children chewing off lead containing paints on their toys or other things at home-grown-ups who during their work are very much exposed to lead, e.g. working in battery producing factories, cutting metals coated with lead containing paints e.g. old bridges/constructions/ships during which one's face is very much near the cutting/burning point so inhalating lead vapors.  In The Netherlands we don't see this in white Dutch workers, but a lot in North African e.g. Moroccan workers due to differences in the way the hold their heads relative to the flame during this operation.-people getting their drinking water through lead lined pipes (almost all replaced now in the developed world).So I wouldn't worry too much, as long as you don't have any new complains.However, if you have belly complains, have psychological problems, anemia, have your doc check your blood lead levels.  Lead intoxication can be treated e.g. by infusing chelation therapy with the combination of 2,3-dimercapto-1-propanol (BAL) and edathamil calcium disodium (CaEDTA).From Elsevier  Perspective on lead toxicity, a comparison between the United States and Iran by Ali Pourmand, Tareq Khedir Al-tiae and Maryann Mazer-AmirshahiSignificant lead toxicity is noted with BLLs of greater than 70 μg/dL in children and 100 μg/dL in adults. Patients with moderate lead toxicity (BLL 50 to 70 μg/dL in children, 70 to 100 μg/dL in adults) can also have altered mental status, gastrointestinal distress, and hematologic abnormalities. Peripheral neuropathy and nephropathy occurs more commonly in adults. In children, “asymptomatic” lead exposure generally associated with BLLs less than 49 μg/dL can lead to impaired cognitive, behavioral and motor development. In adults, low level lead exposure can result in subtle cognitive effects, hypertension, nephropathy, and impaired fertility http://...[1].                There is mounting evidence that even low-level lead exposure can have significant health effects, especially in susceptible populations such as children and there are multiple studies in the US and Iran showing clinical repercussions even with previously accepted BLLs of 10 μg/dL.BLL = blood lead level.  Embed QuoteVia  Raman Shah.

Alex K. Chen's answer to Nutrition: What are good nutrition tips to keep a healthy brain?Alex K. Chen's answer to Is organic food better for you?Environmental Health/Toxicology: What are some common VOCs found in the air and what are their chronic effects on human health? http://www.experimentalman.com/e... - someone who got his exposome measured better than anyone elseListshttp://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/substan... - CDC's, very comprehensivehttp://www.ewg.org/skindeep/EPA guide to indoor air pollution - http://www.epa.gov/iaq/voc.htmlEPA factsheets: https://www.google.com/search?su...Environmental Toxicologyhttp://www.ewg.org/http://www.whatsonmyfood.org/ind... - best easy-to-read pesticide database there ishttp://www.epa.gov/pesticides/Air Pollutionhttp://www.reddit.com/r/askscien...What are some particularly nasty neurological effects of air pollution?Pesticides of concernparaquat, ziram, maneb, organochlorines (phased out now), organophosphates (many phased out, but some, like phosmet, still remain), chlorpyfirosMore discussion at http://www.longecity.org/forum/t...NeurotoxicityWhy don't nerve cells regenerate? (the key thing here is that most CNS neurons don't reproduce. But there are several distinct mechanisms of neurotoxicity. For example - the axons can be damaged, and it's a very open question whether or not axon damage is permanent or not. On the other hand, loss of the neuronal cell itself is possibly permanent, except possibly in the Hippocampus [but even then, H.M. could not regenerate his hippocampal neurons])This article (http://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/2...) shows that we might eventually be able to predict which genes (and proteins) could actually help protect against man-made environmental toxins. Then we can try a microarray analysis to see which genes are expressed more in the animals that have mutated receptors that have protected against new toxins.Today, scientists can scan the entire genomes of New York’s animals and plants to look for evolutionary changes. Last month, Mr. Harris presented new data on white-footed mice at the annual meeting of the Society for the Study of Evolution. Mr. Harris and his colleagues have identified mutations in more than 1,000 genes that are present in all New York City mice, but missing from mice in Harriman State Park, 45 miles north of the city.The scientists are investigating whether these mutations have helped the mice adapt to life in New York City. Clues that some of them do are found in the functions of the mutated genes. Many of the genes are involved in fighting bacteria, while others are for reproduction and still others for coping with stress from exposure to chemicals. It’s possible that these new mutations are spreading independently in each of the parks in the city.“The idea is that the urban pressures are the same everywhere, and they’re all adapting,” said Mr. Harris.Cities attract only a small fraction of evolutionary biologists, who often work in lusher places like the Amazon. But urban evolution is attracting more research these days, because cities are fast-growing, and the urban environment is quickly taking over large areas of the Earth’s surface.==Top toxicology journal: http://toxsci.oxfordjournals.org/Is there a database of all possible receptors that a drug (or molecule) can react with? => http://www.bindingdb.org/bind/in...http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tem... => Wikipedia template on toxins, lots of resources in each of the individual subcategorieshttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tem... => Wikipedia toxicology templatehttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tem...http://books.google.com/books?id... => Principles of Biochemical Toxicologyhttp://ctd.mdibl.org/query.go?ty... =>Chemical–Gene Interaction Query - CTDhttp://www.pharmgkb.org/ => The Pharmacogenomics Knowledge Base [PharmGKB]http://potency.berkeley.edu/ => The Carcinogenic Potency Project (CPDB)http://www.reactome.org/Reactome...http://ctd.mdibl.org/ => The Comparative Toxicogenomics Database - CTDhttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tox...http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyt... => Cytochrome P450: Understand this well. This system is more important than any in the field of toxicologyBisphenol A: http://blogs.forbes.com/trevorbu...Not being able to detect it just means it's eliminated at such speed (relative to it's absorption) that it doesn't reach concentrations high enough to overcome the threshold of their detection test.If you reach back to the farmaco-kinetics of your Farmacology 101 class, you'll recall that the blood concentration of any substance is the result of a variety of effects: the speed of infusion, the speed of clearence relative to concentration, and the hydrophilic-lipophilic nature of the substance, among other things.In my experience, these sort of things go one of two ways: Or the speed of infusion is greater than the speed of clearence and thus the chemical builds up to high levels, or the speed of clearence is greater than the speed of infusion and the chemical doesn't build up and has little chance of doing an effect. We've just discovered on which end of that spectrum BPA is.Nice Physics Forums replies to toxicologically significant properties:mg/kg - how relevant?: http://physicsforums.com/showthr...protein folding/computational toxicology: http://physicsforums.com/showthr...Predicting toxicity based on chemical structure (this is a VERY hot field for research right now):http://potency.berkeley.edu/pdfs...http://books.google.com/books?id... => A comprehensive guide to the hazardous properties of chemical substanceshttp://www.citeulike.org/user/In... => Toward molecular design for hazard reduction—fundamental relationships between chemical properties and toxicity - this is a really recent (and readable) paper that shows a way to classify a chemical's potential toxicity based on its chemical structure. Summary at http://www.sciencenews.org/view/...http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/QSAR => QSAR modelhttp://www.jstor.org/stable/3433032 => very early system of classifying chemicals toxic to rodentsCase studies of particular toxins:What is the evolutionary explanation of extraordinarily toxic venom?http://www.reddit.com/r/askscien...http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Och...http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tet... => very important for neurophysiology researchMore specific resources: (I have many resources about amphetamine toxicity in particular, but I won't list them here for now)http://www.longecity.org/forum/t... => very interesting discussion about research papers on amphetamine toxicity in particular (just be leery about the posts that advocate a particular consumption pathway).http://www.nature.com/nrd/archiv... - Nature Drug Discovery  Embed QuoteAnswered in one minute.
Yes http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/L...  Embed Quote

column9: What software could be downloaded?
column10: You can calculate the nanoparticle size distribution by writing an image segmentation script in Matlab.  Check out their image processing toolbox demos for information on how to do this. Calculating the number of elements of a given size in an image is a very well studied problem.  You'll start off by converting the image to a black & white region by setting some brightness threshold.  Then the bright regions will correspond to particles and the dark regions will correspond to empty space.  It's been a while since I did image processing in Matlab but I believe they have some built-in functions to calculate the size-distribution from such an image.I'm not sure if you can get information on the alloy from TEM images.  If the alloy corresponds to brightness, you might be able to further segment images based on that.  Embed Quote

column9: What software could be downloaded?
column10: If you already have a TEM, it is far easier to do EELS or EDX and get the alloy composition. Image analysis will almost never give you very correct answers. As for analyzing images, by far the most commonly used software is Digital Micrograph made by Gatan. However it is not free, and with plugins can cost upwards of $5000.  Embed Quote

Fog and pollution are unrelated. Fog is really just a particularly low lying stratus cloud. Smog is what is increased by air pollution. Smog is a mix of chemicals from the burning of coal and other fossil fuels, and other forms of pollution, such as Sulfur Dioxide, smoke, etc. Photochemical smog, a term you might here, is caused by the chemical reaction of sun with this byproducts of energy and other pollution causing things. It is a mix that volatile organic compounds, ozone, aldehydes, nitrogen oxides and more. This was a huge problem in Los Angeles, Mexico City, London, and other areas with high populations and high pollution emissions. Sorry for the tangent if that's not what you were looking for. In short, No, air pollution does not increase fog levels, fog levels actually decrease air pollution, as the water molecules floating in the air carry dust particles and others to the ground when they settle. Fog Cleans Air Pollution -- Atmospheric Chemists Show Morning Fog Captures Particulate MatterFog  Embed QuoteAnswered in fifty-six minutes.

column9: I have MCS(Multiple Chemical Sensitivity), so the effects of these exposures are acute and can be debilitating. Furthermore, studies have shown brain scans indicating that these exposures cause seizure-like activity, leaving long term, permanent damage in their wake. Is there a way(s), other than the almost impossible avoidance or industry suddenly going green, that I can be around these things and mitigate or reduce their effects?

column9: I've read that coal-burning is a source of Hg in fish... and also that there is naturally-occurring Hg in the ocean... where is the Hg in fish today coming from?
column10: The mercury found in fish comes from both anthropogenic (human-made/induced) and "natural"sources. However, it should be noted that "natural" mercury emissions are accounted as including re-emission of both anthropogenic and "natural" deposits, and that re-emission of previously anthropogenically-attributable mercury has been estimated to account for 50% of all "natural" land and ocean emissions into the atmosphere (Lindberg et al. 2007, pg. 20). So, mercury vapor entering the atmosphere from an open field would be counted as a "natural" emission, even if that mercury had been deposited in that field as a result of a nearby coal-fired power plant.Mercury cycles through the environment, so the question of where the mercury found in fish comes from depends on how many steps back you go. The short version is that mercury in fish comes from what they eat, including plants, crustaceans, and other fish. Mercury bioaccumulates up the food chain, which is why top predatory fish have higher concentrations than those at the bottom of the food chain. The mercury bioaccumulating up the food chain (and the one of major concern to human health) is methylmercury (MeHg), which has been converted from inorganic mercury by bacteria living at the sedimentary level. This methylmercury is then taken up by the marine food web, and also explains why bottom-dwelling animals tend to have higher mercury concentrations than you would otherwise expect.The mercury in sediment has settled from the water. Mercury enters the water from atmospheric and terrestrial deposition. There is run-off from surface deposits, direct dumping, settling of mercury-laden atmospheric particulates, mercury-laden rain, etc. A 2002 paper by Mason and Shau (see bottom of comment reference) estimated that atmospheric deposition into the oceans accounted for around 15.4 times that of surface deposition.According to a 2010 estimate by Pirrone et al., annual "natural" emissions to the atmosphere (including re-emission of anthropogenic emissions) totalled 5207 megagrams (5,207,000 kilograms), while annual anthropogenic emissions totalled 2320 megagrams (2,320,000 kilograms). The study found that "fossil-fuel fired power plants, ferrous and non-ferrous metals manufacturing facilities, caustic soda production plants, ore processing facilities, incinerators for urban, medical and industrial wastes, cement plants and chemicals production facilities" released significant amounts of mercury into the atmosphere, and that "fossil fuel-fired power plants are the largest point sources of mercury released to the atmosphere" (Pirrone et al. 2010, pg. 4726). It's also important to note that mercury concentrations are higher near their source, so fish living in an area close to coal-fired power plants are likely to have higher concentrations than those that are not. Deposits in sediment and elsewhere may also endure for a long time, so closure of a plant or other point source may not reduce risk for years or decades. My doctoral thesis, Fish Consumption, Mercury Intake, and the Associated Risks to the Kuwaiti Population, considers the past presence of a nearby chlorine and bleach processing plant that had used mercury cathodes as a possible contributor to mercury concentrations in fish in the Arabian Gulf, though the plant closed in the 1970s.I'll have a look for historical databases on mercury concentrations in fish and let you know if something comes up. For which region were you looking for information?- Mey AkashahReferences:Akashah, M. (2010), Fish Consumption, Mercury Intake, and the Associated Risks to the Kuwaiti Population, Harvard School of Public Health.Lindberg, S., et al. (2007), “A Synthesis of Progress and Uncertainties in Attributing the Sources of Mercury in Deposition," Ambio, Vol. 36, No. 1, pp. 19-32.Mason, R.P. and Sheu, G.R. (2002), "Role of the ocean in the global mercury cycle," Glob. Biogeochem. Cycles, Vol. 16, pg. 093.Pirrone, N. et al. (2010), "Global mercury emissions to the atmosphere from anthropogenic and natural sources," Atmos. Chem. Phys. Discuss., Vol. 10, pp. 4719–4752.  Embed Quote

column9: How much of the pollution comes in the form of nanoparticles?
column10: Here are some excerpts from an NYT article that attempted to quantify this:Emissions of nitrogen dioxide in homes with gas stoves exceed the Environmental Protection Agency’s definition of clean air in an estimated 55 percent to 70 percent of those homes, according to one model; a quarter of them have air quality worse than the worst recorded smog (nitrogen dioxide) event in London.  Cooking represents one of the single largest contributors, generating particulate matter (formally known as PM2.5) at concentrations four times greater than major haze events in Beijing.“Because we’re used to the smell, we don’t think of it as an issue,” said Jennifer M. Logue, 32, an air quality engineer at the Berkeley Lab. “When you live in a small building, you cook a lot and don’t use your range hood, which may not be very effective anyway, then you’re probably going to have a problem with pollutants from cooking.”Recently Dr. Logue estimated the long-term health effects expected from hundreds of chemicals found in average homes. Her 2012 study, published in Environmental Health Perspectives, used a common epidemiological metric known as disability-adjusted life-year to show that the population-wide health impact of indoor pollutants is on a par with that of car accidents, and greater than that of traditional concerns like secondhand smoke or radon.When they tested seven different commercially available range hood designs, Dr. Singer and Dr. Delp found that the airflow and the amount of burner exhaust and cooking contaminants whisked away — the so-called “capture efficiency” — varied from 15 percent to 98 percent. [1]There is also acrolein which is emitted when meats and oils are cooked and "is a genotoxic tissue irritant and was used as a nerve agent in World War I."[2]There's a good comment below from a restaurant equipment technician who says that:A larger issue with older (especially dirty) ranges is that the venturi and air shutters become clogged with dust and grease. This can easily lead to incomplete combustion of your fuel gas. This results in very high levels of carbon monoxide in the exhaust gases.The technician offers tips as well:With the burner lit look at the flame... it SHOULD be blue and tight... if there is any yellow/orange at the flame tip/body (not sparkles... that's just dust) then the flame is o2 starved and is producing CO... AMONG OTHER NASTIESBased on this, it may make sense to open a window when cooking — or use other techniques to improve ventilation. Doing so may be beneficial for your health — provided it's not too hot or cold outside and there isn't some other compelling reason to keep your window closed.[1] The Kitchen as a Pollution Hazard [2] Hidden Dangers in the Air We Breathe  Embed Quote

column9: I'm trying to investigate the hypothesis that we should be more concerned about uSv/second rather than total exposure to uSv over a year, since uSv/second comes closer to the rate on which DNA repair enzymes act.(it could be that maximum exposure rate over 100 millisecond intervals [1] could be more relevant but we have no way to calibrate that)[1] which could be subject to stochastic effects
column10: 0.0000761 uSv/second: dose rate of average amount of radiation that person is exposed to. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bac.... Keep in mind that there is a lot of variation.0.001389 uSv/second: dose rate of airplane flying at 12 km. Around 18x the natural dose rate of background radiation. Is this a risk? We don't know (Alex K. Chen's answer to Is there conclusive medical research that flying in airplanes exposes people to unsafe amounts of radiation?), but the study below shows no added risk from 400X times background radiation. Keep in mind, though, that flying during a solar storm can increase the amount of radiation you're exposed to by hundreds of times (or possibly even more during exceptionally rare events that might increase in frequency over the next 50 years - http://news.sciencemag.org/scien...), which could explain why frequent flyers and flight attendants do appear to have higher rates of cancer. See http://www.spaceweather.com to see whether or not there is a solar  storm about to hit, and  http://terra2.spacenvironment.ne... for real-time radiation exposure rates.0.01175 uSv/second: maximum exposure rate during the Halloween 2003 SEP event 3 over the poles at 15km (see http://www.intechopen.com/downlo... ). Calculation from http://www.wolframalpha.com/inpu.... This is 154.4X normal background radiation. Similar for March 2011 SEP event. Keep in mind that most commercial planes only fly at 11-12 km, not 15 km, and that radiation exposure increases by 75% each km at altitudes above 10km (it increases by 160% each km at altitudes below 10km).0.03044 uSv/second: 400X normal background radiation from levels calculated in Wiki article (MIT study uses 0.0283 uSv/second as reference), shown to have no risk to mouse DNA at http://ehp03.niehs.nih.gov/artic... (popular article at http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/20...), but only when present in the form of I-125 irradiator (not all radiation is equal) [1]. 1.39 uSv/second: dose rate of Apollo astronauts during the Apollo missions.1.667 uSv/second: dose rate of dental X-rays if dental X-rays are taken over 3 seconds (I'm not sure how long they are taken over though) - this is at 13,147 times the natural amount of radiation that one is exposed to. Apparently there are some risks: http://www.webmd.com/brain/news/...5.789 uSv/second: maximum dose rate over the poles during the January 2005 SEP event at 15km (see https://docs.google.com/open?id=... and http://www.wolframalpha.com/inpu... for calculation). This event came so quickly that pilots probably wouldn't be able to descend lower into the atmosphere after hearing of it.This seems to be the only recent event above the 0.03044 uSv/second threshold though, and only a small fraction of pilots were probably flying over high latitudes that time... Plus, flares like this are generally pretty rare (how many pilots would be exposed to several of these events while flying at high latitudes in their lifetime?But...Flying near a lightning discharge can *significantly* increase  your dose of radiation in a one-hit event. See http://news.ufl.edu/2009/12/07/l...Scientists  at the Florida Institute of Technology, University of California, Santa  Cruz and the University of Florida have estimated that airplane  passengers could be exposed to a radiation  dose equal to that from 400  chest X-rays if their airplane happens to  be near the start of a  lightning discharge or related phenomena known as  a terrestrial gamma  ray flash.Since each  commercial airplane is hit by lightning by an average of once per year,  this could potentially significantly increase the radiation dose  experienced by airline pilots, frequent fliers, or people who are simply  unlucky.====[1] And when does a danger level start to pop in? Well, let's try with some levels where there doesn't seem to be danger yet (see http://ehp03.niehs.nih.gov/artic...)Info from the study:DNA damage occurs spontaneously even at background radiation levels,  conservatively at a rate of about 10,000 changes per cell per day. Most  of that damage is fixed by DNA repair systems within each cell. The  researchers estimate that the amount of radiation used in this study  produces an additional dozen lesions per cell per day, all of which  appear to have been repaired.Though the study ended after five  weeks, Engelward believes the results would be the same for longer  exposures. “My take on this is that this amount of radiation is not  creating very many lesions to begin with, and you already have good DNA  repair systems. My guess is that you could probably leave the mice there  indefinitely and the damage wouldn’t be significant,” she says. ===1 gray is approximately equal to 1 Sievert for x-rays and gamma rays, but 20 Sieverts for alpha particles0.00017 cGy/min (or 0.0283 uGy/second) from I-125 irradiator (400X higher than background radiation, 5x higher than some sites at Iran) at cumulative dose of 10.5 cGy over 5 weeks => no effects on DNASupposedly, the majority of background radiation tracks through our bodies are photon tracks.7.1 cGy/min at cumulative dose of 10.5 cGy significantly upregulates Cdkn1a but does not lead to statistically significant detectable increase in homologous recombination.  Embed QuoteAnswered in fifteen minutes.

column10: This is, of course, the question of the threshold versus linear no-threshold models of radiation risk. It's an open question, and there is still no consensus in the scientific community, though choosing to err on the side of caution, the linear no-threshold model is typically adopted. The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists has actually devoted its current issue to this question of low-level radiation risks, which has been increasingly discussed in light of the recent Fukushima incident. While I cannot profess to have read this issue, I'd recommend you take a look: http://bos.sagepub.com/content/6...  Embed Quote

Well, they used to say "the solution to pollution is dilution." Once you mix just about anything with a billion gallons of water in the nearby river it doesn't really amount to much. (Of course, that's a terrible mindset to have most of the time! Even if it is true in this case.) Most liquid drain cleaners are pretty safe for the environment once they're washed away and diluted. They're basically just a concentrated mixture of bleach and lye. That's NaClO (sodium hypochlorite) and NaOH/KOH (sodium hydroxide/potassium hydroxide). It is a powerful base and very corrosive but gets progressively milder as water is added until eventually it becomes perfectly safe to drink. When used as intended, a significant amount will react with grease and hair and other drain gunk and simply be neutralized. Long story short, if you pour a gallon of it on the ground or in a creek you could do a small amount of damage. It would definitely burn you very badly if you drank it. But washed through sewage and a treatment plant and into a river, it's perfectly harmless.   Embed Quote

column9: E.g. I think prenatal pesticide exposure is something that is really overlooked (the number of impacted individuals is unknown though)
column10: PBDEs: http://www.sciencedaily.com/rele...Pesticides (especially since developing countries tend to use the more dangerous organochlorides and organophosphates).See http://e360.yale.edu/feature/fro...The New York studies found that for every increased increment of prenatal organophosphate pesticide exposure, the IQs of the children studied dropped by 1.4 percent and their working memory scores dropped by 2.8 percent. A key finding of the Columbia University study was that the relationship between pesticide exposure and IQ and working memory scores was linear and showed “no evidence for a threshold.” In other words, the greater the exposure, the greater the impact on cognition.The third study, led by researchers at the University of California, Berkeley, looked at 329 children living in agricultural communities in the Salinas Valley, in Monterey County, the country’s top vegetable-producing region. The California mothers were predominantly Latino farmworkers, and their exposure resulted from living and working near where these chemicals were used agriculturally; when sprayed on crops, organophosphate pesticides can easily drift with the wind beyond their intended fields.As with the New York study, when researchers measured the IQ of the California children at age seven, those with the highest prenatal exposure scored as much as 7 points lower than the children with the lowest prenatal levels of pesticide exposure.Furthermore, this is just in the U.S., where there are regulations on pesticide use (and where the climate is fairly temperate - freezing periods can really help control pests). The scenario is most likely worse in developing countries.The sad thing is that I tried some aggressive Google-searching for pesticides+"developing countries"+IQ and could find nothing. The article above was written in 2011, so we're really only just starting to discover the nasty effects of pesticides on IQAlso, those in developing nations are often vulnerable to infectious illnesses (http://www.scientificamerican.co... ) that can lower IQ. But the chemicals used to control them (especially ones like DDT) can also decrease IQ. It's possible that these chemicals could reduce the incidence of IQ-lowering infectious diseases for a while, but infectious agents often develop pesticide resistance, which can then produce a double-whammy effect (with the IQ-lowering effects of both infectious illnesses and pesticides)The other thing with developing nations is that most people are younger in them, so a disproportionate of them are now getting exposed by pesticides during the most critical parts of their lives.Anyways - I may sound too much like an environmentalist here, but Alex K. Chen's answer to Ecology: Would any ecosystems or the food chain be drastically affected if mosquitoes became extinct suddenly? should show that I really do look from the other side of the issue as well.(With that all being said, these environmental contributions probably don't explain much of the recorded variance in IQ between countries - as most "country-wide IQ" scores were made several decades ago - when it was the industrialized nations that applied a disproportionate amount of the neurotoxic pesticides. But they could stall out the Flynn Effect for some time).===Also, air pollution (http://www.sciencedaily.com/rele... )Prenatal exposure to environmental pollutants known as polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) can adversely affect a child's intelligence quotient or IQ, according to new research by the the Columbia Center for Children's Environmental Health (CCCEH) at the Mailman School of Public Health. PAHs are chemicals released into the air from the burning of coal, diesel, oil and gas, or other organic substances such as tobacco. In urban areas motor vehicles are a major source of PAHs.The study found that children exposed to high levels of PAHs in New York City had full scale and verbal IQ scores that were 4.31 and 4.67 points lower, respectively than those of less exposed children. High PAH levels were defined as above the median of 2.26 nanograms per cubic meter (ng/m3).  Embed Quote
