column9: I have a neighboring shop that cuts asbestos sheets a lot. Trouble is, considering the health risks I cannot move shop. Would insulating my shop facade with glass help? Some good advice would be really helpful.
column10: You have actually made differing statements in your question: You stated that the shop next door MAKES asbestos (which is exceptionally unlikely as asbestos manufacture, even outside the US, is an complicated process requiring a small factory at the least to perform) and that the shop next CUTS asbestos (an entirely different task.)I'll answer this question with assumption that you are NOT located in North America, Western Europe, Japan or Australia.Why?Because mesothelioma is well-known illness in those areas and any asbestos work would require extensive permitting as well as comprehensive facility safety and remediation efforts, which don't seem to be the case with your neighbors' business.There is almost nothing which you can do to remediate asbestos in your own shop if you don't have the full cooperation of your neighbor and you plan on spending a sizable amount of money, Asbestos remediation is a highly skilled trade, which is best performed by trained professionals who will expect to be well-compensated for their efforts.Unless you and the neighboring business have a sizable amount of money to create the conditions necessary to handle asbestos and any accompanying legal action which may arise from exposure, I would strongly suggest relocating your business. Glass insulation as Bruce Feldman correctly noted will do NOTHING to prevent asbestos infiltration.  Embed Quote

column9: I have a neighboring shop that cuts asbestos sheets a lot. Trouble is, considering the health risks I cannot move shop. Would insulating my shop facade with glass help? Some good advice would be really helpful.
column10: No. Health risks from asbestos exposure come from particles and fibers that become airborne. This occurs during the manufacture, installation and/or removal of asbestos or materials.containing asbestos.Therefore, the only protection from exposure to asbestos would be in the form of ventilation and air filtration sufficient to remove these particles and fibers from the air inside your shop.  Embed QuoteVia  Raheel Shakeel.

column9: I have a neighboring shop that cuts asbestos sheets a lot. Trouble is, considering the health risks I cannot move shop. Would insulating my shop facade with glass help? Some good advice would be really helpful.
column10: Just one asbestos fiber could be enough to cause you to develop some type of cancer.  Putting glass up around your shop will not block each and every asbestos fiber so it won't eliminate the risk.  I urge you in the strongest possible terms to move away or do something to get the other shop to move away. Can you work with the shop to reduce the dangers on their end?  Wetting the asbestos before they cut it will help reduce the fibers released.  Perhaps they could put glass up around their facility as well.  None of these things would eliminate the problem, but perhaps it could lower the risk. Or perhaps you could show the shop next door pictures of a lung that developed mesothelioma.  It's bad, bad stuff.  Embed QuoteVia  Raheel Shakeel.

In summary:Stockholm University reports 0.8 grams per hour with a standard deviation of 0.1.In more detail:This is an interesting question. At first I thought of dust, but it turns out the respiratory danger from lawn mowing is soot particles from engine exhaust gases that are of size PM 2.5 [1] - small enough to penetrate the lung lining and carcinogenic.[2][3]Studies of ultrafine particle emissions from engines have been conducted in Sweden[4] and Australia [5] at least but to answer your question very precisely, the distribution analysis seems to have been focussed on diesel fuelled engines. Nevertheless the Swedish paper addresses the unleaded petrol four stroke lawn mower engine emissions in detail, using two fuels and both with and without the use of a catalytic converter. The breakdown of the emissions is copious and it isn't helpful for me to reproduce it here. But the key statistic would seem to be the emission of 0.8 grams per hour with a standard deviation of 0.1. For expansion on that, please follow the link provided below[4] - it takes you direct to the article without a pay wall.US regulators have been working on this health issue with challenge by the dominant lawn mower engine manufacturer.[6] Ultimately we may see mowers, chain saws, hedge trimmers, line trimmers and other gasoline powered power gardening machines shipping with little catalytic converters.[7] In fact you may be able to buy an aftermarket catalytic converter for your lawn mower right now.[8] Either way, it may be wise to wear a suitable respirator or mask if you are around a lot of such engine emissions.[9] My engine has an air filter ... aren't I just as important?References1. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Par... 2. http://www.dailymail.co.uk/healt...3. http://www.ehow.com/facts_726986...4. Westerholm et al "Measurement of regulated and unregulated exhausts emissions from a lawn mower with and without an oxidizing catalyst: A comparison of two different fuels." http://www.utahmomsforcleanair.o...5. Department of the Environment, "Health Impacts of Ultrafine Particles" http://www.environment.gov.au/at...6. http://www.cleanairwatch.org/200...7. http://www.reginfo.gov/public/do...8. http://news.cnet.com/8301-11128_...9. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Par...  Embed Quote

Catalytic converters finish burning whatever wasn't burned in the engine. So yes, all those hydrocarbons will be broken down from the exhaust gas stream. However, tailpipe emissions aren't the only source of VOCs and other nasties. Gasoline vaporization (directly out of your tank or from spills) is the cause of most unburned hydrocarbon emissions from vehicles today. A catalytic converter will not do anything about tank emissions. This is why gas pumps in cities have those weird little "vapor recovery" bellows on them, and why modern vehicles have sealed fuel systems. It keeps the vapors inside your tank where they belong. But older vehicles, lawnmowers, and so forth don't have these systems so they still emit some gasoline vapors on hot days.  Embed Quote

column9: P95 and P99 filters are mostly only designed for larger particles.
column10: Wow, surprisingly enough, conventional air filters work fine on nanoparticles (in fact, they trap the smallest nanoparticles even better than they trap larger ones)http://www.nanosafe.org/home/lib...http://www.nanosafe.org/scripts/...http://www.nanolawreport.com/200...http://pubs.acs.org/cen/coversto...So NIOSH teamed up with University of Minnesota researchers Seong-Chan Kim and David Pui to study particles in this size range. They found that several different types of commonly used filter materials effectively block the passage of silver particles 3 to 20 nm in diameter. In fact, the filters proved to be better at blocking the very smallest particles than they were at filtering particles in the 100-nm range.There are, however, studies that suggest the filters are less effective for other nanoparticles. Sergey Grinshpun, a professor of environmental health at the University of Cincinnati, tested two types of N95 respirators, which are supposed to filter out 95% of the particles they encounter, under two different inhalation flow rates. He found that under certain conditions up to 7% of sodium chloride particles in the 30- to 70-nm range were getting through the respirators."Not all the respirators that are certified to be 95 provide 95% efficiency for all nanoparticles," Grinshpun concludes. Respirator filters are typically tested against 300-nm particles, a size that NIOSH determined years ago to be the most penetrating. But those tests, he explains, were based on data from uncharged filter material. Since then, respirator makers have shifted to using charged filter material. This shift, Grinshpun thinks, has resulted in a change in the most penetrating particle size.  Embed Quote

column9: P95 and P99 filters are mostly only designed for larger particles.
column10: Here is a link to a CDC Science Blog posting on this topic: http://blogs.cdc.gov/niosh-scien... Key point:  As predicted by single fiber filtration theory, 4 to 20 nanometer particles were captured very efficiently by respirator filter media, because these small particles are constantly bombarded by air molecules, which causes them to deviate from the airstream and come into contact with a filter fiber to become trapped by the filter.  Embed Quote

column9: I have a history of childhood Asthma that typically was aggravated only during a bacterial upper respiratory infection.  Since moving into a new apartment in Baltimore, MD, I noticed that spending long periods of time in my study elicits symptoms of asthma that persist for days.  Prior to moving to my apartment, I never required an oral steroid.  Now, I have to take an oral steroid when this exposure aggravates the symptoms a lot; typically, this occurs after spending hours at the study during weekends.I discovered recently that although the apartment unit is new, the building is an old ware house from the 1800s.  My neighboor--who owns his unit--had a similar issue, and when he was president of the condo association, he had the building tested.  They suspect the problem is with the bricks inside the units; they are not sealed and release brick dust.  His physician believe this to be the culprit of his reactive airway disease (i.e.,asthma.)My girlfriend and I signed a 12 month lease prior to moving in.  After 2 months of being in the apartment, I want to break the lease for medical reasons.  I've discussed this health issue with my land lord; before learning about the issue with the exposed bricks, my landlord addressed this by having the ventilation system checked for mold and the filter replaced.  Incidentally, there was no mold.One month ago, I left my landlord a voicemail indicating since replacing the filter, things haven't improved.  I asked her to call me back, but she didn't.  I then e-mailed her yesterday to communicate that the problem persists, and informed her of my conversation with the former president of the condo association.  She replied, indicating that she has e-mailed the condo association and will get back to me.As I await the association's reply, I'd like to know: What are my rights as a tenant in the state of Maryland, given these circumstances? Can I break my lease without penalty? I live in Baltimore, Maryland (downtown.)
column10: It would be highly unlikely that you would be permitted to break your lease without penalty under the circumstances you describe.  Most attorneys will probably tell you that you must first establish an actual causal relationship, or link, between your medical symptoms and your apartment living environment.  This must be confirmed by certified medical professionals, not simply suspected as a cause.  Even then, in most cases there would have to be the presence of mold, mildew, asbestos fibers, or other known hazards, contaminants or allergens present in the environment that could be removed or abated; brick dust is probably not one of them.  Nor is brick dust generally known as a contaminant or allergen, so the lanldord would likely not be required to address this condition, notwithstanding that it may be harmful to you.  Your best course of action is to try to sublet the apartment, with permission of your landlord or, if possible, assign your lease (again, with permission) to a new tenant and relocate to a new home.If you can establish a documented causal relationship between the presence of brick dust and your medical condition, then you may have another course of action available to you.  Under the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1989, landlords are required to make "reasonable accomodations" for the handicapped, which includes people with certain medical conditions.  If, for example, it was exposed brick in your apartment that was causing your medical condition, you can require your landlord to cover the brick with paint, laquer or other covering material so the dust cannot enter the living space or make similar reasonable accomodations to abate the dust material.  In cases where accomodations cannot be made to abate the condition, then you may be able to require the landlord to allow you to break your lease without penalty as the reasonable accomodation you are requesting under the ADA, which would require your consultation with an attorney.  Embed Quote

column9: I have a history of childhood Asthma that typically was aggravated only during a bacterial upper respiratory infection.  Since moving into a new apartment in Baltimore, MD, I noticed that spending long periods of time in my study elicits symptoms of asthma that persist for days.  Prior to moving to my apartment, I never required an oral steroid.  Now, I have to take an oral steroid when this exposure aggravates the symptoms a lot; typically, this occurs after spending hours at the study during weekends.I discovered recently that although the apartment unit is new, the building is an old ware house from the 1800s.  My neighboor--who owns his unit--had a similar issue, and when he was president of the condo association, he had the building tested.  They suspect the problem is with the bricks inside the units; they are not sealed and release brick dust.  His physician believe this to be the culprit of his reactive airway disease (i.e.,asthma.)My girlfriend and I signed a 12 month lease prior to moving in.  After 2 months of being in the apartment, I want to break the lease for medical reasons.  I've discussed this health issue with my land lord; before learning about the issue with the exposed bricks, my landlord addressed this by having the ventilation system checked for mold and the filter replaced.  Incidentally, there was no mold.One month ago, I left my landlord a voicemail indicating since replacing the filter, things haven't improved.  I asked her to call me back, but she didn't.  I then e-mailed her yesterday to communicate that the problem persists, and informed her of my conversation with the former president of the condo association.  She replied, indicating that she has e-mailed the condo association and will get back to me.As I await the association's reply, I'd like to know: What are my rights as a tenant in the state of Maryland, given these circumstances? Can I break my lease without penalty? I live in Baltimore, Maryland (downtown.)
column10: This is a very specific question of how a specific law might be applied to a specific set of facts.  It's highly unlikely that you'll find an attorney who will be willing to answer your question on an online forum such as this, as it's tantamount to giving legal advice to a non-client (something that we don't do for liability reasons).  I would strongly advise you to contact a tenants' rights organization in your area or a licensed attorney who is familiar with landlord-tenant disputes in Baltimore.  Embed QuoteThis answer is not a substitute for professional legal advice.... (more)Loading... Answered in five minutes.

column10: Sounds like you have the makings of a claim for "constructive eviction" meaning the property is not habitable due to your medical problems. (While I agree that subletting is not a bad idea to try and mitigate, you'd have to disclose your problem to a prospective tenant the same way that your landlord had a duty to disclose this "latent" defect. If the landlord knew about it before signing your lease (he certainly knows now) your damages would be higher. I suspect that his liability insurer would pay or seriously consider paying your claim. Get notice to your landlord to notify his insurer of your claims and attendant damages.   Embed Quote

column9: The law enumerates seven specific rights to which Mother Earth and her constituent life systems, including human communities, are entitled to:To life: It is the right to the maintenance of the integrity of life systems and natural processes which sustain them, as well as the capacities and conditions for their renewalTo the Diversity of Life: It is the right to the preservation of the differentiation and variety of the beings that comprise Mother Earth, without being genetically altered, nor artificially modified in their structure, in such a manner that threatens their existence, functioning and future potentialTo water: It is the right of the preservation of the quality and composition of water to sustain life systems and their protection with regards to contamination, for renewal of the life of Mother Earth and all its componentsTo clean air: It is the right of the preservation of the quality and composition of air to sustain life systems and their protection with regards to contamination, for renewal of the life of Mother Earth and all its componentsTo equilibrium: It is the right to maintenance or restoration of the inter-relation, interdependence, ability to complement and functionality of the components of Mother Earth, in a balanced manner for the continuation of its cycles and the renewal of its vital processesTo restoration: To Restoration: It is the right to the effective and opportune restoration of life systems affected by direct or indirect human activitiesTo live free of contamination: It is the right for preservation of Mother Earth and any of its components with regards to toxic and radioactive waste generated by human activitiesvia http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law...
column10: There are better alternatives to protect the environment than this kind of general announcements in law format. One very effective solution is a serious strategical campaign by the government targeted to general public. The goal for the campaign is to create accurate awareness for the environment and providing a solution and course of action for individuals. Simultaneously they can have a tax penalty for non-environmental products. By doing so they will create a conscious demand for more environmental products and create a higher price differentiation for non-environmental products to award the environmental alternatives. This solutions have been extremely successful in Europe particularly Scandinavian countries.A stipulation in law regarding acceptance and recognition of rights for planet earth is not going to be effective, if general public is not demanding it, and a violation on manufacturer side is not directly connected to a cost increase for each unit manufactured.  Embed Quote

column9: [1] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law...A 2001 study showed that some mowers emit the same amount of pollution (emissions other than carbon dioxide) in one hour as driving a 1992 model car for 650 miles (1,050 km).[17] Another estimate puts the amount of pollution from a lawn mower at four times the amount from a car, per hour.[18]
column10: Hepa filters will work for particulates but they won't work for VOC's. You'll need e mask which is designed for VOC's. This can be a cartridge mask or a mask with its own oxygen supply.  With cartridge masks you need to make sure the cartridge is able to handle the contaminant(s) of concern.  Embed Quote

column10: A HEPA air filter is going to remove larger particles. In order to remove VOCs you are going to need an air purifier that uses PCO as an air purification process. Photo catalytic oxidation can remove VOCs from ambient air and is the only process that can. The problem with air purification companies, is that they say they can remove small particles, but in reality they can't. PCO is a newer process, and there are only a few companies that use it. Most masks will not remove VOCs as well. The particles are so small they they will just go right through the mask. Look at this website: ino-labs.com for more info on PCO and particle sizes.  Embed Quote

column9: I've heard numerous conflicting opinions on whether there it's harmful to live next to or near power stations or power lines.  Are there any credible studies arguing either direction?
column10: Make of this what you want. I'm not convinced either way yet, but both sides have a case.As for cell phone towers and cancer risk (not cell phones specifically,but stll relevant as these are the same frequencies), see intense discussion at http://www.reddit.com/r/science/...In particular, see http://www.reddit.com/r/science/...32.1 to 43.4 is a 35% increase in risk which is NOT good.The 95% confidence interval on the mortality rate is quite tight due to large numbers of observed deaths. Additionally there is an obvious progression linked with distance which would appear to refute your appeal to error.Table 5. Mortality rates by neoplasia in the Belo Horizonte municipality, according to distance from the base station.Distance    CMR    95% C.I.Until 100   43.4   42.02 to 44.87Until 200   40.2   39.12 to 41.35Until 300   37.1   36.19 to 38.08Until 400   35.8   34.94 to 36.69Until 500   34.8   33.94 to 35.60Until 600   33.8   33.04 to 34.64Until 700   33.8   33.01 to 34.60Until 800   33.5   32.71 to 34.28Until 900   33.2   32.44 to 34.00Until 1000  32.8   32.02 to 33.55Null hypoth 32.1   31.39 to 32.87Distances in meters. See how distances below 100 meters have the highest crude mortality rate.CMR = Crude mortalit rate in deaths per 10,000 population95% C.I. = 95% confidence interval for the CMRThe evidence strongly supports proximity to a base station being linked to neoplasia related death.And  http://www.reddit.com/r/science/... ...Also, a lot of people are rejecting this with the correlation<>causation. I understand that with what the article claims, but not the paper. They are attempting to reject the hypothesis that there is no significant difference, which is rejected because there is a significant difference.Yes, there will be some overlap on factors here, but it's really not enough to out of hand dismiss the claims. You can see the distribution of both deaths and base stations on pages 10 and 11, and granted I cannot go through the analysis they did, but it does not look like density clumping is the issue. You see that again on page 15, with it approaching norms as you get farther from base towers. I can think of a few confounding factors too, but such is the case with most studies. Again, they are attempting to reject the null hypothesis, and they do.Finally, this is not the first paper to find such correlations. I would be curious if anyone has papers that do not show a correlation, or shows a regression fully explaining such a correlation. Those that do attempt to seem to be hitting on a strawman, self reported complaints, rather than robust data driven studies.What I do find interesting is how much immediate rejection there is to such a paper. It's very emotionally reactive, which is kind of odd. The same goes with figuring out the interaction - well, that's the point. If a correlation is consistently found (null hypothesis is not rejected would be the interesting parts now), it points to trying to find out what the issue is.Keep in mind that the advice they give is related to the inverse square rule, and apparently they have significantly more power being pushed in this region. Hopefully they picked the area based on that. Anyway, the answer could be as simple as having more towers with less power. That could be another large (maybe meta - not sure how many papers have come out already) test, actually, to compare cities with different strengths. shrug  Embed QuoteAnswered in twenty-two minutes.

column9: I've heard numerous conflicting opinions on whether there it's harmful to live next to or near power stations or power lines.  Are there any credible studies arguing either direction?
column10: A preliminary PubMed (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov) search for the most recent review articles on this topic  led to this article,...I included the MeSH terms for further searching...if needed.[PubMed is the largest indexer of biomedical literature in the world, it is a product of the US National Institutes of Health and US National Library of Medicine...only about 1/3 or so of the articles are freely available on the Internet to all]I am no expert in this field, but a preliminary search of PubMed seems to indicate that the jury is still out on the severity of health consequences.Let me know if I can be of further assistance. For example, I would be happy to come up with a relevant list of 10 or so articles...much as I would do in my past capacity as a medical reference librarian...Or I could search "popular" literature/Web sites for reputable info.Just let me know!Chronic Dis Can. 2010;29 Suppl 1:69-83.Electric and magnetic fields at power frequencies.Miller AB, Green LM.SourceDepartment of Public Health Sciences, University of Toronto, Toronto, Ontario.AbstractExposures to electric and magnetic fields are among the most ubiquitous exposures that the Canadian population experiences. Sources of electric and magnetic field exposures may be occupational or residential and include proximity to certain types of electrical equipment, transmission and distribution power lines as well as appliance use. The early studies of children tended toward a consistent association between risks for leukemia and brain cancer and residential proximity to power lines having high wire configuration. More recent studies-and studies which have attempted to improve upon the measurement of exposure by using calculated fields, point-in-time or personal monitoring-have been inconsistent, with some suggesting increased risk and others not. Occupational exposures have suggested an increase in risk for leukemia, and to a lesser extent brain cancer and Non-Hodgkin lymphoma. However, studies of residential exposures and cancer in adults generally have suggested no effect. Laboratory work has been unable to demonstrate a biological mechanism which might explain the epidemiological findings. In spite of extensive efforts over the past 20 years and many expert reviews, it has been difficult to reach consensus regarding the carcinogenic effects of electric and magnetic fields. Exposure assessment has proven to be complex, and agreement on the relevant exposure metric has not yet been obtained. There is justification to question whether point-in-time measures in homes are appropriate indices of the relevant etiological exposure, as they fail to account for changes over time, peak exposures or time-varying fields. Nevertheless, it is probably desirable to err on the side of caution in not placing too much weight on the inconsistencies. The IARC has classified EMF as a "possible carcinogen" which refers to the circumstances where there is limited evidence of carcinogenicity in humans and inadequate evidence in experimental animals. The IARC review indicated limited evidence for the carcinogenicity of extremely low-frequency magnetic fields in relation to childhood leukemia at high level exposure in the residential environment (average residential magnetic field strength >0.4 μT). Even higher levels of exposure in the occupational environment may increase the risk of leukemia in adults.PMID: 21199600 [PubMed - indexed for MEDLINE]Publication Types, MeSH TermsPublication TypesReviewMeSH TermsCanada/epidemiologyCausalityElectromagnetic Fields/adverse effects*Environmental Exposure/adverse effectsEnvironmental Monitoring/standardsHumansLeukemia/epidemiology*Leukemia/etiology*Occupational Diseases/epidemiologyOccupational Diseases/etiologyRisk Assessment/methodsRisk Assessment/standards  Embed QuoteAnswered in twenty-seven minutes.

column9: I LOVE firework displays! They always bring out the big kid in me, and the louder, brighter and more spectacular they are the more I grin, laugh, whoop and cheer. The New Year fireworks in London this year were particularly impressive (they've been getting better every year, and of course we are hosting the Olympics this year so the organizers probably wanted to make them extra-special). Some thoughts do occur to me when watching massive firework displays like this, though: exactly how many toxic substances of various kinds are all those pretty bangs putting into the atmosphere, could those substances pose a health-risk to spectators from 'fall-out' in the immediate area, and is there any longer-term residue that contaminates the site for days or weeks later? The last thing I want to be accused of is being a party-pooper, fun-sponge or kill-joy, and neurotic, over-cautious Health & Safety zealots who are always trying to spoil everyone's fun are no friends of mine. But I just wonder where all the chemicals in fireworks end up, and whether any assessments have ever been made about their potential effects on public health? If there are proven risks, should people be told so that they can make an informed choice about whether to expose themselves to them?
column10: Fireworks produce smoke and dust that may contain residues of heavy metals, sulfur-coal compounds and some low concentration toxic chemicals. These by-products of fireworks combustion will vary depending on the mix of ingredients of a particular firework. Sources of perchlorate range from lightning and certain fertilizers to the perchlorate compounds in rocket fuel and explosives. Scientists long suspected community fireworks displays were another source, but few studies had been done on the topic.The concern over pollution from fireworks constitutes a red herring, since the amount of contamination from fireworks is minuscule in comparison to emissions from sources such as the burning of fossil fuels. Coal fueled electricity generation alone is a much greater source of heavy metal contamination in the environment than fireworks.  Embed QuoteVia  Steve Denton.

column10: Brian has good points about the relative adverse effects of occasional fireworks in one location contribute on environmental contamination and health risks. The little research I've done seems to indicate that there is little risk in individual firework displays or a series of displays over a few days (see Emission Factor abstract below]  However, the displays can adversely effect those with poor health conditions [See Recreational Factor abstract below]Another thing to think on. How much pollution is being generated already in the locale? How much do fireworks contribute to the mix? Could a firework display be used to educate folks on pollution generators in the area and the relative contributions of fireworks? (these are just thinking out loud quesitons!)You are not alone in your concerns. (We've come a long way since the 60's...I remember as a 6th grade student..we passed  about 1 tablespoon of mercury around the room to "play with" ...with the teacher's encouragement!).A 2007 research paper in the international peer reviewed journal "Atmospheric Environment" reported on the aerosol samples collected during massive fireworks displays at the 6 day event Las Fallas in Valencia, Spain.The conclusion in the abstract ""Although firework-related recreational pollution episodes are transient in nature, they are highly concentrated, contribute significantly to total annual metal emissions, and are on average fine enough to be easily inhaled and a health risk to susceptible individuals. "[Recreational atmospheric pollution episodes: Inhalable metalliferous particles from fireworkdisplays; Atmospheric Environment; Feb2007, Vol. 41 Issue 5, p913-922, 10p]I haven't done detailed research [only a cursory search at Academic Search Premier] but there have been some studies on the effects of firework by products on human health/environment. --Emission factors and exposures from ground-level pyrotechnics.[Atmospheric Environment; Sep2010, Vol. 44 Issue 27, p3295-3303, 9p]From the abstract "Potential exposures from ground-level pyrotechnics were assessed by air monitoring and developing emission factors. Total particulate matter, copper and SO<sub>2</sub> exposures exceeded occupational health guidelines at two outdoor performances using consumer pyrotechnics. Al, Ba, B, Bi, Mg, Sr, Zn, and aldehyde levels were elevated, but did not pose a health hazard based on occupational standards. There seems to be some trends in making less toxic fireworks..For example, the US Army is considering replacing a barium compound with a much less toxic boron compound in green colored fireworks. [The free online article Cleaner, Greener Fireworks(http://www.nature.com/news/2011/...) also discusses other variables in firework production as cost and performance. Boron seems to "pass these tests".So, there are good reasons to be concerned about the effects of at least some firework components. This raises good ethical questions about the responsibility of people shooting fireworks (this is a general question, Brian, not  pointing fingers at the industry!) Can only speak for myself, I know in my own daily life I don't always walk lightly on the earth...but once aware of the (at least potential) adverse effects of what I do...as being an agent of free will (sorry, what little philosophy I had is creeping in!)...I do have some responsibility on choosing what to do or not do....This isn't really a complete answer. Just the results of about 15 minutes or so of searching.I would be happy to search further. Let me know which direction.  Embed QuoteVia  Steve Denton.

The smell of air is entirely due to the particles that are present in the air. These polluting particles come from all sorts of different sources. A portion of indoor air pollution is due to dead skin cells but household fabrics like those of your couches, carpets, or drapes can also breakdown and become airborne. If you have pets your indoor air quality will be even worse due to pet dander. Even things like the plastics and paints in your house give off chemicals that contribute to poor indoor air quality.Outdoor air smells "fresher" because even though there are many sources of pollution there is still a huge volume of air in the atmosphere and natural processes are constantly at work to bring air to a natural or "fresh" state.A good analogy might be to compare your indoor air to the water in your bathtub. If you were to put a bottle of food coloring into a full bathtub you would end up with a very colorful bathtub. But even a thousand gallons of food coloring in the middle of the ocean would soon dissipate and have no effect on the ocean's color.  Embed Quote

Air-ReNu is an inexpensive eco-friendly green solution to improving indoor air quality and eliminates bacteria, viruses, smoking odors, pet odors and urine odors. Air-ReNu is a blend of natural rare-earth minerals made from a variety of elements, including aluminum, iron, magnesium, sodium, potassium and lithium. These minerals are finely ground then mixed with paint. When the paint is applied to a wall of a home, Air-ReNu will remain effective for10-12 years, cleansing the air of impurities and removing odors. If you are seeking a long-term solution to air quality and odor control, Air-ReNu is the answer.  Embed Quote

column9: Article suggests that Lead is one of the big reasons behind people going nuts in the before the late 90s.America's Real Criminal Element: LeadNew research finds Pb is the hidden villain behind violent crime, lower IQs, and even the ADHD epidemic. And fixing the problem is a lot cheaper than doing nothing.
column10: I'm no expert on this, but I've read a lot of the crime theories, and the lead theory is one of the few ones that strikes me as a plausible explanation for a wide variety of crime phenomena. That being said, I'm not completely convinced yet (I'd have to read the studies in more detail to figure out).Nonetheless, let's be clear what the hypothesis says, if true. The hypothesis doesn't say that lead is the chief or major explanation for crime rates, or even for regional or individual differences in crime rates. What it does say is that the specific temporal anomaly of crime rates rising around the 60s and falling beginning with the 90s owes most of its explanation to lead, and ceteris paribus, if lead levels fall, then crime rates would fall. It would still be true that, even after controlling for lead levels, there is considerable variation in crime rates across regions, due to a variety of other factors in operation.Also, the relevance of the finding may be relatively limited for future crime prevention in the US, if lead levels are already declining and there are diminishing returns to further declines in terms of crime rates. But it may hold important lessons for people in other parts of the world, where leaded fuels are widely used and lead levels are likely to increase as the extent of road transportation increases to cater to the needs of a growing and more prosperous population.See also Steven Pinker's remarks on the problem with drawing inferences across multi-step causal chains in the context of the lead-crime connection: http://stevenpinker.com/files/pi...  Embed Quote

column10: A fit tested NIOSH certified N95 filtering facepiece respirator will reduce your exposure to particulate matter.  There are numerous brands available at Amazon or at your local hardware store or pharmacy.  There are some more expensive respirators that add a charcoal layer for odor control that should reduce VOC exposure to some extent.   There was an article in slate published a few years that discussed these types of devices. http://www.slate.com/id/2196988/  Embed Quote

To measure indoor air pollution you need to test for every possible or likely pollutant. An exception to this is a Volatile Organic Compounds (VOC) sensor, which tests for multiple pollutants and gives you an aggregated value/level.There are devices that test for one or a few pollutants. Most air quality monitoring devices test temperature & humidity ( combined can lead to mold ), Carbon Dioxide, Carbon Monoxide. Usually for Carbon Monoxide there are standalone devices.However, this is just the tip of the iceberg, there are lots of possible and probable pollutants: Ozone, Nitrogen oxides, Sulfur Dioxide, Radon, Lead, etc. The list goes on and on and they are not as rare as one might think/hope.For example, Radon is a radioactive gas without color or smell. Radon comes from Uranium, which is present in the soil nearly everywhere in the US. It is said to be the second leading cause for lung cancer in the US.There is a lot of information and studies on the subject of indoor air quality, although much more is needed. I myself found only limited scientific studies exist for some specific pollutants.I am fascinated by this topic and I am actually currently involved in creating a monitoring device called AirPlusPlus for common indoor air pollutants. This is just the first step of a much larger vision. Hopefully one day anyone interested can monitor, track and improve the quality of the air in their homes.  Embed Quote

The federal government recommends that you measure the level of radon in your home. Without measurements there is no way to tell whether radon is present because it is a odorless, colorless, radioactive gas. There are Inexpensive devices available for measuring radon. There are also specific mitigation techniques that have proven effective in reducing levels of radon in the home.For pollutants other than radon, measurements are most appropriate when there are either health symptoms or signs of poor ventilation and specific sources or pollutants have been identified as possible causes of indoor air quality problems. Before monitoring your home for pollutants, consult your local health department or professionals who have experience in solving indoor air quality problems.  Embed Quote

column9: Waste anesthesia gases (WAGs) are a significant health problem for operating room staff. So, anesthesia systems have scavenging systems that redirect the waste gases, usually to the outside. But there are environmental risks to that (see http://www.anesthesia-analgesia....) and anesthesia gases are also fairly expensive.Anesthetic Gas Reclamation (http://www.gasrecycler.com/index...) out of Nashville has a system, and there is a company in Canada that provides collection services (http://www.bluezone.ca/).What hospitals are using these reclamation and collection services? What are experiences with using them? (Also, are there other firms doing this that I can't seem to find?)
column10: I am an anesthesiologist (anaesthetist) and have worked in Australia, New Zealand, Ireland and the uk. Every hospital has scavenging but I have not came across gas reclamation, although I've heard talk of this if xenon anaesthesia were to be used due to xenon's cost. Unless it was very cheap it would be hard to justify for other anaesthetic gases I think  Embed Quote

Not sure what you mean by "air pollution solutions," but if you mean policy solutions, then there are several prominent examples.[n.b. if you are talking about air pollution control technologies rather than policy, then this post isn't for you.  But those exist as well!]The most famous is the Montreal Protocol, which was created in 1987 and came into force in 1989, to mandate the elimination of CFCs, substances that degrade the ozone layer.  It is widely regarded to be among the most successful international environmental efforts in history.  Of course, it was largely successful because DuPont, the major manufacturer of CFCs, had already patented non-ozone-destroying alternatives and was prepared to deploy them aggressively, even as it agitated politically against the treaty. [see, e.g. 1, also 2]In the US, the Clean Air Act, originally passed in 1963 and continually revised, has been a spectacular success- it essentially gave the Public Health Service (later, the EPA) the authority to identify hazardous pollutants and regulate their emission from point sources.  The law was famously open-ended, allowing for science-based decision making and broad regulatory authority. Another success story has to do with sulfur dioxide emissions from power plants- the principal cause of acid rain.  President Bush (#1) oversaw the implementation of a cap-and-trade program  by which polluters had to purchase permits to pollute, and the number of permits gradually decreased with time.  Though the power industry argued the policy would be prohibitively expensive, in the end the costs were less than half of what was projected [3].  And how often do you hear about acid rain anymore?[1] http://www.ametsoc.org/atmospoli...[2] The Technological Egg and Regulatory Chicken[3] http://www.epa.gov/airmarkets/re...  Embed Quote

Leaf blowers give rise to airborne pollutants, noise pollution and eye hazards. They may contribute to respiratory and allergy problems and threaten the hearing period over time. Children are mostly susceptible among our population for these hazards.Leaf blowers contribute to smog and ozone pollution, a problem particularly in the warm months Among the substances blown into the air and respired are heavy metals, pesticides, and other carcinogenic substances.  In addition, the exhaust from the engine also contains benzene and other carcinogens.  Embed Quote

In summary:From the USA Environmental Protection Agency via Straightdope.com http://www.straightdope.com/colu...assuming a car averages 40 miles per hour, a push mower produces more HC+NOx than six cars and the same CO as tenFrom the University of Stockholm via Science Dailyhttp://www.sciencedaily.com/rele...In the Swedish testing, the researchers used regular unleaded fuel in a typical four-stroke, four horsepower lawn mower engine and found, after one hour, that the [polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons] emissions are similar to a modern gasoline-powered car driving approximately 150 kilometres (93 miles).The addition of a catalytic converter was found to significantly decrease the harmful emissions from the engine.  Embed Quote
Depends, some lawn mowers have very clean engines and some cars are filthy. You need to compare specific cars and specific mowers.  Embed Quote

column9: Question edit: But what about the possibility that air pollutant nanoparticles could cross the nasal epithelium? (see Can air pollutant nanoparticles cross the nasal endothelium and possibly enter the brain? )
column10: My answer is based on physiology, not a scientific trial. With that caveat: your nose has hair for a reason-- it acts to filter particulates. Ever go walking in a really dusty location? After you start blowing your nose, the mucous will be the color of the dust around you . Mouth Breathing let's the particles that could have been captured into your lungs which have cilia that also work to bring it up;hence the crap you cough up. Of course if you are talking really small particles, you are out of luck either way. But any air is better than no air ( i.e. when you have a stuffed nose!)  Embed QuoteThis answer is not a substitute for professional medical advic... (more)Loading...

column9: Does an official classification for microplastics exist?E.g., like the stuff floating in the Pacific/Atlantic gyres [1]/[2] & in the Great Lakes [3] Happy New Year![1 & 2] See Global Research - 5 Gyres - Understanding Plastic Pollution Through Exploration, Education, and Action [3] Microplastic Beads Pollute Great LakesMicroplastic pollution in the surface waters of the Laurentian Great LakesFYI: Another common culprit for microplastics: exfoliating beads in bodywash/soaps.fig. 1: Plethora of glitter in jars.
column10: It seems to me that glitter flakes are the very definition of micro plastic debris, and a particularly flagrant example of the problem of hapless and sloppy environmental degradation at the hands of the indolent West. Consider: used once, without regard to consequences or implications, for a frivolous and entirely self-involved purpose; literally impossible to dispose of properly after use; destined to disperse their entirely cosmetic dyes and adhesives into whatever ecosystem has the misfortune to receive them; small enough to be uptaken into virtually any animal's gullet. There's a special place in environmentalist hell for users off this kind of stuff.  Embed Quote

Some amount of cleanup would be "possible", but it certainly would not be efficient, nor ultimately effective. This is because:-The patch is very large (300,000-6,000,000 square miles), and there are actually 5 patches in the world's oceans (see 5gyres.org)-The debris is quite diffuse and is distributed throughout the water column down to great depthsand-The debris breaks down into smaller and smaller pieces. You would have to decide what mesh-sized net you wanted to use, but you would be inadvertently catching sea life of the same size range, something I assume one would want to avoid.The only solution is to reduce the amount of plastic pollution entering the oceans. As with many things, it is far superior to address the cause, rather than try to fix the damage. So much debris is entering the oceans as we speak that even if there were a method to clean up the patch, it would immediately be replenished.  Embed Quote

1The NOAA leads efforts to research, prevent, and reduce the vortex, but cleaning it isn't simple - especially because the vortex(es) are moving, and the pieces of plastic very small. I wrote a bit about it here: (Trash Vortexes, Garbage Patches, Or Floating Islands Of Waste? Why Marine Debris Is Bad News - Curiousmatic)Basically, attempts to clean could cost between 100 and 500 million a year - and using nets could kill more ocean wildlife. So it's definitely complicated, to say the least. You might be glad to hear, though, that there was an IndieGogo campaign to test the feasibility of an invention/concept that would remove vast amounts of plastics using floating booms. It was funded, and is currently in preliminary testing phases - aaand you can check that out here: The Ocean Cleanup - Boyan Slat  Embed Quote

column9: Or if not time-lapsed, perhaps a series of photographs, that show its magnitude and location on the map?
column10: The debris in the patch wouldn't be able to be captured in photograph, the items are too diffuse, the area too large, most of the pieces too small and below the surface to be photographed for this purpose. The contents and density of the patch are most commonly analyzed by water column trawls or by modeling. The size of the patch itself is difficult to estimate because the the debris just gets more diffuse as you go further out- it would be difficult to define an absolute border. That said, here are some studies describing those garbage patches. You'll find some images and graphs that are of the nature you are interested in.(List generated as a subset of a list from See Global Research | 5 Gyres - Understanding Plastic Pollution Through Exploration, Education, and Action)Tracking Ocean Debris		  Maximenko, 2008		 	    	  	  	  	   	  	   	  	   	  	  	  	  	   	   		 		  The Quantitative Distribution And Characteristics Of Neuston Plastic in the North Pacific Ocean		  Day, 1989		 	    	  	  	  	   	  	   	  	   	  	  	  	  	   	   		 		  Marine debris collects within the North Pacific Subtropical Convergence Zone		  Pichel, W.		 	    	  	  	  	   	  	   	  	   	  	  	  	  	   	   		 		  A Comparison of Plastic and Plankton in the North Pacific Central Gyre		  Carpenter, 1972  Embed QuoteVia  Anonymous.

column9: Or if not time-lapsed, perhaps a series of photographs, that show its magnitude and location on the map?
column10: You can't really see the Great Pacific Garbage Patch. Not in aerial photos, not in satellite photos.Regarding the availability of satellite imagery of the oceans: Unfortunately we haven’t found great sources of data for most of the open ocean because most imagery providers focus their efforts on the land. Where we do have satellite imagery for the ocean surface, we’ve preserved it in the most recent version of Google Earth and the satellite view in Maps. For example you can still see trawling vessels in southeast Asia. There are a number of potential applications for such imagery, from amateur interest in finding ships to looking at off-shore oil platforms to locating illegal fishing vessels, so it’s certainly worth exploring how we could track down data for the rest of the ocean.Regarding the gyre: the trash gyre presents its own set of challenges. Even if we had satellite imagery, the gyre likely wouldn’t appear in it. Most of the plastic is particulate and/or a bit under the surface so you can’t see it in the imagery. A number of groups are starting to focus on collecting more data about the gyre via expeditions and sampling – we’d love to see one or more of them produce maps that could be viewed in Google Earth.  --  Why You Can't See The Great Pacific Garbage Patch On Google Earth  Embed Quote

column9: Is the clean-up of Great Pacific Garbage Patch possible? What would it cost? Where will the accumulated trash go?
column10: It's hard.  The technological problems are all quite difficult, and the scale of the problem is very large.:The particles are very small -- smaller than sandThere are quite a lot of themThe oceans are very big.  Mind-bogglingly big.More plastic is being dumped every dayThe ocean is a very hostile environment; waves and storms can easily damage your cool platforms; salt water is corrosive to many construction materialsI keep thinking of new difficulties: Shipping!  One freighter through your fancy set-up and you've just lost a few million dollars.The clean-up technology, whatever it is, needs to run by itself with minimal supervision, day in and day out, for years.  Here  is an example of some experimental technology, but at least people are  working on the problem.  It pumps water into a sifter, which separates  out the plastic particles.  The long booms collect plastic-laden water and gently urge it into  into  the device.  19-Year-Old Develops Ocean Cleanup Array That Could Remove 7,250,000 Tons Of Plastic From the World’s Oceans  Embed Quote

column9: Is the clean-up of Great Pacific Garbage Patch possible? What would it cost? Where will the accumulated trash go?
column10: As Brian said, the scale of this challenge is as huge and overwhelming as the ocean itself-- because of the nature of the plastic (teeny, tiny particulates). But yes, there is reason for optimism and there's a few projects in development. The really fascinating one, which I learned of from watching his TedX Talk, is being spearheaded by Boyan Slat, a teenage engineering student. Yes, a teen! You can watch him give his talk (I'll embed the video at the bottom) but the gist of it is for a mesh-free system that would not disturb the fish or plant life, and would be powered by the sun and wave currents (not creating any emissions). And it could remove 7 million tons of plastic--which is certainly not all of it but is incredibly ambitious.These booms act as giant 'funnels', where an angle of the booms create a component of the surface current force in the direction of the platforms.The debris then enters the platforms, where it will be filtered out of the water, and eventually stored in containers until collected for recycling on land. Those "processing plants" in the pictures are computer models, of course. But there are 50 engineers working on Boyan's project! And it's possible it could be a feasible solution in the future. You can visit his site (The Ocean Cleanup - Boyan Slat) or watch his amazing talk at the bottom.  Embed Quote

column9: Is the clean-up of Great Pacific Garbage Patch possible? What would it cost? Where will the accumulated trash go?
column10: No. As Steve Demmer correctly states, most of the plastic is particulate matter. There are beaches in Hawaii now where 7 of 10 particulates are plastic, not sand.I don't agree with Steve, alas, that a coagulant would be a good idea: Gulf of Mexico clean-up makes 2010 spill 52-times more toxic; Mixing oil with dispersant increased toxicity to ecosystems (EDIT: please see the comments, where Steve Demmer correctly distinguishes between coagulants and dispersants.)A better idea would be to get the Precautionary principle in place on Earth in a big way. (I'm not waiting by the mailbox for this news.)  Embed Quote

column9: Is the clean-up of Great Pacific Garbage Patch possible? What would it cost? Where will the accumulated trash go?
column10: The Great Pacific Garbage Patch would not easily be cleaned up because its mostly made of suspended plastic particles, not solid and visible particles. The easiest way to clean the "garbage" or suspended particles would be to determine the charge of the particles. They're suspended in water now because they are all of the same charge (either positive or negative) thus they repel each other and don't want to settle to the ocean floor. The plastic's density, which is less than water, is also why it's floating on the top of the water and not sinking to the bottom. Once the charge of the suspended plastics are determined, the easiest and most cost effective way to remove the particles would be to add a coagulant, or a chemical to neutralize the charge of the suspended particles. Once the charge of the plastic is neutralized, it would more than likely settle to the ocean floor in clumps, where it would be more easily removed from the water.  Embed Quote

column9: Is the clean-up of Great Pacific Garbage Patch possible? What would it cost? Where will the accumulated trash go?
column10: I recall hearing of plastic eating bacteria and here are some links going back to 2011:Plastic-eating bacteria found in 'ocean desert,' scientist says The article from Nature is more balanced/cautious and says that we don't know yet for sure: Marine microbes digest plastic More recently, in 2013, two teenage girls from Vancouver, Canada presented their findings at the TED conference, and extracting a portion from the news story from the Vancouver Sun  (link to the full story below):  Wang and Yao's research focused on phthalates,  a fossil fuel-based additive  and known carcinogen found in some plastics. The plasticizer is used in a large  range of products to which people have a high exposure, such as foot wraps,  beverage containers and food wraps. "Phthalates are horrible because they are so easily taken into our bodies.  They can be absorbed by skin contact, ingested and absorbed," Wang told the  audience.The two girls identified bacteria from two sites along the Fraser River with  varying concentrations of phthalates: the Richmond landfill and the Reifel bird  sanctuary.With assistance from University of B.C. professor Lindsay Eltis, they  isolated 14 different strains of bacteria, and then cultured several to feed on  a phthalate-enriched diet. They were stunned to find they could convince the  bacteria to target the chemical to the exclusion of other food sources."This led us to conclude that our bacteria doesn't only grow in a macroscopic  culture that has phthalates as a sole carbon source, but is genetically capable  of breaking down phthalates. It actually has a genetic pathway to create enzymes  that can degrade phthalates," Wang said. Vancouver students take their plastic-eating bacteria ideas to the stage at TED Finally, back on the land , there have been some discoveries as well : Amazonian Rainforest Fungus Eats Polyurethane, Potentially Solving a Big Landfill Problem All said and done, this is not necessarily great news if the organisms eating bad stuff are themselves eaten by a bigger creature - especially before the bad stuff is broken down.  We will also need to be very very careful if we decide to artificially make an organism that will consume the plastics.  Embed Quote

Yes! They could take swipes at the edges, against the gyre. But, imo, your concern about killing too many fish is a bit sentimental because the fish that live there have bellies full of plastic debris and other contaminants so, in order to clean up the gyre you would need to scoop them up too. Perhaps more concerning are the sea turtles and certain species of migratory avians and mammals; they are endangered.  Embed Quote

Nope.Despite its size and density, the patch is not visible from satellite photography, since it consists primarily of suspended particulates in the upper water column. Since plastics break down to even smaller polymers, concentrations of submerged particles are not visible from space, nor do they appear as a continuous debris field. Instead, the patch is defined as an area in which the mass of plastic debris in the upper water column is significantly higher than average.[1]Here's  a bit more:Microplastics that make up the majority of garbage patches can’t always be seen by the naked eye. Satellite imagery of oceans doesn’t show a giant patch of garbage.The existence of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch was predicted by many oceanographers and climatologists. However, the actual discovery of the patch was made by a racing boat captain, Charles Moore. Moore was sailing from Hawaii to California after competing in a yachting race. Crossing the North Pacific Subtropical Gyre, Moore and his crew noticed millions of pieces of plastic surrounding his ship.Any kind of trash can get into the ocean—from glass bottles to aluminum cans to medical waste. The vast majority of marine debris, however, is plastic. Scientists have collected up to 750,000 bits of plastic in a single square kilometer (or 1.9 million bits per square mile) of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch. [2]Can you see the “garbage patches” with satellite photos?NO. Relative to the expanse of the North Pacific Ocean, sightings of large concentrations of debris, especially of large debris items are not very common. A majority of the debris observed in the “garbage patch” is small plastic pieces. Small debris pieces are difficult to see due to their size, and many of these pieces may be suspended below the surface of the water, which would make them even harder to see, even with the human eye. For these reasons, the debris, or “patch” of debris is not visible with existing satellite technology. [3][1] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gre...[2] http://education.nationalgeograp...[3] http://marinedebris.noaa.gov/inf...  Embed Quote

No. There is surely a lot of garbage out there, but its not an actual floating island. Its just a highly polluted area. Vice.com has done a great piece on this subject. http://www.vice.com/toxic/toxic-...  Embed Quote

column9: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gr...
column10: 1. What is the Pacific Garbage Patch?The  pacific garbage patch is as real a problem as global warming. The patch  cannot be seen from space because the plastic particles are small and this size of Texas thing is speculation. The problem however is very real. The particles are small because of the way plastic behaves when in  water. It depends on the conditions existing near the surface such as  turbidity, salinity, wind speed, and dissolved solids present.(This is to show that there is no patch, and the plastic is distributed along the ocean current routes. See Juan Videla's answer for the real picture, I did not want to add it as he had covered it already) People  believe the ocean to be a single large body, but think of the water as  having layers similar to how the atmosphere has different layers.http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wat...Now  the plastics float near the surface, with no decomposition or sink to  the bottom depending on what type of plastic it is made from. Due to  factors such as ocean currents and winds, these plastics become smaller  and finer particles, becoming a part of the ocean drift: http://5gyres.org/what_is_the_pr...This ultimately causes the garbage to accumulate instead of being distributed. Consider the case of the rubber duckies:http://suite101.com/article/rubb...If  28,800 duckies that float take 25 years to wash up on shores taking 3-4  round trips in the pacific, think of the amount of plastic that gets  dumped. Garbage does not float as much as the duckies mentioned above  and they break into smaller particles, implying that they may never wash  up at all. 2. What is the extent of plastic in the sea?Estimates of how much plastic ends up in the ocean is highly  varied as country/region wise data is hard to find. According to Green  Peace, it is about 10%. According to 5gyres.com , it could be as high as 30%. But given that in certain countries  recycle up to 12 - 30% of their plastic, the remaining 70% remains  unaccounted for:http://earth911.com/recycling/pl...http://www.epa.gov/osw/conserve/...Reality  is no reliable data exists which can validate or negate this data. 4. What can be done about it?Existing damage cleanup:This  plastic can neither be cleaned up nor decomposed in the foreseeable  future. Many projects exist, including the usage of solar powered micro-bots to gather the plastic from the surface of the sea. However the economic viability of the projects and poor funding have prevented any of them from lifting off.Cleanup on the surface:Cleanup under the surface:As I said earlier, these are proven projects with no further funding to start execution because maritime laws are such that the seas don't belong to any one country. After you cross the territorial waters, the open seas are everyones to pollute but noones responsibility to clean. This issue is not the same as airpollution which is being negotiated globally. As such no frame work or mechanism to pool in a global effort exists.Prevention:The only way go go about it is for now is prevention of plastic entering the water stream. It is not the production and use of plastics that is the problem here, but the recycling ratio and unaccounted/lost to water streams plastic that is the problem. There are several key points here:How bio-degrable is it? - anywhere from 2-15 years to break upWhat is the type of plastic used? polystyrene/polyvinyl chloride etc decide the lifecycle tooHow do you prevent it from entering the water stream?There are thousands of ways in which plastic can end up in the water, but there is a very simple solution to the whole problem - reduce, reuse and recycle. Though Captain Planet might repeat that many times, the recycle ratio is a measly 20%. As long as that does not improve, there is no clear solution to this, the ocean is changing. I will not say dying - it is changing the ecology of the ocean. Old ones which are not able to adapt to the plastic are dying, new ones which thrive on the floating garbage are thriving. Ultimately, humans are harmed either way - the interactions are complex and even after years of research, the results are still uncertain.So reuse, reduce and recycle. The basic steps are sometimes the most important ones.  Embed Quote

column9: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gr...
column10: 1. Attack the problem at the source. Limit the use of non-biodegradable plastics to where they are the only practical option. Price some of the environmental externalities into the products that do use them.2. Stronger regulations on disposal and dumping. In the developed world, corporations and governments shouldn’t be able to get away with improper dumping of these materials by using loopholes involving offshore entities.3. Educate the public. Work to reduce demand for the offending products and further encourage proper disposal.4. Make modern disposal and dumping regulations a requirement for developing countries to join trade agreements. These must actually be enforced.As for actually reversing the damage that has already been done. I honestly have no idea. There doesn't seem to be any remotely viable fix available now or in the near future.  Embed QuoteAnswered in thirty-two minutes.

column9: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gr...
column10: I can only add to the excellent answers already here, but I think the point cannot be made enough that the "garbage patch" is not the problem- it's the symptom.  The problem is wastage of resources, an insistence on using long-durable materials for single-use applications, and a general negligence among people both wealthy and poor to clean up after themselves.  One way that manifests is by the accumulation of garbage in the oceans.Putting a value on trash would be a huge stride (see, for example, bottle deposit programs).  Whether the consumer pays or the producer pays, either way it would be a good thing because it would provide market incentives to create fewer disposable products, as well as to collect and properly dispose of waste.  Embed Quote

column9: Estimates of size range from 700,000 square kilometres (270,000 sq mi) to more than 15,000,000 square kilometres (5,800,000 sq mi) (0.41% to 8.1% of the size of the Pacific Ocean).
column10: It's not always a direct kg/kg conversion, because in order to produce some plastics the oil molecules must have extra atoms included. For example PVC is polyvinyl chloride, which by mass is over half chlorine. But polypropylene or polyethylene are more common and are pretty close to mass parity from hydrocarbons."Of the more than 200 billion pounds of plastic the world produces each year, about 10 percent ends up in the ocean [source:Greenpeace]. Seventy percent of that eventually sinks, damaging life on the ocean floor [source:Greenpeace]. The rest floats; much of it ends up in gyres and the massive garbage patches that form there, with some plastic eventually washing up on a distant shore."http://science.howstuffworks.com... So if we believe Greenpeace (not usually a good idea) that's 3 million short tons of floating plastic added to the world's oceans every year, or about 20 million barrels of oil. Some or most of this would end up floating back onto beaches. No way to know what percent ends up in the Garbage Patch.  Embed QuoteVia  Anonymous.

column9: Estimates of size range from 700,000 square kilometres (270,000 sq mi) to more than 15,000,000 square kilometres (5,800,000 sq mi) (0.41% to 8.1% of the size of the Pacific Ocean).
